Content: CHICAGO — A drug now used to prevent recurrences of breast cancer can also reduce the risk of it occurring in the first place, providing a new option for women at high risk of getting the disease, researchers reported here on Saturday.
Title: Drug Can Reduce Risk of Breast Cancer, Study Says

Content: Dan Woska was weighing his treatment options after he was found to have prostate cancer two years ago when a friend mentioned a new genomic test that could gauge how lethal his tumor was.
Title: New Diagnostic Tools for Prostate Cancer

Content: A new radiation therapy can extend the lives of men with the most advanced form of prostate cancer, a large new study has found.
Title: New Radiation Therapy Prolongs Prostate Cancer Survival

Content: In my recent Raw Data column about whether fruits and vegetables are crucial to avoiding cancer, I referred to two thick reports, published in 1997 and 2007 by the American Institute for Cancer Research and its affiliate, the World Cancer Research Fund. Sitting side by side on my desk, the books look similar: One cover is blue and the other green, and both are adorned with images of fruits, vegetables, legumes and grains interspersed with people working and playing, all apparently enjoying good health. Presiding over the scene is an image of Mother Earth.
Title: From an Apple a Day to ‘Energy Balance’ in Cancer Research

Content: A new generation of DNA tests for colon cancer seems likely to improve the detection both of cancers and of the precancerous polyps that precede them. The tests, if validated, could reduce the burden of disease substantially by detecting tumors at an early stage, including those not picked up by a colonoscopy.
Title: DNA Test May Speed Colon Cancer Diagnosis

Content: THE FACTS
Title: Really? Drinking Coffee Lowers Colon Cancer Risk

Content: Rashidam Shakirova moved from Atlanta to New York in 2008 so she could earn more as a home health-care aide  $9 an hour instead of $7. But she now believes that her new job indirectly took a drastic toll on her health.
Title: Battling for Health Coverage as Cancer Spreads

Content: The majority of people diagnosed with cancer are over 65, but most major cancer studies exclude them, leaving a wide gap in knowledge about how best to treat older patients.
Title: Older Cancer Patients Often Excluded From Research

Content: After I finished eight months of treatment for testicular cancer in my mid-20s, my psychologist said, “Well, that was like having five years of therapy all at once.” What he meant was that you learn a lot about yourself in weekly talk sessions, but during a life-threatening illness, the “issues” come at you nonstop. I relished the slow unfolding of myself in the first, but I resented — no, hated — every step of the second. Nearly two decades later, when confronted with the same diagnosis, I finally understood the benefits of that earlier trial by fire, much as I did the wisdom of Ralph Waldo Emerson when he wrote, “The years teach much which the days never knew.”
Title: Taking On Cancer Again, This Time With the Wisdom of Age

Content: Four years ago, my sister found out she had two types of cancer at the same time. It was like being hit by lightning — twice.
Title: For cancer patients, empathy goes a long way

Content: Cancer treatments can compromise fertility, but new research suggests that when survivors of childhood cancer are able to have children, their babies do not face an increased risk of birth defects.
Title: Babies Born to Childhood Cancer Survivors Do Well

Content: SEOUL, South Korea  The North Korean leader Kim Jong-il, who suffered a stroke last August, was also found to have “life-threatening” pancreatic cancer around the same time, a South Korean cable television network reported on Monday.
Title: N. Korea’s Leader May Have Cancer, Report Says

Content: Two new studies revealed bad news about minimally invasive surgery for cervical cancer, a widely used procedure performed through small slits in the abdomen instead of a big incision.
Title: Studies Warn Against Minimally Invasive Surgery for Cervical Cancer

Content: Ligand Pharmaceuticals said yesterday that two studies had found that its drug Targretin failed to prolong life when used with chemotherapy against the most common form of lung cancer. The company's stock fell 29 percent. The company is seeking expanded approval of Targretin to treat non-small-cell lung cancer. The drug is already sold to treat a form of skin cancer. An initial review of the trials showed no increase in overall survival or survival after two years compared with patients treated using chemotherapy alone, the company said. The results were a setback in Ligand's bid to expand Targretin sales as growth slows for its biggest product, the Avinza pain treatment. Stock in the company, which is based in San Diego, fell $2.35, to $5.88 a share.
Title: LIGAND SAYS RESULTS OF CANCER DRUG TRIALS DISAPPOINT

Content: BEIJING — As a child, the road cyclist Amber Neben was admitted to a California hospital with meningitis. Doctors instructed her parents to prepare for the worst, and told them the odds were against survival.
Title: Amber Neben, cyclist who beat cancer

Content: For the next four weeks we will be awash in a sea of pink as women’s groups promote October as breast cancer awareness month. But while awareness is high, many women still have some key facts about breast cancer all wrong.
Title: Despite Awareness Campaigns, Breast Cancer Myths Linger

Content: Almost half of patients who undergo fecal blood tests to screen for colon and rectal cancer fail to follow up with a repeat test within two years as recommended, a new study reports.
Title: Screening: Many Skip Follow-Up Tests for Colon Cancer

Content: I’m driving my mother to her second week of radiation on a glorious spring day. Pale green leaf-lace froths on the trees, a verdant scribble working its way up the foothills of Mt. Greylock. Spring is an irrepressible fact in New England, not a cliché. And the weather is our favorite subject now that Mom has moderate Alzheimer’s.
Title: Dementia’s Gift: Facing Cancer Without the Fear

Content: When the essayist and novelist Jenny Diski, who died last week at 68, learned she had inoperable lung cancer, her first impulse was to make a “Breaking Bad” joke. She turned to her husband and said, in front of her doctor, “We’d better get cooking the meth.”
Title: Review: Jenny Diski’s ‘In Gratitude,’ an Uphill Life on and Off Cancer Road

Content: PARIS — Dr. David Servan-Schreiber, a psychiatrist and best-selling author whose cancer diagnosis at the age of 31 compelled him to explore and then popularize the use of natural and holistic methods in dealing with cancer and depression, died on July 24 in a hospital near Fécamp, France. He was 50.
Title: David Servan-Schreiber, Exponent of Cancer Treatments, Dies at 50

Content: With the arrival of two revolutionary treatment strategies, immunotherapy and personalized medicine, cancer researchers have found new hope — and a problem that is perhaps unprecedented in medical research.
Title: A Cancer Conundrum: Too Many Drug Trials, Too Few Patients

Content: Dr. Judah Folkman, a pathbreaking cancer researcher who faced years of skepticism before his ideas led to successful treatments, died Monday in Denver. He was 74.
Title: Dr. Judah Folkman, 74, cancer researcher

Content: Though more than one-third of patients 85 or older in veterans hospitals receive tests for prostate-specific antigen, or P.S.A., the cancer marker, researchers report, no professional associations or advocacy groups recommend the test for that age group. And there is no evidence that such patients benefit from treatment of prostate cancer if it is found by the test.
Title: Testing: V.A. Hospitals May Screen Needlessly for Cancer

Content: Nicholas Wade of The New York Times reports on two new DNA-related tests in an article recently posted on our Web site. The tests, he notes, “one of them described at a meeting in Philadelphia on Thursday, hold the promise of detecting early — and sharply reducing — colon cancer, a disease that afflicts 150,000 people a year in the United States and costs an estimated $14 billion to treat.”
Title: New DNA Tests Aim at Reducing Cancer

Content: The incidence of advanced breast cancer among younger women, ages 25 to 39, may have increased slightly over the last three decades, according to a study released Tuesday.
Title: Study Sees More Breast Cancer at Young Age

Content: Katherine Russell Rich, whose gritty, darkly comic memoir of her protracted battle with breast cancer became a beacon for other patients, died of the disease on Tuesday. She was 56, and against all predictions had lived with cancer for nearly a quarter-century.
Title: Katherine Russell Rich, Who Wrote of Battle With Cancer, Dies at 56

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved Celgene’s drug Abraxane for use in treating advanced pancreatic cancer, supplementing the thin arsenal available to fight the disease.
Title: F.D.A. Approves a Drug for Late-Stage Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Watching Robin Roberts tear up in front of millions of viewers on “Good Morning America” last month, I cried, too.
Title: New Cancer Threat Lurks Long After Cure

Content: NEW YORK — A drug already in widespread use to prevent bone thinning in women past menopause can also reduce their risk of invasive breast cancer, researchers reported.
Title: Osteoporosis drug shown to decrease chances of breast cancer

Content: Reitza Rosado Salgado was four months shy of graduating from high school when, in January 2008, she felt a pain in her side. Her mother, Maritza Salgado, took her to a hospital in Sabana Grande, Puerto Rico, where they live. When the pain did not subside, they went to a hospital in San Juan. Doctors performed a series of tests.
Title: Managing an Extended Struggle Against Cancer

Content: Medicare confirmed on Thursday that it would continue to pay for two expensive cancer drugs that had been at the center of debate — Avastin from Genentech for breast cancer and Provenge from Dendreon for prostate cancer.
Title: Medicare Will Continue to Cover 2 Expensive Cancer Drugs

Content: The waters of Flushing Bay, within view of La Guardia Airport, are some of the more polluted around New York City. The bay has poor circulation, and during heavy rainfalls sewers spew raw waste into the water from nearby homes and businesses.
Title: Cancer Survivors Apply Tenacious Spirit to Bay Cleanup

Content: In the usual cancer biopsy, a surgeon cuts out a piece of the patient’s tumor, but researchers in labs across the country are now testing a potentially transformative innovation. They call it the liquid biopsy, and it is a blood test that has only recently become feasible with the latest exquisitely sensitive techniques. It is showing promise in finding tiny snippets of cancer DNA in a patient’s blood.
Title: New Blood Test Shows Promise in Cancer Fight

Content: A large study has found that drinking coffee is associated with a reduced risk of death from oral cancer.
Title: Risks: Coffee Linked to Fewer Oral Cancer Deaths

Content: ALBANY  Each year, there are 200,000 new cases of cancer in New York State, and each one is reported to the State Health Department and meticulously recorded.
Title: Lawmakers Approve Detailed Map of State’s Cancer Cases

Content: About half of all Bernese mountain dogs are prone to an unusual blood cancer called malignant histiocytosis. Boxers are four times more likely to get lymphomas than dogs in general, while Pomeranians are 10 times less likely. Cocker spaniels are more likely to get B cell lymphomas, and huskies are more susceptible to T cell lymphomas.
Title: Dogs May Help Find Genes That Cause Cancer

Content: Women with metastatic breast cancer are living longer.
Title: Women With Aggressive Breast Cancer Are Living Longer

Content: Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of the presidential candidate John Edwards, elaborated on her cancer diagnosis in an interview broadcast last night, saying that the disease had spread to one of her hips.
Title: Edwards’s Cancer Has Spread Into One of Her Hips

Content: WASHINGTON — Government scientists are expected today to declare styrene a likely human carcinogen, a move that manufacturers have long feared. Styrene is used to make those ubiquitous white foam coffee cups and food containers and is widely used in building materials.
Title: U.S. Weighs Cancer Risk of Styrene and Formaldehyde

Content: Lori Siegel did not even wait for her hair to grow back. Still feeling the effects of radiation treatments, she sent her résumé to potential employers, bought a new suit and a wig that does not look like a wig, and started going on job interviews.
Title: Cancer Survivors Struggle to Find Jobs, Study Finds

Content: Lori Siegel did not even wait for her hair to grow back. Still feeling the effects of radiation treatments, she sent her résumé to potential employers, bought a new suit and a wig that does not look like a wig, and started going on job interviews.
Title: Cancer Survivors Struggle to Find Jobs, Study Finds

Content: WASHINGTON — A top official of the American Cancer Society has resigned in part because of concern over some of the organization’s fund-raising partnerships.
Title: Cancer Society Executive Resigns Amid Upset Over Corporate Partnerships

Content: The Broadway star Marin Mazzie brings the same exuberance to living with late-stage ovarian cancer that she displays in her performances. Or perhaps the roles she has undertaken in musicals like “Ragtime,” “Kiss Me Kate” and “The King and I” have contributed to her proactive efforts to improve the fate of other women who will have to cope with the disease.
Title: How the Broadway Star Marin Mazzie Confronts Cancer

Content: A second opinion from a team of specialists after an initial diagnosis of breast cancer resulted in a significant change in the recommended surgical treatment in more than half of cases, a new study has found.
Title: Second Opinion May Aid Breast Cancer Treatment

Content: Kenneth P. Thompson, the first black district attorney of Brooklyn and a voice for racial justice at a moment of tension between law enforcement and minority communities, died on Sunday from cancer, his family said. He was 50.
Title: Ken Thompson, Brooklyn District Attorney, Dies After Disclosing Cancer

Content: When Juliet Jacobs found out she had lung cancer, she was terrified, but realized that her hope lay in getting the best treatment medicine could offer. So she got a second opinion, then a third. In February of 2010, she ended up at Duke University, where she entered a research study whose promise seemed stunning.
Title: How Bright Promise in Cancer Testing Fell Apart

Content: When women with low incomes or low levels of education start chemotherapy for breast cancer, they routinely get insufficient doses, a new study suggests. That may be one reason they are less likely to survive the disease than other women.
Title: All Breast Cancer Patients Are Not Treated the Same

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Sorting Out Pills to Reduce Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Data from the National Center for Health Statistics show that death rates over the past 60 years  the number of deaths adjusted for the age and size of the population  plummeted for heart disease, stroke, and influenza and pneumonia. But for cancer, they barely budged.
Title: As Other Death Rates Fall, Cancer’s Scarcely Moves

Content: A second opinion from a team of specialists after an initial diagnosis of breast cancer resulted in a significant change in the recommended surgical treatment in more than half of cases, a new study has found.
Title: Second Opinion May Aid Breast Cancer Treatment

Content: The Venezuelan president, Hugo Chávez, appeared on national television on Monday for the first time with a shaved head, a stark visual reminder of the treatment he is currently receiving for an unspecified cancer.
Title: Chávez, Battling Cancer, Appears With Shaved Head

Content: Pittsburgh wide receiver Hines Ward arrived for this month’s Steelers minicamp with two books tucked in his duffel bag: the team’s playbook and a copy of “The Last Lecture,” co-written by Randy Pausch, who left his job as a computer science professor at Carnegie Mellon University last September.
Title: Dying of Cancer, but Full of Life Lessons

Content: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Sushil Koirala of Nepal is undergoing radiation therapy in New York to treat a cancerous tumor found on his lung, and his indefinite absence could further paralyze Nepalese politics.
Title: Nepal’s Premier Is Being Treated for Lung Cancer

Content: Lung cancer screening with CT scans does not appear to save lives and exposes people to serious risks of injury and even death from needless surgery, researchers were to report Wednesday.
Title: Study points to dangers of CT scans for lung cancer

Content: Amgen is halting a late-stage clinical trial of an experimental drug for pancreatic cancer after an outside monitoring panel concluded that the drug was unlikely to improve the survival of patients with an advanced form of the disease.
Title: Amgen, Citing Weak Results, Halts Study of a Cancer Drug

Content: ALBANY — New York unveiled what it billed as the nation’s first comprehensive statewide cancer map, which became available Monday on the Web site of the State Department of Health.
Title: Map Tracks Incidences of Cancer Throughout New York State

Content: Annie Toglia, who developed a physical rehabilitation program for women with breast cancer, died in Mount Kisco, N.Y. on Wednesday. She was 56.
Title: Annie Toglia, 56, Who Aided Breast Cancer Survivors, Is Dead

Content: Women with an aggressive type of breast cancer lived longer if they received immunotherapy plus chemotherapy, rather than chemo alone, a major study has found.
Title: Immune-Based Treatment Helps Fight Aggressive Breast Cancer, Study Finds

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Marriage, Nuts and a Cancer Breakthrough

Content: The attendant walked into the hospital waiting room and called my name. I took a deep breath and hurried through the door. “I’m always surprised when my name is pronounced properly at a doctor’s office,” I said.
Title: Cancer Survivors Celebrate Their Cancerversary

Content: Some 470,000 cases of cervical cancer are diagnosed worldwide each year, and about half as many people die from the disease. Here are five things every woman — and the parents of every pre-teen and teenage girl — should know about preventing, detecting and treating cervical cancer:
Title: Cervical Cancer: Preventable, Treatable but Still a Major Killer

Content: About half of all Bernese mountain dogs are prone to an unusual blood cancer called malignant histiocytosis. Boxers are four times more likely to get lymphomas than dogs in general, while Pomeranians are 10 times less likely. Cocker spaniels are more likely to get B cell lymphomas, and huskies are more susceptible to T cell lymphomas.
Title: Dogs May Help Find Genes That Cause Cancer

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Spanish Doctor Denies Castro Has Cancer

Content: An international panel of experts convened by the World Health Organization concluded Monday that eating processed meat like hot dogs, ham and bacon raises the risk of colon cancer and that consuming other red meats “probably” raises the risk as well. But the increase in risk is so slight that experts said most people should not be overly worried about it.
Title: Meat Is Linked to Higher Cancer Risk, W.H.O. Report Finds

Content: “You are being deported,” a surgeon announced to me last fall. That’s a scary thing for a child of two immigrants to hear. But he was referring to the removal of my port, a medical device implanted just beneath my right collarbone — a gateway for the dozens of rounds of chemotherapy, antibiotics and blood transfusions that have entered my body since I received a leukemia diagnosis at age 22.
Title: Lost in Transition After Cancer

Content: Diesel fumes cause lung cancer, the World Health Organization declared Tuesday, and experts said they were more carcinogenic than secondhand cigarette smoke.
Title: W.H.O. Declares Diesel Fumes Cause Lung Cancer

Content: CLEVELAND, July 23 — A welcome sense of normalcy returned to the young life of Jon Lester on Monday night. Instead of thinking about anaplastic large cell lymphoma or chemotherapy treatments, he was able to focus on retiring major league batters. His ability to get outs, apparently, has not been diminished by his battle with cancer.
Title: Victorious Night for Lester in His Return From Cancer

Content: The death rate from cervical cancer in the United States is considerably higher than previously estimated and the disparity in death rates between black women and white women is significantly wider, according to a study published Monday in the journal Cancer.
Title: Wider Racial Gap Found in Cervical Cancer Deaths

Content: Despite optimistic claims by American officials that the tide is finally turning against cancer, a growing number of patient advocates and researchers say they are discouraged by continuing slow progress in the 36-year-war against the disease in the United States.
Title: Slow pace of advances against cancer frustrate researchers

Content: WASHINGTON — The government issued warnings on Friday about two materials used daily by millions of Americans, saying that one causes cancer and the other might.
Title: Government Says 2 Common Materials Pose Risk of Cancer

Content: Dr. Alfred G. Knudson, who deduced how certain cancers strike a family generation after generation, died on Sunday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 93.
Title: Dr. Alfred G. Knudson, the ‘Mendel of Cancer Genetics,’ Dies at 93

Content: Vaccines against the human papillomavirus have sharply reduced infections, genital and anal warts, and precancerous lesions in young women and girls in more than a dozen wealthy countries, a major new study has found — powerful evidence that these vaccines will ultimately cause major drops in cervical cancer.
Title: HPV Vaccines Are Reducing Infections, Warts — and Probably Cancer

Content: A campaign to change attitudes about people with a familiar form of cancer is proving to be provocative enough that some posters are being torn down — and those behind the campaign could not be more pleased.
Title: Cancer Campaign Tries Using Shock to Change Attitudes

Content: Lung cancer screening with CT scans does not appear to save lives and exposes people to serious risks of injury and even death from needless surgery, researchers were to report Wednesday.
Title: Study points to dangers of CT scans for lung cancer

Content: The young woman in the American Cancer Society advertisement holds up a photograph of a smiling blonde. "My sister accidentally killed herself. She died of skin cancer," reads the headline.
Title: Doctors balk at cancer ad, citing lack of evidence

Content: The Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday that it would move to revoke approval of the widely used drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer because the drug was not effective in helping patients.
Title: F.D.A. Plans to Revoke Approval for Breast Cancer Drug

Content: Dr. Carolyn M. Kaelin, a breast cancer surgeon who continued her research and advocacy for patients after her own diagnosis of breast cancer ended her surgical career, died on July 28 at her home in Charlestown, Mass. She was 54.
Title: Carolyn Kaelin, Breast Cancer Surgeon, Patient Advocate and Patient, Dies at 54

Content: My grandfather received a diagnosis of brain cancer a week before I had to hand in my master’s thesis. The very first chapter discussed a scientific paper about his type of brain tumor. I found comfort in losing myself in the work: I sat by his hospital bed as he slept, and analyzed cancer data, typing out equations filled with Greek symbols that he had joked were some kind of sorcery.
Title: Seeking a Cancer-Free World

Content: The Food and Drug Administration has granted a hearing for Genentech to argue in favor of preserving the approval of its drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer.
Title: F.D.A. Grants Hearing on Avastin as Treatment for Breast Cancer

Content: Cancer experts have identified a set of health problems that may be symptoms of ovarian cancer, and they are urging women who have the symptoms for more than a few weeks to see their doctors.
Title: Common symptoms emerge as warning signs of ovarian cancer

Content: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 26 — A Spanish surgeon who examined Fidel Castro last week said Tuesday that the 80-year-old Cuban president did not have cancer and could return to work after recovering from the intestinal surgery he had last summer.
Title: Spanish Doctor Denies Castro Has Cancer

Content: On Tuesday, I got an e-mail from JAMA Oncology, a leading medical journal, saying that it planned to publish a paper and editorial on ductal carcinoma in situ, or D.C.I.S., a condition that has become increasingly controversial over the years. As many as 60,000 women are told each year that they have it: tiny clusters of abnormal breast cells, confined to a milk duct and too small to be felt. It’s often called stage 0 cancer, and it almost never was detected before the early 1980s when mammograms came into widespread use.
Title: Aggressive Treatment for Early Breast Cancer: Reporter’s Notebook

Content: A Chinese hospital treating the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Liu Xiaobo has invited cancer experts from the United States, Germany and other nations to join his team of doctors, judicial officials said in a brief statement Wednesday.
Title: Chinese Hospital Invites Cancer Experts to Help Treat Nobel Laureate

Content: NEWARK — Devils center Brian Boyle said he had plenty of things on his mind besides his battle with chronic myeloid leukemia when he stepped onto the ice Nov. 1 for his first shift of the season. More than anything, he wanted to help his new team win.
Title: After a Cancer Diagnosis, the Devils’ Brian Boyle Is Thriving

Content: A drug already in widespread use to prevent bone thinning in women past menopause can also reduce their risk of invasive breast cancer, researchers reported yesterday.
Title: Drug Found to Help Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Nice but noisy
Title: Waging the Cancer War, Surrounded by Signs of Life

Content: NEW YORK — In a blow to ImClone Systems and a triumph for a prominent Israeli research institution, a judge has ruled that three scientists from Israel are the true inventors of a process used in the delivery of the blockbuster cancer drug Erbitux.
Title: Israelis win ruling on patent for cancer drug

Content: Rates of the most common form of breast cancer dropped a startling 15 percent from August 2002 to December 2003, researchers reported yesterday.
Title: REVERSING TREND, BIG DROP IS SEEN IN BREAST CANCER

Content: PEORIA, Ariz.  Gleaming green fields spread before Darrel Akerfelds. He sits at a picnic bench under a canopy behind the spring training clubhouse of the San Diego Padres, where he has been the bullpen coach for a decade. He gazes at the reassuring sights  mounds and batting cages, grass and dirt  and it seems as if he might cry.
Title: Padres Coach Gains Energy From Baseball in Cancer Fight

Content: The Mediterranean diet — rich in vegetables, fruits, whole grains and olive oil, and low in dairy products and red meat — is linked to a reduced risk for breast cancer, according to a randomized trial.
Title: Mediterranean Diet Linked to Reduced Breast Cancer Risk

Content: In the documentary “Baring it All,” a young woman declares, “The scar represents everything I’ve been through. I’m proud of what I’ve been through.” The film focuses on the fashion photographer David Jay, who created a pictorial series about breast cancer called “The Scar Project.”
Title: Living With Cancer: The Scar Project

Content: Physical activity, even including walking, can substantially reduce a woman’s risk of developing breast cancer, encouraging new science shows, in part, it seems, by changing how her body deals with estrogen.
Title: How Walking May Lower Breast Cancer Risk
Running for your life: It helps, but research is mixed on cancer

Content: Update | 2:49 p.m.  Paul Calello, the chief executive of Credit Suisse‘s investment bank, is undergoing treatment for cancer. Eric Varvel, an executive based in London, would become the investment bank’s acting chief executive on an interim basis.
Title: Credit Suisse Investment Chief Treated for Cancer

Content: Update | 2:49 p.m. Paul Calello, the chief executive of Credit Suisse's investment bank, is undergoing treatment for cancer. Eric Varvel, an executive based in London, would become the investment bank's acting chief executive on an interim basis.
Title: Credit Suisse Investment Chief Treated for Cancer

Content: Updated:
Title: F.D.A. Panel Rejects Use of Avastin for Breast Cancer

Content: JERUSALEM, Oct. 29 — Israel’s prime minister, Ehud Olmert, announced today that he has early stage prostate cancer, but said the cancer is not life-threatening and would not distract him from his work.
Title: Olmert Says He Has Prostate Cancer

Content: FOUNTAIN HILLS, Arizona — Senator John McCain, a three-time melanoma survivor, appears cancer-free, has a strong heart and is in generally good health, according to eight years of medical records released by his campaign Friday.
Title: Records show McCain apparently free of cancer

Content: Pat Burns, the coach of the Devils since the 2002-3 season, has had a recurrence of cancer and will not coach the team if, or when, the National Hockey League resumes play, General Manager Lou Lamoriello said yesterday.
Title: Devils to Seek New Coach After Burns's Cancer Recurs

Content: JERUSALEM — Israel's prime minister, Ehud Olmert, announced Monday that he has early stage prostate cancer, but said the cancer is not life-threatening and would not distract him from his work.
Title: Olmert says he has prostate cancer

Content: It can be hard for physicians to follow current thinking of experts on medical care. It must be exponentially harder for the public to make sense of it. Recently, the United States Preventive Services Task Force changed its recommendation on prostate cancer screening from a D (that is, don’t do it) to a C (discuss it with your doctor).
Title: The ABCs and Ds of Whether to Get Prostate Cancer Screening

Content: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25  Amgen, the biotechnology company, said Thursday that its anemia drug Aranesp increased the risk of death when used to treat certain cancer patients, a finding that will probably raise more questions about it and similar drugs.
Title: Amgen Finds Anemia Drug Holds Risks in Cancer Use

Content: A drug widely used to treat H.I.V. infection may also be effective in fighting cancer, a new study suggests, and a human trial of the medicine is already under way.
Title: AIDS Drugs May Help Against Cancer, Too

Content: SAN FRANCISCO — Some leading pharmaceutical companies are joining forces in an effort to speed the testing of new types of cancer drugs that harness the body’s immune system to battle tumors.
Title: Drug Companies to Try a Unified Front Against Cancer

Content: For the first time in decades, doctors have begun making major changes in the treatment of lung cancer, based on research proving that chemotherapy can significantly lengthen life in many patients in whom it was previously thought to be useless.
Title: Chemotherapy Research Leads to Shifts in Lung Cancer Treatment

Content: WASHINGTON — In a major test case, Medicare is poised to cover a promising but expensive new type of cancer treatment, with significant restrictions meant to hold down the cost.
Title: Medicare Aims to Expand Coverage of Cancer Care. But Is It Enough?

Content: WASHINGTON  Doctors told Ann B. Maddox that she had thyroid cancer and that the cure was to swallow radioactive iodine, to kill the malignant cells. She traveled 500 miles from her home in Fayetteville, N.C., for treatment at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore.
Title: When a Cancer Therapy Puts Others at Risk

Content: I’ve trudged through Stage 3 prostate cancer and its treatment in good shape. Nearly two years after learning I had cancer, I’m an active 52-year-old, I exercise regularly, my blood tests are where they need to be and my oncologist wants to see me only twice a year.
Title: After Surviving Cancer, a Focus on True Manhood

Content: Help contribute to The New York Times Magazine’s special Health Issue.
Title: Share Your Story About the New Science of Cancer

Content: In his last years, Steven P. Jobs veered from exotic diets to cutting-edge treatments as he fought the cancer that ultimately took his life, according to a new biography to be published on Monday.
Title: Jobs Tried Exotic Treatments to Combat Cancer, Book Says

Content: Some recent studies have suggested that lycopene, a chemical in tomatoes and other red fruits, is protective against prostate cancer, but a large prospective study has found that it has no effect.
Title: Outcomes: Lycopene Does Not Fight Off Prostate Cancer, Study Shows

Content: Lung cancer screening with CT scans does not appear to save lives and exposes people to serious risks of injury and even death from needless surgery, researchers are reporting today.
Title: Researchers Dispute Benefits of CT Scans for Lung Cancer

Content: Excitement over a promise of a new type of cancer treatment ignited a frenzy on Wall Street Friday as a little-known year-old company pulled off one of the largest initial public stock offerings in the biotechnology sector.
Title: I.P.O. of Juno Therapeutics, Developer of a Cancer Treatment, Excites Investors
'Stunning' test shows hope for new cancer tactic

Content: Tightened security at airports has created new problems for medical patients, who may be subjected to embarrassing public pat-downs after imaging machines detect devices or implants related to their health.
Title: Airport Pat-Down for Breast Cancer Patient

Content: Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, who has been undergoing cancer treatments, joined a contingent of club executives at the New York Athletic Club on Thursday for Mike Piazza’s Hall of Fame news conference.
Title: Sandy Alderson, Recovering From Cancer, Defends Mets’ Moves

Content: Lung cancer screening with CT scans does not appear to save lives, and it exposes people to serious risks of injury and even death from needless surgery, researchers are reporting.
Title: Study Raises Doubts About Lung Cancer Screening

Content: The laboratory of Vera Gorbunova and Andrei Seluanov, a husband-and-wife team of biologists at the University of Rochester, has the feel of a petting zoo. They maintain colonies of several species of rodents — some familiar, like mice and guinea pigs, and some much more exotic, like blind mole rats from Israel and naked mole rats from East Africa.
Title: A Homely Rodent May Hold Cancer-Fighting Clues

Content: Two reports scheduled for publication in the United States on Wednesday call for greatly expanded use of Magnetic Resonance Imaging for women who have breast cancer or who are at high risk of developing the disease.
Title: Expanded use of MRI urged in breast cancer prevention

Content: People who were cured of cancer as children often suffered later in life from health problems caused by chemotherapy and radiation, a study of more than 10,000 survivors has found.
Title: Childhood Cancer Survivors Face Increased Risks Later

Content: BEIJING — Living in China these days, we’re bombarded with scary accounts of rising cancer rates that are partly linked to some of the world’s worst pollution.
Title: As Cancer Rates Rise in China, Trust Remains Low

Content: WASHINGTON  Federal agencies in charge of radiation protection are struggling to revise their standards to take into account the differences in susceptibility to radiation-induced cancer among men, women and children, and, according to a report released Wednesday, are lagging in that task.
Title: Report Faults U.S. Measure of Cancer Risk

Content: A low-fat diet may reduce a postmenopausal woman’s risk for ovarian cancer, but only if the diet lasts for many years, a new randomized trial has found.
Title: Regimens: Low-Fat Diet May Lower Risk of Ovarian Cancer

Content: CHICAGO — A new drug looks poised to become the first effective medication for liver cancer, one of the most common and deadliest cancers in the world, doctors here said.
Title: Drug may be first effective medication for liver cancer

Content: Julia Louis-Dreyfus has breast cancer, she announced on Thursday, less than two weeks after her record-setting Emmy win for “Veep.”
Title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Shares Breast Cancer Diagnosis

Content: “I am waiting for test and scan results, laying low after a busy and stressful week,” Lisa Bonchek Adams wrote on her blog in 2013, one of hundreds of posts to go along with thousands of Twitter messages documenting her life after she learned she had breast cancer in 2007, when she was 37.
Title: Lisa Bonchek Adams Dies at 45; Chronicled Fight With Breast Cancer

Content: People whose faces turn red when they drink alcohol may be facing more than embarrassment. The flushing may indicate an increased risk for a deadly throat cancer, researchers report.
Title: Drinkers’ Red Face May Signal Cancer Risk

Content: The government is beginning a project that aims to unlock all the genetic abnormalities that contribute to cancer, an effort that would exceed the Human Genome Project in complexity but could eventually lead to new diagnostic tests and treatments for the disease.
Title: New Effort Aims to Unlock Secrets of Cancer Genes

Content: NEW YORK — After his annual physical, a middle-age man is told that his PSA level has jumped to 2.3 after having been stable for years at 1.5. Should he be alarmed?
Title: Re-examining guidelines for key test for prostate cancer

Content: In an apparent nod to growing concern over the rapidly climbing costs of cancer drugs, Genentech announced yesterday that it would cap the total cost of its drug Avastin at $55,000 a year for patients below a certain income level.
Title: Genentech Caps Cost of Cancer Drug for Some Patients

Content: Women who have had ovarian stimulation to produce eggs for in vitro fertilization are at slightly increased risk for a type of ovarian cancer, a large study has found.
Title: Risks: I.V.F. Brings a Slightly Higher Cancer Risk

Content: The pink ribbon, that ubiquitous emblem of breast cancer awareness, has long been an object of controversy and derision, but the poet and essayist Anne Boyer doesn’t just pull it loose, unfastening its dainty loop; she feeds it through a shredder and lights it on fire, incinerating its remains.
Title: ‘The Undying,’ an Extraordinary and Furious New Memoir About Cancer

Content: Rates of the most common form of breast cancer dropped a stunning 15 percent from August 2002 to December 2003, researchers reported yesterday.
Title: Breast Cancer Rate Falls in U.S., Study Shows

Content: NEW YORK — Two important studies published Wednesday challenge conventional thoughts about treating and avoiding breast cancer.
Title: 2 breast cancer studies question old treatments

Content: Plexxikon, Inc. is a small biotechnology company in Berkeley. Its creation, PLX4032, a melanoma drug tailored to a gene mutation known as B-RAF, played a central role in Amy Harmon’s three-part series in The New York Times about “targeted therapy.”
Title: The Story of PLX4032: A Berkeley Company’s Cancer Therapy

Content: Hospitals that buy surgical robots end up performing more prostate cancer operations, suggesting that technology has become a driving force behind decisions about men’s cancer care, new research shows.
Title: Hospitals With Robots Do More Prostate Cancer Surgery

Content: David Carr, the New York Times media columnist who died unexpectedly Thursday night, had lung cancer, and died of complications from the disease, according to the results of an autopsy released Saturday evening.
Title: Autopsy Cites Cancer as Cause in Death of David Carr, Times Reporter

Content: A federal advisory committee voted yesterday that Genentech’s drug Avastin should not be approved as a treatment for breast cancer.
Title: Advisory Panel Rejects New Use for Cancer Drug

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first of an eagerly awaited new class of cancer drugs that unleashes the body’s immune system to fight tumors.
Title: F.D.A. Allows First Use of a Novel Cancer Drug

Content: Mitt Romney's wife, Ann, released a statement today that she was diagnosed last week with early stage breast cancer and had undergone a lumpectomy.  Mrs. Romney was a regular presence on the campaign trail last year with her husband and has spoken often about coping with multiple sclerosis, a disease she was diagnosed with about the time Mr. Romney took charge of the Salt Lake City Olympics.  Here is her statement:    Last week, following my annual mammogram at Brigham and Women's Hospital, I was diagnosed with Ductal Carcinoma In Sutu (DCIS). While this is commonly referred to as early stage breast cancer, it is technically not cancer but rather pre-cancer, as it has not become invasive. Today, I have had a lumpectomy. This procedure does not require hospitalization. Mitt and I feel fortunate to have caught this so early. And, it reminds us how important it is for women to have regular mammograms. As in all cases of cancer, early detection is critical. Many families are facing medical hardships--our hearts go out to all of you and also our wishes for healing holidays.
Title: Ann Romney Diagnosed With Early Stage Breast Cancer

Content: Mitt Romney's wife, Ann, released a statement today that she was diagnosed last week with early stage breast cancer and had undergone a lumpectomy.  Mrs. Romney was a regular presence on the campaign trail last year with her husband and has spoken often about coping with multiple sclerosis, a disease she was diagnosed with about the time Mr. Romney took charge of the Salt Lake City Olympics.  Here is her statement:    Last week, following my annual mammogram at Brigham and Women's Hospital, I was diagnosed with Ductal Carcinoma In Sutu (DCIS). While this is commonly referred to as early stage breast cancer, it is technically not cancer but rather pre-cancer, as it has not become invasive. Today, I have had a lumpectomy. This procedure does not require hospitalization. Mitt and I feel fortunate to have caught this so early. And, it reminds us how important it is for women to have regular mammograms. As in all cases of cancer, early detection is critical. Many families are facing medical hardships--our hearts go out to all of you and also our wishes for healing holidays.
Title: Ann Romney Diagnosed With Early Stage Breast Cancer

Content: Proactive approach to symptoms advised
Title: Common symptoms could be warning signs of ovarian cancer

Content: EVEN though screening tests can prevent colorectal cancer or find it early enough to cure, the disease is still the second-leading cause of cancer death in the United States, with nearly 165,000 new cases and more than 52,000 deaths expected this year.
Title: How to Halve the Death Rate From Colon Cancer

Content: In a small, preliminary study, an experimental vaccine provoked a strong immune response against precancerous cells in women treated for cervical lesions that can progress to cancer.
Title: Therapeutic Vaccine Shows Potential in Fighting Cervical Cancer

Content: Two drugs can delay by several months the time before advanced breast cancer worsens, potentially providing new options for women with that disease, researchers reported Wednesday.
Title: Two Drugs Appear to Delay Progression of Breast Cancer

Content: A drug used to treat advanced breast cancer has had what appears to be unprecedented success in prolonging lives in a clinical trial, researchers reported on Sunday.
Title: Roche Breast Cancer Drug Perjeta Appears to Greatly Extend Patients’ Lives

Content: The new vaccine designed to protect girls and young women from cervical cancer has a safety record that appears to be in line with that of other vaccines, a government report has found. Some serious complications occurred, including at least 20 deaths and two cases of Lou Gehrig’s disease, but they were not necessarily caused by the vaccine, the study said.
Title: Study Weighs Risks of Vaccine for Cervical Cancer

Content: Compared with women who have never given birth, those who recently had babies may have a slight increased risk of breast cancer that peaks after about five years and then gradually declines, according to a study published this week.
Title: Breast Cancer Risk May Rise After Childbirth, but Is Still Low

Content: Democratic presidential contender John Edwards and his wife Elizabeth announced today that Mrs. Edwards’s cancer had returned, this time in a rib on her right side.
Title: Edwards: ‘The Campaign Goes On’ Despite Wife’s Cancer Recurrence

Content: Among the many challenges women with breast cancer face, here’s one most people don’t pay attention to: a smaller paycheck.
Title: Wage Loss a Costly Side Effect of Breast Cancer

Content: CHICAGO — Shark fin soup might taste good, but it will not do much for cancer.
Title: Shark cartilage no help in cancer cases, study finds

Content: To see Barry Cooper working out at the YMCA in Brooklyn, New York, every morning before going to work as a patent lawyer, you would be unlikely to guess that he has cancer. Cooper, 63 and a grandfather of two, is one of a small but growing number of patients for whom once-fatal cancer has become a chronic disease.
Title: Once-fatal cancers now treated as a chronic disease

Content: Elwood V. Jensen, a medical researcher whose studies of steroid hormones led to new treatments for breast cancer that have been credited with saving or extending hundreds of thousands of lives, died on Dec. 16 in Cincinnati. He was 92.
Title: Elwood V. Jensen, Pioneer in Breast Cancer Treatment, Dies at 92

Content: Racing to embrace a new vaccine, at least 20 states are considering mandatory inoculation of young girls against the sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer.
Title: Furor on Rush to Require Cervical Cancer Vaccine

Content: The government is beginning a project designed to unlock the genetic abnormalities that contribute to cancer, an effort that would exceed the Human Genome Project in complexity and could eventually lead to new diagnostic tests and treatments for the disease.
Title: New Genome Project to Focus on Genetic Links in Cancers

Content: Some women who drink to their health may want to reconsider. A new study shows that women who routinely have even small amounts of alcohol, as few as three drinks a week, have an elevated risk of breast cancer.
Title: A Few Drinks a Week Raises Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Dr. Howard Riina threaded a slender tube through a maze of arteries in Dennis Sugrue’s brain, watching X-ray images on a monitor to track his progress. At the site where a previous operation had removed a malignant tumor, he infused a drug called mannitol and unleashed a flood of the cancer drug Avastin.
Title: Breaching a Barrier to Fight Brain Cancer

Content: SciClone Pharmaceuticals said Friday it had discontinued a study of its experimental drug for pancreatic cancer after a recommendation by a safety review committee. The drug, known as RP101, is a nucleoside analog that was being tested for patients with late-stage cancer of the pancreas, the company said. The decision to stop the study was based on a review of data by a safety monitoring group overseeing the trial, the company said. SciClone, based in Foster City, Calif., markets Zadaxin, a treatment for hepatitis B, hepatitis C and certain cancers. The RP101 study was in the second of three phases generally required by regulators before they will approve a drug. The company did not specify what the safety panel found.
Title: Drug Maker Halts Test of Pancreatic Cancer Drug

Content: A nonprofit group in Washington has filed a lawsuit against Bayer Healthcare charging that the company’s labels and commercials falsely claimed its One A Day multivitamins for men may reduce the risk of prostate cancer.
Title: Bayer Labels’ Cancer-Fighting Claim Draws Suit

Content: As a growing number of Americans are learning, surviving cancer can mean slipping into a rabbit hole of long-term medical problems — from premature menopause and sexual dysfunction to more debilitating side effects of chemotherapy and radiation, like heart disease and even new cancers.
Title: Cancer Care Seeks to Take Patients Beyond Survival

Content: Scientists have discovered yet another reason that alcohol might be good for you. Using pooled data from 12 studies and more than 750,000 subjects, researchers found that moderate alcohol consumption — about a drink a day — is associated with a decreased risk of renal cell carcinoma, one type of kidney cancer.
Title: Outcomes: Alcohol Is Tied to Lower Risk of One Type of Kidney Cancer

Content: Michael Mercado, 20, has made a bargain with fate. He would finish school and find a good job working on cars if only, he says, “the cancer stays away.”
Title: At 20, Surviving Battle With Cancer on His Own

Content: Members of the news media gathered in a conference room at Citi Field on Friday for the annual off-season luncheon with Mets executives, including the chief operating officer Jeff Wilpon, the assistant general manager John Ricco and the top front-office aide J. P. Ricciardi.
Title: Mets’ Sandy Alderson Needs Treatment for Cancer

Content: The Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation has canceled half of its “3-Day” fund-raising races around the country next year as it struggles to regain support nearly 18 months after its 2012 decision to withdraw funding for breast cancer screening at some Planned Parenthood affiliates.
Title: Komen Breast Cancer Charity Cancels Races in 7 Cities

Content: Many women with early-stage breast cancer who would receive chemotherapy under current standards do not actually need it, according to a major international study that is expected to quickly change medical treatment.
Title: Good News for Women With Breast Cancer: Many Don’t Need Chemo

Content: OncoMed Pharmaceuticals, a company developing therapeutics to target cancer stem cells, has raised $3.7 million in a third tranche of its Series A financing round. OncoMed also said that it has signed a development deal with a German antibody company, MorphoSys.
Title: OncoMed Raises $3.7 Million for Cancer Treatment

Content: CHICAGO — Two biotechnology giants did battle here at the largest U.S. cancer conference over the weekend. And both remained standing.
Title: Cancer drug works as initial treatment, ImClone says

Content: The cyclist Lance Armstrong's successful treatment for advanced metastatic testicular cancer was not a miracle, though some accounts have portrayed it as one.
Title: Testicular Cancer Success Has Doctors Asking Why

Content: Mitt Romney’s wife, Ann, released a statement today that she was diagnosed last week with early stage breast cancer and had undergone a lumpectomy.
Title: Ann Romney Diagnosed With Early Stage Breast Cancer

Content: Right at 9:30, punctual as usual, Jessica Kuebler padded down the hallway and into the ninth-floor lounge at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Anne Marie Cicciu was already waiting, her 5-foot-10 frame bent into a child-size chair, beneath a sign announcing, "Class in Session."
Title: In a Children’s Cancer Ward, Lessons Beyond A B C’s

Content: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a new form of the widely used cancer drug Taxol that is easier to administer and avoids some side effects.
Title: New Form of Breast Cancer Drug Approved

Content: In the corridors of Scottsdale Memorial Hospital-North in 1993, women who ranked among the best golfers in the world took turns walking to the bedside of a young rival, Heather Farr, to listen to her confidently plot her return to the L.P.G.A. Tour.
Title: L.P.G.A. Golfers Unite to Battle Shared Burden of Breast Cancer

Content: The McCain campaign issued a statement this evening from the Mayo Clinic in Arizona, where Senator John McCain had a small spot on his face removed and biopsied on Monday.
Title: Mayo Clinic: McCain’s Biopsy Cancer-Free

Content: Wyeth, the largest maker of hormone-replacement medicines used during menopause, won dismissal of a lawsuit in Minnesota linking its Premarin and Prempro drugs to breast cancer.
Title: Cancer Claim Is Dismissed Against Wyeth Hormone Drugs

Content: THE BREAKTHROUGH Immunotherapy and the Race to Cure Cancer By Charles Graeber Illustrated. 302 pp. Twelve. $28.
Title: Could Immunotherapy Offer a Cure for Cancer?

Content: ISTANBUL/ANKARA — Demet Isil Yilmaz was halfway through a debilitating chemotherapy course when the coronavirus pandemic erupted, intensifying her struggle for health which she has chronicled for her thousands of Instagram followers.
Title: 'This Will Pass': Turkish Cancer Blogger Hopeful Despite Coronavirus

Content: ORLANDO, Fla., May 14 - A drug now used to treat breast cancer might be able to prevent prostate cancer in men with a precancerous condition, doctors said here Saturday. Another study suggested that the widely used cholesterol-lowering drugs called statins might stave off breast cancer.
Title: Studies Find 2 Drugs May Prevent Cancer

Content: A team of scientists in Cleveland and San Francisco said today that they have discovered a new virus among patients who had a rare form of prostate cancer and a particular genetic mutation.
Title: Scientists Find Virus in Some Prostate-Cancer Patients
A Revolutionary Cancer Therapy Made From Patients’ Cells

Content: Last Friday a group of 15 cancer researchers cut short a meeting at the Food and Drug Administration. The reason: They had been invited to Vice President Joseph R. Biden’s office to discuss his “moonshot” to cure cancer.
Title: ‘Moonshot’ to Cure Cancer, to Be Led by Biden, Relies on Outmoded View of Disease

Content: ORLANDO, Fla., May 13 - New drugs developed using the tools of biotechnology are helping prevent relapses among cancer patients and prolonging some lives, cancer specialists said Friday at the opening of the biggest annual conference devoted to treatment of the disease.
Title: New Biotech Drugs Are Producing Gains Against Cancer

Content: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, announced to his staff on Friday that his doctors had found no evidence of cancer in his body, a few months after he concluded treatment for throat cancer.
Title: Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase Says, ‘No Evidence of Cancer’

Content: Pfizer agreed to buy the rights to an experimental drug for lung-cancer drug from the closely held Coley Pharmaceutical Group for as much as $505 million. Pfizer will pay Coley $50 million up front and as much as $455 million more for meeting certain goals. The drug, called ProMune, has already been tested in more than 900 patients with blood cancer and solid tumors, the companies said. Coley is based in Wellesley, Mass. Pfizer is based in New York.
Title: PFIZER BUYS RIGHTS TO EXPERIMENTAL LUNG CANCER DRUG

Content: A particularly fast-growing form of breast cancer should be treated aggressively after surgery even when tumors are very small, according to new research that could dramatically alter treatment for one in five women diagnosed with breast cancer.
Title: For Some Women, Aggressive Treatment for Early Breast Cancer

Content: Intrauterine devices may offer some protection against cervical cancer, a large review of studies has found.
Title: Patterns: IUDs May Protect Against Cervical Cancer

Content: Venezuela will create a scientific panel to investigate the illness of Hugo Chávez, after an accusation by the interim president last week that the former president’s cancer was mysteriously caused by his enemies. “We have this intuition that our Commander Chávez was poisoned by dark forces that wanted to get rid of him to destroy the Bolivarian revolution and strike at Latin America and the Caribbean,” Nicolás Maduro, the interim president, said Monday night. Mr. Chávez, a charismatic leftist, died last week after 14 years in office. The government has refused to say what type of cancer Mr. Chávez had, but Mr. Maduro said that it had behaved in a very unusual way. Mr. Maduro said that the United States and other countries had developed programs in the 1940s and 1950s to experiment with intentionally causing cancer, but he added, “I’m not accusing the United States at this moment.” He did not say when the scientific panel would be created or who would be on it.
Title: Venezuela: Panel Will Investigate Roots of Cancer That Killed Chávez

Content: Anew blood test aimed at detecting ovarian cancer at an early, still treatable stage is stirring hopes among women and their physicians. But the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and some experts say the test has not been proved to work.
Title: New blood test for ovarian cancer creates concern

Content: A friend in my cancer support group suggested a call to Look Good Feel Better when I arrived at lunch looking bad and feeling worse. The program had given her eyebrows. Eyebrows, I thought, would be good. Eyebrows seem like something it might be reasonable to want.
Title: Living With Cancer: Look Good, Feel Better

Content: Amgen’s bone drug denosumab delayed the spread of prostate cancer to bones in a clinical trial, the company said late Monday. However, the drug did not prolong the lives of men.
Title: Amgen Drug Slows Spread of Cancer but Doesn’t Extend Life

Content: New Medicare rules for a small but promising class of cancer drugs may cause thousands of lymphoma patients to lose access to the treatment, which in some cases is the only therapy available to them.
Title: Medicare Cuts Payout on 2 Cancer Drugs

Content: New Medicare rules for a small but promising class of cancer drugs may cause thousands of lymphoma patients to lose access to the treatment, which in some cases is the only therapy available to them.
Title: Medicare Cuts Payout on 2 Cancer Drugs

Content: Advances in imaging technology mean that more and more breast cancers are being detected at the earliest stages — sometimes when the rogue cells are as tiny as a few grains of salt. But now there are new questions about whether many pathologists are able to render reliable opinions on such tiny lesions, according to an extensive New York Times examination of breast cancer cases.
Title: Doubt About Pathology Opinions for Early Breast Cancer

Content: The story of Mandi Schwartz has been heard far and wide: a Yale hockey player stricken with leukemia, she needs a stem-cell transplant to survive, and her family and friends are searching everywhere to find her one.
Title: Questions About Yale Cancer Patient’s Benefactor

Content: They are among the most challenging prostate cancer patients to treat: about 150,000 men worldwide each year whose cancer is aggressive enough to defy standard hormonal therapy, but has not yet spread to the point where it can be seen on scans.
Title: Two Prostate Cancer Drugs Delay Spread of the Disease by Two Years

Content: When scientists tested people for a genetic mutation that increases the risk for colon cancer, they thought that telling people of their increased risk would encourage them to get the recommended screening. They were wrong.
Title: Knowing Cancer Risk May Not Affect Screening Rates

Content: A Hurdle Arises In Tracking Cancer
Title: An Indefinite Pause in Tracking Cancer

Content: THE FACTS Scientists have known for some time that night shift workers are prone to sleep disorders and trouble staying awake. But when epidemiologists compared people who worked at night with daytime workers several years ago, they found something unexpected: female nightshift workers had elevated rates of breast cancer.
Title: The Claim: Artificial Light Can Increase Breast Cancer

Content: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new life-prolonging drug for men with late-stage prostate cancer on Friday, adding to an increasingly crowded field.
Title: New Drug For Prostate Cancer Gets F.D.A. Nod

Content: In October 2006, Dr. Claudia Henschke of Weill Cornell Medical College jolted the cancer world with a study saying that 80 percent of lung cancer deaths could be prevented through widespread use of CT scans.
Title: Cigarette company paid for lung cancer study in U.S.

Content: ORLANDO, Fla., May 15 - New drugs are offering new hope to people with kidney cancer, which until now has mostly defied treatment, doctors said here over the weekend.
Title: In Trials, Drugs Show Promise Against Kidney Cancer

Content: Half a century ago, my grandmother died of esophageal cancer. For decades preceding her death, a bottle of milk of magnesia was her steady companion because she suffered daily from heartburn, now known as gastroesophageal reflux disease, or GERD. But many years passed before a link was clearly established between chronic irritation of the esophagus by stomach acid and this usually fatal cancer.
Title: New techniques help in fight against esophageal cancer

Content: Women who take drugs like raloxifene or tamoxifen can reduce their risk of developing invasive breast cancer by up to half, but they may be at greater risk for potentially serious blood clots, according to a new paper that reviews the risks and benefits of the drugs.
Title: Risks: Breast Cancer Drugs Bear Health Cautions

Content: It took only an instant for 58-year-old Gailanne Reeh to go from the picture of health to death's door. By chance, her doctor noticed a lump under her arm during a routine exam. It turned out to be advanced breast cancer.
Title: Costly cancer drug offers hope, but also a dilemma

Content: CHICAGO — Women with early-stage breast cancer could benefit from taking an estrogen-suppressing drug for 10 years rather than the standard five, researchers reported here on Sunday, citing the results of a new study.
Title: Extending Estrogen Suppressor May Aid Breast Cancer Patients, Study Says

Content: Last year, an influential study examined whether breast cancer survivors with lymphedema could safely lift weights. Lymphedema, a painful and even disabling swelling of the arm, is a dreaded complication of breast-cancer surgery, especially if a woman had lymph nodes removed. Experts long thought that hefting weight of almost any kind would contribute to lymphedema in breast-cancer survivors and advised them to avoid picking up or carrying heavy purses, grocery bags, suitcases or their own children and to steer away, by all means, from formal weight training. But in last year’s study, breast-cancer survivors with a history of lymphedema who completed a slow, progressive program of weight training suffered fewer subsequent flare-ups of the condition than women who didn’t train, suggesting that weight lifting might actually combat lymphedema, not cause it.
Title: Phys Ed: Lifting Weights After Breast Cancer

Content: HOUSTON — Ronald DePinho, the president of the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center, part of the University of Texas, becomes animated when he talks about his ambitious plans in leading the institute’s efforts to combat the disease.
Title: Leader of Cancer Center Works on Changes After Feedback

Content: Scientists reported that they have detected a variant gene associated with prostate cancer, a finding that may make possible a diagnostic test to help decide which patients are the best candidates for aggressive treatment.
Title: Detection of gene may aid prostate cancer test

Content: CHAPEL HILL, North Carolina — John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat, said today that his wife's cancer had returned, but that his bid for the presidency "goes on strongly."
Title: John Edwards to continue campaign, despite wife's cancer

Content: Hamilton Jordan, the former White House chief of staff for President Jimmy Carter, was a well-known force in the health community. During the past 24 years he battled four different forms of cancer and urged cancer patients to empower themselves with information.
Title: One Man’s Advice From Four Cancer Battles

Content: People who were cured of cancer as children often suffered later in life from health problems caused by chemotherapy and radiation, a study of more than 10,000 survivors has found.
Title: Childhood Cancer Survivors Face Increased Risks Later

Content: When I caught up with Nancy Borowick on Thursday morning, she was running around East Harlem shooting a neighborhood feature for AM New York, a free newspaper distributed in the subways. Earlier this week, she worked fund-raisers for a charter school and a humanitarian relief organization. She is 28, a freelance photographer, and often rises at 6 a.m. to call assignment editors at newspapers around the city looking for day work — a politician campaigning, a news conference by the mayor, a good perp walk.
Title: Side by Side, Battling Cancer and Sending Off the Bride

Content: Rachel Troxell and Kristin Dudley joined an unlikely sorority when they started a company called Lymphedivas to sell fashionable compression sleeves for women suffering from lymphedema — businesses that owe their inspiration to a brush with breast cancer.
Title: New Ventures Help Fight the Frustrations of Fighting Breast Cancer

Content: Pat Malone had her lymph nodes removed as part of her breast cancer treatment, and for almost a decade she managed to keep her lymphedema, a chronic condition that causes swelling from an accumulation of fluid, under control. Then she decided to paint her kitchen.
Title: A Painful Lymph Illness Often Follows Cancer

Content: Gov. Tom Wolf of Pennsylvania has a treatable form of prostate cancer that was “thankfully detected early,” he announced on Wednesday. He will continue to serve as governor while undergoing treatment that will last several months.
Title: Pennsylvania Governor, Tom Wolf, Says He Has Prostate Cancer

Content: The defenseless 7-year-old boy was surrounded by a crew of evil ninjas trying to kill him, when suddenly a team of New York City police officers responded to his call and, with flying kicks and spectacular karate chops, beat the ninjas into submission.
Title: Sweat | Helping Children Kick at Ninjas, and Cancer

Content: The Starz cable channel said on Tuesday that it will delay production on the second season of its original series “Spartacus: Blood and Sand” so that the actor Andy Whitfield, who plays the title character, can begin treatment for non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
Title: ‘Spartacus’ Is Delayed While Star Is Treated for Cancer

Content: In a finding that challenges the conventional wisdom about the risks of some hormones used in menopause, a major government study has found that years after using estrogen-only therapy, certain women had a markedly reduced risk of breast cancer and heart attack.
Title: Estrogen Lowers Breast Cancer and Heart Attack Risk in Some

Content: Colon cancer survivors with diets high in meat and refined grains triple their risk of recurrence or death compared with those who eat fruits, vegetables and fish, a new study reports.
Title: Hazard: High-Fat Diet Raises Risk of Colon Cancer Return

Content: In an apparent nod to growing concern over the rapidly climbing costs of cancer drugs, Genentech announced yesterday that it would cap the total cost of its drug Avastin at $55,000 a year for patients below a certain income level.
Title: Genentech Caps Cost of Cancer Drug for Some Patients

Content: "Chasing Daylight: How My Forthcoming Death Transformed My Life," by Eugene O'Kelly, McGraw-Hill, $19.95.
Title: When Cancer Strikes, a High Achiever Plans

Content: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has throat cancer and will begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, he said in a note to the bank’s employees and shareholders late Tuesday.
Title: JPMorgan’s Jamie Dimon Has Throat Cancer That He Calls ‘Curable’

Content: Thirty years ago Forbes Hill of Brooklyn learned he had prostate cancer. At age 50, with a young wife and a fear of the common side effects of treatment  incontinence and impotence  he chose what oncologists call “watchful waiting.” For 12 years, Mr. Hill was fine. Then in 1990 his PSA count, a measure of cancer activity, began to rise, and he had radiation therapy. That dropped the count to near zero. In 2000, with the count up again, he chose hormone therapy, which worked for a while.
Title: In Cancer Therapy, There Is a Time to Treat and a Time to Let Go

Content: Lindsey Wilkerson was given a tour when she first began working in the event and patient-liaison department at St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital in Memphis more than 14 years ago.
Title: Love Not Lost: Two Childhood Cancer Survivors Marry at St. Jude

Content: Taking aspirin every day may significantly reduce the risk of many cancers and prevent tumors from spreading, according to two new studies published on Tuesday.
Title: Studies Link Daily Doses of Aspirin to Reduced Risk of Cancer

Content: On a lab bench in Philadelphia sits a tiny box lined with nearly invisible nanotubes and gold. A clear plastic pipe runs through it, and a thicket of pins, each sprouting a red or blue wire, protrudes from its end. As air from the pipe wafts over the nanotubes, electrical signals surge out of the box along the wire threads. The whole apparatus is situated near a vial of blood, “sniffing” the air above it through the pipe.
Title: What Does Cancer Smell Like?

Content: “Cancer doesn’t just put your life on hold,” says Suleika Jaouad, Well columnist, in a new video that documents her experiences as a 23-year-old woman with cancer. “It’s not like you get to skip back a few months and pick up exactly where you left off. I wasn’t going to get my old life back.”
Title: Life, Interrupted: A Video Portrait of Cancer in Young Adulthood

Content: For nearly a year, Times editor Dana Jennings has been coping with an aggressive form of prostate cancer. Recently, one of his good friends was diagnosed with the disease and is soon scheduled for surgery.
Title: Baby Powder, Soft Pillows and Other Cancer Wisdom

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Tumor Types May Explain Survival Rates for Cancer

Content: Researchers at Johns Hopkins University have developed a way to monitor the progress of a patient’s cancer treatment using a new technique for rapidly sequencing, or decoding, large amounts of DNA.
Title: Speed Reading of DNA May Help Cancer Treatment

Content: Should healthy women take drugs to lower their risk of breast cancer?
Title: Breast Cancer Drugs Urged for Healthy High-Risk Women

Content: For Larisa Shchetinina, now 72, the decision to leave Ukraine  though not the act itself  came suddenly. In 1992, she went to Kiev to say goodbye to her brother, who was moving to Israel. In the center of the country’s capital she saw graffiti on a wall that read, in large letters: “Let’s drown Russians in Jewish blood.”
Title: Surviving Hitler and Stalin to Fight Poverty and Cancer

Content: Q.
Title: How Often Will Medicare Pay for Colon Cancer Screening?

Content: Yong Ning Dai, 74, recently took up baking, making a vanilla sponge cake with bananas, fresh whipped cream and just the right amount of sweetness. He did not hone his baking skills during the hours of free time that often fill the days of the elderly, but while doing odd jobs at bakeries around Flushing, Queens.
Title: Battling Cancer, but Staying on Path to Citizenship

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Tumor Types May Explain Survival Rates for Cancer

Content: PITTSBURGH — The head of a prominent cancer research institute has issued an unprecedented warning to his faculty and staff: Limit cellphone use because of the possible risk of cancer.
Title: Researcher warns of brain cancer risk from cellphones

Content: Many patients with advanced cancer must feel great relief after last week’s decisions by Medicare to pay for two drugs that provide limited medical benefits. For these patients, even a few more months of life is beyond price.
Title: Extremely Expensive Cancer Drugs

Content: Noreen Fraser, a television producer who used her broadcasting skills to raise money and public awareness in a national campaign against breast cancer, died on Monday at her home in Brentwood, Calif., more than 15 years after she learned she had the disease. She was 63.
Title: Noreen Fraser, Who Led a Public Fight Against Cancer, Dies at 63

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Vaccine Prevents Cervical Cancer. So, What's the Down Side?

Content: Leroy Sievers, a television news producer who covered more than a dozen wars but became best known to the public as he chronicled his illness for NPR, died at home in Potomac, Md., on Friday. He was 53.
Title: Leroy Sievers, 53, Journalist Who Wrote of Cancer Battle, Dies

Content: When Nancy M. Cappello learned that she had breast cancer, and that mammography could not find it, she turned her misfortune into a tireless campaign that led 36 states to require fuller disclosure to women about their mammogram results and the limitations of the test.
Title: Nancy Cappello, Breast Cancer Activist, Is Dead at 66

Content: Two new DNA-based tests, one of them described at a meeting in Philadelphia on Thursday, hold the promise of detecting early  and sharply reducing  colon cancer, a disease that afflicts 150,000 people a year in the United States and costs an estimated $14 billion to treat.
Title: New DNA Tests Aimed at Reducing Colon Cancer

Content: Many surgeons and radiation centers tout promising statistics when they talk to men about the risk of sexual side effects from prostate cancer treatment. But as I write in the Sunday Review, new research published last week finally offers men some straight talk about what to expect from treatment for prostate cancer.
Title: Telling Men the Truth about Sex and Prostate Cancer

Content: The cyclist Lance Armstrong’s successful treatment for advanced metastatic testicular cancer was not a miracle, though some accounts have portrayed it as one.
Title: Testicular Cancer Success Has Doctors Asking Why

Content: Over the weekend, I heard from a New York Times picture editor, Soo-Jeong Kang, who was involved in the publication of a photograph that generated a great deal of discussion when it appeared on The Times’s front page (PDF) last Wednesday. Ms. Kang assigned the photo shoot that resulted in that much-discussed image of an Israeli woman’s upper torso, including incision scars, a portion of her areola and her Star of David tattoo. It did not show her face.
Title: The Woman in the Breast Cancer Photo Responds to Times Readers

Content: Two important studies being published today challenge conventional thoughts about treating and avoiding breast cancer.
Title: Two New Breast Cancer Studies Yield Surprises

Content: Pfizer plans to submit its proposed new lung cancer drug to the Food and Drug Administration in the first half of next year at the same time that it submits a gene diagnostic test being developed with Abbott to identify patients most likely to benefit from the drug, company officials said Thursday.
Title: Pfizer Hopes to Pair Cancer Drug, Gene Test

Content: TOKYO — More than seven years after a devastating earthquake and tsunami caused meltdowns at a nuclear power plant in Fukushima, Japan acknowledged for the first time this week that a worker died from cancer after being exposed to radiation.
Title: In a First, Japan Says Fukushima Radiation Caused Worker’s Cancer Death

Content: Men who take a drug to reduce hair loss may also be reducing their levels of P.S.A., a marker for prostate cancer.
Title: Side Effects: Hair-Loss Drug May Affect Marker for Cancer

Content: Genentech stopped enrolling women with advanced ovarian cancer in a trial testing another use for its Avastin drug after researchers noticed higher rates of gastrointestinal perforations.
Title: Genentech Stops Enrolling Patients in Cancer Drug Trial

Content: Justina Mejia has become fluent in the language of cancer.
Title: Sibling Bond Strengthens Amid the Ordeal of Cancer

Content: One in four American girls and women ages 14 to 19 has a sexually transmitted disease, and one in four ages 14 to 59 is infected with HPV.
Title: A Lifesaving Tool Against Cervical Cancer Remains Underused

Content: Few families have been as devastated by pancreatic cancer as that of former President Jimmy Carter.
Title: In a Former First Family, Cancer Has a Grim Legacy

Content: Grains and cereals have been fortified with folic acid in the United States since 1998, as part of an effort to reduce the incidence of neural tube birth defects in babies. But a new study has raised safety concerns, linking megadoses of the vitamin to increased cancer rates, particularly lung cancer.
Title: Regimens: Cancer Concerns in Big Doses of Folic Acid

Content: The use of annual CT scans to screen for lung cancer is either an enormous breakthrough that holds the first real promise for curing this normally lethal disease - or an unproven tool whose real value is yet to be determined. Those are the possibilities raised by a multinational study led by researchers at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical College.
Title: Lung cancer breakthrough? - Opinion - International Herald Tribune

Content: Many men 75 years and older, who are far more likely to be harmed than helped by prostate cancer screening, continue to be tested for the disease, despite federal guidelines strongly advising against the practice.
Title: Older Men Still Being Screened for Prostate Cancer

Content: Dr. Alan S. Rabson, who helped define the field of cancer pathology, who figured out why shingles and recurrent cold sores occur, and who helped lead the National Cancer Institute into new eras over several decades, died on July 4 in Skillman, N.J. He was 92.
Title: Dr. Alan S. Rabson, Influential Cancer Researcher, Is Dead at 92

Content: FLORENCE, Italy — The black-and-white checkered floor of the taxi looks a bit like home flooring. The seats are yellow, purple and orange leather, while the pea-green interiors are plastered with daisy stickers. When riding in the cab, passengers can play with plastic swords and a megaphone, or make soap bubbles.
Title: ‘Taxi Therapy’ for Young Cancer Patients in Italy

Content: An exhaustive new report meant to address public fears about possible links between breast cancer and the environment finds evidence strong enough to make only a few firm recommendations, most already well known and none with a large proven benefit.
Title: Scientific Panel Finds Few Clear Environmental Links to Breast Cancer

Content: Dr. Peter C. Nowell, who with a colleague discovered the first genetic defect proven to cause cancer, died on Dec. 26 in Newtown Square, Pa. He was 88.
Title: Dr. Peter Nowell, Who Helped Transform Cancer Research, Dies at 88

Content: Valley Stream
Title: Three Sisters, One Battle to Break a Chain of Cancer

Content: In medical experiments on human beings, every patient must sign an “informed consent” form acknowledging the risks, and researchers are required to keep track of those statements.
Title: Review Casts More Doubts on a Lung Cancer Study

Content: If anything about my mother was conventional, it was the smoking. Like many of her generation she smoked early and often, and I swear she waited to light up until we were hermetically sealed in our family’s Ford Country Squire.
