Content: Wielding coat hangers, a coalition of sixty abortion rights groups organized a rally in Warsaw, Poland, over the weekend to protest a proposed law that would further restrict legal abortions in the country. [One of the protesters, Anna Jakobic, said that the right to an abortion must be defended, especially if one has a baby with disabilities. Ã¢ÂÂNo government can decide this. Maybe they also want to prohibit oncological operations? Cancer is also live tissue,Ã¢ÂÂ she said.  PolandÃ¢ÂÂs current legislation, dating back to 1993, bans abortions except when the pregnancy is a result of rape or incest, poses a Ã¢ÂÂhealth riskÃ¢ÂÂ to the mother, or if the fetus bears an anomaly, such as Down Syndrome. The Prenatal Life Protection Law, backed by the prime minister, Beata SzydÃÂo, would ban abortion outright. The new bill, which has been submitted to the Polish parliament, acknowledges that rape is an evil act, but prohibits Ã¢ÂÂpunishing the childÃ¢ÂÂ for the crimes of the rapist. According to opponents, the Law and Justice party (PiS) which was voted into office last October, carries Ã¢ÂÂan agenda of nationalist conservatism, Euroscepticism and Catholic propaganda. Ã¢ÂÂ Abortion activists reportedly organized Ã¢ÂÂsolidarity protestsÃ¢ÂÂ in several other European cities as well, and a few hundred people demonstrated in front of the Polish embassy in London, shouting Ã¢ÂÂmy body, my choice. Ã¢ÂÂ The weekend demonstrations underscored the tremendous impact that the American abortion lobby has had on Polish society and the abortion debate in particular. It was the American feminist Ann Snitow who first brought modern abortion technology to Poland in the early 1990s. The use of coat hanger imagery by protesters was also imported into Europe by U. S.   groups as a symbol of illegal, Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ abortions. Ã¢ÂÂThe thing is, I donÃ¢ÂÂt think women in Poland ever used hangers. I think thatÃ¢ÂÂs strictly American,Ã¢ÂÂ said Polish abortion activist and researcher Agata CheÃÂstowska. At the annual meeting of the UN Commission on the Status of Women in March, the head of the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) suggested said that being   really means being  . Ã¢ÂÂWe care about the womanÃ¢ÂÂs life, and the child whoÃ¢ÂÂs coming Ã¢ÂÂ  if they are sick, like Zika, what we are hearing Ã¢ÂÂ  or thrown on the streets, or kidnapped, or dead. We want all alive, and healthy, and productive, and equal to all humanity. We dare to talk about abortion,Ã¢ÂÂ said IPPF President Tewodros Melesse during the New York event. Meanwhile, the European Parliament will vote on Wednesday on a motion that accuses Polish authorities of undermining Ã¢ÂÂconstitutional democracy. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂRecent events in Poland,Ã¢ÂÂ the text reads, Ã¢ÂÂhave given rise to concerns regarding the ability of the Constitutional Court to uphold the constitution and guarantee the respect for the rule of law. Ã¢ÂÂ The first draft of the motion included a direct reference to PolandÃ¢ÂÂs proposed ban on abortion but it was removed from the final version, as well as mentions of other controversial laws on public media and the civil service. Content: Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton claimed in the third presidential debate in Las Vegas on Wednesday that Planned Parenthood Ã¢ÂÂprovides cancer screeningsÃ¢ÂÂ and therefore should not be   in spite of controversy about abortion.[ : MOSTLY FALSE,  This is a repeated claim deployed in defense of Planned Parenthood, but it is not true, at least as regards breast cancer.  As the   Washington PostÃ¢ÂÂs   wrote in 2015: When Democratic lawmakers or other supporters assert that Planned Parenthood Ã¢ÂÂprovidesÃ¢ÂÂ mammograms, this is highly misleading language because it could be interpreted to mean that the group directly administers the  . The group does not Ã¢ÂÂprovideÃ¢ÂÂ mammograms. Rather, the situation is similar to other clinics where patients are referred to a licensed facility that can provide biopsies,   or other specialized services. It is slightly more accurate to say that women have Ã¢ÂÂaccessÃ¢ÂÂ to mammograms via Planned Parenthood, though itÃ¢ÂÂs still slippery language. The Post awarded Three Pinnochios (out of four) to the claim that Planned Parenthood provides mammograms. Planned Parenthood does offer Pap tests and HPV tests, which are screenings for cervical cancer. So the claim is not completely false, but mostly so.
Title: Fact-Check: No, Planned Parenthood Does Not Ã¢ÂÂProvide Cancer ScreeningsÃ¢ÂÂ - Breitbart

Content: A woman in Indiana has been accused of injecting human feces into the IV bag of her   son in a likely effort to hasten his death, authorities say. [Prosecutors have charged Wolcott, Indiana, resident Tiffany Alberts, 41, with seven felony charges, including aggravated battery and one count of neglect of a dependent resulting in serious bodily injury, according to WLFI Channel 18.  Marion County officials say Alberts knowingly injected the feces mixture into her    sonÃ¢ÂÂs IV bag as he underwent treatment for cancer. The womanÃ¢ÂÂs actions were eventually discovered when doctors encountered infections popping up in the stricken child that couldnÃ¢ÂÂt be explained. Hospital staffers placed video surveillance on the childÃ¢ÂÂs hospital room to figure out the source of the constant infections. Eventually, the surveillance video showed the childÃ¢ÂÂs mother injecting something into the boyÃ¢ÂÂs IV bags. Upon further investigation, doctors identified organisms that usually only appear in feces. There was no legitimate explanation for the organisms to be present in the boyÃ¢ÂÂs blood unless it was an act of sabotage. Under questioning, Alberts initially insisted she only injected water into the bags to Ã¢ÂÂclean the linesÃ¢ÂÂ but later allegedly admitted to injecting feces into the bags. Doctors also feared the woman injected diarrheal medication and weight loss pills into the boy causing further harm and preventing his body from fighting the cancer. The child responded well to medical treatment after his mother was taken into custody, but doctors fear the delay in proper treatment caused the boy to miss the optimal window to help him beat his Leukemia into remission. Title: Indiana Mother Is Accused of Injecting Feces into Cancer-Stricken SonÃ¢ÂÂs IV Bag - Breitbart

Content: Ben Stiller revealed he was diagnosed with prostate cancer two years ago and underwent surgery to be treated for the disease in an interview with Howard Stern on Tuesday. [The    Meet the Parents star told Stern he was diagnosed with an Ã¢ÂÂintermediately aggressiveÃ¢ÂÂ form of the illness in 2014, when he was 48 years old, and that the news had come Ã¢ÂÂout of the blue. Ã¢ÂÂ  Stiller appeared on Howard SternÃ¢ÂÂs SiriusXM radio show alongside his surgeon, Dr. Edward Schaeffer, who had conducted a Ã¢ÂÂrobotic assisted laparoscopic radical prostatectomyÃ¢ÂÂ to successfully remove the actorÃ¢ÂÂs tumor. Stiller said that if he hadnÃ¢ÂÂt been receiving a regular test called a PSA test to screen for the deadly cancer, he may never have caught it in time.  Stiller followed up his appearance on Howard SternÃ¢ÂÂs show with an essay posted to Medium about his experience. Ã¢ÂÂI got diagnosed with prostate cancer Friday, June 13th, 2014. On September 17th of that year I got a test back telling me I was cancer free,Ã¢ÂÂ Stiller wrote. Ã¢ÂÂThe three months in between were a crazy roller coaster ride with which about 180, 000 men a year in America can identify. Ã¢ÂÂ He continued: Ã¢ÂÂTaking the PSA test saved my life. Literally. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why I am writing this now. There has been a lot of controversy over the test in the last few years. Articles and   on whether it is safe, studies that seem to be interpreted in many different ways, and debates about whether men should take it all. I am not offering a scientific point of view here, just a personal one, based on my experience. The bottom line for me: I was lucky enough to have a doctor who gave me what they call a Ã¢ÂÂbaselineÃ¢ÂÂ PSA test when I was about 46. I have no history of prostate cancer in my family and I am not in the   group, being neitherÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂto the best of my knowledgeÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂof African or Scandinavian ancestry. I had no symptoms. Ã¢ÂÂ The actor praised the Ã¢ÂÂthoughtfulÃ¢ÂÂ internist who conducted PSA tests on him, avoiding guidelines set forth by by the American Cancer Society to wait until age 50 to conduct them. The actor wrote that critics of the test contend that, Ã¢ÂÂdepending on how they interpret the data, doctors can send patients for further tests like the MRI and the more invasive biopsy, when not needed. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂBut without this PSA test itself, or any screening procedure at all, how are doctors going to detect asymptomatic cases like mine, before the cancer has spread and metastasized throughout oneÃ¢ÂÂs body rendering it incurable?Ã¢ÂÂ Stiller wrote. Stiller concluded by revealing that he has now been   for two years. The actor and filmmaker has a number of projects coming up, both in front of and behind the camera, including a starring role opposite Adam Sandler and Dustin Hoffman in Noah BaumbachÃ¢ÂÂs next movie and as a producer on Dodgeball 2 and Jack Black comedy The Polka King.   Follow Daniel Nussbaum on Twitter: @dznussbaum
Title: Ben Stiller Reveals Battle with Prostate Cancer

Content: (CNN) When Erin Chieze saw an indentation on her breast in December 2015, her conclusion was immediate. Ã¢ÂÂI instantly knew I had breast cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ she wrote on Facebook, thanks to a breast cancer awareness photo a friend had shared. Ã¢ÂÂHad I not seen that photo, I would have assumed that it was an indentation from the underwire of my bra,Ã¢ÂÂ Chieze, 38, a nursing student at West Hills College in Lemoore, California, told CNN. Within five days of noticing the indentation, she was told she likely had breast cancer. A month later, doctors told her it was stage IV the cancer had metastasized outside the breast. Ã¢ÂÂI knew all about self exams,Ã¢ÂÂ Chieze wrote on Facebook last week, Ã¢ÂÂbut a picture of what to look for keyed me into knowing I had a terminal disease.Ã¢ÂÂ In telling her story, she found a similar photo online, an egg carton filled with lemons, on the website for a charity called Worldwide Breast Cancer. She shared it on Facebook with an impassioned call to promote awareness with useful, practical information.  Her post with the    image has now been shared nearly 42, 000 times. When life gives you lemons, Corrine Ellsworth Beaumont, who launched the Ã¢ÂÂKnow Your LemonsÃ¢ÂÂ campaign and founded Worldwide Breast Cancer in 2014, lost both of her grandmothers to the disease. The second died while Beaumont was pursuing a masterÃ¢ÂÂs degree in graphic design, when Beaumont was in her early 20s. Uncertain of her own risk, she went off in search of more information. She found leaflets of older women Ã¢ÂÂall smiling about breast cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂI couldnÃ¢ÂÂt relate to those materials,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂI didnÃ¢ÂÂt know what I should be looking for. What does a lump feel like, and when should I be screened?Ã¢ÂÂ Then, in 2002, Beaumont had an idea. She started photographing pairs of different items to illustrate breasts: cantaloupes, flashlights, muffins. She tried to put herself in the patientÃ¢ÂÂs shoes, setting up a mock mammogram appointment and talking with women in waiting rooms.  Finally, she found the visual metaphor she needed. Ã¢ÂÂEverything clicked,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂTheyÃ¢ÂÂre just these yellow, friendly lemons.Ã¢ÂÂ The campaign includes three images: the carton of lemons, a lemon slice to illustrate breast anatomy and a flowchart of the steps it may take to receive a breast cancer diagnosis. Beaumont says the lemonsÃ¢ÂÂ appeal is the key to avoiding the censorship and fear issues that come with images of breast cancer.  Ã¢ÂÂYou can be incredibly detailed about symptoms without grossing people out,Ã¢ÂÂ she said, recalling her experience looking at graphic breast cancer images online.  In the years since, the lemons have traveled to 70 countries in many languages. But it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt until this past week, when Chieze posted on Facebook, that they found overwhelming popularity. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm absolutely overwhelmed by the positivity that this campaign has generated,Ã¢ÂÂ Beaumont said. Ã¢ÂÂHealth brochures donÃ¢ÂÂt go viral.Ã¢ÂÂ The science behind the lemons, Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs all about knowing what changes to look for,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Andrea Barrio, a breast surgical oncologist at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.  Barrio said the Ã¢ÂÂKnow Your LemonsÃ¢ÂÂ design illustrates how breast cancer symptoms can look very different depending on the type of cancer, how big it is and where it is growing.  Breast cancer often presents with a lump or a mass, but many cases, like ChiezeÃ¢ÂÂs, have no detectable lumps at all. However, most lumps are not cancerous and may be related to pregnancy, cysts, lymph nodes and hormonal changes.  Although 80% of breast lumps are benign, said Barrio, they should always be checked out by a doctor. The indentation Chieze noticed, Barrio said, may occur when cancer grows into the connective tissue that keeps the breastÃ¢ÂÂs normal shape and structure. These tissues, called CooperÃ¢ÂÂs ligaments, tug on the skin from the inside as the tumor grows, creating a dimple. An inverted nipple, said Barrio, can occur when the cancer invades the same connective tissue behind the nipple. One lemon has clear and dark fluid leaking from the stem end. Certain growths, such as benign tumors that occur in the breast ducts, can irritate the milk lining, creating a clear or bloody discharge, said Barrio. Most often, the discharge comes from one nipple, not both. A couple of the lemons show common signs of inflammation, such as redness and heat. With more advanced cancers, Barrio said, the breast may take on the appearance of what doctors call peau dÃ¢ÂÂorange, French for Ã¢ÂÂorange peel.Ã¢ÂÂ As the tumor grows, it can cause fluid to build up in the breast, making pores appear dimpled on the inflamed skin, like an orange rind. Ã¢ÂÂOur breasts normally drain fluid, like water flowing through a river,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂA tumor can almost be like a dam.Ã¢ÂÂ The lemons also show how a growing vein may indicate tumor growth underneath. More advanced cancers can even begin to grow out of the skin. Ã¢ÂÂIt can actually erode the skin, like a burn,Ã¢ÂÂ Barrio said. There are other cancer clues that are not illustrated in the viral graphic, according to Barrio. Rarely, cancers send cells up to the skinÃ¢ÂÂs surface, which can form tiny red skin nodules. Barrio said these can be easily mistaken for inflamed hair follicles at first, but they do not go away. Rashes caused by breast cancer can also be mistaken for eczema. Despite the popularity of the graphic, Barrio said, most of the cases she sees are picked up by routine mammogram before a patient has any symptoms. In her work as a surgeon, she does not often see patients with the symptoms in BeaumontÃ¢ÂÂs graphic. Ã¢ÂÂBut this can depend on screening and access to health care,Ã¢ÂÂ she said, adding that in areas such as many of the developing countries where the lemons have been distributed, many patients do arrive at the clinic with visible symptoms. Even then, Barrios cautions that a clear mammogram is not an  . Ã¢ÂÂYou can have a normal mammogram and still have changes that need to be looked into,Ã¢ÂÂ she said  Life after lemons, For BeaumontÃ¢ÂÂs next project, she is working with metastatic breast cancer patients through the Metastatic Breast Cancer Alliance, a patient advocate organization that connects breast cancer patients with resources and clinical trials. Her project will use similar images to prompt conversations between these patients and their doctors. Of the recent attention to her Facebook post, breast cancer patient and nursing student Chieze said, she has had mixed emotions. Having to tell her story and explain her disease at length can be difficult. Ã¢ÂÂAt the same time, being able to help someone along the way has been fantastic,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Chieze, whose prognosis is uncertain but whose cancer is currently in remission, hopes that the renewed attention in this campaign will support the ongoing demand for research and resources for metastatic breast cancer patients. About 22% of these patients live five years past their diagnoses, according to the American Cancer Society. Ã¢ÂÂI can only touch so many patients in a single day,Ã¢ÂÂ Chieze said, Ã¢ÂÂbut now IÃ¢ÂÂve been able to help people on a much larger scale.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Lemons teach about breast cancer

Content: (CNN) The risk of dying from cervical cancer might be much higher than experts previously thought, and women are encouraged to continue recommended cancer screenings. Black women are dying from cervical cancer at a rate 77% higher than previously thought, and white women are dying at a rate 47% higher, according to a study published in the journal Cancer on Monday.  READ: Erin Andrews reveals cervical cancer surgery, The study found that previous estimates of cervical cancer death rates didnÃ¢ÂÂt account for women who had their cervixes removed in hysterectomy procedures, which eliminates the risk of developing the cancer. Ã¢ÂÂPrior calculations did not account for hysterectomy because the same general method is used across all cancer statistics,Ã¢ÂÂ said Anne Rositch, assistant professor of epidemiology at Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health in Baltimore and lead author of the study. That method is to measure cancerÃ¢ÂÂs impact across a total population without accounting for factors outside of gender, she said. There were about 12, 990 new cases of cervical cancer in the United States last year and 4, 120 cervical cancer deaths, according to the National Cancer Institute. Ã¢ÂÂA better understanding of the magnitudeÃ¢ÂÂ For the study, researchers analyzed data on cervical cancer deaths in the United States, from 2000 to 2012, from the National Center for Health Statistics and the National Cancer InstituteÃ¢ÂÂs Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results databases.  The data were limited to only 12 states in the country, but the researchers noted that the data still provided a nationally representative sample of women. Then, the researchers collected data from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System on how many women in 2000 to 2012, 20 and older, reported ever having a hysterectomy. They used that data to adjust the cervical cancer deaths rates. Before the adjustment, the data showed that the cervical cancer killed about 5. 7 out of 100, 000 black women and 3. 2 per 100, 000 white women. After adjusting for hysterectomies, the rate was 10. 1 per 100, 000 black women and 4. 7 per 100, 000 white women. The data showed that the racial disparity seen in cervical cancer death rates for black and white women was underestimated by 44% when hysterectomies were not taken into account.  Ã¢ÂÂWe canÃ¢ÂÂt tell from our study what might be contributing to the differences in cervical cancer mortality by age and race,Ã¢ÂÂ Rositch said. Ã¢ÂÂNow that we have a better understanding of the magnitude of the problem, we have to understand the reasons underlying the problem.Ã¢ÂÂ Cervical cancer is highly preventable in the United States because of the availability of screening tests and a vaccine to prevent human papillomavirus, or HPV, which can cause cervical cancer, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Ã¢ÂÂRacial disparity may be explained by lack of access or limited access to cervical cancer screening programs among black women when compared to whites,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Marcela del Carmen, a gynecologic oncologist at the Massachusetts General Hospital Cancer Center, who was not involved in the new study. Ã¢ÂÂThis gap and disparity need to be addressed with initiatives focusing on better access to prevention or screening programs, better access to HPV vaccination programs and improved access and adherence to standard of care treatment for cervical cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. The new findings add to the current understanding of cervical cancerÃ¢ÂÂs impact on different communities, said Dr. John Farley, a practicing gynecologic oncologist and professor at Creighton University School of Medicine at St. JosephÃ¢ÂÂs Hospital and Medical Center in Arizona. Ã¢ÂÂIt lets us know that there is substantial work to do to investigate and alleviate the racial minority disparity in cervical cancer in the US,Ã¢ÂÂ said Farley, who was not involved in the study but   an editorial about the new findings in the journal Cancer on Monday. Ã¢ÂÂThose who get cancer, many times, do not have access to screening,Ã¢ÂÂ he said.  Even though cervical cancer mortality rates are higher than previously thought, Farley said that he thinks the current screening recommendations for cervical cancer are still adequate. However, he added, more women should have access to screenings and other preventive measures. Rositch said, Ã¢ÂÂIt may be that some women are not obtaining screening according to our current guidelines, not necessarily that   care is insufficient.Ã¢ÂÂ How to prevent and screen for cervical cancer, The American Cancer Society recommends that women begin cervical cancer screenings at age 21 by having a Pap test every three years. Then, beginning at 30, women should have a Pap test combined with a HPV test every five years. However, the recommendations are not universal among all expert groups. Symptoms of cervical cancer tend to not appear until the cancer has advanced, which is why screening and HPV vaccinations are urged.  Ã¢ÂÂWe have a vaccine which can eliminate cervical cancer, like polio, that is currently available, and only 40% of girls age 13 to 17 have been vaccinated,Ã¢ÂÂ said Farley,   of the editorial. Ã¢ÂÂThis is an epic failure of our health care system in taking care of women in general and minorities specifically.Ã¢ÂÂ Women over 65 might not need to continue screening if they donÃ¢ÂÂt have a history of cervical cancer or negative Pap test results, according to the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Each year, about 38, 793 new cases of cancer are found in parts of the body where HPV is often found. The virus has been linked not only to cervical cancer but to cancers of the vulva, vagina, penis, anus or throat.  A study published in the journal JAMA Oncology last week found that among a group of 1, 868 men in the United States, about 45% had genital HPV infections and only about 10% had been vaccinated. Ã¢ÂÂMale HPV vaccination may have a greater effect on HPV transmission and cancer prevention in men and women than previously estimated,Ã¢ÂÂ the researchers wrote in that study.
Title: Cervical cancer death rates are much higher than thought, study says

Content: (CNN) A new study published earlier this week in the journal Cancer reveals that mortality rates are far higher and racial disparities in mortality are far larger than was previously thought for cervical cancer,  a disease that can be screened for and for which there is a vaccine.  As an Osteopathic Family Physician who provides womenÃ¢ÂÂs health services to my patients as well as medical care for general medical conditions, these findings directly impact my patients and my profession. As a black woman, they affect me personally. As a family physician, this study was a hard pill to swallow, but as a black woman it is even harder.  Racial disparities in health exist not only with cervical cancer but other cancers and medical conditions as well. The National Cancer Institute states that   have the highest mortality rate Ã¢ÂÂof any racial or ethnic group for all cancers combined and for most major cancers.Ã¢ÂÂ Furthermore, for all cancers combined, Ã¢ÂÂthe death rates is 25% higher for    than for whites. Researchers who conducted the study found that a lack of consideration for hysterectomy rates in prior studies has resulted in an Ã¢ÂÂunderestimationÃ¢ÂÂ of mortality rates and racial disparities regarding cervical cancer. When researchers adjusted US cervical mortality rates and racial disparities for the presence of hysterectomy in the study population, the results were staggering. Perhaps one of the most dramatic findings by researchers is that without correction for hysterectomy, racial disparities for cancer mortality rates between black and white women have been underestimated by about 44%. Somewhat more hopefully, the study showed that black women had a significant yearly decrease in cervical cancer mortality overall when compared to white women after correction for hysterectomy.  The sobering news is, however, that upon adjusting for hysterectomy, researchers found that the mortality for black women increased from 5. 7 per 100, 000 (uncorrected) to 10. 1 per 100, 000 (corrected) and for white women, the mortality rate increased from 3. 2 per 100, 000 (uncorrected) to 4. 7 per 100, 000 (corrected). Both corrected and uncorrected   cervical cancer mortality rates were much higher for black women than white women across all age groups except   and      and black women over 85 were at greatest risk of death.  The issue of the hysterectomy is clearly a key piece of information. One reason why is the body mechanics involved in complete hysterectomy, which also removes the cervix. Another reason, cited by study researchers, is a matter of numbers. Black women have the highest prevalence of hysterectomy. Thus the presence, or lack of, a hysterectomy potentially impacts how to measure the incidence of cervical cancer by race.  I have long known that health disparities exist between and among social groups. This is not a new phenomenon and it is not unique to cervical cancer, but it still takes my breath away that racial disparities in health continue to be so robust.  So why do health disparities by race persist and what can we do to fix them? The answer to both questions: ItÃ¢ÂÂs complicated. Institutions including the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Institute of Medicine, the World Health Organization and so many others have been working on identifying and reducing racial disparities in health for years. In this study, researchers suggest as possible factors a lack of access to care, decreased   for abnormal results and disparities in cervical cancer treatments offered. I agree with the studyÃ¢ÂÂs authors. Access to quality care    something I think all Americans should have    is a crucial component to good health. This study underscores just how important this is.  The study also mentions that differences in cancer types may contribute to disparities in age and race: Ã¢ÂÂThe rates of adenocarcinoma in black women increase with age, whereas they plateau at the age of 35 in white women. . .. Compared with squamous histology, adenocarcinoma is associated with a worse prognosis and worse survival for both early  and   disease.Ã¢ÂÂ   The most critical reason access to affordable, quality care is so crucial is because it increases the likelihood of prevention. As a family physician, I also know how important preventive services such as mammograms, colonoscopies and pap smears (the most common screening test for cervical cancer) are. For cervical cancer, vaccines are also important. HPV (Human Papilloma Virus) vaccines    recommended since 2006    protect against strains of the HPV virus that cause most cervical cancers. Undoubtedly, the role of the HPV vaccine is important in preventing cervical cancer, and it is a vaccine that I routinely recommend and administer to my patients.  This study illustrates in stark terms the importance of accessible health care at a time when our current health care landscape is changing, as the Affordable Care Act enacted in 2010 will likely undergo change with the new administration. This may also mean a change for organizations that provide health services to women. As we work to improve mortality rates for all cancers and look for causes and solutions for racial disparities in health, these recent findings about cervical cancer should be part of the discussion.
Title: New cervical cancer research is personal

Content: (CNN) Even though the phrase Ã¢ÂÂimage recognition technologiesÃ¢ÂÂ conjures visions of   surveillance, these tools may soon be used in medicine more than in spycraft.  A team of Stanford researchers trained a computer to identify images of skin cancer moles and lesions as accurately as a dermatologist, according to a new paper published in the journal Nature.  In the future, this new research suggests, a simple cell phone app may help patients diagnose a skin cancer    the most common of all cancers in the United States    for themselves.   Ã¢ÂÂOur objective is to bring the expertise of   dermatologists to places where the dermatologist is not available,Ã¢ÂÂ said Sebastian Thrun, senior author of the new study, founder of research and development lab Google X and an adjunct professor at Stanford University. He added that those who live in developing countries do not have the same level of care as can be found in the US and other industrialized nations. Melanomas represent fewer than 5% of all skin malignancies diagnosed in the US, yet they account for nearly   of all deaths related to this form of cancer. If detected early, the   survival rate for melanoma is 99%. When detected in its latest stage, the survival rate plummets to just 14%. Generally, dermatologists identify whether a mole or other abnormality is cancerous by looking at it. They can confirm their diagnosis with   biopsies and tests. With a team of researchers, Thrun developed a deep learning computer system to perform the first task in detecting skin cancer: identifying it at a glance.  Essentially, the team created an automated dermatologist. How it works, Thrun and his colleagues began by coaching a computer to develop pattern recognition skills. The method they used is an   technique known as Ã¢ÂÂdeep learning.Ã¢ÂÂ   Specifically, the research team employed a convolutional neural network. Carl Vondrick, a Ph. D. candidate at MITÃ¢ÂÂs Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Lab, who was not involved in this study, explained the process. Ã¢ÂÂA convolutional neural net is a type of computer software that is very good at learning to recognize different concepts,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. By downloading digital images, researchers can Ã¢ÂÂtellÃ¢ÂÂ the computer they are images of skin cancer, or without skin cancer. The machine will basically try to learn some rules that can predict whether itÃ¢ÂÂs cancer. Ã¢ÂÂAn algorithm is just a fancy name for a sequence of steps that the computer takes. So in this case, the algorithm refers to the whole process that they did to train the system,Ã¢ÂÂ Vondrick said. Andre Esteva,   author of the new paper with Brett Kuprel, both electrical engineering Ph. D. students at Stanford, said he, Thrun and their colleagues began by Ã¢ÂÂbasically teaching the algorithm what the world looks like.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂWe taught it with cats and dogs and tables and chairs and all sorts of normal everyday objects look like,Ã¢ÂÂ Esteva said. Ã¢ÂÂWe used a massive data set of well over a million images.Ã¢ÂÂ This phase of learning took about a week. Then, Esteva trained the algorithm in different skin conditions. Here, the team addressed a complex problem: Cancerous and noncancerous skin aberrations vary greatly in appearance from patient to patient. To overcome this difficulty, the researchers presented the      or Ã¢ÂÂartificially intelligentÃ¢ÂÂ    computer with an extensive dataset of 129, 450 images representing more than 2, 000 skin diseases. The images came from 18   online repositories as well as the Stanford University Medical Center. Since each image of a mole or abrasion had been diagnosed, the computer was fed this information as well.  Differences between AI and human intelligence, Ã¢ÂÂWhatÃ¢ÂÂs really powerful about computer vision and these convolutional neural nets is, all you have to do is specify the input and output, and the machine will learn its own rules how to do that automatically,Ã¢ÂÂ Vondrick said. Ã¢ÂÂIt learns kind of a series of mathematical transformations to essentially transform an image into an answer (to the question) Ã¢ÂÂIs there skin cancer or not?Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ  ThereÃ¢ÂÂs an important distinction between computer visual systems and the human visual system, added Vondrick. Though humans can learn to recognize patterns from very little data, machines require thousands or even billions of examples. Ã¢ÂÂYou can grow up to be in your 20s and never have seen skin cancer, and you can go to medical school and just see a few examples on slides, and all of a sudden, youÃ¢ÂÂre going to be pretty good at recognizing that,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. No computer has been trained to do the same, but computer visual systems may detect subtleties within digital photographs unseen by the human eye, the researchers pointed out.  The moment of truth came when the researchers presented previously unseen images to their algorithm. Would their artificial intelligence system be able to recognize both the most common and the most deadly types of skin cancer: malignant carcinomas and melanomas, respectively?  Ã¢ÂÂThis algorithm performed as well as   dermatologists at several key diagnostic tasks,Ã¢ÂÂ Esteva said.  Notably, the computer was able to Ã¢ÂÂdiagnose multiple different kinds of skin cancer, not just melanoma, and we were able to do this with regular clinical images, rather than with specialized dermoscopic images,Ã¢ÂÂ said Roberto Novoa, a   of the study and a dermatologist at Stanford Medicine.  He explained that doctors commonly use a dermatoscope, a specialized tool, to examine the skin for cancer. This tool enables a view from a similar distance with similar lighting and magnification, for easier diagnosis.  Though the algorithm lacked access to this expensive tool, its performance still equaled the accuracy of 21 dermatologists. Though Thrun, Esteva and their colleagues warn that real testing in a clinical setting    a doctorÃ¢ÂÂs office    is still needed, they believe their research might be expanded to include other areas of medicine, such as ophthalmology, radiology and pathology.  With 6. 3 billion smartphone subscriptions estimated to be in use by 2021 (PDF) the researchers noted, their new system, in the form of an app, could provide   universal access to diagnostic care.   Paging Dr. McCoy, Science fiction is rife with visions of technology replacing human doctors. Dr. Leonard McCoy used a portable diagnostic device known as a tricorder to determine the medical condition of the USS Enterprise crew members in the Ã¢ÂÂStar TrekÃ¢ÂÂ TV series and movies, recalled Dr. Sancy A. Leachman, a dermatologist and chairwoman of the department of dermatology at Oregon Health and Science University, and Glenn Merlino, a senior investigator at the National Cancer Institute, in their published commentary on the new study. Though still Ã¢ÂÂfanciful,Ã¢ÂÂ machines capable of   diagnosis are Ã¢ÂÂbecoming a reality,Ã¢ÂÂ wrote Leachman and Merlino, neither of whom was involved in the new study.  That said, at least one issue still requires more investigation when it comes to a skin   automated system.  According to Leachman and Merlino, it is not known whether the artificial intelligence system featured in the new study can distinguish between   diseases. For example, a system would need to be able to identify melanoma versus benign seborrhoeic keratosis    basically, a   wart. Ã¢ÂÂEven the benign growths can be associated with certain syndromes and diseases that only a physician that has been clinically trained for detecting can diagnose,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Jill Waibel, a dermatologist and owner of the Miami Dermatology and Laser Institute.  Waibel, who did not participate in the study, added that Ã¢ÂÂmedical Imaging has dramatically transformed the practice of medicine,Ã¢ÂÂ especially her field of dermatology. Yet despite many exciting developments, all of the new imaging systems are still being studied and explored for optimal uses, she said.  For many scientists, though, Ã¢ÂÂStar TrekÃ¢ÂÂ still beckons: a future filled with machines that learn with each corrected mistake, improving their performance over time. Ã¢ÂÂThis is a very specific study, and it has a very encouraging result,Ã¢ÂÂ Thrun said. But he warned that before this research might be leveraged into anything resembling a tricorder, Ã¢ÂÂwe would have to run many more studies.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: AI system detects skin cancer with expert accuracy

Content: Hartford, Wisconsin (CNN) Tiffany Koehler was raised in foster care, is biracial, a veteran and a cancer survivor. She also is a former candidate for the Wisconsin state legislature. She ran as a Republican and once was  . Today she says she supports it    mostly.  Her biggest objection remains the mandate that individuals must obtain health insurance coverage. Ã¢ÂÂWe all want to thrive,Ã¢ÂÂ said Koehler, Ã¢ÂÂand make America great again, as (President Donald Trump) says, but we canÃ¢ÂÂt do that if weÃ¢ÂÂre struggling to pay bills.Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂPeople have to be able to get to their doctors. People have to be able to get their medicine,Ã¢ÂÂ said Koehler, Ã¢ÂÂand out of any country in the world we should be doing it.Ã¢ÂÂ  Two years ago, after losing her job, she did something she always had wanted to do she ran for a seat in the Wisconsin State Assembly. She lost, and in the aftermath of that disappointment, got some awful news    she had cancer. Koehler had been diagnosed with   lymphoma.   Ã¢ÂÂI was Stage 4. My prognosis was poor. I wasnÃ¢ÂÂt supposed to survive,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂ  implicationsÃ¢ÂÂ  When she lost her job she got health insurance through the Affordable Care Act marketplace. But she soon found that the $400 monthly bill was too high for someone who was unemployed.  So she dropped Obamacare and opted for Medicaid, under WisconsinÃ¢ÂÂs BadgerCare Plus program. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the only state in the US to adopt federal guidelines for Medicaid expansion but not accept federal money.   Koehler, recently was diagnosed with a thyroid condition possibly related to her cancer and still has three years of monitoring before she can be declared cancer free. In all her care and treatment so far has cost more than $1 million. She has a message for Congress and President Trump as they press ahead with repealing President ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs signature legislation. Ã¢ÂÂThey can be celebratory in WashingtonÃ¢ÂÂ but, she said, Ã¢ÂÂitÃ¢ÂÂs going to have   implications and they have to realize that.Ã¢ÂÂ Dick Woodruff, who lobbies Congress on behalf of the American Cancer SocietyÃ¢ÂÂs Cancer Action Network, said under the current Republican proposal  a   cancer survivor making around $50, 000 a year could expect to pay at least $1, 000 monthly for treatment    far above the $400 Koehler was paying in the Obamacare market.  They probably would qualify for a partial tax refund at the end of the year, but the    expense would likely be substantially more under the plan Congress is considering. Ã¢ÂÂThe lowest income individuals who currently receive premium subsidies,Ã¢ÂÂ said Woodruff, Ã¢ÂÂare going to be losers because theyÃ¢ÂÂre going to get fewer subsidies.Ã¢ÂÂ Many with cancer rely on Medicaid, He also said Medicaid recipients    the poorest and most vulnerable    will likely also suffer over time.   The Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act covered some 11 million Americans    but estimates by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities calculate the current Republican plan would cut $560 billion from the federal Medicaid program over the next decade.  Woodruff said today there are about 1. 5 million Americans with cancer relying on Medicaid, many of them children.   Under the current Republican proposal Ã¢ÂÂitÃ¢ÂÂs quite possible that as states begin to lose money . .. and begin to change the enrollment requirements or eligibility requirements, particularly for single adults, some of those people could be dropped.Ã¢ÂÂ Koehler was born to a mother with mental illness, cycled through 19 foster homes by the time she was an adult and served 14 years in the Wisconsin National Guard. For her, surviving cancer and losing a political race were bumps in the road.  She wants to write a book about her experiences to inspire others. Ã¢ÂÂMaybe down the road,Ã¢ÂÂ she said, Ã¢ÂÂwhen thereÃ¢ÂÂs an open seat I will run and win.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Cancer survivor has change of heart over Obamacare

Content: (CNN) Surrounded by the debris and dust of the fallen Twin Towers, Ray Pfeifer slept in his fire truck for a week after the terror attack on September 11, 2001.  He would spend the next eight months scouring through the rubble, Ã¢ÂÂsearching for friends,Ã¢ÂÂ he said.  But this weekend, he would pay the ultimate price for his heroism. After an   battle, Pfeifer died of terminal cancer, caused by the noxious cloud that hung over the disaster site.  A champion among heroes, For tens of thousands of people, PfeiferÃ¢ÂÂs legacy lives on through the Zadroga Bill, which secured medical care for   first responders, survivors, and recovery workers. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio honored Pfeifer with a key to New York City last year, Ã¢ÂÂfor his work to pass the Zadroga Bill,Ã¢ÂÂ the mayorÃ¢ÂÂs office said in a tweet. Today, de Blasio tweeted a message of condolence. Ã¢ÂÂWith the death of Ray Pfeifer, New York City has lost a hero and an inspiration. My prayers are with his family and all of the FDNY.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂWe got something done that I never would have thought would have gotten done,Ã¢ÂÂ Pfeifer said.  Ã¢ÂÂWe dealt with people who didnÃ¢ÂÂt really get it. We held it to (politicians) about never forgetting. We told them, Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre still dying from terrorists. WeÃ¢ÂÂre still sick from terrorists.Ã¢ÂÂ They started to get it,Ã¢ÂÂ Pfeifer said. Ã¢ÂÂI was just the poster boy . .. but everybody did something,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. In December 2015, Congress passed the Zadroga Act extension, which extends the health program coverage to 2090. More than 33, 000 first responders and survivors are living with illnesses or injuries related to the attack, according to a release by Congress following the extension. Ã¢ÂÂA true fighterÃ¢ÂÂ Pfeifer was diagnosed with stage 4 cancer that was linked to his work at ground zero. He spent his final days in hospice care, suffering from brain cancer, and cancer in his nodules, lungs and adrenal glands, according to CNN affiliate WPIX.  New York Sen. Chuck Schumer reacted to the news of PfeiferÃ¢ÂÂs parting on Twitter, Ã¢ÂÂJust learned that Ray Pfeifer has died. You meet very few truly great men in your life. Ray was one of them.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂRay Pfeifer was a true fighter who bravely battled fires as a New York City Firefighter and fought tirelessly for all first responders who    like him    suffered from World Trade   illness. The entire FDNY family deeply mourns his loss,Ã¢ÂÂ said Fire Commissioner Daniel A. Nigro in a statement on Twitter. Because of PfeiferÃ¢ÂÂs leadership, de Blasio said, survivors Ã¢ÂÂget to wake up in the morning and not have that horrible, pervasive worry about their future. They donÃ¢ÂÂt have to wonder whatÃ¢ÂÂs going to happen next to them and their families because they did the right thing when it was their moment to stand up.Ã¢ÂÂ Pfeifer leaves behind a wife, a daughter, and a son who chose to follow in his fatherÃ¢ÂÂs footsteps as a member of an FDNY EMS station.
Title: Hero firefighter dies from 9/11-related cancer

Content: (CNN) Fewer than half of ovarian cancer patients survive more than five years after their diagnosis. But new research indicates that preemptive surgery to remove a womanÃ¢ÂÂs ovaries and fallopian tubes might benefit more women than previously thought.  According to a recent study by Queen Mary University London scientists, for women age 40 or older with a lifetime risk level of 4% or greater, this operation, in combination with hormone replacement therapy, would provide 43 extra days of life expectancy on average. Though so few days may seem a very small gain to most people, Ã¢ÂÂthis is an average across the population,Ã¢ÂÂ explained Dr. Ranjit Manchanda, lead author of the study. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs pretty high in health statistics.Ã¢ÂÂ An individual woman might live considerably longer.  Ovarian cancer is the most lethal of reproductive cancers in women. According to Manchanda, 152, 000 deaths from ovarian cancer occur each year worldwide. Though it affects women of all ages, ovarian cancer is diagnosed most commonly after menopause. The strongest risk factors are older age and a family history.  Women at highest risk include those with a mother, sister or child affected by the disease and those who carry risk genes, including the BReast CAncer genes 1 and 2 (the BRCA genes).  Mutations in the BRCA  genes account for 15% of ovarian cancers overall, according to the National Cancer Institute. Actress Angelina Jolie put   surgery, known as   in the spotlight when she announced last year that sheÃ¢ÂÂd had the procedure to cut her cancer risk. Manchanda and his colleagues explored whether it might benefit women at different risk levels, since this operation is considered the best option for preventing disease among women at high risk of developing the disease. In fact, according to the Society of Gynecologic Oncologists (PDF) three studies demonstrated that carriers of BRCA mutations who undergo   surgery have a 71% to 96% reduction in the risk of subsequent ovarian cancer.  Though the surgery is generally safe and may be   it is not without complications. The ovaries contain a womanÃ¢ÂÂs reproductive eggs and secrete the hormones estrogen and progesterone. Younger women who undergo this surgery will be thrust into early menopause. The chances that a woman might develop heart disease increase after the procedure, and she might face osteoporosis as she ages, since estrogen helps build bones. Also, although the surgery may reduce anxiety, it often increases sexual dysfunction. Ã¢ÂÂOvarian conservation before menopause may be especially important in patients with a personal or strong family history of cardiovascular or neurological disease,Ã¢ÂÂ the Society of Gynecologic Oncologists said. Ã¢ÂÂConversely, women at high risk of ovarian cancer should undergo   bilateral  .Ã¢ÂÂ In the United Kingdom, the procedure is available only to women with at least a 10% lifetime risk of developing the disease. Yet this standard had never been tested for   Manchanda explained. So he and his colleagues used a mathematical model to compare preemptive surgery with no surgery for   women who were at least 40 years old but not yet menopausal.  They turned to national statistics of average life expectancies and years lived in good health for women with and without cancer. The researchers also looked at 2012 prices for surgeries, medication and other health care costs, and they calculated results for different levels of lifetime risk for ovarian cancer. Their analysis showed that preemptive surgery for women at a lifetime risk of 4% or greater would be   among those 40 or older.   The researchers admit their analysis is weak in that it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt include increased mortality data from other cancers. However, they believe their results are, overall, robust. In light of genome testing technologies and evolving genetic discoveries, Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ women might use surgery as a cancer risk management and prevention strategy, the evidence suggests. Ã¢ÂÂIt could open up possibilities for many women,Ã¢ÂÂ said Manchanda.
Title: Ovarian cancer prevention extends life

Content: Washington (CNN) Rep. Mark Takai of Hawaii has died after a battle with pancreatic cancer, his office announced Wednesday. He was 49. Ã¢ÂÂThe Takai family thanks the people of Hawaii for their support during this difficult time,Ã¢ÂÂ said an official statement issued by the congressmanÃ¢ÂÂs office, which noted Takai was surrounded by his family.  Takai, a Democrat, made his cancer publicly known last year after a tumor was found in his pancreas.  Ã¢ÂÂA few days ago, my doctors conducted diagnostic tests in response to certain stomach pains and discomfort that I have been experiencing for several weeks,Ã¢ÂÂ Takai said in a statement in October. Ã¢ÂÂThe tests show that I have a small tumor in the pancreas and I will shortly begin treatment.Ã¢ÂÂ Takai was elected to Congress in 2014 after spending 20 years as a state lawmaker. President Barack Obama issued a statement honoring Takai, calling him a Ã¢ÂÂfighterÃ¢ÂÂ who Ã¢ÂÂleaves a legacy of courage, of service, and of hope.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs the spirit he brought to more than two decades of public service on behalf of the people of Hawaii,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂHe stood up for AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs most vulnerable. He championed our troops and veterans, and proudly wore our nationÃ¢ÂÂs uniform. And his relentless push for cancer research inspired countless Americans fighting the same battle as him Simply put, our country is better off because of MarkÃ¢ÂÂs contributions.Ã¢ÂÂ Colleagues on Capitol Hill were quick to respond with condolences on Twitter.  House Speaker Paul Ryan tweeted: Ã¢ÂÂHe was an exemplary soldier, public servant and beloved member of the House of Representatives. His love for Hawaii and the people he represented was evident every day. My prayers are with his wife, Sami, and his children, Matthew and Kalia.Ã¢ÂÂ Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz tweeted: Ã¢ÂÂDeeply saddened to hear about my colleague Mark TakaiÃ¢ÂÂs passing from cancer. The Democratic familyÃ¢ÂÂs thoughts are with the Takais today.Ã¢ÂÂ Minnesota Rep. Keith Ellison tweeted: Ã¢ÂÂSaddened to hear about the death of @RepMarkTakai. A great public servant, and an even better father. IÃ¢ÂÂm thinking about his family.Ã¢ÂÂ California Rep. Loretta Sanchez tweeted: Ã¢ÂÂHeartbroken by the passing of my dear colleague @RepMarkTakai after his battle with pancreatic cancer. My deepest condolences to his family.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Congressman dies after cancer battle

Content: (CNN) The U. S. menÃ¢ÂÂs basketball team missed having NBA sideline reporter Craig Sager at the Olympics in Rio. So they sent him a special message during the broadcast at the start of the games. Ã¢ÂÂWe wish you were here, man. WeÃ¢ÂÂre gonna try to win this gold for you . .. you know youÃ¢ÂÂre a part of our family,Ã¢ÂÂ said star forward Kevin Durant.  Ã¢ÂÂKeep the faith, and we gonna do this for you,Ã¢ÂÂ added teammate Carmelo Anthony. The upbeat sportscaster has inspired players, coaches and fans with his Ã¢ÂÂnever give upÃ¢ÂÂ attitude during a grueling     year battle with cancer. Known for his lively interviews and colorful outfits at NBA games, the    Sager said he realized something was amiss at a game in April 2014. Ã¢ÂÂI ran into the doctor for the [Dallas Mavericks] and he looked at me and said, Ã¢ÂÂSager, whatÃ¢ÂÂs wrong?Ã¢ÂÂ I go, Ã¢ÂÂDoc, I donÃ¢ÂÂt know.Ã¢ÂÂ He says, Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂve got to go to the emergency room. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ When Sager arrived at the hospital his   cell count was so low he was near death. The veteran reporter for TBS and TNT (both networks, like CNN, are part of Turner Broadcasting) who had never missed a day of work in his life, was suddenly sidelined. The diagnosis was grim: acute myeloid leukemia. Ã¢ÂÂYour world just comes crumbling down. ItÃ¢ÂÂs devastating,Ã¢ÂÂ said his wife, Stacy Sager. Ã¢ÂÂWhat he needed to do was just be strong and know that he and I can fight this together.Ã¢ÂÂ A son steps up, Sager went through chemo and needed a bone marrow transplant. As it turned out, his son Craig was a perfect match.  Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a bond that you canÃ¢ÂÂt talk about or describe with a son,Ã¢ÂÂ Sager said. Ã¢ÂÂNow I was relying on him, and I needed him.Ã¢ÂÂ The transplant was successful, and Sager couldnÃ¢ÂÂt wait to return to the court. He received a standing ovation from fans at his first game back in March of 2015.  Ã¢ÂÂIt was just an incredible night,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂI thought that was it. IÃ¢ÂÂd beat cancer, and IÃ¢ÂÂd never have to worry about it again.Ã¢ÂÂ But the cancer came back. SagerÃ¢ÂÂs only option this time was a grueling clinical trial of 14 days of chemo at MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. When he needed a second bone marrow transplant, his son saved his life again. Ã¢ÂÂI didnÃ¢ÂÂt really even think of it as donating,Ã¢ÂÂ said his son, Craig Sager II. Ã¢ÂÂWe were in it together.Ã¢ÂÂ Sager recovered just in time for the start of the   NBA season. Ã¢ÂÂI went through the whole year, and I didnÃ¢ÂÂt miss a game. I felt great,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. A second relapse, Then in February, another relapse. Doctors told him that without treatment, he had three to six months to live.  But Sager has refused to let cancer win. #SagerStrong: Fans sport splashy duds to support TNTÃ¢ÂÂs Craig Sager, Ã¢ÂÂCraig and I had some serious conversations,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Naveen Pemmaraju, SagerÃ¢ÂÂs physician. Ã¢ÂÂThey essentially went like this: Ã¢ÂÂDoc, you gotta let me keep working.Ã¢ÂÂ I said, you better believe it.Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂThey wanted to try this outpatient chemo, and I said no problem. I was adamant. I didnÃ¢ÂÂt want to miss any games,Ã¢ÂÂ Sager said. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs where IÃ¢ÂÂm supposed to be, and I wanted to be there.Ã¢ÂÂ Through chemo and blood transfusions, he never stopped working. ESPN invited Sager to cover Game 6 of the NBA Finals in June    the first NBA Finals of his career.  Ã¢ÂÂIt was a tremendous night,Ã¢ÂÂ Sager said. Ã¢ÂÂI was just glad I was a part of it.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂStolen timeÃ¢ÂÂ Now Sager is back at the hospital enduring intense chemo to prepare for a rare third transplant, this time with an anonymous donor. But SagerÃ¢ÂÂs son is still supporting his dad any way he can. Ã¢ÂÂWe almost have stolen time. I mean IÃ¢ÂÂve been told heÃ¢ÂÂs had two weeks to live five times. And each time heÃ¢ÂÂs fought his way through it,Ã¢ÂÂ his son said. The elder Sager, who has five children, said he wants Ã¢ÂÂto embrace every day.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThereÃ¢ÂÂs no way to know how many months or how many weeks somebody has,Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Pemmaraju said. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve never seen anyone as positive as him.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe most important thing for us is just to live our normal life and [for him] to just continue to do what he loves,Ã¢ÂÂ said his wife Stacy.  Even though Sager couldnÃ¢ÂÂt travel to Rio for the Olympics, he left the hospital to support the U. S. menÃ¢ÂÂs basketball team at their final exhibition game in Houston. Ã¢ÂÂI was really surprised that Coach [Krzyzewski] asked me to address the team [in the locker room],Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂIt was a special moment.Ã¢ÂÂ Last month, Sager received the Ã¢ÂÂJimmy V Perseverance AwardÃ¢ÂÂ at the ESPYS, the ESPN awards show. He delivered an emotional speech, declaring he Ã¢ÂÂwill never give up.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂI will continue to keep fighting, sucking the marrow out of life as life sucks the marrow out of me,Ã¢ÂÂ Sager told the audience. Ã¢ÂÂI will live my life full of love and full of fun. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the only way I know how.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Craig SagerÃ¢ÂÂs battle with cancer

Content: (CNN) Most shoppers wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt buy a gallon of milk if they thought they could only drink a pintÃ¢ÂÂs worth. So why are hospitals and clinics buying larger amounts of cancer therapies than they can use, forcing them to throw these expensive drugs in the trash? The answer, according to a new study, is that many of the top cancer drugs in the United States are only available in   vials, and often that dose is more than the average patient needs. The result is an estimated $3 billion in overspending in the health care system each year, a cost that gets passed on to taxpayers and patients.  In one of the more egregious examples, the pharmaceutical company Merck sells a melanoma drug, pembrolizumab, called Keytruda, in vials that contain 100 milligrams of the drug. A   patient gets about 140 milligrams of Keytruda, meaning that more than half of the second vial would not be used. Although some of the leftover drug might go to another patient, the study determined that on average, 21% of the drug, costing about $200 million, goes to waste. The problem with Keytruda tipped researchers off to look at the amount of waste among the 20 most common drugs used to treat a range of cancers, including breast, prostate, skin and colorectal. Waste was rampant.  Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt think we thought weÃ¢ÂÂd find multiple drugs with   percentage of the vials wasted, and that is what we found,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Peter B. Bach, director of the Center for Health Policy and Outcomes at the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Bach is the lead author of the study, which was published on Tuesday in The BMJ journal.  There was a large spread among the top 20 cancer medicines in how much of a vial is typically thrown out, from 1% up to 37%. The amount of waste was typically lower for medicines that were available in several   vial options containing a range of doses. Sharing vials between patients also reduced waste, but this is generally only practical at hospitals treating large numbers of cancer patients, not at doctorÃ¢ÂÂs offices.  Bach and his colleagues estimate that the companies producing the top 20 cancer medicines, including Genentech, Takeda and Onyx Pharmaceuticals, will make nearly $2 billion this year just from wasted drops of these most common cancer drugs. And doctors and hospitals will make $1 billion in markup fees from these tossed treatments.  Although insurance companies pick up the tab, it ultimately affects the entire population by driving up taxes and insurance premiums.  Ã¢ÂÂThe fact that we have insurance doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean someone else is paying the bills    we are paying the bills,Ã¢ÂÂ Bach said. Waste might be especially bad in the United States compared with other countries. TakedaÃ¢ÂÂs myeloma drug, bortezomib, called Velcade, is only available in 3.  vials in the United States, but the average patient only needs 2. 5 milligrams. More appropriately sized   vials are available in the United Kingdom. In a statement, a Takeda spokeswoman said the company Ã¢ÂÂworked closely with the FDA to establish the Velcade vial size of 3. 5 mg to ensure that one vial would provide an adequate amount of the drug for a patient of almost any size.Ã¢ÂÂ The company does not have plans to introduce additional vial size options to the U. S. market, the email statement said. In another example, Merck stopped selling its   vials of Keytruda in the United States last year. These smaller vials had less potential for waste than the   vials that replaced them. But in Europe, where agencies can participate in drug pricing decisions, the   vial is still available. According to a statement from Merck, Ã¢ÂÂour understanding of dosing in multiple tumor types has improved.Ã¢ÂÂ The company is now conducting trials of   Keytruda vials, which it says would Ã¢ÂÂeliminate wastage.Ã¢ÂÂ  However according to Bach, this strategy would only mean that more wasted medicine is administered to patients instead of thrown away. Ã¢ÂÂTheir new plan is to change the dose so all patients get all of the drug,Ã¢ÂÂ but studies so far do not suggest the higher dose would carry any benefit for patients, Bach said.   Bach and his colleagues suggest two possible solutions for reigning in cancer drug waste: Require companies to provide drugs in vials that contain more appropriate doses or require companies to refund the expense of leftover drug.  Ã¢ÂÂI think either one is pretty doable,Ã¢ÂÂ Bach said. Ã¢ÂÂThe (Food and Drug Administration) could definitely issue a much more instructive guidance on vial size where they ask companies to take into account this exact issue, and they can do that without an act of Congress. . .. Companies know the market and their regulators and will generally respond to that.Ã¢ÂÂ The current study is Ã¢ÂÂexcellent,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Daniel A. Goldstein, an adjunct assistant professor of medical oncology at Emory University and senior physician at Rabin Medical Center in Israel.  Ã¢ÂÂAs the elections are coming upon us and thereÃ¢ÂÂs increased discussion about the possibility of legislation to try to impact the pricing mechanism of cancer drugs, this paper is telling us one piece of legislation is to ensure drug companies are forced to provide multiple different options of vial sizes,Ã¢ÂÂ Goldstein said.  Referring to the milk analogy, Goldstein said that drugs should give you the option to buy them in the pint and gallon equivalents. Wasted cancer drugs is only one small part of overspending in healthcare in the U. S. compared with contributors such as excessive use of diagnostic testing and    care, Goldstein said. At the same time, he added that, Ã¢ÂÂthose are very complicated to solve, but this is an extremely simple thing to solve.
Title: Why is $3 billion worth of cancer drugs being thrown away?

Content: (CNN) Donald TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs pick to be national security adviser, retired Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn, called Islamism a Ã¢ÂÂvicious cancer inside the body of 1. 7 billion peopleÃ¢ÂÂ that has to be Ã¢ÂÂexcisedÃ¢ÂÂ during an August speech.  Flynn, who has called Islam as a whole a Ã¢ÂÂcancerÃ¢ÂÂ in the past, made the comments during a speech to the Ahavath Torah Congregation in Stoughton, Massachusetts. Video of his speech is available on YouTube and was reviewed by CNNÃ¢ÂÂs KFile.  Ã¢ÂÂWe are facing another Ã¢ÂÂism,Ã¢ÂÂ just like we faced Nazism, and fascism, and imperialism and communism,Ã¢ÂÂ Flynn said. Ã¢ÂÂThis is Islamism, it is a vicious cancer inside the body of 1. 7 billion people on this planet and it has to be excised.Ã¢ÂÂ In the same speech, Flynn falsely claimed that Florida Democrats voted to impose Islamic shariah law at the state and local level. The claim, peddled by   blogs in 2014, was rated Ã¢ÂÂpants on fireÃ¢ÂÂ by the independent   organization PolitiFact, which explained that the bill in question was about prohibiting judges from using foreign law in family law cases if the law conflicted with existing U. S. policy. Democrats voted against the bill, saying it was unnecessary and targeted Muslims in the state.  Ã¢ÂÂLook up something called Ã¢ÂÂthe American laws for American courts,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Flynn said. Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt know if itÃ¢ÂÂs happening up here in Massachusetts, itÃ¢ÂÂs happening in other states. I have had people in the media, mainstream media, say, Ã¢ÂÂoh, thatÃ¢ÂÂs all a conspiracy, itÃ¢ÂÂs a lie. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂNo, in the state of Florida,Ã¢ÂÂ he continued. Ã¢ÂÂThe state of Florida they have 36 senators at the state level. 36 senators at the state level. 12, of them are Democrats, the Republicans hold the majority in the Florida state senate. All 12 Democrats, all 12 Democrats voted to impose shariah at the local and state level. Now, it was beaten because the Republicans are in charge. IÃ¢ÂÂm telling you, this is Ã¢ÂÂAmerican laws for AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs courts. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Flynn didnÃ¢ÂÂt respond to a comment request for this story. CNNÃ¢ÂÂs KFile reported last week Flynn shared fake news and interacted with figures of the     on Twitter. On Monday, CNNÃ¢ÂÂs KFile reported Flynn said Ã¢ÂÂwho knowsÃ¢ÂÂ when asked about a conspiracy about the 2013 sarin gas attack in Syria being a Ã¢ÂÂfalse flag.Ã¢ÂÂ In the speech, Flynn fielded a question asking if President Obama was a Muslim.  Ã¢ÂÂOkay let me repeat the question,Ã¢ÂÂ Flynn said. Ã¢ÂÂIs Obama doing this intentionally or is he incompetent and is he a Muslim?  This is where I say weÃ¢ÂÂre to blame. We. We. You, me, are to blame. All you have to do, and most people donÃ¢ÂÂt do these things, I do because itÃ¢ÂÂs part of who I am, all you got to do is read what heÃ¢ÂÂs written and listen to what he says. ItÃ¢ÂÂs that simple.Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂWell before he became president of the United States the first time, he said what he was going to do,Ã¢ÂÂ Flynn added. Ã¢ÂÂHe said it. The second time    fool me once, shame on me. Fool me twice, shame on you. I mean what happened? The second time he comes in    honestly, the first time I was kind of hopeful. Maybe weÃ¢ÂÂre enlightened. This country, this is going to be a good guy. He says all these things. IÃ¢ÂÂm listening to what heÃ¢ÂÂs saying. IÃ¢ÂÂm like, Ã¢ÂÂwow. This is different. This is different.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThis is an individual who has an ideologyand he has apologized for all the ill will of the United States of America over our history, for who we have been. He has. The apology tour. His speech in Cairo was unbelievable. IÃ¢ÂÂm sitting there and IÃ¢ÂÂm listening to it because I was deployed at that time and we were watching what our presidentÃ¢ÂÂs saying because itÃ¢ÂÂs going to cause some impact, and boy did it cause some impact. It caused the Muslim world to blow up.Ã¢ÂÂ Watch the full speech:
Title: Michael Flynn in August: Islamism a Ã¢ÂÂvicious cancerÃ¢ÂÂ in body of all Muslims that Ã¢ÂÂhas to be excisedÃ¢ÂÂ

Content: (CNN) After more patient deaths, Juno Therapeutics announced Wednesday that it is voluntarily putting its Ã¢ÂÂROCKETÃ¢ÂÂ trial on hold for the second time this year. The patients enrolled in this Phase II trial are adults with relapsed or refractory B cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, according to the biopharmaceutical companyÃ¢ÂÂs website. Ã¢ÂÂWe took this action after two additional patients in this trial experienced cerebral edema earlier this week,Ã¢ÂÂ Juno CEO Hans Bishop said on a conference call this morning. One patient died Tuesday, and another died earlier Wednesday. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is a type of blood cancer that can spread quickly through the body and, if left untreated, can be fatal within months. Cerebral edema is brain swelling caused by excess fluid inside the skull. In July, the trial was put on a clinical hold at the direction of the Food and Drug Administration. At that time, the company revealed three patient deaths, also the result of cerebral edema. According to Bishop, investigators pinpointed the likely culprit as the addition of fludarabine to the   regimen. Fludarabine is a chemotherapy drug used here as a   primer for treatment, used in an effort to increase the effectiveness of the experimental therapy. In this particular course of treatment,   consists of a heavy dose of chemotherapy to kill off existing cancer cells in order to give the new     room to grow. ItÃ¢ÂÂs like hitting a reset button to restart the immune system. But an unforeseen interaction between fludarabine and genetically modified JCAR015 cells proved to be lethal. After petitioning the FDA, Juno was permitted to continue the trial without the use of fludarabine. In August, the trial resumed, and 12 patients have been treated since, said Juno Chief Medical Officer Mark Gilbert on Wednesday. This includes the two patients who died this week after being treated last week. The FDA monitors all US drug trials and says fatal adverse events are Ã¢ÂÂextremely rare.Ã¢ÂÂ Immunotherapy has been heralded as the new frontier in the war on cancer. It works by harnessing the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs immune system to fight cancer from within. But many of these   treatments are still in the experimentation phase.  A Phase II clinical trial is designed to test the effectiveness of a new drug or treatment. It typically follows a Phase I trial, which evaluates safety and side effects. Before a new drug or treatment goes to market, it must also pass through a Phase III trial, as outlined by the National Institutes of Health. Ã¢ÂÂGoing forward, all options remain on the table for JCAR015,Ã¢ÂÂ Bishop said Wednesday. Ã¢ÂÂThe options include, among others: moving forward with JCAR015 in the current study under a modified protocol, beginning a new study or terminating the program.Ã¢ÂÂ JunoÃ¢ÂÂs other ongoing trials, including JCAR017 cells, are not affected, according to the company. Ã¢ÂÂAny decision on how to move forward will of course need to be made, taking into account feedback from the FDA and our (Data and Safety Monitoring Board) as well as the treating physicians in the trial,Ã¢ÂÂ Bishop said. He added that the patients in this trial often have no other options. Bishop said the company plans to provide a more thorough update in the next few weeks.
Title: Cancer trial stopped again after 2 more deaths

Content: Tarkio, Montana (CNN) In kayaking, a Ã¢ÂÂfirst descentÃ¢ÂÂ is when someone successfully paddles a section of river that no one has ever paddled before.   By the time Brad Ludden was 18 years old, he had attained close to 100 of them. Ã¢ÂÂEvery time you come around a corner, youÃ¢ÂÂre the first person to see it from that perspective,Ã¢ÂÂ said Ludden, now 35. Ã¢ÂÂYou feel a lot of personal transformation and growth through that process.Ã¢ÂÂ Today, Ludden is giving that   experience to young adults with cancer Ã¢ÂÂ  helping them face down their fears and realize theyÃ¢ÂÂre not alone. Ã¢ÂÂWhen youÃ¢ÂÂre a young person with cancer, itÃ¢ÂÂs so isolating,Ã¢ÂÂ said Ludden, who watched his own aunt battle cancer when she was 38. Ã¢ÂÂAll your friends are getting married, having children, starting jobs and living life. Here you are fighting for yours.Ã¢ÂÂ  Every year, more than 70, 000 young adults in the U. S. are diagnosed with the disease. LuddenÃ¢ÂÂs nonprofit Ã¢ÂÂ  First Descents Ã¢ÂÂ  offers free outdoor adventures based around kayaking, surfing and rock climbing.  The weeklong camps are held at picturesque locations, where 15 young adult cancer fighters and survivors from across the country come together to challenge themselves physically and bond with others whoÃ¢ÂÂve gone through the same battle.  Ã¢ÂÂWhile thousands of people have kayaked these sections of river before them, itÃ¢ÂÂs their first time down,Ã¢ÂÂ Ludden said. Ã¢ÂÂYou see it at the bottom of the rapids in the look of accomplishment and pride on their faces.Ã¢ÂÂ Since 2001, Ludden and his group have brought these transformative experiences to more than 3, 000 people.  Ã¢ÂÂI have learned more from First DescentsÃ¢ÂÂ participants than anything else in my entire life,Ã¢ÂÂ Ludden said. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve learned how to be much more vulnerable, the importance of laughter and to not just accept each day as it comes but to go out and define it.Ã¢ÂÂ CNNÃ¢ÂÂs Meghan Dunn spoke with Ludden about his work. Below is an edited version of their conversation. CNN: During the week, you see a transformation in the participants. WhatÃ¢ÂÂs that like?  Ludden: Day one, they get all their gear and they learn the very basics of whatever it is theyÃ¢ÂÂre there to do. And then each day, we ratchet that up a little bit and build on the previous day so that by the end of the week, theyÃ¢ÂÂre applying everything theyÃ¢ÂÂve learned to one final challenging day. And that could be a   ascent, or a bigger break, or harder whitewater.  ItÃ¢ÂÂs fascinating to watch not only the physical transformation, but also the social and emotional transformation. The way they bond together and the confidence that theyÃ¢ÂÂre building Ã¢ÂÂ  itÃ¢ÂÂs a really beautiful transformation to witness in a relatively short amount of time. CNN: Each participant gets a nickname. Why? Ludden: (It) is a huge part of our culture. This experience can be a real stake in the sand in their recovery or their life  . It can be one of their greatest victories and a really defining experience. This name becomes associated with that experience.  ItÃ¢ÂÂs the name of them as a kayaker, or a climber, or a surfer. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not the name of them as someone with cancer. And so itÃ¢ÂÂs an opportunity for a fresh start. WeÃ¢ÂÂve found a lot of people take a lot of pride in their name. CNN: First Descents goes beyond a weeklong program. How do participants continue their journey? Ludden: The weeklong trip hopefully is the beginning of their First Descents experience. When they go home from that, weÃ¢ÂÂve created local adventure communities around the country that they can engage in, go on more localized adventures.  We host (additional)   to   programs. Those are much more   and are all over the world Ã¢ÂÂ  everywhere from Africa to Indonesia and Alaska to Patagonia.  We believe that this shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be a    experience. As part of that, we truly see healing in the act of helping someone else. And we believe that we all as a community who are experiencing these programs have the same obligation to help other people have the same experience. So we try to create this    aspect. We create fundraising challenges around the country that everyoneÃ¢ÂÂs invited to be a part of, all with the goal of providing that   experience to someone who hasnÃ¢ÂÂt had it, but wants it. CNN: What do you hope participants gain from each week?  Ludden: I hope that they come here seeking some answers, perhaps seeking some personal growth and maybe some victory over their cancer. We infuse a lot of challenge and adventure, beautiful settings, laughter, great people and good food. But I think at the end, all that bundled together just represents a very large transformation in everyoneÃ¢ÂÂs life.   ItÃ¢ÂÂs that important reminder that this life, itÃ¢ÂÂs really fleeting. The end is going to come sooner than we want. With that knowledge, we have this obligation to go out and live as fully as possible. Want to get involved? Check out the First Descents website and see how to help. You can make a donation right now to First Descents. Just click the CrowdRise widget below!
Title: Outdoor adventure empowers young cancer patients

Content: (CNN) On Friday, when the hospital chaplain asked Raul Hinojosa for his final wish, the   patient just said, Ã¢ÂÂI want to marry her.Ã¢ÂÂ His longtime fiancee, Yvonne Lamas, told CNN, Ã¢ÂÂI looked around the room, and said Ã¢ÂÂWho?Ã¢ÂÂ That was just the way we played.Ã¢ÂÂ  LetÃ¢ÂÂs do it, the chaplain said, and she left to get people to help make a dying wish into reality. Family and hospital staff hurried to put a wedding together. One of the hospitalÃ¢ÂÂs chaplains took Lamas to the courthouse to acquire a marriage license. When they arrived, the judge waived the typical   waiting period, Lamas said.  The director of the critical care unit    who never wears a coat and tie to work, but had that morning after going to see his daughterÃ¢ÂÂs Christmas program at school    shed his suit and gave it to Raul to wear for the ceremony, she said.  Cooks in the hospitalÃ¢ÂÂs cafeteria baked a wedding cake, and relatives ran out to get a dress for Lamas.  Ã¢ÂÂIt was a perfect fit,Ã¢ÂÂ said Angie Paiz, RaulÃ¢ÂÂs aunt.  After Hinojosa was admitted to a critical care unit in Amarillo, Texas, in late October, Lamas had spent every day at his side, balancing his needs with the needs of their children at home. Hinojosa and Lamas had been together for 11 years. Ã¢ÂÂHe was very respectful, very romantic and always wanted to give me the world,Ã¢ÂÂ Lamas said. Ã¢ÂÂHe knew how to put a smile on my face no matter the situation.Ã¢ÂÂ  They have a son who is 9, and Lamas has three daughters from a previous marriage, but Hinojosa took them in as if they were his own.  Ã¢ÂÂAs a father figure he was very loving, very caring to my kids,Ã¢ÂÂ Lamas said. Ã¢ÂÂHe gave them the world and was there for them when times were tough.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂHe was a good person. He was a giving person,Ã¢ÂÂ Paiz told CNN. He worked hard to provide for his family, picking up odd jobs even after he got sick because he couldnÃ¢ÂÂt keep a steady one.  Hinojosa proposed in 2007, but he and Lamas had been waiting to marry. Ã¢ÂÂHe was determined to give me the best fairytale wedding,Ã¢ÂÂ Lamas said. Ã¢ÂÂHe tried saving up, but within that time he ended up getting diagnosed with the leukemia.Ã¢ÂÂ  Hospital bills stacked up, and it started to look as if their dreams would never be realized. But within a couple of hours, thanks to the collective effort of family and the hospital staff, the wedding was ready.  Nursing staff lined up outside the hospital room, and Lamas was escorted down the makeshift aisle by her father.  Ã¢ÂÂWhen I walked down the aisle and saw him in the suit, he just took my breath away,Ã¢ÂÂ Lamas said. Ã¢ÂÂHe was so handsome. It was priceless.Ã¢ÂÂ Her father delicately placed LamasÃ¢ÂÂ hand in HinojosaÃ¢ÂÂs, and the chaplain choked back tears as she recounted their story. Ã¢ÂÂWhen this illness was diagnosed,Ã¢ÂÂ she said, Ã¢ÂÂYvonne promised she would never leave him. She would be with him. They would do this together.Ã¢ÂÂ  With his    on his left and his son on his right, Hinojosa recited his vows.  With their children, family and friends gathered around them, Hinojosa and Lamas were finally married.  Hinojosa, 33, died of leukemia on Saturday, just 36 hours later.  When she signed her husbandÃ¢ÂÂs death certificate, it was the first time Lamas had signed her married name.
Title: Man weds fiancee hours before succumbing to cancer

Content: Two thin tubes that connect the ovaries to the uterus have assumed an outsize role in the battle against ovarian cancer.  Research increasingly points to the likelihood that some of the most aggressive ovarian cancers originate in the fallopian tubes. Most doctors now believe there is little to lose by removing the tubes of women who are done bearing children    and potentially much to gain in terms of cancer prevention. The stakes in this research are high. Ovarian cancer is the deadliest of gynecologic cancers, killing 14, 000 women a year in the United States. It is often diagnosed in the late stages, when it is more difficult to treat.  Routine screening tests to identify it early largely have been discredited. Earlier this fall, the U. S. Food and Drug Administration released a statement recommending against their use. For that reason, prevention is particularly important. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a really interesting topic and itÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Noelle Cloven, a gynecologic oncologist with Texas Oncology in Fort Worth. Ã¢ÂÂAny opportunity to decrease the risk of ovarian cancer or improve our understanding of ovarian cancer, IÃ¢ÂÂm in support of that. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a terrible disease.Ã¢ÂÂ  The risks associated with the removal of the fallopian tubes    known as salpingectomy    appear to be minimal, according to a study by Kaiser Permanente Northern California, which was published this summer in the journal Obstetrics  Gynecology. (Kaiser Health News is not affiliated with Kaiser Permanente.) Between June 2013 and May 2014, nearly 73 percent of the women in the study had their fallopian tubes removed while undergoing a routine hysterectomy. Just two years earlier, fewer than 15 percent of a comparable group had. The large increase yielded no difference in surgical outcomes.
