And operating times and blood loss were slightly improved for patients whose fallopian tubes were removed.  Dr. Bethan Powell, senior author of the study and a gynecologic oncology surgeon with Kaiser Permanente, said the fallopian tubes until recently have been Ã¢ÂÂa neglected region.Ã¢ÂÂ As a result, when women were undergoing hysterectomy    the removal of the uterus and cervix    the tubes were often left behind. Ã¢ÂÂNobody thought it made any difference which side you put your clamp on,Ã¢ÂÂ Powell said. Ã¢ÂÂIf there are health benefits to leaving the ovary, we should leave the ovary. But thereÃ¢ÂÂs no reason we should leave the tube.Ã¢ÂÂ In recent years, two medical societies have issued statements about the importance of removing the fallopian tubes. In 2013, the Society of Gynecologic Oncology developed a clinical practice statement recommending the removal of both fallopian tubes as Ã¢ÂÂa viable approach to prevent ovarian cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ   In 2015, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommended that surgeons discuss the potential cancer prevention benefits of the procedure with their patients.  While itÃ¢ÂÂs now recommended that patients have their tubes removed during a routine hysterectomy, doctors are still wrestling with more complicated scenarios. Jennifer Klute, 35, a   pathologist in Napa, Calif. was diagnosed breast cancer in 2015. SheÃ¢ÂÂd first noticed a lump while breastfeeding her daughter, Genevieve, and doctors initially reassured her that the lump was probably related to that.  Then the lumps multiplied. Biopsies were ordered. Klute received the dreaded phone call, and cut short a family vacation to Nebraska. Klute had a family history of breast cancer and a genetic test revealed a BRCA1 mutation. Women who are positive for the BRCA1 mutation have a 39 percent likelihood of developing ovarian cancer, in addition to a 55 to 65 percent likelihood of developing breast cancer. Klute faced a difficult decision. ItÃ¢ÂÂs recommended that women with the mutation have their fallopian tubes and ovaries removed between the ages of 35 and 40, as actress Angelina Jolie did in 2015.  Jolie earlier had a preventive double mastectomy. Removal of the ovaries has significant cancer prevention benefits    both for ovarian and breast cancer. But it also carries real consequences, particularly for younger women like Klute. The ovaries regulate hormones and their removal plunges women into early menopause and increases their risk of osteoporosis, cardiovascular disease and dementia. Klute had chemotherapy, radiation and a double mastectomy. Once she recovered, her doctor recommended she have her fallopian tubes and ovaries removed. Klute requested a second opinion and ended up meeting with Powell. Klute told Powell that while she had a family history of breast cancer, she didnÃ¢ÂÂt have one of ovarian cancer.  Klute wondered whether she might delay the removal of her ovaries for a few more years. She didnÃ¢ÂÂt plan to have more children, but she knew keeping her ovaries a little longer could reduce her risk of other health problems. Powell knew that leaving the ovaries in   women is Ã¢ÂÂnot recommended and not standardÃ¢ÂÂ at this point. But she was willing to discuss the idea with Klute, who eventually opted to keep her ovaries for a little longer. She knows theyÃ¢ÂÂll eventually need to go. Not all doctors feel comfortable offering such a choice to their   patients. Dr. Jill Whyte, a gynecologic oncologist at Northwell Health on Long Island, is waiting for more data before sheÃ¢ÂÂs willing to recommend it. Cloven, the gynecologic oncologist  in Texas, also said she would be nervous taking that approach unless the patient was Ã¢ÂÂreally motivatedÃ¢ÂÂ and understood the risks of delays. Even then, Cloven said she would prefer that a patient choose that option only if participating in a clinical trial.  Nevertheless, Lisa Schlager, vice president of community affairs and public policy for Facing Our Risk of Cancer Empowered, a   advocacy group devoted to hereditary ovarian and breast cancers, said she thinks more doctors are recommending the approach as an interim step for   women in their 30s.  Ã¢ÂÂIf you want to have children and donÃ¢ÂÂt want to be plunged into surgical menopause, the options are: do nothing, do imperfect screening, or Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂThat   is salpingectomy.Ã¢ÂÂ In KluteÃ¢ÂÂs case, she said the salpingectomy itself was easy: Powell made a small laparoscopic incision to remove the tubes. Klute had a little nausea after she woke and couldnÃ¢ÂÂt lift Genevieve for a few weeks. But the pain was manageable.  SheÃ¢ÂÂs now enrolled in two clinical studies and has submitted her information to the National Salpingectomy Registry. Ã¢ÂÂI think thatÃ¢ÂÂs super important,Ã¢ÂÂ Klute said. Ã¢ÂÂThe more knowledge we have, the more informed decisions we can make    and the greater the outcomes for individuals with cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Fallopian tubes may have big role in ovarian cancer fight

Content: (CNN) Josh Katrick had just walked out of his eighth round of chemotherapy, when good fortune struck.  He had just won a competition: free pizza for a year from a neighborhood restaurant in Pennsylvania.  But instead of seizing the opportunity to spend the better part of 2017 gorging on the   melted mozzarella wellspring, Katrick, who has colon cancer, decided other people needed it more.  So he gave every slice away.  The local Northampton food bank is the recipient of his generosity.  Ã¢ÂÂYou know the saying, Ã¢ÂÂWhen life gives you lemons make lemonade,Ã¢ÂÂ well, when life gives you pizza, give away a slice,Ã¢ÂÂ the    told CNN Sunday.   Katrick has been feasting on MarioÃ¢ÂÂs Pizza in Northampton since he was a child, and was one of 1, 200 people to enter the competition.  The winner would walk away with 2 large (and they mean large) pizzas and soda, every month for the next year.  But after KatrickÃ¢ÂÂs act of holiday kindness, the pizza restaurant about 65 miles north of Philadelphia decided to extend its own.  The restaurant is doubling the prize to make sure Katrick gets his share of pizza, along with the food bank.  Ã¢ÂÂI thought someone would win, theyÃ¢ÂÂd be excited, come in and get their pizzas, but a story like this to come out of a contest like that. ..Ã¢ÂÂ Giuseppe Aiello, the son of the   pizzeriaÃ¢ÂÂs   told CNN affiliate WFMZ.  Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs better to give than receive, and especially during this time of year    Christmas,Ã¢ÂÂ Aiello said.  Katrick said he was inspired to pay it forward because of the generosity he had received from others during his cancer treatment. Ã¢ÂÂAfter everything I went through these last few months    I met so many people and have been receiving so much    I felt I wanted to give back.Ã¢ÂÂ Katrick said. Ã¢ÂÂThe food bank are very thankful. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre amazed by it. They will put it to good useÃ¢ÂÂ Katrick said he had surgery for stage 2 colon cancer in August and has been receiving chemotherapy since September.  Ã¢ÂÂMy family and friends are amazed    so many positive reactions. Around Christmas it really brought everybodyÃ¢ÂÂs spirits up and made people know there are good people in the world fighting the good fight.Ã¢ÂÂ JoshÃ¢ÂÂs father, Ron Katrick, told CNN he is Ã¢ÂÂvery proudÃ¢ÂÂ of his son. And his generosity doesnÃ¢ÂÂt end there.  Josh, still reluctant to indulge in all the pizza coming his way, told CNN, Ã¢ÂÂMaybe IÃ¢ÂÂll share with my friends on Facebook [and] make a contest of my own to see if anyone would like some pizza.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Cancer patient wins a year of free pizza, gives it to food bank

Content: (CNN) Ever marvel at someone who smoked and still lived to be 90? Just plain good luck, researchers say. And those who live like Puritans and get cancer anyway?  ThatÃ¢ÂÂs bad luck    and itÃ¢ÂÂs the primary cause of most cancer cases, says a Johns Hopkins Medicine research study. Roughly   of cancers in adults can be attributed to random mutations in genes capable of driving cancer growth, said two scientists who ran statistics on cancer cases. That may sound  . And Johns Hopkins anticipates that the study will change the way people think about cancer risk factors.  They also believe it could lead to changes in the funding of cancer studies, with a greater focus on finding ways to detect those cancers attributed to random mutations in genes at early, curable stages. Smoking can still kill you, But, no, thatÃ¢ÂÂs not permission to smoke or to not use sunblock.  Some forms of cancer are exceptions, where lifestyle and environment play a big role. Lung cancer is one of them. So is skin cancer. And, if cancer runs in your family, this unfortunately doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean youÃ¢ÂÂre in the clear. Some cancers are more strongly influenced by genetic heritage than others. Ã¢ÂÂThe remaining third (of cancer cases) are due to environmental factors and inherited genes,Ã¢ÂÂ the Kimmel Cancer Center said in a statement on the study published Friday in the magazine Science. In fact, all three factors work together. Ã¢ÂÂAll cancers are caused by a combination of bad luck, the environment and heredity, and weÃ¢ÂÂve created a model that may help quantify how much of these three factors contribute to cancer development,Ã¢ÂÂ said cancer researcher Bert Vogelstein. Compounding matters, An unhealthy lifestyle can compound matters, but more for some cancers than for others, the scientists said. Ã¢ÂÂChanging our lifestyle and habits will be a huge help in preventing certain cancers, but this may not be as effective for a variety of others,Ã¢ÂÂ medical statistician Cristian Tomasetti said. He placed heavy emphasis on early detection. Stem cells in our organs divide constantly to replenish damaged tissue. Sometimes there are random mistakes in the replication of DNA, small mutations, Vogelstein said.  Some genes, when they mutate, are more apt to promote cancer growth.  Ã¢ÂÂThe more these mutations accumulate, the higher the risk that cells will grow unchecked, a hallmark of cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ Vogelstein said. Scientist have known this for a long time, but what the study reveals was how big of an influence it is. Ã¢ÂÂThe actual contribution of these random mistakes to cancer incidence, in comparison to the contribution of hereditary or environmental factors, was not previously known,Ã¢ÂÂ says Vogelstein. Dr. Otis Brawley, chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society, told CNN the study was Ã¢ÂÂgood scienceÃ¢ÂÂ that backed up what many scientists already thought.  Ã¢ÂÂThis is actually just confirmation of something that we have known for probably 20 years,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂAs we have learned more and more about cancer . .. weÃ¢ÂÂve come to realize that a number of cancers start purely because of mutations that happen that are just unexplainable. Bad luck is, unfortunately, the right way to explain it.Ã¢ÂÂ Those cancers that develop have escaped at least three   systems in the body that deal with these cell mutations, he said these are programmed cell death, or apoptosis, DNA repair enzymes and certain cells in the immune system. Cell division and statistics, For their study, the two scientists came up with an average total number of cell divisions in 31 different tissues within a human lifetime. And they looked at the cancer risk in each of those tissues. They determined that the more a tissueÃ¢ÂÂs cells divide, the higher the chance cancer could develop in that tissue. Ã¢ÂÂOur study shows, in general, that a change in the number of stem cell divisions in a tissue type is highly correlated with a change in the incidence of cancer in that same tissue,Ã¢ÂÂ says Vogelstein. Colon tissue, for example, divides much more than other intestinal tissue, and cancer in the colon is much more prevalent there, the study said.  With colon tissue, the scientists took environmental influences into account. Doing the math overall, the two scientists arrived at a rate at which cancer risk can be explained by the cell divisions. It was 65% they said. Lifestyle, But the researchers drew a line between one group of cancers and another. Of the 31 they looked at, they determined that 22 were basically Ã¢ÂÂbad luckÃ¢ÂÂ cancers. But nine others appeared at rates noticeably higher than could be expected from cell division alone    which the researchers said is probably due to habits, pollution or genetics. No surprise: Lung cancer and skin cancer were two of them, they said. Smoking and too much sun exposure are still strongly linked to those cancers. Brawley said the studyÃ¢ÂÂs findings should be no reason to alter behaviors shown to lessen the risk of cancer. Ã¢ÂÂWe have good epidemiological data to show that people can reduce their risk of cancer and I would encourage them to do those things,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. They include not smoking, managing their weight so they donÃ¢ÂÂt become obese and taking physical exercise, he said. As for the suggestion the studyÃ¢ÂÂs findings may prompt changes in funding, Brawley said he would be pleased just to see more money go into research. Ã¢ÂÂOnly 10% of the grants submitted to the NIH (National Institutes of Health) actually get funded because we have such a shortage of money,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂWe invested in the United States last year $5 billion in cancer research. I would like to see more.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Cancer: Ã¢ÂÂBad luckÃ¢ÂÂ seen as primary cause in study

Content: (CNN) It is an unmistakable voice, that of Oliver Sacks, neurologist. Ã¢ÂÂPrecise, probing, and epigrammaticÃ¢ÂÂ is how Wired writer Steve Silberman once described it. And soon, the world learned Thursday, it  may be silenced. In a New York Times essay that received instant acclaim for its poignancy, beauty and determination, the renowned scientist and doctor revealed that he has incurable cancer. Ã¢ÂÂOver the last few days, I have been able to see my life as from a great altitude, as a sort of landscape, and with a deepening sense of the connection of all its parts, Ã¢ÂÂ he wrote in the Times. Ã¢ÂÂThis does not mean I am finished with life.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂOn the contrary, I feel intensely alive, and I want and hope in the time that remains to deepen my friendships, to say farewell to those I love, to write more, to travel if I have the strength, to achieve new levels of understanding and insight,Ã¢ÂÂ wrote Sacks, 81. Ã¢ÂÂOliver Sacks has cancer. Damn. He writes about it as beautifully as you would expect,Ã¢ÂÂ Twitter user Ian Leslie wrote. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not SacksÃ¢ÂÂ first bout with the disease. Nearly a decade ago, he was diagnosed with  ocular melanoma that eventually left him blind in one eye and served as the basis for one of his books, Ã¢ÂÂThe MindÃ¢ÂÂs Eye.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂAlthough the radiation and lasering to remove the tumor ultimately left me blind in that eye, only in very rare cases do such tumors metastasize. I am among the unlucky 2 percent,Ã¢ÂÂ he wrote in the Times. Ã¢ÂÂI feel grateful that I have been granted nine years of good health and productivity since the original diagnosis, but now I am face to face with dying. The cancer occupies a third of my liver, and though its advance may be slowed, this particular sort of cancer cannot be halted.Ã¢ÂÂ The   Sacks, who is on the staff of the New York University School of Medicine, is perhaps best known as the inspiration for the doctor portrayed by the late actor Robin Williams in the 1990 film Ã¢ÂÂAwakenings.Ã¢ÂÂ The film is based on SacksÃ¢ÂÂ 1973 book of the same name, recounting his experiences treating patients who long been in a catatonic state after contracting Ã¢ÂÂsleeping sickness.Ã¢ÂÂ In his long career, he has made a practice of marrying clinical practice with narrative storytelling. Ã¢ÂÂIf we wish to know about a man, we ask Ã¢ÂÂwhat is his story    his real, inmost story?Ã¢ÂÂ    for each of us is a biography, a story,Ã¢ÂÂ he wrote in his 1985 book, Ã¢ÂÂThe Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂEach of us is a singular narrative, which is constructed, continually, unconsciously, by, through, and in us    through our perceptions, our feelings, our thoughts, our actions and, not least, our discourse, our spoken narrations,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂBiologically, physiologically, we are not so different from each other historically, as narratives    we are each of us unique.Ã¢ÂÂ The habit that endeared him to many also brought criticism from some who accused him of being exploitative. Disability advocate Tom Shakespeare once called him Ã¢ÂÂthe man who mistook his patients for a literary career.Ã¢ÂÂ But little of that was evident Thursday as fans reacted to the news, seizing on the eloquence of the essay and hoping for yet more from Sacks before he goes. In his essay, Sacks says he plans to ignore politics and leave debate over climate change to the next generation, and instead focus on living Ã¢ÂÂin the richest, deepest, most productive way I can.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂI feel a sudden clear focus and perspective. There is no time for anything inessential. I must focus on myself, my work and my friends.Ã¢ÂÂ For fans, there is good news among the gloom. Sacks will publish an autobiography in the spring and in his Times essay says he is nearly done with several other books.
Title: Oliver Sacks says he has incurable cancer

Content: (CNN) Dropping red meat, and sticking to a   diet that incorporates fish may be the key to preventing colorectal (colon and rectum) cancers, according to a   study published Monday. Pescetarians, as they are commonly referred, had a 43% lower chance of getting the cancer compared to people with omnivorous diets. Why focus on colorectal cancer? It is the third most diagnosed cancer, and the third leading cause of   death in the US in 2014, according to American Cancer Society statistics. The disease is particularly dangerous because it is usually asymptomatic in its early stages, making it more difficult to detect when itÃ¢ÂÂs less deadly. Only 59% of those recommended for screenings receive procedures that are in line with the American Cancer SocietyÃ¢ÂÂs standards.  The study, which followed nearly 78, 000 people and was published in the Journal of American Medical Association, adds to the growing body of evidence touting the health benefits of a   diet. Another study, reviewing data from 39 separate studies showing that a plant based diet leads to an average drop in blood pressure similar to   minutes of exercise per day. Yet another study from last year found an average weight loss of nearly 7. 5 pounds for vegetarians.  While evidence shows the health benefits of reducing red meat consumption, the recent study highlights the differences between even a fully vegetarian diet and a pescetarian diet. Within the sample group there was a 27% drop in the risk of contracting colorectal cancer if you switch from fully vegetarian to eating fish. The authors of the study suggest that   fatty acids may be the key to such a low risk of cancer in the pescetarian group. Nutritionist Lisa Drayer agrees. Ã¢ÂÂIn addition to other dietary factors, fish may provide added protection from its high content   fatty acids. This is consistent with previous research that has found   have   activity and that they may be helpful in the prevention and treatment of colorectal cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Some questions can be raised though, from observing the recent studyÃ¢ÂÂs participants Seventh Day Adventists, a group that typically avoids alcohol and tobacco. But despite the caveat, Drayer is optimistic. Ã¢ÂÂWhile the study is observational and cannot prove a   relationship, it is exciting to think that in addition to regular screenings, a diet rich in fish and   foods may play an important role in reducing the risk of colorectal cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Cancer risk drops for vegetarians eating fish

Content: Like many aspiring singers on YouTube,    Carley Allison has uploaded several videos of herself belting out covers and original songs. But her most popular YouTube video, which was later posted on CNN iReport, was shot just after doctors sliced a hole in her neck. A    tumor    what turned out to be an extremely rare cancer    was causing her to have difficulty breathing, and she needed an emergency tracheotomy.  Even after the tracheotomy, she could still sing. Ã¢ÂÂMusic has been my passion ever since I was young,Ã¢ÂÂ the Toronto resident wrote on her blog. Ã¢ÂÂI started taking guitar lessons when I was 11 years old, and IÃ¢ÂÂve been singing for as long as I can remember.Ã¢ÂÂ Allison hopes that, despite the tumor, sheÃ¢ÂÂll still be able to pursue singing as a career. The diagnosis, Music wasnÃ¢ÂÂt always the primary focus of AllisonÃ¢ÂÂs life. She initially hoped to become a competitive figure skater, training six days a week for more than five years.  The intense training was something she learned from her mother, who was an Olympic marathon runner in 1996.  It was through skating that Allison first suspected something might be wrong. Ã¢ÂÂHer skating coach noticed that just walking up a flight of stairs, sheÃ¢ÂÂd breathe hard,Ã¢ÂÂ said her mother, May Allison. It seemed unusual that such a young athlete might have trouble breathing. Allison and her family went for a year believing    as doctors told them    that she had asthma. But a CT scan in February revealed a clear cell sarcoma outside the trachea. Allison knew her skating career would be put on hold. Teen with cancer blogs her bucket list, A rediscovered passion, Without skating to fill her time, Allison turned her efforts to singing. She has uploaded seven videos to YouTube in the past year, where she has nearly 50, 000 views. Ã¢ÂÂEverything happens for a reason,Ã¢ÂÂ she said of her condition. Ã¢ÂÂIt was an easy switch to put music as the biggest thing in my life right now . .. and my music has taken off, which is nice.Ã¢ÂÂ In April, her videos received the notice of actress and pop star Selena Gomez. Gomez tweeted, Ã¢ÂÂCarley Allison you are so strong girl. Love you! And praying for you. Keep singing.Ã¢ÂÂ The words echo many of the comments on AllisonÃ¢ÂÂs YouTube and Twitter pages    and helped her singing videos take off online. She has certainly followed GomezÃ¢ÂÂs advice, too. Singing is Ã¢ÂÂtherapeutic for her in a way,Ã¢ÂÂ said her mother. May Allison believes this is the best way her daughter has found to deal with the fact that she has a hole in her trachea and her hair has been shaved down, and itÃ¢ÂÂs how she has chosen to express herself.  Her daughter put it this way: Ã¢ÂÂBefore February 4, my biggest problem was trying to find a prom dress.Ã¢ÂÂ May Allison added, Ã¢ÂÂShe wants to make something of (her condition) instead of moping around.Ã¢ÂÂ AllisonÃ¢ÂÂs focus on singing isnÃ¢ÂÂt unusual for a patient, said Dr. Michael E. Kupferman of the MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. He has seen others with cancer turn to creative outlets. Ã¢ÂÂAny kind of devastating medical situation will make people more introspective,Ã¢ÂÂ he explained. Ã¢ÂÂArtistsÃ¢ÂÂ careers have sometimes evolved having gone through cancer. IÃ¢ÂÂve seen patients find that creativity to express themselves whether in music or in art. WeÃ¢ÂÂve seen that for millennia. It changes the tenor of their art and productivity.Ã¢ÂÂ What the future holds, Will Allison still be able to belt out her songs in the same way when her cancer is eventually surgically removed? Luckily, Ã¢ÂÂher vocal cords are not involved with the tumor,Ã¢ÂÂ according to her mother. Teen beating the odds after brain injury, However, she added, Ã¢ÂÂThe one side that the tumorÃ¢ÂÂs on, the vocal cord nerve may be affected by the tumor. ItÃ¢ÂÂs very difficult to tell on the CT scan. WeÃ¢ÂÂre hoping the chemotherapy will help the situation.Ã¢ÂÂ Allison herself maintains a positive attitude.  Ã¢ÂÂThere is a smaller chance there may be some permanent damage, but I try not to think about that,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Early on, there were some fears as well. Allison admitted that she was originally scared by her diagnosis after searching online. She has since mostly stayed away from searching for information on her illness. When the family learned about the tumor, May Allison said she and her husband got choked up. Ã¢ÂÂ(Carley) turned to us in a calm voice and said she was glad it was her and not anyone else in the family, because she knew she could handle it.Ã¢ÂÂ Despite being told there was a 5% chance that chemotherapy would affect a tumor in the trachea, the tumor has become softer since treatment and has moved away from the thyroid gland, which makes it easier to remove surgically. No matter what happens, Allison still plans to pursue her passions. SheÃ¢ÂÂs still thinking about a possible singing career, despite the fact that she had to cancel an audition for BostonÃ¢ÂÂs Berklee College of Music a few days after she was diagnosed. She looks forward to getting back on the ice one day as well. ItÃ¢ÂÂs that unstoppable attitude that has been the most inspirational to witness, her mother said. Ã¢ÂÂFrom an early age, Carley always knew what she wanted and had no fear trying to get it,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂFor her, every day presents a new opportunity to take a step closer. The interesting thing about Carley is that she actually enjoys the journey as much as achieving her goals. When things donÃ¢ÂÂt go according to plan, she rallies quickly and moves on. She has the ability to make anything fun and finds it very difficult to sit still.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂSheÃ¢ÂÂs been able to touch people,Ã¢ÂÂ May Allison added. Ã¢ÂÂHer public school raised $5, 000 in a fundraiser for (TorontoÃ¢ÂÂs) Sick Kids Hospital where sheÃ¢ÂÂs having her chemotherapy. There are thousands of dollars coming into Princess Margaret Hospital where she has the link on her blog. SheÃ¢ÂÂs very proud of that.Ã¢ÂÂ In the meantime, Allison continues to inspire people on social media with her positive attitude. Ã¢ÂÂFor me to be able to reach out to other people throughout all this has been great,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂPeople want to hear from me and hear my music right now so it keeps me happy. I cherish every moment. I have a different perspective on everything now. In the end, I think it will make me a better person.Ã¢ÂÂ 36 stories that prove citizen journalism matters
Title: Cancer canÃ¢ÂÂt stop teen singerÃ¢ÂÂs music

Content: (CNN) All Elizabeth Sedway wanted was to leave paradise and head home. But she couldnÃ¢ÂÂt.  Why? Because, according to her, she has cancer. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what she said in a video posted to Facebook that shows her group packing up from their Alaska Airlines plane as it sat at the gate in Hawaii.  Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂre taking me off the airplane because I donÃ¢ÂÂt have a doctorÃ¢ÂÂs note saying I can fly,Ã¢ÂÂ a woman is heard saying. Ã¢ÂÂAll these people are waiting, and IÃ¢ÂÂm being removed as if  IÃ¢ÂÂm a criminal or contagious, because I have cancer and no note to fly.Ã¢ÂÂ Sedway did eventually get on a flight back to San Jose, California, although she didnÃ¢ÂÂt get home until late Tuesday night.  And she got an apology. Ã¢ÂÂWe regret the inconvenience Ms. Sedway experienced . .. and are very sorry for how the situation was handled,Ã¢ÂÂ Alaska Airlines spokeswoman Bobbie Egan said. Ã¢ÂÂ. .. While our employee had the customerÃ¢ÂÂs   in mind, the situation could have been handled differently.Ã¢ÂÂ Her cancer fight notwithstanding, Sedway was in Hawaii in time to celebrate her 14th wedding anniversary. Still, on Monday, she was on a plane to head east. Then, according to her Facebook post, an airline employee who saw Sedway seated in the handicapped section asked her how she was doing. The second time she inquired, Sedway wrote that she responded by saying she sometimes felt weak. That was followed by a call to a doctor, then her removal from the plane. Egan, the Alaska Airlines spokeswoman, acknowledged that the carrierÃ¢ÂÂs policy when someone has a medical issue is to call MedLink, a group of ER nurses and doctors. The idea, she explained, is that Ã¢ÂÂit is better to address medical issues or concerns on the ground rather than in the air, especially on flights to or from HawaiiÃ¢ÂÂ    which in that case would last   hours over open ocean. The decision to pull Sedway from the flight was done with Ã¢ÂÂthe customerÃ¢ÂÂs  Ã¢ÂÂ in mind, according to Egan. Still, that doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean it was the right decision. Alaska Airlines since apologized to Sedway Ã¢ÂÂfor the disruption this has caused,Ã¢ÂÂ in addition to refunding her familyÃ¢ÂÂs tickets and paying for their overnight accommodations.Ã¢ÂÂ Even though she was stuck in Hawaii, Sedway made clear on Facebook that this was a real Ã¢ÂÂdisruption.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂBecause of this, I will miss my chemotherapy, my children will miss school and my husband will miss important meetings,Ã¢ÂÂ she said.
Title: Woman with cancer told she canÃ¢ÂÂt fly back home

Content: (CNN) Pop star Taylor Swift, who has built an intense bond with her fans by sharing personal details of her life, revealed some sobering news Thursday: Her mother has cancer. The singer did not divulge the nature or severity of the cancer, saying Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂd like to keep the details of her condition and treatment plans private.Ã¢ÂÂ Andrea Swift, 57, who years ago quit her job as a mutual fund marketing executive to raise Swift and SwiftÃ¢ÂÂs younger brother, Austin, has joined her famous daughter on tour and in several of her videos. In a post on Tumblr, the blogging platform, Swift said that for Christmas last year, she asked her mom to get screened for potential health issues, Ã¢ÂÂjust to ease some worries of mine.Ã¢ÂÂ Her mother felt Ã¢ÂÂperfectly fineÃ¢ÂÂ but went to the doctor for tests anyway Ã¢ÂÂjust to get me and my brother off her caseÃ¢ÂÂ about it. Ã¢ÂÂThe results came in, and IÃ¢ÂÂm saddened to tell you that my mom has been diagnosed with cancer. IÃ¢ÂÂd like to keep the details of her condition and treatment plans private, but she wanted you to know,Ã¢ÂÂ Swift added. #PrayForMamaSwift was a trending hashtag Thursday on Twitter, where SwiftÃ¢ÂÂs legions of fans offered prayers and messages of support. Within an hour and a half, SwiftÃ¢ÂÂs tweet about her mom had been retweeted more than 21, 000 times. Many fans shared Ã¢ÂÂthereÃ¢ÂÂs something in your eyes that says we can beat this,Ã¢ÂÂ a lyric from SwiftÃ¢ÂÂs 2008 song Ã¢ÂÂChange.Ã¢ÂÂ Swift also urged her fans to make sure their parents get screened for cancer and other potential health problems. Ã¢ÂÂShe wanted you to know because your parents may be too busy juggling everything theyÃ¢ÂÂve got going on to go to the doctor, and maybe you reminding them to go get checked for cancer could possibly lead to an early diagnosis and an easier battle . ..Ã¢ÂÂ she wrote. Ã¢ÂÂOr peace of mind in knowing that theyÃ¢ÂÂre healthy and thereÃ¢ÂÂs nothing to worry about.Ã¢ÂÂ Swift, 25, added that Ã¢ÂÂusually when things happen to me, I process them and then write music about how I feel, and you hear it much later. This is something my family and I thought you should know about now. Ã¢ÂÂThank you for caring about my family so much that she would want me to share this information with you. I hope and pray that you never get news like this.Ã¢ÂÂ Andrea Swift and SwiftÃ¢ÂÂs father, Scott Kingsley Swift, live in Nashville, Tennessee, in a mansion bought by their daughter in 2011 for $2. 5 million.
Title: Taylor Swift: My mom has cancer

Content: (CNN) Actress Rita Wilson is speaking out about her battle with breast cancer. Wilson, 58, revealed in a statement to People magazine that she underwent a double mastectomy after being diagnosed with invasive lobular carcinoma, a form of breast cancer. Ã¢ÂÂI have taken a leave from the play Fish in the Dark to deal with a personal health issue,Ã¢ÂÂ Wilson said in the statement. Ã¢ÂÂLast week, with my husband by my side, and with the love and support of family and friends, I underwent a bilateral mastectomy and reconstruction for breast cancer after a diagnosis of invasive lobular carcinoma. I am recovering and most importantly, expected to make a full recovery. Why? Because I caught this early, have excellent doctors and because I got a second opinion.Ã¢ÂÂ  Read: What every woman should know about breast cancer, Wilson, who is married to actor Tom Hanks, said her doctors had been monitoring her for a condition called lobular carcinoma in situ, which can increase the risk of breast cancer, according to the Mayo Clinic. After biopsies found no cancer, a friend urged Wilson to get a second opinion, which revealed cancer. Wilson says the second opinion was crucial. Ã¢ÂÂ(A) second opinion is necessary and vital. Not just by another doctor but by another pathologist,Ã¢ÂÂ she wrote on Facebook.  Wilson, who has appeared in the films Ã¢ÂÂSleepless in SeattleÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂRunaway BrideÃ¢ÂÂ and on television in Ã¢ÂÂThe Good WifeÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂGirls,Ã¢ÂÂ expressed gratitude for her support system and hope for the future. Read: You donÃ¢ÂÂt have to fear breast cancer, Ã¢ÂÂI feel blessed to have a loving, supportive husband, family, friends and doctors and that I am the beneficiary of advances in the field of breast cancer and reconstruction. I am getting better every day and look forward to renewed health.Ã¢ÂÂ Fans sent   via Facebook, and some thanked Wilson for being so open about her fight.  Ã¢ÂÂAll the best Rita, you will be in my thoughts. Thanks for sharing such a personal health issue in the hope it saves others. Very very kind. Keep strong gorgeous,Ã¢ÂÂ wrote one Facebooker.
Title: Rita Wilson reveals cancer fight

Content: Phoenix, Arizona (CNN) Nearly 12 million parents in the United States currently are raising kids on their own.   When single parents face a devastating illness such as cancer, everyday needs like cleaning and cooking can become a struggle.  Jody   saw the need firsthand, when her childhood friend faced that situation. Ã¢ÂÂMaking ends meet is insurmountable,Ã¢ÂÂ said  . Ã¢ÂÂThere are so many doctorsÃ¢ÂÂ appointments, copays, surgeries, prescriptions.  And then the inability to work    any savings that there may have been is gone very quickly.Ã¢ÂÂ She did all she could to help.  After her friend passed away,   helped start a nonprofit dedicated to assisting others in similar circumstances.  Since 2006, Singleton Moms has provided practical, financial and emotional support to more than 300 parents in the Phoenix area. Tiffany Montgomery, 48, was a newly single mom when she was diagnosed with   breast cancer.  Ã¢ÂÂ group pitched in to help, so Montgomery could spend more time with her daughter Ezri, now 10. Ã¢ÂÂWhen you canÃ¢ÂÂt really do much and youÃ¢ÂÂre looking at the dirt on the floor, itÃ¢ÂÂs one more level of stress,Ã¢ÂÂ she said.  Ã¢ÂÂYou have these people that come in, that donÃ¢ÂÂt know you, and Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂre going to help me with cleaning my house? Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂSingleton Moms has actually changed my whole outlook. They care about you, and theyÃ¢ÂÂre demonstrating their love through their actions.Ã¢ÂÂ I sat down with   to ask her about her work. Below is an edited version of our conversation.   CNN: Tell me about the woman who inspired your work.  :  I grew up with a girl named Michelle Singleton who was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 30.  She was a single mother of four children and I was a young mom with two kids. And it was scary. You just want to be there to watch them grow up.   Paying the bills, cleaning her home, making dinner for her kids    all of that became a real struggle. I wanted to make things as easy as possible for her.   So when I would go to the store, IÃ¢ÂÂd grab an extra Tide and extra toilet paper. When I would make my meals for my family, I would double it and bring a meal over to her house.  Once I helped with an electric bill.  I just tried to do those little things that I hoped would relieve her of some stress. About six months after she passed, we got to thinking she couldnÃ¢ÂÂt have been the only one. There were other people like her that needed help.  And thatÃ¢ÂÂs how Singleton Moms was born. CNN: IÃ¢ÂÂd imagine that many people havenÃ¢ÂÂt thought about the struggles of being a single parent with cancer.  How are you able to help?  : We focus on    support    financial assistance, housecleaning, prepared meals, supplies for the home, kidsÃ¢ÂÂ events. ItÃ¢ÂÂs that   mentality of neighbors helping neighbors.  Who doesnÃ¢ÂÂt like a clean house that they didnÃ¢ÂÂt have to clean themselves? We have a team of volunteers that have all been   and they sweep, mop, clean the bathrooms. We even have a couple of volunteers who go way above and beyond and will do laundry and fold clothes.   And so, our parents can come home from chemo, sit on the couch and read a book with their child without having to worry about, Ã¢ÂÂUgh, the bathroom needs to be cleaned.Ã¢ÂÂ  ItÃ¢ÂÂs just to allow them to focus on whatÃ¢ÂÂs important, which is their health and their family.  CNN: Is this work hard for you sometimes, on a personal level?   : About 80% of the parents we support are stage 4, which means that battling cancer is their   job. They will not go back to work and for the rest of their lives, theyÃ¢ÂÂll be in treatment.   ItÃ¢ÂÂs hard.  ItÃ¢ÂÂs a rollercoaster.  IÃ¢ÂÂve had bouts when a certain mom has passed where I didnÃ¢ÂÂt get out of bed for two weeks. And I thought, Ã¢ÂÂWhy am I doing this?Ã¢ÂÂ  But then I come back and remember why.  And so, while Michelle is and always will be our inspiration, there are now so many others that are just as inspirational. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre why I keep doing what I do.   CNN: We should note that name of the organization is no longer entirely accurate.  : WeÃ¢ÂÂre not just about moms    we have dads, too! Not a lot, but if you are a single parent, you need the support.  They tend to even get a little special treatment.  EverybodyÃ¢ÂÂs like, Ã¢ÂÂOh, thereÃ¢ÂÂs a dad here.Ã¢ÂÂ  And so they give them lots of hugs and pay a lot of attention to them.   CNN:  ItÃ¢ÂÂs such a serious subject, but your group seems to have a very fun vibe.  : WeÃ¢ÂÂre very social!  Once a month, all of our families come to pick up their supplies.  We do crafts with the kids, snacks and have a good time.  We like having any event because cancer sucks, and thereÃ¢ÂÂs not a lot of happy that goes with that.   But life does still go on, so itÃ¢ÂÂs really important that these families can just   and have fun. No one can understand what theyÃ¢ÂÂre going through like another single parent with cancer. So giving them the opportunity to meet and support each other is very powerful. Cancer can be so defeating.  ItÃ¢ÂÂs an ugly word and itÃ¢ÂÂs a sad word.  And so, itÃ¢ÂÂs my hope that Singleton Moms can bring joy and say to cancer, Ã¢ÂÂYou canÃ¢ÂÂt defeat us.  We are still going to be strong and weÃ¢ÂÂre going to celebrate life.  And you canÃ¢ÂÂt take that away from us.Ã¢ÂÂ Want to get involved? Check out the Singleton Moms website at www. singletonmoms.  and see how to help.
Title: Being there for single parents with cancer

Content: (CNN) Tawny Willoughby grew up in   Kentucky, where, she said, it was normal to use a tanning bed four or five times a week.   Ã¢ÂÂI had my own personal tanning bed in my home, and so did a lot of my friends growing up. . .. Everyone tanned,Ã¢ÂÂ Willoughby said. Ã¢ÂÂI didnÃ¢ÂÂt really even think about the future or skin cancer at the time.Ã¢ÂÂ  After one of her classmates in nursing school was diagnosed with melanoma, Willoughby made her first dermatology appointment at age 21. Sure enough, she had skin cancer. Now 27, Willoughby says she has had basal cell carcinoma five times and squamous cell carcinoma once. She goes to the dermatologist every six to 12 months and usually has a cancerous piece of skin removed at each checkup. SheÃ¢ÂÂs become a cautionary tale about the hazards of tanning beds, thanks to a selfie she posted last month on Facebook. The grisly image, taken after one of her cancer treatments, shows her face covered with bloody scabs and blisters. ItÃ¢ÂÂs since been shared almost 50, 000 times. Ã¢ÂÂIf anyone needs a little motivation to not lay in the tanning bed and sun here ya go! This is what skin cancer treatment can look like,Ã¢ÂÂ she wrote in a post along with the photo. Ã¢ÂÂWear sunscreen and get a spray tan. You only get one skin and you should take care of it.Ã¢ÂÂ One in five Americans will develop skin cancer in their lifetime, according to the American Academy of Dermatology. Exposure to tanning beds increases the risk of melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer, said the academy, which reports that more than 419, 000 cases of skin cancer in the U. S. each year are linked to indoor tanning. Melanoma is the most common form of cancer for adults   years old and the   common form of cancer for adolescents and young adults   years old, according to the academy. Warning signs include changes in size, shape or color of a mole or other lesion, the appearance of a new growth on the skin or a sore that doesnÃ¢ÂÂt heal.  Risk factors for all types of skin cancer include skin that burns easily, blond or red hair and a history of excessive sun exposure, including sunburns and   use    dangers that the blonde,   Willoughby now knows all too well.   Willoughby, a registered nurse who now lives in northern Alabama, said she never expected the Facebook picture of her damaged face to go viral.  But sheÃ¢ÂÂs excited to think her story might save someoneÃ¢ÂÂs life. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve lost count of how many people shared it now and told me IÃ¢ÂÂve helped them,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs really cool to hear people say they wonÃ¢ÂÂt tan anymore. IÃ¢ÂÂve had mothers thank me after sharing my pictures with their daughters. People in my hometown said they are selling their tanning beds. Ã¢ÂÂI never thought about the future when I was in high school I just tanned because it was normal to me.Ã¢ÂÂ  Willoughby knows sheÃ¢ÂÂll deal with the consequences of tanning for the rest of her life. SheÃ¢ÂÂs at high risk for developing melanoma but is now doing everything she can to ensure that sheÃ¢ÂÂs around for her husband, Cody, and their young son, Kayden, for years to come.  Ã¢ÂÂLearn from other peopleÃ¢ÂÂs mistakes,Ã¢ÂÂ she wrote on Facebook. Ã¢ÂÂDonÃ¢ÂÂt let tanning prevent you from seeing your children grow up. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs my biggest fear now that I have a    little boy of my own.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Frequent tanner shares grisly skin-cancer selfie

Content: Washington (CNN) In a rare joint action with attorneys general for each of the 50 states, the Federal Trade Commission says four cancer charities run by extended members of the same family conned donors out of $187 million from 2008 through 2012 and spent almost nothing to help actual cancer patients. Each of the charities charged were the subject of extensive reporting by CNN in 2013.  And in each instance, none of the four charities would comment. We were ordered out of the building at the Cancer Fund of America in Knoxville, Tennessee, and were the object of an obscene gesture by the CEO of The Breast Cancer Society in Mesa, Arizona. The Cancer Fund of America is run by James Reynolds Sr. His son James Reynolds Jr. is the CEO of the Breast Cancer Society. Another charity, the ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Cancer Fund of America, is run by Rose Perkins, the   of the elder James Reynolds. HeÃ¢ÂÂs also the CEO of the fourth charity, Cancer Support Services. The government says the charities claimed to provide direct support for cancer patients, breast cancer patients and children with cancer. Ã¢ÂÂThese were lies,Ã¢ÂÂ the governmentÃ¢ÂÂs complaint says. Jessica Rich, chief of the FTCÃ¢ÂÂs Bureau of Consumer Protection, says that in all, the charities spent about 97% of donations they received either on private fundraisers or on themselves. Only 3% she says, went to help actual cancer patients. According to the complaint, funds donated to help cancer patients instead went for personal use, in often lavish ways. Ã¢ÂÂ[D]onated funds were used to pay for vehicles, personal consumer goods, college tuition, gym memberships, Jet Ski outings, dating website subscriptions, luxury cruises, and tickets to concerts and professional sporting events,Ã¢ÂÂ the complaint says. Ã¢ÂÂMost of what we are doing is bringing actions against fraud,Ã¢ÂÂ says Rich. Ã¢ÂÂAnd this is as about as bad as it can get: taking money away from cancer victims.Ã¢ÂÂ CNN Investigations: Hidden cameras reveal airport workers stealing, There was also what the FTC calls Ã¢ÂÂrampant nepotismÃ¢ÂÂ at play in all of the charities. For instance, at the Breast Cancer Society, James Reynolds Jr. hired his wife, Kristina Hixson, to be his public relations manager. The complaint states that he also hired HixsonÃ¢ÂÂs two sisters, her son by a previous marriage, her mother and her  . According to the complaint, HixsonÃ¢ÂÂs mother had been a caterer. At the Breast Cancer Society, she was hired to write grant applications.  Moreover, on their tax returns, each charity claimed millions of dollars in donated goods shipped to overseas locations on behalf of cancer patients. The complaint says the charities never owned any of the goods in question and simply paid a fee to a private firm in South Carolina to ship the goods, called   . CNN went to Guatemala in early 2014 to investigate anyone who may have received those gifts and could find no evidence that they even existed. As a result of the complaint, two of the charities say they will close their doors. Both the Breast Cancer Society and the ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Cancer Fund of America are being dissolved, according to the complaint. James Reynolds Jr. faces a judgment of more than $60 million in fines and Rose Perkins, who runs the ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Cancer Fund of America, faces a judgment of around $30 million.   Under a proposed final order, the judgment against Reynolds Jr. will be suspended when he pays $75, 000. The judgments against ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Cancer Fund of America will be partly met upon liquidation of its assets, and the judgment against Perkins will be suspended due to her inability to pay.  CNN Investigations: Many airport workers not screened, The FTCÃ¢ÂÂs Jessica Rich, however, said there are few assets left. Government regulators will be lucky to recover $1 million, she told CNN. As for James Reynolds Sr. he will contest the charges in the complaint, the government says. CNN hasnÃ¢ÂÂt yet been able to reach attorneys for Reynolds Sr. his son or Perkins for comment, but in a message posted on the Breast Cancer Society website, Reynolds Jr. said: Ã¢ÂÂWhile the organization, its officers and directors have not been found guilty of any allegations of wrong doing, and the government has not proven otherwise, our Board of Directors has decided that it does not help those who we seek to serve, and those who remain in need, for us to engage in a highly publicized, expensive, and distracting legal battle around our fundraising practices.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Government says four cancer charities are shams

Content: (CNN) Cheryl Mauthe is hoping that 2015 is the year when good things begin again.  In 2012, her    son, Colin, was diagnosed with leukemia. That same year, her father died from ALS. In 2013, her house flooded and the family lost everything in the basement. And in 2014, the single mother of two was diagnosed with breast cancer. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs when Tim Smith, a photojournalist for the Brandon Sun in Brandon, Manitoba, asked if he could document the familyÃ¢ÂÂs story.   Smith had captured images of Colin during a blood drive at his school in 2012. And now, Cheryl was entering an impossible journey on her own.  Cheryl thought that it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt possible for both her and Colin to make it through cancer alive, but she hoped that her son would be the one to survive. Allowing Smith to take photos would ensure that the family was in photos together    that her children could remember her through the images and know that she fought to beat cancer and be there for them.  Smith gained CherylÃ¢ÂÂs trust and began to visit regularly. He was there for the appointments, the treatments, the surgeries    and the very worst days after those treatments when Cheryl was in the kind of pain that she can only describe as Ã¢ÂÂ .Ã¢ÂÂ Colin and Cheryl were both enduring chemotherapy while her daughter, Emily, felt left out because she didnÃ¢ÂÂt have cancer, too.  This surreal moment contributed to what became a new normal for Cheryl and her children, trying to make Ã¢ÂÂcancerÃ¢ÂÂ a familiar word in their home rather than a scary one. Ã¢ÂÂI tried to make sure that we didnÃ¢ÂÂt live in the cancer world,Ã¢ÂÂ Cheryl said. Ã¢ÂÂWe focused on the little moments and what made us happy: going to the zoo, the fair, birthday parties. ItÃ¢ÂÂs hard to find the good when youÃ¢ÂÂre surrounded by tragedy, but when you have two children looking up to you, you forget all of your pain and stress. They deserve the best mom possible, and thatÃ¢ÂÂs what I tried to do.Ã¢ÂÂ Cheryl had tried her hardest to make ColinÃ¢ÂÂs leukemia navigable. By using pamphlets from the cancer care center, they had educated the teachers and children in his school about what Colin was enduring    and in turn, he became the school rock star rather than an outcast.  In a rare moment, as her hair, eyelashes and eyebrows began to disappear after the chemotherapy, Cheryl caught herself looking in the mirror and tearing up.  Ã¢ÂÂMom, youÃ¢ÂÂre still beautiful,Ã¢ÂÂ Colin said to his mother.  While Cheryl could keep up a positive face for the kids, it was at night, when she was alone in her room with no one to tell her that everything would be alright, that she feared breaking down. As a single mother, she said, breaking down is one of the hardest things because thereÃ¢ÂÂs no one to help pick you back up again.  But Cheryl was surrounded by close friends who didnÃ¢ÂÂt desert her. They cooked meals for her, made sure her lawn was maintained and provided her with infinite encouragement. Even Smith, with his regular presence in their lives, became a positive support system who never lost his optimism.  Ã¢ÂÂI find myself surprised at how much can be thrown at one person, or one family, and see them stay so positive through the majority of it all,Ã¢ÂÂ Smith said. Ã¢ÂÂOn the surface, it seems so devastating. But I found those   moments that showed their happiness as a family.Ã¢ÂÂ Cheryl has fought through moments made difficult by her illness, like getting her kids dressed and ready for school when the slightest pressure on her fingertips made her feel like she was on fire. But a lot of her worry was directed toward Colin and the dangers that his leukemia presented. ColinÃ¢ÂÂs friends disinfect their hands before playing with him because his immune system is so compromised. When Cheryl brushes his teeth, they have to be careful with his gums if ColinÃ¢ÂÂs gums bleed, he could get an infection that could halt his chemotherapy.  There were days that Cheryl didnÃ¢ÂÂt want Smith and his camera around. In turn, Smith tried to be present, like a fly on the wall, without feeling invasive during such personal moments. This dedication to documenting the family allowed him to glimpse the happier moments as well. And Cheryl is grateful to see those moments frozen in time    bright smiles and laughter amid the tears and tangible pain. Together, the series presents an   portrait of strength, love and endurance in the best and worst of times.  Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a huge blessing to see yourself through someone elseÃ¢ÂÂs eyes,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂNow, we can step back and look at that year. IÃ¢ÂÂm so proud of who weÃ¢ÂÂve become. My kids have handled every moment with grace and dignity.Ã¢ÂÂ Even with all of the pain, 2015 has brought good news to the family: Cheryl has been declared   and Colin will hopefully be cleared of his leukemia by October. Both of them will have regular,   appointments to make sure that the cancer doesnÃ¢ÂÂt return    Cheryl is especially at risk. She still has one more reconstructive surgery, but it wonÃ¢ÂÂt stop her from returning to work for the first time in a long while. SheÃ¢ÂÂs working toward a future for her family that establishes yet another new sense of normal    where she can return to work, live with no pain and take her kids on a   vacation.  Smith, now like a part of the family, keeps closely in touch with Cheryl and her kids. He hopes to be in the room when Colin is cleared of leukemia. Documenting their story has left an impression on him.  Ã¢ÂÂYou appreciate what you have,Ã¢ÂÂ Smith said. Ã¢ÂÂIt made me realize that I donÃ¢ÂÂt want to live my whole life through the lens. I want to stop and enjoy life with my family, too.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Mother, son both fighting cancer

Content: (CNN) Researchers meeting in Chicago are hailing what they believe may be a potent new weapon in the fight against cancer: the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs own immune system. An international study found that a combination of two drugs that helped allow the immune system to fight the cancer    ipilimumab and nivolumab    stopped the deadly skin cancer melanoma from advancing for nearly a year in 58% of the cases.  Melanoma, though a skin cancer, can spread to the lungs, liver, bone, lymph nodes and brain. The study was designed and led by Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York. Other studies have shown promise in treating lung cancer. The research is being presented in Chicago at the annual conference of the American Society of Clinical Oncology and published in The New England Journal of Medicine. Those involved in the fight against cancer are divided as to just how excited to get over the promise of immunotherapy in battling cancer.  Results Ã¢ÂÂencouraging,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂpromisingÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂImmunotherapy drugs have already revolutionized melanoma treatment, and now weÃ¢ÂÂre seeing how they might be even more powerful when theyÃ¢ÂÂre combined,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Steven OÃ¢ÂÂDay, an expert with the American Society of Clinical Oncology.  Ã¢ÂÂBut the results also warrant caution    the nivolumab and ipilimumab combination used in this study came with greater side effects, which might offset its benefits for some patients. Physicians and patients will need to weigh these considerations carefully,Ã¢ÂÂ OÃ¢ÂÂDay said. In the study, 36% of the patients receiving the   combination had to stop the therapy due to side effects. Both drugs are made by   Squibb, the sponsors of the study. And Nell Barrie, a spokeswoman for Cancer Research UK, while calling the results Ã¢ÂÂencouragingÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂpromising,Ã¢ÂÂ told CNN that much remains to be learned and the new drugs would not replace any of the existing cancer treatments. Surgery, she said, would remain vital. So, too, would chemotherapy and radiotherapy, she said.  She noted that researchers had yet to study the   survival rates for immunotherapy. And the side effects can include inflammation of the stomach and bowel serious enough to require hospitalization, she  said.  But Dr. James Larkin, the lead author of the melanoma study, called the results a game changer. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂve seen these drugs working in a wide range of cancers, and I think we are at the beginning of a new era in treating cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ Larkin told The Telegraph, a British newspaper. Ã¢ÂÂAnother weapon in the arsenalÃ¢ÂÂ Barrie said immunotherapy could offer hope to people with cancers that are otherwise difficult to treat, such as melanoma, advanced lung cancer or cancer that has spread throughout the body. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre looking at another weapon in the arsenal,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. At the heart of immunotherapy is that cancer    unlike most other diseases    is not an invader. It consists instead of the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs own cells gone rogue. So the immune system is not programmed to target the cancerous cells because it does not recognize them as foreign. The immunotherapy drugs, Barrie said, Ã¢ÂÂwork to switch the immune system back on.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Immunotherapy shows promise in fighting cancer

Content: (CNN) If youÃ¢ÂÂre one of the nearly 3 million men currently living with a diagnosis of prostate cancer, listen up: A new study says what you eat makes a big difference as to how long youÃ¢ÂÂll live with your cancer.  Ã¢ÂÂThere is currently very little evidence to counsel men living with prostate cancer on how they can modify their lifestyle to improve survival,Ã¢ÂÂ said Jorge Chavarro, the studyÃ¢ÂÂs senior author. Ã¢ÂÂOur results suggest that a   diet may benefit these men by specifically reducing their chances of dying of prostate cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ  Chavarro and fellow researchers from Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health interviewed 926 men with nonmetastatic prostate cancer about their dietary habits over a   period. Prostate cancer is frequently   and nonaggressive and therefore has one of the highest survival rates of any type of cancer.  Two types of eating habits emerged: a Ã¢ÂÂprudentÃ¢ÂÂ pattern that included a high intake of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fish, and beans and other legumes, and a Western pattern made up of processed and red meats,   dairy and refined grains such as often used in processed foods. The study then followed the men over another 10 years to see how they did. They found men who ate mostly a Western diet of processed and   foods had a 2ÃÂ½ times greater risk of dying from prostate cancer as well as a 67% higher risk of death overall. Men who were Ã¢ÂÂprudentÃ¢ÂÂ in their food choices had a 36% lower risk of dying from any cause. Related: Mediterranean diet leads to long life, Eating less processed foods, more fruits, veggies and lean meat and fish are cornerstones of   diets, such as the Mediterranean diet. These diets have a long history of benefits in the scientific world. This is one of the first studies to look at the benefits for prostate cancer. Even though the study followed men over a long period of time, the authors point out some limitations: They did not collect data on   diets of the men, didnÃ¢ÂÂt track physical activity, and most of the 926 participants were white physicians, which might skew results. Ã¢ÂÂTherefore it is very important that our results are replicated in other studies with more diverse socioeconomic and   backgrounds,Ã¢ÂÂ lead author Meng Yang said.
Title: Study: High-fat diet increases risk of prostate cancer

Content: (CNN) Def Leppard guitarist Vivian Campbell is pulling out of the rock bandÃ¢ÂÂs tour after his cancer returned.  Campbell, 52, announced  two years ago that he was getting chemotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma, which affects the lymphatic system. He later said he was in remission.  Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm saddened by the fact that my cancer has returned,Ã¢ÂÂ he said in a statement Saturday. Ã¢ÂÂHowever, IÃ¢ÂÂm beyond consolation that its return will prevent me from being able to do my job for a while.Ã¢ÂÂ Campbell joined Def Leppard in 1992. Before that, he was in a series of other bands, including Whitesnake and Shadow King. The band is on the North American leg of its tour, and is scheduled to perform Tuesday in Tampa, Florida.
Title: Def Leppard guitarist Vivian Campbell pulls out of tour after cancer returns

Content: (CNN) A   doctor who authorities say gave cancer treatment drugs to patients who did not need them     including some who didnÃ¢ÂÂt actually have cancer    was sentenced  Friday to 45 years in prison. Dr. Farid Fata, 50, pleaded guilty in September to giving cancer treatments to misdiagnosed patients, telling some they had a terminal blood cancer called multiple myeloma. He pleaded guilty to 13 counts of Medicare fraud, one count of conspiracy to pay or receive kickbacks and two counts of money laundering.                    Federal prosecutors called him the Ã¢ÂÂmost egregious fraudster in the history of this country.Ã¢ÂÂ To Fata, they said, Ã¢ÂÂpatients were not people. They were profit centers.Ã¢ÂÂ Fata forfeited $17. 6 million that he collected from Medicare and private insurance companies. Some 553 patients received medically unnecessary infusions or injections, prosecutors said. The   gave an emotional apology in court, saying he was Ã¢ÂÂashamedÃ¢ÂÂ of his actions. Ã¢ÂÂI have violated the Hippocratic oath and violated the trust of my patients,Ã¢ÂÂ Fata said, according to CNN affiliate WDIV. Ã¢ÂÂI do not know how I can heal the wound. I do not know how to express the sorrow and the shame.Ã¢ÂÂ But to the dozens of FataÃ¢ÂÂs victims who filed into U. S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan throughout the week to watch his sentencing, his apology doesnÃ¢ÂÂt matter. Many will live with the effects of his, at times, unnecessary treatments, for the rest of their lives. As Geraldine Parkin, the wife of one former patient said in court, many were Ã¢ÂÂtortured until their last breaths.Ã¢ÂÂ Treated, but not sick, Robert Sobieray went to Fata and was given chemotherapy treatments for two and a half years. But he never had cancer. Ã¢ÂÂIt just gets to me,Ã¢ÂÂ Sobieray said. Ã¢ÂÂWhat was the motivation? Why, why me? I donÃ¢ÂÂt know what did I ever do to him.Ã¢ÂÂ The chemotherapy treatments were painful, and made him physically sick. They were so strong that his teeth fell out and his jaw started to change shape. Years after finding out he didnÃ¢ÂÂt have cancer, he has lost all but one of his teeth. Ã¢ÂÂWith all the bills piling up, I canÃ¢ÂÂt afford to get new teeth,Ã¢ÂÂ Sobieray said. Ã¢ÂÂ(I) would like to eat a good meal again someday. Like salad, used to love eating salad. I canÃ¢ÂÂt eat that anymore. A lot of things I love I canÃ¢ÂÂt eat anymore.Ã¢ÂÂ Patty Hester went to Fata in 2010 after being recommended by another doctor. Her white blood cell counts were low, and Fata was a renowned hematologist and oncologist. Ã¢ÂÂHe was, according to the web page, and according to the fliers, heÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂ Hester said. Ã¢ÂÂWhen you went in his office, he was top doc.Ã¢ÂÂ Hester, who worked in an emergency room at the time, was devastated when Fata told her she had myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). Ã¢ÂÂHe said, Ã¢ÂÂYou need to start on chemo, like, immediately,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Hester recalled. She was in disbelief. And after debating with Fata, he instead put her on iron treatments and, eventually, blood plasma treatments. She was still taking those pricey plasma treatments the day   made her come to the TV and see the news: her doctor had been arrested. Hester did not have cancer. Ã¢ÂÂTook full advantage of my trust Ã¢ÂÂ Some of FataÃ¢ÂÂs patients did have various forms of cancer. Chris Sneary faced Fata for the first time since his former doctorÃ¢ÂÂs arrest on Tuesday as he read his victim impact statement in court. He turned to glance at Fata, took a deep breath and read his story. Sneary came to Fata to be treated for testicular cancer from 2010 to 2013. He had 40 days of chemotherapy, 14 days of hydration therapy and dozens of other treatments and procedures. Ã¢ÂÂI gave full and total trust to this man to get me and my family through this journey I was about to begin,Ã¢ÂÂ Sneary said. Sneary discovered after FataÃ¢ÂÂs arrest that heÃ¢ÂÂd been given Ã¢ÂÂgross overtreatmentÃ¢ÂÂ    more expensive and harsh chemotherapy than was necessary and, worse, he had a testicle removed that was medically unnecessary. Ã¢ÂÂDr. Fata took full advantage of my trust in him, my fear of dying and, most of all, my top of the line health insurance,Ã¢ÂÂ Sneary said, at times fighting back tears in court. And one patient who did have cancer spoke out in court posthumously. Donald CrabtreeÃ¢ÂÂs wife, Marietta, read a statement he wrote back in December last year, before he passed away. Ã¢ÂÂNone of the tumors were helped    they increased in number, they increased in size,Ã¢ÂÂ Crabtree read in court. Ã¢ÂÂI believe Dr. Fata knowingly and purposely treated me for the wrong cancer and gave me the wrong chemotherapy.Ã¢ÂÂ Crabtree said it was his dying wish for Fata to spend the rest of his life in prison. Fata apologizes to patients, Before being sentenced, Fata turned to face those who were at his sentencing and apologized. Ã¢ÂÂThe quest for power is Ã¢ÂÂ he said, according to WDIV. Ã¢ÂÂThey came to me seeking compassion and care. I failed. Yes, I failed.Ã¢ÂÂ Now some of his former patients have a chance to file claims and possibly be awarded some of the funds that he collected from Medicare and insurance companies. Fata is expected to serve at least 34 years of his sentence, possibly at a   prison in Michigan. Prosecutor: New York doctor gun drug charges
Title: Michigan cancer doctor gets 45 years in prison

Content: Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   WeÃ¢ÂÂre starting to get a clearer picture of some of the   consequences of cancer immunotherapy, a new area of   therapies that harness the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs immune system to take on cancer   cells.  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   The drugs have generated a lot of excitement for the   revolutionary way they treat cancer. The drugs donÃ¢ÂÂt have the   same side effects as chemotherapy, and in cases   like  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   But now, as more data comes out and newer waves of drugs get   closer to approval, that excitement is starting to get tempered   in the face of deadly side effects and failed trials.  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   The first wave of these treatments are called checkpoint   inhibitors. Most people have a type of protein that stops their   immune systems from fighting the cancerous cells. These   checkpoint inhibitors block those proteins. ItÃ¢ÂÂs like taking   down a guard tower, allowing the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs own immune system to   flood past a barrier, where it then gets to work killing and   clearing away the cancer cells. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Checkpoint inhibitors were first approved to treat melanoma but   have since gone on to tackle lung cancer, bladder cancer, blood   cancers, and other cancers. There are now six approved .  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   But theyÃ¢ÂÂre far from perfect.  could be . Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Now, a second wave of cancer immunotherapy is facing some   challenges.  Short for Ã¢ÂÂchimeric antigen   receptorÃ¢ÂÂ   therapy, the treatment takes a personÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs own   cells, takes them out of the body, reengineers them, then puts   the cells back in the body where they can attack a particular   cancer cell. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not the first time these   therapies have experienced that severe side effect. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   The   therapies are Ã¢ÂÂassassins,Ã¢ÂÂ  That makes them a really powerful weapon, he   said, but that can be good and bad depending on whether itÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs   hitting the intended cancer target or accidentally affecting   other parts of the body. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Gritstone is working on another type of cancer immunotherapy   called cancer vaccines that wants to help amplify the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs   immune system to fight off cancer cells. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Even with the deaths that have been reported, there still could   be an upside to treating some patients with the drug even if   there are deadly risks attached.  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Ã¢ÂÂI feel there is a long way to go. And ultimately if in many   cases itÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs curing patients, we have to take the risk and   then manage the benefits,Ã¢ÂÂ Roman Yelensky, chief technology   officer at Gritstone Oncology, told Business Insider.  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Kelly Page, TakedaÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs vice president of strategic planning in   oncology, said this isnÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂt all too different from the speed bumps   the first immunotherapies (namely the checkpoint inhibitors)   experienced when they first hit the field.
