Content: Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂCatching cancer early is an incredible challenge, but a new way to detect it in the blood may totally revolutionize cancer treatment in just a few years.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ the $25 billion maker of gene sequencing technology, has created a new company to invent a blood test to detect all cancers in their early stages, something that would be a tremendous help to those trying to detect the illness before it is too difficult to treat effectively.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThis isnÃ¢ÂÂt the first attempt of this nature, and previous efforts by other companies have been criticized for having too little research behind them or focusing too much on detection rather than treatment. Crucially, this blood test does not exist yet, and while scientists will be working furiously to try to make it happen, it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean they will succeed.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂBut this latest bet is one of the   with a number of illustrious scientists already involved  Ã¢ÂÂ   and IlluminaÃ¢ÂÂs backing may give it a crucial boost.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe new company, called Grail (as in, itÃ¢ÂÂs trying to achieve something considered the Holy Grail for cancer researchers) hopes to have a   blood test by 2019, an extremely ambitious goal. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThat would mean that anyone could add such a test onto their annual physical  Ã¢ÂÂ   no need for separate tests for different types of lung cancer, prostate cancer, or any other form of the illness.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂGrail is launching with $100 million in Series A financing, backed by Illumina, Bill Gates, Sutter Hill Ventures, and Jeff BezosÃ¢ÂÂ Bezos Expeditions. Illumina and Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center are partnering to help launch a study to see if GrailÃ¢ÂÂs test can actually do what they hope it will do.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂWe look forward to a day in the not too distant future where there would be a simple blood test for every form of cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Richard Klausner, former director of the National Cancer Institute and a board member of Grail, said on a press call on Sunday.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe key to this effort is the ability to detect whatÃ¢ÂÂs known as circulating tumor DNA, or CTDNA. In recent years, doctors have discovered that the genetic material from cancerous tumors starts circulating in our bodies.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs abundantly clear that these molecules are in the blood,Ã¢ÂÂ Illumina CEO Jay Flatley said on the call.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂSo, along with Memorial Sloan Kettering, Grail plans on following hundreds of thousands of patients over the next few years and trying to see if they can detect CTDNA in those patients whenever they develop cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThat research will be crucial: An earlier effort by another company, Pathway Genomics, to create a Ã¢ÂÂliquid biopsyÃ¢ÂÂ for cancer was greeted in September by  from the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) warning that the agency had Ã¢ÂÂnot found any published evidence that this test or any similar test has been clinically validated as a screening tool for early detection of cancer in high risk individuals. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂFlatley is well aware of the minefield Grail is entering. Ã¢ÂÂIf you look at this business, itÃ¢ÂÂs littered with failures. With a few exceptions, screening tests have been invariably horrible,Ã¢ÂÂ he . Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a big challenge. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂIf GrailÃ¢ÂÂs trials show its test can detect stage 2 cancer, Flatley says the market value of those tests could be from $20 to $40 billion. If CTDNA can accurately identify stage 1 cancers, that would give them a $100 billion value, according to Flatley.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂDoing something like this does also comes with risks for overdiagnosis, even if the research is successful; a regular test for cancer risks causing many people to receive potentially dangerous treatment for cancers that wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have seriously impacted their health in the long run, according to JosÃÂ© Baselga,    and Chief Medical Officer of Memorial Sloan Kettering.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂBut the ways that CTDNA screening could work, and the opportunities that screening creates for early treatment, could revolutionize cancer treatment in ways that Ã¢ÂÂcannot be overemphasized,Ã¢ÂÂ according to Baselga.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂWe must diagnose cancer earlier,Ã¢ÂÂ he says.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Illumina is teaming up with Bill Gates and Jeff Bezos to develop a new kind of cancer test

Content: Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂJeff Huber spent over a decade  helping Google launch some of its biggest projects  Ã¢ÂÂ   from its ad platform to Google Maps.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThis week, he left the company to take on a more personal challenge: developing test for cancer at the earliest possible stage.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂHuber was just named  which was created last month by   giant Illumina and a group of including Jeff Bezos and Bill Gates.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂGrail also now has the backing of Google Ventures, it said when announcing HuberÃ¢ÂÂs appointment on Wednesday.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂHuber spoke with Business Insider about his reasons for joining Grail, the companyÃ¢ÂÂs plans to conduct the biggest ever clinical trial, his most recent stint at Google X, the companyÃ¢ÂÂs research unit, and his personal experience with the disease. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂHuber started his tenure at Google working to build its ad platform. From there, he went on to work on everything from Google Apps to Google Maps. After he hit the   mark, he started to think about what he wanted to do next and realized that working at that intersection of biology and technology was going to be his next step.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂAs I thought about what I wanted to do next at Google, it seemed to me like biology and science was having a pretty fundamental shift,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂHuber was most recently a senior vice president at Google X, where he spent time bringing big data and analytics to biology. He also served on IlluminaÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs board for the last two years, where he felt the ethical imperative of what the companyÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs been doing with its Ã¢ÂÂ  sequencingÃ¢ÂÂ research.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂDNA sequencing is a process in which researchers can break down DNA into its most basic building blocks, which they can then analyze to inform everything from where your ancestors came from to what diseases you might be predisposed to. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂHuberÃ¢ÂÂs motives are also deeply personal. His wife died last year of   cancer. A screening test that could diagnose her disease early on might have changed the course of her life.  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂEvery day we donÃ¢ÂÂt have a test available, lives are being lost,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. So, GrailÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs plan is to move with Ã¢ÂÂ  speed,Ã¢ÂÂ balanced by science and quality results.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂMoving at   speed as a healthcare company has to be taken with some caution: If the excitement around a certain idea moves faster than the science, it could have some serious  Ã¢ÂÂ   possibly even deadly  Ã¢ÂÂ   consequences. But, if GrailÃ¢ÂÂs able to pull off the scientific validation at the same time, it could be astonishing to see. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂHuberÃ¢ÂÂs first task is going to be to build a team that can take on the seemingly impossible task of developing a universal   test. His 12 years of working at the  in the world, have taught him a lot about how important a   workplace is. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂGoogle did a great job of recognizing importance of having a great team going after the big challenges,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre putting together best team of scientists with the best understanding of cancer biology, the best big data and informatics and build the infrastructure it takes to do this,Ã¢ÂÂ he said.  Ã¢ÂÂThat way we can see the patterns, correlations, data that will then feed the predictions and hypotheses and give us a better understanding of cancer biology. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe idea behind a   test is to identify the tiny bits of cancer DNA that are hanging out in our blood but currently undetectable. If Grail is successful, itÃ¢ÂÂll be the first to pull off a   blood test that works proactively. The concept is similar to liquid biopsy tests, which use  to sequences genetic information in that blood to figure out how tumors are responding to a certain cancer therapy.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂWith one simple blood draw, GrailÃ¢ÂÂs plan is to sequence and screen for those bits with the hope that it will help catch cancer before it starts to be a   problem. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs been a team of about 30 working within Illumina laying out the groundwork for the test for at least a year, and the group officially received their Grail job offers last week.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂFor the next two years, the focus will be on optimizing the technology of the test thatÃ¢ÂÂs in the making. GrailÃ¢ÂÂs working with health systems and research institutions like Memorial Sloan Kettering to do this.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂOnce they work out the kinks, Huber expects to do the   clinical trial to see how the cancer screening works in practice  Ã¢ÂÂ   thereÃ¢ÂÂs nothing more frightening than the thought of a misdiagnosis for cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThat is going to be three or four years away, he said. If it means running the screen on millions of people and waiting to see if the test proved accurate, Grail is many more years away from reaching its goal, even at Ã¢ÂÂ . Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThis timeline is a point that Huber is keen to remind people of. He does this by pointing out his start date: February 29. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂI think starting on Leap Day underscores   mission we have,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Because, get it? HeÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂll technically only have an anniversary every four years.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂDisclosure: Jeff Bezos is an investor in Business Insider through his personal investment company Bezos Expeditions.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂJeff Huber spent over a decade . ..Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: This man built Google Ads and Maps Ã¢ÂÂ and now heÃ¢ÂÂs working on an unprecedented test for cancer

Content: Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂA  from two major research groups just linked processed meat  Ã¢ÂÂ   including everyoneÃ¢ÂÂs favorite, bacon  Ã¢ÂÂ   to cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂIf this story sounds familiar, then thatÃ¢ÂÂs because it is.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂJust last October, the World Health Organization  concluding that eating processed meats was linked with a higher risk of developing  a specific type of the disease that begins in the colon or rectum.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThis new report looks even worse for AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs favorite breakfast meat.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂIn it, the American Institute for Cancer Research (AICR) and the World Cancer Research Fund (WCRF) find links between eating processed meat and developing cancer of the lower stomach.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe links are creepily similar to those found in the previous WHO report on colorectal cancer and processed meat.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂIn fact, the researchers found the same risk factor  Ã¢ÂÂ   down to the gram and percentage  Ã¢ÂÂ   for eating processed meat and developing   cancer as the WHO had found for eating processed meat and developing colorectal cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂHereÃ¢ÂÂs a quote from the  on stomach cancer:Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂAnd hereÃ¢ÂÂs the  and  on colorectal cancer:Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂAccording to Dr. Susan Higginbotham, AICRÃ¢ÂÂs vice president of research, thatÃ¢ÂÂs purely coincidental, as both reports used different publications and did different analyses. And we need to keep in mind that, at the end of the day, these estimates are just ballpark figures. They donÃ¢ÂÂt tell us precisely what is causing disease or how it happens in the body.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂCancer is complicated. ItÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs kind of showing thereÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs an increase in risk and we have ideas about why it might be happening, but weÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂre not sure. And the fact that itÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs happening in more than one cancer is definitely interesting,Ã¢ÂÂ Higginbotham told Business Insider.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂIn other words, this is bad news for bacon.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂStill, Higginbotham warns, you shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt go banning the ingredient just yet. While these numbers are certainly scary, the situation is probably nowhere near as bad as you think. It doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean, for example, that for every piece of bacon you consume youÃ¢ÂÂre drastically jacking up your chances of getting colorectal or   cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂLetÃ¢ÂÂs try comparing theoretical you with two of your theoretical friends: Susie and Fred.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂSusie is practically vegetarian. SheÃ¢ÂÂs completely sworn off hot dogs and smoked ham, but she maybe indulges in a few pieces of bacon every month. You, on the other hand, make a mean   BLT and have been known to occasionally indulge in a hot dog at a baseball game.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThen thereÃ¢ÂÂs Fred. He fries up a few pieces of bacon for breakfast every day, eats a pastrami sandwich for lunch a few times a week, and typically has ham for dinner.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂGenetics and environmental factors aside, you and Susie are at a pretty low risk of developing colorectal or   cancer as a strict result of your eating habits, at least according to these two reports. Neither of you is indulging in the equivalent of a hot dog or a serving of pastrami each day. Reminder: One daily hot dog or its equivalent was the amount of processed meat the study found to be linked with an 18% increased risk of the two cancers.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂFor Fred, itÃ¢ÂÂs a different story. HeÃ¢ÂÂs eating plenty more than the equivalent of a single hot dog each day, and, based on this research, is more likely to develop one of these two cancer types over his lifetime than you or Susie.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂLest you begin having flashbacks to the terrifying  which compared noshing on a few strips of delicious bacon with smoking cigarettes, the two are not equally unhealthy.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe  an international research group, estimates that roughly  per year across the globe can be attributed to diets high in processed meats like bacon.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂOn the other hand, close to as much as 29 times that amount  Ã¢ÂÂ   1 million people  Ã¢ÂÂ   die of cancer every year from smoking tobacco. Another 600, 000 people die each year as a result of alcohol consumption, and about 200, 000 die each year as a result to air pollution, according to the project.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂSo keep that in mind before opting to ban processed meat from your diet altogether. Instead, just cut back a bit.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂA new report from two major research groups. ..Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Yes, bacon has been linked to cancer AGAIN Ã¢ÂÂ hereÃ¢ÂÂs how bad processed meats actually are for you

Content: Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂVice President Joe Biden spoke in front of one of the largest gatherings of cancer doctors and healthcare executives in the world and asked for their help on Monday.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂTo succeed, I desperately need help,Ã¢ÂÂ he told attendees of the American Society of Clinical OncologyÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs annual conference.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂBiden and the White House launched a  and heÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs spent the past few months compiling ideas and meeting with leaders in research and healthcare as he zeroes in on what the initiative will actually try and achieve. Biden said in his speech that heÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs received a lot of interest around the world and from both sides of the aisle for the moonshot.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂThis is the only bipartisan thing left in America right now. Content: Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   The world of cancer treatments is an explosive area, especially   as treatments get more targeted. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   But with that will come some big costs. The IMS Institute for   Healthcare Informatics expects cancer treatment costs to hit $150   billion by 2020, up from $107 billion in 2015. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Enter a new potential side effect: debilitating cost. How do   doctors and researchers factor in the costs that a patient is   paying? Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the kind of thing Dr. Derek Raghavan, president of Levine   Cancer Institute at Carolinas HealthCare, thinks about a lot. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Ã¢ÂÂWe are spending more and more time thinking about cost for   patients,Ã¢ÂÂ he told Business Insider. He pointed to a study by    Dr. Jonas de Souza who uses   the term Ã¢ÂÂfinancial toxicityÃ¢ÂÂ to look at how much of a role   finances play in a cancer patientÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs quality of life. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Cancer isnÃ¢ÂÂt just one disease: ItÃ¢ÂÂs a whole group of cancers.   ItÃ¢ÂÂs gotten so big that whole companies are devoted to developing   cancer treatments. IMS cites more than 500 companies that are   developing cancer drugs. In fact, pharmaceutical company Novartis   just split out its oncology business into a separate branch from   its other disease areas. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   And because itÃ¢ÂÂs so complex, thereÃ¢ÂÂs a whole web of     that needs to happen as cancer progress, while at   the same time, newer drugs become more targeted and more   specific. HereÃ¢ÂÂs how leading cancer researchers and   pharmaceutical executives are addressing it all. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Raghavan said there are two main questions he thinks about when   determining how to treat a cancer patient. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Ã¢ÂÂThe first question is how much survival benefit will you   get from the patient?Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂThree weeks? Not worth   it. Three months, maybe. But probably not. If youÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂre talking a   year plus, thatÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs a relatively easy one to solve.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   But that three months gets a little complicated if it means there   arenÃ¢ÂÂt any extreme side effects (either physical or breaking the   bank). If that three months means seeing a major life event, like   a holiday or graduation, itÃ¢ÂÂs likely worth it. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Ã¢ÂÂEverything is contextual. If youÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂre dealing with an      whoÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs had a stroke and a coronary, and you can do something   thatÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs going to make them really sick, but will give them an   extra three months, youÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂd have to be an idiot to say thatÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs worth   it to them,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂBut you also have to ask them:   WhatÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs important to them?Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Newer treatments, including the   field of   immunotherapy (drugs that harness the immune system to better   attack cancer cells) are seeing much better and longer survival   rates, which is also where costs will factor in. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Within immunotherapy, researchers are trying to figure out how to   get more people to respond to treatment. Take Keytruda, the drug   thatÃ¢ÂÂs credited with helping get  after he was diagnosed   with melanoma that had spread to his liver and brain. Only about   30% of   patients using Keytruda alone respond   completely. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs still better than the  of chemotherapy treatments on their own in   cases of metastatic melanoma, but itÃ¢ÂÂs not 100%. However,   companies think the solution may lie somewhere in combination   with other drugs, potentially even other immunotherapies. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   But the problem is these drugs can often be upward of  depending on how long you   stay on the drug. Add that to another $100, 000 drug, and the cost   for such good results is a bit staggering. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Trials are already being run for combinations of two and even   three immunotherapies at the same time. Beyond that, companies   are looking at ways to pair drugs together to help them work   better. For example, ones that target the programmed cell death 1   (or  ) receptor to essentially take the Ã¢ÂÂfoot off the brake   pedalÃ¢ÂÂ in the immune system might be put together with other   immunotherapies that activate the immune system in different   ways. Or, those   inhibitors might be matched up with targeted   chemotherapies, or other tools in the   toolbox. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Pfizer, which has a number of immunotherapy compounds in   development and a partnership with Merck KGaA to develop the     drug avelumab, said it plans to work closely with other   areas of healthcare to set prices on combinations based on how   well they work. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Ã¢ÂÂI think that the concern thatÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs being raised time and time again   is more about the future and around combinations,Ã¢ÂÂ PfizerÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs   global president of oncology Liz Barrett told Business Insider.   Ã¢ÂÂAnd I think when you start to think about that, thatÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs where I   feel like PfizerÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs in a unique position, because we have the   multiple   drugs and the targeted therapy drugs.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Before companies even get to that pricing question, there are a   lot of unknowns still left in the immunotherapy world. Merck   & Co. the company that makes Keytruda, thinks a solution   lies in answering the question about where combinations are   necessary, and where drugs like Keytruda can work the best on its   own. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Ã¢ÂÂWe know for some patients, just single application or single   modality treatment with a   antibody is enough,Ã¢ÂÂ the companyÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂs   senior vice president of clinical development, Roy Baynes, told   Business Insider. But for those who donÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂt, there are a few   questions he pinpointed that need to be answered next: Ã¢ÂÂCan we   identify the group that is most likely to benefit from     therapy? Next, who needs a combination and can we   identify which combination?Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   Ideally, the clinical trials that are ongoing or in the works   will give researchers some hints as to what those answers may be. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe world of cancer treatments is an explosive. ..Ã¢ÂÂ

Title: Lloyd Blankfein, now in remission, describes the initial moments of his cancer diagnosis

Content: Five years ago, on Charlie RyanÃ¢ÂÂs second birthday, a big lump mysteriously formed on the side of his abdomen. At the emergency room his parents took him to, doctors suggested the lump was a hernia caused by some unknown trauma, and referred the family to a surgeon. The surgeon told them it was a benign tumor, and sent them home. Charlie already had a host of medical issues. HeÃ¢ÂÂd been born with an abnormally large head and other features of autism, including being nonverbal. Now this. Like many a baffled and worried parent, his mother, Autumn Ryan, turned to Google, typing in CharlieÃ¢ÂÂs ailments and coming up with a possible cause: a mutation in PTEN, a gene that reins in cell growth. Further searching led her to websites dedicated to families whose children have PTEN mutations. It all looked familiar Ã¢ÂÂ  and worrisome. Ã¢ÂÂI read stories of little boys who havenÃ¢ÂÂt lived, descriptions of these children with a multitude of bumps all over their bodies,Ã¢ÂÂ Ryan recalls. Ã¢ÂÂI was freaked out. Ã¢ÂÂ Two years later, after visits to multiple doctors and the nine months it took for his genetic test to be analyzed, her hunch proved right. Charlie has a mutation in PTEN. Ryan immediately faxed the results to Charis Eng, a PTEN expert at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio, whose name she had come across in her research. A few months later, the family made their first trip from their home in Tulsa, Oklahoma, to see Eng and her colleague, autism expert Thomas Frazier. Together, Eng and Frazier have treated more than two dozen children like Charlie Ã¢ÂÂ  who all have PTEN mutations, autism, and large heads. In Eng, Ryan finally found someone who understood CharlieÃ¢ÂÂs condition. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs like going to the person who has all the knowledge in the world, and you can ask her any question,Ã¢ÂÂ Ryan says of Eng. Eng was first and foremost a cancer geneticist, and stumbled upon   autism through her work in that field. In 1997, she discovered the genetic root of Cowden syndrome, a rare condition characterized by   growths and a high lifetime risk of many cancers. Following people with the syndrome, as well as their unaffected family members, she noticed that a few relatives of people with Cowden syndrome have an autism diagnosis. She thought little of it it was probably a coincidence. But then Eng noticed a few more children with autism in the families. And then a few more. Ã¢ÂÂWe started going, Ã¢ÂÂHuh, how come thereÃ¢ÂÂs all this autism in the family members? Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ she recalls. Curious to see if this trend was more than a fluke, Eng teamed up in 2004 with Merlin Butler, a clinical geneticist at the University of Kansas Medical Center in Kansas City. Eng and Butler screened 18 children with an autism diagnosis and macrocephaly, because enlarged head size is a hallmark of both Cowden syndrome and autism. They found that three of the 18 children have mutations in PTEN. Mutations in PTEN have been linked to dozens of cancers, but the gene had never before been shown to have any effect on social skills or behavior. Ã¢ÂÂWow,Ã¢ÂÂ Eng recalls thinking. Ã¢ÂÂPTEN plays a role in a neurodevelopmental disorder, too. Ã¢ÂÂ The finding was so unexpected that it was a tough sell. The Lancet and the New England Journal of Medicine both rejected the paper. Ã¢ÂÂThey didnÃ¢ÂÂt believe us,Ã¢ÂÂ says Eng, now head of the Cleveland ClinicÃ¢ÂÂs Genomic Medicine Institute. Ã¢ÂÂTheir reaction was: Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a cancer gene. How can this be? Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ To Eng, it was perfectly plausible that a mutation in the gene could lead to autism as well as to the many cancers of Cowden syndrome. Cancer arises when PTEN mutations release their brake on cell growth and proliferation, and cells grow out of control. When PTEN mutations cause an overgrowth of nerve fibers in the brain, Eng reasoned, they might instead lead to autism. The Journal of Medical Genetics ultimately published the study in 2005. Other groups soon confirmed the findings, and today the subtype of autism with PTEN mutations and macrocephaly Ã¢ÂÂ  called   Ã¢ÂÂ  is estimated to represent up to 2 percent of all autism cases. The unexpected connection between cancer and autism isnÃ¢ÂÂt limited to PTEN. In the past decade, many cellular pathways involved in cancer have been found to overlap with those implicated in autism, and dozens of genes have been linked to both. Ã¢ÂÂWe didnÃ¢ÂÂt know, when we started out, how [the autism genes] would look,Ã¢ÂÂ says Michael Wigler, a molecular biologist at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory in New York who became involved in autism research after 25 years as a cancer scientist. Ã¢ÂÂIt turns out that they are all over the place,Ã¢ÂÂ says Wigler. Ã¢ÂÂThe body doesnÃ¢ÂÂt invent each cellular system from scratch. Ã¢ÂÂ The findings have sparked investigations into whether autism treatments can piggyback off of approved cancer drugs that target specific genes. They also raise concerns that Charlie and other children with autism who have mutations in known cancer genes might be at increased risk for developing malignancies. So far, scientists have no concrete answers to address this worry. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂve barely scratched the surface,Ã¢ÂÂ says Eng. * * * Most researchers agree that a combination of genetics and environmental factors lead to autism. Hundreds of genes are involved in autism, though only a fraction of these are strong candidates for the condition. Mutations are typically categorized as either Ã¢ÂÂgermline,Ã¢ÂÂ meaning that someone is born with the mutation and carries it in nearly every cell of the body, or Ã¢ÂÂsomatic,Ã¢ÂÂ meaning that the mutation occurs after birth and affects only a subset of the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs cells. Cancer is usually a disease of aging, caused by somatic mutations autism, a developmental condition, is usually linked to germline glitches. So it was a surprise when autism studies started picking out genes in pathways typically associated with cancer. In several instances, the crossover emerged in much the same way it did with Cowden syndrome Ã¢ÂÂ  with scientists noticing autism traits in people they were treating for other conditions. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what happened with tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) a rare condition caused by in TSC1 or TSC2. Both genes are located downstream from PTEN on a pathway known as mTOR (for mammalian target of rapamycin mutations). In people with this condition, benign tumors grow in the brain and other organs, causing seizures, lung and kidney disease and other health problems, and occasionally turn malignant. Around 20 years ago, as autism diagnoses started to rise, clinicians began to recognize that autism was strikingly common among people with TSC. Today, up to half of people with TSC are estimated to have autism. Something similar also happened with RASopathies, a group of five disorders characterized by developmental issues, tumors and skin discoloration. Katherine Rauen, chief of genomic medicine at the University of California, Davis, identified mutations in the   pathway, a   cancer pathway, as the cause of RASopathies. Around 15 years ago, Rauen began to notice that many people with RASopathies are diagnosed with autism or have   features. Ã¢ÂÂWhen you see rare syndromes, and you see a lot of them, you start picking out patterns,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. In 2013, Rauen and her colleagues reported that 27 percent of people with RASopathies meet the criteria for autism. Other researchers hit upon the cancer connection directly, through deep dives into the genome. Geneticist Evan Eichler and his collaborators are sequencing the DNA of tens of thousands of children with autism as well as their unaffected family members to show that genetic mutations underlie autism. Among the first genes that popped up in their quest was CHD8, a gene that is involved in arranging DNA into tightly packed chromosomes. CHD8 also interacts with the WNT signaling pathway, which translates messages from outside cells into changes in gene expression, and has strong cancer ties. Eichler and his colleagues found that spontaneous, or de novo, mutations in CHD8 seem to cause a distinct subtype of autism with specific physical traits. When they looked at children with CHD8 mutations and autism, they noted that the children have broad foreheads, large heads,   eyes, and gastrointestinal issues. The growing number of cancer genes linked to autism piqued the curiosity of Janine LaSalle, an autism researcher at the University of California, Davis. In a study published in March, she and her colleagues reported that at least 43 genes thought to be involved in autism are also associated with cancer. Of those, 16 genes, including PTEN and CHD8, have strong autism links, and 8 others lead to   conditions such as Rett syndrome and TSC. Ã¢ÂÂSome themes jumped outÃ¢ÂÂ from the list, says LaSalle. She saw genes involved in chromatin  Ã¢ÂÂ  the   complex that forms chromosomes Ã¢ÂÂ  DNA repair and the transmission of signals that alter cell activity. Nine genes involved in the WNT pathway alone showed up all are involved in genome maintenance, or fighting damaging assaults on DNA Ã¢ÂÂ  and thatÃ¢ÂÂs a clue. The thinking is that early in brain development, errors in pathways that maintain the genomeÃ¢ÂÂs integrity may lead to autism. If the mistakes happen later in life, says LaSalle, they may occur in cell types prone to tumors. There may be more to it than timing and cell type. Eng and others are delving into the specific types of mutations, too, to see whether certain kinds of mutations contribute to autism, whereas others shift the balance toward cancer.   * * * When Eng first made the autism connection in 2005, she knew sheÃ¢ÂÂd hit upon a mystery she couldnÃ¢ÂÂt solve alone. She needed to find the right partner. As it turns out, someone else was looking for a similar meeting of minds. Clinical psychologist Thomas Frazier had just shifted his focus from attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and bipolar disorder to concentrate on autism, after his son was diagnosed with autism. Frazier and Eng, who had just moved to the Cleveland Clinic, clicked immediately. Ã¢ÂÂHad we met 20 years before, we wouldÃ¢ÂÂve shaken hands, and that wouldÃ¢ÂÂve been it,Ã¢ÂÂ says Frazier, who now runs the Cleveland ClinicÃ¢ÂÂs Center for Autism. Ã¢ÂÂThere would have been no reason for us to collaborate. Ã¢ÂÂ Eng invited Frazier to attend her weekly lab meetings. After publishing on   in 2005, EngÃ¢ÂÂs autism research had stalled, and she was eager to get it moving again. For his part, Frazier needed a mentor to guide him through genetics. When he showed up for EngÃ¢ÂÂs lab meetings, he initially had to look up words on his phone. EngÃ¢ÂÂs team would talk about the chemical modifications of DNA that alter gene expression, for example. Ã¢ÂÂI had no idea what methylation was. The first year was really brutal like that,Ã¢ÂÂ he says, laughing. FrazierÃ¢ÂÂs hard work paid off, and Eng was impressed with how deeply he came to understand genetics. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs really rare,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. The two now partner to explore what PTEN mutations do in people with autism, and hope to use their knowledge to find targeted treatments. In 2009, for instance, they began hunting for biological markers of autism, comparing people with   and those who have autism but no PTEN mutation. To understand how mutations in PTEN cause autism features, they compared 17 children who have   with three other groups: 16 children with autism and large heads, 38 with autism alone, and 14 controls. Compared with the other groups, children with   had lower PTEN protein levels. Magnetic resonance imaging scans revealed that they had enlarged volumes of white matter, the fibers that brain cells use to communicate. The children also had poorer working memory and slower processing skills than the children in the other groups. Taken together, says Frazier, the findings indicate that low PTEN protein levels drive white matter abnormalities, which in turn impair cognition. The next step, says Frazier, will be to pin down the exact molecular effects of the loss of PTEN protein Ã¢ÂÂ  an endeavor that other groups are working on as well. PTEN typically cycles between the cytoplasm (the fluid inside the cells) and the nucleus (the control center where the DNA is stored). The protein plays different roles in each location: In the nucleus, PTEN stabilizes DNA strands and plays some role in the cell cycle, whereas in the cytoplasm it plays multiple roles, including controlling cell proliferation and helping to suppress tumor activity. EngÃ¢ÂÂs lab created mice in which the PTEN protein clusters in the cytoplasm rather than in the nucleus, hoping to understand how the location of the protein influences brain physiology and behavior. Mice with most of the protein in the cytoplasm perform better in maze trials but display abnormal social behavior, traits that line up with those seen in people who have mild features of autism. Eng and Frazier havenÃ¢ÂÂt thoroughly studied mice with PTEN primarily in the nucleus, but the mice appear to perform poorly on memory tasks and be socially withdrawn. EngÃ¢ÂÂs lab and others are also working to tease apart how PTEN mutations in autism and cancer differ. So far, theyÃ¢ÂÂve found that PTEN mutations associated with autism tend to be missense mutations, in which one amino acid is replaced by another. That change drastically lowers, but does not halt, its key activity. A variety of mutations seen in cancers, by contrast, entirely disrupt PTEN, effectively halting its activity and releasing a brake that prevents tumors. EngÃ¢ÂÂs group is developing stem cell models that could pinpoint more specific differences. In cases of autism caused by mutations in other genes, it appears that the same mutation sometimes occurs in people with autism and those with cancer the difference is in when and where in the body the mutation occurs. For example, the same germline mutation in a person with   autism might also be found in someone with bladder cancer Ã¢ÂÂ  but only in the cells lining the bladder, and accompanied by mutations in other genes. Likewise, mutations of the TSC genes seem to have different effects in neurons than they do in other cells of the body, says Mustafa Sahin, director of the Translational Neuroscience Center at Boston ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Hospital. In cancer cells, the genes control cell growth and proliferation through the mTOR pathway, but in neurons, they appear to regulate connections between the cells. In mice missing one of the TSC genes, the axons Ã¢ÂÂ  the long, thin part of nerve cells that conduct electrical impulses Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂgo to the wrong places in the brain,Ã¢ÂÂ Sahin says. Diffusion tensor imaging, which maps nerve fibers, also reveals abnormalities in the wiring of the corpus callosum Ã¢ÂÂ  the bridge between the two hemispheres of the brain Ã¢ÂÂ  and in language pathways in people with TSC. For now, however, the precise series of events that push development off track remain a mystery. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs really what weÃ¢ÂÂre focusing on right now,Ã¢ÂÂ Sahin says. * * * There are no drugs approved to treat autismÃ¢ÂÂs core features, but the cancer link offers at least one clear possibility for leapfrogging forward. Billions of dollars devoted to cancer research have produced treatments that zero in on specific mutations Ã¢ÂÂ  shutting down defective enzymes, for instance, or checking overactive proteins. Autism researchers are looking to borrow from cancerÃ¢ÂÂs medicine cabinet. Targeted therapies devised for cancer could become Ã¢ÂÂincredibly effectiveÃ¢ÂÂ for the subtypes of autism that arise from a single mutation, says Luis Parada, director of the Brain Tumor Center at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York. Parada has made mouse models for both cancer and autism, with the mice lacking genes including PTEN, TSC1, TSC2 and NFI, a gene linked to autism and pediatric cancers. In support of this hope, Sahin and others found in 2012 that mice missing TSC1 or TSC2 display   behaviors, including atypical social interactions and repetitive behaviors. Rapamycin, a compound that blocks the mTOR pathway, halts these behavioral problems and seizures. Buoyed by these results, researchers then moved into clinical trials. In 2016, Sahin completed a   trial of 47 people with TSC, aged 6 to 21 years.   of the participants received a placebo, while the rest were given everolimus, a safer analog of rapamycin that is frequently used to treat pancreatic cancer. Neither the participants nor the clinicians knew who was receiving the drug. The researchers are still analyzing the results, but so far they do not see marked improvement in cognitive function in the everolimus group compared with the placebo group. The team hasnÃ¢ÂÂt yet looked at autism features such as impaired social behavior and communication. Even so, Sahin is already thinking about next steps. In mice, he says, Ã¢ÂÂwe can rescue   behaviors if we start the treatment early, in the first days or weeks after birth, but often not if we start much later. Ã¢ÂÂ So a   treatment may not be enough to improve autism features in the age range tested. Ã¢ÂÂWe may have to redesign the trial to potentially look at the effects of everolimus in younger children,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Eng and Frazier plan to launch their first trial of everolimus in people with   early in 2017. Rapamycin and related compounds have been shown to prevent the overgrowth of brain cells that leads to macrocephaly and   behaviors in mice lacking PTEN. Their trial will last two to three years, with participants taking the drug for six months. Ã¢ÂÂWe want to give the medicine time to actually show an effect,Ã¢ÂÂ says Frazier. The aim is to enroll 40 participants, also between 6 and 21 years of age. Judging from the people Frazier and Eng have seen at their clinic in Cleveland, however, they anticipate that the participants will skew young. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs when the brain is most malleable,Ã¢ÂÂ says Frazier. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂll certainly look at age as a possible moderator of treatment outcome. Ã¢ÂÂ He emphasizes that although he is hopeful the drug will prove safe, and that the participants show at least a small improvement in brain function, he canÃ¢ÂÂt predict the outcome of the trial. Ã¢ÂÂIn a wild, wild scenario, maybe their autism symptoms get better,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. * * * Autumn Ryan hopes Charlie will participate in the trial, but she knows thatÃ¢ÂÂs not a given. Eng, ever the straight shooter, has told her that Charlie, who is now 7, may be too intellectually disabled to participate. Ryan is reassured to know that even if Charlie doesnÃ¢ÂÂt take part in the trial, Eng and Frazier will continue to care for him, answering questions by phone or email, and seeing him once a year when the family visits the Cleveland Clinic. ItÃ¢ÂÂs an arduous trip that requires two plane rides and wears out both Charlie and his mom. Yet Ryan wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt skip it. Ã¢ÂÂI wonÃ¢ÂÂt travel all day to go on vacation with Charlie,Ã¢ÂÂ she says, Ã¢ÂÂbut I will to go to the Cleveland Clinic. Ã¢ÂÂ As Charlie gets older, these visits will involve more invasive tests to screen for cancer, such as colonoscopies beginning when heÃ¢ÂÂs 9. Ryan worries about breast cancer, too: People with PTEN mutations have an 85 percent lifetime risk of developing that malignancy, and a drug Charlie is on to treat aggressiveness and hyperactivity, risperidone, is causing him to develop breasts. Ã¢ÂÂAll we can do is watch and wait,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. RyanÃ¢ÂÂs concerns are shared by other parents whose children are on the spectrum and have mutated cancer genes. They canÃ¢ÂÂt help but worry: Are their children also at heightened risk for malignancies? In short, nobody knows for certain. A handful of studies indicate that the genetic overlap might not increase these individualsÃ¢ÂÂ odds of developing cancer. In one analysis of the medical records of thousands of people with autism in California, cancer didnÃ¢ÂÂt make the list of the conditions these individuals are most likely to develop. In fact, some evidence suggests that they might have an unusually low cancer risk. In another   analysis, University of Iowa researchers compared the medical records of 1, 837 people who have an autism diagnosis with those of 9, 336 controls. They found that people with autism have a lifetime cancer risk of 1. 3 percent versus 3. 9 percent in the control group. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs not enough evidence to say that mutations in cancer genes that contribute to autism prevent malignancies, Eng cautions. No study has specifically analyzed cancer risk in people with autism who have mutations linked to cancer pathways. Eng and Frazier are collaborating with researchers at four other institutions to follow up to 100 children with   long term. They might not have to wait decades to get a signal for risk, because thyroid cancer, which can be detected with a simple ultrasound, can develop in children as young as 4. (To date, none of the 30 children with   seen at the Cleveland Clinic has developed thyroid cancer.) If people with   do develop cancer, there are several effective drugs that might be able to combat it Ã¢ÂÂ  some of which, like rapamycin, are the very same therapies being tested for autism. Even if Eng is successful in finding targeted treatments for people with   however, she would be helping only a small fraction of people with autism. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs how precision therapy works,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. But given her years of experience in cancer biology, Eng inevitably thinks of the parallels: Just as cancer drugs developed for one type of cancer have turned out to be effective at fighting other types, perhaps a treatment for one subtype of autism will follow a similar arc. The everolimus trial is a first step to testing this optimistic scenario. EngÃ¢ÂÂs team is looking for gene variants, or even novel pathways, that havenÃ¢ÂÂt yet been identified as being important to autism. Should they hit upon anything promising, they plan to scour the enormous inventory of existing cancer drugs. Ã¢ÂÂSome drug companies may have these therapies already,Ã¢ÂÂ Eng says. Ã¢ÂÂMaybe thereÃ¢ÂÂs a drug theyÃ¢ÂÂve shelved because it didnÃ¢ÂÂt work as theyÃ¢ÂÂd hoped, and voilÃÂ , it targets the underlying mechanism we donÃ¢ÂÂt even yet know exists. Ã¢ÂÂ Ryan, meanwhile, says she knows Eng and Frazier are in for the long haul Ã¢ÂÂ  and so is she. Ã¢ÂÂCharlie will be a part of any study that he qualifies for,Ã¢ÂÂ Ryan says. Ã¢ÂÂWe want to get as much information about this condition as possible, and to help other families as much as we can. Ã¢ÂÂ This article appears courtesy of Spectrum.
Title: Could Cancer Drugs Treat Autism?

Content: In recent years, scientists have been dealing with concerns about a reproducibility crisis Ã¢ÂÂ  the possibility that many published findings may not actually be true. Psychologists have grappled intensively with this problem, trying to assess its scope and look for solutions. And two reports from pharmaceutical companies have suggested that cancer biologists have to face a similar reckoning.   In 2011, Bayer Healthcare said that its   scientists could only validate 25 percent of basic studies in cancer and other conditions. (Drug companies routinely do such checks so they can use the information in those studies as a starting point for developing new drugs.) A year later, Glenn Begley and Lee Ellis from Amgen said that the firm could only confirm the findings in 6 out of 53 landmark cancer papers Ã¢ÂÂ  just 11 percent. Perhaps, they wrote, that might explain why Ã¢ÂÂour ability to translate cancer research to clinical success has been remarkably low. Ã¢ÂÂ But citing reasons of confidentiality, neither the Bayer nor Amgen teams released the list of papers that they checked, or their methods or results. Ironically, without that information, there was no way of checking if their claims about irreproducibility were themselves reproducible. Ã¢ÂÂThe reports were shocking, but also seemed like Ã¢ÂÂ says Tim Errington, a cell biologist at the Center for Open Science (COS). Elizabeth Iorns had the same thought, and she saw a way to do a better and more transparent job. She had founded a   called Science Exchange, which uses a large network of contract labs to provide research support to scientists Ã¢ÂÂ  and in some cases, check their work. She contacted the COS, and together, they launched the Reproducibility Project: Cancer Biology Ã¢ÂÂ  an initiative that used the Science Exchange labs to replicate key results from the 50 most cited papers in cancer biology, published between 2010 and 2012. (The COS recently used the same model for psychology studies to good effect.)   The results from the first five of these replication attempts were published today Ã¢ÂÂ  and they offer no clean answers. Two of them largely (but not entirely) confirmed the conclusions of the original studies. One failed to do so. And two were inconclusive for technical reasons Ã¢ÂÂ  the mouse strains or cancer cell lines that were used in the original studies didnÃ¢ÂÂt behave in the same way the second time round. These uncertainties mean that itÃ¢ÂÂs very hard to say whether each replication attempt Ã¢ÂÂworked,Ã¢ÂÂ or whether each original study was actually reproducible. Ã¢ÂÂEveryone wants us to paint the project in black and white,Ã¢ÂÂ says Errington. Ã¢ÂÂWhat percent of these papers replicate? IÃ¢ÂÂve been asked that so many times, but itÃ¢ÂÂs not an easy question. Ã¢ÂÂ To him, the projectÃ¢ÂÂs goal isnÃ¢ÂÂt to get a hard percentage, but to understand why two seemingly identical goes at the same experiment might produce different results, and to ultimately make it easier for one group of scientists to check anotherÃ¢ÂÂs work. The Reproducibility Project team   all of their work. That is, for each targeted paper, they wrote up their experimental plans in full, ran them past the original authors, and submitted them to the journal eLife for peer review. Only then did they start the experiments. Once the results were in, they were reviewed a second time, before being published. The hardest part, by far, was figuring out exactly what the original labs actually did. Scientific papers come with methods sections that theoretically ought to provide recipes for doing the same experiments. But often, those recipes are incomplete, missing out important steps, details, or ingredients. In some cases, the recipes arenÃ¢ÂÂt described at all researchers simply cite an earlier study that used a similar technique. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve done it myself: you reference a previous paper and that one references a paper and that one references a paper, and now youÃ¢ÂÂve gone years and the methodology doesnÃ¢ÂÂt exist,Ã¢ÂÂ admit Errington. Ã¢ÂÂMost people looking at these papers wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt even think of going through these steps. TheyÃ¢ÂÂd just guess. If you asked 20 different labs to replicate a paper, youÃ¢ÂÂd end up with 10 different methodologies that arenÃ¢ÂÂt really comparable. Ã¢ÂÂ So, in every case, he had to ask the scientists behind the original experiments for the details of their work. Oftentimes, the person who actually did the experiments had left the lab, so an existing team member had to rummage through old notebooks or data files. The project ended up being hugely   for everyone concerned. Ã¢ÂÂWe spent a boatload of time trying to get back to ground zero,Ã¢ÂÂ says Errington. And for what? The results of the first five papers show just how hard it is to interpret a replication attempt in this field. For example, in 2012, Levi Garraway at the   Cancer Institute found that melanoma skin cancers frequently carry mutations in a gene called PREX2. His team then showed that these mutations accelerate the growth of human melanoma cells that were transplanted onto mice. But replicating team couldnÃ¢ÂÂt confirm the latter result in their experiment, the PREX2 mutations made no difference. Does that mean that GarrawayÃ¢ÂÂs study was wrong? Not quite. Even though the replication team got their melanoma cells and mice from the same source as GarrawayÃ¢ÂÂs group, in their hands, the transplanted tumours grew much faster than had been reported. The PREX2 mutations made no difference because all the cells were already zooming along in sixth gear. Small differences in the ways the cells were grown or the mice were housed could have contributed to the differences between these studies, writes Roger Davis, a cell biologist at the University of Masschussetts Medical School, reviewed the PREX2 replication paper. In another case, Irving Weissman from Stanford Medicine showed that cancer cells carry high levels of a protein called CD47, and antibodies that target this protein can slow the growth of human tumor cells that had been transplanted into mice. In this case, the replication experiment was inconclusive because all the transplanted tumors would spontaneously regress, antibodies or no. Some might argue that these differences arise because the project relied on contractors, who lack the experience and artisanal skills of the scientists in the original teams. Iorns disagrees. Ã¢ÂÂThe teams were all selected for their technical expertise in the experiments being conducted,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂThey routinely run these types of experiments all the time. Ã¢ÂÂ Instead, she and Errington argue that the differences stem from the inherent and underappreciated variability of the cells and animals being used in these studies. In psychology, researchers who replicate a study have no choice but to recruit different volunteers, who might differ from the original sample in critical ways. But in theory, cancer biologists should be able to use the exact same lineage of cells or breed of rodents Ã¢ÂÂ  genetically identical and sourced from the same suppliers Ã¢ÂÂ  which should behave in the same way. Ã¢ÂÂBut some of these models kind of fell apart, and you canÃ¢ÂÂt dismiss that,Ã¢ÂÂ says Errington. He hopes that these results will spur other scientists to better explore those variations, and include more quality control steps in their work. And perhaps the most important result from the project so far, as Daniel Engber wrote in Slate, is that it has been Ã¢ÂÂa hopeless slog. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂIf people had deposited raw data and full protocols at the time of publication, we wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have to go back to the original authors,Ã¢ÂÂ says Iorns. That would make it much easier for scientists to truly check each otherÃ¢ÂÂs work. The National Institutes of Health seem to agree. In recently released guidelines, meant to improve the reproducibility of research, they recommend that journals ask for more thorough methods sections and more sharing of data. And in this, the Reproducibility Project have modelled the change they want to see, documenting every step of their project on a wiki. Ã¢ÂÂWe want to applaud replication efforts like this,Ã¢ÂÂ says Atul Butte from the University of California, San Francisco, whose study was among the two that were successfully reproduced. Ã¢ÂÂIt is important for the public to have trust in scientists, and belief in the veracity of our published findings. Ã¢ÂÂ But he suggests that the team chooses their targeted studies in a Ã¢ÂÂmore impactful mannerÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ  not by citations, but by those that are most likely to lead to new treatments. In the meantime, the team still needs to finish its first wave of replications. They initially set out to replicate 50 old papers, but the unexpectedly high costs of doing so have forced them to scale back. Ã¢ÂÂIn the end, we think weÃ¢ÂÂll complete 30,Ã¢ÂÂ says Iorns.
Title: How Reliable Are Cancer Studies?

Content: LaFleur was first diagnosed with breast cancer in July 2011. Six rounds of chemotherapy, a lumpectomy, a second surgery, and six weeks of radiation drove the cancer into remission Ã¢ÂÂ  only for it to return in September 2014. This time, she underwent the mastectomy and reconstruction, and after one final surgery, she was  . But the invasive treatments left her feeling that her body no longer quite belonged to her. Ã¢ÂÂI realized recovering from this trauma was going to be a complicated process,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. On the floor, LaFleurÃ¢ÂÂs mind drifted to, of all things, belly dance. Before her diagnosis, she had danced with Fata Morgana, a   troupe in Charlottesville, where sheÃ¢ÂÂs working toward a Ph. D. in ancient Greek and Latin historiography at the University of Virginia. The slew of medical treatments had driven LaFleur into a sedentary life, disconnected from the activities she once enjoyed. She wondered, could returning to belly dance help her find a way back to the life she had known before cancer? LaFleur knew that belly dance couldnÃ¢ÂÂt treat, let alone cure, cancer. But the practice incorporates a mix of gentle movements and intense focus that she realized was the perfect balance of physical activity, play, and meditation for her recovery. In fact, maybe it could be the perfect activity for other people recovering from cancer, too. Soon, she was thinking through how she could design a   class. Beyond Charlottesville, LaFleurÃ¢ÂÂs inclination to connect healing with play aligns with a growing sector of therapists in the United States. The field, known as recreational therapy, uses games and other leisurely pursuits, including activities as mundane as   tosses and art projects, to help patients regain fine motor skills and reduce anxiety or depression. Like its   relatives Ã¢ÂÂ  such as physical or occupational therapy Ã¢ÂÂ  recreational therapy relies on measurable outcomes, but aims for fun and socialization outside of the medical office. The field isnÃ¢ÂÂt widely known Ã¢ÂÂ  and itÃ¢ÂÂs controversial. Because most states donÃ¢ÂÂt license recreational therapists, itÃ¢ÂÂs difficult to determine whether a practitioner is offering legitimate therapy or promising unrealistic results. Music therapy, a subset of recreational therapy, has also come under scrutiny in recent years as some people insist that it helps children with developmental disorders and others worry the impact is irresponsibly exaggerated. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, employment opportunities for recreational therapists are predicted to grow by 12 percent between 2014 and 2024, a rate faster than average across all occupations, due in part to AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs aging of population as baby boomers retire. Currently licensed in Utah, North Carolina, Oklahoma, and New Hampshire, with bills pending in several other states, recreational therapists must earn a   college degree, complete a   internship, and pass a   exam. Since its formation in 1984, the American Therapeutic Recreation Association Ã¢ÂÂ  the largest national membership organization for recreational therapists Ã¢ÂÂ  has grown from 60 to more than 2, 200 practitioners. Vincent Bonadies has practiced recreational therapy for nearly 38 years and currently serves on ATRAÃ¢ÂÂs board. In reflecting on his career, he recalled one of his first patients, a young man who had been in a motorcycle wreck that left him almost completely paralyzed. The man spent hours every day sitting in bed with little to break up the monotony. Ã¢ÂÂHe had the ability to move his head, and he loved painting,Ã¢ÂÂ Bonadies says. So Bonadies helped the patient learn to hold a paintbrush in his mouth. Like many other patients whose cancer has come back after remission, LaFleur remains afflicted by the nagging doubt that the cancer is ever truly gone. Ã¢ÂÂCancer is, at its core, your body turning against itself,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂYou have a hard time trusting your immune system. ItÃ¢ÂÂs very alienating, and it can be frustrating to not have the stamina youÃ¢ÂÂve had your whole life. Ã¢ÂÂ LaFleur liked that belly dance can promote body positivity and isnÃ¢ÂÂt too difficult to pick up. The dance can also be modified to accommodate students who might need to sit or lie down due to weakened health. She decided to limit her class to other cancer survivors with the goal of connecting over the shared experience. She named the project My Body Raqs, in reference to a classic Egyptian style of belly dance, and began offering free classes. While the notion that exercise and community involvement has a positive impact on health isnÃ¢ÂÂt controversial, some do question the legitimacy of recreational therapy. With few states licensing recreational therapists, regulation is nonexistent and purported recreational therapists may not be qualified to practice. The petition website Change. org is littered with appeals for licensing from people in states that donÃ¢ÂÂt currently recognize recreational therapists. Unlike LaFleurÃ¢ÂÂs free, casual classes, an unlicensed recreational therapist could potentially charge steep    fees while promising impossible results. Bonadies, the recreational therapist, believes that the lack of public familiarity with his profession is the key issue holding licensing back. Ã¢ÂÂ[Recreational therapy] is not a household name like physical therapy,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Recently, there are some signs that this will change. In 2016, the VeteransÃ¢ÂÂ Health Administration endorsed recreational therapy as a valuable treatment option for veterans, noting that the practice has been in use since the Civil War. Christiana Brenin, a University of Virginia oncologist who specializes in breast and colorectal cancer, would not readily recommend recreational therapy to her patients. Ã¢ÂÂThe short answer is no,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. During treatments, she works closely with a team of clinical psychologists who help her patients address the anxiety and fear that can accompany a diagnosis. Additional layers of therapy could be unnecessary, if not harmful, for patients already dealing with   and exhausting treatments, she says. And in cases of breast cancer like LaFleurÃ¢ÂÂs, she points out, most patients continue to work and do recreational things throughout their treatment anyway. Why introduce unnecessary approaches? Still, Brenin wonÃ¢ÂÂt stop patients from pursuing recreational therapy if they think it will help. Ã¢ÂÂI definitely believe in placebo effect,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. She has noticed that patients who embrace placebo treatments regain a sense of control over their care and tend to be less stressed. Moreover, she encourages any activity that can help patients shore up their support networks. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve had some patients decide to volunteer in support groups to help others who are having a hard time,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂThey find a meaning in life. ItÃ¢ÂÂs really good way to reintegrate into society. Ã¢ÂÂ This was true of LaFleur. She planned her first   class with no idea whether she would spend the session teaching or waiting in an empty room. To her relief, a small group of women arrived, curious to see what she would offer. Over the course of eight weeks, nearly all of the students returned. Away from doctors and caretakers, the group found relief in speaking frankly about their shared cancer experiences. Ã¢ÂÂWe make all these morbid jokes,Ã¢ÂÂ LaFleur says. When the class ended, she shared everyoneÃ¢ÂÂs contact information and has occasionally organized  . Cancer still affects LaFleurÃ¢ÂÂs daily life. The illness has left her with chronic fatigue syndrome, a constellation of symptoms that makes her search for words that used to come easily and forces her to take naps during the day. SheÃ¢ÂÂs had to put her belly dance classes on pause while completing a teaching assignment for her Ph. D. in Lynchburg, Virginia, but hopes to return with a new round of My Body Raqs class offerings this summer. No one has determined a perfect formula for helping cancer patients heal. As Brenin points out, each cancer patient is unique, and treatment that works with some patients may not work for others. Regardless, LaFleur is convinced that a little belly dance doesnÃ¢ÂÂt hurt.
Title: Belly Dancing to Recover From Cancer Treatment

Content: When I meet Brealey in April 2016, in a brightly colored room at University College Hospital, sheÃ¢ÂÂs about to start her third drug Ã¢ÂÂ  a new one called nivolumab that her doctor, a young oncologist named Charlie Swanton, is hopeful about. As he preps her for the new treatment, he is also thinking about how to manage the severe pain that the tumor is causing, as it presses against the nerves that run along BrealeyÃ¢ÂÂs ribs. Ã¢ÂÂIt hasnÃ¢ÂÂt been easy for Laura,Ã¢ÂÂ says Swanton. Ã¢ÂÂWhen I first told her she couldnÃ¢ÂÂt go back to Singapore to visit her family. .. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ. .. I nearly fell off my chair in shock,Ã¢ÂÂ she finishes. Brealey, now 75, has bright blue eyes, short white hair, and preternaturally high spirits. Ã¢ÂÂMy best friendÃ¢ÂÂs brother calls me the Indestructible Laura. IÃ¢ÂÂm very active. Before this, I was going to the gym, doing   pilates, gardening. Now, I just sleep. This has been a nuisance. Ã¢ÂÂ She misses the theater, longs to return to Asia, dreams about going on the   Railway. When she mentions the tumor that is curtailing all of those plans, she talks as if it was an errant child. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs so stubborn,Ã¢ÂÂ she says.   BrealeyÃ¢ÂÂs story is typical. An initial wave of treatments seemed to knock a tumor out, but despite the scalpels, the radiation, and the drugs Ã¢ÂÂ  not to mention relentless optimism Ã¢ÂÂ  the tumor recurs, seemingly more resilient than before. Stubborn, as she says. Even the latest drugs, tailored to strike at the specific genetic faults behind a personÃ¢ÂÂs tumor, fail to permanently halt the backswing of a tumorÃ¢ÂÂs pendulum. The problem, according to Swanton and a growing group of other   scientists, is that weÃ¢ÂÂve been neglecting one of the most fundamental aspects of cancer Ã¢ÂÂ  that it is a disease of evolution. That might sound strange. WeÃ¢ÂÂre used to the idea that animals, plants, or microbes can evolve, but cancer isnÃ¢ÂÂt a   organism. ItÃ¢ÂÂs part of us. And yet, it also evolves, adapting to new challenges as surely as Galapagos finches. In the classical view of cancer, a cell picks up mutations until it shakes off the checks and balances that restrain its growth, allowing it to divide uncontrollably and turn into a tumor. This linear process is a macabre version of that famous image where a chimp walks to the right and gradually morphs into a human hunter. And both visuals are wrong. In reality, tumors quickly become seething masses of varied cells, all with their own mutations. One area might start growing faster its neighbor might come to evade the immune system. Over time, the fittest lineages produce more descendants and rise to dominance Ã¢ÂÂ  the essence of Darwinian natural selection. So forget the linear march. The better visual is that of a tree, with an initial trunk radiating into a web of branches. In 1837, Charles Darwin drew one such tree in one of his notebooks to represent how species evolve from a common ancestor. He could just as easily have been sketching the birth of a tumor. This realization goes some way to explaining why the war against cancer has been so entrenched and unexpectedly difficult. Clinicians often diagnose these diseases by taking a biopsy from a tumor, but a single sample could miss important mutations with very different prognostic implications just centimeters away. And when we hit tumors with drugs or radiation, we create a potent source of artificial selection, effectively breeding for hardier tumors. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs why relapses occur. Ã¢ÂÂWe deal with patients, day in and day out, whose disease initially benefits from chemo,Ã¢ÂÂ says Swanton. Ã¢ÂÂBut over time, they develop resistance against multiple drugs. The only way you can really fathom how a tumor can be one step ahead of the clinician at all times is through Darwinian selection. Ã¢ÂÂ The legendary biologist Theodosius Dobzhansky said that Ã¢ÂÂNothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution. Ã¢ÂÂ Cancer researchers are now learning that lesson. By understanding how cancer evolves, they hope to start thinking several moves ahead of the disease Ã¢ÂÂ  halting, redirecting, or even preventing its evolution. To start, in 2013, Swanton launched an ambitious study called TRACERx, which stands for Tracking Cancer Evolution through Treatment (Rx). ItÃ¢ÂÂs a    initiative to nail down the evolution of lung cancer. SwantonÃ¢ÂÂs team of over 200 collaborators followed 850 patients through their treatments, taking several samples from across their tumors at several points in time Ã¢ÂÂ  from diagnosis to treatment to either cure or relapse. They then used this information to understand how the cancers change over time, how that affects a patientÃ¢ÂÂs fate, how to detect that evolution, and how to beat it. Brealey, whose name has been changed for this story, was the 39th patient to sign up for TRACERx Ã¢ÂÂ  and when I meet her, she is dressed for the part. She holds up the pale stone necklace around her neck, which depicts a   tree. Ã¢ÂÂLook, IÃ¢ÂÂm wearing the tree of life,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂHow appropriate!Ã¢ÂÂ says Swanton, delighted. Ã¢ÂÂMaybe itÃ¢ÂÂs a good omen,Ã¢ÂÂ she adds. * * * His suggestions went largely unheeded because he made them at the wrong time. In the 1970s, molecular biology was the hot new thing, and scientists were swept up by new techniques for studying cells in incredible detail. Many biology departments split into separate factions, walling off those who studied tiny cells and molecules from those who studied entire organisms. Cancer researchers clustered with the former, and evolutionary biologists with the latter. Mel Greaves was an exception. Now the director of the Center for Evolution at The Institute of Cancer Research, Greaves studied at University College London in the 1960s, in a department that focused heavily on the principles of evolution. His mentors drummed into his head that cells within a body are also subject to natural selection, just like individuals within a species. So when he read NovellÃ¢ÂÂs paper, it blew his mind. Ã¢ÂÂI thought: This is fundamental. This is how cancer works. It just smelled right. It made me think about everything I was doing in that light,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Greaves carried that realization with him throughout his work on childhood leukemia. But he could only act upon it at the turn of the century Ã¢ÂÂ  when new technology allowed him to efficiently sequence the genomes of individual cancer cells. In 2010, Greaves and his team used to tools to study 30 leukemia patients. In each one, they identified the mutations within 200 cancerous cells, and compared them to see how the cells were related. Ã¢ÂÂImmediately, we saw trees,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂYou could find the simplest cell and work out its descendants and their descendants. Within two years, everyone was doing this. Ã¢ÂÂ For example, in 2012, Swanton and his colleagues found a similar metaphorical tree in a   tumor that they had cut out of a   patient. Even by eye, the variation was obvious. Ã¢ÂÂIt was a large lump, of course, but you could see individual nodules that had different colors,Ã¢ÂÂ recalls team member Marco Gerlinger. Ã¢ÂÂSome bled more. Some had this yellowish translucent appearance because they were storing fats. Others were brown and very dense because they lacked blood vessels. Ã¢ÂÂ In analyzing the tumor, Gerlinger and Swanton showed that this cancer was a world unto itself. Cells at one end had a different set of mutations from those at the other, or from secondary tumors that had spread around the patientÃ¢ÂÂs body. Of the 128 mutations that Swanton had detected, only a third of these were found throughout the patientÃ¢ÂÂs tumors. A quarter were unique to just one part. The same was true for three more kidney cancers that the team studied. Others found the same pattern in cancers of the esophagus, bowel, brain, breast, and more. Ã¢ÂÂEvery patient has several essentially independent cancers at one time,Ã¢ÂÂ says Greaves. Ã¢ÂÂThree to 20 in leukemia. Goodness knows how many in lung cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ Propelled by these discoveries, cancer research started evolving, too. The biggest cancer conferences were devoting keynote talks and entire sessions to the evolutionary side of cancer. When I went to one such session in 2014, a researcher joked to a huge, packed auditorium that Ã¢ÂÂwe used to be in the small room. Ã¢ÂÂ But this flurry of activity was tempered. Ã¢ÂÂThe reaction from oncologists was: Oh my God, this is bloody awful,Ã¢ÂÂ says Greaves. Ã¢ÂÂLook at all this complexity! ItÃ¢ÂÂs so pessimistic. And all I, Charlie, and others could say was: This is just what cancer is. We havenÃ¢ÂÂt understood the nature of the beast until now. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt feel daunted,Ã¢ÂÂ he adds, smiling. Ã¢ÂÂNow we know why the therapies are failing, why weÃ¢ÂÂre having such difficulty in eradicating the disease. ItÃ¢ÂÂs just like drug resistance in bacteria Ã¢ÂÂ  a rapidly evolving disease that weÃ¢ÂÂre racing to defeat. ItÃ¢ÂÂs an evolutionary arms race. Ã¢ÂÂ That insight, he says, is half the battle. The next half is working out what to do about it. * * * The diversity that Greaves, Swanton, and others have found explains why. A drug might successfully take out the vast majority of a tumorÃ¢ÂÂs cells, but even if a few survivors contain mutations that allow them to resist these assaults, they will repopulate. The cancer evolves its way around the drug, and the tumor recurs. Worse, tumors are diverse, so targeted therapies only might hit one part of the entire mass, leaving behind a reservoir of genetically different cells to grow anew. Targeted therapies are powerful, but cancer is a target with many bullseyes that shift position whenever struck. Ã¢ÂÂThis realization prompted me to change the way I think,Ã¢ÂÂ says Alberto Bardelli, an oncologist at the University of Torino, who studies targeted therapies. Rather than going after specific cancer genes, Ã¢ÂÂwe need to target the evolution of tumors Ã¢ÂÂ  how they change over time. Then weÃ¢ÂÂll make progress much more quickly. Ã¢ÂÂ For a start, reconstructing the evolution of cancer can help researchers to pick the right targets. Some mutations occur early in a tumorÃ¢ÂÂs life and are found in all of its cells Ã¢ÂÂ  theyÃ¢ÂÂre called trunk mutations. Others occur later are found in small regions Ã¢ÂÂ  branch mutations. Ã¢ÂÂIf youÃ¢ÂÂre going to target mutations, for goodness sake go for the trunk ones,Ã¢ÂÂ says Greaves. Ã¢ÂÂOtherwise itÃ¢ÂÂs like pruning a bush Ã¢ÂÂ  youÃ¢ÂÂll just stimulate growth. Ã¢ÂÂ ItÃ¢ÂÂs no coincidence that Gleevec, one of the most successful target therapies around, works by targeting a trunk mutation in leukemia Ã¢ÂÂ  one that almost always occurs at the very start of the disease. Ã¢ÂÂIt hits every cell, which is why it works pretty well,Ã¢ÂÂ says Greaves. Other scientists have started to identify common trunk mutations in other cancers. Attacking these is certainly a better strategy than ineffectually hacking at the branches, but it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt change the fact that tumors could adapt and regrow. A better tactic might be to use combinations of targeted drugs Ã¢ÂÂ  one to target mutations that already exist, and others to attack those that are likely to occur. Many cancers involve mutations in a gene called EGFR, and a drug called cetuximab was designed to block this gene. But tumors that initially shrink in the face of cetuximab invariably bounce back Ã¢ÂÂ  many because of mutations in a second gene called MEK. By using cetuximab and a   drug, Bardelli managed to successfully treat bowel cancers in mice, without any relapse. He had cut the tumors off from their usual evolutionary escape routes, intercepting resistance rather than simply reacting to it. As Robert Gatenby from the Lee Moffit Cancer Center and his colleagues once put it, Ã¢ÂÂIt is chess, not   . Ã¢ÂÂ But Banerji thinks this approach is unlikely to work in practice because the side effect of chemotherapies become too toxic when drugs are given in combination. You might kill a tumor Ã¢ÂÂ  but youÃ¢ÂÂll take the patient along with it. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂve looked at multiple ways of doing it and exhausted all the combinations,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs not going to be  . Ã¢ÂÂ Their opponent is nothing less than evolution itself Ã¢ÂÂ  the most dangerous foe of all, with a counter for every move. As the British chemist Leslie Orgel once said, Ã¢ÂÂEvolution is cleverer than you are. Ã¢ÂÂ So rather than opposing the inevitable evolution of cancer, it might be better to redirect it. Ã¢ÂÂEverything comes at a cost in evolution,Ã¢ÂÂ says BanerjiÃ¢ÂÂs colleague Andrea Sottoriva. Ã¢ÂÂBy standing up on two feet, we free up our hands but we canÃ¢ÂÂt outrun a lion. Ã¢ÂÂ In the same way, a mutation that allows cancer cells to resist a drug might also, say, slow their growth. This means that resistant cells only do better than their sensitive cousins in the presence of a drug Ã¢ÂÂ  under normal conditions, theyÃ¢ÂÂre less competitive. Doctors could potentially exploit this weakness by giving treatments in waves. Hit a tumor with a drug, and the sensitive cells die off while the resistant ones start to grow. Stop the drug, to let the sensitive cells bounce back. Rinse and repeat. The goal of this Ã¢ÂÂadaptive therapyÃ¢ÂÂ isnÃ¢ÂÂt to destroy the tumor, but to keep it in balance. Gatenby tried this approach on breast cancers in mice. By varying doses, he managed to control the growth of the animalsÃ¢ÂÂ tumors, despite frequently skipping treatments for weeks at a time. Other scientists are going after the evolutionary process itself. Swanton has shown that some kidney tumors have trunk mutations in a gene called SETD2 that helps to repair DNA damage. Ã¢ÂÂGenes like this maintain the integrity of the genome,Ã¢ÂÂ he explains. Mutating them doesnÃ¢ÂÂt lead to cancer directly, but it does nix a cellÃ¢ÂÂs ability to repair errors in its own DNA and ensures that further mutations accrue more quickly. In other words, these mutations make cells more evolvable. By targeting them, it might be possible to slow the evolution of cancers altogether. Even simple substances like aspirin might do the trick. This drug is known to reduce the risk of bowel, esophageal, and pancreatic cancers. Partly, this might be because it puts the brakes on a tumorÃ¢ÂÂs early evolution. In a study of people with BarrettÃ¢ÂÂs esophagus Ã¢ÂÂ  a condition that often leads to esophageal cancer Ã¢ÂÂ  Carlo Maley from Arizona State University found that mutations arise 13 times faster when people donÃ¢ÂÂt take aspirin than when they swallow the drug. Ã¢ÂÂThe study was small It was just 13 patients, and ideally, IÃ¢ÂÂd want to confirm it in a large cohort of people, half of whom are randomly given aspirin,Ã¢ÂÂ Maley admits. But he adds that the broader idea of averting evolution before it has a chance to get going Ã¢ÂÂ  and prevent cancers before drug resistance is even an issue Ã¢ÂÂ  is the right one. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre not trying to beat evolution but to manage it, which sounds plausible to me,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂThe field is still dominated by cancer therapy but we should focus on cancer prevention. We should intervene before it becomes such a hard problem. Ã¢ÂÂ * * * The first results from their TRACERx study are finally published today in two companion papers. In the first, the team focused on the first 100 patients Ã¢ÂÂ  Brealey included Ã¢ÂÂ  of the 842 they have since recruited. Again, they found that each tumor is a world in itself. In total,   of the mutations they found were in the branches of the tumor, restricted only to particular parts of the mass. Some patients had just a handful of these branches. One had 2, 310. These mutations are like single typos in a book, but SwantonÃ¢ÂÂs team found evidence of larger chromosomal rearrangements Ã¢ÂÂ  the equivalent of entire paragraphs being duplicated, deleted, or rearranged. On average, these   changes affected half of a tumorÃ¢ÂÂs genome, and patients with high levels were five times more likely to experience recurrence than those with low levels. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs an incredibly complex disease,Ã¢ÂÂ says Swanton. Ã¢ÂÂIt has a lot more instability than what we saw in kidney cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ Worse still, this instability can rewire a lung cancerÃ¢ÂÂs evolutionary history, altering the trunk mutations that ought to be present and consistent throughout a tumor. In other words, as lung cancer evolves, the trunk can turn into branches, which means that going after the trunk mutations is unlikely to be lung cancerÃ¢ÂÂs downfall. Still, Swanton sees reason for hope. His team showed that many of these   changes are caused by a family of   enzymes called APOBEC. These are usually involved in immune responses, but seems to go rogue in lung cancer Ã¢ÂÂ  and several other types Ã¢ÂÂ  providing what Swanton calls Ã¢ÂÂmutagenic fuel for cancer evolution. Ã¢ÂÂ Even in heavy smokers, APOBEC enzymes can create even more mutations than the potent   chemicals in tobacco smoke. Ã¢ÂÂThere are multiple efforts going on around the globe to target the enzyme and arrest evolution in its tracks,Ã¢ÂÂ says Swanton. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm really excited about this. Ã¢ÂÂ Such efforts may take a long time to bear fruit, but the acceptance of cancerÃ¢ÂÂs evolutionary side is already changing how clinicians approach the disease.
