Doctors typically take a single biopsy of a patientÃ¢ÂÂs tumor at the time of diagnosis, and use that sample to make decisions about treatments, even if the tumor recurs. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs like using last decadeÃ¢ÂÂs stock information to guide tomorrowÃ¢ÂÂs investments. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂve accepted that profiling those archived tumors could be doing the patients a disservice,Ã¢ÂÂ says Samra Turajlic, one of SwantonÃ¢ÂÂs colleagues. Ã¢ÂÂWe now try to get the most recent and representative verison of the patientÃ¢ÂÂs disease. But biopsies wonÃ¢ÂÂt cut it Ã¢ÂÂ  itÃ¢ÂÂs impractical to keep on slicing chunks out of a patientÃ¢ÂÂs tumor over time, and as SwantonÃ¢ÂÂs work has shown, you need several such slices from different regions to really capture a tumorÃ¢ÂÂs diversity. Fortunately, thereÃ¢ÂÂs another option. In the second of the two TRACERx papers, SwantonÃ¢ÂÂs team showed that ctDNA provides an edifying look at lung cancer, too. In some cases, patients showed increasing levels of ctDNA immediately after surgery, showing that their tumors were bouncing back despite the chemotherapy that they were taking. In other cases, the   DNA revealed the presence of new branch mutations, suggesting that tumors were relapsing several months before they became visible on CT scans. It could act as a marker that reveals how cancers evolve in   and it could reveal the efficacy of measures designed to curb that evolution. As ever, there are caveats. Modern techniques for sequencing ctDNA are still too expensive to be used regularly in the clinic, and they arenÃ¢ÂÂt sensitive enough to detect cancers at their earliest stages. ItÃ¢ÂÂs also still unclear exactly how representative the floating DNA is of tumors as a whole. But Swanton thinks that these hurdles can be overcome. Ã¢ÂÂTen years from now, IÃ¢ÂÂd like to see us doing this regularly Ã¢ÂÂ  using circulating DNA to constantly monitor disease over space and time, and alter our therapies accordingly,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Five years ago, his big kidney cancer left him pessimistic and unsettled. But like the diseases he studies, he too has rebounded. Ã¢ÂÂI was pretty depressed when we first started on this route, but IÃ¢ÂÂve come out the other side,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂAnd IÃ¢ÂÂve been getting pretty optimistic in the last couple of years. By understanding and embracing the complexity, we can fight it. Ã¢ÂÂ 	A haunting documentary about a West Virginia town plagued by painkiller addiction
Title: How to Fight Cancer (When Cancer Fights Back)

Content: , I want to receive updates from partners and sponsors. Mary Elizabeth Williams was just 44, a staff writer at Salon and a mother of two who was freshly reunited with her husband (from whom she had separated two years earlier) when she noticed a bump about the size of a pencil eraser on her scalp. It didnÃ¢ÂÂt hurt. It didnÃ¢ÂÂt itch. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm sorry to tell you this,Ã¢ÂÂ her dermatologist said, Ã¢ÂÂbut you have malignant melanoma,Ã¢ÂÂ a cancer that kills some 10, 000 people annually. Back then, in 2010, her tumor was only Stage 2. But a year after it was removed Ã¢ÂÂ  along with a chunk of her scalp Ã¢ÂÂ  the disease came back. This time it was Stage 4 there is no Stage 5. Her   prognosis? She could have as little as six months to live. Then she got lucky: She qualified for a clinical trial at New YorkÃ¢ÂÂs Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, testing drugs that were supposed to harness a patientÃ¢ÂÂs immune system against the disease. As the first line of her new memoir reveals, Ã¢ÂÂSpoiler: I lived. Ã¢ÂÂ Written with candor, humor (Ã¢ÂÂDonÃ¢ÂÂt think of it as losing your hair Ã¢ÂÂ  think of it as a   Brazilian! Ã¢ÂÂ) and just the right amount of rage, WilliamsÃ¢ÂÂs book, A Series of Catastrophes and Miracles, is about the ravages of metastatic disease and the innovations of science, but itÃ¢ÂÂs equally about resilience. Most of all, perhaps, it is about womenÃ¢ÂÂs friendship: WilliamsÃ¢ÂÂs college roommate, Debbie, died of ovarian cancer right when Williams learned that she herself was cured. On the day Williams spoke with me, she had just lost another friend to cancer, a    law school graduate who had begun a treatment program similar to the one that had saved Williams. Ã¢ÂÂIt sucks,Ã¢ÂÂ she told me. Ã¢ÂÂIt fucking sucks. Ã¢ÂÂ Having been through treatment for breast cancer twice Ã¢ÂÂ  and lost my mother to pancreatic cancer earlier this year Ã¢ÂÂ  I understood that sentiment all too well. Here, Williams talks about living with   disease, her experience with the sometimes hollow,   culture of cancer activism, and how, despite all the bleakness, she found beauty. Orenstein: Many cancer memoirs are written by people with   disease who, no surprise, survive. How is your book different? Williams: Even within the cancer community, a lot of advocacy groups donÃ¢ÂÂt want to talk about people with Stage 4 disease. They want that inspirational story of Ã¢ÂÂI kicked cancerÃ¢ÂÂs butt!Ã¢ÂÂ If itÃ¢ÂÂs a darker scenario, or just a more complicated one, you are ignored. That frustrated me as a person and as a reader. I wasnÃ¢ÂÂt seeing stories about people who were living [with the disease] like I was. Orenstein: What was it like to find out that you had Stage 4 cancer? Williams: It was surreal. You leave your body for a time. When I hear about people who are Stage 4 for years   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     How do you basically live on death row never knowing whether youÃ¢ÂÂre going to get a reprieve from the governor or if youÃ¢ÂÂre going to get sent to the chair? And you canÃ¢ÂÂt just stop doing your regular life. You have to take care of your kids. You have to do your job. You have to do your laundry. Orenstein: You canÃ¢ÂÂt sit around and wait to die. Williams: Right. My kids and I got lice right after my second diagnosis. Maybe thatÃ¢ÂÂs why laundry is uppermost in my mind. I did so much laundry. And you want to do that everyday stuff, until you become really incapacitated. I certainly saw that with my friend Debbie. You want to hang out with your friends. You want to read a book. You want to do whatever you can. Orenstein: Do you feel survivor guilt over your friendÃ¢ÂÂs death? Williams: Years ago I went to a reading by an author who had served in Vietnam. I hate the whole battle metaphor, that cancer is like war, but he said something great. He said, Ã¢ÂÂYou go to basic training with these guys. You go in the trenches with them. You see every horror imaginable together. Then one day one of them gets a bullet through him and you donÃ¢ÂÂt. And youÃ¢ÂÂre happy. And then you live with that for the rest of your life. Ã¢ÂÂ ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what it is: ItÃ¢ÂÂs the guilt of being happy. I get to live my life. I get to listen to music and eat cake Ã¢ÂÂ  and Debbie doesnÃ¢ÂÂt. Of course I feel guilt. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs okay. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not my fault that I got sick or that I got better either, but I want to always respect that I have a privilege that so many, including people I loved, do not. Orenstein: WhatÃ¢ÂÂs the experimental therapy that is responsible for your being here? Williams: Immunotherapy is different from conventional cancer treatment Ã¢ÂÂ  surgery, radiation, and chemo Ã¢ÂÂ  which will probably one day be looked back on as barbaric. The way that cancer works is that it scrambles the signals of your bodyÃ¢ÂÂs defenses and confuses your immune system, allowing the mutant cells to multiply. What immunotherapy does is override that confusion so your [your immune system goes] after the cancer anyway. There are different kinds of immunotherapy. There are vaccines in development. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs adoptive   transfers, where a patientÃ¢ÂÂs cells are collected,   and then reintroduced into the body to fight cancer. ItÃ¢ÂÂs brilliant, but you can understand why discovering this took decades of trial and error. And a lot of immune therapy comes out of the lessons of other forms of immune treatment, including AIDS research. Orenstein: How quickly did it work for you? Williams: A tumor had grown on my back, and after my first treatment, I could actually see it shrinking. [Now that the FDA has approved this drug therapy,] the next challenge is figuring out why it works for some of us and not for others. During treatment I put up a poster in my bedroom that says, Ã¢ÂÂWhen the odds are a million to one, be the one. Ã¢ÂÂ But you know what? I donÃ¢ÂÂt want to be the only Ã¢ÂÂone. Ã¢ÂÂ Orenstein: You were raising two kids while going through all this. How did you handle being both a patient and a parent? Williams: My husband and I were always transparent with the kids. They saw me cry they saw me get scared. We used words like died rather than passed away. Now I see the kids as these amazing, compassionate,   people who know how to comfort others and who have made space in their life for death. That is so unusual in our culture. I want my kids to have a relationship with the fluidity of life Ã¢ÂÂ  with the fact that sometimes people get sick and sometimes bad things happen, and to know that within that there is also grace, thereÃ¢ÂÂs also beauty, thereÃ¢ÂÂs also comfort. Because if you go down into the depths, there is treasure there. Cancer still sucks, but thereÃ¢ÂÂs also profound connection. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the privilege of allowing yourself to participate in the full experience of humanity, which includes grief and sickness and death. If you donÃ¢ÂÂt look at [those things] youÃ¢ÂÂre not living. Orenstein: At the same time, you never romanticize illness in the book. And from the day you show up at the doctorÃ¢ÂÂs in a   that says FUCK CANCER, you resist what I think of as the tyranny of the positive attitude. Williams: ThereÃ¢ÂÂs this assumption that because you got better, you did it courageously. But thatÃ¢ÂÂs not my story. I didnÃ¢ÂÂt Ã¢ÂÂwarriorÃ¢ÂÂ my way into getting better. It was not my achievement it was scienceÃ¢ÂÂs. Whenever I hear someone say Ã¢ÂÂI beat cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ it just feels so disrespectful to others, such as my friend Debbie. It divides us into winners and losers. I know itÃ¢ÂÂs not deliberate. We want to make meaning. We want to make sense of it. But you see how random [survival] is. I have known people who were healthier than me and younger than me who tried, I think, harder than I did to fight their cancer but who didnÃ¢ÂÂt live. Orenstein: Tell me the significance of the butterfly on the cover of your book. Williams: The story is about losing something Ã¢ÂÂ  yourself, people you loved, what you thought you knew about the world Ã¢ÂÂ  yet still being whole. Butterflies are all about transformation. I try to see the beauty in all the damage. I try to see the beauty in all the ruin. And I definitely see the love.             Like this? Subscribe to the Atlantic Daily, a newsletter with stories,             ideas, and images from The Atlantic.
Title: Surviving Cancer Without the Positive Thinking

Content: I want to receive updates from partners and sponsors. In the northwest coast of Spain, a delicious clam called the golden carpet shell is suffering from an extraordinary type of cancer Ã¢ÂÂ  a contagious leukemia.   Almost every other case of cancer in animals Ã¢ÂÂ  including humans Ã¢ÂÂ  begins when a single cell in an individual starts growing and dividing uncontrollably, producing a tumor. If the tumor kills its host, it dies too. But the clamÃ¢ÂÂs leukemia is caused by cancer cells that have become independent parasites they can travel between individuals, creating fresh tumors in each new host. And if that wasnÃ¢ÂÂt astonishing enough, this transmissible tumor didnÃ¢ÂÂt even originate in a golden carpet shell. Instead, its genes reveal that it first arose in a related species Ã¢ÂÂ  the pullet shell. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the first known cancer that not only jumps into new hosts but has, at least once, leapt over the species barrier. Some cancers are caused by contagious things like HPV, the virus that causes cervical cancer, or Helicobacter pylori, a bacterium that causes stomach cancer. But in these cases, the tumor cells themselves stay put. ItÃ¢ÂÂs so exceptional for cancers to become infectious in their own right that until a year ago, scientists knew of only two types that did so. One is a facial tumor that infects Tasmanian devils. It evolved recently, spreads through bites, and threatens the future of its hosts. The second is a far older veneral tumor that affects dogs. It arose 11, 000 years ago and has spread to six continents. A third example emerged last year. Along North AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs east coast,   clams were dying from a strange type of leukemia. Michael Metzger and Stephen Goff,  scientists from Columbia University, studied these cancers and found that they were all genetically identical to each other, but genetically distinct from their hosts. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs the same pattern seen in the Tasmanian devil and dog tumors Ã¢ÂÂ  a  clear sign that these cancers arrive in their hosts, rather than originating from them. They drift through the sea, these selfish shellfish cells, traveling from one   clam to another. Intrigued, Metzger and Goff polled their marine biologist colleagues and learned that many other shellfish species are afflicted by similar rapidly spreading leukemias. They collected cockles and golden carpet shell clams from the coast of Spain, and mussels from the coast of Vancouver. In all three cases, they found the same signature pattern: a genetic match between all the tumors, and a mismatch between each tumor and its respective host. Ã¢ÂÂPrior to this, we believed that transmissible cancers were bizarre flukes of nature that happened due to a set of unfortunate coincidences in very unlucky species,Ã¢ÂÂ says Elizabeth Murchison, a University of Cambridge cancer researcher who studies the Tasmanian devil tumor. Instead, they are Ã¢ÂÂprobably relatively common, at least some bivalves, and the processes whereby cancers become transmissible are not as rare as we previously thought. Ã¢ÂÂ Indeed, Metzger and Goff found that cockles have given risen to two strains of contagious cancer. Their tumors belonged to two distinctive lineages, each of which seems to have independently arisen from a different healthy cell. That explains why the same disease presents in two distinct ways, characterized by cells that look different under the microscope. Ã¢ÂÂPeople noted that, said, Ã¢ÂÂIsnÃ¢ÂÂt that odd?Ã¢ÂÂ and moved on,Ã¢ÂÂ says Goff. Ã¢ÂÂThis explains the mystery. Ã¢ÂÂ   ThereÃ¢ÂÂs precedent for a dual origin. Earlier this year, Murchison showed that the Tasmanian devilÃ¢ÂÂs contagious tumor also arose twice. Ã¢ÂÂWe absolutely couldnÃ¢ÂÂt believe it,Ã¢ÂÂ she told me at the time. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs the last thing I could have possibly imagined. Ã¢ÂÂ It might now be the    thing. A bigger surprise came when Metzger and Goff studied the golden carpet shells. Their tumors were not just genetically distinct from their hosts, but wildly so, with matches as low as 78 percent for certain critical genes. Ã¢ÂÂThey werenÃ¢ÂÂt even close,Ã¢ÂÂ says Goff. Ã¢ÂÂWe then realized they were a near perfect match to the cells of another species, the pullet shell. Ã¢ÂÂ The cells must have originated there before jumping into the golden carpets. Oddly, the pullet shells themselves show no signs of the cancer. They may have given rise to it, but they no longer suffer from it. Why? Ã¢ÂÂOne could imagine that the    is now resistant to the tumor,Ã¢ÂÂ says Goff, Ã¢ÂÂbut we donÃ¢ÂÂt know that. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂIt would be good to know how the tumors are transmitted in nature,Ã¢ÂÂ says Clare Rebbeck, from the University of Cambridge.  On land, devils and dogs can only spread their tumors by biting and mating. In the water, Goff thinks that transmission might be far easier. The infected mollusks release cancer cells in their feces, so every time they poop, they seed the water with transmissible tumors. And since they are   that sieve through huge volumes of seawater, they are also   to picking up the cells from their neighbors. This might also explain why shellfish seem to be so uniquely susceptible to contagious cancers. Goff guesses that their immune systems are involved, too. Human immune systems would usually stop incompatible foreign cells from setting up shop in our bodies thatÃ¢ÂÂs why people have to take immunosuppressive drugs before receiving organ transplants. Ã¢ÂÂThe most fascinating aspect of transmissible cancers is their ability to avoid those immune responses,Ã¢ÂÂ says Hannah Siddle from the University of Southampton. Ã¢ÂÂAnd the transmission of cells across a species barrier is even more striking. Ã¢ÂÂ Fortunately Ã¢ÂÂ  for us, if not the clams and mussels Ã¢ÂÂ  thereÃ¢ÂÂs no evidence that these cells could affect humans, or that we are plagued by any contagious cancer at all. Ã¢ÂÂI would only worry deeply if I was a mollusk,Ã¢ÂÂ Goff says. Ã¢ÂÂCould it happen in rare circumstances? WeÃ¢ÂÂd be eager to look for that. It would presumably have to happen between genetically closely matched peers, or people who are profoundly  . Ã¢ÂÂ Still, his discovery adds to the growing realization that contagious cancers are more common than anyone assumed. There are now eight of them, and they are organisms unlike anything else. Since time immemorial, people have dreamed of immortality. WeÃ¢ÂÂve filled our fiction with vampires, elves, fountains of youth, horcruxes, and the Singularity. Well, in the real world, this is what immortality looks like. Each of these eight contagious cancers represents a single animal Ã¢ÂÂ  a dog, two Tasmanian devils, and a handful shellfish Ã¢ÂÂ  whose original body is long dead, but that lives on as dynasties of cells that propagate in new hosts.
Title: The Contagious Cancer That Jumped Between Species

Content: For us to continue writing great stories, we need to display ads.             Please select the extension that is blocking ads.     Please follow the steps below,         This article is part of a feature we also send out via email as The Atlantic Daily, a newsletter with stories, ideas, and images from The Atlantic, written specially for subscribers. To sign up, please enter your email address in the field provided here.     A   Victory: The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals has struck down a Texan law requiring voters to show ID, ruling that the law was racially discriminatory as it disproportionately burdened black and Hispanic voters. Should Texas fight the ruling, its next step will be an appeal to the Supreme Court. TurkeyÃ¢ÂÂs State of Emergency: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has declared a   state of emergency as his governmentÃ¢ÂÂs crackdown on TurkeyÃ¢ÂÂs military, judiciary, educational institutions, and civil service continues after the attempted coup last Friday. What Erdogan does next is likely to signal his final agenda for Turkey. A New Cancer Treatment: A team of scientists at the University of California, San Diego, have engineered Salmonella bacteria to kill tumors by producing   drugs that are delivered when they  . So far, itÃ¢ÂÂs only been tested on laboratory cells and mice, but the treatment technology is promising Ã¢ÂÂ  not only for cancer, but also for other diseases that require regular drug treatments, such as diabetes and high blood pressure. Donald Trump officially became the Republican nominee last night, and his running mate Mike Pence is in the spotlight Ã¢ÂÂ  yet the strongest force unifying Republicans seems to be a shared hatred of Hillary Clinton. Our veteran political writer, James Fallows, is in Cleveland for the convention Ã¢ÂÂ  the 11th of his career Ã¢ÂÂ  and is blogging about the memorable moments: When Trump was mentioned in The Atlantic for the first time. The 1992 story involves a   poll, and two very active phone numbers. When recycling became a Trump family tradition. Donald Trump Jr. may not have plagiarized his speech, but after MelaniaÃ¢ÂÂs debacle, you would think heÃ¢ÂÂd be more careful. When Trump got a new set of campaign rules. As a reader points out, heÃ¢ÂÂs seemingly immune to scandal. How did it happen? Read all of our convention coverage here, and follow tonightÃ¢ÂÂs   from our politics team here. Ã¢ÂÂYou can feel like making $800, 000 is almost like living in poverty. Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ  Sam Polk, a former stock trader, on Wall Street culture, Ã¢ÂÂThreatening to jail your opponent is mean. Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ  Alex Castellanos, a GOP consultant, Ã¢ÂÂIt is actually more important than ever today not to do things completely out of fear. Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ  Wagaye Johannes, who works to increase the number of U. S. students who study abroad, James Elliott on a controversial method for autism communication, in which Ã¢ÂÂcommunication partnersÃ¢ÂÂ are said to help people with the condition express themselves: Such partners Ã¢ÂÂ  alternatively called Ã¢ÂÂfacilitators,Ã¢ÂÂ among other terms Ã¢ÂÂ  are not akin to translators, who merely take on valid means of communication and frame it into another, but are the means of communication itself. Whereas someone who speaks French or American sign language has alternative means of verifying their communication (such as in writing) a person with a condition that can affect communication, such as autism, may lack any other means of verifying that what is being communicated to the listener accurately reflects what the person is trying to say. Not only does this run the very real danger of providing incorrect services and supports to the person, stemming as they will from the facilitatorÃ¢ÂÂs judgment and not the personÃ¢ÂÂs, mistaking the source can have real, profound consequences: Families have been torn apart by spurious accusations of abuse, including sexual abuse. Worse, such communication has been used to try to justify the abuse itself. Continue reading here. You can see our readersÃ¢ÂÂ stories about autism, and add your own, here. 1. The chemicals in limes make human skin extra sensitive to ____________, which can lead to a condition called margarita burn. (Scroll down for the answer, or find it here.) 2. ______________, who created the sitcoms Happy Days and Mork  Mindy, also directed the movies Pretty Woman, Beaches, and The Princess Diaries.  (Scroll down for the answer, or find it here.) 3. More than ____________ local, state, and federal police have been assigned to cover the Republican National Convention. (Scroll down for the answer, or find it here.) Could national service bring Americans together? This reader says yes: As a veteran, I am flummoxed by the level of political vitriol some people hold. I served next to men and women from all kinds of backgrounds Ã¢ÂÂ  the children of missionaries with a loose grasp of pop culture, farm kids, young people whoÃ¢ÂÂd been homeless before the military, children of hippies rebelling against their parents, people from the island territories, children of influential families, people with political ambition, Muslims, Mormons, atheists, socialists, libertarians, you name it. We had lots of fascinating discussions on guard shifts in the wee hours of the morning. Our differences were no obstacle to the mission. We worked together regardless. Indeed, we benefited from a variety of perspectives. And we had each otherÃ¢ÂÂs backs when our lives were on the line in a war zone. But this reader doubts it: Austria is one of the few developed countries with mandatory national service. Their latest election was between the Green Party and a party with   roots. Greece has mandatory service too, and their politics are also now dominated by a   party with an openly   party in the wings. Israel has mandatory national service, and is a   for divisive politics. Singapore has mandatory national service, and itÃ¢ÂÂs a program that the government uses to quash dissent and enforce conformity to the party line. Read more here, and join the debate via hello@theatlantic. com. Floating doughnuts disputed, national rectangles ranked, mini border wall erected, tooth secrets told. Answers: Sunlight, Garry Marshall, 5, 000
Title: The Atlantic Daily: Voting Rights in Texas, TurkeyÃ¢ÂÂs Crackdown, Cancer-Fighting Salmonella

Content: For us to continue writing great stories, we need to display ads.             Please select the extension that is blocking ads.     Please follow the steps below, NEWS BRIEF U. S. Democratic Representative Mark Takai of Hawaii died Wednesday, two months after announcing he wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt seek a second term in Congress. Takai, 49, was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer last fall, and in the following months, he channeled his personal experiences into advocacy for cancer research. He was a strong supporter of Vice President BidenÃ¢ÂÂs cancer Ã¢ÂÂmoonshotÃ¢ÂÂ initiative and a member of two   caucuses in the House of Representatives. A Victory For Voting Rights in Texas, Takai initially planned to continue campaigning despite his diagnosis and announced a reelection campaign this past winter. But in May, Takai revealed his cancer had spread and he was dropping out of the race. According to Honolulu Civil Beat, former Representative Colleen Hanabusa was an Ã¢ÂÂearly favoriteÃ¢ÂÂ to fill his seat when she formally declared her candidacy in June, and Takai supported her bid. The seat is safely blue. Ã¢ÂÂIn life, we often make plans for ourselves,Ã¢ÂÂ Takai said when he revealed his plans not to run for reelection. Ã¢ÂÂI had envisioned a long career in the U. S. House of Representatives, building up the seniority and influence that were key to Senator [Daniel] InouyeÃ¢ÂÂs ability to deliver for Hawaii.   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     But as often happens, we find ourselves on a different journey than what we had planned. Ã¢ÂÂ In a statement Wednesday, his family thanked their fellow islanders for their support, and asked for privacy. Although Takai spent less than one full term in Congress, he was a longtime public servant. He worked for two decades in the Hawaii statehouse and was a lieutenant colonel in the Hawaii Army National Guard. Ã¢ÂÂIn his service to America and the people of Hawaii, Congressman Takai embodied our nationÃ¢ÂÂs highest ideals,Ã¢ÂÂ House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said in a statement Wednesday. Ã¢ÂÂIn his fight against cancer, Mark showed the courage and strength that defined the wonderful person he was. Ã¢ÂÂ Those sentiments were echoed by his other colleagues Wednesday as they learned the news, as The Washington Post reports.
Title: A Hawaii Congressman Dies After a Months-Long Cancer Fight

Content: I want to receive updates from partners and sponsors. Salmonella bacteria are best known as a causes of food poisoning and typhoid fever. Every year, they sicken millions of people. But those in Jeff HastyÃ¢ÂÂs lab at the University of California, San Diego, are different. TheyÃ¢ÂÂve been neutered and modified so that rather than causing   they kill tumors. HastyÃ¢ÂÂs team has engineered the microbes to produce a variety of   drugs, and to   when they reach a certain density. In their death throes, the bacteria release their toxic payloads to kill the tumor cells around them. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs like a kamikaze mission,Ã¢ÂÂ says Hasty. But not all the bacteria die. About 10 percent of them survive and can   the population, triggering many more rounds of   and drug delivery. These engineered microbes have only been tested in laboratory cells and mice. Needless to say, there are many unresolved questions about safety and efficiency, and this preliminary approach is a long way from being a legitimate cancer treatment. But thatÃ¢ÂÂs almost not the point. What Hasty has created is a probiotic on a timer Ã¢ÂÂ  or rather, with a snooze button. HeÃ¢ÂÂs proved that itÃ¢ÂÂs possible to engineer bacteria to produce and release drugs at regular intervals, to the beat of a genetic metronome that he can set. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs useful not just for cancer, but for diseases like diabetes and high blood pressure that require regular doses of medicine. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs going to open up opportunities more general than cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ says Hasty. ItÃ¢ÂÂs part of a growing number of attempts to turn the bacteria that share our lives Ã¢ÂÂ  the microbiome Ã¢ÂÂ  into medical assistants. Scientists and doctors have been trying to use bacteria to fight cancer for more than a century. In 1891, the surgeon William Coley infected cancer patients with Streptoccocus, thinking that the microbes would trigger an immune response that would also destroy the cancer cells. Coley treated over a thousand people in this way, and although some recovered, others didnÃ¢ÂÂt. Amid mixed results, the approach fell into neglect. It resurfaced when doctors started realizing that tumors were not sterile, as had long been thought, but often contains multitudes of microbes. The   bacteria that thrive in our gut can readily grow in the interior of tumors, which are similarly low in oxygen and sheltered from patrolling immune cells. The presence of such microbes was attractive to scientists because one of the big challenges in cancer medicine is actually getting drugs into tumours in the first place. If   microbes could be engineered to make those drugs, they could be the perfect Trojan horses. First, you need to pick the right microbe. Salmonella is a good choice. It can survive without oxygen and readily accumulates in tumors. ItÃ¢ÂÂs also closely related to Escherichia coli, the favoued bacterium of the modern biologist. Which means that all the techniques that geneticists have developed for engineering E. coli can be used to modify Salmonella too. Ã¢ÂÂWe can quickly leverage an enormous toolbox,Ã¢ÂÂ says Hasty. But, wait Ã¢ÂÂ  bacteria are living things. They grow. They multiply. They trigger immune responses. Other scientists have tested engineered strains of   Salmonella, with poor results. Ã¢ÂÂWe killed our mice,Ã¢ÂÂ says Seigfried Weiss from the Helmholtz Centre for Infection Research. Ã¢ÂÂThey had such a high load of bacteria that they probably suffered a toxic shock. Ã¢ÂÂ So if you want to use Salmonella to shuttle drugs into tumors, you need some way of controlling their numbers. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what HastyÃ¢ÂÂs team, led by student Omar Din, developed. They started with a   strain of Salmonella that doesnÃ¢ÂÂt cause disease, and gave it the ability to make an   drug. They also added genes that   viruses use to destroy their victims, and cleverly wired these up to genes that Salmonella and other bacteria use to sense each other. The result is a   microbe with   population control. Once the population hits a certain size, 90 percent of the cells rupture synchronously, releasing their cargo. The survivors can then repopulate, and the whole cycle beings again, like clockwork. Of course, Ã¢ÂÂyouÃ¢ÂÂre still putting in a live Salmonella strain,Ã¢ÂÂ says Beth McCormick from the University of Massachusetts Medical School. They might be neutered but theyÃ¢ÂÂre still bacteria, and they could still trigger inflammation and other immune problems. Ã¢ÂÂBut these synchronized circuits allow a persistent but low state of infection, which might overcome the issue with immune responses. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a great preliminary step. Ã¢ÂÂ The   approach doesnÃ¢ÂÂt just stop the bacteria from  . It also delivers a big pulse of a drug directly to the site of a tumor. And it makes it easy to program the bacteria to release many kinds of drugs. HastyÃ¢ÂÂs team tested three: a   toxin that bores into mammalian cells, a substance that stimulates the immune system, and one that causes cancer cells to commit suicide. The teamÃ¢ÂÂs colleagues, led by Sangeeta Bhatia at MIT, then tested these microbes in mice with incurable tumors that had spread to their livers. On their own, the bacteria did no better than a standard chemotherapy drug. But when the team used both together, the tumors shrank by a third and the mice lived 50 percent longer. That makes sense, says Hasty. Ã¢ÂÂSalmonella can grow in the   region inside the tumor, where chemotherapy isnÃ¢ÂÂt as effective. The bacteria get behind enemy lines and work from the inside out while the chemotherapy works at the growing rim of the tumour. Ã¢ÂÂ ThatÃ¢ÂÂs promising, but there are many kinks to iron out. If the bacteria were ever to be tested in humans, theyÃ¢ÂÂd need more safety features to stop them from growing, spreading, or mutating unpredictably. TheyÃ¢ÂÂd need to be more effective, too the teamÃ¢ÂÂs mice initially benefited from their microbial injections but their tumors started growing again after three weeks. Ã¢ÂÂThere are many things that need to be worked out before we think about testing these things in humans,Ã¢ÂÂ says Hasty. Ã¢ÂÂI want to show some restraint. Ã¢ÂÂ HeÃ¢ÂÂs right to do so. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs a long history of medical techniques that seemed exciting in mice but that faceplanted in people. For example, in the late 1990s, David Bermudes from California State University also developed Salmonella strains that could shuttle drugs into tumours. These fared well in mice and monkeys, but when they were eventually tested in human clinical trials, they didnÃ¢ÂÂt work. Ã¢ÂÂWe could show safety but there was no measurable   activity,Ã¢ÂÂ says Bermudes. Ã¢ÂÂIn mice, the bacteria targeted a wide range of tumors 100 percent of the time. In the human study, they targeted tumors just a third of the time and only at the highest dose. We all know mice donÃ¢ÂÂt predict tumor therapies, or weÃ¢ÂÂd have cured cancer already. Ã¢ÂÂ Still, Bermudes thinks the approach has merit, as do many other scientists. Some are trying to program Salmonella to release toxins after invading cancer cells directly. Others are modifying the bacterium to release substances that either remove the shields that cloak cancer cells from the immune system, or that activate immune cells directly. Ã¢ÂÂOne of the problems in using bacteria against tumors was the lack of acceptance by oncologists,Ã¢ÂÂ says Weiss. Ã¢ÂÂVery few groups worked on it. But slowly, more are getting interested. New ideas will fertilize the field, and IÃ¢ÂÂm sure that eventually, this will bring bacterial therapy into the clinics. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: How Salmonella Could Be Used to Kill Cancer

Content: For us to continue writing great stories, we need to display ads.             Please select the extension that is blocking ads.     Please follow the steps below, Imagine for a moment that you have a tiny but worrisome lung nodule or, say, a growing bulge in a crucial blood vessel. You have no choice but to continue with normal life: going to work, running errands, paying taxes, negotiating with your kids over screen time. But youÃ¢ÂÂre always living, at least to some degree, under the looming shadow of a medical question mark. Judy Refuerzo ventured further along that uncertain journey this summer, walking the full length of the Camino de Santiago Ã¢ÂÂ  some 500 miles and 38 days across the Pyrenees into Spain Ã¢ÂÂ  to commemorate her 60th birthday. It had been a   trek, one that she tackled with a backpack and a close girlfriend for company. SheÃ¢ÂÂs not in denial, she insists, about the malignant cells that doctors found in her breast nearly two years ago. SheÃ¢ÂÂs been getting regular imaging tests to make sure that the cells Ã¢ÂÂ  collectively called ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) or sometimes stage 0 breast cancer Ã¢ÂÂ  have not migrated beyond the milk ducts. But the California yoga teacher has decided against any kind of treatment, including surgery Ã¢ÂÂ  at least for now. Ã¢ÂÂI just donÃ¢ÂÂt want to be cut open for no reason,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. In the process, Judy has joined a growing group of   watchful waiters, snared within a   web of aggressive testing and medical uncertainty. The concept of watchful waiting (synonymous, for some doctors at least, with Ã¢ÂÂactive surveillanceÃ¢ÂÂ) is nothing new. Through the ages, doctors have sometimes recommended hitting pause on treatment. Increasingly, though, more and more people are caught up in a peculiar medical purgatory, particularly in countries like the U. S. A. where an emphasis on screening and   imaging to rule out medical problems can cascade into more testing and other uncertainties. Ã¢ÂÂI think our technologies are moving faster than our ability to know what to do with the conditions we find,Ã¢ÂÂ says Shelley Hwang, a breast surgeon at Duke University Medical Center and a prominent DCIS researcher. Ã¢ÂÂAnd once you know it, you canÃ¢ÂÂt   it. Ã¢ÂÂ Sometimes, as in JudyÃ¢ÂÂs situation, people will choose that    path. While still quite controversial, some doctors are willing to delay surgery and other treatment for DCIS unless there are signs that the malignant cells are moving into the surrounding breast tissue. In other medical scenarios, patients are told   that monitoring is the only immediate option, as itÃ¢ÂÂs too risky to operate until circumstances become more  . Medicine has reached a crossroads. Shadows, nodules, and other changes can be flagged much earlier, in the      stage. Meanwhile, researchers and clinicians are learning that, for some conditions, less medical care might be better, both in the short term and also possibly over the longer haul. Even some cancer cells, it seems, can flare and fade away. But that shift in medical thinking raises other big questions: Are some people more psychologically able to cope with medical limbo? Can clinicians identify which patients might better weather uncertainty? And how do doctors counteract that innate human desire to Ã¢ÂÂdo something,Ã¢ÂÂ not only in their patients, but in themselves? * * * Ã¢ÂÂPeople donÃ¢ÂÂt like this idea of watching,Ã¢ÂÂ says Rita Redberg, a cardiologist at the University of California, San Francisco. Ã¢ÂÂThe whole fact that weÃ¢ÂÂve told you to watch   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     makes you feel like something bad is going to happen. Ã¢ÂÂ Even though, she says, a lot of things that are watched will never progress, there is a drop in a personÃ¢ÂÂs quality of life when they get into a surveillance situation. If she chose to, Redberg could tout medical credentials that run for pages. SheÃ¢ÂÂs a   cardiology researcher, a vocal opponent of inappropriate imaging, and the chief editor of JAMA Internal Medicine. In the late 1970s, she and her fellow medical students were learning how to perform a physical exam, which meant practicing on each other. One student found a lump in RedbergÃ¢ÂÂs neck, which Ã¢ÂÂ  after more than two decades of monitoring with blood tests Ã¢ÂÂ  was eventually biopsied in 2000. It was papillary thyroid cancer, the most common form of thyroid cancer. Soon after, she had surgery. If she had had her biopsy today, Redberg might have had another, albeit controversial, option: to simply monitor her cancer. Surveillance has long been considered an option for   prostate cancer, and now researchers are exploring its use in other cancers, including papillary thyroid, which is, very often, so   that someone can fare well for years without it spreading. Another is DCIS, JudyÃ¢ÂÂs diagnosis. As mammography and other imaging has become more common and more sensitive, diagnoses of DCIS now make up as many as a quarter of breast cancer diagnoses. Previously, it was virtually unheard of. The question is: how risky is it to leave those cells alone? Since few women choose surveillance, research answers are limited. But a recent look back at patients treated in Boston proved encouraging. After ten years, over 98 percent of women hadnÃ¢ÂÂt died from their   DCIS, whether they had had surgery or not. While the cancer outcomes are crucial, the impact on someoneÃ¢ÂÂs quality of life shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be ignored. Some women who choose surgery, radiation, and other measures for DCIS might struggle with related pain and recovery for some time, Hwang says. But without surgery, she counters, Ã¢ÂÂthereÃ¢ÂÂs another flavor of misery where youÃ¢ÂÂre just worried every day of your life that youÃ¢ÂÂre going to get cancerÃ¢ÂÂ. Hwang is leading the first   randomized DCIS study in the USA, known as the COMET trial, which will analyze cancer rates as well as the psychological ripple effects. Psychological and    aspects also are part of a similarly designed study called LORIS, which was launched in 2014 in the UK. Prior research shows that women with DCIS harbor similar fears about recurrence and dying as those who have invasive breast cancer, despite DCIS being less serious. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂve got a lot of worry going on, and we donÃ¢ÂÂt even know if the treatment that theyÃ¢ÂÂre receiving actually is of any value to them at all,Ã¢ÂÂ says Lesley Fallowfield, the principal investigator on the LORIS studyÃ¢ÂÂs    assessment. During discussions after her 2014 diagnosis, JudyÃ¢ÂÂs doctors recommended a myriad of treatment approaches Ã¢ÂÂ  mastectomy, lumpectomy, radiation, and tamoxifen Ã¢ÂÂ  in various combinations to prevent the malignant cells from spreading. Finally, a surgeon suggested that Judy talk to doctors at the University of California, San Francisco, early proponents of monitoring as an alternative strategy. Ã¢ÂÂHe said, Ã¢ÂÂThey have a different view of DCIS than the rest of the world,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Judy recalls. As she mulled over her options, Judy worried about the risk of surgery and radiation, including   discomfort and possible    . Plus, no one could guarantee her that the malignant breast cells would be eradicated for good. Do I want to live my life healthy and feeling good, she asked herself, or miserable and not feeling good, with the same outcome? Judy, who already avoided meat, has made other changes to her diet since her diagnosis, dropping wheat and dairy. SheÃ¢ÂÂs also taking vitamin D to supplement her low natural levels. She believes that many of us periodically harbour malignancies somewhere in our bodies, cells that can be beaten back with exercise, nutrition and other healthy habits. But she also admits to flickers of doubt: Ã¢ÂÂOccasionally IÃ¢ÂÂll think, Ã¢ÂÂWhy do I think IÃ¢ÂÂm special? Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ * * * Theresa Monck, a    from Brooklyn, New York, is soaking up her first years of retirement, especially the opportunities to travel. But her next lung scan lurks in the back of her mind. The former smoker started getting annual CT scans in 2013 to look for any early signs of lung cancer. Two small nodules were identified. Over the last several years they have not grown, a reassuring sign. Still, Theresa has pushed for a biopsy. Doctors, she says, have told her that the nodules are too small to risk the procedure, which involves inserting a needle into her lung. Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt like having them  Ã¢ÂÂ¦    Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂBut what am I going to do?Ã¢ÂÂ Theresa and patients like her are providing some insights into just how much angst men and women living in medical limbo really suffer. In 2013, the U. S. Preventive Services Task Force recommended   screening for   current and former smokers. (European countries have been slower to conduct such screening outside of research studies, which are ongoing.) The goal is to find cancers at an earlier and likely more treatable stage. But thereÃ¢ÂÂs a significant catch. Anywhere from 20 to 50 percent of people, depending on the study cited, will have to deal with a false positive, where a nodule is found that, after further testing and scrutiny, doesnÃ¢ÂÂt prove to be cancerous. Sometimes patients wonÃ¢ÂÂt know one way or the other for years, but will continue to undergo imaging to see if the nodule is growing. For some people monitoring can morph into an endless loop, says Renda Soylemez Wiener, a pulmonologist at Boston University School of Medicine. While the typical guidance is to stop after several years if the nodule hasnÃ¢ÂÂt changed, this regular scanning can highlight another nodule, and the clock starts over. Ã¢ÂÂPatients wind up in this prolonged period of uncertainty,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. How much distress those scans generate, though, is still not clear. One study tracked just over 2, 800 participants in the U. S.  National Lung Screening Trial. Researchers found that those who had a suspicious nodule detected (and later ruled out) didnÃ¢ÂÂt suffer any more anxiety than those whose imaging tests didnÃ¢ÂÂt turn up anything. Joanne Marshall, a former smoker, is among those who might have reason to fuss. Her mother was diagnosed with lung cancer in 2012. Soon after, Joanne got her first scan, which identified three small nodules. But they havenÃ¢ÂÂt grown and neither has her concern. Ã¢ÂÂSome people can be nervous nellies Ã¢ÂÂ  thatÃ¢ÂÂs just not me,Ã¢ÂÂ says the    who lives near Los Angeles. Ã¢ÂÂI need to watch it because I would like to have a fighting chance, and I canÃ¢ÂÂt take back the smoking history. Ã¢ÂÂ But Wiener says her research shows that not everyone is similarly sanguine if a nodule is found. Sometimes patients act as though theyÃ¢ÂÂve already been diagnosed with lung cancer, she says. A woman in one of her studies quit her job to find another that would allow more time with her family. In another study, Wiener assessed the perceptions of 122 veterans whose nodules had been picked up in the course of checking out another potential medical problem. Nearly 40 percent reported at least mild distress after the nodule was identified 16 percent described their distress as moderate to severe. And even when a doctor says that CT scans are no longer necessary, 29 percent of patients report being Ã¢ÂÂsomewhat nervousÃ¢ÂÂ to stop surveillance, and 10 percent would be Ã¢ÂÂextremely nervous. Ã¢ÂÂ Theresa, the Brooklyn retiree, had a similar reaction when she learned that clinicians typically donÃ¢ÂÂt follow nodules that havenÃ¢ÂÂt changed for longer than several years. SheÃ¢ÂÂd continue the CT scans, she maintains, even if she had to go to another hospital, and even if her insurance wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt cover them and she had to pay herself. How else would she know if one of those nodules ever began to grow? Theresa and Joanne both carry several small, relatively   nodules in their lungs. Yet their reactions have been notably different. Fallowfield, the principal investigator on the LORIS studyÃ¢ÂÂs    assessment, says research indicates that we all have personality filters through which we sift medical information, sometimes in surprising ways. Years back, Fallowfield was involved with a study which looked at the processing styles of 154 women wrestling with the weighty decision of whether or not to have prophylactic surgery to remove both breasts. Just over half of the women Ã¢ÂÂ  all of whom faced a high risk of breast cancer based on family history or other risk factors Ã¢ÂÂ  chose surgery. Most of the rest declined, with a small number delaying their decision for various reasons. Understandably, both groups reported high anxiety at the start. But among those who chose the double mastectomy, those feelings Ã¢ÂÂby and largeÃ¢ÂÂ eased over the course of 18 months, Fallowfield says. But they didnÃ¢ÂÂt among those women who opted for surveillance. How could that be? Researchers found some indications in a Ã¢ÂÂways of copingÃ¢ÂÂ questionnaire that they had asked both groups to fill out in order to gauge how they handled lifeÃ¢ÂÂs difficulties. The women who chose surgery tended to have a more proactive,   approach, and likely that helped ease their anxiety moving forward, says Fallowfield. The women who declined were prone to using Ã¢ÂÂdetachment or distraction as a way of coping with lifeÃ¢ÂÂs traumas,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂThese were       people. Ã¢ÂÂ But that coping mechanism had a crucial flaw. Imaging tests and   kept reminding them of their cancer vulnerability. Suzanne Miller, a clinical health psychologist who studies medical   believes that the U. K. women who turned down the operation fall into a subset known as Ã¢ÂÂmonitors,Ã¢ÂÂ one of two coping styles that she first described in the late 1970s. The others Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂbluntersÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ  prefer to engage with medical details and discussions on an   basis. Ã¢ÂÂThey hear what theyÃ¢ÂÂre told,Ã¢ÂÂ she says, but are not inclined to dig further. Monitors are more likely to do research before an appointment and pepper the doctor with questions. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre also more likely to amplify any medical risks, which can become stressful if they decide on surveillance for a condition such as DCIS, Miller says. They may choose it Ã¢ÂÂon the basis of the rational, concrete pros and cons,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂBut many of them understand going into it that this is going to have an emotional toll. Ã¢ÂÂ In recent years, Miller has come to believe that monitors can be divided even further by coping style. Ã¢ÂÂ  monitorsÃ¢ÂÂ likely havenÃ¢ÂÂt taken steps to mitigate the emotional toll between scans and  . They might continue to fret and stew, which can snowball into regret that they havenÃ¢ÂÂt taken a more Ã¢ÂÂactiveÃ¢ÂÂ step, Miller says. Hence the pervasive anxiety suffered by the women who turned down prophylactic mastectomy in FallowfieldÃ¢ÂÂs study. Another example is men with   prostate cancer who initially commit to surveillance, but eventually go under the knife because they canÃ¢ÂÂt stand the uncertainty. Judy Refuerzo is what Miller describes as a Ã¢ÂÂstrategic monitor,Ã¢ÂÂ someone who relies on support,   and other strategies to dampen their own monitoring tendencies. Along with boosting her nutrition and striving to live life to the max Ã¢ÂÂ  Judy says sheÃ¢ÂÂs probably a bit more spontaneous these days Ã¢ÂÂ  she tries not to think too much about her cancer risk. Yet she still has scans every six months. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm under surveillance,Ã¢ÂÂ Judy says. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm not an idiot Ã¢ÂÂ  IÃ¢ÂÂm proactive. Ã¢ÂÂ In February 2016, JudyÃ¢ÂÂs most recent MRI scan showed some DCIS growth, but no signs of invasive cancer. * * * MillerÃ¢ÂÂs tool, the Monitor Ã¢ÂÂ  Blunter Style Scale, is one way that clinicians can get a snapshot of a patientÃ¢ÂÂs coping style. It would also be helpful if a doctor could capture a sense of an individual patientÃ¢ÂÂs risk tolerance, says Shelley Hwang, the Duke breast cancer surgeon Ã¢ÂÂ  something similar, she says, to how financial planners assess whether their client is capable of or interested in taking on additional financial risk. Patients and doctors caught in this cycle of surveillance are fighting one of the most innate human tendencies: the desire to act, says Paul Han, a physician and researcher who studies medical uncertainty and risk communication. That impulse can infect far more mundane situations than expanding aortic aneurysms or   cancers, Han says, noting that every day doctors must decide whether to prescribe antibiotics to patients with respiratory symptoms. Ã¢ÂÂEverybody wants something done, when in fact often nothing is really needed except observation and letting things run their course,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂBut there is this sort of general impatience in our medical culture, and in our culture at large. Ã¢ÂÂ Han speculates that this discomfort with watchful waiting might figure more prominently in the U. S. A. than in countries in Europe and elsewhere where conversations about healthcare costs and   are more publicly hashed out. Fallowfield agrees, wondering if the U. S.  DCIS study (COMET) might struggle more than the U. K. one she works on (LORIS) to recruit patients willing to have their treatment randomly assigned, as Americans tend to be Ã¢ÂÂless  Ã¢ÂÂ. Fallowfield also echoes other clinicians who worry that misleading medical language can unduly alarm patients, ramping up their perception of their own risk status and thus influencing their treatment choices. When talking to LORIS study participants, clinicians use the term Ã¢ÂÂactive monitoringÃ¢ÂÂ rather than Ã¢ÂÂwatchful waiting. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂWatchful waitingÃ¢ÂÂ sounds quite passive Ã¢ÂÂ  you are sitting there waiting for something to happen,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Using the term Ã¢ÂÂductal carcinoma in situÃ¢ÂÂ is similarly like waving a red flag in front of patients, Fallowfield says, because it includes the word Ã¢ÂÂcarcinoma. Ã¢ÂÂ If keeping DCIS as an acronym is important, she suggests other terminology, such as Ã¢ÂÂductal changes in situÃ¢ÂÂ or Ã¢ÂÂductal calcifications in situ. Ã¢ÂÂ In the prostate field, thereÃ¢ÂÂs an analogous diagnosis to DCIS, a   condition called   prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the word Ã¢ÂÂneoplasiaÃ¢ÂÂ that Ã¢ÂÂcan set off patient alarm bells,Ã¢ÂÂ says Ian Thompson, a prostate cancer researcher in San Antonio, Texas. Ã¢ÂÂDidnÃ¢ÂÂt Ralph Nader call the Corvair unsafe at any speed? The terminology does affect behavior. Ã¢ÂÂ Thompson and other clinicians have proposed a less   albeit clunky, alternative: IDLE, short for indolent lesions of epithelial origin. To reduce patient fears, clinicians should do a better job at communicating medical risk, says Renda Soylemez Wiener, the Boston pulmonologist. She points out that just   of 244 patients diagnosed with lung nodules were able to predict with any degree of accuracy the likelihood that their nodules would prove to be cancerous. Overall they pegged their risk at 20 percent, but their actual risk based on nodule size was 7 percent. Nearly   of them didnÃ¢ÂÂt realize that some lung nodules grow so slowly that they will never prove to be  . A surveillance contract could also help avert patient Ã¢ÂÂ  doctor misunderstandings, says Brendan Stack, Jr, an Arkansas thyroid cancer specialist. A written agreement for patients considering thyroid monitoring could ensure an upfront discussion of the risks involved, he says. It could also lay out the circumstances under which the patientÃ¢ÂÂs decision would be revisited. Once a patient has Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ that surveillance is the best course, it can be difficult to convince them to deviate, even if the malignancy shows signs of becoming more aggressive, says Thompson. Ã¢ÂÂChanging horses from doing nothing to something is sometimes difficult for people, if you will Ã¢ÂÂ  to push a reboot to the computer and reassess. Ã¢ÂÂ * * * From Rita RedbergÃ¢ÂÂs perspective, there is one easy way to reduce the expanding pool of watchful waiters: stop searching for medical ills so fiercely in the first place. She now wishes that she hadnÃ¢ÂÂt dug so far, literally, into her own thyroid. After the lump was detected during medical school, a radioactive iodine scan determined that it was a Ã¢ÂÂhotÃ¢ÂÂ nodule Ã¢ÂÂ  one that produces excess thyroid hormone  Ã¢ÂÂ  but likely benign. Redberg did little more to check it out for some two decades, other than periodic blood tests, until her primary care doctor worried that it might be growing. She agreed to a needle biopsy, which she now regrets. Her surgery in 2000 left Redberg with a scar on her neck. Each day, she takes a thyroid replacement pill. Strangely enough, Brendan Stack has a similar story. He was teaching medical residents about ultrasound technology and they were practicing on his neck when they found a thyroid nodule. It was biopsied twice, but cancer still couldnÃ¢ÂÂt be completely ruled out. Watchful waiting was one possibility. Ã¢ÂÂI couldnÃ¢ÂÂt tolerate that,Ã¢ÂÂ Stack recalls. Ã¢ÂÂI said, Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre taking it out. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ In 2006, he had surgery to remove the half of his thyroid where the nodule was located. The pathology showed no signs of cancer. Even so, he has no regrets: Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂd do the same thing today. Ã¢ÂÂ And Redberg? SheÃ¢ÂÂs not quite so unequivocal, given how slowly thyroid cancer typically grows. Ã¢ÂÂProbably, on balance,Ã¢ÂÂ she says, Ã¢ÂÂI would have been happier not to have known about it. Ã¢ÂÂ This article appears courtesy of Mosaic.
Title: When Should Cancer Treatment Wait?

Content: A couple years ago, Sibel Blau, an oncologist outside of Seattle, was working with the company Guardant Health to test their novel Ã¢ÂÂliquid biopsiesÃ¢ÂÂ in patients. The idea behind liquid biopsies is both elegant and promising. A doctor takes a blood sample from a patient, and then Guardant looks for tumor DNA floating in the blood, allowing doctors to identify the tumorÃ¢ÂÂs unique mutations and offer a personalized drug regimen Ã¢ÂÂ  all without an invasive tissue biopsy. Blau was excited to be on board. When that study wrapped up, Blau still had Guardant test kits left over, so she offered some to her patients at no cost to them. At this point, Blau was routinely ordering DNA sequencing of traditional tissue biopsies, so some patients got both tests. The tissue DNA test from Foundation Medicine was Ã¢ÂÂroutineÃ¢ÂÂ in her practice, but even that test had only become available in 2012. The field of cancer DNA has been changing fast. But BlauÃ¢ÂÂs patients who got both tests didnÃ¢ÂÂt get more clarity Ã¢ÂÂ  if anything, they often got more confusion. The two tests would pick up on different mutations in the same person. So the Foundation   test might suggest two drugs targeted toward the mutations in the patientÃ¢ÂÂs tumor, and the Guardant liquid biopsy a third based on different mutations in the same tumor. In a small study published today in JAMA Oncology, Blau and her colleagues found no overlap between the drugs the tests recommended in five out of eight patients. The new study is very small, but it aligns with other recent work comparing tissue and   sequencing results. A paper from Northwestern researchers in August looking at these same two tests, for example, found that more than half of the mutations identified by one test did not show up in the other. Another study looking at a few especially important mutations (for many kinds of cancers) found the tests agreed 70. 3 percent or 88. 1 percent or  93. 1 percent of the time, depending on the mutation. So which test do you believe? Ã¢ÂÂThere is no easy answer,Ã¢ÂÂ says Richard Schilsky, the chief medical officer of the American Society of Clinical Oncology. Ã¢ÂÂBecause nobody actually knows what is the truth in terms of whatÃ¢ÂÂs happening inside a personÃ¢ÂÂs tumor throughout the body. Ã¢ÂÂ Tissue and liquid biopsies are two ways to look inside a tumor, and both views are incomplete in different ways. ASCO is currently developing guidelines for doctors on this exact topic. A tissue biopsy is exactly what it sounds like: The doctor sticks a large needle into the tumor and physically removes a small chunk. Liquid biopsies are little more complicated. Dying tumor cells shed DNA fragments into the bloodstream. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs very little of this circulating tumor DNA in the blood, but recent advances in DNA sequencing have made it much easier to find. A major reason the two kinds of tests return different results is that even a tumor contains multitudes. One chunk may have cells with mutation A,  while another chunk has cells with mutation B. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the luck of the needle draw. Liquid biopsies, on the other hand, can pick up DNA shed by all cancer cells Ã¢ÂÂ  maybe even a nascent tumor in a different location Ã¢ÂÂ  but not all cancer cells shed as much DNA. Ã¢ÂÂWith a tumor biopsy, itÃ¢ÂÂs like you read the book cover to cover. With a liquid biopsy, you read an entire shelf of books, but you only read the dust jackets,Ã¢ÂÂ says Justin Odegaard, the senior medical director of Guardant Health. Guardant thinks that the two kinds of tests are complementary. They tell you different things and the more you know the better. (Foundation Medicine declined to comment on the study.) And indeed, a cancer patient might very reasonably want to take both tests. But GuardantÃ¢ÂÂs and FoundationÃ¢ÂÂs tests both cost $5, 800, and most insurance policies, including Medicare, do not cover them for most types of cancer. In some cases, the advantage of liquid biopsies might be obvious Ã¢ÂÂ  when the tumor is close to a major blood vessel or when blood cancer has spread to multiple sites. In many cases, though, the choice will not be clear.  Medicine tends to have a bias toward the known quantity, and tissue biopsies are the current standard. Blau, for instance, thinks liquid biopsies Ã¢ÂÂare not really ready for primetime. Ã¢ÂÂ When given conflicting information from the two tests, she tells her patients to prioritize the tissue biopsy results.   There is definitely an incentive to make liquid biopsies ready for prime time. The tests could be very lucrative. Since theyÃ¢ÂÂre so   patients could get several liquid biopsies for weeks, months, or even years as their cancer progresses Ã¢ÂÂ  compared to the one initial tissue biopsy. That would allow doctors to look out for new mutations in the cancer and adjust drug regimens as needed. Many companies are now in this space. Foundation has since come out with its own   test, FoundationACT. (ItÃ¢ÂÂs also embroiled in a patent lawsuit with Guardant Health.) Grail, a spinoff from the DNA sequencing machine maker Illumina, is reportedly looking to raise an   $1. 7 billion to test its own   product. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂBut for liquid biopsies to really enter primetime, insurance companies will have to start paying for them.
Title: One Patient, Two Cancer DNA Tests, Two Different Results

Content: The first time finding a cure for cancer ever showed up on the presidential radar was in the early 1970s, when President Nixon signed the National Cancer Act. The bill, passed in 1971, provided more funding to the National Cancer Institute (NCI) and the National Institutes of Health (NIH) to identify new treatments and diagnostic tools, and Ã¢ÂÂadvance the national effort against cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ Every administration has made the Ã¢ÂÂwar on cancerÃ¢ÂÂ a national mandate, but how close are we in winning that war? And as we stand in 2016, many scientists who deal with all forms of the disease would say that weÃ¢ÂÂre winning the war for sure, but the bigger question is: Would we ever stop fighting? And the answer is no. Ã¢ÂÂLetÃ¢ÂÂs make America the country that cures cancer once and for all,Ã¢ÂÂ President Obama declared Tuesday night during his last State of the Union Address. His remark, a statement uttered by many a political leader since Nixon, is certainly a pretty sound bite, but to achieve it, we have a great deal of work to do. Now, I am hopeful about AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs war on cancer, and some of the countryÃ¢ÂÂs leading experts on this disease agree.  Anna Barker, previously the deputy director of the NCI, told me during a Fox News special in 2010, Ã¢ÂÂWinning the War on Cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ that Ã¢ÂÂat this juncture, I see more promise to really advance against this disease than IÃ¢ÂÂve seen in the last 35 or so years. Ã¢ÂÂ Another topic discussed was the promise of personalized treatment and immunotherapy Ã¢ÂÂ   two approaches that continue to be integral in the progression of the war on cancer today. Ã¢ÂÂI see this as one of the more exciting new developments in the treatment of cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ Steven Rosenberg, who is still the chief of surgery and a research scientist at the NCI, told me in 2010. Looking back, weÃ¢ÂÂve definitely come a long way in screening and diagnosing cancers early, and clearly coming up with a multitude of different technologies that we hope will one day eradicate the development of tumors all together. But we still donÃ¢ÂÂt know for sure what causes cells to mutate, then divide and spread Ã¢ÂÂ   some scientists think itÃ¢ÂÂs bad luck, while others say itÃ¢ÂÂs due to choices we make every day. There are also many kinds of cancer that are difficult to diagnose until theyÃ¢ÂÂre   Ã¢ÂÂ   and by then, are more challenging to treat Ã¢ÂÂ   from pancreatic cancer, to ovarian cancer and lung cancer. And there still remains a lot to be learned about the genetics of the human body as they relate to cancer development, in a world population faced with compromising lifestyle factors and environmental factors that are seriously out of control. Air pollution, smoking, dirty water and poor housing Ã¢ÂÂ   you name it Ã¢ÂÂ   all of these factors can affect our disease risk, and measures to improve those factors must be propelled if we want to reduce the incidence of cancer among Americans. On Tuesday, President Obama said that, with regards to finding a cure for cancer, he wants to accomplish in five years what would normally take a decade to achieve. Many political leaders have spouted off similar wishes, and IÃ¢ÂÂm sure they have all meant it. But saying that we can Ã¢ÂÂcureÃ¢ÂÂ all forms of cancer at any stage of its development is an overstatement at present. Now, America has the best scientists in the world. ItÃ¢ÂÂs filled with brave men and women who are  working around the clock every day to find effective treatments, early diagnostic tools and therapies to keep cancer at bay, and provide those people who are afflicted with the disease with effective treatments that could let them live a long, healthy life. With all those things in our favor, I remain optimistic about the Ã¢ÂÂwar on cancerÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ   and our nationÃ¢ÂÂs ability to fight it Ã¢ÂÂ   but thereÃ¢ÂÂs still much progress that needs to be made.
Title: DR. MANNY: The US is winning the Ã¢ÂÂwar on cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ but the fight is far from over

Content: The veteran Utah police officer shot and killed Sunday morning while investigating a car crash had just overcome a lengthy battle with cancer. Sgt. Doug Barney had recently received a clean bill of health after fighting bladder cancer for several years, said Unified Police Department spokesperson Lex Bell, who said he was a friend of BarneyÃ¢ÂÂs. Ã¢ÂÂHeÃ¢ÂÂs had cancer for a long time and fought hard,Ã¢ÂÂ Bell told FOX13. Ã¢ÂÂThere were a couple occasions where he got really, really sick and has always powered through it. Ã¢ÂÂ Barney, an   veteran of the force and a married father of three, was shot in the head while pursuing two people who had left the scene of a car crash, officials said. The suspected gunman, Cory Lee Henderson, was also shot and wounded in an exchange of gunfire. The woman he was with is still on the run. An officer with Barney was shot three times and had surgery Sunday evening. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs always a tragedy when someone dies young and leaves people behind,Ã¢ÂÂ Bell said.
Title: Utah police officer killed Sunday had overcome cancer

Content: An Arizona motherÃ¢ÂÂs keen eye detected something might be amiss while studying photos she had taken of her infant son. Andrea Temarantz started seeing a glint in her son RyderÃ¢ÂÂs left eye caused by the flash of her cellphone, NY Daily News reported. Ã¢ÂÂI kind of chalked it up to my cellphone just being a crummy phone,Ã¢ÂÂ Temarantz told the Daily News. Ã¢ÂÂIt very well could have gotten so much bigger. Ã¢ÂÂ The glint that Temarantz, 36, was actually seeing was caused by a rare cancer called retinoblastoma. Doctors confirmed RyderÃ¢ÂÂs diagnosis at his     and gave his parents two options: they could either remove his eye, or give him intravenous chemotherapy that may expose him to a greater risk of developing another cancer, the newspaper reported. The family would later learn of a third option for Ryder, who also has Down syndrome. He could travel to New YorkÃ¢ÂÂs Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center for an   chemotherapy session, which targets the affected blood vessel behind the eye through a    catheter entering through his groin. Patients undergo one session per month over a three month span, according to the report. Ryder is scheduled to undergo his second treatment in early February. Dr. David Abramson, chief of ophthalmic oncology service at Memorial Sloan Kettering, told the Daily News that the process cures 99 percent of patients, and children can keep their affected eye. Abramson said he has treated 1, 600 children using this method. Ã¢ÂÂAlmost all of these children were scheduled to have those eyes removed somewhere,Ã¢ÂÂ Abramson told the Daily News. Ã¢ÂÂWe donÃ¢ÂÂt have one child who has died from this cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ The family has been updating followers through a blog called Ã¢ÂÂRyderÃ¢ÂÂs Retinoblastoma Battle #PrayerForRyder,Ã¢ÂÂ and hopes that their story can serve as a lesson for other parents. Ã¢ÂÂWe just hope for people to see how easy it would be to recognize this,Ã¢ÂÂ Temarantz told the Daily News. Ã¢ÂÂMy husband has always thought that I was Ã¢ÂÂcrazy picture mom,Ã¢ÂÂ but look at us now. So early detection is the main thing. Ã¢ÂÂ Retinoblastoma is the most common type of eye cancer in children and typically develops before age 5.
Title: Arizona mom detects sonÃ¢ÂÂs eye cancer while looking at picture

Content: As country singer Joey Feek, 40, continues her battle with cervical cancer, for which she stopped receiving treatment in 2015, her husband and singing partner Rory Feek updated fans Monday that his wife has been Ã¢ÂÂasleep for days now, and her body is shutting down quickly. Ã¢ÂÂ Feek was diagnosed with cancer in May 2014 and underwent a radical hysterectomy to treat it that summer, The Tennessean reported. In June 2015, the disease returned as stage 4 cervical cancer, according to RoryÃ¢ÂÂs blog. Joey underwent surgery and aggressive treatment, but they werenÃ¢ÂÂt able to halt its spread. In October, she announced she would be stopping treatment, and, at the time, noted doctors gave her six to nine months to live. She entered hospice care in November. Cervical cancer is relatively rare, but each year about 12, 000 women in the U. S. are diagnosed with the disease and about 4, 000 women die from it, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The cancer begins on the surface of the cervix, the lower part of the uterus. In the past 30 years, the number of cervical cancer cases and corresponding rates of death have decreased significantly Ã¢ÂÂ   by more than 50 percent Ã¢ÂÂ   which the CDC and American Cancer Society attribute to many women getting regular Pap tests, which can find cervical precancer before it turns to cancer. Women with early cervical cancers and   usually do not have symptoms, according to the American Cancer Society. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not until the cancer becomes invasive and grows into nearby tissue that symptoms begin. The most common symptoms of the disease are abnormal vaginal bleeding, unusual discharge, and pain during intercourse. Gardasil, the vaccine that helps protect against certain human papillomavirus (HPV) types, can also prevent cervical cancer, as the virus has been linked to the disease. HPV types 16 and 18 cause the majority of cervical cancers. CDC data suggests HPV infections among American teenage girls has dropped by more than 60 percent since the vaccine was introduced in 2006. Stage 4 cervical cancer is the most advanced stage, and indicates the cancer has spread to nearby organs or other parts of the body. It has a 15 to 16 percent   survival rate. Joey and Rory married on June 15, 2002. Rory began his blog, This Life I Live, in January 2014, when his wife was still pregnant with their daughter and she had not been diagnosed with cancer. Their daughter, Indiana, was born in February 2014 and has Down syndrome. The family also includes RoryÃ¢ÂÂs two daughters from a previous marriage. In a post published Monday, Rory expressed that he was grateful for the prospect that his familyÃ¢ÂÂs story may encourage others. Ã¢ÂÂThat is a good thing,Ã¢ÂÂ he wrote. Ã¢ÂÂNo, that is a great thing. Thank you. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Joey FeekÃ¢ÂÂs diagnosis: Understanding cervical cancer

Content: An    Georgia boy is getting the chance to attend senior prom a decade early after his neighbor, who considers him her superhero, asked him to the big dance. Alex Richards, who is battling cancer for the third time, will escort Shelby Butler to prom on Saturday after accepting her flashcard promposal, MyFoxAtlanta. com reported.  Alex, of Barrow County, was initially diagnosed with cancer when he was 4 and received a bone marrow transplant from his sister, but the cancer cells recently returned.  Ã¢ÂÂI see what he goes through. He never stops fighting, he has always been kind of a hero to me, a role model to never stop giving up,Ã¢ÂÂ Butler told MyFoxAtlanta. com. Ã¢ÂÂI want him to be able to get out and have fun, and not be stuck somewhere in one place. Ã¢ÂÂ  She came up with the idea to ask Alex, whom she considers a brother, with flashcards that compared him to Batman and Superman.  Her flashcards read: Ã¢ÂÂSuperman is cool because he has   vision. Superman is cool because he scales tall buildings. Batman is cool because he drives the fanciest car on the planet. Alex is cool because he never stops fighting. I would like my superhero Alex to be my date to the prom.Ã¢ÂÂ Alex checked off the Ã¢ÂÂyesÃ¢ÂÂ box and was presented with a suit to match ButlerÃ¢ÂÂs dress.  Ã¢ÂÂI think it will mean more to him when he gets older and looks back on it,Ã¢ÂÂ Sheri Richards, AlexÃ¢ÂÂs mom, told MyFoxAtlanta. com. Ã¢ÂÂRight now it is going to be a fun thing, but when he gets older and looks back on it, it is going to have a bigger impact on him. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Teen asks 8-year-old neighbor battling cancer to prom

Content: A decorated Army veteran who battled the VA over treatment for cancer he claimed to have gotten from working over burn pits in Iraq has died, his family said Monday. Former Army Sgt. John Marshall, who went to his grave believing his cancer was caused by standing over burn pits where the military disposed of everything from disabled IEDs to lithium batteries, died at his home in Surprise, Ariz. March 29. He was 31, and left behind a wife and two young children. Ã¢ÂÂJohn was the type of guy who touched people even if he didnÃ¢ÂÂt know them that long,Ã¢ÂÂ said MarshallÃ¢ÂÂs wife and fellow veteran, Ashley. Ã¢ÂÂThe amount of people that have come from all over to offer condolences has been amazing and overwhelming. I knew John was a great person, but it shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have amazed me as it did that so many other people thought so, too.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂJohn was the type of guy who touched people even he didnÃ¢ÂÂt know them that long.Ã¢ÂÂ   Ashley Marshall, In February, FoxNews. com wrote about MarshallÃ¢ÂÂs struggle after being diagnosed with soft tissue sarcoma two years ago. He claimed the VA ruled his illness was not related to his service, and Marshall said he was unable to appeal the ruling with evidence because he was laid up in a hospital bed in January 2015 with pneumonia.  Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs all just a big slap in the face,Ã¢ÂÂ Marshall told FoxNews. com. Ã¢ÂÂI tried to be the perfect soldier. I did everything I was told, and now they just forced my claim through and denied coverage and my benefits. Ã¢ÂÂ VA officials told FoxNews. com at the time that they would   his case, but by then, MarshallÃ¢ÂÂs cancer had reached the terminal phase, according to his wife. The family raised money for his private medical treatment through a GoFundMe. com page, where friends and strangers continued to offer support on Monday. Ã¢ÂÂAs retired Army, we are saddened that the VA did not come through for you,Ã¢ÂÂ wrote Bob and Edna Woods in a post that accompanied a donation. Ã¢ÂÂYou and your family are in our prayers. God bless!Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe support for my husband is so heartwarming and beyond what I ever thought would happen when this journey started,Ã¢ÂÂ Ashley Marshall wrote on the site. Marshall told FoxNews. com he had no doubt that the soft tissue sarcoma he was diagnosed with 14 months ago is a result of his work on Improvised Explosive Device Disposal (IEDD) units. Ã¢ÂÂDuring my second tour, we were providing security for the EOD [Explosive Ordnance Disposal] guys,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂWe didnÃ¢ÂÂt know what we were blowing up, so itÃ¢ÂÂs possible that there we were exposed to something toxic. We stood over open burn pits. Ã¢ÂÂ An October 2013 report from the United States Government Accountability Office identified open burn pits as the likely cause of   health issues for many veterans returning from service in the Middle East. Ã¢ÂÂThe U. S. military returning from Iraq and Afghanistan may be suffering chronic,   health issues as a result of exposure to toxic fumes from open burn pits,Ã¢ÂÂ reads the report. Ã¢ÂÂDefense contractors have used burn pits at the majority of U. S. military bases in the Middle East as a method of military waste disposal. All kinds of toxic waste have been incinerated in these open burn pits, including human waste, plastics, hazardous medical waste, lithium batteries, tires, hydraulic fluids and vehicles    often using jet fuel as an accelerant. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Soldier who fought VA, blamed cancer on Iraq Ã¢ÂÂburn pits,Ã¢ÂÂ dies

Content: I write this from the hospital. Seems I have lung cancer. My doctors tell me my growth was caught early and IÃ¢ÂÂll be fine. Soon I will barely notice that a fifth of my lung is gone. I believe them. After all, IÃ¢ÂÂm at New   Hospital. U. S. News  World Report ranked it No. 1 in New York. I get excellent medical care here. But as a consumer reporter, I have to say, the hospitalÃ¢ÂÂs customer service stinks. Doctors keep me waiting for hours, and no one bothers to call or email to say, Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm running late.Ã¢ÂÂ Few doctors give out their email address. Patients canÃ¢ÂÂt communicate using modern technology. I get   EKG tests, echocardiograms, blood tests. Are all needed? I doubt it. But no one discusses that with me or mentions the cost. Why would they? The patient rarely pays directly. Government or insurance companies pay. I fill out long medical history forms by hand and, in the next office, do it again. Same wording: name, address, insurance, etc. I shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be surprised that hospitals are lousy at customer service. The Detroit Medical Center once bragged that it was one of AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs first hospitals to track medication with barcodes. Good! But wait    ordinary supermarkets did that  decades before. Customer service is sclerotic because hospitals are largely socialist bureaucracies. Instead of answering to consumers, which forces businesses to be nimble, hospitals report to government, lawyers and insurance companies. Whenever thereÃ¢ÂÂs a mistake, politicians impose new rules: the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act paperwork, patient rights regulations, new layers of bureaucracy. .. Nurses must follow state regulations that stipulate things like, Ã¢ÂÂNotwithstanding subparagraph (i) of paragraph (a) of this subdivision, a nurse practitioner, certified under section   hundred ten of this article and practicing for more than three thousand six hundred hours may comply with this paragraph in lieu of complying with the requirements of paragraph (a). ..Ã¢ÂÂ Try running a business with rules like that. Adding to that is a fear of lawsuits. Nervous hospital lawyers pretend mistakes can be prevented with paper and procedure. Stressed hospital workers ignore common sense and follow rigid rules. In the intensive care unit, night after night, machines beep, but often no one responds. Nurses say things like Ã¢ÂÂold machines,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂbad batteries,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂwe know itÃ¢ÂÂs not an emergency.Ã¢ÂÂ Bureaucrats donÃ¢ÂÂt care if you sleep.
