No one sues because he canÃ¢ÂÂt sleep. Some of my nurses were great    concerned about my comfort and stress    but other hospital workers were indifferent. When the customer doesnÃ¢ÂÂt pay, customer service rarely matters. The hospital does have Ã¢ÂÂpatient representativesÃ¢ÂÂ who tells me about Ã¢ÂÂpatient rights.Ã¢ÂÂ But it feels unnatural, like grafting wings onto a pig. IÃ¢ÂÂm as happy as the next guy to have government or my insurance company pay, but the result is that thereÃ¢ÂÂs practically no free market. Markets work when buyer and seller deal directly with each other. That doesnÃ¢ÂÂt happen in hospitals. You may ask, Ã¢ÂÂHow could it? Patients donÃ¢ÂÂt know which treatments are needed or which seller is best. Medicine is too complex for consumers to negotiate.Ã¢ÂÂ But cars, computers and airplane flights are complex, too, and the market still incentivizes sellers to discount and compete on service. It happens in medicine, too, when you get plastic surgery or Lasik surgery. Those doctors give patients their personal email addresses and cell phone numbers. They compete to please patients. WhatÃ¢ÂÂs different about those specialties? The patient pays the bill. Leftists say the solution to such problems is government health care. But did they not notice what happened at Veterans Affairs? Bureaucrats let veterans die, waiting for care. When the scandal was exposed, they didnÃ¢ÂÂt stop. USA Today reports that the abuse continues. Sometimes the VAÃ¢ÂÂs suicide hotline goes to voicemail. Patients will have a better experience only when more of us spend our own money for care. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what makes markets work. John Stossel is the host of Ã¢ÂÂStosselÃ¢ÂÂ (Fridays at 9  ) a weekly program highlighting current consumer issues with a libertarian viewpoint. Stossel also appears regularly on Fox News Channel (FNC) providing signature analysis. Click here for more information on John Stossel.
Title: Stossel: I have lung cancer. My medical care is excellent but the customer service stinks

Content: Eating nuts has been linked to a number of health benefits, such as a reduced risk of obesity, diabetes and heart disease. Now, new findings from South Korea suggest that a   diet may also reduce a personÃ¢ÂÂs risk of colon cancer. The researchers found a reduction in this risk for both men and women, according to the findings, presented here today (April 18) at the American Association for Cancer ResearchÃ¢ÂÂs annual meeting. Eating a serving of nuts three or more times a week appeared to have a big effect on risk, said Dr. Aesun Shin, an associate professor of preventive medicine at Seoul National University College of Medicine in South Korea and an author of the study. In the study, a serving of nuts was considered to be 15 grams (0. 5 ounces) Shin told Live Science. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a smaller amount than whatÃ¢ÂÂs considered a serving in the United States, she added. (A serving in the U. S. is 28 g, or 1 oz.) Although the researchers included many types of nuts in their analysis, peanuts were the most widely consumed nuts among people in the study. This may be due to the availability of peanuts in South Korea, the researchers said. [6 Foods That Are Good For Your Brain] To examine the relationship between eating nuts and colon cancer risk, the researchers looked at 923 patients who had been diagnosed with colon cancer and compared their diets with those of 1, 846 people who did not have colon cancer. The researchers found that men who reported eating three or more servings of nuts a week had a 69 percent lower risk of colon cancer than those who reported eating no nuts. Women who ate three or more servings had an 81 percent lower risk than those who ate no nuts, according to the study. In addition, the researchers looked at several different types of colon cancer, based on the location in the colon where the cancer is found. Nut consumption was associated with a reduced risk across all of the different locations that the researchers examined, Shin said. The study does not prove a    relationship between eating nuts and having a lower risk of colon cancer, the researchers said. However, the researchers hypothesized that some of the compounds, including fiber and antioxidants, found in nuts may help reduce a personÃ¢ÂÂs risk of colon cancer. [Top 10   Foods] Shin noted that a limitation of the study is that participants were asked to recall their own nut intake, and itÃ¢ÂÂs possible that they may have made mistakes. The findings have not been published in a   journal. Copyright 2016 LiveScience, a Purch company. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
Title: Eating nuts linked to lower risk of colon cancer

Content: SquibbÃ¢ÂÂs cancer immunotherapy drug, Opdivo, helped advanced head and neck cancer patients with a dismal prognosis live longer than other standard treatments, according to data from a   study presented on Tuesday.  Opdivo treatment led to a 30 percent reduction in risk of death, with median overall survival of 7. 5 months in the   trial, compared with 5. 1 months for those who received any of three commonly used treatments chosen by researchers.  While a median survival difference of less than three months may not sound like much, some patients taking that type of immunotherapy experience far more durable responses.  After one year, 36 percent of Opdivo patients were still alive compared with 16. 6 percent of those who received either methotrexate, docetaxel or Eli LillyÃ¢ÂÂs Erbitux, researchers reported.  The data likely paves the way for another approval for Opdivo, which is currently approved to treat advanced melanoma,   cell lung cancer and kidney cancer.  Ã¢ÂÂThe most important thing is the difference in the proportion of patients who survived to a year,Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Maura Gillison, the studyÃ¢ÂÂs lead investigator who presented the data at the American Association of Cancer Research meeting in New Orleans, said in an interview. Ã¢ÂÂIn a disease that was uniformly rapidly fatal, weÃ¢ÂÂre seeing a subset of the population clearly benefiting.Ã¢ÂÂ  Patients in the study had advanced cancer that had progressed within six months of receiving   chemotherapy.  Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a very devastating cancer when it recurs,Ã¢ÂÂ said Gillison, noting an average survival of less than six months.  Earlier at the meeting, researchers presented data showing 34 percent of patients who received Opdivo for advanced melanoma, the deadliest of skin cancers, were still alive after five years.  Opdivo proved effective whether the head and neck cancer was positive or negative for human papillomavirus (HPV) researchers said. But the magnitude of benefit was greater for   patients, with median overall survival of 9. 1 months versus 4. 4 months for the standard treatments.  Ã¢ÂÂWhatÃ¢ÂÂs got the field so excited is this tumor where weÃ¢ÂÂre seeing a survival benefit is like the worst of the worst actors,Ã¢ÂÂ Gillison said.  Merck  CoÃ¢ÂÂs rival drug, Keytruda, received a priority review for head and neck cancer from U. S. regulators and could be approved for that use by August.  Both drugs belong to a class called   inhibitors that block a mechanism that tumors use to avoid detection from the immune system.  (Reporting by Bill Berkrot in New York Editing by Peter Cooney)
Title: Bristol-MyersÃ¢ÂÂ Opdivo extends survival in head and neck cancer, study finds

Content: Imagine if there were cells of terrorists inside the United States that had the ability to strike without warning, kill mothers and children, drive families into bankruptcy, cripple productivity, and put the populace in a constant state of fear. Controlling and eradicating these terrorist cells would be all the presidential candidates would be discussing. But what about if instead of terrorist cells, those cells were inside of our bodies in the form of cancers? When President Nixon signed the National Cancer Act in 1971, the fed increased its funding for cancer research. That infrastructure has essentially remained unchanged, with subsequent presidents merely adding to or decreasing the amount of government funding allocated for this study. But no president has taken the time or interest to determine whether the funding policies, approval processes, rules, and regulations that govern the   war against cancer meet AmericansÃ¢ÂÂ current needs. We are fighting the cancer war with strategies that were implemented in 1971, and we have not used the knowledge we have gained to adjust or reform our strategies, resulting in significant wasted resources and inefficiencies. Much of our recent progress in cancer research has been made despite government intervention instead of because of government efforts. We are at an exciting time in the fight against cancer. Developments underway would add at least 2 significant tools to the toolbox we use to approach cancers: early cancer detection in the form of blood tests and immunotherapies, which have the potential to destroy cancer cells, while leaving healthy cells and tissue intact. These new technologies have the potential to be transformative, meaning that eventually they could lessen our reliance Ã¢ÂÂ   or in some instances even replace Ã¢ÂÂ   the hallmarks of cancer treatment used over the past 50 years: surgery, radiation and chemotherapy. One thing scientists have learned over the past 45 years is the earlier that cancer is diagnosed, the better an individualÃ¢ÂÂs chances are for survival. Among cancers diagnosed early Ã¢ÂÂ   at stage 1 or stage 2 Ã¢ÂÂ   the   survival rate is generally between 90 percent and 100 percent. But for cancers diagnosed later Ã¢ÂÂ   at stage 3 or stage 4 Ã¢ÂÂ   the   survival rate is typically between 20 percent and 30 percent. Despite these overwhelming statistics,   government funding is invested in developing   technologies.   companies have recognized the potential of   technologies for cancer and have stepped in to fill the void. The objective of Cancer4Pres. org is to make cancer a priority for the next U. S. president. Over the course of the next   presidential term, 2. 4 million people Ã¢ÂÂ   1, 644 people each day Ã¢ÂÂ   will die from cancer related illnesses, 7 million additional people will be diagnosed with cancer, and the government will spend over $500 billion on cancer care. A thorough review of the governmentÃ¢ÂÂs role in the fight against cancers is certainly worthy of the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs attention, and is long overdue. One way to make cancer a priority for our next president is to make cancer a campaign issue. The way to make cancer a campaign issue is to show the candidates that cancer is important to voters, which is the immediate goal of Cancer4Pres. org. Our hope is that when one candidate recognizes the opportunity to attract voters with a comprehensive policy to address the ongoing national cancer healthcare crisis, the other candidates will follow. Robert Berman is the President and CEO of ITUS Corporation (NASDAQ: ITUS) whose subsidiary company is developing Cchek, a platform of blood tests for the early detection of cancers. He is also the   of Cancer4Pres. org.
Title: The case for making cancer a campaign issue

Content: WASHINGTON (AP)    Vice President Joe Biden unveiled a public database for clinical data on cancer on Monday that aims to help researchers and doctors better tailor new treatments to individuals. Overseen by the National Cancer Institute, the Genomic Data Commons starts with genomic and clinical data for 12, 000 patients. The system is designed to increase sharing of information about the gene sequences of tumors and how patients with those tumors responded to specific treatments, Biden, speaking at the American Society of Clinical OncologyÃ¢ÂÂs annual meeting in Chicago, said recent advances in DNA sequencing technology had allowed researchers to generate vast amounts of new data in a short period of time. But he said the cancer world Ã¢ÂÂcan do much better than weÃ¢ÂÂre doing. Ã¢ÂÂThe information is scattered among different government and academic repositories. Most of it is out of the reach of scientists,Ã¢ÂÂ Biden said. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre bringing it into one space.Ã¢ÂÂ The database has emerged as the most tangible component of BidenÃ¢ÂÂs cancer Ã¢ÂÂmoonshot,Ã¢ÂÂ a push in his final year in office to double the pace of cancer research toward a cure. Although the Obama administration has sought an influx of federal funds to accelerate research, Congress has approved only a fraction of whatÃ¢ÂÂs been requested. Since taking on the cancer issue last year, Biden has repeatedly argued that confining data within institutions has hampered cancer research, with scientists and medical companies reluctant to share proprietary information. In fact, cancer research institutions have significant   arrangements in place, although Biden and other critics say itÃ¢ÂÂs too limited and not happening early enough in the process. Though easily searchable, the database includes protections for privacy and security, Biden said. He urged cancer experts gathered in Chicago to Ã¢ÂÂupload your raw genomic dataÃ¢ÂÂ to the system for use by fellow researchers. Ã¢ÂÂAll of you know itÃ¢ÂÂs the right thing to do,Ã¢ÂÂ Biden said. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs the quickest way for us to move forward. And itÃ¢ÂÂs not technically hard for us to do it.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Biden unveiling public database for clinical data on cancer

Content: A New York man pleaded guilty Thursday to killing his    daughter with a wooden baseball bat before burning her body and dumping her remains in an upstate waterway. Ryan Lawrence has pleaded guilty to murdering his daughter, Maddox Lawrence. pic. twitter.      Ryan Lawrence pleaded guilty to   murder in a plea deal with Onondaga County prosecutors. CBS8 reported that authorities said he was jealous over the attention his daughter Maddox received after surviving eye cancer. BREAKING: Ryan Lawrence has been indicted on 1st degree murder for his daughter Maddox . Details @TWCNewsCNY pic. twitter.  Lawrence admitted beating the girl to death outside Syracuse in February. Authorities say he burned the girlÃ¢ÂÂs body in a fire pit, then tied the remains to a cinder block that he dumped in Onondaga Creek in Syracuse. The childÃ¢ÂÂs body was found by police divers about 36 hours after an Amber Alert was issued for the missing child. Prosecutors say the babyÃ¢ÂÂs mother agreed to the plea deal. Lawrence, whose own mother worked as a advocate for victims of abuse, will be sentenced next month to 25 years to life in prison. Onondaga County Distirct Attorney Bill Fitzpatrick told the station that the girl had a very unusual form of cancer, but she was a fighter, and treatments appeared successful. The girlÃ¢ÂÂs father reportedly told authorities that he was jealous of the attention the girl received Ã¢ÂÂas opposed to the attention he was getting. Ã¢ÂÂ The Associated Press contributed to this report
Title: NY dad, jealous of the attention his cancer-survivor daughter received, pleads guilty to killing her

Content: Stowell, a   developer from Austin, Texas, taped the quiz show back in August, and the episode is set to premiere on Dec. 13, a Ã¢ÂÂJeopardy!Ã¢ÂÂ spokesperson confirmed. This marks the first posthumous airing of a contestantÃ¢ÂÂs appearance. Ã¢ÂÂWhen Cindy Stowell taped her appearance on Ã¢ÂÂJeopardy! ,Ã¢ÂÂ she had Stage IV cancer. Competing on Ã¢ÂÂJeopardy!Ã¢ÂÂ was a lifelong dream for Cindy, and weÃ¢ÂÂre glad she was able to do so,Ã¢ÂÂ said host Alex Trebek in a statement provided to The Post. Ã¢ÂÂSadly, Cindy died on Dec. 5. All of us at Ã¢ÂÂJeopardy!Ã¢ÂÂ offer our condolences and best wishes to her family and friends. Ã¢ÂÂ Her death and forthcoming Ã¢ÂÂJeopardy!Ã¢ÂÂ appearance was first announced on Twitter by her longtime boyfriend Jason Hess, who posted that Ã¢ÂÂShe was fighting a   fever (which turned out to be a blood infection) and was on painkillers while taping. Ã¢ÂÂ Stowell competed with the goal of donating her prize winnings to   organizations. Ã¢ÂÂCindy came on Ã¢ÂÂJeopardy!Ã¢ÂÂ to play the game she loved and in doing so, she was able to make a contribution to cancer research in the hopes that no one else would have to go through what she did,Ã¢ÂÂ said Hess and her parents, Greg and Carole Stowell, in a joint statement. Only Trebek and a select group of staffers knew that she was sick. Stowell, who had a Ph. D. in chemical engineering, first passed the online audition test in early 2016, and received an invitation to an   audition in Oklahoma City this past summer. She was able to tape three weeks after qualifying, when she informed a show producer that she had recently been told by her doctor that she had about six months to live. Title: Ã¢ÂÂJeopardy!Ã¢ÂÂ contestant dies of cancer week before episode airs

Title: EU clears Bristol-Myers immunotherapy drug for blood cancer

Content: A leading cancer hospital is tackling a big problem that keeps many patients from healing Ã¢ÂÂ  loss of appetite. The innovative program, getting under way at NYU LangoneÃ¢ÂÂs Perlmutter Cancer Center in New York City, will design customized diets for patients after assessing their particular reasons for not eating enough, such as nausea, difficulty swallowing or depression. Patients will receive prepared meals at home from a nonprofit group called GodÃ¢ÂÂs Love We Deliver. A randomized controlled trial will assess whether patients benefit from the program. Cancer patients traditionally get dietary advice, but it may provide little help in overcoming eating difficulties. The NYU program aims to offer patients more concrete solutions. Ã¢ÂÂWe are not simply throwing food at them,Ã¢ÂÂ says Erin Jennings, an oncology dietitian and a   on the study. Ã¢ÂÂWe are providing a nutritional Ã¢ÂÂinterventionÃ¢ÂÂ for them. Ã¢ÂÂ Omar Ishaq, chief resident in radiation oncology at NYU who came up with the   idea, says even though patients are getting the very latest in cancer therapies, many of them stop eating and become malnourished. Ã¢ÂÂThey end up staying in the hospital and have more complications from treatment,Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Ishaq says. NYU doctors are beginning to enroll 180 patients with advanced, stage 4 lung and gastrointestinal cancers to participate in the randomized controlled trial. Half the group will be assessed for eating problems and receive customized meals, while the rest will get just the nutrition counseling that NYU typically provides its cancer patients. Click for more from the Wall Street Journal.
Title: In a test, cancer hospital customizes diet to help patients

Content: Nina Cusick was diagnosed with bowel cancer in February 2015. At the time, she was pregnant and gave birth to her son six weeks early. Doctors told Nina and her husband, Ed, the    only had six weeks to live, but the couple found a drug that has helped extend her life. Now, the family of three is fundraising in the hopes that Nina will live long enough to see their    son open his Christmas presents. The Cusicks, of Aylesbury, England, launched an online campaign to raise $125, 000 for the drug Regorafenib, which costs more than $6, 000 every three weeks, Inside Edition reported. The drug is not covered by national health care, so the family is paying for fully it out of pocket. They hope the funding will cover the cost of the drug until a new clinical trial next year, which is not guaranteed to accept Nina. According to Inside Edition, NinaÃ¢ÂÂs cancer has spread to her liver and bones. Ã¢ÂÂCancer is very sneaky. It really can suddenly switch things round, but if we have got a bit of hope to cling onto, then we are going to take it,Ã¢ÂÂ Ed told Inside Edition. Ã¢ÂÂShe is our all. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Dad fundraises for cancer drug to keep wife alive for Christmas

Content: Sen. Claire McCaskill ( ) announced Monday that she has breast cancer, but said her prognosis is Ã¢ÂÂgoodÃ¢ÂÂ and she expects a full recovery. McCaskill posted on her website that she will be in St. Louis for three weeks receiving treatment, during which her staff will work with constituents and she will post on her Senate website. Read her full statement below: Thank you for the honor of serving you in the Senate. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton also tweeted her support to McCaskill, signing the tweet with her initial: . @clairecmc If ever cancer picked the wrong person to mess with, itÃ¢ÂÂs you. Stay strong and take care of yourself. IÃ¢ÂÂm in your corner.
Title: McCaskill Announces She Has Breast Cancer, Expects Ã¢ÂÂFull RecoveryÃ¢ÂÂ

Content: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. (AP)  Ã¢ÂÂ   Missouri Sen. Claire McCaskill says sheÃ¢ÂÂs returning to work after breast cancer treatment. The Democratic senator told reporters Monday that she has received a good prognosis. She spent three weeks in St. Louis receiving treatment, including surgery to remove a lump and some surrounding tissue. McCaskill said the cancer was detected early through a regular mammogram. McCaskill said the treatment provided Ã¢ÂÂa really good time for me to refocus on some of the things that are really important in life.Ã¢ÂÂ She said she spent a lot of time with her husband and did a lot of reading. McCaskill is backing former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in MissouriÃ¢ÂÂs Democratic presidential primary Tuesday. McCaskill said the cancer treatment prevented her from actively campaigning on ClintonÃ¢ÂÂs behalf. Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
Title: Missouri Sen. McCaskill Back To Work After Cancer Treatment

Content: Silicon Valley startups are racing to develop a blood test for cancer that many scientists believe is years, if not decades, away. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a   competition, fueled by hundreds of millions of dollars in venture capital. The winner could help millions of patients fight off cancer before the disease shows any outward symptoms  Ã¢ÂÂ   early enough to drastically improve their odds of survival. Or at least thatÃ¢ÂÂs what these companies envision on their websites and pitch decks, and at scientific meetings  Ã¢ÂÂ   and investors are buying it. Founded in 2014, Freenome raised $65 million last month from Andreessen Horowitz, Peter ThielÃ¢ÂÂs Founders Fund, and AlphabetÃ¢ÂÂs venture arm GV. One of FreenomeÃ¢ÂÂs most prominent rivals, Grail, which spun out of the   monolith Illumina in 2016, has raised an   $1 billion from the likes of Bill Gates and Jeff Bezos. Another competitor, Guardant Health, has amassed close to $200 million. So far, however, these companies have shared scant few details about how, exactly, theyÃ¢ÂÂre creating a test that could fundamentally change how we deal with cancer. FreenomeÃ¢ÂÂs CEO and cofounder, Gabriel Otte, told Fast Company in April 2016 that its test would hit the market within nine months, after being published in a scientific journal. In June, he wrote a blog post claiming that those results would appear Ã¢ÂÂvery soon. Ã¢ÂÂ That hasnÃ¢ÂÂt happened. Otte told BuzzFeed News his staff is still setting up clinical trials and will publish results Ã¢ÂÂwhen weÃ¢ÂÂre ready to publish. Ã¢ÂÂ (Otte recently admitted to BuzzFeed News that he does not have a PhD, despite multiple references to the contrary in the press, company materials, and scientific conferences.) Grail and Guardant have not published any findings, either, although their executives also say they intend to. Academic cancer researchers, meanwhile, say producing this kind of test is an incredibly difficult scientific and logistical challenge. Nascent tumors sometimes shed telltale markers in the blood, but often donÃ¢ÂÂt, and these Ã¢ÂÂbiomarkersÃ¢ÂÂ can be different from one person to another, or even in one person from one month to the next. Plus, credible data will take at least several more years to accumulate in rigorous clinical trials, if not longer. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs not going to be a Star Trek, Ã¢ÂÂletÃ¢ÂÂs take a quick sample and tell you exactly what disease you have and how to treat it,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Jeremy Jones, an assistant professor of cancer biology at the City of Hope in Los Angeles, told BuzzFeed News. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs no question that such a test would be revolutionary. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs no question that such a test would be revolutionary, giving its inventors enormous social and financial rewards. Ã¢ÂÂEarly detection is incredibly attractive, because if you can detect cancers early, you can cure them at a much higher frequency,Ã¢ÂÂ Tony Blau, a hematologist who directs the Center for Cancer Innovation at the University of Washington, told BuzzFeed News. Just as investors in Theranos, the $9 billion startup now fighting for its life after very public regulatory missteps, envisioned a world where doctors could test for all kinds of conditions from a few drops of blood, Silicon Valley is embracing the vision of cancer screening for everyone, early and often. Blood tests for   cancer would be drastically better than current diagnostic methods like Ã¢ÂÂtissue biopsies,Ã¢ÂÂ in which doctors extract potentially cancerous tissue with needles and surgeries. Tests on a couple teaspoons of blood could be much less expensive and invasive, and performed more often. A highly accurate test would also have an advantage over todayÃ¢ÂÂs   tests. Mammograms, for instance, have high rates of both false negatives (they miss one in five breast cancers) and false positives (which happen to about half of women who get the test annually over a decade). Scientists have long known that cancer cells routinely shed bits of DNA into the bloodstream. But in the past few years, thanks to advances in DNA sequencing, these bits have become far easier to detect. There are already a handful of tests, led by Guardant, that use these DNA bits to detect cancer in a cancer patientÃ¢ÂÂs blood, or to identify certain mutations that might be treatable with personalized therapies. But so far, there is no reliably accurate commercial test that can do this for people who are early in the disease and have not yet been diagnosed  Ã¢ÂÂ   the lofty goal of Freenome and its competitors. The DNA shed by   tumors accounts for less than   of a percent of all DNA in a patientÃ¢ÂÂs blood, said Ash Alizadeh, a Stanford University oncologist who helped develop and sell a technology to potentially help doctors monitor how a tumor responds to therapy. For some tumors, such as those that start in the brain, their DNA is virtually undetectable even in tens of milliliters of blood, he added. Ã¢ÂÂThe computations are so low,Ã¢ÂÂ Alizadeh said. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs been a major challenge for early detection. Ã¢ÂÂ Even if a test was able to detect every single molecule of DNA in a blood sample, that wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be enough. Machines often generate   readings of clumps of cells that are deceptively   such as moles that donÃ¢ÂÂt turn into melanoma or colorectal polyps that donÃ¢ÂÂt become colon cancer, Alizadeh says. Ã¢ÂÂDo we know that those changes are always going to lead to a cancer that could threaten a patientÃ¢ÂÂs life?Ã¢ÂÂ said Blau of the University of Washington. Ã¢ÂÂThe answer to that is no, we donÃ¢ÂÂt know that. Ã¢ÂÂ Yet another hurdle is simply knowing what DNA sequences to look for, since, as Blau points out, cancer cells differ within the same patient, and even within the same tumor. And even if a test appears to work in a lab, proving it works in people will take years. Ã¢ÂÂYou have to test thousands of patients, wait long enough that enough of them get cancer and enough of them ultimately die of the disease, to be able to really evaluate if a new test is a useful screening test,Ã¢ÂÂ Max Diehn, an assistant professor of radiation oncology at Stanford, told BuzzFeed News. (He also consults for Roche, which owns the technology he   with Alizadeh.) One of GrailÃ¢ÂÂs first steps is a   clinical trial in the United States with at least 7, 000 patients with untreated cancer, and 3, 000   people. It began in August 2016 and plans to wrap up by August 2022. Scientists hope to understand the molecular differences in the two groupsÃ¢ÂÂ blood samples, as well as how they change as disease develops. Grail has an advantage in its ties to Illumina, the worldÃ¢ÂÂs dominant supplier of   machines, which expects Grail to become Ã¢ÂÂone of IlluminaÃ¢ÂÂs largest customers over time. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂOur hope is over time that weÃ¢ÂÂll be marching the population back earlier and earlier to where almost everyone who has cancer is diagnosed early,Ã¢ÂÂ Grail Chief Business Officer Ken Drazan told BuzzFeed News. Guardant, on the other hand, believes that the knowledge it has already gleaned from testing 35, 000 cancer samples can help pinpoint how the disease arises. President AmirAli Talasaz says that in addition to studying tumor DNA fragments, the company is looking at other kinds of chemical changes in tumors, called Ã¢ÂÂepigenomicÃ¢ÂÂ variations. Guardant is running clinical trials of various sizes, including on   patients and cancer survivors a spokeswoman said there is no estimated date of completion. Meanwhile, Freenome is testing its technology on patient blood samples from UC San Francisco, UC San Diego, Massachusetts General Hospital, and other clinics. For some samples, Freenome tries to predict if the patients received a cancer diagnosis or not. Other samples are from patients who are still being tracked for cancer but havenÃ¢ÂÂt yet been diagnosed. In total, Freenome plans to test Ã¢ÂÂthousandsÃ¢ÂÂ of samples, though Otte declined to say how many have been tested to date. He still contends that these data will be published in a scientific journal before tests are sold commercially. The CEO reportedly hooked FreenomeÃ¢ÂÂs main investor, Andreessen Horowitz, after acing a blinded test of five blood samples provided by the venture capital firm (which also invests in BuzzFeed). As Otte wrote last year, the company correctly categorized two of the samples as normal, and the other three as cancerous  Ã¢ÂÂ   and even accurately labeled what stage of disease. Although two of the cancer samples were from patients in late stages, he wrote, the third was stage one, a sign that the test could detect early cancer in a   person. At a conference in San Francisco in February, Otte shared some striking numbers with an audience of scientists. Freenome had an accuracy rate of more than 95% in detecting the presence or absence of prostate cancer in 351 samples, according to an abstract of the presentation that Otte subsequently confirmed was real. Supposing that FreenomeÃ¢ÂÂs test is as sensitive and specific as the rate claimed, Ã¢ÂÂthat would be a surprising result,Ã¢ÂÂ Diehn, of Stanford, said. Alizadeh said there doesnÃ¢ÂÂt seem to be enough information about the studies to know what to make of the technologyÃ¢ÂÂs apparently high performance. Ã¢ÂÂFor any test, especially a clinical one,Ã¢ÂÂ he said by email, Ã¢ÂÂinterpreting accuracy requires knowing the error rate. Ã¢ÂÂ In DiehnÃ¢ÂÂs view, too, there isnÃ¢ÂÂt enough information to evaluate FreenomeÃ¢ÂÂs claims. Ã¢ÂÂWhen you have a surprising result, the onus is on the scientists to provide evidence  Ã¢ÂÂ   strong evidence, supportive evidence  Ã¢ÂÂ   for such a claim. Ã¢ÂÂ During his presentation, Otte also said Freenome had a 97% average accuracy rate in detecting breast, prostate, lung, and colorectal cancers across four stages of progression, including stage one. The sample size wasnÃ¢ÂÂt disclosed. Ã¢ÂÂIf theyÃ¢ÂÂre trying to say they can tell what stage a patient has, based on a blood test, I would find that would be very surprising,Ã¢ÂÂ Diehn said. A stage is defined by how far a tumor has spread from where it started, which usually requires imaging and pathological tests, according to Diehn. Sometimes, he said, the only difference between a   and   tumor is being slightly bigger, or spreading to a single lymph node. According to Jones, who attended the presentation, Otte said that Freenome could tell when a case of prostate cancer was aggressive or  . There are Ã¢ÂÂearly indicationsÃ¢ÂÂ that the technology can do this, Otte told BuzzFeed News, but it is still in development. Otte acknowledged that all of these results need to be validated in larger clinical trials. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre focused on making sure that we get the numbers we need to prove to the world that our tests are safe and function well. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂWhat theyÃ¢ÂÂre saying could be theyÃ¢ÂÂve developed a great test, or they donÃ¢ÂÂt really have the data, and theyÃ¢ÂÂre trying to make it sound like they have. Ã¢ÂÂ OtteÃ¢ÂÂs talk left Jones impressed, he said, but wondering, Ã¢ÂÂHow do we know itÃ¢ÂÂs real?Ã¢ÂÂ He understands why Freenome wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt want to reveal its technologyÃ¢ÂÂs   to competitors before the test is on the market. But that choice, he said, Ã¢ÂÂmakes it difficult in academic science to know how valid it is. Ã¢ÂÂ Diehn put it more bluntly: Ã¢ÂÂWhat theyÃ¢ÂÂre saying could be theyÃ¢ÂÂve developed a great test, or they donÃ¢ÂÂt really have the data, and theyÃ¢ÂÂre trying to make it sound like they have. Ã¢ÂÂ FreenomeÃ¢ÂÂs test picks up not only tumor DNA fragments, Otte said, but DNA changes that signal Ã¢ÂÂhow the immune system is responding to the presence or absence of the tumor. Ã¢ÂÂ FreenomeÃ¢ÂÂs   platform deduced that a    link between these unspecified immunological signatures and cancer, Otte said. It makes sense that the immune system would respond to an abnormal growth early on, Jones says. But Ã¢ÂÂthe immune system obviously responds to things other than cancer all the time,Ã¢ÂÂ he added. Ã¢ÂÂWhat if a patient is on antibiotics, what if they have an active viral or bacterial infection? Does that cloud the ability to detect the cancer pattern?Ã¢ÂÂ Unlike Guardant and Grail, Freenome does not have a clinical or scientific advisory board. The company is in the process of building them, Otte wrote last month. Vijay Pande, a general partner at Andreessen Horowitz and a Freenome board member, said the company is rightfully broadening its analysis beyond just tumor DNA. Ã¢ÂÂThereÃ¢ÂÂs a whole landscape, in principle, of whatÃ¢ÂÂs going on in your body available in blood,Ã¢ÂÂ he told BuzzFeed News. There arenÃ¢ÂÂt existing papers that describe the basis of FreenomeÃ¢ÂÂs approach, Pande acknowledged  Ã¢ÂÂ   but thatÃ¢ÂÂs because its computational methods are so advanced, theyÃ¢ÂÂre effectively creating new knowledge. Ã¢ÂÂThis is new territory,Ã¢ÂÂ said the former Stanford computational biologist. Ã¢ÂÂThis could not be done 20 years ago. Ã¢ÂÂ Whether it can be done today remains to be seen.
Title: Can A Simple Blood Test Really Spot Cancer Early? DonÃ¢ÂÂt Bet On It Yet, ScientistsÃÂ Say.

Content: Ã¢ÂÂ In January, Sachi Nakamura, from Chicago, Illinois, received two envelopes addressed to her and her daughter, Miho. Miho died in 2016, at the age of 21 from stomach cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ In the envelopes were two letters, written by her daughter, to her future self.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Miho wrote the letters as part of her English class at school and was supposed to get the letters back when was 19 and another when she was 22, but her teacher had passed away in 2013, before the letters were sent out. Sachi believes someone recently found them and put many classes worth of letters in the mail.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Sachi told BuzzFeed News that, after taking time off from college for depression, Miho was studying at the University of Illinois when she was diagnosed with stomach cancer in April 2015.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ She says when she opened the letters, which she wasnÃ¢ÂÂt expecting, and read the words, Ã¢ÂÂDear Miho,Ã¢ÂÂ she was shocked.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ While reading through the letter, Sachi said she could see her daughter growing up, but also the first signs of her depression.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Sachi shared the surprise on her Facebook, where many people commented to say they also had received there letters.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Sachi also told BuzzFeed that she agreed with commenters whoÃ¢ÂÂd called the occurrence a Ã¢ÂÂgift from God. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂI agree with them. While it is bittersweet, I was very happy to receive something from her life, 10 months after her passing. It is particularly special because Mr. Wall is also gone,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂWhen I think about it, it is not that miraculous  Ã¢ÂÂ¦    but receiving them made me happy. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ]
Title: A Mother Received Letters From Her Daughter, Months After She Died FromÃÂ Cancer

Content: Ã¢ÂÂThis week in the British Medical Journal, a group of experts argue patients are being misled by claims that cancer screening Ã¢ÂÂsaves livesÃ¢ÂÂ.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ They say screening should be measured against the total number of deaths, rather than just deaths from one specific type of cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Screening means testing healthy people for early signs of cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ But thereÃ¢ÂÂs a difference between Ã¢ÂÂsaving livesÃ¢ÂÂ and lowering rates of cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Most trials measure how screening changes the death rate from the cancer being screened for.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Screening often reduces the death rate from a specific cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ But when you look at overall deaths, they can remain the same.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Screening doesnÃ¢ÂÂt help us deal with all kinds of cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Screening can lead to overdiagnosis and unnecessary treatment.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ So what should be done about it? Ã¢ÂÂ] Saying that screening Ã¢ÂÂsave livesÃ¢ÂÂ is misleading, Prasad told BuzzFeed News, because dying in general Ã¢ÂÂhas not been proven to be lowerÃ¢ÂÂ. Epidemiologst Gilbert Welch, who was not involved in the analysis but whose work was cited, told BuzzFeed News that he agrees with the authors.  In his book Less Medicine, More Health (Beacon Press, 2015) Welch writes:  Screening is often promoted as Ã¢ÂÂsaving lives. Ã¢ÂÂ I bet when most people hear that language they think it means that screening helps people live longer. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what most of my patients think Ã¢ÂÂ  and thatÃ¢ÂÂs what I would have thought before I started to study cancer screening. In 2013, 30 years after the initial screening, the studyÃ¢ÂÂs researchers published a  . They found that in the screened group, 2% of people had died from colon cancer. In the unscreened group, 3% had (as is illustrated in the graph below). So the screening worked, right? Screening might Ã¢ÂÂsave livesÃ¢ÂÂ from one disease, but not Ã¢ÂÂsave livesÃ¢ÂÂ overall. The turtles arenÃ¢ÂÂt going anywhere. They are the indolent, nonlethal cancers. The rabbits are ready to hop out at any time. They are the potentially lethal cancers, cancers that might be stopped by early treatment. Then there are the birds. Quite simply: they are already gone. They are the most aggressive cancers, the ones that have already spread by the time they are detectable, the ones that are beyond cure.  Screening can only help with the rabbits. The turtles donÃ¢ÂÂt need help the birds canÃ¢ÂÂt be helped. This is how some types of cancer can counterintuitively end up causing more damage if they are caught early on. It is the turtles  Ã¢ÂÂ   cancers that were never really going anywhere in the first place  Ã¢ÂÂ   that cause the problem of overdiagnosis. In their BMJ analysis, Prasad and his   use the example of PSA, a test for prostate cancer. They say PSA tests lead to lots of false positives, which contribute to 1 million people undergoing prostate biopsies every year. This can have bad consequences: Prostate biopsies are associated with serious harms, including admission to hospital and death. Moreover, men diagnosed with prostate cancer are more likely to have a heart attack or commit suicide in the year after diagnosis or to die of complications of treatment for cancers that may never have caused symptoms. But in the meantime, Prasad and his colleagues say the risks of screening need to be better communicated to patients to help them make up their own minds. Ã¢ÂÂScreening is a discussion,Ã¢ÂÂ he told BuzzFeed News. Ã¢ÂÂIt is not a box to check off at a certain age. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: We DonÃ¢ÂÂt Know If Cancer Screening Actually Ã¢ÂÂSaves LivesÃ¢ÂÂ, ExpertsÃÂ Argue

Content: The announcement was posted to DionÃ¢ÂÂs website: RenÃÂ© AngÃÂ©lil, 73, passed away this morning at his home in Las Vegas after a long and courageous battle against cancer. The family requests that their privacy be respected at the moment more details will be provided at a later time. AngÃÂ©lil, who guided DionÃ¢ÂÂs career as her manager, is survived by the coupleÃ¢ÂÂs three children, including    twins. He is also survived by two adult children from a previous relationship. The following year, Dion began to receive gold medals and world recognition for her singing. AngÃÂ©lil continued to manage her career, and in 1994 the couple married. In interviews, Dion said their relationship was based on Ã¢ÂÂtrue love. Ã¢ÂÂ The couple celebrated their 21st wedding anniversary last month.  In 1999, AngÃÂ©lil was diagnosed with throat cancer, but, after aggressive treatment, was declared cancer free in 2000, when the couple renewed their vows in a lavish celebration. But in 2013, Dion and AngÃÂ©lil learned the cancer had returned.  In a recent appearance on Good Morning America, Dion also revealed that AngÃÂ©lil had to be fed through a feeding tube, telling host Deborah Roberts, Ã¢ÂÂWe are taking life one day at a time, [but] we are choosing to live. Ã¢ÂÂ DionÃ¢ÂÂs shows scheduled for Jan. 16 and Jan. 17 at Caesars Palace were canceled.
Title: Celine DionÃ¢ÂÂs Husband, RenÃÂ© AngÃÂ©lil, Dies OfÃÂ Cancer

Content: Sen. Claire McCaskill of Missouri announced Monday that she has been diagnosed with breast cancer but that she expects to make a full recovery. McCaskill, a    Democrat, said in a statement posted to her Tumblr account that she plans to take three weeks off to get treatment in St. Louis. This is the full statement: I will be in St Louis for the next 3 weeks receiving treatment. During this time my staff will continue to assist Missourians and I will be posting on my Senate website (McCaskill. senate. gov) how I would have voted on any matters that come before the Senate during my absence  Ã¢ÂÂ   which IÃ¢ÂÂll also enter into the Congressional record. Additionally, IÃ¢ÂÂll be submitting questions in writing for any missed Senate hearings. Thank you for the honor of serving you in the Senate. McCaskill, who is the first woman to represent Missouri in the U. S. Senate, recently made headlines by live tweeting parts of her jury duty. She was chosen to decide a civil case regarding a man who fell in side a convenience store. Generally viewed as one of the more moderate Democratic senators, McCaskill has recently been a vocal member of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee in its battle with Backpage. com, which is being accused of enabling sex trafficking. The committee recently voted to hold the online advertising company in contempt of Congress over its refusal to hand over documents on how it screens clients. Ã¢ÂÂI am disgusted that any company would not participate and cooperate in an investigation into the trafficking of children,Ã¢ÂÂ McCaskill said during a hearing earlier this month.
Title: Missouri Senator Claire McCaskill Announces She Has BreastÃÂ Cancer

Content: In 1989, a New Yorker writer named Paul Brodeur published a story about Meadow Street in Guilford, Connecticut, where cancer cases had clustered near power lines and an electric substation. His influential book, called The Great Power Line Cover Up, followed in 1993. It was a sequel, of sorts, to stories Brodeur had written in the 1970s linking microwave ovens, TV broadcasts, and CB radios to potentially lethal doses of radiation. Ã¢ÂÂAfter reading Ã¢ÂÂThe Great   Ã¢ÂÂ the only thing I am convinced of is that author Paul Brodeur truly believes that electromagnetic waves from   cause cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ a reviewer wrote in the Los Angeles Times in 1993. These days, we donÃ¢ÂÂt hear much about microwaves, or power lines, or CB radios causing cancer, because now we have new gadgets to worry about: our cell phones. On Thursday, a preliminary cell phone radiation study in rats, posted online by the very respectable National Toxicology Program, part of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) has once again raised the question of whether invisible radiation is giving us all cancer. The study found low rates  Ã¢ÂÂ   in the 2% to 3% range  Ã¢ÂÂ   of brain and heart tumors in 90 male rats dosed with nine hours a day of cell phone exposure for two years, starting in the womb. The rats exposed to cell phone signals also lived longer than others, which is kind of weird if the radiation is so deadly. And it didnÃ¢ÂÂt affect female rats. Despite the slew of headlines the study spurred, cancer researchers say one rat study doesnÃ¢ÂÂt erase a patchy history of claims of a link between electric fields and cancer. Plus, there just isnÃ¢ÂÂt any human data, and no increase in brain or heart tumors in people that should show up with hundreds of millions of them using cells phone, if there really was a link. Ã¢ÂÂThere is a really long history here of studies like this one, where the immediate response of people in the field is that Ã¢ÂÂthis must be wrongÃ¢ÂÂ we would have seen it long ago if it was true. Which is infuriating,Ã¢ÂÂ cancer epidemiologist Richard Stevens of the University of Connecticut, who was not involved in the study, told BuzzFeed News. Ã¢ÂÂOn the other side, we have had a long history of scares, where many times, they are junk science. Ã¢ÂÂ A 1992 study linking power lines to cancer, for example, turned out to be a case of scientific misconduct, where a researcher from Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory fabricated data to suggest cells altered their chemistry in response to electromagnetic fields. The new NTP study isnÃ¢ÂÂt junk science, which is why it has gotten some notice, after it was first reported by Microwave News (dedicated to Ã¢ÂÂreporting on the potential health and environmental impacts of electromagnetic fields and radiationÃ¢ÂÂ for 35 years). The experiment was requested by the Food and Drug Administration after a 2011 World Health Organization classification of cell phone signals as a Ã¢ÂÂpossible carcinogenÃ¢ÂÂ and conducted by   federal scientists. Ã¢ÂÂThis report from the National Toxicology Program is good science,Ã¢ÂÂ Otis Brawley of the American Cancer Society said in a statement on the study that called it a Ã¢ÂÂparadigm shiftÃ¢ÂÂ in cell phone risk thinking. Ã¢ÂÂThis is a striking example of why serious study is so important in evaluating cancer risk. Ã¢ÂÂ On the other hand, Ã¢ÂÂa lot of these basic science studies just donÃ¢ÂÂt work out and are never replicated,Ã¢ÂÂ Nicole Willmarth of the American Brain Tumor Association. Ã¢ÂÂPeople should take studies like this one with a grain of salt. Ã¢ÂÂ The rat study is just part of a bigger effort scheduled for completion next year, which also includes mice. One NIH reviewer of the paper, Michael Lauer, suggested that the results were likely false, simply based on the low number of rats involved in the study. The curious finding that male rats in the control group unexposed to cell phone signals died sooner, and that past studies havenÃ¢ÂÂt seen such an effect, Ã¢ÂÂleaves me even more skeptical of the authorsÃ¢ÂÂ claims,Ã¢ÂÂ Lauer wrote. Ã¢ÂÂWe do not know why the male rat control group had a low survival rate,Ã¢ÂÂ the NTP research team acknowledged in their report. But they stood by their statistics, suggesting there is only a 5% chance it is a fluke. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs standard in medical studies, but it makes a lot of statisticians nervous, especially after a 2005 Stanford study titled Ã¢ÂÂWhy Most Published Research Findings Are FalseÃ¢ÂÂ raised the profile of unreliable statistics in biomedicine. The dose of cellphone radiation  Ã¢ÂÂ   not enough to warm the rats, but close  Ã¢ÂÂ   and its duration starting in the womb, make it very hard to extrapolate from the findings to the average person whose cell phone spends most of its time plugged into the dashboard of their car, Willmarth said. Ã¢ÂÂWhatÃ¢ÂÂs remarkable is they are finding any effect at all. Ã¢ÂÂ About 240 million Americans own cell phones, while only 150 million owned one in 2000. And over that same time period, brain cancer rates have remained flat or declined slightly, according to National Cancer Institute data, at about 6 cases in every 100, 000 people. Ã¢ÂÂYou might argue that brain tumor rates are not increasing and more people are using cell phones, but you could also say people donÃ¢ÂÂt hold cell phones to their heads so much anymore, they are reading or sending text messages on them,Ã¢ÂÂ said Willmarth. Most researchers just see the new NIH study as science at work, slow and steady. But the original radiation alarmist Brodeur, now 85, sees a conspiracy. Ã¢ÂÂThese findings are nothing short of a bombshell,Ã¢ÂÂ he told BuzzFeed News by email, saying they will force NCI and NIH to weigh in after Ã¢ÂÂignoring or denying the existence of this problem for more than two decades. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: No, Your Cell Phone Probably IsnÃ¢ÂÂt Giving YouÃÂ Cancer

Content: Craig Sager, the NBA sideline reporter famous for his colorful suits, died Thursday after having cancer for years. He was 65. Ã¢ÂÂCraig Sager was a beloved member of the Turner family for more than three decades and he has been a true inspiration to all of us,Ã¢ÂÂ Turner Broadcasting President David Levy said in a statement. Sager, a longtime face on TNT, stood out on the sidelines with his flashy suits. Ã¢ÂÂWhile he will be remembered fondly for his colorful attire and the TNT sideline interviews he conducted with NBA coaches and players, itÃ¢ÂÂs the determination, grace and will to live he displayed during his battle with cancer that will be his lasting impact,Ã¢ÂÂ Levy continued. Ã¢ÂÂOur thoughts and prayers are with CraigÃ¢ÂÂs wife, Stacy, and the entire Sager family during this difficult time. We will forever be Sager Strong. Ã¢ÂÂ In addition to his wife, Sager is survived by his five children. Sager had been open about his 2014 diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia, and in 2015 he took time off for treatment. When he returned to the air in December 2015, Gregg Popovich, the notoriously difficult coach of the San Antonio Spurs, offered a touching welcome back. Ã¢ÂÂI can honestly tell you this is the first time IÃ¢ÂÂve enjoyed doing this ridiculous interview weÃ¢ÂÂre required to do,Ã¢ÂÂ Popovich said. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs because youÃ¢ÂÂre here and youÃ¢ÂÂre back with us. Ã¢ÂÂ NBA Commissioner Adam Silver said Sager was widely respected for his insightful reporting, as well as the courage he showed in the face of his illness. Ã¢ÂÂCraig Sager was as vital to the NBA as the players and coaches,Ã¢ÂÂ Silver said in a statement. Ã¢ÂÂA true original and an essential voice on Turner SportsÃ¢ÂÂ NBA coverage for 26 seasons, Craig chronicled some of the most memorable moments in league history and was a ubiquitous presence with his splashy suits and equally colorful personality. Ã¢ÂÂ In July, Sager was honored with the Jimmy V Award for Perseverance at the ESPYs. He reflected on his life in sports, and the effect being diagnosed with a terminal disease had on him. Ã¢ÂÂI will never give up, and I will never give in,Ã¢ÂÂ Sager said. Ã¢ÂÂI will continue to keep fighting, sucking the marrow out of life as life sucks the marrow out of me. I will live my life full of love and full of fun. ItÃ¢ÂÂs the only way I know how. Ã¢ÂÂ Vice President Joe Biden, who has led a federal push for cancer research, presented Sager with the award. On Thursday, Biden praised Sager for his courage in face of cancer. Ã¢ÂÂCraig Sager died as he lived  Ã¢ÂÂ   with courage, passion, perseverance,Ã¢ÂÂ Biden tweeted. Ã¢ÂÂFearless and hopeful, a real hero. Ã¢ÂÂ Craig Sager died as he lived Ã¢ÂÂ  with courage, passion, perseverance. Fearless and hopeful, a real hero.
Title: Sportscaster Craig Sager Dies From Cancer AtÃÂ 65

Content: Ã¢ÂÂMy check didnÃ¢ÂÂt come. Ã¢ÂÂ 	Eviction court is not the saddest place in the world, but if you were taking a Dantean descent through the underworld of underclass despair and dysfunction, it would be somewhere around the fourth or fifth circle. Because my Virgil on this journey is an actual attorney, with a suit and tie and everything, the judge has moved us to the end of the docket on the theory that there might be arguments in our case, that this litigation might turn into something resembling litigation. There are not going to be any arguments, but we get to sit through a few hoursÃ¢ÂÂ worth of very sad stories. I think the lawyer enjoys this even less than I do, even though he gets paid by the hour. 	The teacher in me cannot help but notice that when it comes time to explain the facts of the case, the people in this courtroom rarely appear as the subjects in their own sentences. A Ã¢ÂÂdomestic eventÃ¢ÂÂ just Ã¢ÂÂhappened,Ã¢ÂÂ and now the man in her life cannot reside under the same roof as her daughter  Ã¢ÂÂ   or Child Protective Services will take that daughter away. Which means that after her eviction (which is never seriously in doubt) she cannot rely on the person upon whom most people in her situation instinctively would rely. 	She is not the only person whose check didnÃ¢ÂÂt come. The passivity and subjectlessness of these narratives is striking, and strikingly consistent. Domestic events happen. Checks come or donÃ¢ÂÂt come. (Mostly they donÃ¢ÂÂt.) Husbands are sent to jail, children are taken away by the   minions of Authority, disease descends. The money isnÃ¢ÂÂt there. And, in the end, they are evicted. Bad things just happen, and, today, I am the bad thing that is just happening to one of these luckless and unhappy children of God. I am eviction, I am CPS, I am the check that didnÃ¢ÂÂt come. I am diabetic amputation. I am cancer. 	Ã¢ÂÂWhy are you doing this to us?Ã¢ÂÂ the womanÃ¢ÂÂs daughter demanded. Because I am the bad thing that is just happening to you today, the unforeseeable event that has been hanging over you by a single hair of a horseÃ¢ÂÂs tail for a decade, the inevitable end of a terrible lamentation. 	But people love their sad stories. They feel compelled to tell them. Local law here is pretty straightforward on the matter of evictions: If you donÃ¢ÂÂt pay your rent (mine is the only case today not involving rent) then you have to go. Ã¢ÂÂDid you pay any rent in February?Ã¢ÂÂ the judge asks two dozen times. Ã¢ÂÂDid you pay any rent in March?Ã¢ÂÂ The judgeÃ¢ÂÂs power in these matters extends only to ordering (or not ordering) an eviction and ordering the payment of unpaid back rent. If a tenant wants to sue the landlord for violating the lease, or if the landlord wants to sue the tenant for failing to pay an electricity bill or damaging the property, that is a separate action. But even though the judge repeatedly explains that the sins of the landlords are irrelevant at this moment to the immediate legal question before his court, the tale must be told: He didnÃ¢ÂÂt return phone calls or text messages. There were repairs left unmade. There were bedbugs. Tenants put scarce and desperately needed money into making unlivable rental properties just barely livable. 	Ã¢ÂÂDid you pay any rent in April?Ã¢ÂÂ 	It is different in other places that have laws making it more difficult to evict   tenants. One Californian whose family owns a number of residential rentals reports that he routinely pays people cash to vacate properties rather than endure the trouble, expense, and uncertainty of eviction proceedings. I had had the same thought myself, but it quickly became clear that eviction would be the more economical route. They very much wanted to stay in the house, though not enough to offer to rent it or buy it. But certainly enough to sit tight and hope that the situation would somehow just resolve itself in their favor. 	The woman I am evicting does not show up in court. (About half of those evicted decline to attend the proceedings today.) Her son attends on her behalf. My lawyer asks me five or six    questions. The judge asks the son if he has a response. Ã¢ÂÂNo. Ã¢ÂÂ He asks if he would like to present an argument. Ã¢ÂÂNo. Ã¢ÂÂ 	And that was that. 	Of course, thatÃ¢ÂÂs never really that. Many people who have been evicted simply refuse to leave after being ordered to, which means that they will in the end be visited by constables who remove them and their belongings from the property, often to a chorus of wailing and lamentation. And another bad thing just happens to people who, for whatever reason, have no sense of agency in their own lives. 	Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂll give you a break on my rate,Ã¢ÂÂ says my lawyer, looking at his watch. He is the son of   farm laborers, who learned at least one thing from his hard and poor childhood: DonÃ¢ÂÂt be a farm laborer. Law looked like a pretty good alternative, and it seems to be working out pretty well for him. The idiomatic English would be, Ã¢ÂÂHe became a lawyer. Ã¢ÂÂ The better English would be, Ã¢ÂÂHe made himself a lawyer. Ã¢ÂÂ How did that happen? It must have begun with decisions he made as a child or as a very young man: A leads to B leads to C leads to a good income and a nice house and a bass boat. 	A few months ago, I recounted the story of Preston Smith, a man from a very poor background (think outhouses and bare feet) who walked across a wide stretch of Texas to attend college at the beginning of a career that would see him become (make himself) a successful businessman and, later, governor of Texas. He and a friend made a living in college by opening up what at the time would have been called a Ã¢ÂÂfilling station,Ã¢ÂÂ a gas   store. By the time he was out of school, he had a few of them, and a movie theater, too. The reaction to that column surprised me: Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs great,Ã¢ÂÂ critics wrote, Ã¢ÂÂbut he lived at a time when someone in his circumstances could open a gas station without backing and financing, and without all the taxes and regulation we have now. Ã¢ÂÂ As though the Indian, Pakistani, and Bangladeshi immigrants who operate convenience stores from coast to coast show up in the United States with a $1 million line of business credit from Chase, an MBA, and a gas station waiting for them in Oklahoma. Next time youÃ¢ÂÂre filling up in some country location late at night, take a peek around the back of the place, and see how many of those immigrants are quietly living in the gas stations they operate. It is not uncommon, for a time. But they donÃ¢ÂÂt stay there long. 	And while I am not much of a   on these kinds of questions (we have a positive moral obligation to help the poor, and not just the Ã¢ÂÂdeservingÃ¢ÂÂ poor) I cannot help but think of those hustling immigrants when I encounter the   sons and daughters of this sweet land of liberty who, if it were raining jobs and opportunity, would find a way to walk between the raindrops. 	Ã¢ÂÂMy check didnÃ¢ÂÂt come. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂDid you pay any rent in January?Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe factory closed down. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe textile jobs moved to Thailand and Vietnam. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂMy little town is dying. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂMy check didnÃ¢ÂÂt come. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂDid you pay any rent in February? In March?Ã¢ÂÂ 	Ã¢ÂÂMy check didnÃ¢ÂÂt come. Ã¢ÂÂ 	Your check didnÃ¢ÂÂt come. ItÃ¢ÂÂs never coming. 	Now what? Title: I Am Cancer

Content: So, Joe Biden is going to cure cancer. That was among President ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs big ideas in his final State of the Union pageant. LetÃ¢ÂÂs start with the obvious: Joe Biden is not going to cure cancer. Joe Biden couldnÃ¢ÂÂt find chlamydia backstage at a MÃÂ¶tley CrÃÂ¼e concert. (ItÃ¢ÂÂs easy to picture Joe Biden backstage at a MÃÂ¶tley CrÃÂ¼e concert, isnÃ¢ÂÂt it?) He couldnÃ¢ÂÂt find NaCl in an aqueous solution if he fell into the Pacific Ocean. Joe Biden is about as likely to discover a cure for cancer as J. J. Watt is to sing the lead in The Marriage of Figaro and dance in La Sonnambula with the Bolshoi in between    Super Bowl wins. AinÃ¢ÂÂt gonna happen. In fact, it is isnÃ¢ÂÂt very likely that anybody is going to cure cancer  Ã¢ÂÂ   ever. There are some reasons for that, none of which seems to have occurred to Barack Obama. To begin with, thereÃ¢ÂÂs the inconvenient fact that there is no such thing as cancer. Ã¢ÂÂCancerÃ¢ÂÂ refers to a category of diseases, one that contains hundreds of different maladies. Some of those have a great deal in common with one another, many do not.   breast cancer really isnÃ¢ÂÂt very much at all like HodgkinÃ¢ÂÂs lymphoma the former presents a very difficult course of treatment with a poor outlook, while the latter is so effectively treated (90 percent survival rate) that it is sometimes described as Ã¢ÂÂcurable,Ã¢ÂÂ though physicians tend to shy away from the use of that word. Cancer is one of natureÃ¢ÂÂs great survivors, an eternal (so far) reminder that you can give your heart to Jesus but your ass belongs to evolution. As   surgeon David Gorski puts it, Ã¢ÂÂCancer progression can be viewed as being due to a case of evolution in which the tumor cells that survive selection to continue to grow are the ones that become best at doing all the things that tumor cells need to do to evade the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs defenses and overcome its   signals. Ã¢ÂÂ Cancer is unlikely to be Ã¢ÂÂcuredÃ¢ÂÂ for the same reason that crime will never be eradicated: adaptation. At the same time, it would not be at all surprising if, in a generation or two, dying from cancer were as rare and exotic as being crippled by polio is today. There is a great deal of promising research in any number of fields, from genetics to nanobiology, that should instill in us a cautious and sober optimism that we can make more cancers treatable and manageable, that in a few decades having cancer could be more like having diabetes. But that is a very different thing from finding a cure. This is an example of political thinking. The political mind imagines that if political will is bent toward some particular end, and that if the right people with the right philosophy are empowered to command sufficient resources, then all of reality is malleable. That isnÃ¢ÂÂt how the world actually works if it were, there would never be a recession or other economic shocks, intractable   problems related to distant primitive desert savages, or, for that matter, traffic jams. But these things exist, because the world that exists in the political imagination is not the real world. President Obama might have made a different sort of declaration: Ã¢ÂÂWe are going to spend some additional money to fund a number of different   projects, and we hope that at least some of those projects will yield results that enable us to develop, at some point in the future, marginally more effective treatments for some kinds of cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ But that isnÃ¢ÂÂt what President Obama said. It isnÃ¢ÂÂt what President Richard Nixon said, either. In 1971, the federal government  Ã¢ÂÂ   stupid phrase  Ã¢ÂÂ   Ã¢ÂÂdeclared war on cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ President Nixon, with some fanfare, signed into law the National Cancer Act, which increased support to the National Cancer Institute. Ã¢ÂÂAs a result of signing this bill,Ã¢ÂÂ President Nixon said, Ã¢ÂÂthe Congress is totally committed to provide the funds that are necessary, whatever is necessary, for the conquest of cancer. The president is totally committed. . . . You will have, of course, the total commitment of government, and that is what the signing of this bill now does. Ã¢ÂÂ Everyone was committed  Ã¢ÂÂ   and cancer didnÃ¢ÂÂt care, because cancer doesnÃ¢ÂÂt follow politics. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre going to cure cancerÃ¢ÂÂ isnÃ¢ÂÂt a   agenda  Ã¢ÂÂ   itÃ¢ÂÂs a political promise. Government funding of basic scientific research at its   stages is one of the most fruitful (or, if you prefer, least destructive) things that government does. Sometimes that research is in the service of an explicit federal priority (usually military) and sometimes it is more general. Ensuring that the money is well spent without putting research decisions in the hands of lawyers is sometimes a tricky business, one that the researchers themselves often enough complicate by following their own political agendas. Our management practices here probably should tend toward the regular and the general, rather than directing resources into moonshot projects that sound more plausible on television than in the laboratory.  Joe Biden isnÃ¢ÂÂt going to cure cancer. LetÃ¢ÂÂs make sure that he and the imperial hubris he brings with him donÃ¢ÂÂt get in the way of our making progress in treating it, and in advancing our understanding of other diseases.,
Title: No, Joe Biden IsnÃ¢ÂÂt Going to Cure Cancer

Content: Last Monday, the White House announced the formation of its Cancer Moonshot Task Force, a   to President ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs State of the Union exhortation to Ã¢ÂÂmake America the country that cures cancer once and for all. Ã¢ÂÂ At the time, the presidentÃ¢ÂÂs announcement elicited snickers from many on the right concerned about expansive government programs that promise more than they can deliver. But conservatives who worry about the governmentÃ¢ÂÂs role in combating cancer are missing a key part of the picture: When it comes to making big gains against cancer, itÃ¢ÂÂs not about central planners generating solutions from whole cloth itÃ¢ÂÂs about making sure nothing gets in the way of the   treatments that are already within our reach. Conservatives can play an important part in the cancer moonshot by helping to keep it focused on its key task. Cancer cells cloak themselves from the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs immune system. We can now strip that cloak away with drugs called Ã¢ÂÂcheckpoint inhibitors. Ã¢ÂÂ We can also genetically modify   T cells and send them, like predator drones, to attack tumors. Based on research showing that genetic screening could detect   cancer in pregnant women, Illumina just launched a company called Grail to develop and commercialize a test to detect circulating tumor DNA, potentially identifying   patients before they show any clinical symptoms. The earlier we can detect cancer, the more easily we can cure it. But enormous challenges still loom. We desperately need a new Ã¢ÂÂgold standardÃ¢ÂÂ for testing promising cancer medicines  Ã¢ÂÂ   a system that uses the latest advances in artificial intelligence, statistics, and powerful diagnostic platforms to rapidly identify and test promising combinations of drugs in the patients who are most likely to respond.  Another key challenge is to get researchers, companies, and academic medical centers to embrace robust data sharing. Universities use prominent journal articles as a yardstick for tenure, salary, and promotion  Ã¢ÂÂ   encouraging researchers to hoard, not distribute, data. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs also a complex web of privacy regulations at the state and federal levels that discourages data sharing, or provides a   excuse for avoiding it. As a result, everyone pays data sharing lip service, but very few institutions have committed to the kind of massive, routine data sharing that we need to make rapid strides against cancer. Vice President Joe Biden  Ã¢ÂÂ   tasked by President Obama to lead the moonshot efforts  Ã¢ÂÂ   is already making a difference through the call to arms he has issued from the bully pulpit. Share article on FacebookshareTweet A large coalition of pharma and biotech companies, along with academic cancer centers and community oncologists, have agreed to test more than 60 medicines in different immunotherapy combinations, attacking up to 20 tumor types in   trials through the National Immunotherapy Coalition. They call the program Cancer Moonshot 2020.  The NIC aims to use the latest diagnostics tests, including   genomic and proteomic sequencing, to match 20, 000 cancer patients with combination immunotherapies that match their particular disease profiles. The goal is to achieve Ã¢ÂÂdurable,   remission for patients with cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ ItÃ¢ÂÂs the largest immunotherapy trial network of its kind. This is the first time that a major private insurer has agreed to cover   sequencing for cancer patients. (The insurer is Independence Blue Cross.) If this effort is successful, the NIC will help rewrite the rules for rapidly developing and testing novel combination treatments for cancer. BidenÃ¢ÂÂs call for routine data sharing is also shaking up the status quo, drawing long overdue attention to a complex system that claims to protect patient privacy but often operates against the wishes of cancer patients, who are overwhelmingly eager to share their data. Government is well positioned to tackle this problem, because it regulates   research and pays for much of the underlying research and patient care (through Medicare). In short, the opportunity is certainly there to make big strides against cancer quickly. Conservatives should take BidenÃ¢ÂÂs promise to Ã¢ÂÂclear the wayÃ¢ÂÂ of regulatory hurdles for scientists and researchers at face value, and help him find the right walls to knock down. Critics have correctly noted that the engineering problem implied by the Ã¢ÂÂMoonshotÃ¢ÂÂ phrase is wrong. Cancer research isnÃ¢ÂÂt rocket science itÃ¢ÂÂs orders of magnitude more complicated. But theyÃ¢ÂÂre nitpicking when they should be engaging. They should join with Biden and call for government to pare back or repeal costly and ineffective regulations that slow research, empower patients to control their own data, and commit federal agencies to moving towards a nimble,   framework for rapid   development.   ItÃ¢ÂÂs easy to become cynical about government when it tries to do too much. But if we fail to engage, we lose the opportunity to articulate a conservative vision for what government can do well: direct public resources more efficiently and effectively, provide the right incentives for unleashing entrepreneurship and innovation, and set a regulatory framework that empowers patients and their physicians to make informed decisions about the risks and benefits of new technologies.  It might take decades, but the battle against cancer is one America can win. Conservatives shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be on the sidelines in that fight.  Ã¢ÂÂ   Paul Howard, Ph. D. is a senior fellow and director of health policy at the Manhattan Institute.
Title: Conservatives Can Ã¢ÂÂ and Should Ã¢ÂÂ Play a Role in the Cancer Moonshot

Content: The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) now faces congressional inquiries, legal challenges, and harsh criticism from the scientific community that are shredding the agencyÃ¢ÂÂs credibility and threatening its future. The Lyon, France Ã¢ÂÂ  based group is an arm of the World Health Organization and has received millions in U. S. tax dollars, funding that is now being questioned by top lawmakers on Capitol Hill including House Oversight Committee chairman Jason Chaffetz. Congress is also investigating whether IARC is colluding with officials at the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to advance a political agenda rather than sound science. IARCÃ¢ÂÂs central role is to evaluate certain risk factors and whether they can cause cancer. Each year, an IARC working group produces a report  Ã¢ÂÂ   called a monograph  Ã¢ÂÂ   classifying the level of risk for each agent. Out of the nearly 1, 000 factors IARC has evaluated, only one (caprolactam) was deemed  . That report raised immediate suspicions for being politically motivated glyphosate is a widely used weedkiller now targeted by environmental and   groups around the world because it is used on several genetically engineered crops. The chemical was created by Monsanto, which also sells genetically engineered seeds, and sold under the brand name Roundup. Nearly every other scientific and governmental agency has determined that glyphosate is safe. (After the IARC report in March 2015, a separate WHO agency found that glyphosate is unlikely to cause cancer.) But armed with the imprimatur of a global health agency,   activists brandish the report as proof that glyphosate is unsafe and unhealthy. It wasnÃ¢ÂÂt long before IARCs monograph was widely discredited. Even the head of the European Food Safety Authority denounced the report and the IARC as Ã¢ÂÂthe first sign of the Facebook Age of Science,Ã¢ÂÂ writing, Ã¢ÂÂYou have a scientific assessment, you put it on Facebook, and you count how many people Ã¢ÂÂlikeÃ¢ÂÂ it. Ã¢ÂÂ Questions about a corrupt process also began to emerge the man who pushed for the glyphosate review, Christopher Portier, is an environmental activist and worked part time for the Environmental Defense Fund (he told me he didnÃ¢ÂÂt view this as a conflict and did not see the need to disclose that to the IARC). Another agency seems to be playing political games about glyphosate: the EPA. The agency continues to delay a safety reevaluation on glyphosate despite two recent reports that reaffirm EPAs longstanding position that glyphosate does not cause cancer. Lawmakers suspect that the delay is politically motivated and are demanding answers. In a scathing letter to EPA administrator Gina McCarthy on October 25, House Science, Space, and Technology Committee chairman Lamar Smith accused McCarthy of making Ã¢ÂÂmisleading and untruthful statementsÃ¢ÂÂ to Congress last summer about the glyphosate report as well as about her agencyÃ¢ÂÂs involvement with IARC: Ã¢ÂÂThe increasing amount of evidence depicting the close ties between EPA officials, Christopher Portier, and the IARC study of glyphosate show that there are activists working both inside and outside the agency to derail this process. Ã¢ÂÂ Smith is seeking testimony from three EPA employees tied to the IARC working group. Chaffetz is now asking the National Institutes of Health to explain why U. S. taxpayers continue to fund IARC Ã¢ÂÂdespite this record of controversy, retractions, and inconsistencies. Ã¢ÂÂ Chaffetz accuses IARC of trying to Ã¢ÂÂinfluence American policymaking, even though IARC avoids having to meet the strict scientific standards and government scrutiny afforded to science advisory committees in America. Ã¢ÂÂ But despite the fact that IARC gets U. S. tax money, it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt feel bound by U. S. law. IARC officials counseled its   members to ignore Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests from the Energy and Environment Legal Institute (EE Legal) which is seeking documents related to the glyphosate monograph. IARC   members include scientists from American public universities and EPA employees who are required to comply with FOIA. (A Mississippi State University professor offered his resignation from a subsequent IARC group in response to the groupÃ¢ÂÂs request to avoid FOIA inquiries.) EE Legal blasted the cancer agency: Ã¢ÂÂUnfortunately, by their behavior, every player in this unfolding drama thinks they have a right to hide public records from the public. They do not. Ã¢ÂÂ As if congressional and legal pressures arenÃ¢ÂÂt enough, IARC is on the receiving end of withering criticism from its own ranks. Ten top experts in the fields of toxicology and oncology published a report in a prestigious scientific journal on October 26, writing that IARCÃ¢ÂÂs methods are outdated and cause Ã¢ÂÂunnecessary health scares and unnecessary diversion of public funds. Ã¢ÂÂ The scientists are recommending an international initiative to develop updated methods for carcinogenicity assessments. Ã¢ÂÂIARC has become the byword for activist science, disgracing the reputation of international research agencies and undermining the public trust in   scientific policy advice,Ã¢ÂÂ said David Zaruk, a   professor and blogger who has extensively covered the IARC fiasco. Ã¢ÂÂI strongly urge countries like the U. S to take responsibility for the mess this agency has become, demand a wholesale reorganization, or stop funding it. Ã¢ÂÂ Might be time for lawmakers to pull the plug on this ailing agency.,
Title: A Malignancy Grows at an International Cancer Agency

Content: Minnesota Gov. Mark Dayton says heÃ¢ÂÂs been diagnosed with prostate cancer but will finish the final two years of his term. Dayton made the announcement Tuesday, just a day after  . The    Democrat says heÃ¢ÂÂll travel to the Mayo Clinic in Rochester on Tuesday afternoon for tests on why he fainted. HeÃ¢ÂÂll return to Mayo next week to discuss his prostate cancer treatment options.
Title: Governor reveals he has prostate cancer afterÃÂ collapsing

Content: Days after being diagnosed with cervical cancer and just moments before surgery, Erin Andrews had one request for her oncologist. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm not watching any football games at home. This is [FoxÃ¢ÂÂs] Super Bowl year, and IÃ¢ÂÂm not missing the Super Bowl,Ã¢ÂÂ Andrews recalled saying. The FOX broadcaster, who has become a sideline staple on NFL Sundays,   she was diagnosed in late September following a routine checkup last June. While in a meeting with colleagues ahead of the GiantsÃ¢ÂÂ Week 3 showdown with the Redskins at MetLife, Andrews received a phone call from her doctor confirming it was cancer. Ã¢ÂÂWhen you hear the word cancer, you fear the worst,Ã¢ÂÂ said AndrewsÃ¢ÂÂ father, Steve. Ã¢ÂÂWhen itÃ¢ÂÂs your child, you think to yourself, you think, Ã¢ÂÂGod: Take me, not her.Ã¢ÂÂ She has been through enough. She is just getting her life back. Ã¢ÂÂ ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a reference to AndrewsÃ¢ÂÂ other terrifying ordeal: a stalker who followed her to hotel rooms and recorded nude footage of her, later leaked online, through the peephole. Michael David Barrett went to jail, and Andrews eventually settled with the hotel operator after being awarded $55 million in a civil lawsuit in March. Now this. But Andrews was back in the grind 48 hours after her surgery. Ã¢ÂÂShould I have been standing for a full game five days after surgery? LetÃ¢ÂÂs just say the doctor didnÃ¢ÂÂt recommend that,Ã¢ÂÂ Andrews told the website. Ã¢ÂÂBut just as I felt during my trial, sports were my escape. I needed to be with my crew. Ã¢ÂÂ Andrews eventually came clean to her   about what she was going through. Ã¢ÂÂAfter the trial, everyone kept telling me, Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂre so strong, for going through all of this, for holding down a job in football, for being the only woman on the crew,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Andrews said. Ã¢ÂÂFinally I got to the point where I believed it too. Ã¢ÂÂHey, I have cancer, but dammit, I am strong, and I can do this. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Andrews faced another procedure on Nov. 1, less than a month after her first. Nearly two weeks later, she received the phone call she had been waiting for: She was in the clear. Ã¢ÂÂSuch an incredible weight had been lifted off her shoulders,Ã¢ÂÂ AndrewsÃ¢ÂÂ father recounted. Ã¢ÂÂI try not to think about what happened to her too much.
