But when I do, and I consider the enormity of what Erin has endured, IÃ¢ÂÂll often just sit down and cry. Ã¢ÂÂ Andrews will cover the Super Bowl on Feb. 5, and she got   a former NHL player, in the form of a holiday engagement. Ã¢ÂÂWe went there for Christmas to see the Christmas decorations, and we had a lovely dinner and he did it right there at dinner at Disneyland,Ã¢ÂÂ Andrews   Ã¢ÂÂI was bawling like a child. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Erin Andrews reveals cancerÃÂ diagnosis

Content: You may have to think twice before noshing on a plate of crispy roasted potatoes. On Monday, a new campaign by   Food Standards Agency referenced a 2002 study that says overcooked starchy foods, such as roasted potatoes and burnt toast, contain a compound called acrylamide that could increase your risk of cancer,  . The chemical is responsible for turning bread and potatoes golden when cooked, and higher levels of acrylamide are produced as starches turn from golden to brown. Ã¢ÂÂOur research indicates that the majority of people are not aware that acrylamide exists, or that they might be able to reduce their personal intake,Ã¢ÂÂ Steve Wearne, director of policy at the Food Standards Agency,  . Researchers have studied the effects of this chemical on mice, but have not done human trials. Ã¢ÂÂNo one will willingly eat acrylamide .Ã¢ÂÂ.Ã¢ÂÂ. [but] because itÃ¢ÂÂs carcinogenic in animals, it would be carcinogenic in humans,Ã¢ÂÂ Donald Mottram, emeritus professor of food chemistry at the University of Reading in the UK, told CNN. To lower your risk, the British health campaign says to only cook starches until theyÃ¢ÂÂre yellow or golden brown, eat a balanced diet and do not refrigerate potatoes before cooking, which can increase acrylamide levels.
Title: Delicious roast potatoes could give youÃÂ cancer

Content: The day after his dramatic Super Bowl victory, Tom Brady spoke for the first time about his mother GalynnÃ¢ÂÂs illness since it was revealed she was diagnosed 18 months ago with cancer, and gave positive reports on her recovery. Though it was widely known last week Galynn was dealing with health issues  Ã¢ÂÂ   especially when Brady   on consecutive days leading up to the Super Bowl  Ã¢ÂÂ   her exact illness remained unknown publicly until early Monday when MMQB. com  . Patriots owner Robert Kraft also   that BradyÃ¢ÂÂs mother has been going through chemotherapy and radiation treatment for her illness. Ã¢ÂÂMomÃ¢ÂÂs doing better,Ã¢ÂÂ Brady   on Monday morning. Ã¢ÂÂOur prayers are with her. SheÃ¢ÂÂs the best mom in the world. It was nice to win for her. Ã¢ÂÂThe prognosis is good and sheÃ¢ÂÂs not quite through it, but hopefully there was some healing energy from last night. We love her so much. Ã¢ÂÂ MMQB. com reported Galynn wasnÃ¢ÂÂt cleared to travel until a checkup last Wednesday at   Francisco. But there she was, wearing a wrap over her head, celebrating with her superstar son. (She also was accompanied Sunday night by    Kevin Youkilis, the former Red Sox and Yankees third baseman.) Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm overwhelmed!Ã¢ÂÂ Galynn said after the win. Ã¢ÂÂI was just praying. All I did was pray, the whole game, just pray. Ã¢ÂÂ Brady also addressed his motherÃ¢ÂÂs health at a press conference Monday morning when Roger Goodell   Ã¢ÂÂSheÃ¢ÂÂs been through a lot,Ã¢ÂÂ Brady said. Ã¢ÂÂWay harder than what I went through last night, what the team went through. Ã¢ÂÂAll families go through challenging times personally. But she has a lot of support and a lot of love. IÃ¢ÂÂm just happy last night to be able to celebrate with her. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Tom Brady reveals Ã¢ÂÂprognosis is goodÃ¢ÂÂ for momÃ¢ÂÂs cancerÃÂ fight

Content: All inherited diseases could be cured within 20 years, a leading British expert claims. That includes eradicating   conditions such as cystic fibrosis and HuntingtonÃ¢ÂÂs disease. Speaking at the worldÃ¢ÂÂs largest science conference, Dr. Edze Westra, a senior research fellow at the University of Exeter, says the breakthrough is possible  Known as CRISPR, they let scientists accurately cut out tiny sections of faulty genes and replace them with healthy DNA. Westra said the technology will soon allow medics to screen embryos and replace genes that trigger illness before babies are born. There are more than 4, 000 known   conditions. And they are thought to affect around 1 percent of births worldwide. It means doctors can one day use   to prevent these inherited conditions being passed on to future generations. Westra said it could also be used to prevent cancer by removing rogue genes.  which multiplies a personÃ¢ÂÂs chance of breast cancer. WestraÃ¢ÂÂs comments come just days after two major US scientific institutions backed the technology. The National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Medicine  First introduced in 2012, CRISPR is already rapidly transforming research. Asked where we will be in 20 years, Westra said scientists may have cured all inherited diseases. Speaking at the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) annual meeting in Boston, Westra he said   is causing a Ã¢ÂÂtrue revolutionÃ¢ÂÂ in science and medicine. He said: Ã¢ÂÂA mutation in a gene that causes disease can now be repaired using CRISPR. Ã¢ÂÂIn the coming decades, CRISPR will become   and I think we will see it being used to cure genetic diseases and cancers. Ã¢ÂÂ Scientists could also use the technology to fight off epidemics, such as malaria  Ã¢ÂÂ   and even cure cancer. They hope to one day Ã¢ÂÂcut and pasteÃ¢ÂÂ genes into cells that produce antibodies against such diseases. Westra said: Ã¢ÂÂThis is going further than just genetic editing and essentially placing the CRISPR machinery inside of cells so that they will always make, for example, an antibody in a mosquito which would prevent malaria infection. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs like turning cells into a factory. Ã¢ÂÂBut we need to do lots of   work to find out what the implications will be. Ã¢ÂÂ Critics warn the technology could be abused to create Ã¢ÂÂdesignerÃ¢ÂÂ babies. The technique could allow scientists to alter the color of a babyÃ¢ÂÂs eyes or hair, height or intelligence by picking and choosing their DNA. Dr. David King, director of Human Genetics Alert, said: Ã¢ÂÂIf scientists create GM babies, it will be impossible to avoid the Ã¢ÂÂdesigner babiesÃ¢ÂÂ dystopia, because the line between therapy and enhancement has not been respected with any other medical technology. Ã¢ÂÂ But Westra defended the technology. He said: Ã¢ÂÂThe main thing is that I want to inform the public about we aim to do with CRISPR. Ã¢ÂÂThere are fears about designer babies and we have to start having discussions about that so we can understand the consequences and   risks. Ã¢ÂÂ This article   on  .
Title: This controversial science could cure cancer within 20ÃÂ years

Content: Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt Courtesy of Lauren Watt View Slideshow When Lauren Watt learned in 2015 that her best friend, Gizelle, had cancer and wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt live much longer, she created a bucket list of all the things they wanted to do together before Gizelle passed away. Ã¢ÂÂIt was a silly thing,Ã¢ÂÂ said Watts, now 27, of her final plans for Gizelle, her    mastiff. Ã¢ÂÂBut it helped me create memories as opposed to crying about it. Ã¢ÂÂ She details the experience in her memoir, Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ (Simon & Schuster, out Tuesday). But itÃ¢ÂÂs not just a story of death; itÃ¢ÂÂs also about how Gizelle saved WattÃ¢ÂÂs life. Ã¢ÂÂMy heart hurt miserably. [But] I knew that we had the best adventures we possibly could have had.Ã¢ÂÂ The author was 19 and about to start her sophomore year at the University of Tennessee when she got Gizelle as a puppy in 2008. At the time, her mother was struggling with drug and alcohol addiction. Watt writes of her mom having a   seizure at Christmas and being so out of it that she Ã¢ÂÂansweredÃ¢ÂÂ the familyÃ¢ÂÂs Chihuahua instead of a ringing phone. Watt would temporarily flee the chaos of her home with Gizelle, the two of them driving, walking, even running for hours to escape. Ã¢ÂÂNo matter how bad you feel about yourself, [dogs] are always there providing love unconditionally,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂSo I made up my mind to love my mom no matter what. Ã¢ÂÂ When Watt graduated in 2011, the two set out for New York City. While looking at apartments, the author would tell brokers that Gizelle  Ã¢ÂÂ   who weighed about 160 pounds  Ã¢ÂÂ   was Ã¢ÂÂjust over 100 poundsÃ¢ÂÂ so as not to be turned away. The two moved, along with a friend, into a small   apartment in Times Square. Ã¢ÂÂGizelle was so mellow and   so it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt too bad,Ã¢ÂÂ Watt said of the space. Ã¢ÂÂWe were happy. Ã¢ÂÂ The canine soon became a local celebrity after she took part in the Tompkins Square   competition one Halloween, dressed as the Beast from Ã¢ÂÂSandlot. Ã¢ÂÂ But when Gizelle was about 7 years old, she was diagnosed with Ã¢ÂÂaggressiveÃ¢ÂÂ bone cancer. Doctors could amputate GizelleÃ¢ÂÂs back leg and start chemotherapy; the treatment would be painful and, as the cancer had likely already reached her lungs, she would not survive. Or Watt could make the most of her petÃ¢ÂÂs last days. Ã¢ÂÂI was devastated. I didnÃ¢ÂÂt want to lose my best friend,Ã¢ÂÂ Watt said. Ã¢ÂÂIt was a matter of learning to accept the situation and then figuring out [how] to make it   . Ã¢ÂÂ One of the first things that came to mind was the fact theyÃ¢ÂÂd never been to the beach together. In fact, there were a lot of things they hadnÃ¢ÂÂt done yet: eating ice cream, going pumpkin picking. Those things turned into GizelleÃ¢ÂÂs bucket list. Completing the items on the list was bittersweet. Sometimes the days were full of laughter, like when Watt took Gizelle on a canoe in New Hampshire and nearly fell overboard upon the discovery of a spider. One of their best times was a trip to the beach, where Gizelle got to play in the waves, and dog and owner napped together on the sand. On their last night, Watt made steaks. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs how she knew it was the end, she writes: Gizelle barely lifted her head when the steak was ready. Months before, she would have wolfed it down. Ã¢ÂÂMy heart hurt miserably,Ã¢ÂÂ she writes of the day in 2015 she took her best pal for a final ride to the vet. But Ã¢ÂÂI knew that we had the best adventures we possibly could have had. Ã¢ÂÂ Two years later, Watt still thinks of Gizelle every day. In August 2016, she adopted a basenji mix named Bette. Ã¢ÂÂI know Gizelle is happy I have a new friend,Ã¢ÂÂ said Watt, who moved to Los Angeles in 2016. Ã¢ÂÂDogs help us live in the moment. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Woman makes the best bucket list ever for her dog withÃÂ cancer

Content: A    woman has gained a legion of fans online after documenting her journey leading up to a double mastectomy and her road to recovery. Paige More, who tested positive for the BRCA1 gene mutation and has a family history of ovarian and breast cancer on her fatherÃ¢ÂÂs side, said she wants people to view her as a Ã¢ÂÂprevivor,Ã¢ÂÂ  . Once she tested positive for the genetic mutation, doctors presented her with the option for a double mastectomy or a lifetime of surveillance, the news outlet reported. Ã¢ÂÂIt was this huge daunting feeling, because I was making this huge life decision and either choice was really going to change my life,Ã¢ÂÂ More, a Ã¢ÂÂGood Morning AmericaÃ¢ÂÂ booker, told People. Ã¢ÂÂEven if I choose to do the surveillance, IÃ¢ÂÂm choosing to spend so much of my life in the doctorÃ¢ÂÂs office. It felt less like a surveillance and more like I was waiting to get cancer, and IÃ¢ÂÂve never been that person. I wanted to just tackle this thing for my life and my future. Ã¢ÂÂ More underwent a double mastectomy in January, and said she was moved to share her story with others partly to help her    sister cope.         Ã¢ÂÂI just hope that in a couple years when she gets tested, god forbid I hope sheÃ¢ÂÂs not positive, but if she is she can think back to this and say I can do this too,Ã¢ÂÂ More told People. She set up an Instagram page under the handle   and has since gained more than 12, 400 followers. Her posts, which regularly garner more than 1, 000 likes and hundreds of comments, provide an insight to her medical recovery as well as her return to her work and life activities. Ã¢ÂÂI never expected such a beautiful amount of support,Ã¢ÂÂ More told PEOPLE. Ã¢ÂÂI call them my breast friends. YouÃ¢ÂÂre instantly connected to these people, even if you donÃ¢ÂÂt actually know them. Ã¢ÂÂ This article   on  .
Title: Breast cancer Ã¢ÂÂprevivorÃ¢ÂÂ gets a doubleÃÂ mastectomy

Content: Riding the elevator to the ninth floor in a nondescript lower Manhattan loft building, I put on my brave face. I am as nervous as it gets. IÃ¢ÂÂm going to pose nude and post it on the Internet. Photographer Charise Isis quickly puts me at ease with stories about other women she has   a series of portraits of   survivors whoÃ¢ÂÂve had mastectomies. She leads me through a guided meditation to calm me. Then she turns to set up her camera and I drop my clothes. I put my hands on my hips, lift my chin, and take a deep breath. Click, click, click. I am proud, yet scared. Ã¢ÂÂAre you ready to let the world see you like that?Ã¢ÂÂ I wonder. Prior to being diagnosed with breast cancer in 2011, I never could have imagined posing nude, let alone posting those photos online. I was shy about my 34DD breasts. I didnÃ¢ÂÂt like the attention they brought. No more. Now, IÃ¢ÂÂm comfortable as a Ã¢ÂÂflattie. Ã¢ÂÂ Instead of using baggy clothes to conceal my figure, I wear plunging necklines to accentuate my lithe, svelte shape. On Jan. 10, 2011, doctors discovered a lump in my right breast during a mammogram. I was shocked. I was only 41, had no family history, I ate healthy and never smoked. It was Stage 3 cancer, but the prognosis was good if I followed all the protocols. I immediately started six rounds of chemo over the next four months and scheduled surgery, followed by 28 days of radiation. My breast surgeon made me see a psychiatrist to make sure I was of sound mind, and ensure that I wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt regret having my healthy breast removed, too. I was uncomfortable with the idea of reconstruction from the start. I didnÃ¢ÂÂt want to insert silicone implants under my skin to create the semblance of a breast. And I didnÃ¢ÂÂt want to wear prostheses to even myself out and conform to the standards set by society. Nonetheless, at my doctorÃ¢ÂÂs urging, I saw a plastic surgeon before proceeding. (Patients typically start reconstruction at the same time as cancer removal.) To my dismay, he simply assumed I would have reconstruction. As he described the options and multiple surgeries, none of it sounded right for me. When I got home, I was numb. I had no clear idea how to proceed. I searched the Internet for images of Ã¢ÂÂbilateral mastectomy without reconstruction. Ã¢ÂÂ To my relief, up popped a photo of a young mother, flat and topless, playing with her children on the beach. She gave me hope and courage. I showed my husband, David Romine, 60, an inventory manager in book publishing. Ã¢ÂÂDo it,Ã¢ÂÂ he said, supporting me completely. I made my decision to go breastless two weeks after my diagnosis. Yet, I faced opposition. My breast surgeon made me see a psychiatrist to make sure I was of sound mind, and ensure that I wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt regret having my healthy breast removed, too. I found a second plastic surgeon who understood my decision. Next, my insurance company refused to pay. This was despite the   which requires insurance plans that cover mastectomies to provide reconstruction, including to the other  Ã¢ÂÂ   often unaffected  Ã¢ÂÂ   breast, to produce a symmetrical appearance. The act, however, does not specify what type of reconstruction, and it isnÃ¢ÂÂt clear that Ã¢ÂÂgoing flatÃ¢ÂÂ is a reconstructive choice. So insurers decide what they want. Thankfully, my plastic surgeon wrote off the $20, 000 cost. IÃ¢ÂÂm not sure why, but three times the insurance company denied my claim, and he always reassured me I would not be saddled with the bill. After surgery in June 2011, I was as flat as a child. At first, it was a challenge to accept  Ã¢ÂÂ   it took time and compassion to change my deeply ingrained ideas of female attractiveness. My husband had to come to grips with the changes in my body in his own way, but he loves me with all his heart. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not about my breasts; itÃ¢ÂÂs about what weÃ¢ÂÂve been through together. And we are stronger for it. Many other things changed. I had to get a new wardrobe, because everything I owned was too blousy. Even then, I still had to remove the darts from every blouse I bought. ItÃ¢ÂÂs freeing to run without boobs or a bra and not have straps dig into my shoulders, although sometimes I wear a lacy bra under a sheer top when I want to look more feminine. And I sleep easier on my stomach. I started lifting weights to bolster my confidence. Now, my pec and ab muscles are more defined  Ã¢ÂÂ   David calls me the Ã¢ÂÂBreastless Wonder,Ã¢ÂÂ like itÃ¢ÂÂs my superpower. I had rebuilt myself, inside and out, yet I still felt alone a year later. Where were the other   or   women? I never saw them on the street; the subject was rarely discussed. Fed up, in June 2012, I ranted on an online cancer discussion board. To my surprise, support poured in. More than 4, 000 women who had made similar choices or were considering them responded. Ã¢ÂÂYou are an inspiration,Ã¢ÂÂ one wrote. Ã¢ÂÂI, too, want to see other women who are flat, and I want to be seen. I want to connect and feel connected. Ã¢ÂÂ That summer, I met a beautiful,    woman who had lost a breast to cancer decades ago. We were in a   water exercise class at the  . She noticed how I was flat under my bathing suit. Ã¢ÂÂYou are so brave,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve been trying not to wear this prosthesis for 30 years. I canÃ¢ÂÂt even go to the corner store without it. Ã¢ÂÂ I was aghast. Social inhibitions were holding her prisoner. It was then that I knew I had to become an advocate for women like her and let others know there are choices out there. In February 2014, I posted my first nude photo and an essay about my decision to go flat on my blog. I worried that my followers might reject me  Ã¢ÂÂ   but once again, people were welcoming. I want newly diagnosed women to understand that reconstruction isnÃ¢ÂÂt for everyone. Be a uniboober. Be a flattie. The important thing is to be you. Emboldened, I walked the runway topless for Play Out Underwear, a genderless lingerie company. In September 2015, I joined 12 other breastless survivors who walked topless through the streets of Berlin for   that was submitted to the Berlin International Film Festival, highlighting our diverse beauty and sexuality  . Through it all, IÃ¢ÂÂve learned to love my scars. In them, I see the strength of my conviction. I made choices against my doctors and society, and IÃ¢ÂÂve never regretted it. Cancer taught me that the only person I need to please is me. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not easy to be flat in a world where breasts are an omnipresent marketing tool, selling everything from shampoo to cars. I get stares of curiosity and confusion. I hear ignorant comments about my vaguely gendered body. But there are uplifting moments. One day, a legless drummer in the subway looked at me. His eyes dipped to my chest, and he smiled so deeply, I felt an intense connection. He understood; I had lost a part of my body, too. Lately, IÃ¢ÂÂve noticed a sea change. Flatties are banding together in support, posing topless and changing perceptions of what female bodies look like. I hope the movement will continue to grow until acceptance becomes the norm. I want newly diagnosed women to understand that reconstruction isnÃ¢ÂÂt for everyone. Be a uniboober. Be a flattie. The important thing is to be you. You are beautiful, no matter what.
Title: Why I stayed flat after breastÃÂ cancer

Content: A    Virginia boy will soon take a brief break from battling stage 4 cancer to escort a neighborhood teen to her high school prom. Beckett Wyatt, who was diagnosed with Ewings Sarcoma in June, received his   Ã¢ÂÂpromposalÃ¢ÂÂ from an older sister of one of his classmates,  .  Ã¢ÂÂI wanted to take Beckett because what if he never gets to,Ã¢ÂÂ Kaelyn Brakefeld, a junior at Midlothian High School, told WRIC. Ã¢ÂÂI want him to be able to do the things that I got to do. Ã¢ÂÂ  While Beckett gears up for the special day next month, his mother, Kymmie Wyatt, is thankful for the memories theyÃ¢ÂÂre building courtesy of BrakefeldÃ¢ÂÂs kind gesture. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs special getting to see him getting to do those things,Ã¢ÂÂ Wyatt told WRIC. Ã¢ÂÂBut also no matter what comes, IÃ¢ÂÂll have those memories with him. Ã¢ÂÂ  Beckett told his mother that this will be the first of many proms he attends, and that she should take one million pictures of his special day, WRIC reported.  Ã¢ÂÂHe truly believes that heÃ¢ÂÂs got this and if anyone can beat this itÃ¢ÂÂs him,Ã¢ÂÂ Wyatt told WRIC.  This article   on  .
Title: Teen asks 9-year-old boy battling cancer to her high schoolÃÂ prom

Content: The mom of a   teenage boy has revealed she gave her son cannabis Ã¢ÂÂto ease his painÃ¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ   and has made a miraculous recovery. Callie Blackwell and her husband Simon, of Norfolk, decided to give her teen son Deryn the Class B drug after he became addicted to the   drugs he was being given at hospital. In her new book  Ã¢ÂÂ   Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ   Callie tells the story of her then    son being diagnosed with leukemia in 2010 and Langerhans Cell Sarcoma  Ã¢ÂÂ   a rare and aggressive cancer, two years later. Deryn, now 17, has since defied doctors by surviving two deadly cancers. The youngster is dubbed the Ã¢ÂÂboy in seven billionÃ¢ÂÂ because he is thought to be the only person to have had both conditions at the same time. His mum Callie detailed in her book how they made the decision and the Ã¢ÂÂfrighteningÃ¢ÂÂ experience of finding cannabis and administrating it to their son.  Callie said: Ã¢ÂÂDeryn was nauseous and, worse, had become addicted to his   drugs. Ã¢ÂÂWe couldnÃ¢ÂÂt sit by and watch him spend his last days in a morphine fog. Enough was enough. Ã¢ÂÂ She added: Ã¢ÂÂWe took a decision that will horrify many parents reading this  Ã¢ÂÂ   and horrified me, too. Ã¢ÂÂAfter all, IÃ¢ÂÂd never seen anything positive come of smoking cannabis, and in my days working in nightclubs, illegal drugs had been my enemy. Ã¢ÂÂBut if it could help my darling boy escape his daily torment, I was willing to try it. Ã¢ÂÂ   A post shared by SoFloCBDÃ°ÂÂÂ´ (@soflocbd) on  She said she spent hours researching online before buying a vaporizer pen  Ã¢ÂÂ   a specialist equipment for inhaling drugs. Her husband Simon then arranged to meet someone at a nearby petrol station to pick the illegal drug  Ã¢ÂÂ   which carries a sentence of up to five yearsÃ¢ÂÂ imprisonment for possession. Based on her online research, Callie was then able to make the Ã¢ÂÂtinctureÃ¢ÂÂ using a rice cooker and glycerine  Ã¢ÂÂ   suitable for the vaporizer pen. She gave it to her son Deryn, who by then, had moved out of hospital and into a hospice. Callie said: Ã¢ÂÂAfter 10 minutes, Deryn said that the pain had decreased a little and he felt more relaxed  Ã¢ÂÂ   the words we had been longing to hear. Ã¢ÂÂ After the cannabis use continued, Callie claims her sonÃ¢ÂÂs finger  Ã¢ÂÂ   which had been black and dead  Ã¢ÂÂ   was beginning to heal after he had Ã¢ÂÂno immune system and no way of fighting of infection. Ã¢ÂÂ She also claims doctors later told her they were Ã¢ÂÂno longer sure DerynÃ¢ÂÂ was dying. Since then Deryn left the hospice and went back to school to take his GCSEs. He left school in June 2016 with seven GCSEs and wants to pursue a career as a chef. This article   on  .
Title: I gave my cancer-stricken son weed and it saved hisÃÂ life

Content: The chancellor of the City University of New York has been diagnosed with throat cancer, he announced to colleagues Friday in a letter. James Milliken, who signed on as the head of CUNY in 2014, said the cancer was found during a routine checkup earlier this month. Ã¢ÂÂI am otherwise in excellent health, the cancer has not spread beyond the throat area, and my prognosis is very good,Ã¢ÂÂ he wrote. Milliken will soon undergo seven weeks of radiation and chemotherapy at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and will continue working during that period. Ã¢ÂÂI will be meeting with the Board of Trustees, my senior staff and the college presidents in the coming days to plan for what I expect will be minimal disruption in our operations during the period of my treatment and recovery,Ã¢ÂÂ he said.
Title: CUNY chancellor reveals throat cancerÃÂ diagnosis

Content: WASHINGTON  Ã¢ÂÂ   It sounds like science fiction, but a   device that makes electric fields to fight cancer improved survival for the first time in more than a decade for people with deadly brain tumors, final results of a large study suggest. Many doctors are skeptical of the therapy, called tumor treating fields, and itÃ¢ÂÂs not a cure. ItÃ¢ÂÂs also    Ã¢ÂÂ   $21, 000 a month. But in the study, more than twice as many patients were alive five years after getting it, plus the usual chemotherapy, than those given just the chemo  Ã¢ÂÂ   13 percent versus 5 percent. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs out of the boxÃ¢ÂÂ in terms of how cancer is usually treated, and many doctors donÃ¢ÂÂt understand it or think it can help, said Dr. Roger Stupp, a brain tumor expert at Northwestern University in Chicago. He led the   study while previously at University Hospital Zurich in Switzerland, and gave results Sunday at an American Association for Cancer Research meeting in Washington. Ã¢ÂÂYou cannot argue with them  Ã¢ÂÂ   theyÃ¢ÂÂre great results,Ã¢ÂÂ and unlikely to be due to a placebo effect, said one independent expert, Dr. Antonio Chiocca, neurosurgery chief at Brigham and WomenÃ¢ÂÂs Hospital in Boston. Dr. George Demetri of the   Cancer Institute in Boston and a board member of the association hosting the conference, agreed but called the benefit modest, because most patients still die within five years. Ã¢ÂÂIt is such a horrible diseaseÃ¢ÂÂ that any progress is important, he added. The device, called Optune, is made by Novocure, based in Jersey, an island near England. ItÃ¢ÂÂs sold in the U. S. Germany, Switzerland and Japan for adults with an aggressive cancer called glioblastoma multiforme, and is used with chemo after surgery and radiation to try to keep these tumors from recurring, as most do. Patients cover their shaved scalp with strips of electrodes connected by wires to a small generator kept in a bag. They can wear a hat, go about their usual lives, and are supposed to use the device at least 18 hours a day. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not an electric current or radiation, and they feel only mild heat. It supposedly works by creating low intensity, alternating electric fields that disrupt cell division  Ã¢ÂÂ   confusing the way chromosomes line up  Ã¢ÂÂ   which makes the cells die. Because cancer cells divide often, and normal cells in the adult brain do not, this in theory mostly harms the disease and not the patient. In a 2011 study, the device didnÃ¢ÂÂt improve survival but caused fewer symptoms than chemo did for people whose tumors had worsened or recurred after standard treatments. The U. S. Food and A second study, in newly diagnosed patients, was stopped in 2014 after about half of the 695 participants had been tracked for at least 18 months, because those using the device were living several months longer on average than the rest. The FDA expanded approval but some doctors were leery because the device wasnÃ¢ÂÂt compared with a sham treatment  Ã¢ÂÂ   everyone knew who was getting what. Study leaders say a sham was impractical, because patients feel heat when they get the real thing, and many would refuse to shave their heads every few days and use an inconvenient device for years if the treatment might be fake. Some doctors said they would withhold judgment until there were   results on the whole group. Now theyÃ¢ÂÂre in: Median survival was 21 months for those given Optune plus chemo versus 16 months for those on chemo alone. Survival rates were 43 percent versus 31 percent at two years; 26 percent versus 16 percent at three years, and 13 percent versus 5 percent at five years. Side effects were minimal but included   problems, weakness, fatigue and skin irritation from the electrodes. Ã¢ÂÂThe device is now impossible to ignore   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     it absolutely is an advance,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Andrew Lassman, brain tumor chief at the Columbia University Medical     Hospital. He consults for Novocure, as do some doctors running the study. The latest National Comprehensive Cancer Center guidelines include Optune as an appropriate treatment for brain tumors. ItÃ¢ÂÂs also is being tested for pancreatic, ovarian and lung cancers; electrodes are worn on the belly or chest for those. A big issue is cost  Ã¢ÂÂ   roughly $700 a day. Most U. S. insurers cover it but Medicare does not and Ã¢ÂÂwe are paying,Ã¢ÂÂ said NovocureÃ¢ÂÂs chief executive, Bill Doyle. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂve never refused a patient regardless of insurance status. Ã¢ÂÂ The price reflects Ã¢ÂÂan extremely sophisticated medical device, made in very low quantities,Ã¢ÂÂ with disposable parts changed several times a week and a support person for each patient, he said. Plus 17 years of lab, animal and human testing. That cost? Ã¢ÂÂThe round number is half a billion dollars,Ã¢ÂÂ Doyle said. Joyce EndresenÃ¢ÂÂs insurance covers all but about $1, 000 a year for her device. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a great plan, and thatÃ¢ÂÂs why I still work,Ã¢ÂÂ said Endresen, 52, employed by a direct mail company in suburban Chicago. She has scans every two months to check for cancer and Ã¢ÂÂtheyÃ¢ÂÂve all been good,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂWe celebrated two years of no tumor in December and went to South Africa. Ã¢ÂÂ Doctors say many patients wonÃ¢ÂÂt try the device because of the trouble involved or because they donÃ¢ÂÂt want a visible reminder of their cancer. Not Endresen. Ã¢ÂÂI wear it and wear it proudly,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs an incredible machine and IÃ¢ÂÂm fine not having hair. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Ã¢ÂÂSci-fiÃ¢ÂÂ device extends survival for brain cancer patients Ã¢ÂÂ for $21K aÃÂ month

Content: The life of    Ayden   was celebrated Saturday, as family and friends gathered to remember the boy whose   battle with brain cancer was followed by thousands after his Army veteran father shared his bucket list online. Ã¢ÂÂHe just gave his all and his best,Ã¢ÂÂ Jennifer Zeigler, AydenÃ¢ÂÂs mother,  .  Ã¢ÂÂHe was my miracle from the beginning. Ã¢ÂÂ Ayden, who lived in Pennsylvania, was diagnosed with diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) a rare and notoriously    type of brain cancer, after he collapsed at football practice. Initially, it was believed he was suffering from a concussion, but once his motor skills began to deteriorate doctors discovered a tumor in his cerebellum and another in his brain stem, the Statesman Journal reported. When doctors gave him 8 to 12 months to live, AydenÃ¢ÂÂs father, Bill Kohler, set out to cram as many life experiences as they could into the remaining time they had left. He   and a   to keep supporters    on their latest adventures, which included a hunting trip and a    with AydenÃ¢ÂÂs favorite WWE stars at a show in Hershey. On March 22, Kohler, who said that AydenÃ¢ÂÂs birth saved him from the brink of depression and   stress disorder (PTSD) shared that he died. Ã¢ÂÂTo all who have been following Ayden, we have lost our battle today,Ã¢ÂÂ Kohler wrote in part. Ã¢ÂÂAyden has passed to a better place, and I would like to thank all those who have supported or followed him. He was my heart and the center of my world, and the love that was real. He was the greatest son I could ask for, and the greatest friend a son could be. Ã¢ÂÂ About 400 people gathered at Utz Arena at the York Expo Center on Saturday adorning purple shirts and Pittsburgh Steelers jerseys in support of Ayden,  . Ã¢ÂÂEverything today is from Ayden to the community,Ã¢ÂÂ Kohler told the news outlet. Ã¢ÂÂThis is what he had asked for. Ã¢ÂÂ  This article   on  .
Title: Bucket list of 10-year-old who died of cancer goesÃÂ viral

Content: A Manhattan oncologist who charged a dying patient $50, 000 for an experimental cancer treatment he never performed hasnÃ¢ÂÂt returned the dough, according to a lawsuit. Cheryl Stoebenau, 69, was being treated for ovarian cancer in 2015 when her doctor, William Grace, told her about a treatment that wasnÃ¢ÂÂt   but Ã¢ÂÂthat potentially could save her life,Ã¢ÂÂ according to court papers. Stoebenau would have to pay the $50, 000 cost up front because insurance wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt cover it, said the doctor, who also told her she needed to be healthier to receive the treatment. Stoebenau, a marketing guru who once worked on licensing deals for Cabbage Patch Kids, ran CAS Marketing out of a West End Avenue space. She wrote a $50, 000 check from CAS Marketing to the doc, but her condition quickly deteriorated, despite a stint at Lenox Hill Hospital intended to strengthen her. She died in September 2015, but Grace never returned the cash, according to the Manhattan Supreme Court lawsuit filed against him by CAS Marketing. Grace told The Post he couldnÃ¢ÂÂt return the drugs once they were purchased, and asked Stoebenau what he should do once it became clear her health was failing. He offered to give her the drugs, Opdivo & Yervoy, anyway, but claims Stoebenau declined. Ã¢ÂÂI asked what to do, she said, Ã¢ÂÂYou probably have someone who canÃ¢ÂÂt afford it and doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have the resources that I have, why donÃ¢ÂÂt you give it to them,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Grace told The Post. Ã¢ÂÂI went strictly with Mrs. StoebenauÃ¢ÂÂs wishes.   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     ItÃ¢ÂÂs not like IÃ¢ÂÂm trying to scam people in any way,Ã¢ÂÂ he said, adding that he treated a patient with the drugs meant for Stoebenau. Ã¢ÂÂDr. Grace was paid $50, 000 to administer an experimental cancer treatment, but the patient died before she could receive it. He did not earn this money and should refund it,Ã¢ÂÂ a CAS attorney, Mark Pincus, said.
Title: Doctor stiffed terminal cancer patient on $50K treatment:ÃÂ suit

Content: ItÃ¢ÂÂs only been one month since Sarah and Lee Reed exchanged vows, but now the newlywed with terminal cancer is   her husband the dos and donÃ¢ÂÂts of dating in hopes that heÃ¢ÂÂll land a partner after her death. Sarah, 37, has just months to live, and is desperate for    Lee to find a girlfriend suitable for him and her    autistic daughter, Chloe,  . Sarah, who lives in the U. K. was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2015, two years after the pair had gotten together, according to the news outlet. Despite years of chemotherapy and radiation, doctors discovered the cancer had spread to her lungs and ovaries and told her it was incurable, according to The Scottish Sun. Sarah   in hopes of raising enough money for treatment at the Hallwang Clinic in Germany. She blogs regularly about her treatments in a Facebook group titled Ã¢ÂÂMy battle. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe hardest thing about this is being a parent and having to explain to my 10 year old autistic daughter that mummy is going to die,Ã¢ÂÂ Sarah wrote on the GoFundMe page. The couple applied to Gift Of A Wedding, a charity that helps partners facing terminal illnesses, and in the lead up to the big day, Sarah focused on teaching Lee the ropes of dating. Ã¢ÂÂIt had taken him ages to get together with me and on the first date heÃ¢ÂÂd not brought his wallet, so I knew he needed some help,Ã¢ÂÂ Sarah told The Scottish Sun. Ã¢ÂÂI explained I needed to know he would be happy again and that would help make sure Chloe was happy too. Ã¢ÂÂ Sarah instructed Lee to sign up for online dating and is focused on coaching him through the initial   process. Ã¢ÂÂIt might sound crazy teaching my man how to meet a new woman when we have only just got married, but I need to know he will be happy after me,Ã¢ÂÂ she told The Scottish Sun. Ã¢ÂÂLife must carry on for them so IÃ¢ÂÂm helping the only way I knew how. HeÃ¢ÂÂll make an incredible husband for one lucky woman. Ã¢ÂÂ Sarah told the news outlet that Lee was Ã¢ÂÂhorrifiedÃ¢ÂÂ at first, but has since accepted his wifeÃ¢ÂÂs help. Ã¢ÂÂWhen Sarah told me I had to meet someone else I was upset but I understood itÃ¢ÂÂs her way of looking after me,Ã¢ÂÂ Lee told The Scottish Sun. Ã¢ÂÂIn my eyes she is irreplaceable and i want to be her husband for as long as possible. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Wife with terminal cancer teaches her husband how toÃÂ date

Content: An    student from Mexico won the top prize at the Global Student Entrepreneur Awards (GSEA) this weekend for his creation of EVA, an intelligent bra that can help in the early detection of breast cancer. Julian Rios Cantu said he was inspired by his motherÃ¢ÂÂs struggles as she repeatedly battled the disease and eventually had both breasts removed. The bra, which he developed with three friends through his company Higia Technologies, is equipped with around 200 biosensors that map the surface of the breast and monitor its temperature, shape and weight. He said the device was conceived primarily for women with genetic predisposition to the disease. Ã¢ÂÂWhy a bra? Because it allows us to have the breasts in the same position and it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have to be worn more than one hour a week,Ã¢ÂÂ he said in an  . Rios Cantu, an engineering student from Monterrey, explained that the biosensors map the surface of the breast and can determine thermal conductivity by specific zones. More heat would indicate more blood flow, he said, therefore indicating that those blood vessels are Ã¢ÂÂfeedingÃ¢ÂÂ something  Ã¢ÂÂ   usually some type of cancer. Ã¢ÂÂEVA is a network of biosensors that covers the womanÃ¢ÂÂs breast, takes the temperature data, analyzes them, and sends the information to an application or any computer,Ã¢ÂÂ Rios Cantu said, as quoted by Infobae. Ã¢ÂÂAs soon as there is a malformation in the breast or a tumor, there is an  ; so to more [flow of] blood, the higher the temperature,Ã¢ÂÂ he added. Rios Cantu took home $20, 000 after beating out 13 other student entrepreneurs from around the world. He had previously won the first edition of MexicoÃ¢ÂÂs Everis Award for Entrepreneurs. This yearÃ¢ÂÂs GSEA award was presented on Saturday at a ceremony in Frankfurt, Germany.
Title: Student creates bra that can detect breastÃÂ cancer

Content: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Ã¢ÂÂ   An Alabama woman was jailed Friday on charges of stealing at least $38, 000 by portraying herself as a terminal cancer patient in a pair of online fundraising schemes. Jennifer Flynn Cataldo, 37, of Sterrett was charged with two counts of theft by deception, according to a statement from the state attorney generalÃ¢ÂÂs office. Bond was set at $100, 000. Cataldo did not yet have a lawyer to speak on her behalf, court records showed. She was arrested Thursday in Shelby County, a suburb of Birmingham. Cataldo was accused of using two GoFundMe drives to solicit money for medical bills and a family trip to Disney. While the campaigns portrayed Cataldo as someone with a terminal case of cancer, authorities said an investigation showed that wasnÃ¢ÂÂt true. GoFundMe said such cases were rare and donors would get their money back. Ã¢ÂÂWe are working with law enforcement officials. If the funds cannot be recovered, GoFundMe will refund donors,Ã¢ÂÂ said company spokesman Bobby Whithorne. Ã¢ÂÂEither way, donors are fully protected. Ã¢ÂÂ Authorities said they believe Cataldo acted alone. Cataldo signed a form stating that she was married, has been unemployed for five years and has no income, records show. Cataldo is in need of mental health care and could pose a risk to herself and her family, prosecutors said in a court document.
Title: Woman arrested for faking cancer in GoFundMeÃÂ scheme

Content: Smoking until age 102 didnÃ¢ÂÂt kill her  Ã¢ÂÂ   but a broken heart did.    dies hours after being told of the death of her only son, a former Glasgow teacher     Ã¢ÂÂ   caroline wilson (@WilsonC75HT)  Maysie Strang of Scotland, who recently made news by saying her   smoking habit never harmed her, died just hours after her son succumbed to cancer. His mother was featured in the paper in October 2016 as she celebrated her 102nd birthday at the Glenlivit care home in Newton Mearns, where Sandy paid tribute to her indomitable spirit. Former schoolteacher Sandy Strang, 65, died a month after he was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer,  At the time, Sandy said she still enjoyed a bit of Chardonnay and noted that it was Ã¢ÂÂabsurdÃ¢ÂÂ how young she looked. Maysie was born Oct. 5 1914, in Pollokshaws, shortly after the outbreak of World War I. She worked as a secretary at the Daily Express in Glasgow for more than 10 years before getting a job at a law firm. Later, she landed at Southern General Hospital, where she worked in administration in the obstetrics ward until she was in her 70s. The   said she began smoking as a teen and gave it up only once, when she was hospitalized for five weeks with a broken femur in her  . Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs absurd thinking that some people who smoke for a while get all these health problems. It is the ultimate paradox,Ã¢ÂÂ she said last year,
Title: Centenarian passes away hours after son dies fromÃÂ cancer

Content: Brad Grey, the former head of Paramount Pictures, died on Sunday evening at age 59. His family said in a statement that the cause was cancer and that they were with him when he passed in his Holmby Hills, Calif. home. Grey ran Paramount for 12 years before being forced out in February  Ã¢ÂÂ   collateral damage caused by a bruising power struggle pitted the head of Paramount parent company Viacom with the Redstone family that controls it. Ã¢ÂÂI look forward to new adventures,Ã¢ÂÂ the   studio head wrote in his farewell memo to colleagues. Grey, who looked in good health, kept his illness a secret from almost all of Hollywood. His achievements at Paramount include overseeing the studioÃ¢ÂÂs   film, Ã¢ÂÂTransformers: Dark of the Moon,Ã¢ÂÂ as well as profitable franchises Ã¢ÂÂStar TrekÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂMission Impossible. Ã¢ÂÂ Paramount also produced such acclaimed properties as Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂThe Big Short,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂNo Country for Old Men,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThere Will Be BloodÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂUp in the AirÃ¢ÂÂ on GreyÃ¢ÂÂs watch. The   studio head entered the entertainment business while still a student at the State University of New York at Buffalo, where he became an intern to another Buffalo alum, Harvey Weinstein. Weinstein, who was more a concert promoter than an independent movie maven back then, gave a    Grey just enough experience to produce his first concert  Ã¢ÂÂ   a Buffalo appearance by Frank Sinatra. In 1986, Grey teamed Bernie Brillstein to form   Entertainment, a talent manager that took to packaging programming. Eventually recognized as one of HollywoodÃ¢ÂÂs most successful firms,   produced numerous television hits, including Ã¢ÂÂThe Sopranos,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe Larry Sanders ShowÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂReal Time with Bill Maher. Ã¢ÂÂ In 1996, Brillstein sold his shares of the company to Grey, who renamed it Ã¢ÂÂBrad Grey Television. Ã¢ÂÂ Grey ventured into film that same year, producing Ã¢ÂÂHappy Gilmore,Ã¢ÂÂ an Adam Sandler vehicle.  In 2001, he   Plan B with Brad Pitt and Jennifer Aniston but gave up his ownership stake after leaving to run Paramount in 2005. After a promising start, Grey lost his momentum at an increasingly unstable Paramount, which has ranked last among the five major studios in   market share since 2012. Recent flops like Ã¢ÂÂZoolander 2Ã¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂTeenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows,Ã¢ÂÂ racked up losses of nearly $450 million last year, setting the stage for GreyÃ¢ÂÂs exit when new management cleaned house at ViacomÃ¢ÂÂs operating divisions. GreyÃ¢ÂÂs family said thereÃ¢ÂÂll be a private funeral later this week and a memorial service in the near future. In lieu of flowers, it asked that donations be made to the Lawrence J. Ellison Institute for Transformative Medicine of USC.
Title: Hollywood mogul Brad Grey dies of cancer atÃÂ 59

Content: A Texas beauty queen has undergone a radical surgery that allowed her to use her ankle as her knee after having her leg amputated. Jesse Williams, 20, of Odem, was a gifted college volleyball player and Miss Teen USA contestant when she learned that she had been diagnosed with a rare type of bone cancer called EwingÃ¢ÂÂs sarcoma. In September 2016, she had been competing in a volleyball tournament when she began to experience knee pain. Ã¢ÂÂMy trainer said he thought it sounded like a torn meniscus. You can technically still play on that as long as you arenÃ¢ÂÂt in too much pain,Ã¢ÂÂ Williams told Barcroft Media. Ã¢ÂÂSo I played all season on it and the plan was to send me to the doctor and look at surgery options at the end of the season. Ã¢ÂÂ But the Texas Lutheran University student couldnÃ¢ÂÂt shake the feeling that there might be something seriously wrong. Ã¢ÂÂI had that feeling of what if, but I was like it cant be,Ã¢ÂÂ Williams said. Ã¢ÂÂI mean IÃ¢ÂÂm 19 years old. IÃ¢ÂÂm playing college volleyball. How could that have happened?Ã¢ÂÂ She met with an orthopedic surgeon who determined that she had a rapidly growing bone cyst and referred her to an oncologist. Ã¢ÂÂSo they did an open biopsy and thatÃ¢ÂÂs when it came back positive for EwingÃ¢ÂÂs sarcoma,Ã¢ÂÂ Williams said. Ã¢ÂÂWhen they told me that it was cancer, I was so shocked, I didnÃ¢ÂÂt really believe it. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs when Williams was faced with a tough decision: simply remove the tumor and keep her leg or undergo a   surgery that would require amputation, but increase her chances of beating the cancer. Ã¢ÂÂI could have just had the tumor taken out and salvaged the limb, but from research I have done and people I have met, there is a higher relapse rate if you go that route and thatÃ¢ÂÂs not what I wanted,Ã¢ÂÂ Williams said. Ã¢ÂÂInstead I opted just to have the leg removed and rotationplasty offered me the best way of life once that decision had been made. Ã¢ÂÂ Since the tumor was in her femur, doctors removed the middle portion of her leg. The procedure then involved rotating the foot, ankle and shin 180 degrees to reattach them to her upper leg. She was given a prosthetic lower leg to walk. Williams has remained positive through the procedure and treatment, but admits that it has been an adjustment. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs kind of been   because I always had long pretty hair. IÃ¢ÂÂve always been the tall, pretty girl. ItÃ¢ÂÂs difficult being bald and  . I say that all the time. A lot of people tend to shy away because theyÃ¢ÂÂre like, Ã¢ÂÂWhy does she look like that? Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Since the surgery, she has kept busy training to return to volleyball and get back on the pageant circuit. Ã¢ÂÂThe thing is I still want to compete again for Miss Texas, so I need to get my body back in shape for where it needs to be for that,Ã¢ÂÂ Williams said. Williams said wants to show other amputees that they can still pursue dreams  Ã¢ÂÂ   such as becoming the first amputee Mist Texas and representing the national volleyball team in the Paralympic Games. Ã¢ÂÂMy motto of life is Ã¢ÂÂI want to make a difference by being different,Ã¢ÂÂ and I feel like thatÃ¢ÂÂs what IÃ¢ÂÂm doing with rotationplasty, with cancer, with anything I do in life,Ã¢ÂÂ she said.
Title: Cancer-stricken beauty queen gets knee replaced withÃÂ ankle

Content: A dog found near death at a rest stop in New Jersey will be reunited with her family two years after she disappeared from their New York home.    Cali, a Rhodesian ridgeback, was taken to Broken Promises Sanctuary weighing under 40 pounds and was nursed back to life. Ã¢ÂÂShe was all but dead,Ã¢ÂÂ Stuart Goldman, the sanctuary president,  The sanctuary discovered that CaliÃ¢ÂÂs nose had been bleeding because of a tumor, and later determined that cancer had spread through her nose and behind her eyes. They found a treatment center in Pennsylvania and are raising money   to help cover the $18, 000 bill. The treatment shrank her tumors, and veterinarians gave her between a year and 18 months to live. During examinations vets, discovered that Cali had a microchip and tracked down her family, who was shocked to hear she was found. Brittney DiBartolo, CaliÃ¢ÂÂs owner, told Asbury Park Press she was sobbing uncontrollably when she found out. The family had left New York in 2016 and relocated to North Carolina. Ã¢ÂÂIt was kind of hard to leave New York and not have Cali with us,Ã¢ÂÂ DiBartolo told Asbury Park Press. Ã¢ÂÂI assumed someone picked her up and kept her because she was such a good dog. Ã¢ÂÂ Cali is set to reunite with her family next month as she continues her recovery.
Title: Cancer-stricken dog to reunite with family after twoÃÂ years

Content: Scientists are optimistic that   techniques could lead the way toward new, more effective cancer treatments that are also less harmful to the body.  published in the most recent issue of the journal Science, scientists have found that they can halt the spread of certain types of cancers using a technology known as CRISPR. The method is still in its early stages, but researchers were able to edit out the protein that causes cell division and proliferation in isolated cervical and kidney cancer cells in the lab. This, in turn, slows down cancer growth.  published in the journal Nature Biotechnology earlier this month, researchers found that CRISPR technology can target and alter   fusion genes, shrinking tumors caused by liver and prostate cancer in lab mice. The technique works by removing mutated DNA in cancer cells and replacing it with a gene that kills the unhealthy cells, while leaving healthy cells alone. Ã¢ÂÂOther types of cancer treatments target the foot soldiers of the army,Ã¢ÂÂ said study author Dr.   Luo, of the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine. Ã¢ÂÂOur approach is to target the command center, so there is no chance for the enemyÃ¢ÂÂs soldiers to regroup in the battlefield for a comeback. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Cancer cures of theÃÂ future

Content: He loved them  Ã¢ÂÂ   and fleeced them. Queens assistant principal Michael Scaduto shacked up with a teacher he was supervising while cozying up to another teacher on his staff and then pressured each to give him $5, 000 for a fictional homeless child suffering from cancer named Ã¢ÂÂTom,Ã¢ÂÂ according to school investigators. The Special Commissioner of Investigation for city schools found the lying Lothario cashed in further when he convinced the father of the teacher Scaduto was living with to fork over $150, 000 for a down payment on a house the couple bought together. Scaduto, 36, carried out his   schemes while serving as assistant principal and athletic director at the HS for Construction Trades, Engineering and Architecture, in Ozone Park. With investigators at his heels, he quickly resigned in August 2015 from the city Department of Education  Ã¢ÂÂ   which has since banned him from future employment  Ã¢ÂÂ   and landed a   gig at MacArthur HS in Levittown, LI. Ã¢ÂÂI wanted that community feel,Ã¢ÂÂ Scaduto told the LI Herald news site when he started. One Queens teacher told investigators she began a relationship with Scaduto in December 2014 and they bought a house together with her dadÃ¢ÂÂs cash. In June 2015, she was upset to learn Scaduto was involved with another teacher, an SCI report said. The first teacher said she gave Scaduto $5, 000 Ã¢ÂÂpurportedly for a sick childÃ¢ÂÂ and $10, 000 for legal expenses because he claimed he was under investigation for his romantic affairs. The second teacher told investigators she and Scaduto had a Ã¢ÂÂclose emotional relationship but maintained it was not sexual,Ã¢ÂÂ SCI says. As the two grew closer, Scaduto told her he was a Ã¢ÂÂBig Brother mentorÃ¢ÂÂ to    Ã¢ÂÂTom,Ã¢ÂÂ who had cancer. He later told her Ã¢ÂÂTomÃ¢ÂÂ had died and he was raising money for his homeless family and mother, who also was battling cancer. Scaduto also told the second teacher he was under an SCI investigation  Ã¢ÂÂ   which was false at the time  Ã¢ÂÂ   working several   jobs to pay for a lawyer and Ã¢ÂÂexhausted. Ã¢ÂÂ She gave him another $10, 000. But the second teacher was suspicious. She Ã¢ÂÂconducted several surveillancesÃ¢ÂÂ of Scaduto when he claimed to have lawyer appointments or to be working other jobs, the report said. She found Scaduto Ã¢ÂÂnever left his residence. Ã¢ÂÂ The first teacher finally told the second Ã¢ÂÂit was all lies; there was no Tom or SCI investigation. Ã¢ÂÂ The second teacher confronted Scaduto, who admitted he lied to her and returned the money, according to the report. Scaduto, who joined the DOE in 2007, made $122, 236 at the Queens vocational high school in  . His base salary at MacArthur HS is $134, 310. Last month  Ã¢ÂÂ   nearly two years after Scaduto quit his city job, the Conflicts of Interest Board announced it had fined Scaduto $7, 000 for violating a law forbidding employees Ã¢ÂÂto request   obtain money, favors, or things of value from a subordinate. Ã¢ÂÂ The Levittown School District said it learned about the allegations on Friday, when The Post inquired, saying it was Ã¢ÂÂshocked. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂOur district takes these allegations very seriously, and will be looking into this further,Ã¢ÂÂ Superintendent Tonie McDonald said. Scaduto, who refused to speak to SCI investigators, did not return messages seeking comment.
Title: Assistant principal duped teachers to give thousands to kid who Ã¢ÂÂhadÃÂ cancerÃ¢ÂÂ

Content: You might want to hold off on  The risk of developing cancer from the galactic cosmic rays on Mars is twice as high as originally estimated,  Current assessments used by NASA suggest that cancer caused by this type of cosmic radiation would be contained within the damaged cells. But the latest research shows that damaged cells actually increase the risk of healthy Ã¢ÂÂbystanderÃ¢ÂÂ cells also getting sick. Ã¢ÂÂWe learned the damaged cells send signals to the surrounding, unaffected cells and likely modify the tissuesÃ¢ÂÂ microenvironments,Ã¢ÂÂ Francis Cucinotta, the studyÃ¢ÂÂs lead researcher,   Ã¢ÂÂThose signals seem to inspire the healthy cells to mutate, thereby causing additional tumors or cancers. Ã¢ÂÂ According to 2013 data from the Radiation Assessment Detector on NASAÃ¢ÂÂs Curiosity Rover, a roundtrip mission to Mars would expose an astronaut to 0. 66 sieverts of radiation. That level is 13 times higher than what someone working at a nuclear power plant can be exposed to in a year. In addition to cancer, cosmic ray exposure can also cause cataracts, circulatory diseases and acute radiation syndromes. Researchers say this discovery calls for a lot more thorough research and risk analysis. A Mars astronaut would spend at least 900 days on the red planet and more than a year traveling through deep space. Cucinotta said current radiation shields would only Ã¢ÂÂmodestlyÃ¢ÂÂ decrease the amount of radiation exposure. Ã¢ÂÂWaving or increasing acceptable risk levels raises serious ethical flags, if the true nature of the risks are not sufficiently understood,Ã¢ÂÂ Cucinotta said. NASA wants to send humans to the
Title: Mars astronauts face a huge risk of gettingÃÂ cancer

Content: Not even cancer can stop runner Gabriele Grunewald from pursuing her dreams. In March, the    athlete and    (  ) cancer survivor found out that small cancer tumors had formed in her liver. This past Monday, she went for a biopsy and began chemotherapy the next day. But that didnÃ¢ÂÂt keep her from running the   race at NashvilleÃ¢ÂÂs Music City Distance Carnival on Saturday, where she hoped to finish in 4:9 (4 minutes, 9 seconds) to qualify for the   on June 23 in Sacramento. And although Grunewald, whoÃ¢ÂÂs professionally running for   fell short of her goal  Ã¢ÂÂ   she finished in 4:28 (4 minutes, 28 seconds)  Ã¢ÂÂ   her spirits remained high. Ã¢ÂÂAs for me, Wonder Woman doesnÃ¢ÂÂt live here,Ã¢ÂÂ she wrote on Twitter. Ã¢ÂÂBut I am: smiling, trying, showing up, failing, living, doing what I can. Thank you for support. Ã¢ÂÂ As for me, Wonder Woman doesnÃ¢ÂÂt live here. But I am: smiling, trying, showing up, failing, living, doing what I can. Thank you for support.  Ã¢ÂÂ   gabriele grunewald (@gg_runs)  Grunewald, whoÃ¢ÂÂs based in Minneapolis, Minn. was first diagnosed with adenoid cystic carcinoma  Ã¢ÂÂ   a rare form of cancer that had spread through one of her salivary glands  Ã¢ÂÂ   when she was a senior at the University of Minnesota in April 2009. Though she received treatment, the cancer returned to her thyroid in October 2010, and she underwent surgery and   treatment. In August 2016, Grunewald announced on social media that a large cancerous tumor, which she would then have surgically removed, had been found in her liver. Despite her health struggles, Grunewald won the womenÃ¢ÂÂs   USA Indoor Track & Field Championship in 2014. And although Grunewald did not make the qualifying time for this yearÃ¢ÂÂs championships, sheÃ¢ÂÂs received an outpouring of support on social media. Ã¢ÂÂCancer can stop you from doing a lot of things,Ã¢ÂÂ she wrote in a blog post for the  . Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm well aware of that. But IÃ¢ÂÂm more interested in what cancer canÃ¢ÂÂt stop me from doing. HereÃ¢ÂÂs to finding out. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: A fourth bout of cancer isnÃ¢ÂÂt slowing this runnerÃÂ down

Content: Anthony Young, a Mets fan favorite who is known as the owner of baseballÃ¢ÂÂs longest losing streak, passed away Tuesday at the age of 51, the team announced. In January, it was reported Young  . Early Tuesday, former teammate Lenny Harris tweeted Young was in a coma, and later in the day, his passing was announced by the Mets. Ã¢ÂÂAnthony was a true gentleman,Ã¢ÂÂ Turk Wendell, a former Mets pitcher who participated in the teamÃ¢ÂÂs fantasy camp with Young the last several years, said in a statement. Ã¢ÂÂAt this yearÃ¢ÂÂs fantasy camp, he told us he had a brain tumor. That was Anthony. He never ran away from anything. Ã¢ÂÂ Young was drafted by the Mets as a   pick out of the University of Houston in 1987. Young reached the major leagues in August 1991. But the following season, he began what is still a record losing streak, dropping 27 consecutive decisions from May 6,   24, 1993. During the streak, though, Young also converted 12 straight saves and threw 23   consecutive scoreless innings while filling in for regular Mets closer John Franco. Thirteen of his 27 consecutive starts without a win were quality starts. Despite notching a a solid 3. 89 ERA during his career, Young finished with a record of  . Ã¢ÂÂA. Y. took a lot of kidding about his losing records,Ã¢ÂÂ Doug Flynn, a fellow Mets player, said in a statement. Ã¢ÂÂBut he was the victim of some bad luck during the streak. He knew inside that he was a better pitcher than his numbers. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Beloved ex-Met Anthony Young loses battle with brainÃÂ cancer

Content: Bad news for vino lovers: Drinking white wine could increase your risk of skin cancer. A recent study in the medical journal   examined the drinking habits of more than 210, 000 Caucasian men and women over 18 years of age and found that those who drank one glass of white wine daily increased their risk of melanoma by 13 percent. Researchers believe that white wine contains acetaldehyde, a carcinogenic compound. But unlike their   counterparts, red wines contain antioxidants that can mitigate these   chemicals. But Dr. Hooman Khorasani, of Mount Sinai Health System,   that the increased risk was too small for people to give up their sauvignon blanc. Ã¢ÂÂI would not necessarily stop drinking completely,Ã¢ÂÂ Khorasani said. Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt think the data are strong enough to support that. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Drinking white wine could be putting you at risk forÃÂ cancer

Content: The cancer death rate has fallen 23 percent from its peak a generation ago, thanks to advances in treatment, early detection  Ã¢ÂÂ   and more people quitting cigarettes, a new study revealed Thursday. The drop translates to more than 1. 7 million fewer deaths from cancer through 2012, according to the research in Ã¢ÂÂCancer Statistics 2016,Ã¢ÂÂ  the American Cancer SocietyÃ¢ÂÂs annual report on cancer incidence, mortality, and survival. The study forecast a mixed message for New York state residents, predicting more cancer cases Ã¢ÂÂ   with roughly the same number of deaths. In 2016, there will be 110, 280 new cases ito go along with 34, 910 deaths by cancer this year, researchers said. A year ago, it was estimated thereÃ¢ÂÂd be 107, 840 new cases of cancer diagnosed in the Empire State and 34, 600 deaths. Dr. Otis Brawley, the groupÃ¢ÂÂs chief medical officer, said the increase of new cancer cases are based on a rise in the increase of New YorkÃ¢ÂÂs overall population and the number of people, more like to to be diagnosed. Those numbers, he said, are still favorable to New York state residents. Ã¢ÂÂOverall itÃ¢ÂÂs not bad at all,Ã¢ÂÂ Brawley said of the New York data. More American men than women died of cancer between 2008 and 2012, with New York State residents suffering slightly less than the national average. There were 193. 8 cancer deaths per 100, 000 men in New York state during that span, compared to the national average of 207. 9.  There were 141. 7  cancer deaths per 100, 000 women here from 2008 through 2012 vs. the national female average of 145. 4. Despite encouraging findings overall, researchers said thereÃ¢ÂÂs still much work to be done. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre gratified to see cancer death rates continuing to drop,Ã¢ÂÂ said Brawley. Ã¢ÂÂBut the fact that cancer is nonetheless becoming the top cause of death in many populations is a strong reminder that the fight is not over. Ã¢ÂÂ In 1991 there were 215. 1 cancer deaths per 100, 000 Americans,  compared to 166. 4 cancer deaths in 2012, the latest year of hard data. Ã¢ÂÂSo while the average AmericanÃ¢ÂÂs chances of dying from the disease are significantly lower now than they have been for previous generations, it continues to be    the reason for shortened lives, and too much pain and suffering,Ã¢ÂÂ Brawley said. Overall, itÃ¢ÂÂs expected that 595, 690 Americans will die from cancer this year, compared to a year ago when it was estimated that  589, 430 would die of the disease in 2015. Cancer is the No. 2 killer of all Americans, second only to heart disease, researchers said.
Title: Cancer deaths are wayÃÂ down

Content: When your boyfriend is having his head shaved before emergency surgery to remove a brain tumor, the right thing to say about his shiny new head is probably not Ã¢ÂÂYou were going bald anyway. Ã¢ÂÂ But thatÃ¢ÂÂs what I said, because I am an idiot and because nobody ever knows what to say in awkward, terrible situations. Aaron laughed, because he had the superhuman ability to laugh at himself, but even today I feel terrible about how that came out. Even though, I mean, I was right. Since that bizarre  episode of a Halloween night where my boyfriend went from being a normal     dude to being a cancer patient, our family has gotten emails from   acquaintances and friends of friends of friends. We have been stopped in restaurants and on the street by total strangers, people who just want to tell us they love our love, that they think of us often and wish us well. Even though this tends to happen when I am out in public wearing no makeup and looking like a drowned sewer rat, thatÃ¢ÂÂs a really amazing feeling. ItÃ¢ÂÂs been like a   fire hose of love and energy that we get to dance in like sweaty children on a hot summer day, with occasional pauses for someone to instead pelt me in the face with a water balloon.  Yes! Cancer is just like getting hazed at your sorority or failing your driverÃ¢ÂÂs test because   cars didnÃ¢ÂÂt exist in the nineties. I think youÃ¢ÂÂre on to something here.              You know what? Great question. ItÃ¢ÂÂs definitely not what a bride traditionally hears after her wedding, but thatÃ¢ÂÂs what makes this such a memorable choice. Well done, former coworker.                Oh! Great! Please consider adding a spoiler alert to this conversation.        Thank you so much for sharing your medical expertise. I know most people prefer to consult Ã¢ÂÂdoctorsÃ¢ÂÂ about their cancer treatment, but why would we when youÃ¢ÂÂve got the answers?!                          Well, thereÃ¢ÂÂs only one way to tell: acquire a time machine, travel back in time and have him get a CAT scan in about 2006, when his brain tumor was probably just starting to form and was likely not yet cancerous. Then, conduct an elaborate scheme to get him to break up with his girlfriend and fall in love with me, and see if we still end up married. IÃ¢ÂÂm guessing that tipping him off to the murderous cells hiding in his brain might help convince him to love me or totally freak him out, but itÃ¢ÂÂs worth a try!            Yeah? I mean, cancer isnÃ¢ÂÂt much of a fight for some people. There are some where treatment is basically you just standing there while the Mike Tyson of cancers   you over and over again. This is hard stuff, and a person can only take so much. When itÃ¢ÂÂs clear that itÃ¢ÂÂs time to call it, thatÃ¢ÂÂs okay, too.                Thank you for the pep talk. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a really nice thing to hear at my husbandÃ¢ÂÂs funeral. Do you think thereÃ¢ÂÂs anyone here who is interested in dating me? Do you mind putting some feelers out for me?  Oh thanks yep you nailed it. YouÃ¢ÂÂll definitely feel the exact same way when your husband and father die right after your miscarriage.          Hey, God! Great plan! I  it. Super fun.      Like MarthaÃ¢ÂÂs Vineyard? It can be hard to know what to say to a person who is going through something difficult, but you can probably wipe these options from your list of conversation starters. There are no right words, though I wish there were because I would say them instead of the stupid, awkward shit that comes out of my mouth. If there were right words, I wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have told my hysterical coworker to put her cat to sleep because it sounded like cat chemotherapy was kind of expensive. YouÃ¢ÂÂre thankful for the kind things people say, you forgive the dumb things, but youÃ¢ÂÂre crushed by the silence. I always like to think the best of myself, so IÃ¢ÂÂd like to think that if something terrible happened to someone I knew, IÃ¢ÂÂd be able to acknowledge it with love and encouragement, though I know itÃ¢ÂÂs easier said than done. When Aaron died, I heard from strangers around the world, but some of his closest friends disappeared completely. New friends came into my life, but some people IÃ¢ÂÂd known forever didnÃ¢ÂÂt return. I ran into my very first boyfriend the way Catholics tend to do . . . at a funeral. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm sorry,Ã¢ÂÂ he said to me as he stood up from our lunch table in the church basement to head back to the office. Ã¢ÂÂI never said anything to you about your dad or your husband. I didnÃ¢ÂÂt know what to say. Ã¢ÂÂ WeÃ¢ÂÂd dated for nearly eight years, and my father had loved him and threatened to murder him on occasion. IÃ¢ÂÂd noticed his absence in the piles of cards and emails I got after Aaron and my father died, and I let it burn me a little bit, to take the edge off the grief. Ã¢ÂÂI know,Ã¢ÂÂ I told him, my heart cracking open just enough to feel for him, the   boy whoÃ¢ÂÂd kissed me on my parentsÃ¢ÂÂ steps and always struggled to put his heart into words. I meant it  Ã¢ÂÂ   that I knew he didnÃ¢ÂÂt know what to say, and that I knew why. Ã¢ÂÂNobody knows what to say. I donÃ¢ÂÂt even know what to say. Ã¢ÂÂ I donÃ¢ÂÂt worry so much about saying the right thing or the wrong thing anymore, and even all of the stupid things that people have said have a special place in my heart, because theyÃ¢ÂÂre a sign that somebody tried. Sure, it was awkward and I wanted to punch a few throats, but being a human is awkward and uncomfortable. WeÃ¢ÂÂre all just doing our best here. I have to remind myself of that all the time, especially since my Facebook feed has become 90 percent pyramid schemes involving either vitamins, essential oils, or nail decals. Being a founder of the Hot Young Widows Club didnÃ¢ÂÂt bring me the wisdom to know what to say when IÃ¢ÂÂm faced with death and sickness and grief. Most people are illiterate in the language of grief, and I count myself among that number. I am trying to learn and teach at the same time, but I am beginning to think that there is no right thing to say, and that perhaps it is okay for language to fail us at this time. ItÃ¢ÂÂs okay for us to stumble for words when weÃ¢ÂÂre faced with death and sickness and grief; itÃ¢ÂÂs okay for stupid and awkward ones to slip out where weÃ¢ÂÂd hoped sweet and comforting ones would have appeared. You may be the person who says the wrong thing, but thatÃ¢ÂÂs better than being the one who says nothing at all.
Title: DonÃ¢ÂÂt say this to your friend whose boyfriend hasÃÂ cancer

Content: How cool would it be to stop cancer dead in its tracks using a vaccine that would work regardless of cancer type? It turns out that humanity is already thinking along those lines, and itÃ¢ÂÂs looking to introduce a type of Ã¢ÂÂuniversal cancer vaccineÃ¢ÂÂ that would be able to trigger the humanÃ¢ÂÂs body   defenses to kill cancerous cells. Specifically, researchers at the Johannes Gutenberg University in Mainz, Germany, have initiated a limited safety human trial, after experiments on mice showed impressive results.   Unlike other vaccines that are supposed to prevent a certain disease, the cancer vaccine would only be administered to cancer patients. Each vaccine therapy would actually be a customized treatment,   as it would use pieces of RNA extracted from the patientÃ¢ÂÂs cancer cells to trigger a reaction from his or her immune system. Ã¢ÂÂ[Such] vaccines are fast and inexpensive to produce, and virtually any tumor antigen can be encoded by RNA,Ã¢ÂÂ  . Ã¢ÂÂThus, the nanoparticulate RNA immunotherapy approach introduced here may be regarded as a universally applicable novel vaccine class for cancer immunotherapy. Ã¢ÂÂ Because cancer cells can look and behave like normal cells, the immune system does not attack them. However, by using a   antigen, the vaccine would fool the immune system into initiating an   attack against all cells that express it, taking out tumors anywhere in the body. To deliver it, scientists have coated the cancer RNA in a fatty acid membrane that has a slightly negative charge. This allows it to travel anywhere in the body, including spleen, lymph nodes, and bone marrow. Once the vaccine meets dendritic immune cells, the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs T cells get to inspect the RNA information. The next response is the neutralization of all tumorous cells that are similar in design. Tests conducted on mice showed that their immune systems were able to combat cancer aggressively. The team started a limited human trial that includes three patients with melanoma. The point of the test was to see whether the vaccine is safe for humans, and the results are promising. The initial results are promising, with side effects including   symptoms, which are better than what comes with chemotherapy treatments. A larger trial can only start in the following years. The team has to wait 12 months to perform   tests on the three patients before moving to the next step, which involves the actual test of the vaccineÃ¢ÂÂs efficiency at killing cancer.
Title: The cure for cancer could be as simple as aÃÂ vaccine

Content: Ã¢ÂÂNonprofitÃ¢ÂÂ hospitals turn out to be some of the nationÃ¢ÂÂs most profitable. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs just part of the lunacy that increasingly dominates the US   system. Researchers at Johns Hopkins and Washington and Lee Universities report that seven of AmericaÃ¢ÂÂs 10 most profitable hospitals are officially not for profit. That status entitles them to huge state and federal tax breaks  Ã¢ÂÂ   whose value has doubled in recent years  Ã¢ÂÂ   for Ã¢ÂÂcharity care and community benefit. Ã¢ÂÂ Topping the list is the Gundersen Lutheran Medical Center in La Crosse, Wis. which netted $302. 5 million profit from patient services alone (not including donations, etc.) in 2013. A   outlet will pay taxes and returns to investors. Nonprofits wind up paying huge sums to executives  Ã¢ÂÂ   and plowing cash into gaining more market share. None of the   hospitals is in New York, by the way. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs because the most profitable facilities generally dominate and even monopolize the market in their area. And that gives them enormous leverage when setting prices and negotiating reimbursement from private insurers  Ã¢ÂÂ   whose hands are tied because they need those hospitals to be part of their network to attract paying customers. As Dr. Marty Makary of Johns Hopkins wrote in The Wall Street Journal back in 2014: Ã¢ÂÂWhen youÃ¢ÂÂre the only game in town, you call the shots. Ã¢ÂÂ And the biggest losers in all this, of course, are John and Jane Q. Public. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a basic economic fact that competition breeds lower prices and greater choices, while monopolies lead to higher prices, less choice and worse service. But ObamaCare pushes hospital mergers and consolidations, which have been rising at record rates. The law directly bribes doctors and hospitals to form Ã¢ÂÂaccountable care organizations,Ã¢ÂÂ and it also encourages   consolidation  Ã¢ÂÂ   which forces hospitals to do the same to preserve negotiating leverage. WeÃ¢ÂÂre certainly not opposed to an honest profit, nor to charities doing good by doing well. But New Yorkers are all too familiar with how nonprofits get abused to serve insiders more than the public. And the government shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be forcing mass consolidation in any industry. These forces are also turning traditional, individual and   doctorsÃ¢ÂÂ offices into an endangered species. Bottom line: Local   monopolies are the nationÃ¢ÂÂs future, unless Washington changes course  Ã¢ÂÂ   drastically.
Title: Cancerous nonprofits and the monopolization of American healthÃÂ care

Content: ItÃ¢ÂÂs the rare star who covers for his own understudy. But   Miranda did just that when Javier MuÃÂ±oz, his alternate in Ã¢ÂÂHamilton,Ã¢ÂÂ missed a Sunday matinee. Considering Sunday matinees are the only shows MuÃÂ±oz plays, you may wonder what kept him away. Blame it on cancer. Ã¢ÂÂI was diagnosed in October,Ã¢ÂÂ MuÃÂ±oz tells The Post. Ã¢ÂÂI spent about six weeks not wanting to think about it, face, it, deal with it. Ã¢ÂÂ Even now, heÃ¢ÂÂd rather not say exactly what cancer heÃ¢ÂÂs up against, only that Ã¢ÂÂI had never felt fear before like this in my life. Ã¢ÂÂ For weeks, the    says, he said nothing. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂd just call out [sick] or push through,Ã¢ÂÂ says the slender, goateed MuÃÂ±oz, whose job includes observing every Ã¢ÂÂHamiltonÃ¢ÂÂ performance for any new nuances, and to go on for Miranda if needed. (Good luck with that, MuÃÂ±oz says: Ã¢ÂÂLinÃ¢ÂÂs such a workhorse  Ã¢ÂÂ   if both his legs fell off, heÃ¢ÂÂd wheel himself out there! Ã¢ÂÂ) But in November, MuÃÂ±oz did what he had to do: He left the show to undergo surgery, followed by radiation treatments that depleted him, then physical therapy to get him strong enough to take the stage. All told, he missed two months of Sundays, in which cast member Jon Rua often went on in his stead. Another show might have gone on with an alternate understudy. Not Ã¢ÂÂHamilton. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThere was no thought at all about [replacing him],Ã¢ÂÂ says Thomas Kail, the director of both Ã¢ÂÂHamiltonÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂIn the Heights,Ã¢ÂÂ the 2008 Tony winner in which MuÃÂ±oz also alternated with Miranda. Ã¢ÂÂJaviÃ¢ÂÂs someone who has given so much,Ã¢ÂÂ Kail continues. Ã¢ÂÂNow we wanted to make sure he had what he needed to be well, and to know he wasnÃ¢ÂÂt alone. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂI was diagnosed in October. I spent about six weeks not wanting to think about it, face it, deal with it.Ã¢ÂÂ He wasnÃ¢ÂÂt. Ã¢ÂÂGod bless Leslie Odom Jr. !Ã¢ÂÂ MuÃÂ±oz says. His eyes fill with tears as he recalls how the man who plays Aaron Burr, HamiltonÃ¢ÂÂs frenemy, organized a food drive: Meals, paid for by members of the cast, arrived at MuÃÂ±ozÃ¢ÂÂs Astoria apartment every day. And, yes, his parents were there for him  Ã¢ÂÂ   and knew just what he was up against: Some 12 years ago, within a period of six months, they were both diagnosed with cancer. MuÃÂ±oz took a year off from acting and auditioning to take a day job, moving back into his boyhood home in Brooklyn to help with meals, laundry and doctor appointments. Happily, his parents recovered, and on Feb. 14 celebrated their 56th anniversary by watching their son star in Ã¢ÂÂHamilton. Ã¢ÂÂ That day, just five weeks after his last radiation treatment, MuÃÂ±oz showed why some fans call him Ã¢ÂÂthe sexy Hamilton. Ã¢ÂÂ Though heÃ¢ÂÂs tailored his Alexander on MirandaÃ¢ÂÂs, MuÃÂ±oz brings an edgy intensity to the role. MirandaÃ¢ÂÂs    Alexander is someone youÃ¢ÂÂd proudly introduce to your parents; MuÃÂ±ozÃ¢ÂÂs is someone youÃ¢ÂÂd sneak up the back stairs. Then again, any comparisons between the two make him uncomfortable. Ã¢ÂÂWe work so hard and so well together that, in my mind, I find it almost impossible to separate our versions,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. (Well, maybe Mel Brooks can  Ã¢ÂÂ   or thinks he can. MuÃÂ±oz says the Ã¢ÂÂ   ManÃ¢ÂÂ came backstage one Sunday and said, Ã¢ÂÂSo youÃ¢ÂÂre better than him, right? Yeah, yeah, so heÃ¢ÂÂs the writer, but youÃ¢ÂÂre better! Ã¢ÂÂ) As far as KailÃ¢ÂÂs concerned, MirandaÃ¢ÂÂs created a role thatÃ¢ÂÂs bigger than he is. Ã¢ÂÂJaviÃ¢ÂÂs not the alternate  Ã¢ÂÂ   he is Hamilton on Sundays,Ã¢ÂÂ the director says. Adds RenÃÂ©e Elise Goldsberry, the showÃ¢ÂÂs Angelica Schuyler, HamiltonÃ¢ÂÂs    and intellectual equal: Ã¢ÂÂTo understudy or standby takes a tremendous amount of humility. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a very supportive role. [But] when Javi goes on, thatÃ¢ÂÂs a lion going on, jumping headfirst into the battle. Javi proves that both sides  Ã¢ÂÂ   supporting and alpha male  Ã¢ÂÂ   exist. And he does it brilliantly. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Ã¢ÂÂHamiltonÃ¢ÂÂ starÃ¢ÂÂs secret cancerÃÂ struggle

Content: Brooklyn District Attorney Ken Thompson is battling an Ã¢ÂÂaggressiveÃ¢ÂÂ form of cancer and has left the    operations of his office to his   .
