Thompson, 50, who took office in 2014 after defeating longtime incumbent Charles Hynes in a Democratic primary, did not disclose the type of cancer he has or when he was diagnosed. But a source said the cancer is Ã¢ÂÂaggressiveÃ¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ   and added that Thompson has a Ã¢ÂÂtough road ahead of him. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂSince May heÃ¢ÂÂs been out of the office regarding a health issue. HeÃ¢ÂÂs extremely   but heÃ¢ÂÂs been out of the office for long periods of time,Ã¢ÂÂ another source said. Thompson, sources said, has been getting paperwork delivered to his Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, home, and has been working from there while undergoing treatment following the diagnosis. His staff had been only told he was suffering from a bad back, according to the same source, and many only learned the news after reading a statement Thompson issued Tuesday. Ã¢ÂÂWhat really triggered the chatter was the West Indian Day Parade, all the politicians, thatÃ¢ÂÂs their big day well he wasnÃ¢ÂÂt there. That really started the chatter, everyone saying whatÃ¢ÂÂs going on with this guy?Ã¢ÂÂ the source said. In his statement, Thompson sounded optimistic. Ã¢ÂÂRecently, I was diagnosed with cancer. As a man of intense faith, I intend to fight and win the battle against this disease   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     and respectfully ask that you honor my familyÃ¢ÂÂs need and wish for privacy during this time,Ã¢ÂÂ the statement said. But sources said the diagnosis calls into question whether the DA will be up for running for reelection. Ã¢ÂÂThe next election for Brooklyn DA is right around the corner. ItÃ¢ÂÂs all about the primary in September but you need to get your name on the ballet by June. Is he going to run? thatÃ¢ÂÂs the big question,Ã¢ÂÂ the source said. His    Eric Gonzalez, will be taking over the primary duties, he added. Gonzalez is the first Latino to hold the position as Chief Assistant DA, and has served as ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs advisor on legal matters. The former prosecutor has worked at the Brooklyn DA for the past 15 years, spanning multiple administrations. He was appointed to the spot of Chief ADA in October 2014, by Thompson. Speculation is already swirling over who might replace Thompson should he be unable to run. Ã¢ÂÂThe big question is whether heÃ¢ÂÂs going to run and who is going to run against him if he does run?Ã¢ÂÂ in a primary. Sources said possible candidates include Gonzalez and Anne J. Swern of the Brooklyn Defender Services, a former prosecutor for over 33 years in the Brooklyn DAÃ¢ÂÂs office. Thompson was a successful trial lawyer in private practice who made headlines defending Nafissatou Diallo, an African immigrant working as a housekeeper in the Sofitel hotel in Midtown in her   case against Dominique   who led the International Monetary Fund.   was eventually cleared when Manhattan DA Cyrus Vance Jr. said he lacked enough evidence to bring charges. It was a complicated debut year for Mr. Thompson, who after a rancorous campaign against the longtime incumbent, Charles J. Hynes, assumed his post in January 2014 promising not only to revitalize an office that had fallen prey to scandal, but also to recalibrate the way that BrooklynÃ¢ÂÂs   system deals with its minority communities. Rising to power on the same progressive wave that swept Mayor Bill de Blasio into City Hall, he took over the position flush with optimism, vowing to reinvestigate dozens of his predecessorÃ¢ÂÂs dubious convictions and to end  Ã¢ÂÂ   against the wishes of the police  Ã¢ÂÂ   the prosecution of minor marijuana busts. But even as he set about enacting his agenda, events overtook him. Seven months into his tenure, Eric Garner died in Staten Island after being put in a chokehold by Officer Daniel Pantaleo. One month later, Michael Brown was fatally shot in Ferguson, Mo. by Officer Darren Wilson. Then, in November, just days before two grand juries impaneled in these cases failed to bring charges against either of the men, Officer Liang discharged his service weapon during a   Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂvertical patrolÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ in a dark stairwell of the Louis H. Pink Houses in the Brooklyn neighborhood of East New York. The ricocheting bullet killed Akai Gurley, 28, who had just gotten his hair braided for Thanksgiving and had entered the stairwell with his girlfriend.
Title: Brooklyn district attorney says he hasÃÂ cancer

Content: Last week, the National Enquirer reported that Jennifer Aniston is using a portable infrared sauna installed at home to fend off cancer cells. Proponents of the unregulated treatment believe that, unlike regular saunas, which only heat the skinÃ¢ÂÂs surface, infrared rays warm from the inside, killing off bacteria, molds, viruses, fungi and cancer cells before they turn into a tumor.  But not everyoneÃ¢ÂÂs on board with the practice. Oncologists from   and the   donÃ¢ÂÂt vouch for the saunaÃ¢ÂÂs health benefits. Brent Bauer, the director of   program, said that, although a few small preliminary studies have explored using saunas to treat high blood pressure, congestive heart failure and arthritis, more research is needed to measure the saunaÃ¢ÂÂs effectiveness for cancer.  However, for   student Wendy Myers, saunas are a way to extend her life  Ã¢ÂÂ   literally. For the last five years, the    lifestyle blogger has been using a $1, 200 infrared sauna in her Los Angeles home    times a week, for 45 minutes at a time, to fight cancer cells. Myers started using the portable   five years ago as a   way to treat low hormone production and thyroid function, which she says stimulate cancer cell growth. She first read about the treatment on an   Web site.  Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve never felt better,Ã¢ÂÂ Myers says. Ã¢ÂÂPeople who use this are going to have longer health and longevity. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂI like saunas because I feel better afterward,Ã¢ÂÂ Bauer adds. Ã¢ÂÂFor now, thatÃ¢ÂÂs the best reason to use one. If the science shows us some stronger benefits down the road, IÃ¢ÂÂll increase my usage then. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Does Jennifer Aniston have the secret to preventingÃÂ cancer?

Content: In 2006, Sheryl Crow was preparing to attend the Grammy Awards and looking forward to celebrating her three nominations. But what should have been a routine mammogram just before the ceremony changed her priorities in an instant. Ã¢ÂÂI was very healthy at the time and almost canceled the mammogram because I had a lot going on,Ã¢ÂÂ Crow tells The Post. Ã¢ÂÂBut they called me back and said they could see some things. Ã¢ÂÂ Those Ã¢ÂÂthingsÃ¢ÂÂ turned out to be   breast cancer, but after a lumpectomy and seven weeks of radiation, she made a full recovery. Ten years on, Crow is honoring Breast Cancer Awareness Month by   with all proceeds going to Stand Up to Cancer, a nonprofit that funds cancer research. Now 54, the   country   describes the trauma of her diagnosis, her recovery and how attitudes toward breast cancer have changed.   A post shared by sherylcrow (@sherylcrow) on  There are a couple of velvet jackets that IÃ¢ÂÂve worn onstage, obviously in the winter. From a practical standpoint, IÃ¢ÂÂm impressed I was even able to wear them. You have to be able to maneuver yourself and get a guitar over your head. The velvet jackets are quite a commitment. I was always the kind of person who worked hard to take care of everybody. I didnÃ¢ÂÂt say no to anything, but I didnÃ¢ÂÂt take care of myself very well. I ran myself into the ground. For the first time, I was forced to confront my mortality and how I live my life. It made me realize that life goes on if you say no to things  Ã¢ÂÂ   and not to record [music] unless I really felt like it or had something to say. Sometimes you just have to do whatÃ¢ÂÂs best for your own  . It changed my work ethic and the way I look at life. I tried to keep things as simple and normal as possible, even though people would always try to jump in and do things for you. [Everyday tasks such] as feeding the dogs made me feel normal. I always tell people going through the same thing to try to do those things. ItÃ¢ÂÂs hard to believe that pretty much no one talked about it before Betty Ford came along. EverythingÃ¢ÂÂs still changing. No matter where you are,   survivors find each other. I can be at Starbucks or wherever, and, invariably, someone will come up to me and say theyÃ¢ÂÂre a   survivor, or someone they knew passed away from it. I think weÃ¢ÂÂre all a little more willing to talk about it now.
Title: How breast cancer changed Sheryl CrowÃ¢ÂÂs outlook onÃÂ life

Content: Cancer was an enormous blessing. It saved my life. That may sound crazy, but itÃ¢ÂÂs true. The disease taught me that our greatest trials can be our greatest opportunities for growing and finding purpose. When the doctor diagnosed me with Stage 3 breast cancer in March 2008, I was 46 years old and told that I had a 10 percent or less chance of living if I did not begin treatment immediately. I knew I needed to do it  Ã¢ÂÂ   I wanted to beat cancer. But I had a secret that I could not share with anyone. I had been living a huge lie: While traveling around the United States, lecturing people on nutrition and talking about being a   triathlete, I routinely had bile on my tongue. Literally. I struggled with bulimia, making myself sick eight to 10 times per day  Ã¢ÂÂ   to the point where I was throwing up blood  Ã¢ÂÂ   and I was too ashamed to admit it. My eating disorder began during sophomore year of college when somebody told me the secret of being able to eat whatever I wanted: Just throw it up. I binged on bagels, ice cream, waffles, cake. It all went down my throat and came right back out. Soon there was a voice in my head that I called the TaskMaster, the SlaveMaster, the Liar, the Deceiver. It would tell me, Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂre worthless, youÃ¢ÂÂre fat, you might as well be dead. Ã¢ÂÂ That voice commanded me to throw up and I rationalized bulimia as the only way to stay thin. But it also became an escape from feeling inadequate. Vomiting gave me an endorphin chemical reaction. I lived on the high for a few seconds and then felt terrible again. I stopped throwing up when I was pregnant  Ã¢ÂÂ   I felt responsible for the life inside me  Ã¢ÂÂ   but after my three sons were born I went back to it. It became like a drug  Ã¢ÂÂ   even while I worked as a dietitian and ran triathlons. At night, while everyone in the house slept, I went in the kitchen and binged. I got so good at vomiting that sometimes I could do it without my fingers. ThereÃ¢ÂÂd be days when my kids banged on the bathroom door as I threw up and heard the demon voice: Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂre a bad mother. YouÃ¢ÂÂre fat. YouÃ¢ÂÂre worthless. Ã¢ÂÂ When I got diagnosed with cancer, I stood     my weight was 105 pounds, and hereÃ¢ÂÂs how sick I was: I looked forward to the chemotherapy. Ã¢ÂÂYou may be nauseous from the medication,Ã¢ÂÂ my doctor told me. That, I thought to myself, will be great. It will help keep me thin. At the same time, I instinctively knew I would have to stop being bulimic. I knew that if I wanted to see my kids grow up, the bulimia had to stop. Making myself sick while receiving chemotherapy would have killed me. I went cold turkey, and it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt easy. I would have cravings to make myself vomit, and I would hear the demon voice. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs when I told myself, Ã¢ÂÂKaren, you canÃ¢ÂÂt. If you do it, you will die. Ã¢ÂÂ I fought the voices. I wanted nothing more than to live. Cancer was a   call. Through it all, I knew I needed to continue competing in triathlons. It may sound like another compulsion, but it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt. At certain points in my life I had exercised to craziness, but this was different. By the time of my diagnosis, I had earned a slot in the Age Group World Triathlon Championships. I had to show my kids that I was still strong, that I was still somebody who could compete in that kind of a race. Crumbling to a disease does not bear well for your fight. It took three doctors for me to find one whoÃ¢ÂÂd clear me to race. A lot of cancer patients wear masks to keep from contracting other peopleÃ¢ÂÂs germs; racing in a triathlon is the opposite of that. So I can see why the doctors were concerned. But I needed to do it. I finally found a doctor who agreed that if I maintained a certain level of red and white blood cells, then I could race. Luckily, my cells never dropped below the level that heÃ¢ÂÂd set. Over a   period following the diagnosis, I completed seven triathlons while getting chemotherapy. That experience totally changed my perspective on what it means to be a champion. Every Wednesday, I went right from training in the pool to chemotherapy. For 36 hours after chemo, it was nonstop nausea, and there was zero chance of me being able to train then. I was praying to stop throwing up and, in the midst of it, wondered how I ever made myself sick. It was such an awakening. Then IÃ¢ÂÂd start training seriously on Sunday  Ã¢ÂÂ   biking, running, swimming  Ã¢ÂÂ   and by the time I was due for my next chemo, which happened every other week, I would feel fantastic. It took two weeks for me to feel good. But then the chemo treatment would leave me feeling miserable. IÃ¢ÂÂd start the cycle all over again. I knew that if I wanted to see my kids grow up, the bulimia had to stop. Before cancer, I used to think these races were only about winning. But during my first triathlon after beginning chemo, I learned differently. This race, the Championships, took place in Vancouver, BC, and competitors got hypothermia while battling waves in frigid English Bay. I wasnÃ¢ÂÂt sure I would make it  Ã¢ÂÂ   but I couldnÃ¢ÂÂt let down my family members, doctors and other cancer patients. They were all rooting for me. A side effect of chemo is that you lose feeling in your fingers. Upon exiting the water my frozen fingers wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt work. I painstakingly wiggled out of my wet suit and watched all the other racers passing me by. Then I struggled to get my bicycling helmet buckled! I ended up second to last  Ã¢ÂÂ   and I was exhilarated. For the first time in my life, I recognized that winning does not count as the only victory. In 2013,   after a single radical mastectomy and radiation treatment, my weight was around 110 pounds, where it remains to this day. The bulimia is gone. Words still come into my head sometimes, calling me names, but I donÃ¢ÂÂt listen. I know theyÃ¢ÂÂre not true, and IÃ¢ÂÂve stopped keeping the bulimia a secret. Power grows from that.
Title: How cancer made me kick my demons Ã¢ÂÂ and saved myÃÂ life

Content: Doctors are determining the next steps in former Toronto Mayor Rob FordÃ¢ÂÂs cancer treatments as he continues to work on rebuilding his strength to resume chemotherapy treatments, his chief of staff Dan Jacobs said Thursday. FordÃ¢ÂÂs family joined him in the hospital as he continues to battle the disease. Jacobs said Ford has had about 10 rounds of chemotherapy so far. The Ford family has asked for privacy at this time. JacobsÃ¢ÂÂ announcement debunked a rumor going around on social media that Ford had died,  . Ford was thrust into the spotlight in 2013 when he acknowledged that he smoked crack in one of his Ã¢ÂÂdrunken stupors,Ã¢ÂÂ after months of denials. He refused to resign at the time. He was diagnosed with pleomorphic liposarcoma in 2014 and underwent surgery last May to remove the tumor. In October, doctors discovered two cancerous growths on his bladder. He has been in the hospital since late February. Doug Ford, RobÃ¢ÂÂs brother, told CP24 in October that his tumors were roughly 2 to 3 inches long and that additional rounds of chemo were necessary to determine whether surgery would be an option. Ã¢ÂÂRobÃ¢ÂÂs in a massive battle right now, and weÃ¢ÂÂre just going to keep fighting and do whatever we can, leave no stone unturned, and making sure he gets as much help as he needs,Ã¢ÂÂ Doug Ford said,  . Ford was forced out of his mayoral   bid in 2014 when doctors discovered his rare cancer. He ran successfully for council instead. The Toronto Star reported that Ford was going to take part in a clinical trial at Mount Sinai in Toronto and would be one of the first Canadians to receive a new method of treatment. The method involves oncologists giving mice the same tumor to determine the best treatment for a patient by testing different drugs on the rodent.
Title: Doctors are flummoxed by Toronto crackheadÃ¢ÂÂs cancer

Content: It was a regular Friday afternoon when Lin Riley was pulled over for a random breath test on Oxford Street, near Centennial Park in Sydney, Australia. Knowing she hadnÃ¢ÂÂt consumed a drop of alcohol that day, the    wound down her window and presented her licence to the police officer. Ã¢ÂÂWhen the officer gave it back to me, he stopped and said, Ã¢ÂÂWhat are you doing? What do you have on your seatbelt? Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Riley told news. com. au. What caught the officerÃ¢ÂÂs eye was a   bulldog clip attached to the seatbelt retractor above her right shoulder. The reason for the clip was to alleviate the pain the belt caused to her   side, because of a recent breast   operation. Three years ago, Riley was informed she had cancer, and was required to have various treatments on her left breast, which resulted in a mastectomy. In September 2015, one of her implants ruptured and she subsequently suffered from lymphedema, which created significant swelling to her left side and caused discomfort with pressure and pain. Her seatbelt, in its regular form, created Ã¢ÂÂgreat discomfortÃ¢ÂÂ in her chest when driving  Ã¢ÂÂ   and so to alleviate the pain, she placed the bulldog clip at the retractor above her right shoulder. Ã¢ÂÂThe belt made it very uncomfortable to drive, so when I didnÃ¢ÂÂt have a passenger or I couldnÃ¢ÂÂt catch public transport, I put a bulldog clip where the seatbelt comes out of the roller,Ã¢ÂÂ she said.  Ã¢ÂÂIt just lifts the belt away from my chest just a small amount so it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt go tight across my left side and cause me pain. Ã¢ÂÂ After the officer noted the clip, Riley explained her condition and why she needed relief from the seatbelt. Ã¢ÂÂHe said to me: Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs not my problem,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂI told him and showed him that I still had the belt on, and the officer just said that my issues werenÃ¢ÂÂt his problem. Ã¢ÂÂHe asked me to pull over to the side of the road, and another officer walked over to my car and asked why I was still there. I explained to him about my breast cancer and my seatbelt, and that officer didnÃ¢ÂÂt care either. Ã¢ÂÂ Riley pleaded with the officers that she would take the clip off the seatbelt, but they insisted what she had done was Ã¢ÂÂa breach and they had to fine her for incorrectly wearing a seatbelt. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThe officer walked away with my license, and kept me waiting for 35 minutes,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂThen when he returned with the ticket, he said, Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve done you a favor, and the ticket will only be for $360.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂI was so cross and upset by how rude they were to me. I showed it to my son, and I was just in tears. Ã¢ÂÂ Riley, who admitted she didnÃ¢ÂÂt have a doctorÃ¢ÂÂs certificate with her to prove she had breast cancer, said she had no idea she needed permission to make a small alteration to her belt if it meant she was no longer in pain. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs unsafe to be driving in that sort of pain. I was on my own and didnÃ¢ÂÂt have someone in the car to help,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs just really unfortunate because the officers were so rude and not understanding of my situation. When they said my health problems werenÃ¢ÂÂt their problems   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     that really upset me, to be frank. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ After the incident, Riley, who is a learning resource developer, went to her oncologist, who said they had Ã¢ÂÂnever heard of a story like itÃ¢ÂÂ and provided her with a doctorÃ¢ÂÂs certificate to help fight the fine. Ã¢ÂÂBasically, the officer said my only option to dispute the ticket was to get a doctorÃ¢ÂÂs certificate, and take the matter to court,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂIf I was going around without a seatbelt, I would completely understand the fine and pay it. But this was just a minor alteration. Ã¢ÂÂ According to New South Wales Transport, Riley had in fact broken the law because she didnÃ¢ÂÂt have a medical certificate with her at the time of infringement. Ã¢ÂÂDrivers or passengers may be exempt from wearing a seatbelt if they carry a medical certificate saying that a seatbelt cannot be worn due to a medical condition,Ã¢ÂÂ an NSW Transport spokesman said. Ã¢ÂÂAccording to NSW road rules, all drivers and passengers are required to wear an approved seatbelt. Tampering with an approved seatbelt may mean it no longer meets compliance standards. Ã¢ÂÂModification to an approved seatbelt can reduce the performance of the safety features and increase the likelihood of an injury during a crash. Ã¢ÂÂEnforcing road rules is the responsibility of the NSW Police Force. Ã¢ÂÂ After being contacted by news. com. au, a police spokesman said they had been in contact with Riley and Ã¢ÂÂthe issue is being resolved. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂThey were very apologetic about what had happened,Ã¢ÂÂ Riley said. The spokesman was unable to advise how they would be assisting Riley with the fine.
Title: Breast cancer patient fined for wearing an alteredÃÂ seatbelt

Content: Vice President Joe Biden last year tragically lost his son Beau to brain cancer at the age of 46. No parent should ever have to bury a child. And now Biden, ever the fighter, has responded with a personal commitment to eradicating cancer: Ã¢ÂÂa new moon shot. Ã¢ÂÂ At Tuesday nightÃ¢ÂÂs State of the Union address, President Obama handed him the keys to a new national effort against cancer. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm putting Joe in charge of mission control,Ã¢ÂÂ Obama said. Biden tweeted the focus for this initiative, which is to Ã¢ÂÂincrease resources  Ã¢ÂÂ   both private and public  Ã¢ÂÂ   to fight cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ And also to Ã¢ÂÂbreak down silos and bring all the cancer fighters together  Ã¢ÂÂ   to work together, share information, and end cancer as we know it. Ã¢ÂÂ While we donÃ¢ÂÂt yet know where the moneyÃ¢ÂÂs going to come from, the sentiment is certainly laudable, and top cancer centers around the country  Ã¢ÂÂ   including MD Anderson in Houston, Sloan Kettering Memorial here in New York, Dana Farber in Boston and many others  Ã¢ÂÂ   certainly duplicate efforts that could be streamlined. (Though in my experience, the top researchers each know what the others are up to, and they frequently collaborate.) There is also no doubt that weÃ¢ÂÂre seeing important developments in the war on cancer. Major advances in immunotherapies, including vaccines, have enabled oncologists to directly target the surface of cancerous cells instead of using toxic chemicals that affect the whole body in an effort to stop cancer growth. Cancer is often able to survive and grow by hiding from the immune system, but top researchers are finding ways to counter that for many of our worst cancers including lung, breast, melanoma and bone. The treatments are often more effective and less toxic than traditional chemotherapy. And genetic therapies are being developed to counter the mutations that cause cancer to grow. So whatÃ¢ÂÂs the catch? Well, President Obama is the wrong    for the war on cancer. His signature health care program, ObamaCare, may be responsible for signing up more than 16 million people who were previously uninsured, but the kind of health insurance theyÃ¢ÂÂre getting will hardly pay for the new treatments. ObamaCare is    ; it usually pairs a high deductible (typically more than $5, 000 per year) with   care in a narrow network that excludes most top doctors, hospitals and drugs. Plus, with all its regulations, taxes and penalties ($500 billion in new taxes in the first 10 years) ObamaCare stifles the very innovation necessary for drug companies to develop new cures. Research and development is currently growing much faster in Asia, India and Europe than in the United States. And evolving,   cancer doesnÃ¢ÂÂt suit     treatments. Exciting new cancer drugs will lead to more personalized care, meaning that the vaccine or directed antibody may respond to the proteins of your tumor but not someone elseÃ¢ÂÂs. Expensive drugs that only work well for small numbers of people are difficult to justify to insurance companies that participate in ObamaCare, especially when these treatments are very expensive. And targeted therapies routinely cost over $100, 000 a year per patient. Well worth it if itÃ¢ÂÂs your life on the line, but ObamaCare isnÃ¢ÂÂt designed to respond to your personalized medical needs. ObamaÃ¢ÂÂs cancer pronouncement on Tuesday brings to mind another declared war on cancer  Ã¢ÂÂ   by President Richard Nixon, 45 years ago. But Nixon immediately put his money where his mouth was, asking for $100 million and signing the National Cancer Act into law. This act gave the National Cancer Institute the power and budget to develop many new lifesaving treatments. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs no doubt Joe BidenÃ¢ÂÂs heart is in the right place. But this president is unlikely to give him the resources and flexibility he needs to succeed.
Title: BidenÃ¢ÂÂs cancer Ã¢ÂÂmoon shotÃ¢ÂÂ is a grand idea thatÃ¢ÂÂsÃÂ doomed

Content: Do most people who get cancer simply have bad luck? Or is cancer something they might be able to prevent? Two new studies suggest the latter. A study   found that between 40  Ã¢ÂÂ   70% of cancer cases could be prevented if we changed our lifestyles by doing things like staying at a healthy weight, quitting smoking, reducing alcohol consumption and getting 2 ÃÂ½ hours of exercise a week. Ã¢ÂÂA large proportion of cancers are due to environmental factors and can be prevented by lifestyle modification,Ã¢ÂÂ the authors concluded.  revealed that it is mostly environmental and external factors like smoking, drinking, diet, getting too much sun and exposure to toxic chemicals that cause cancer, rather than intrinsic factors like random cell mutations. Intrinsic factors accounted for just 10% to 30% of peopleÃ¢ÂÂs lifetime risk of getting cancer, while extrinsic risks accounted for 70% to 90% for most common cancer types, the study showed. Ã¢ÂÂCancer risk is heavily influenced by extrinsic factors,Ã¢ÂÂ the study researchers, who work at Stony Brook University in New York, concluded. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs good news for many, as it means that cancer might be more avoidable  Ã¢ÂÂ   through changes in our lifestyles  Ã¢ÂÂ   than we previously thought. Ã¢ÂÂEnvironmental factors play an important role in cancer incidence and they are modifiable through lifestyle changes   vaccinations,Ã¢ÂÂ the researchers write in Nature. Or as the researchers in JAMA Oncology put it: Ã¢ÂÂA substantial cancer burden may be prevented through lifestyle modification. Ã¢ÂÂ Many experts cheered this finding. Ã¢ÂÂThereÃ¢ÂÂs no question whatÃ¢ÂÂs at stake here,Ã¢ÂÂ  . Ã¢ÂÂThis informs whether or not we expend energy on prevention. Ã¢ÂÂ The authors of the study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association Oncology noted that Ã¢ÂÂprevention should remain a priority for cancer control. Ã¢ÂÂ These conclusions do fly in the face of other cancer research. A report in the journal Science published earlier in 2015 concluded just the opposite: that roughly   of cancers were caused by intrinsic factors. (These findings came to be known as the Ã¢ÂÂbad luckÃ¢ÂÂ hypothesis.) But the Stony Brook researchers concluded that the incidence of cancer is too high for that to be true. Ã¢ÂÂThe rates of mutation accumulation by intrinsic processes are not sufficient to account for the observed cancer risks,Ã¢ÂÂ they write in the study published in Nature.
Title: 70% to 90% of cancer is your own damnÃÂ fault

Content: You wonÃ¢ÂÂt have to watch this over anybodyÃ¢ÂÂs shoulder  Ã¢ÂÂ   but you may need to watch it through your fingers. A doctor at New YorkÃ¢ÂÂs Mt. Sinai Hospital will use a robot to perform a prostate surgery on Monday morning, and the whole thing will be  . Prostate cancer is expected to kill more than 25, 000 Americans in 2016  Ã¢ÂÂ   while another 180, 000 US men will be diagnosed with the cancer, according to the American Cancer Society. Streaming the surgery will help raise awareness of the issue. Dr. Ash Tewari, who will perform the surgery, expects to remove a cancer from a manÃ¢ÂÂs prostate while preserving the patientÃ¢ÂÂs nervous and urinary functions. Ã¢ÂÂWhy not prostate?Ã¢ÂÂ the star urologist told The Post, when asked why this particular surgery was chosen to be streamed around the world. Ã¢ÂÂProstate cancer happens to be one of the biggest killers for men in the US  Ã¢ÂÂ   28, 000 a year,Ã¢ÂÂ Tewari said. The   surgery, which is being webcast via Microsoft Azure and LiveArena, will be watched by doctors and med students at 15 institutions worldwide. It can be accessed
Title: Watch a man get his prostate cancer removed Ã¢ÂÂÃÂ live

Content: HOUSTON  Ã¢ÂÂ   The chemotherapy has diminished Craig SagerÃ¢ÂÂs   chestnut hair to a few unruly strands, and on this day of hope, a simple green   and blue shorts adorn the man known by millions for his ostentatious wardrobe and easy rapport with the NBAÃ¢ÂÂs elite. He methodically extended a long, skinny arm to an IV pole holding the stem cells he is counting on to save his life. There was silence as he cradled the tube, watching the crimson liquid drip, drip, drip in a perfect cadence into the cannula feeding it into his   body. TNTÃ¢ÂÂs most beloved basketball broadcaster received a rare third bone marrow transplant on Wednesday as an aggressive form of leukemia continues to take its toll. The    Sager has battled acute myeloid leukemia since 2014, and announced in March that he was no longer in remission. Sager knows the odds are against him. Yet he is unfazed. Ã¢ÂÂI like to gamble,Ã¢ÂÂ he told the Associated Press. Ã¢ÂÂI like to bet on horses, I like to bet on dogs, I like to bet on a lot of things. IÃ¢ÂÂve bet on a lot of things with a lot higher odds than this. Ã¢ÂÂ Two other times Sager has received a bone marrow transplant with stem cells, and in both instances it put him into remission for several months. His son, Craig Sager II, was the donor then. This time, the anonymous    donor was considered a perfect match. Sager has been hospitalized for a month and has another   stay ahead. He hasnÃ¢ÂÂt thought a lot about the random man whose bone marrow could change everything for him. But when he learned of his age, he expressed a possibly only   concern. Ã¢ÂÂMy only thing was I was afraid that when he signed up to be the donor, he may have been in some drunk fraternity house, trying to impress his date,Ã¢ÂÂ Sager said with a smile. Ã¢ÂÂAnd they call him up the next day and say: Ã¢ÂÂWant to come down to the hospital?Ã¢ÂÂ and heÃ¢ÂÂs like: Ã¢ÂÂWhat? Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ His fears turned out to be unfounded. Ã¢ÂÂHe came through,Ã¢ÂÂ Sager said. It is the latest of close to 100 procedures Sager has endured in his   fight and it was performed at MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. Sager began the transplant at about 11:30 a. m. Central time and it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt complete until more than 10 hours later. Dr. Muzaffar Qazilbash, SagerÃ¢ÂÂs stem cell transplantation physician, researched thousands of such transplants at MD Anderson over the last 15 years to illustrate just how uncommon SagerÃ¢ÂÂs procedure was. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs less than 1 percent of the total number of transplants,Ã¢ÂÂ Qazilbash said. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs very rare to have three transplants. Ã¢ÂÂ Sager, who has worked for TNT for more than three decades, calls himself coachable and said heÃ¢ÂÂs open to trying anything doctors believe might help. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve had every chemo in the alphabet, most of them more than once,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂSome of them that arenÃ¢ÂÂt even in the alphabet, theyÃ¢ÂÂre just numbers  Ã¢ÂÂ   clinical trials. But I bet if you added all those up, it would have to be like   or  . IÃ¢ÂÂve had 23 bone marrow aspirations. Having one isnÃ¢ÂÂt fun and IÃ¢ÂÂve had 23. So thatÃ¢ÂÂs been tough. Ã¢ÂÂ Despite the rigors of treatment and how they can ravage his body, heÃ¢ÂÂs never thought about giving up. In fact, he gets angry when he meets other patients who say theyÃ¢ÂÂve grown weary of fighting. Ã¢ÂÂMan, life is too beautiful, too wonderful, thereÃ¢ÂÂs just too many things,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs not just you. ItÃ¢ÂÂs your family and kids and all. Fight. Fight until the end. Fight as hard as you can. Ã¢ÂÂ With his radiant smile and   persona, it takes time to peel back the layers of positivity and catch a glimpse of how hard that fight can be. Ã¢ÂÂHis attitude is (that) nobody wants to hear it,Ã¢ÂÂ said Stacy Sager, his wife,   caregiver and No. 1 fan. Ã¢ÂÂAnd so it makes you reflect on yourself and the things that you say when youÃ¢ÂÂre complaining about little things in life and trivial things and it just puts things in perspective. Ã¢ÂÂ But there are times, often as night creeps into early morning, when it all becomes too much. No medication can help. Ã¢ÂÂFight. Fight until the end. Fight as hard as you can.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve never had any of those days where IÃ¢ÂÂve actually said Ã¢ÂÂWhy me,Ã¢ÂÂ or Ã¢ÂÂI canÃ¢ÂÂt do it,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂBut IÃ¢ÂÂll have some dark nights where IÃ¢ÂÂll be here by myself and maybe getting some medicine thatÃ¢ÂÂs making me jump around like a rabbit. And IÃ¢ÂÂm in pain and IÃ¢ÂÂve got chills and IÃ¢ÂÂve got fever and IÃ¢ÂÂve got everything mixed into one and IÃ¢ÂÂm throwing up and have diarrhea   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     and IÃ¢ÂÂll just say: Ã¢ÂÂStacy, I need you. I need you.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂAnd sheÃ¢ÂÂll come to me and just hold me and it just makes it better,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. A few days before his transplant, Stacy came down with a bad cold and doctors sent her home, fearful sheÃ¢ÂÂd transmit her illness to her husband. Hall of Famer and TNT colleague Charles Barkley heard she couldnÃ¢ÂÂt be there for a couple of days and hopped on a plane from Phoenix. The problem was that Sir Charles had hip replacement surgery less than a month ago and wasnÃ¢ÂÂt cleared to travel. He said his doctor was livid when he learned Barkley had defied orders and flown halfway across the country. Barkley informed the doctor that it was an emergency  Ã¢ÂÂ   though it was hard to know who was there for whom. Ã¢ÂÂCraig Sager is one of the most interesting people IÃ¢ÂÂve ever met,Ã¢ÂÂ Barkley said. Ã¢ÂÂWe go to see Sager to cheer him up and by the time you leave youÃ¢ÂÂre like, Ã¢ÂÂIs anything wrong with him?Ã¢ÂÂ He has the most positive attitude   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     when you go to try and cheer him up, his attitude is so upbeat he cheers you up. Ã¢ÂÂ Sager has found inspiration in a little girl who lost her fight with cancer before her ninth birthday. He befriended Lacey Holsworth and her family while working on a story about her illness and remained friends with her parents after she died in April 2014. Holsworth had cheered on the Michigan State basketball team and  . Last weekend, her parents visited Sager in his Houston hospital room. They left him with a more tangible reminder of her bravery. Ã¢ÂÂThey brought me little LaceyÃ¢ÂÂs boots that she used to always wear to games and a picture of her wearing them,Ã¢ÂÂ Sager said, clutching the   cheetah footwear accessorized with laces made from silk ribbons. Ã¢ÂÂThat little girl was so amazing. Fought for all of those years, was always positive, always cheerful, always brought other peopleÃ¢ÂÂs spirits up. So if IÃ¢ÂÂm laying here feeling bad, I just think about Lacey and it puts everything in perspective. Ã¢ÂÂ Sager is also bolstered by his drive to be back on the sideline for the NBA season. He doesnÃ¢ÂÂt expect to have recovered from WednesdayÃ¢ÂÂs transplant in time for the season opener on Oct. 25, but aims to return by early November for more of the gentle sparring with the likes of Spurs coach Gregg Popovich . It would be a victory not just for him, but for all the people his fight has inspired. Ã¢ÂÂIt means that youÃ¢ÂÂre surviving and youÃ¢ÂÂre winning,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂThat youÃ¢ÂÂre knocking down obstacles and clearing hurdles that are put in front of you and youÃ¢ÂÂre doing them with flying colors. Ã¢ÂÂ On Wednesday, five colorful balloons were tied to one side of his hospital bed. Several had birthday greetings and two said: Ã¢ÂÂHappy birthday, itÃ¢ÂÂs your big day. Ã¢ÂÂ Festive, yes. But Sager was born in June. Ã¢ÂÂWhen you get stem cells, they say itÃ¢ÂÂs your new birthday,Ã¢ÂÂ Stacy explained. Ã¢ÂÂSo this is his fourth birthday. Ã¢ÂÂ Sager tried to downplay the pageantry surrounding the event, saying it wasnÃ¢ÂÂt Ã¢ÂÂa big deal. Ã¢ÂÂ That earned a sweet, yet stern, admonishment from his beloved wife. Ã¢ÂÂIt is a big deal,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs giving you life. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Inside the hospital room where TNTÃ¢ÂÂs Craig Sager bravely battlesÃÂ cancer

Content: BRISTOL, Conn.  Ã¢ÂÂ   ESPN analyst Chris Mortensen says his throat cancer has been Ã¢ÂÂvirtually reduced to zero detection. Ã¢ÂÂ Mortensen was diagnosed in January and underwent intensive chemotherapy and radiation treatments. He  . He says he anticipates returning for NFL coverage Ã¢ÂÂon a limited basisÃ¢ÂÂ this season. Ã¢ÂÂI do have scheduled exams and scans during the next three months to monitor my status,Ã¢ÂÂ he says, Ã¢ÂÂbut my oncologists have directed me to recover and rehab from the treatments that have resulted in lengthy hospitalization, significant weight loss, strength, endurance and related health issues. I am following instructions to overcome these challenges. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: ESPNÃ¢ÂÂs Chris Mortensen gets best news in cancerÃÂ battle

Content: More than 5, 400 Ground Zero responders and others who lived, worked or went to school near the fallen Twin Towers have come down with    cancers, a grim tally that has tripled in the past   years. As of June 30, 5, 441 people enrolled in the   with some struck by more than one type, officials said. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs up from 1, 822 victims in January 2014. Ã¢ÂÂYou see an alarming increase,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Michael Crane, medical director of the WTC Health Program at Mount Sinai Hospital. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs been steady for at least the last year and a half  Ã¢ÂÂ   weÃ¢ÂÂre seeing new people here being certified for cancer 10 to 15 times week. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs every week. Ã¢ÂÂ Crane told The Post. The program now monitors more than 48, 000 cops, hardhats, volunteer firefighters, utility workers and others who toiled at Ground Zero. The FDNY has its own   health program with 16, 000 members. In all, at least 1, 140 have died, officials said. The feds have listed more than 50 types of cancer believed to be related to the toxic smoke and dust of  . Those afflicted may seek payments from the    Victim Compensation Fund. Veteran firefighter Ray Pfeifer, 58, has advanced kidney cancer that has spread through his body. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm a lucky guy,Ã¢ÂÂ Pfeifer told The Post. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve had 15 years with my kids after   and IÃ¢ÂÂm still here with Stage 4 cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ He has undergone 11 surgeries, including a kidney removal, hip, femur and knee replacement and radiation for a brain tumor. On the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, Pfeifer had the day off and was golfing with buddies when the planes hit. He rushed downtown to join the frantic dig for survivors and stayed nine days straight, sleeping on a rig. All 12 of his fellow Bravest assigned to Engine   35 on the Upper West Side were among the 343 firefighters killed when the towers collapsed. Pfeifer stayed eight months to search for remains. The   brushed off his Ã¢ÂÂWorld Trade Center coughÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂa little shortness of breath,Ã¢ÂÂ but in 2009 he felt pain in his hip and doctors found a   tumor. He kept working as a chiefÃ¢ÂÂs aide, but a   heart attack forced him to retire in 2014. He now visits Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center every two weeks: Ã¢ÂÂI see cops and firemen there. ItÃ¢ÂÂs not unheard of to see five to 10 people who worked on the pile getting treated for cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ Cancer was the last thing on the mind of an    girl who had just moved into a dorm at Pace University downtown to start her freshman year. On   she heard a loud boom, felt the building rattle and saw shards of glass flying from the Trade Center. Nicole, who asked that her last name not be printed, went home to Long Island covered in white dust and resumed classes about a week later: Ã¢ÂÂEverybody was reporting it was safe. Ã¢ÂÂ At age 31, Nicole was married and giving birth to a son by   when the doctor noticed an orange   goop. She was diagnosed with a rare appendix cancer. She underwent a hysterectomy, removal of other organs and a chemo bath in her abdominal cavity. Before the surgery, she and her husband froze four embryos. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre now seeking a surrogate gestational mother. Ã¢ÂÂThis disease didnÃ¢ÂÂt kill me, but it robbed me of the ability to give birth to any more children, which has been the most devastating piece of it,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. The city Health Department said Friday it plans to publish a new report on cancer among   workers and survivors in September.  So far, scientists have found five cancers hitting the   community at a significantly higher rate than expected in the normal population  Ã¢ÂÂ   prostate, thyroid, leukemia, lymphoma and multiple myeloma.
Title: Diagnoses of 9/11-linked cancers have tripled in less than 3ÃÂ years

Content: When celebrity makeup artist Tim Quinn arrived at BostonÃ¢ÂÂs Mass General Hospital in 2007, he was too weak from testicular cancer to walk. But he managed to stay positive by thinking about how to beautify his surroundings  Ã¢ÂÂ   and himself. Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt think my doctors had encountered someone like me before,Ã¢ÂÂ says the Giorgio Armani Beauty face makeup designer, 49. Ã¢ÂÂI came in and redecorated the whole room  Ã¢ÂÂ   I brought my own sheets, and I brought my own lamps. Ã¢ÂÂ And, yes, he brought his own makeup. Quinn says he knew looking good was essential to healing himself  Ã¢ÂÂ   and making it through the day. Ã¢ÂÂThe thought of not being tan was terribly tragic, so I learned how to use bronzer and Ã¢ÂÂ he says. He also turned his hospital room into a mini   shop, doling out lipstick and makeup tips to fellow patients. At the Cancer Moonshot Summit on Wednesday, Vice President Joe Biden urged doctors and researchers to work together by sharing data and research to make 10 yearsÃ¢ÂÂ worth of progress against cancer in five. ItÃ¢ÂÂs an approach that Quinn  Ã¢ÂÂ   who attended the summit both as a friend of Jill Biden (he regularly does her makeup) and a cancer survivor  Ã¢ÂÂ   can vouch for. He credits sharing his own skill set of makeup and beauty knowledge with helping him get through his year of treatment. Ã¢ÂÂI had to step out of my life for a year, so setting up my little shop at Mass General [Hospital] took me out of my head, and I saw what it did for other patients,Ã¢ÂÂ Quinn says. Ã¢ÂÂPutting on a little eyebrow pencil and some color when youÃ¢ÂÂre dealing with [losing your hair, and a changing complexion] is amazing. Ã¢ÂÂ With his disease in remission for nearly eight years, Quinn is a cancer research advocate for several groups, including Look Good Feel Better and the American Cancer Society, and serves on the board of the Farrah Fawcett Foundation (Farrah was a friend, client, and source of inspiration for Quinn) and as part of the one hundred for Mass General. HeÃ¢ÂÂs proof, he says, that you donÃ¢ÂÂt need to be a doctor to help battle against cancer. Ã¢ÂÂDonÃ¢ÂÂt wait until you win a Nobel Laureate before you feel like you can do something,Ã¢ÂÂ Quinn says. Ã¢ÂÂAll you have to do is just jump in and start doing your bit to help. Ã¢ÂÂ He also heads back to Mass General to host an annual NursesÃ¢ÂÂ Appreciation Day. Ã¢ÂÂI bring in a team of [makeup artist] volunteers, and we treat it almost like a little mini red carpet event,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂSome of the nurses who come were my nurses, and now theyÃ¢ÂÂre family. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: How makeup helped me get throughÃÂ cancer

Content: Brooklyn District Attorney Ken Thompson died Sunday night,   sources told The Post. He was 50 years old. Ã¢ÂÂHe passed away around 6 oÃ¢ÂÂclock,Ã¢ÂÂ a source said. The DA had been battling a   form of colorectal cancer, another source close to Thompson said. The source did not know when exactly the diagnosis was made  Ã¢ÂÂ   but said Thompson had known for several months. Thompson revealed in a press release Tuesday that he had an Ã¢ÂÂaggressiveÃ¢ÂÂ form of the disease and had stepped down from the    running of his office. He took the job in 2014  Ã¢ÂÂ   becoming the boroughÃ¢ÂÂs first   district attorney  Ã¢ÂÂ   after defeating longtime incumbent Charles Hynes. Ã¢ÂÂWith a heavy heart, the family of Brooklyn District Attorney Ken Thompson announced that the District Attorney passed away today after a hard fought battle with cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ his office said in a statement Sunday night. Ã¢ÂÂThompson is survived by his wife of 17 years,   Thompson, his two children, Kennedy and Kenny, his mother, father, brother and sister. The family were by his side at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital at the time of his passing. Ã¢ÂÂ Sources told The Post last week that Thompson had been out of the office since May, acting Ã¢ÂÂextremely  Ã¢ÂÂ from his Brooklyn home while undergoing treatment at the same time. Ã¢ÂÂAs a man of intense faith, I intend to fight and win the battle against this disease,Ã¢ÂÂ he said in a statement Tuesday. Ã¢ÂÂI humbly seek your sincere prayers as I confront this challenge. Ã¢ÂÂ Thompson had been a federal prosecutor with the US attorney for the Eastern District of New York before he was elected in 2013. A source told The Post that his    Chief ADA Eric Gonzalez, will be taking over until next yearÃ¢ÂÂs election. Ã¢ÂÂThe executive team and I are committed to leading the Office and carrying out DA ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs vision and initiatives,Ã¢ÂÂ Gonzalez said in a statement Sunday night. Ã¢ÂÂHe was a giant among those seeking to reform the criminal justice system and we are all privileged to have worked under his transformative leadership these past three years. Ã¢ÂÂ Flags will be lowered to   on Monday to honor Thompson, according to officials. Ã¢ÂÂI am profoundly saddened to learn of the sudden passing of Brooklyn District Attorney Ken Thompson after a battle with cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ Gov. Andrew Cuomo said in a statement. Ã¢ÂÂKen was a dedicated public servant who embodied the highest principles of the law, and his grand presence will be sorely missed. Ã¢ÂÂ Several others offered their condolences Sunday, including Hynes  Ã¢ÂÂ   who served as DA for 23 years before losing to Thompson. Ã¢ÂÂI am praying for the Thompson family and IÃ¢ÂÂm hoping for the best for his widow and two young children,Ã¢ÂÂ he told The Post in a statement. ThompsonÃ¢ÂÂs former law partner, Douglas Wigdor, said: Ã¢ÂÂAs KenÃ¢ÂÂs former law partner and friend, I will cherish the time we spent together building our law firm, and although he has passed, I will personally make sure his legacy, hard work, and dedication to his family, former clients, and the people of Brooklyn are not forgotten. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Brooklyn DA Ken Thompson dies at 50 after battle withÃÂ cancer

Content: Killing cancer is the ultimate goal for many researchers, and theyÃ¢ÂÂre studying various ways of doing it. Some scientists are   that would kill tumor cells in a patient and stop cancer from spreading. Others are looking to edit genes to enhance the immune response of the organism and eliminate cancerous growth. A federal panel approved the latter type of proposed treatment, marking the first use of CRISPR in humans.   If CRISPR sounds familiar, thatÃ¢ÂÂs because we talked about this   technology before. As   it was widely expected that   would occur in 2017, in a clinical trial supposed to treat a rare form of blindness called  . However, a federal biosafety and ethics panel on Tuesday approved a   clinical trial that would see doctors from various centers treat certain types of cancer by editing immune cells. Proposed by physicians from the University of Pennsylvania, the experiment still needs approval from the medical centers where it would be conducted, and from the FDA. The trial would focus on patients with multiple myeloma, melanoma, and sarcoma, and would be funded by the Parker Institute for Cancer Immunotherapy, which was launched earlier this year by Sean Parker. The scientists plan to remove T cells (immune cells) that are in the first line of defense against foreign cells that make it inside the body, and then edit them so that they can target and kill cancerous cells. The genetic altering process of the T cells would ensure that the cells produce a Ã¢ÂÂchimeric antigen receptor,Ã¢ÂÂ or CAR, which would then bind to   protruding from tumor cells. This way, T cells would go after a specific type of cell, and only take out cancer. But for CAR to work, additional   is needed. CRISPR techniques will be used to slice out two genes in T cells. One gene is for   a molecule found on cancer cells that disable   when meeting them. The other is for endogenous TCR, T cellÃ¢ÂÂs natural receptors, as studies showed that removing the TCR results in better functioning. With   and TCR genes removed, T cells would be more efficient at fighting cancer, and they would have an increased persistence inside the human body. This new type of treatment, as exciting as it may be, also comes with some ethical side effects and conflicts of interest. For starters, we, as a species, are opening doors to something we havenÃ¢ÂÂt done before, playing with human genes. Secondly, the financial interests behind the success of such treatments are enormous, and the committee already spotted a conflict of interest in this matter that it wants to keep in check.
Title: WeÃ¢ÂÂre trying to cure cancer by editing ourÃÂ genes

Content: Frank Lalli, once a   editor of Money magazine, has snagged a book deal  Ã¢ÂÂ   estimated to be in the low six figures  Ã¢ÂÂ   from the Touchstone imprint of Simon & Schuster. LalliÃ¢ÂÂs upcoming effort will be about health care. Lalli began transforming himself from a financial journalist into a health care specialist when he was diagnosed with multiple myeloma five years ago. He has trademarked the phrase Ã¢ÂÂThe Health Care Detective. Ã¢ÂÂ The book, Ã¢ÂÂYour Best Health Care Now,Ã¢ÂÂ is due out Sept. 20. Lalli has plenty of   knowledge about the health care system. When he left Time and was still covered by its health insurance, the plan capped    prescription costs at $1, 000 a year. But shortly after he was diagnosed with the blood cancer  Ã¢ÂÂ   and was taking meds that cost $524 a day  Ã¢ÂÂ   he learned his insurance plan was changing. His meds would now coast him $132, 000 a year. The experience started a whole new career writing about health care. Last Sunday, in Parade magazineÃ¢ÂÂs cover story, Lalli wrote about a woman suffering from myeloma who was down to only 80 pounds before she was admitted to a University of Pennsylvania clinical study that used immunotherapy. Two years later, sheÃ¢ÂÂs miraculously cancer free. Ã¢ÂÂWe all know the health care system is a disaster  Ã¢ÂÂ   there have been a lot of books written about that,Ã¢ÂÂ said Lalli. Ã¢ÂÂMy book starts where those books end. Ã¢ÂÂ When his agent, Nat Sobel, finally sent the proposal to auction, four major publishers bid on the book, with TouchstoneÃ¢ÂÂs Michelle Howry scoring the winning bid.
Title: Longtime editor diagnosed with cancer lands health bookÃÂ deal

Content: Junk bonds genius Michael Milken spent Saturday at the Southampton home of investor Michael Loeb. Loeb, who is the son of former Fortune managing editor Marshall Loeb, hosted   types and tennis pros to help raise money for MilkenÃ¢ÂÂs Prostate Cancer Foundation. New YorkÃ¢ÂÂs best known names in finance hit the courts at LoebÃ¢ÂÂs house and around the Hamptons at the weekend. Tennis pros: Andrew Pavel, Rohan Bopanna and the Jensen brothers were on hand to face off against Wall StreetÃ¢ÂÂs hardest hitters as the US Open is scheduled to start on Monday. Washington Kastles owner Mark Ein of the World Team Tennis told On The Money he beat CantorÃ¢ÂÂs Howard Lutnik in a close match that ultimately ended in a   tie breaker. Not surprising Bill Ackman was particularly aggressive on the court, we heard. David Koch of Koch Industries also joined the lunch for the hungry athletes. Other supporters of MilkenÃ¢ÂÂs efforts included Marc Leder of Sun Capital, Ricky Sandler of Eminence Capital and Steve Roth of Vornado Realty. Milken chatted with On The Money but he wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be drawn on current economics or politics except to say he wants to see more funding headed towards cancer research and drug development. Milken70, is a prostate cancer survivor. Milken told us the Prostate Cancer Foundation has helped reduce the death rate through research and funding. Ã¢ÂÂMore than 99 percent are living 5 years or longer after the diagnosis,Ã¢ÂÂ Milken told The Post. Ã¢ÂÂThe number one ailment is prostate cancer in men,Ã¢ÂÂ he added. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre working to computerize records, to find out why do African Americans have a higher death rate than non African Americans?Ã¢ÂÂ Milken is working with Doctor Francis Collins, who cracked the genetic code, to find some answers.
Title: Investor hosts finance elite, tennis pros for cancerÃÂ fundraiser

Content: An English woman thought she just had a really bad hangover  Ã¢ÂÂ   but it turned out to be cancer. Hope Stringer, a    energy broker from Billericay, Essex, knew something was wrong when her left temple was throbbing and she was still feeling hung over a week after she went out drinking with her gal pals. Ã¢ÂÂI was tired for days after, but I thought it was just a hangover. The older IÃ¢ÂÂm getting, the worse they seem,Ã¢ÂÂ she told Caters News Agency. Her symptoms worsened over the next few months, prompting her to schedule an appointment with her general practitioner. Ã¢ÂÂI was told it was just a migraine and was prescribed painkillers, which didnÃ¢ÂÂt seem unusual as IÃ¢ÂÂd been working long hours at my job where IÃ¢ÂÂm constantly on the phone and on the computer,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂI know my body and I knew something wasnÃ¢ÂÂt right,Ã¢ÂÂ Stringer added. And when the pain just wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt go away, she finally got an MRI that revealed she had   sarcoma at just 23 years old. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂd been completely healthy up until that point and couldnÃ¢ÂÂt believe that what I originally thought was a hangover could be something so serious,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Doctors removed a cancerous tumor from StringerÃ¢ÂÂs neck and then she endured six rounds of chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Ã¢ÂÂI think I dealt with the news that I had cancer extremely well. I told my family the rules: There was to be no sadness or tears. I just wanted to remain positive and focus on getting better,Ã¢ÂÂ she told Caters. She even had a shaving party to get rid of her hair once it started falling out from the chemo treatments. But her fight wasnÃ¢ÂÂt over, as doctors found another tumor that forced them to remove a nerve in her throat in hopes of eradicating the deadly disease. Ã¢ÂÂWhen doctors told me theyÃ¢ÂÂd have to remove a vocal cord nerve as well, which would affect my speech, I didnÃ¢ÂÂt care at that stage,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂI just wanted the cancer gone. Ã¢ÂÂ And now that she is   Stringer is trying to educate people about the disease that nearly killed her. Ã¢ÂÂI want other people to be aware of the signs and symptoms and take action as soon as possible,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂIf I hadnÃ¢ÂÂt kept going back to the doctors, the outcome may be very different today. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Her hangover turned out to beÃÂ cancer

Content: ST. LOUIS  Ã¢ÂÂ   A jury in St. Louis has ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $55 million to a South Dakota woman who claimed the companyÃ¢ÂÂs talcum powder caused her to develop ovarian cancer. Court records show the jury returned the verdict in favor of plaintiff Gloria Ristesund on Monday. It comes after a   who sued Johnson & Johnson over ovarian cancer she said was caused by using its baby powder and other products containing talcum. A Johnson & Johnson spokeswoman says the New   company is beginning the process to appeal the Monday ruling. Spokeswoman Carol Goodrich says the decision goes against decades of research that supports the safety of cosmetic talc.
Title: $55M awarded in another Johnson & Johnson cancerÃÂ suit

Content: Three to four days a week, Philadelphia veterinarian Clint Kuban drops off his    German shepherd, Tsunami, at the   for her   shift. But the pooch isnÃ¢ÂÂt just participating in agility, obedience and search training  Ã¢ÂÂ   sheÃ¢ÂÂs also on the front lines of cancer research. Kuban is one of six   students at the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine followed in the new Animal Planet series Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ premiering Saturday at 10 p. m. Tsunami has worked on   since it launched in 2013 to study whether odors emanating from ovarian tissue can provide a reliable method for early detection. Using a Ã¢ÂÂscent wheelÃ¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ   a circular device with 12 ports used to introduce multiple sources of scent (  samples from cancer patients, benign growths and healthy controls, as well as other Ã¢ÂÂdistractorÃ¢ÂÂ scents)  Ã¢ÂÂ   researchers can isolate the exact volatile organic compounds that the dogs can smell. In these   to   smelling sessions, TsunamiÃ¢ÂÂs nose is more than 90 percent accurate in identifying malignancies. Ã¢ÂÂThere is no machine that is as powerful and as specific as what our dogs can do,Ã¢ÂÂ Kuban, 29, tells The Post. Ã¢ÂÂCanines smell up to 1, 000 times more accurately than humans, and they have up to 300 million olfactory receptors as opposed to [our] 6 million. Ã¢ÂÂBy narrowing it down and analyzing the volatile compounds that are being emitted by the samples, we can eventually reach the specific [odor] markers that we can screen for. Ã¢ÂÂ Tsunami and the two other dogs in the program  Ã¢ÂÂ   a    springer spaniel and a    yellow Labrador retriever  Ã¢ÂÂ   were selected for their precise hunt drive and specifically trained to identify the cancerous compounds, first in tumor samples and then just plasma samples, explains Dr. Cindy Otto, director of the Penn Vet Working Dog Center. The canine study is hoping to increase survival odds through early detection. Ovarian cancer is the   cause of cancer deaths among women in the US, according to the CDC. More than 80 percent of patients are diagnosed at a late stage, according to the Penn Vet Working Dog Center. Otto says researchers have successfully completed the first phase  Ã¢ÂÂ   determining that dogs can detect ovarian cancer  Ã¢ÂÂ   and the next phase will be to determine if dogs can detect it in samples from   cancer patients. The center is applying for a grant to fund a   plan to develop a screening tool (though it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt include Fido seeing patients in place of a local oncologist). Ã¢ÂÂBy isolating the chemicals of cancer that the dogs can smell, the team hopes to one day create an electronic sensor that can detect cancerous tissues early,Ã¢ÂÂ Kuban explains. Ã¢ÂÂThe end goal is actually not to have dogs in doctorÃ¢ÂÂs offices doing diagnoses. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: This dog is at the forefront of cancerÃÂ research

Content: White bachelors diagnosed with cancer wonÃ¢ÂÂt live as long as their married buddies  Ã¢ÂÂ   according to a new study that further proves that love really is the best medicine for fighting the disease. The study, published Monday in the journal Cancer, expanded on previous findings that married individuals diagnosed with invasive cancer live longer than those who are battling it on their own. Researchers found that while money didnÃ¢ÂÂt have an impact on longevity, race and gender did. White bachelors fared the worst with a death rate that was 27 percent higher than married men. Ã¢ÂÂCancer is a very scary thing and itÃ¢ÂÂs good to have someone by your side,Ã¢ÂÂ Scarlett Lin Gomez, one of the studyÃ¢ÂÂs authors and a researcher at the Cancer Prevention Institute of California,  . Ã¢ÂÂTreatments can drag on for months and months. It can be very difficult if youÃ¢ÂÂre single and you donÃ¢ÂÂt have any other means to get to the doctor. Ã¢ÂÂ White single ladies also had a 17 percent higher chance of dying than women who had a ring on it. Ã¢ÂÂWomen seek out help for health concerns more frequently than men, and women tend to remind spouses to see their physicians and live a healthy lifestyle,Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Maria Elena Martinez, the studyÃ¢ÂÂs lead author and a University of California, San Diego professor, told CNBC. Her team tracked the health records of nearly 800, 000 patients  Ã¢ÂÂ   393, 470 men and 389, 697 women  Ã¢ÂÂ   that were placed on the California Cancer Registry for four years. The research also revealed that those who were born outside the US had a better shot at living longer  Ã¢ÂÂ   something Martinez said she believes is connected to race. Ã¢ÂÂOur hypothesis is that   whites donÃ¢ÂÂt have the same social network as other cultures that have stronger bonds with family and friends outside of marriage,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂAs individuals acculturate, they tend to lose those bonds. And while there are a lot of benefits to marriage, Gomez said the studyÃ¢ÂÂs results donÃ¢ÂÂt mean people who arenÃ¢ÂÂt hitched should rush down the aisle. Ã¢ÂÂCertainly weÃ¢ÂÂre not advocating for getting married as a means to improve your outcome,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂBut single people can help themselves by maintaining stronger social networks and being able to rely on friends and family for help. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: You might be able to fight cancer Ã¢ÂÂ withÃÂ marriage

Content: Authentic voices and undiluted storiesBy Jonny Geller, The great thing about living through such a turbulent year as 2016 is that all bets are off in terms of what people will want to read in 2017. All we thought we knew about how people think, receive news and trust authority has changed. This must, and will, have a direct impact on what stories we want to read. Will it lead to more escapism? Or, conversely, will we seek complexity and disruption to make sense of the new order? After the first world war, modernism sprang up, and after 11 September there was an explosion of superhero franchise movies. Big moments in history are reflected back on us through our culture. Fear is always a good starting point. On television, Westworld, Humans and Mr Robot all showed up our fears of a world run by artificial intelligence or by computers out of control. Culture reflects our deepest fears, so I imagine publishing will be looking for worlds where our deepest desires, fears and impulses are released where repressed forces come to the fore. Publishing, like Hollywood, is intensely reactive. Something unlikely will become a success and then define the next wave. Dan Brown caught the wave of uncertainty post   with thrillers that linked us back to a mythical past, unlocking secrets to reveal more about who we thought we were. Gillian Flynn, Paula Hawkins and even EL James unlocked our darkest, most intimate feelings about our own domestic arrangements. I think the next big idea will be a move toward authentic voices and experiences. I think people will want undiluted stories that reflect their lives, experiences and emotions, unfiltered. I believe, too, that voices from outside the urban centres will push their way through the white,   wall of London publishing. Alongside this, there is also growing evidence of more hyperrealism, and satires being written of naturalism (similar to the wave in theatre in   century) where big issues will be explored in a recognisable setting. I am very excited by possibilities of 2017 as writers reflect the changes in narrative form. Jonny Geller is a writer, book agent and joint chief executive of Curtis Brown, the literary and talent agency. The rise of a northern Labour partyBy John Harris, A statement of the bleeding obvious, to start with. The Labour party is in a mess: apparently sliding towards the   in the polls, reeling from its poor showing in recent byelections, and riven by a split between supporters of Jeremy Corbyn and many Labour MPs. Most of all, it is spooked by what happened in the EU referendum, when most of its traditional Ã¢ÂÂcoreÃ¢ÂÂ areas voted for Brexit, highlighting both the cultural gap between the partyÃ¢ÂÂs supposed heartlands  Ã¢ÂÂ   south Wales and the north of England  Ã¢ÂÂ   and the potential threat to Labour from Ukip,   the Ã¢ÂÂpeopleÃ¢ÂÂs movementÃ¢ÂÂ that will be launched in the new year by the Brexit   Arron Banks. So far, this tension hasnÃ¢ÂÂt been reflected in any clear factional divides inside the party, but in 2017 that will change. In May, there will be a handful of elections for EnglandÃ¢ÂÂs new metropolitan mayors, including a contest in Greater Manchester. There, LabourÃ¢ÂÂs   candidate is the   leadership candidate Andy Burnham, who has decided to call time on his Westminster career and have a crack at leading a swath of the country with a population of 2. 8 million. And in the buildup to the campaign, with the tacit support of some MPs, he has come up with a new definition of what he wants to represent: Ã¢ÂÂNorthern LabourÃ¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ   which, he says, Ã¢ÂÂneeds to speak very directly to people and represent them properly in terms of the way [they] think and feelÃ¢ÂÂ. This does not take much decoding. While Corbyn and his inner circle have rejected any calls for Labour to sound tougher on immigration, Burnham has been on manoeuvres, controversially claiming that LabourÃ¢ÂÂs stance is undermining Ã¢ÂÂthe safety of our streetsÃ¢ÂÂ and the vote to leave the EU was partly about Ã¢ÂÂmore control in our immigration systemÃ¢ÂÂ. What he and his allies are aiming at is pretty clear: an offshoot of the Labour party that will try to reconnect with its lost territories, will often speak with a     voice and brazenly position itself against London. How this will sit with a cosmopolitan,   city such as Manchester remains unclear. But be in no doubt: in contrast to the Corbyn version, a different vision of LabourÃ¢ÂÂs future is about to take root 200 miles from the capital, with big political consequences. John Harris is a journalist and author who writes for the Guardian about politics, popular culture and music. All hail Statue of Liberty greenBy Jess   We have passed peak avocado, but the colour wheel has not spun far. The shade of 2017 will be Statue of Liberty green. The colour came into focus in September, when the New Yorker ran a lyrical piece in praise of New York CityÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂsecret, sustaining colourÃ¢ÂÂ. Soon, the colour was everywhere: in the     dress that opened the Emilia Wickstead show at London fashion week painted on the walls at the JW Anderson show. In naming the   Ã¢ÂÂgreeneryÃ¢ÂÂ its symbolic colour of 2017, Pantone championed the power of green Ã¢ÂÂto provide us with the reassurance we yearn for amid a tumultuous social and political environmentÃ¢ÂÂ. In nature, green represents hope and renewal. Our green, however, is a touch more complicated. At a time when US politics has become larger than life, breaking out of its Washington bubble to touch every part of popular culture, Statue of Liberty green is a political colour. That the copper statue had turned from brown to green within 20 years of its unveiling in 1886 means that this colour stands for change and the unstoppability of decay. So, while the symbol is everywhere  Ã¢ÂÂ   the Starbucks logo, if you ask me, although they are coy about it  Ã¢ÂÂ   it can stand for despair as well as pride. In the aftermath of NovemberÃ¢ÂÂs election, a crying Statue of Liberty, and riffs on the Planet of the Apes image of the statue   in the sand, became popular   memes on social media. Statue of Liberty green is a colour that no one planned  Ã¢ÂÂ   indeed, when the oxidisation process became evident, politicians argued over whether a paint job was called for  Ã¢ÂÂ   and that changed our landscape. It is the colour of endurance and of change. It stands for Ã¢ÂÂAmerican valuesÃ¢ÂÂ and for liberal ones. (The inscription on the pedestal, after all, includes the lines: Ã¢ÂÂGive me your tired, your poor   Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free. Ã¢ÂÂ) It is a colour nobody saw coming, and one that represents conflicting views. What could be more 2017? Jess   is the GuardianÃ¢ÂÂs associate editor, fashion. Immunology brings successes and sobering newsBy Siddhartha Mukherjee, Can the human body be taught to reject cancer cells? The biggest idea in cancer this year  Ã¢ÂÂ   and perhaps the most exhilarating idea in all of medicine  Ã¢ÂÂ   was that a dormant immune system could be roused to attack cancer. It is an idea with a tortured history. In the 1890s, William Coley, a New York scientist and surgeon, had proposed injecting cancer patients with a mixture of bacterial toxins (called ColeyÃ¢ÂÂs toxins) to elicit an immune response that would attack cancer cells. But ColeyÃ¢ÂÂs initial results were hard to interpret and reproduce, and enthusiasm for the toxins waned. When I began to study immunology at Oxford in the 1990s, the field of cancer immunology was, frankly, languishing in neglect. In the late 90s, however, the discipline took a surprising turn: scientists working on the immune system (led, particularly, by the visionary immunologist James Allison) began to discover that some tumour cells expressed specific factors to inactivate the immune system or render themselves invisible to immune cells. These invisibility proteins offered an opportunity for a  : specific factors were created to inactivate these cloaking signals so that tumours would become visible again. The first such drugs were deployed against melanomas, and some patients showed durable responses, albeit with severe  . Since those initial trials, dozens of strategies to activate the immune system have been discovered, and fleets of new immunomodulatory drugs have appeared in the clinic. In another twist on the same theme, a patientÃ¢ÂÂs own immune cells were brought out of the body, manipulated with gene therapy to arm them to attack cancer cells, and reintroduced to the patient. These cells grow in the body once reintroduced, making them exemplars of a new generation of Ã¢ÂÂliving drugsÃ¢ÂÂ as Michel Sadelain, one of the pioneers of this strategy, has described them. Immunotherapy for cancer has had some sentinel successes  Ã¢ÂÂ   notably against melanoma, lung cancer, lymphomas and some leukemias. But this year also brought sobering news about unexpected   of these drugs: patients suffered inexplicable fevers or   colitis. Broader questions about efficacy and cost remain. Are these drugs going to be useful to treat only a small fraction of tumours? How much will they cost  Ã¢ÂÂ   and can that be contained? One strange effect of immunotherapy is that tumours can often swell and become larger during the early course of treatment, as immune cells infiltrate the tumours and create inflammation. For decades, the traditional metric to judge tumour responsiveness was to measure the size of the tumour  Ã¢ÂÂ   yet here the cancers seemed to grow before some of them finally responded to the therapy. Will traditional metrics of tumour responsiveness need to be   with immunotherapy? How will we understand why and when these cancers relapse  Ã¢ÂÂ   and can the immune system be retrained, over and over, to attack such perennially evolving cancers? Siddhartha Mukherjee is an assistant professor of medicine at Columbia University and the Pulitzer   author of books including The Gene and The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer. The rise of regional bistro cultureBy Angela Hartnett, London is not the centre of the universe any more, and what we are seeing and  Ã¢ÂÂ   I hope  Ã¢ÂÂ   will continue to see is more chefs moving out of the city and encouraging the growth of local restaurants, which can have positive effects on places and communities, and which increase access to good, affordable food. Gary Usher has done this really well with Sticky Walnut in Chester. Then, he crowdfunded the next two  Ã¢ÂÂ   Burnt Truffle on the Wirral and now Hispi in south Manchester. They are affordable little bistros that do really well. Mitch Tonks is doing it brilliantly, too. He started with The Seahorse in Dartmouth and has opened Rockfish restaurants in seaside towns. And if someone starts it off, other things happen  Ã¢ÂÂ   so thereÃ¢ÂÂs now a crab festival and a food festival in Dartmouth. It happened in Abergavenny, too, starting with the Walnut Tree. We should have affordable restaurants throughout the country. But to make a restaurant work as a business, you have to be busy on a wet Tuesday night, not just twice a week. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs hard to do, but with a bit of effort and imagination, it is possible. Angela Hartnett is a chef and   at Murano, her   restaurant in London. A new ideological spectrum By Chris Anderson, We have just ended a year of political shock. Thanks to Brexit and Trump, the comfy consensus around an   global,   world delivering bounty to all has been blown up. And the old political   spectrum has been replaced by a new spectrum. Some would sneeringly call it that of tribal v global, xenophobic v embracing, backward v forward. But there is a more generous, more productive, framing: protect v connect. From that standpoint, the mistake made by the   status quo these past years has been that in rushing towards an   connected world, we failed to protect. We let millions of people come to fear the loss of their jobs, their dreams, and the cultural norms with which they were familiar. And in the process, aided by an    social media landscape, we have become disgusted by each other. We urgently need new ways to find common ground and recreate a vision for the future worth pursuing. The jolt has been dramatic enough that it has sparked numerous ideas to help achieve this. At a minimum, itÃ¢ÂÂs going to take: Ã¢ÂÂ¾ An assault on fake news. The knowledge era needs knowledge, not clickbait. Look for new,   systems that tap into crowd wisdom, not    . Ã¢ÂÂ¾ A vision for the future of meaningful work for humans in a world filled by increasingly intelligent agents. Ã¢ÂÂ¾ Education reforms that prepare our kids to thrive in that future. Ã¢ÂÂ¾ New economic ideas, such as universal basic income. Ã¢ÂÂ¾ A new articulation of globalist thinking. It should not be driven by faceless global elites, but by individuals connecting with each other across the planet and discovering just how much we can learn from each other. Once we can start listening to each other again, there is a real discussion to be had on how we avoid sleepwalking into a future that humanity canÃ¢ÂÂt handle. We want to be amazed and delighted. But not to lose our souls in the process. LetÃ¢ÂÂs get that conversation rebooted! Chris Anderson is a former technology publisher and the owner of TED (technology, entertainment, design) the global conference and media initiative. An app to record abuse anonymouslyBy Helena Kennedy, I   the International Bar AssociationÃ¢ÂÂs Institute of Human Rights, which champions the rule of law and human rights around the world. Next year, we shall launch a fabulous new tool that will help in the pursuit of justice for breaches of human rights. It will make it possible, for those who witness horrifying events, to film and document them and then send them to an archive for use as evidence in trials. The phone app, for which the IBA director, Mark Ellis, found the funding, will allow people to film ghastly stuff and then send the footage directly to a repository. The time and location coordinates of filming will be attached at the time, helping to later validate the film. The immediate depositing of the film means there can be no accusations of tampering or editing. A second tap of the app will remove the film from the phone that was used to make the recording, so that the owner cannot be caught in possession of incriminating material. This development came as a result of people sending anonymous film to news outlets without authentication of place and time and proof of   the IBA has been struggling with the issue of admissibility of such evidence in a court of law. This will be an exciting development that will help prove that abuses happen all too often. Another sign of hope for 2017: people are sensibly talking about the creation of progressive alliances to combat the ghastly politics of this government. We should all see that this is the way to go. Helena Kennedy is a QC and member of the House of Lords. Gene editing brings a world of extraordinary possibilitiesBy Henry Marsh, I wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be so bold as to predict any immediate big breakthroughs in medical neuroscience, but in an increasingly depressing and frightening world, I derive great pleasure, solace and a sense of wonder from the constant advance of science. One of the great things about science is that it turns up ideas and solutions that are novel, and sometimes unexpected  Ã¢ÂÂ   and I find that spiritually uplifting in a very worrying world politically, socially and environmentally. Who would have thought that ParkinsonÃ¢ÂÂs disease is probably caused by gut bacteria, or that a feathered dinosaur tail would be found in a piece of amber, preserved for 99m years? These are both recent discoveries. Then there are the extraordinary opportunities that Crispr   technology has opened and the potential for it to help us defeat a whole range of incurable illnesses. Of course, what is desperately needed is an effective cure or prevention for AlzheimerÃ¢ÂÂs, and a lot of people are working extremely hard on that. I think a lot of   struggle to understand that there is a deep spiritual and mystical element to science, just as there is in mathematics. A good mathematical proof is elegant, an object of aesthetic beauty that appeals to a deep level of the psyche. The idea of a division between the emotional and the rational is totally false. Doctors think with feelings rather than in terms of pure abstract, dispassionate processes we are not calculating machines. This helps because it helps fuel progress in science, which is unstoppable   and it has to be. I donÃ¢ÂÂt want to be   about it, but I think we have to be positive about the future because if weÃ¢ÂÂre not, bad things will certainly happen. If we think the future is bound to be awful, we wonÃ¢ÂÂt do anything about it. We have to think positively and act positively rather than be carried away with despair.
