Following that bold, hilarious opening sequence, Kelly backtracks a year to trace the gruelling months that led to such an uncomfortable scenario.  Breaking BadÃ¢ÂÂs Jesse Plemons is cast against type as David, a gay comedy writer who relocates from New York City to Sacramento to help his ailing mother, Joanne (Molly Shannon) and lend emotional support to his conservative father (Bradley Whitford) and two sisters (Maude Apatow and Madisen Beaty). David arrives in Sacramento defeated: on top of the news of his motherÃ¢ÂÂs diagnosis, the TV pilot he had high hopes for didnÃ¢ÂÂt get picked up, and he recently split from his boyfriend of five years (Zach Woods). In an effort to keep his motherÃ¢ÂÂs spirits afloat, he pretends to still be in a relationship.  JoanneÃ¢ÂÂs sunny demeanour begins to dissipate as her cancer spreads. To make the most of her last months with her family, she quits chemotherapy  Ã¢ÂÂ   a difficult decision we see in a powerhouse sequence which has Joanne grappling with her mortality alongside her husband in a hospital room. In the corridor outside, her children tearfully listen.  The laughs in Other People come in spurts, often cued by the jarring rhythms of Patrick ColmanÃ¢ÂÂs editing, as well as JoanneÃ¢ÂÂs mordant resignation. When asked by her husband over milkshakes if sheÃ¢ÂÂd like to be cremated, Joanne drolly says sheÃ¢ÂÂd like to be frozen instead: Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt like camping   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     and I donÃ¢ÂÂt like fire. Ã¢ÂÂ Also contributing chuckles are DavidÃ¢ÂÂs grandfather (Paul Dooley) prone to oversharing no matter how uncomfortable the memory, and Justin (JJ Totah) the adopted little brother of DavidÃ¢ÂÂs close friend. The child actor, best known for a short run on Glee, comes close to stealing the movie as a fiercely effeminate,   kid, whose sass lifts DavidÃ¢ÂÂs spirits.  Yet itÃ¢ÂÂs Shannon who leaves the most lasting impression. Another Saturday Night Live veteran, she effortlessly mines the material for all its uncomfortable laughs (Plemons on the other hand plays David a bit too introverted to be fully persuasive as a joke factory). Shannon shows new shades in her deft handling of a tragedy sheÃ¢ÂÂs tasked with bearing. Further proof that when it comes to drama, comedy actors are often the experts.
Title: Other People review: cancer comedy lets Molly Shannon wring all types of tears

Content: IÃ¢ÂÂve known for years that my paternal grandmother died of colon cancer in her early 40s. But I didnÃ¢ÂÂt think it had too much to do with me, beyond being a very sad fact in our family history and inspiring a lot of intense  Ã¢ÂÂ   and embarrassing  Ã¢ÂÂ   conversations about how much fiber we were eating. It wasnÃ¢ÂÂt until nearly 50 years after her death that my family learned that the cause of my grandmotherÃ¢ÂÂs cancer was Lynch syndrome, a genetic condition that carries not just a high risk of colon cancer, but endometrial cancer, ovarian cancer and skin cancer. Others, as well. We learned about my grandmotherÃ¢ÂÂs Lynch syndrome when my father was diagnosed with it six years ago: he had a skin cancer that was typical of Lynch. He had other risk factors, too: he fit the Amsterdam Criteria, which were developed by doctors in 1990 to help to identify families with Lynch. My grandmother died four years before the syndrome was identified at all.  When my dad called me on Skype to tell me the news, he was in Baltimore, and I was living in London. Ã¢ÂÂYou should get tested for this,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. I said OK, but I didnÃ¢ÂÂt do it. I was afraid. My two siblings, an older brother and a younger sister, quickly took the test. With Lynch syndrome you have a 50% chance of carrying the gene if one of your parents does. Neither of my siblings had it. When I think about the many reasons that I didnÃ¢ÂÂt get tested, I have to admit that among them was the fact that I didnÃ¢ÂÂt believe that our family could be so lucky that all three of us had escaped, even though I believe in science over luck.  I blamed administrative issues when my family asked me why I hadnÃ¢ÂÂt had the test. Lynch is rare enough that I assumed it wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be straightforward to arrange for the testing on BritainÃ¢ÂÂs National Health Service (that said, I never tried).   there was a possibility that testing positive would affect my ability to get health insurance when I moved back to the US.   I moved to Berlin, where I had one unsuccessful phone call with a genetics institute  Ã¢ÂÂ   I didnÃ¢ÂÂt know how to say Ã¢ÂÂcolon cancerÃ¢ÂÂ auf Deutsch. Too difficult, I concluded. Another reason that I didnÃ¢ÂÂt get the test  Ã¢ÂÂ   a simple blood draw  Ã¢ÂÂ   is that I was single. Prophylactic hysterectomy is the recommended treatment for women with Lynch syndrome because of the high risk of gynecological cancers. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre hard to catch early and difficult to treat. Being unpartnered in my early thirties hadnÃ¢ÂÂt troubled me too much: I was happy to wait for the right person. But now on first dates IÃ¢ÂÂd look across the rim of my pinot grigio at some man who was mostly a stranger and wonder, Ã¢ÂÂAm I going to have to tell you about the likelihood of my early surgical menopause?Ã¢ÂÂ In the spring of 2012, my father, who never smoked a thing, was diagnosed with advanced lung cancer. The tumor carried the markers of Lynch syndrome  Ã¢ÂÂ   unusual, but not unheard of. On one of my last visits home, we went to Staples together. By then it was painful for him to walk, and he looked lost in the folds of a coat heÃ¢ÂÂd worn every winter for a decade.  Before getting out of the car we sat for a moment. Ã¢ÂÂYou should get tested,Ã¢ÂÂ he said, and I stared hard through the windscreen at the big grey parking lot and said: Ã¢ÂÂYes, Dad, I know. Ã¢ÂÂ But I didnÃ¢ÂÂt intend to do it as long as he was alive. I was scared IÃ¢ÂÂd have to tell my father that I carried the same gene that had caused the cancer that was killing him. After he died at the beginning of 2014, six weeks after I moved back to the US to be near him and my mother, it felt like the biggest reason I had been avoiding the test was gone. Losing my dad was the worst thing that had ever happened to me, and IÃ¢ÂÂd survived. Getting tested, I decided, could not be worse. Lynch syndrome is bad, but it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt have to be fatal: my mother pointed out that my   had it and died in her   from something else altogether. And getting tested was what my dad wanted me to do. I gave up a vial of blood and went on vacation while I waited to hear I felt a kind of relief that IÃ¢ÂÂd finally taken responsibility for my health. This was followed by a feeling of crippling regret. After I got the news, I felt for a time an intense and bleak terror about my future that was far worse than the fear IÃ¢ÂÂd had of taking the test. But in time, I started to feel better. IÃ¢ÂÂd lived with the gene since the day I was born. Now I knew that if I took precautions, my life expectancy would be normal. IÃ¢ÂÂm fortunate to have access to doctors who are enthusiastic about the project of monitoring my health: nothing is perfect, but there are many tests I can take to help identify cancer in its earliest stages.  Surgery is in my future, but several years away. I canÃ¢ÂÂt tell anyone else who is facing the decision to be tested for susceptibility to a disease what the right choice is for them. I can only say that IÃ¢ÂÂm glad that I did it.
Title: Facing my fear: did I have the cancer mutation that killed my dad?

Content: The World Health Organisation has cleared coffee of causing cancer, but a detailed investigation has found that very hot drinks may be linked to cancer of the oesophagus, or gullet. Coffee was classified as a possible cause of cancer in 1991, but the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) which is part of WHO, has now reconsidered the evidence. It carried out a detailed review of the many studies published on the subject and found that coffee drinkers have no reason to worry. IARC also investigated the herbal drink mate, also known as chimarrÃÂ£o or cimarrÃÂ³n, which is widely consumed in South America, where oesophageal cancer is more common than in other parts of the world.  The experts found that mate was not a cause of cancer, but they believe the temperature at which it is drunk probably is  Ã¢ÂÂ   and that other very hot drinks could also be linked to oesophageal cancer. Mate is drunk at temperatures of more than 65C (149F) often through a metal straw. The scientists also looked at drinks including tea consumed at high temperatures in central Asia, China and Japan. Ã¢ÂÂIt is consumed very hot,Ã¢ÂÂ said IARCÃ¢ÂÂs Dr Dana Loomis. Ã¢ÂÂThis led to interest in other hot drinks around the world. There seems to be an effect of temperature. Ã¢ÂÂThere is limited evidence in human studies, and limited evidence in animal studies, for the carcinogenicity of very hot drinks,Ã¢ÂÂ said Loomis. IARC produces what it calls monographs on the causes of cancer, which use classifications from group one, where the link is definite, as with smoking to group four, where there is probably no link.  The new monograph classifies hot drinks as group 2A, meaning they are Ã¢ÂÂprobably carcinogenic to humansÃ¢ÂÂ. Coffee and mate served cold are in group three, which means there is insufficient evidence to believe they cause cancer. IARCÃ¢ÂÂs conclusions are published in the Lancet Oncology journal. Those who enjoy hot tea in Europe and the US probably do not need to worry, Loomis said. Ã¢ÂÂIt is important to recognise that hot drinks that were studied for the basis of this classification are perhaps a bit different from tea or coffee as consumed [in other parts of the world]  Ã¢ÂÂ   65C is quite hot. Ã¢ÂÂ In European countries, coffee and tea are usually drunk at below 60C, he said, and milk is often added, which cools it. Tea in Iran and mate in South America are often drunk at 70C. Ã¢ÂÂMate is not only prepared very hot, but drunk through a metal straw that delivers it directly into the throat,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Studies in animals have shown that very hot water can promote the growth of tumours. Ã¢ÂÂIt appears that there is thermal injury from exposure to hot liquids that is capable of leading to cancer of the oesophagus,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. IARCÃ¢ÂÂs classifications relate to the strength of the evidence for a causal association, rather than the frequency with which something causes cancer. This is why tobacco, which increases the risk of cancer   is in the same group as UV rays from sunbeds, which increase the risk of skin cancer  . The scientists found an inverse relationship between drinking coffee and certain types of cancer. The risk of developing liver cancer dropped by 15% for each cup of coffee drunk, while in breast cancer and endometrial   womb   cancer studies suggest there were fewer incidences among people who drank coffee than those who did not. Other factors could be responsible, however, and IARC does not consider that drinking coffee protects people from cancer.
Title: Very hot drinks may cause cancer, but coffee does not, says WHO

Content: Bob and Linda Carey arenÃ¢ÂÂt your usual couple. The New York   photographer and producer, respectively, march to the beat of their own drum. Ã¢ÂÂI have no problem being weird,Ã¢ÂÂ Linda says. Fourteen years ago, Bob had an idea to photograph himself in a pink tutu. It was a private endeavor that allowed him to express his feelings and blow off some steam. But when Linda was diagnosed with breast cancer a few months later, the project took on a whole new purpose. Listen to the CareysÃ¢ÂÂ inspiring story. For more on the Tutu Project, click here. This content is paid for by Principal
Title: Progress Personified: this couple is fighting breast cancer in an unorthodox way

Content: A    girl who said before dying of cancer that she wanted a chance to live longer has been allowed by the high court to have her body cryogenically frozen in the hope that she can be brought back to life at a later time. The court ruled that the teenagerÃ¢ÂÂs mother, who supported the girlÃ¢ÂÂs wish to be cryogenically preserved, should be the only person allowed to make decisions about the disposal of her body. Her estranged father had initially opposed her wishes. During the last months of her life, the teenager, who had a rare form of cancer, used the internet to investigate cryonics. Known only as JS, she sent a letter to the court: Ã¢ÂÂI have been asked to explain why I want this unusual thing done. IÃ¢ÂÂm only 14 years old and I donÃ¢ÂÂt want to die, but I know I am going to. I think being cryoÃ¢ÂÂpreserved gives me a chance to be cured and woken up, even in hundreds of yearsÃ¢ÂÂ time.  Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt want to be buried underground. I want to live and live longer and I think that in the future they might find a cure for my cancer and wake me up. I want to have this chance. This is my wish. Ã¢ÂÂ Following the ruling, in a case described by the judge as exceptional, the body of JS has now been preserved and transported from where she lived in London to the US, where it has been frozen Ã¢ÂÂin perpetuityÃ¢ÂÂ by a commercial company at a cost of ÃÂ£37, 000. The girlÃ¢ÂÂs parents are divorced. She had lived with her mother for most of her life and had had no    contact with her father since 2008. She resisted his attempts to get back in touch when he learnt of her illness in 2015.  The judge, Mr Justice Peter Jackson, ruled that nothing about the case should be reported while she was alive because media coverage would distress her. She was too ill to attend the court hearing but the judge visited her in hospital.  Jackson wrote: Ã¢ÂÂI was moved by the valiant way in which she was facing her predicament. It is no surprise that this application is the only one of its kind to have come before the courts in this country, and probably anywhere else. It is an example of the new questions that science poses to the law, perhaps most of all to family law   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     No other parent has ever been put in [the] position [of JSÃ¢ÂÂs father]. Ã¢ÂÂ He added: Ã¢ÂÂA dispute about a parent being able to see his child after death would be momentous enough on its own if the case did not also raise the issue of cryonic preservation. Ã¢ÂÂ Since the first preservation by freezing in the 1960s the process has been performed only a few hundred times. The body has to be prepared shortly after death, ideally within minutes. Arrangements then have to be made for the body to be transported by a registered funeral director. Ã¢ÂÂThe scientific theory underlying cryonics is speculative and controversial, and there is considerable debate about its ethical implications,Ã¢ÂÂ Jackson said. Ã¢ÂÂOn the other hand, cryopreservation, the preservation of cells and tissues by freezing, is now a   process in certain branches of medicine, for example the preservation of sperm and embryos as part of fertility treatment. Cryonics is cryopreservation taken to its extreme. Ã¢ÂÂ  The judge said the girlÃ¢ÂÂs family was not well off but that her motherÃ¢ÂÂs parents had raised the money. A voluntary UK group of cryonics enthusiasts, who were not medically trained, had offered to help make arrangements.    of a hospital was required. Ã¢ÂÂThis situation gives rise to serious legal and ethical issues for the hospital trust,Ã¢ÂÂ the judge observed, Ã¢ÂÂwhich has to act within the law and has duties to its other patients and to its staff. Ã¢ÂÂ  The hospital trust in the case was willing to help although it stressed it was not endorsing cryonics. Ã¢ÂÂOn the contrary, all the professionals feel deep unease about it,Ã¢ÂÂ the judge said. The Human Tissue Authority (HTA) which regulates organisations which remove, store and use human tissue, had been consulted but said it had no remit to intervene in such a case. Ã¢ÂÂThe HTA would be likely to make representations that activities of the present kind should be brought within the regulatory framework if they showed signs of increasing,Ã¢ÂÂ Jackson said.  The HTA said: Ã¢ÂÂWe are gathering information about cryopreservation to determine how widespread it is currently, or could become in the future, and any risks it may pose to the individual, or public confidence more broadly. We are in discussion with key stakeholders   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     and the possible need for regulatory oversight. Ã¢ÂÂ The government may need to intervene in future, Jackson said: Ã¢ÂÂIt may be   Ã¢ÂÂ¦     events in this case suggest the need for proper regulation of cryonic preservation in this country if it is to happen in future. Ã¢ÂÂ Inquiries made of American authorities revealed that there was no prohibition on human remains being shipped to the US for cryonic preservation, providing certain provisions were made. During the course of the   Ã¢ÂÂs case, the father changed his mind and told the court: Ã¢ÂÂI respect the decisions [my daughter] is making. This is the last and only thing she has asked from me. Ã¢ÂÂ  A child cannot make a will and the court had to decide where the girlÃ¢ÂÂs best interests lay. The judge concluded that allowing the mother to make a decision about her daughter would be in her best interests. The girl died peacefully knowing that her body would be frozen, the judge recorded. The Department of Health said: Ã¢ÂÂCases such as this are rare. Although there are no current plans for legislative change in this area, this is an area we will continue to keep under review with the Human Tissue Authority.
Title: 14-year-old girl who died of cancer wins right to be cryogenically frozen

Content: A new drug that Ã¢ÂÂwakes upÃ¢ÂÂ the immune system to attack cancer has extended the lives of people with metastatic pancreatic cancer and has no   raising hopes for a new and powerful tool against the most intractable form of the disease. The drug,   is considered groundbreaking because pancreatic cancer that has spread to other parts of the body usually kills within a few months. Unlike other immunotherapy treatments,   is not thought to have any   which have been hugely debilitating for many patients and even led to   disability in some cases.  The patients who were given the new immunotherapy drug actually felt better than those who were on standard chemotherapy, said Angus Dalgleish, professor of oncology at St GeorgeÃ¢ÂÂs, University of London, who led the research. Dalgleish is excited by the potential of the immunotherapy drug, although the trial is relatively small, involving 110 people. Only 18% of patients with advanced pancreatic cancer are alive after one year and 4% after five years, so new treatments for the disease are badly needed. Ã¢ÂÂTo me itÃ¢ÂÂs really exciting,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dalgleish. Ã¢ÂÂThis is the first time we have got an immunotherapy that is a really good candidate to help control pancreatic cancer, which is one of the biggest killing diseases. Its incidence nearly matches its mortality. It is absolutely staggering. Ã¢ÂÂ Most importantly, the drug worked on the immune system without any toxic effects. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs never been seen before,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂYou always add toxicity and misery in my experience with each additional thing you put in. Ã¢ÂÂ Adding   to the standard chemotherapy drug patients receive, gemcitabine, did not benefit those patients whose pancreatic cancer had spread locally, but it improved the lifespan of those whose cancer was metastatic  Ã¢ÂÂ   it had progressed into other parts of the body  Ã¢ÂÂ   and would be expected to die quickly.  The results are published in the British Journal of Cancer. Most of the patients  Ã¢ÂÂ   85%  Ã¢ÂÂ   had metastatic disease. Those who were just given the standard chemotherapy drug survived for a median of 4. 4 months, but those who had the   immunotherapy drug as well survived for seven months. But some lived for more than a year and one died after nearly three years. Immunotherapy drugs have produced exciting results in skin and lung cancer, but not in pancreatic tumours, which are Ã¢ÂÂvery deep and very shieldedÃ¢ÂÂ from their effects, said Dalgleish.      the immune system that the cancer has effectively switched off. Pancreatic tumours have an outer shell of cells which act like a shield.   activates the immune system, enabling it to recognise and target the tumour so that the chemotherapy drug can work. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs rather like   the immune system which has been sent to sleep,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dalgleish. It is very different in its mode of operation from the checkpoint inhibitors, which turn on the immune system in a way that causes it to kill cancer cells but often attack healthy tissue too. It is also given by a simple injection and is far cheaper than the checkpoint inhibitors.  Dalgleish says the immunotherapy drug could have uses in a wide variety of cancers. He carried out an earlier study using   which contains a killed bacterium, on skin cancer patients. Ã¢ÂÂIn my melanoma patients in particular, patients have shown greatly increased survival rates and enjoy a much better quality of life. In some patients IÃ¢ÂÂve actually seen the cancer disappearing altogether,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. The overall survival benefit, however  Ã¢ÂÂ   adding in all of the 110 patients  Ã¢ÂÂ   was not significant. Those who had   survived a median of 6. 7 months compared with 5. 6 months for those just on chemotherapy. That was because those patients in the pancreatic cancer trial who had locally advanced disease  Ã¢ÂÂ   18 out of the total of 110  Ã¢ÂÂ   appeared to do better without the immunotherapy drug. Survival was a median of 6. 7 months with   and 9. 2 months without it. Those numbers are small, which makes it hard to conclude anything from them, but Dalgleish says metastatic cancer is in effect a different disease. A new and bigger trial is being planned which will include only patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer. The study was supported by the Institute for Cancer Vaccines and Immunotherapy from the earliest stages. Harry Cotterell, chair of trustees, said: Ã¢ÂÂThese are exciting results and support our hope that immunotherapy will in future become a generally accepted treatment for a wide range of cancers, improving both survival rates and quality of life. Ã¢ÂÂ Other cancer experts welcomed the development of an immunotherapy drug without   but pointed to the absence of a definitive overall survival benefit for all patients. Dr Justine Alford, Cancer Research UKÃ¢ÂÂs senior science information officer, said: Ã¢ÂÂWhile the results of this early trial didnÃ¢ÂÂt show whether combining the immunotherapy drug with standard chemotherapy actually improved survival, they showed the combination treatment was safe and might help some patients. Further research with more patients is needed to develop therapies that can improve survival. Pancreatic cancer is difficult to treat and survival still remains low, which is why new treatments are urgently needed. Ã¢ÂÂ Kevin Harrington, professor of biological cancer therapies at the Institute of Cancer Research in London, and a consultant at the Royal Marsden, said: Ã¢ÂÂThis looks like a very interesting approach. It is different. It appears to be extremely   and it has led to something that looks interesting in terms of survival but it hasnÃ¢ÂÂt quite got there. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: New drug Ã¢ÂÂwakes upÃ¢ÂÂ immune system to fight one of deadliest cancers

Content: Scientists believe they may have found a way to treat a rare but devastating cancer that kills young children often within months of their diagnosis. There is currently no treatment for malignant rhabdoid tumours, which usually develop in the kidneys and have no symptoms in the early stages. By the time they are diagnosed, the cancer has often spread to other organs and is fatal. Most of those affected are infants and toddlers. The mutated gene that causes the cancer is well known, but scientists have not been able to find a way to target it. However, scientists working for the Institute of Cancer Research (ICR) believe they have a made a breakthrough. They have now identified two other genes that appear to be implicated in driving the growth of the tumour, which produce proteins that can be inhibited by drugs that are already in use in other cancers or are in the development pipeline. Prof Paul Huang, team leader of the protein networks laboratory at the ICR, says they have found Ã¢ÂÂa chink in the armourÃ¢ÂÂ of these very aggressive tumours, using drugs that attack proteins known as kinase inhibitors.   Ã¢ÂÂThere are a lot of kinase drugs out there, so we donÃ¢ÂÂt have to   the wheel,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂIn many cases in drug discovery you find a new target and spend 10 to 20 years developing drugs against it. Ã¢ÂÂ  In this case, they hope that will not be necessary . Ã¢ÂÂWe have been able to   existing drugs, some of which are already approved. Ã¢ÂÂ So far, the drugs have been tested against cancer cells in the laboratory. The scientists, who have published their results in the journal Cell Reports, found that inhibiting proteins produced by one of the genes had little effect, but attacking both of them killed the cancer cells. The drugs pazopanib, dasatinib and sunitinib were all successful at inhibiting the protein from the PDGFRA gene  Ã¢ÂÂ   but if high levels of protein from the other gene, called FGFR1, remained, the cancer returned and would not respond to treatment even at higher doses. This may explain why, when doctors have tried chemotherapy with their young patients, even where it has worked at first, resistance has quickly set in. An existing drug called ponatinib, currently in use as treatment for leukaemia, can target both proteins at once. But there are questions over the safety of the drug in children, so there will be a need to screen other drugs to find one with fewer side effects that works. The cancer is very rare  Ã¢ÂÂ   there is one case in 2 million children  Ã¢ÂÂ   but the work the ICR is doing will pay dividends in other cancers too. About 20% of all cancers have genes from this class.  Studies in mice will now be necessary before the drugs can be tried in children. The ICR is leading the world in the hunt for treatments for very rare childrenÃ¢ÂÂs cancers, which are very unlikely to make a profit and are not a field that private drug companies are keen to enter. Prof Paul Workman, chief executive of the ICR in London, said: Ã¢ÂÂWe need to see much better, more targeted treatments for children with cancer, that further drive up survival rates and spare children the serious     that conventional chemotherapy can cause. Ã¢ÂÂThis study provides an exciting pointer for how we might treat more effectively an aggressive childhood cancer for which there is currently no cure. ItÃ¢ÂÂs crucial, when as here there is a strong scientific rationale for a new treatment approach in children, that we can assess them as rapidly as possible in clinical trials. At the moment, itÃ¢ÂÂs much too easy for pharmaceutical companies to avoid evaluating their drugs in children, even when there is good evidence that they could benefit. Ã¢ÂÂ Jennifer KellyÃ¢ÂÂs four   daughter Grace was diagnosed with malignant rhabdoid tumours two years ago and died soon afterwards. Her mother set up the Grace Kelly Ladybird Trust to fundraise research into childhood cancers. Ã¢ÂÂGrace went from being a happy, healthy schoolgirl to passing away within three weeks,Ã¢ÂÂ said her mother. Ã¢ÂÂShe started school in September and didnÃ¢ÂÂt make it to  . She was an athlete  Ã¢ÂÂ   she was the monkey hanging upside down from the monkey bars. Even when she was admitted to hospital initially she seemed quite well. It progressed very rapidly.  Ã¢ÂÂIt is basically a diagnosis of death, whether they try to hold it at bay with chemotherapy for a while or not. They simply canÃ¢ÂÂt treat them. There is a lack of funding for childhood cancers as a whole. People donÃ¢ÂÂt realise childhood cancer is the biggest medical cause of death in children in the UK. People think it is rare and it actually isnÃ¢ÂÂt. It is that that shocked us more than anything else. Ã¢ÂÂ One in 500 children get some kind of cancer before the age of 14, according to figures from Cancer Research UK. In the UK, 1, 700 children under 14 get a diagnosis each year, and 2, 300 between the ages of 14 and 20.
Title: Scientists find Ã¢ÂÂchink in armourÃ¢ÂÂ of aggressive childhood cancer

Content: A disabled teenage cancer patient was injured during a violent arrest by security agents at Memphis international airport, her family has alleged in a lawsuit filed against the Transport Security Administration. Hannah Cohen, 18, at the time of her arrest on 30 June 2015, and her mother had been on their way home to Chattanooga from St JudeÃ¢ÂÂs hospital in Memphis, where Hannah underwent her final treatment for a brain tumor. Hannah and her mother, Shirley, told the Guardian that the pair had made the trip hundreds of times, and knew the airport security routine well. Shirley would usually go through the scanner first and wait for Hannah on the other side, since HannahÃ¢ÂÂs tumor, and numerous surgeries and treatments since she was two years old, had left her easily confused and frightened in unfamiliar situations.  According to the complaint, the warning alarm was triggered when Hannah passed through the body scanners. Hannah attributed the alarm to her shirtÃ¢ÂÂs design. Ã¢ÂÂMy shirt  Ã¢ÂÂ   it had sequins,Ã¢ÂÂ Hannah told the Guardian, laboring to speak. According to the complaint: Ã¢ÂÂYou could see on the screen what it was pointing out,Ã¢ÂÂ Shirley said. She stood to the side, watching, wearing an immobilization boot on a broken foot. Agents told Hannah they needed to take her to a Ã¢ÂÂsterile areaÃ¢ÂÂ where they could search her further. She was afraid, Shirley said, and offered to take off the sequined shirt as she was wearing another underneath, but a female agent laughed at her. Seeing the scene begin to unfold, Shirley hobbled to a supervisor standing nearby. Ã¢ÂÂShe is a St JudeÃ¢ÂÂs patient, and she can get confused,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂPlease be gentle. If I could just help her, it will make things easier. Ã¢ÂÂ But soon, a voice on the public address system requested more agents to report to the checkpoint, Shirley said. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs when the armed guards came. Ã¢ÂÂ  The brain tumor had left Hannah blind in one eye, deaf in one ear and partially paralyzed, so when the guards grabbed each of her arms, it startled her, she said. Ã¢ÂÂI tried to push away,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂI tried to get away. Ã¢ÂÂ The guards slammed Hannah to the ground, her mother said, smashing her face into the floor, which the complaint alleges left her Ã¢ÂÂphysically and emotionallyÃ¢ÂÂ injured. Shirley had just picked up her phone from the conveyor belt, and she snapped a photo of Hannah on the floor: handcuffed, weeping and bleeding.  Ã¢ÂÂAnother guard pushed me back 20ft, in my boot, and told me I couldnÃ¢ÂÂt be nearby,Ã¢ÂÂ said Shirley, a professor of nursing at a university in Chattanooga.  Ã¢ÂÂI felt so helpless. I sat down on a bench facing away so I couldnÃ¢ÂÂt see what they were doing to my daughter. Ã¢ÂÂ The lawsuit alleges that the TSA did not give Hannah adequate accommodation to screen her, and discriminated against her because of her disability. It names the TSA and the   County airport authority and seeks damages that include medical expenses and for personal injury, both physical and emotional. It calls for a Ã¢ÂÂreasonable sum not exceeding $100, 000 and costsÃ¢ÂÂ and an undisclosed punitive amount.  The TSA has not yet responded to the complaint. Hannah disappeared behind a door, then went to a hospital, and finally to the Shelby County jail. After 24 hours apart, the mother and daughter were reunited in the parking lot of the jail. Shirley said she held her daughter, who sobbed, Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm sorry, Mama. Ã¢ÂÂ The next morning  Ã¢ÂÂ   now two days without their belongings, which had made the flight home  Ã¢ÂÂ   the pair appeared before a local judge, who asked the accused to explain herself.  When Hannah responded, the judge said: Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂre going to have to speak up. Ã¢ÂÂ ThatÃ¢ÂÂs when Hannah looked up and her hair fell back from her face, revealing her unseeing eye, surrounded by cuts and contusions.  Ã¢ÂÂThe judgeÃ¢ÂÂs eyes got big and round,Ã¢ÂÂ Shirley said.  After inquiring if the pair were from Memphis, the judge recommended they get legal representation. The charges were all dropped two days later, and the court refunded the $250 in costs the family had paid. The TSA did not immediately return a request for comment. But a TSA spokeswoman, Sari Koshetz, said in a statement that Ã¢ÂÂpassengers can call ahead of time to learn more about the screening process for their particular needs or medical situationÃ¢ÂÂ. Ã¢ÂÂWhy should I do that when weÃ¢ÂÂve been going through that airport for 17 years?Ã¢ÂÂ Shirley said.  Ã¢ÂÂThese people think they are God. They think they can do anything they want,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂWell, in this country we have the Americans with Disabilities Act. And if they will do this to a disabled girl, does that mean theyÃ¢ÂÂll do it to an    grandmother? ItÃ¢ÂÂs time for justice. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Disabled cancer patient slammed to the ground by TSA guards, lawsuit claims

Content: Americans love tattoos. Nearly a quarter of them have gotten inked, compared with 12% in Europe. The personal expression that is skin deep is particularly popular with young people: 40% of American teenagers sport tattoos. Women are also more likely than men to get one. Yet very little is known about the effects of modern day tattoo ink on the human body. The lack of research and data is worrisome because some of the key ingredients are known to make people sick or die. It also makes it difficult to regulate them. A recent report from the European Commission warns that tattoo ink often contains Ã¢ÂÂhazardous chemicalsÃ¢ÂÂ such as heavy metals and preservatives that could have serious health consequences, including bacterial infections. A separate study issued earlier this month by the Australian government reveals that 22% of the inks tested contained chemical compounds known to cause cancer. The European report notes that regulators are especially wary of imports from the US, which supplies the majority of tattoo inks to the world. The report highlights the health risks and provides European countries with scientific evidence so they can decide if better oversight of tattoo inks is necessary. Ã¢ÂÂThe question is, whatÃ¢ÂÂs in the tattoo and what can it do to the body?Ã¢ÂÂ said Tyler Hollmig, director of Laser and Aesthetic Dermatology at Stanford University Health Care. Ã¢ÂÂThe answer is, we just donÃ¢ÂÂt know. Ã¢ÂÂ Tattoos work by injecting the ink into the second layer of skin known as the dermis, where the ink remains permanently unless it is removed using laser technology. Ã¢ÂÂThe skin is very active in protecting the body from infection, and white blood cells try to eat up tattoo ink,Ã¢ÂÂ said Hollmig. Ã¢ÂÂThe body treats the ink as a foreign substance. Ã¢ÂÂ The Federal Food and Drug Administration (FDA) doesnÃ¢ÂÂt need to approve tattoo inks before they go on the market. The agency can regulate the pigments used by screening them beforehand, but it seldom does so Ã¢ÂÂbecause of other competing public health priorities and a pervasive lack of evidence of safety problems specifically associated with these pigments,Ã¢ÂÂ said Lauren Sucher, an FDA spokesperson. The agency will investigate an ink only when a safety issue is reported. This happened last year, when   company, A Thousand Inks voluntarily recalled some of its products after the FDA found bacterial contamination in unopened bottles of the firmÃ¢ÂÂs grey wash shades. The FDA tested the ink following an outbreak of skin infections in people who had recently got tattoos in Florida. The FDA warned tattoo artists that using the contaminated inks could lead to skin irritation such as redness and swelling, and could spread throughout the body, resulting in swollen lymph nodes and even sepsis, a life threatening blood infection. Ã¢ÂÂThese infections may be severe and may require extensive treatment with antibiotics, hospitalization or surgery,Ã¢ÂÂ warned the FDA. This kind of public health scare and the popularity of tattoos and emergence of health problems are forcing the FDA to consider more oversight over this $2. 3bn industry. ItÃ¢ÂÂs currently investigating how tattoo ink is broken down in the body and its long term safety at the National Center for Toxicological Research in Arkansas. Researchers are examining some pigments, like Yellow 74, which fade in the sunlight. Ã¢ÂÂWe want to know what happens to the ink,Ã¢ÂÂ said Paul Howard, the lead research chemist. Ã¢ÂÂWhere does the pigment go?Ã¢ÂÂ Howard said the pigment may still be there, and that it could be toxic. His team is also looking at the possibility that the body digests and secretes ink in the same way that it destroys bacteria when fighting infection. Meanwhile, ink manufacturers already have to contend with rules from some state or local governments. In 2005, a California judge ruled that two major tattoo ink makers  Ã¢ÂÂ   Huck Spaulding Enterprises and Superior Tattoo Equipment  Ã¢ÂÂ   must include a label on their products warning California customers the ink contains heavy metals that could cause Ã¢ÂÂcancer, birth defects and reproductive harmÃ¢ÂÂ. Some companies claim to use safer ingredients in their ink. Kuro Sumi, a Japanese manufacturer, and   Eternal Ink say they use organic pigments that are  . But since there are no industry regulations for terms like Ã¢ÂÂorganicÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂnaturalÃ¢ÂÂ itÃ¢ÂÂs hard to know whether products containing these ingredients are indeed safer. Tattoo ink is generally sold    and typically contains a number of ingredients, including colorants, preservatives, binding agents and fillers. Colorants, more commonly called pigments, can constitute up to 60% of an ink by weight, according to the EU study. The pigments used by manufacturers arenÃ¢ÂÂt specifically made for use in tattoos, and many are Ã¢ÂÂ  colors suitable for printersÃ¢ÂÂ ink or automobile paintÃ¢ÂÂ according to the FDA. The overall longevity and potential toxicity may differ depending on the color. To make black ink, for instance, manufacturers might use soot or powdered jet, or cinnabar and common rust to make red. Some of the ink ingredients, like the metal cadmium, are known carcinogens, while others, like carbon black, are Ã¢ÂÂpossibly carcinogenicÃ¢ÂÂ according to the International Agency for Research on Cancer, an arm of the World Health Organization (Who). Yet this doesnÃ¢ÂÂt necessarily mean those ingredients are dangerous to human health, said Hayley Goldbach, a resident physician in dermatology at UCLA Health, a healthcare system affiliated with the University of California at Los Angeles. Ã¢ÂÂJust because something can cause cancer doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean that it does,Ã¢ÂÂ she said. Ã¢ÂÂAs far as I know there have not been any studies convincingly or conclusively linking tattoo pigment to an increased risk for cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ A 2012 paper by Finnish researchers, who analyzed previous studies, found the number of skin cancers inside tattoos was Ã¢ÂÂseemingly lowÃ¢ÂÂ and that any link had to be considered Ã¢ÂÂthus far as coincidentalÃ¢ÂÂ. Tattoos can camouflage moles, however, making it difficult to monitor tattooed patients for skin cancer. And tattoo ink ingredients like cadmium have been found in lymph nodes, which help filter waste from the body. According to the EU study, these substances could spread from the lymph nodes to the rest of the body, although more research is needed to support this theory, wrote the authors. Hollmig said he sees skin cancer in and around tattoos, but itÃ¢ÂÂs hard to say whether itÃ¢ÂÂs the ink causing the illness. Ã¢ÂÂYou figure that you inject the carcinogen and skin cancer grows there, but we donÃ¢ÂÂt have data on that,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. The most common   complaints he sees in his practice are skin irritations, usually caused by red ink, which typically contains mercury, a known allergen. Ã¢ÂÂJust the red area of the tattoo would have swollen, tender and really itchy reactions,Ã¢ÂÂ he said, adding that these adverse health effects can occur months and even years after a person gets the tattoo. A 2015 study from New York UniversityÃ¢ÂÂs Langone Medical Center found that at least 6% of tattooed New Yorkers suffered a serious reaction like swelling and severe itching that lasted for more than four months. Almost half of these reactions were to red ink, while   of the cases were linked to black ink. As for tattoo artists, most do care about the safety of the pigments that they use on their clients, said Mike Martin, a veteran tattoo artist and president of the Alliance of Professional Tattooists, a nonprofit that promotes safe tattooing. Ã¢ÂÂPigments are super important to the finished product and our products are what people judge us on,Ã¢ÂÂ said Martin. Ã¢ÂÂGreat color, great line work, quick healing,   no weird skin reactions  Ã¢ÂÂ   these are all hallmarks of good professional tattooing. Ã¢ÂÂ Without strong regulations, however, problematic inks will continue to show up at tattoo parlors. For example, tattoo manufacturers can use different recipes and make their own blends, which could contain different levels of carcinogens and allergens. This makes it Ã¢ÂÂvery hard to study them for safetyÃ¢ÂÂ said Goldbach. Ã¢ÂÂThe composition of tattoo ink has changed over time so it also means that new and potentially dangerous agents could be introduced into tattoo ink at any time,Ã¢ÂÂ she said.
Title: Tattoo ink contains cancer-causing chemicals Ã¢ÂÂ so why isnÃ¢ÂÂt it regulated?

Content: Millions of young British men are being denied a vaccine that could protect them from throat cancers in later life. Scientists say the problem is becoming increasingly worrying as rates of human papilloma virus (HPV)  Ã¢ÂÂ   a common sexually transmitted infection and the prime cause of these cancers  Ã¢ÂÂ   are now rising exponentially. Researchers want the government to include adolescent boys in the current vaccine programme that immunises girls aged 12 and 13 against HPV before they become sexually active. HPV in women is known to lead to cervical cancers. The vaccine, if extended to boys, would protect them in later life against   head and neck cancers. Ã¢ÂÂIf we want to eradicate male throat cancers  Ã¢ÂÂ   which are soaring in numbers  Ã¢ÂÂ   we need to act speedily and that means giving them the HPV vaccine we now give to girls,Ã¢ÂÂ said Professor Mark Lawler of QueenÃ¢ÂÂs University Belfast. Health experts say increased levels of oral sex are in part responsible for the spread of HPV. Ã¢ÂÂSmoking and alcohol add to risks, but the fact that couples are having more and more oral sex is the main factor,Ã¢ÂÂ said Peter Baker, campaign director of HPV Action. A vaccine to block HPV infections was developed a decade ago and from 2008 formed the basis of a programme to inoculate UK schoolgirls to protect them from cervical cancer later in life.  At present more than 3, 000 women develop cervical cancer a year in the UK. Most other western nations have since introduced similar programmes. Ã¢ÂÂHPV is spread sexually. However, this vaccine will not work effectively if a person has already been infected by HPV,Ã¢ÂÂ said Baker. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs why it is given to girls when they are 12 or 13  Ã¢ÂÂ   before they are sexually active. Ã¢ÂÂ Tens of thousands of young women are now given the vaccine, although it is too early to say how cervical cancer rates are going to be affected, said virologist Professor Sheila Graham, of Glasgow University.  Ã¢ÂÂHowever, rates of genital warts in women  Ã¢ÂÂ   which are also caused by HPV  Ã¢ÂÂ   are going down, so there is confidence the vaccine will work. Ã¢ÂÂ However, the introduction of the HPV vaccine for women has come just as infection rates in men have started to soar, with cases of tonsil cancers and cancers of the base of the tongue  Ã¢ÂÂ   both caused by the virus  Ã¢ÂÂ   rising dramatically. Tonsil cancer cases have tripled in numbers since the 1990s, for example.  Ã¢ÂÂUnfortunately, these cancers have very serious outcomes with dreadful morbidity,Ã¢ÂÂ added Graham. Scientists say it would cost about ÃÂ£20m a year to extend the current HPV vaccine programme to boys.  Ã¢ÂÂBy contrast, it costs about ÃÂ£30m a year to treat males for genital warts while the costs of treating the rising numbers of throat cancers are even greater,Ã¢ÂÂ Lawler said. Ã¢ÂÂSo, in purely monetary terms, it makes sense to give boys the vaccine. Ã¢ÂÂ This point is disputed by some health economists. They say the human papilloma virus will have virtually disappeared from sexually active UK women in a few decades, thanks to the vaccine now given to girls at school. As a result men will no longer pick up the virus when having oral sex with women. This effect is known as herd immunity. But Professor Margaret Stanley, of Cambridge University, said the argument was flawed. Ã¢ÂÂRelying on   vaccine programmes to remove HPV from the population is risky. Ã¢ÂÂIn Denmark the   rate of the vaccine recently dropped from around 80% to 20% because of a scare story  Ã¢ÂÂ   which was quite untrue  Ã¢ÂÂ   suggesting the vaccine was spreading disease. We need protection for both sexes to be sure we eradicate HPV. Ã¢ÂÂ In addition, reliance on a   vaccine programme would mean that gay men would never be provided with protection against HPV, she added.  This last point was crucial is persuading health officials in Australia to extend its school HPV vaccine programme to men in 2013. It is the only country to run a free HPV vaccine programme for both sexes. The governmentÃ¢ÂÂs joint committee on vaccination has been considering extending the HPV programme to boys for several years but is not due to give a ruling until 2017. Ã¢ÂÂEven if it gives approval then, we are unlikely to get the programme extended to boys until around 2020,Ã¢ÂÂ said Baker. Ã¢ÂÂBy then millions who could have been protected against throat cancers will have lost the chance to get the vaccine. Ã¢ÂÂ Stanley was also emphatic the vaccine programme should be extended. Ã¢ÂÂA great many health experts in this field are paying privately to have their sons vaccinated.  Ã¢ÂÂIt costs ÃÂ£160 for a double shot. I have had my grandson vaccinated. The nature of the problem is obvious. Ã¢ÂÂIn any case, it is simply discriminatory not to give a vaccine to men when it could save their lives. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Give HPV vaccine to boys to protect against cancers, experts say

Content: The first results from a major project to measure the reliability of cancer research have highlighted a big problem: Labs trying to repeat published experiments often canÃ¢ÂÂt. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs not to say that the original studies are wrong. But the results of a review published Thursday, in the   journal eLife, are a sobering reminder that science often fails at one of its most basic requirements  Ã¢ÂÂ   an experiment in one lab ought to be reproducible in another one. And the fact that they often arenÃ¢ÂÂt could have big health implications. Many exciting ideas in cancer research never pan out. One reason is that findings from the initial studies donÃ¢ÂÂt stand the test of time. Ã¢ÂÂReproducibility is a central feature of how science is supposed to be,Ã¢ÂÂ says Brian Nosek, who spearheaded this research at the Center for Open Science. Nosek is also a psychology professor at the University of Virginia. A few years ago, he organized a similar effort to examine research in his field. And his results garnered worldwide attention when   of the original findings in psychology couldnÃ¢ÂÂt be reproduced. Nosek decided to explore the work from cancer biology labs after two   studies, from drugmakers Bayer and Amgen, reported dismal results when they tried to reproduce some cancer papers. Only 25 percent of the papers Bayer examined were reproduced. Amgen was able to replicate only six out of the 53 studies it examined. Ã¢ÂÂThose were earthshaking reports, in the sense that the community responded very strongly to these reports of challenges to reproduce some of these core findings,Ã¢ÂÂ Nosek says. But scientists at Bayer and Amgen wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt say which experiments they examined, so their work raised many questions but left no way for scientists to answer them. Ã¢ÂÂThe cancer reproducibility project in cancer biology was an attempt to advance that discussion with an open project,Ã¢ÂÂ Nosek says. This project is transparent about how it picked the studies to reproduce. It also published methods and study plans in advance. In collaboration with a California company called Science Exchange, the reviewers got grants to replicate key experiments from as many as 50   studies. (They will very likely run out of money before theyÃ¢ÂÂre able to complete that work, however.) TheyÃ¢ÂÂve now published the results of their first five attempts, in eLife. Ã¢ÂÂThree of the five show very, very striking differences from the original,Ã¢ÂÂ says Timothy Errington, a biologist at the Center for Open Science and collaborator in the project. As for findings from the other two studies, he says, Ã¢ÂÂI think youÃ¢ÂÂll get a lot of opinions about whether they replicate or not.Ã¢ÂÂ Errington says he was quite surprised by the results. In one case, the original scientists went the extra mile to help the labs doing the   studies reduce potential sources of error. Ã¢ÂÂThe lab gave us the same drug. This is wonderful. Because that could have been a sticking point,Ã¢ÂÂ Errington says. Ã¢ÂÂThey gave us the same tumor cells that they used.Ã¢ÂÂ Yet the replicating lab didnÃ¢ÂÂt end up with the same results. Scientists have had so much confidence in two of the original studies that drug companies already have sunk millions of dollars into efforts to try the concepts out in people. But the   experiments for one of those didnÃ¢ÂÂt validate the original results. The inevitable question is whether the original science was wrong, or whether the scientists who tried to repeat that work somehow got tripped up. The review project farmed out its actual laboratory work to commercial labs that perform experiments for the pharmaceutical industry, or to university Ã¢ÂÂcore facilities,Ã¢ÂÂ such as centralized labs that do a lot of research on mice. Those labs generally work to standards required by the Food and Drug Administration. But research with living systems is never simple, so there are many possible sources of variation in any experiment, ranging from the animals and cells to the details of lab technique. And there isnÃ¢ÂÂt even clear agreement about when a studyÃ¢ÂÂs findings can be considered to have been reproduced. Sean Morrison, an editor at eLife and a Howard Hughes Medical Institute investigator at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, says that by his count, two studiesÃ¢ÂÂ findings were substantially reproduced. The findings of one other were not, he says, and two others have results that simply canÃ¢ÂÂt be interpreted. Ã¢ÂÂOne of the difficulties of the reproducibility project is they have limited time and resources to spend on any one study,Ã¢ÂÂ Morrison says. Ã¢ÂÂAs a result, they canÃ¢ÂÂt go back and do these things over and over again when the first results turn out to be uninterpretable.Ã¢ÂÂ Errington agrees that the reproducibility project leaves that big question hanging  Ã¢ÂÂ   but the scientists donÃ¢ÂÂt plan to answer it. Ã¢ÂÂAs exciting as that is, and as important as that is  Ã¢ÂÂ   and we hope someone else will follow up on it  Ã¢ÂÂ   weÃ¢ÂÂre more curious about, Ã¢ÂÂWhat does that look like when we do this across many, many, many studies.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ But Dr. Erkki Ruoslahti, at the nonprofit Sanford Burnham Prebys Medical Discovery Institute in La Jolla, Calif. is worried that the reproducibility project could do real damage. The reviewers couldnÃ¢ÂÂt reproduce his original study but didnÃ¢ÂÂt follow up to understand why. Ã¢ÂÂI am really worried about what this will do to our ability to raise funding for our clinical development,Ã¢ÂÂ he writes in an email to Shots. Ã¢ÂÂIf we, and the many laboratories who have reproduced our results, are right and the reproducibility study is wrong  Ã¢ÂÂ   which I think is the case  Ã¢ÂÂ   they will not be doing a favor to cancer patients.Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Irving Weissman, a professor of pathology and developmental biology at Stanford University, is also disappointed in how the reproducibility project handled his experiment. His paper reported finding a protein thatÃ¢ÂÂs present on all human cancer cells  Ã¢ÂÂ   a finding that Weissman says has been replicated many times in other labs. The reproducibility project chose to repeat a peripheral part of WeissmanÃ¢ÂÂs paper  Ã¢ÂÂ   an experiment involving mice, not human tissues. And, Weissman says, the replicating lab stumbled over an early step in the experiment, but plowed ahead anyway. Weissman says he offered to bring scientists into his lab to train them in the technique, but the Reproducibility Project didnÃ¢ÂÂt do that. (That would undercut one of its goals, which is to see whether scientists working independently can verify published results.) ItÃ¢ÂÂs important to replicate important studies, Weissman tells Shots, Ã¢ÂÂbut you canÃ¢ÂÂt do it halfheartedly. You have to be serious about it.Ã¢ÂÂ Errington and Nosek hope people who hear about the projectÃ¢ÂÂs findings donÃ¢ÂÂt jump to any conclusions about why individual studies came to different conclusions. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre trying to look at the big picture across dozens of studies, the two scientists say, and they donÃ¢ÂÂt place too much confidence in any single result. The reproducibility project is looking for patterns across cancer research and also trying to identify common reasons that labs might have trouble reproducing one anotherÃ¢ÂÂs work. Are the directions offered in the methods section of a paper too sketchy? Or maybe experiments frequently work only under unusual conditions. Morrison, who is involved as a journal editor rather than a participant, says the entire reproducibility project is itself one big experiment. Ã¢ÂÂI think itÃ¢ÂÂs too early for us to know whether this approach is the right approach or the best approach for testing the reproducibility of cancer biology,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂBut it will be a data point, and it will start the conversation.Ã¢ÂÂ The conversation is important because the vast majority of treatment ideas that come from the lab fail when theyÃ¢ÂÂre tried in people. Cathy   a pharmacologist at the University of California, San Francisco, says scientists often donÃ¢ÂÂt know why those clinical failures occur, Ã¢ÂÂand so thatÃ¢ÂÂs why I think studies like this are really, really important.Ã¢ÂÂ Unfortunately, Nosek says, there are few incentives today for scientists to repeat experiments from other labs. The rewards are for publishing new ideas, not the less glamorous, but still critical, work of verifying somebody elseÃ¢ÂÂs findings. Ã¢ÂÂIf weÃ¢ÂÂre going to take reproducibility seriously,Ã¢ÂÂ Nosek says, experiments that attempt to reproduce the findings of others Ã¢ÂÂneed to be a valued part of scientific contribution.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: What Does It Mean When Cancer Findings CanÃ¢ÂÂt Be Reproduced?

Content: Screening for lung cancer using   CT scans can save lives, but at a cost: Tests frequently produce   false alarms and prompt unnecessary procedures. A study from the Veterans Health Administration lays out the considerable effort required by both patients and doctors to undertake screening. Ã¢ÂÂI have heard people say Ã¢ÂÂwhatÃ¢ÂÂs the big deal, itÃ¢ÂÂs just a CT,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ says Dr. Linda Kinsinger, who ran the study at the VA. Ã¢ÂÂBut I think what we tried to show is itÃ¢ÂÂs a lot more than just a CT.Ã¢ÂÂ Federal officials and other medical groups recommend   CT scans to look for lung cancer among people at risk, generally those over the age of 55 who have smoked at least the equivalent of two packs a day for 15 years. The tests typically cost $300, and they arenÃ¢ÂÂt always covered by insurance. Screening does identify cancers, but in the vast majority of cases the test produces false alarms. In the VA study, which was published Monday in JAMA Internal Medicine, 4, 246 patients were eligible for screening. About half of them declined to take the test, even though it was offered at no cost. Of those who took the test, about 55 percent of them were told that they had lung nodules, which often involved   appointments and further scans. But very few of those nodules were actually real problems. In the end, the screeners identified 31 cases of lung cancer, about 20 of which were in the early, most treatable stage. The study involved eight of the 150 or so VA hospitals, and was designed to assess the overall benefits and potential harms of setting up a screening program in a large medical institution. So is it a good idea? Ã¢ÂÂI think itÃ¢ÂÂs a close call,Ã¢ÂÂ Kinsinger says. There was a benefit to the 20 or so patients out of this large initial population who had their cancer detected while it was likely to be treatable. Ã¢ÂÂBut that has to be weighed against the amount of effort on the part of both patients and staff, and the anxiety, the worry, that a false alarm will cause among patients,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂI think a lot of people have a much rosier view of screening in general than the facts bear out,Ã¢ÂÂ says Dr. Rita Redberg, editor of JAMA Internal Medicine and a cardiologist at the University of California, San Francisco who wrote an editorial accompanying the study. Ã¢ÂÂVery few people are actually helped by screening, and a lot of time there are a number of harms.Ã¢ÂÂ Another study published in the same issue found that many people getting CT screens are actually at low risk for lung cancer. Dr. Jinhai Huo and colleagues at the MD Anderson Cancer Center compared screening rates before and after 2011, the year of a key study that supported the idea of   CT screening for lung cancer. Ã¢ÂÂOnce a [radiology] center has the ability to do this screening, they like to use their technology to do as many people as possible,Ã¢ÂÂ Redberg says, Ã¢ÂÂand it seems that   people who are really unlikely to get any benefit and are much more likely to get harmed are getting screened in higher numbers than in the   people who are supposed to be screened.Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Jorge Gomez, a spokesman for the American Lung Association and an oncologist at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York, says that while screening   people doesnÃ¢ÂÂt make sense on a population basis, it sometimes makes sense for individual patients. And as for the experience at the VA, Gomez says medical teams that have learned to interpret the results of scans can generally weed out   results without resorting to biopsies or other invasive   tests. Ã¢ÂÂThere is a concern for unnecessary procedures at institutions where they donÃ¢ÂÂt have the expertise in reading these scans,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. And he acknowledges not everybody has the luxury of going to the     institutions that do this best.
Title: Lung Cancer Screening Program Finds A Lot ThatÃ¢ÂÂs Not Cancer

Content: Cancer researchers are testing whether a generic drug that has been used for more than 40 years to treat parasitic infections may also help fight cancer. The tests of mebendazole are part of a growing effort to take a fresh look at old medicines to see if they can be repurposed for new uses. I first learned about mebendazole several years back when my son came home from camp with a gross but common infection: pinworms. My pediatrician prescribed two doses of mebendazole, and two weeks later the infection was gone.   a couple of years, and I was surprised to find on clinicaltrials. gov, the federal database of medical trials, that mebendazole was being investigated as a potential cancer drug. Curious, I contacted Gregory Riggins, a cancer researcher at Johns Hopkins University who is testing the safety of mebendazole as a potential cancer treatment. He invited me to his lab in Baltimore. Riggins took me inside and showed me cages of cancer research mice. A few years back, he said, his idea to test mebendazole started here. Some of the lab animals got infected with pinworms, the same parasite my son had. The veterinarian at Johns Hopkins treated the whole colony of mice with an animal version of mebendazole. The drug staved off the parasite, but it also did something surprising. Before the mice were treated for pinworms, Riggins and his team had implanted cancer cells into the animalsÃ¢ÂÂ brains. But after the mice got the pinworm drug, the cancers never developed. Ã¢ÂÂOur medulloblastoma stopped growing,Ã¢ÂÂ Riggins says. He found out that other researchers were conducting animal studies to see if the drug had effects on lung cancer and melanoma. So he got funding to do two Phase 1 studies to test whether mebendazole is safe to use in brain cancer patients, one in children and another in adults. So far the drug appears to be safe and well tolerated by patients, Riggins says. That would be expected, given that it has been used for decades around the world to treat pinworms. Ã¢ÂÂBased on the preclinical studies it looks like it has promise,Ã¢ÂÂ says Tracy Batchelor, director of the division of   at Massachusetts General Hospital, who is not involved in the research. Ã¢ÂÂThe next step is to look for a benefit in a Phase 2 trial.Ã¢ÂÂ That would test whether mebendazole has any effect on cancer in people. Riggins hopes to conduct that sort of trial in adult brain cancer patients. At a time when it can cost a billion dollars to develop a new drug, the idea of repurposing existing drugs is appealing, according to Bruce Bloom. HeÃ¢ÂÂs the president and chief science officer of Cures Within Reach, which has helped to fund RigginsÃ¢ÂÂ research. Bloom points to research on metformin, a diabetes drug thatÃ¢ÂÂs being looked at as a potential treatment for a dozen different kinds of cancer and also tuberculosis. A common blood pressure drug, propranolol, is also being studied. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs not likely that mebendazole or any other single repurposed drug is ever going to cure cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ Bloom says. But he envisions the possibility that combinations of repurposed drugs might help the body to manage cancer. Any use of mebendazole as a cancer drug would be years away, if it proves to work at all. Most drugs that emerge from Phase 1 trials never deliver the   benefits. And in an odd twist to a complicated story, the cost of mebendazole in the U. S. has skyrocketed in recent years. Though it remains very affordable in most countries, the wholesale cost of a 100 mg tablet in the U. S. has risen from $4. 50 in 2011 to $369 in 2016, according to Truven Health Analytics. The dynamics that led to the price hike were in play before interest rose in the drug as a potential cancer treatment, analysts say. In 2013, Amedra Pharmaceuticals bought marketing rights to mebendazole from Teva Pharmaceuticals. It already owned rights to another key generic antiparasitic drug, albendazole. Ã¢ÂÂAt that point, anyone who has had a high school or undergraduate economics course would be able to explain the price hike,Ã¢ÂÂ says Joey Mattingly, an assistant professor in the department of pharmacy practice and science at the University of Maryland School of Pharmacy who studies generic drug pricing. That leaves people with pinworm infections with the choice of two expensive prescription medications or cheaper    options. Ã¢ÂÂPinworms are exceedingly common,Ã¢ÂÂ says Rachel Orscheln, an assistant professor of pediatric infectious diseases at Washington University and St. Louis ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Hospital. The CDC estimates 40 million people are infected in the U. S. annually. Orscheln says the people most likely to be infected are children and people who are living in group settings such as nursing homes. Ã¢ÂÂThere are certain cases where we do need to prescribe this medication,Ã¢ÂÂ says Orscheln. But at the higher price, she says, Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm very disinclined to prescribe [it].Ã¢ÂÂ She says    drugs such as   or pyrantel, can work just as well in children, so Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm very likely to steer people in that direction.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: A Pinworm Medication Is Being Tested As A Potential Anti-Cancer Drug

Content: If the last few years are any guide, one group that may find itself in the crosshairs of Rep. Tom Price, President TrumpÃ¢ÂÂs pick to lead the Department of Health and Human Services, is an influential panel of medical experts. The U. S. Preventive Services Task Force, a group of mostly physician and academics from top universities, reviews medical practices to see whether they are supported by research and evidence. Under the Affordable Care Act, the USPSTFÃ¢ÂÂs recommendations have been used to guide private insurers. If the group gives a test high marks, insurers are required to cover it. If it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt, they are free not to. But letters reviewed by ProPublica show that Price twice pushed HHS to quash the task forceÃ¢ÂÂs recommendations to limit widely used cancer screenings. The panel said that the screenings too often led to unnecessary biopsies and other harmful treatment. Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee boycotted a Tuesday vote on PriceÃ¢ÂÂs nomination, citing unanswered ethics questions. In 2011, Price and other lawmakers signed a letter asking the head of HHS to Ã¢ÂÂpush for the withdrawalÃ¢ÂÂ of the panelÃ¢ÂÂs draft prostate screening recommendations. The panel was made up of Ã¢ÂÂbureaucrats,Ã¢ÂÂ the letter said, and decisions about prostate testing were best left to doctors and their patients. Ã¢ÂÂThis recommendation jeopardizes the health of countless American men,Ã¢ÂÂ the letter said. The task force went ahead and in 2012 recommended that men of all ages forgo using blood tests to search for prostate cancer. The recommendation didnÃ¢ÂÂt apply to men with a history of prostate cancer. Three years later, Price signed two letters protesting the task forceÃ¢ÂÂs proposed recommendations that mammograms be given every two years for healthy and   women between the ages of 50 and 74, and by individual choice for women between 40 and 49. Other groups, including the American College of Radiology, recommend starting mammograms at 40 and having them every year or two. In May 2015, Price and other lawmakers wrote that the USPSTF recommendations Ã¢ÂÂwould jeopardize access to screenings.Ã¢ÂÂ In June, a second letter signed by Price and others with the GOP Doctors Caucus, went further, urging the head of HHS to ensure the recommendations werenÃ¢ÂÂt finalized. The recommendations, the letter said, could Ã¢ÂÂresult in thousands of additional breast cancer deaths.Ã¢ÂÂ Despite the complaints, the mammogram recommendations were issued in 2016. Proponents praised them as the fruit of the task forceÃ¢ÂÂs independent and   approach. But the guidelines raised the ire of a much more powerful constituency: the urologists and radiologists who made billions of dollars off the testing and related procedures. Ã¢ÂÂThe dirty underbelly of screening is that itÃ¢ÂÂs a great way to get more patients,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Gilbert Welch, professor of medicine at the Dartmouth Institute for Health Policy  Clinical Practice and a close observer of the task forceÃ¢ÂÂs work. Ã¢ÂÂThe financial underpinnings are huge.Ã¢ÂÂ The health care industry spends more money lobbying Congress than almost any other sector, according to the tracking site OpenSecrets. org. Price, an orthopedic surgeon, took in $479, 000 in health professional donations in the 2016 campaign cycle, one of the largest sums to any member of Congress. To be sure, the industry has a host of more pressing concerns, from the ACA and Medicare and Medicaid to the cost of drugs. But the task forceÃ¢ÂÂs recommendations have continued to draw complaints by lawmakers who received financial support from the industry. In November, lawmakers bashed its screening recommendations during a hearing of the health subcommittee of the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. The task force Ã¢ÂÂcan deprive patients of lifesaving services,Ã¢ÂÂ said Rep. Michael Burgess, a Republican from Texas who received nearly $611, 000 from health professionals in the 2016 campaign cycle. His colleague, Rep. Marsha Blackburn, a Tennessee Republican who received $259, 000 in donations from health professionals in the 2016 campaign cycle, predicted equally dire outcomes. The task force, she said, Ã¢ÂÂturned its back on over 20 million women by finalizing erroneous guidelines that would limit access to mammograms.Ã¢ÂÂ Earlier this month, Blackburn   legislation that would, among other things, add specialists to the panel. The group currently consults with specialists in the areas they are reviewing. Critics of the proposed bill say specialists are not ideal to perform the task forceÃ¢ÂÂs broad array of evidence reviews, and adding them could create conflicts of interest. Ã¢ÂÂThere is considerable support for Ã¢ÂÂdraining the swampÃ¢ÂÂ in Washington,Ã¢ÂÂ Welch wrote in testimony he submitted for the hearing. Ã¢ÂÂBut there is no swamp currently in the task force. Please donÃ¢ÂÂt create one.Ã¢ÂÂ Questions sent to PriceÃ¢ÂÂs office were answered by Ryan Murphy, who is currently an HHS adviser. Murphy was most recently communications director for the House Budget Committee, of which Price is chairman. Ã¢ÂÂDr. PriceÃ¢ÂÂs concerns  Ã¢ÂÂ   shared by others as you noted  Ã¢ÂÂ   were with specific recommendations made by the task force,Ã¢ÂÂ Murphy said. Ã¢ÂÂAs a physician, Dr. Price knows firsthand the value of scientific research as well as how important it is to ensure patients and their doctors are able to make choices regarding treatments that they agree are in the best interest of the individual patient.Ã¢ÂÂ Price has embraced task force findings that recommend more treatment. In 2014, for example, he   a letter to the HHS secretary and the Medicare administrator asking that Medicare expand its coverage for lung cancer screenings for smokers based on task force recommendations. With the shifts in power both in Congress and under the Trump administration, proponents of the task force fear setbacks in the   push for   medicine. The task force has 96 current recommendations, which it routinely updates. Its $11. 6 million budget is funded through HHSÃ¢ÂÂs Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, which has been on the lawmakersÃ¢ÂÂ chopping block in the past. If confirmed, Price or congressional Republicans could reduce the task forceÃ¢ÂÂs influence or independence, or cut its funding. Ã¢ÂÂScience is really under attack,Ã¢ÂÂ said Fran Visco, president of the National Breast Cancer Coalition. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂve spent decades building a scientific and research infrastructure and community all in order to produce the evidence that will save lives. Sometimes the science doesnÃ¢ÂÂt give us the answer we would like, but it actually gives us the facts and the evidence.Ã¢ÂÂ While some disagree with the task forceÃ¢ÂÂs recommendations, its work is in line with a global push toward   medicine and with the guidelines of some other groups. The International Agency for Research on Cancer says there isnÃ¢ÂÂt enough evidence to recommend for or against mammograms for women between 40 and 49. Like the task force, the American College of Physicians says mammograms should be an individual decision for women between the ages of 40 and 49 and be provided every other year at the patientÃ¢ÂÂs request. The task force and others found widespread screening often led to false positives, painful biopsies and   operations for patients who were not actually at risk of cancer. Unnecessary screening also contributes to an overtreatment epidemic that the Institute of Medicine has estimated costs $210 billion a year. Dr. Kirsten   chairwoman of the task force, is a internist and epidemiologist at the University of California, San Francisco. She said the attacks by Blackburn and others risk misleading patients about the effectiveness of screening for patients who are not at risk and are free of symptoms. Ã¢ÂÂPatients and clinicians need to understand the benefits and the harms so they are empowered to make the best decisions for themselves,Ã¢ÂÂ   said. Regardless of what happens politically, she said, patients and doctors will still need   recommendations to make informed decisions. The   work of the task force could be Ã¢ÂÂendangeredÃ¢ÂÂ because the panel is caught up in the political fight around the ACA, said Dr. Sheldon Greenfield executive   of the Health Policy Research Institute at the University of California, Irvine. Ã¢ÂÂIt wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt surprise me if it does become a casualty.Ã¢ÂÂ The worst outcome, he said, would be for health care in the United States to revert to the way it used to be. The old joke is that doctors ignore science and say, Ã¢ÂÂI know best,Ã¢ÂÂ Greenfield said, trumping   medicine with Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ medicine. Marshall Allen is examining how waste and overtreatment are affecting patients and raising the cost of care. If you have evidence of wasted health care dollars, please email him at marshall. allen@propublica. org.
Title: HHS Nominee Tom Price Targeted Panel That Urged Fewer Cancer Screenings

Content: Women with breast cancer who are at high risk for having a BRCA mutation that raises cancer risk often donÃ¢ÂÂt get genetic testing, or even a chance to speak with a genetic counselor whoÃ¢ÂÂd help them weigh the necessity of such a test, a study finds. Mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancers, and women with close relatives who have had those cancers are considered at higher risk of having BRCA mutations themselves. Both the National Cancer Institute and the United States Preventative Task Force recommend that those patients talk to a genetic counselor about whether or not to get the BRCA test. But the study that surveyed newly diagnosed breast cancer patients found that while 80. 9 percent of   patients wanted testing, only 39. 6 percent had had a counseling session, and 50. 9 percent had a genetic test. The test results could help guide treatment, as well as future efforts to prevent more cancer. When asked why they didnÃ¢ÂÂt get tested, the majority of the 773   patients said it was because their doctor didnÃ¢ÂÂt recommend it to them. Just 13. 7 percent of them said the test was too expensive, and 10. 7 percent said they didnÃ¢ÂÂt want it. The researchers say this suggests a disconnect between oncologist and patient, whether it be assessing BRCA risk isnÃ¢ÂÂt on the physicianÃ¢ÂÂs radar, or that they just donÃ¢ÂÂt find it important. The study surveyed 2, 529 women overall. Ã¢ÂÂThose numbers were really striking to us,Ã¢ÂÂ says Allison Kurian, an associate professor of medicine and health   at Stanford University, breast cancer doctor, and lead author on the study, which was published Tuesday in JAMA, the journal of the American Medical Association. Ã¢ÂÂThis really emphasizes the importance of cancer doctors in this process, and that patients get evaluated and tested the way they should be.Ã¢ÂÂ Kurian notes that the study only got the patient side of the story, not the physician side, so itÃ¢ÂÂs unfair to assume the doctors are the sole cause of this disconnect. But by making genetic tests and counselors more available to patients at risk for BRCA, and making physicians more aware of the mutationsÃ¢ÂÂ implications, the gap between the need for and accessibility of genetic testing in these   patients will shrink, she says. Hospitals need to make sure breast cancer patients are screened for BRCA if they need it, says C. Anthony Ã¢ÂÂTonyÃ¢ÂÂ Blau, a professor of hematology at the University of Washington who specializes in breast cancer and was not involved with the study. The screening shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be on the patient or the oncologist, he says, but rather Ã¢ÂÂit should be part of the system. Hospital administrators donÃ¢ÂÂt typically do things that save patientsÃ¢ÂÂ lives, but this could be one of those things.Ã¢ÂÂ Testing for the genes even when patients are already diagnosed with breast cancer and are at high risk for BRCA can be helpful, says Kurian. Ã¢ÂÂKnowing a patient has BRCA1 or 2 affects how we treat the cancer she has,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂWe might give her different medications or different surgery options.Ã¢ÂÂ That knowledge can also help physicians keep an eye out for ovarian cancer, which occurs 11 to 17 percent more often in women with BRCA mutations and is difficult to diagnose early. It also lets oncologists keep an eye out for new cancers and treat them more effectively. Ã¢ÂÂCancers sneak up on you,Ã¢ÂÂ Kurian says. If a woman is flagged during BRCA screening due to her family history, Ã¢ÂÂfinding out she has a BRCA gene would let us start screening her as early as 25 years old. If we do find a really tiny cancer, sheÃ¢ÂÂll probably do a lot better and need less therapy in the long run.Ã¢ÂÂ And because the BRCA mutations have a    chance of being passed down from parent to child, a patient carrying BRCA1 or BRCA2 is likely to pass it down to further generations as well. In screening breast cancer patients for BRCA risk, Ã¢ÂÂthe implications arenÃ¢ÂÂt only for the patient presently affected by breast cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ Blau says, Ã¢ÂÂbut for their families and generations of descendants. The potential impact is enormous, and missing the opportunity to test for it is a big deal.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Women With Breast Cancer Miss Out On Recommended Genetic Testing

Content: ItÃ¢ÂÂs no surprise that most women with breast cancer consider hair loss one of the most traumatic aspects of chemotherapy. That has led to a big market for cooling caps, which are purported to limit hair loss. But cooling caps havenÃ¢ÂÂt been extensively studied in the U. S. and womensÃ¢ÂÂ experiences with the caps have been hit or miss. And just one cooling cap, the DigniCap, is approved by the Food and Drug Administration. Two studies released Tuesday show that at least half the women who used either the DigniCap or another scalp cooling system, the Paxman, lost less than 50 percent of their hair. Ã¢ÂÂThese findings appear to represent a major step forward in improving the quality of life of individuals with cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ says Dr. Dawn Hershman, who studies the effects of cancer treatments at the Columbia University School of Medicine in New York. She wrote an editorial accompanying the studies in JAMA, the journal of the American Medical Association. But Hershman cautions that more study is needed to determine whether there is psychological benefit in using the caps to prevent hair loss.
