But, no matter how loving and connected the two of them are, once cancer enters their lives, Alice is the sick one and Oliver isnÃ¢ÂÂt. Bock could have chosen to write this story as an autobiography. As he tells readers in the Ã¢ÂÂAcknowledgmentsÃ¢ÂÂ here, Alice  Oliver is based on a   nightmare that began in 2009, when his wife  Ã¢ÂÂ   then a young mother  Ã¢ÂÂ   was diagnosed with leukemia she died 2   years later. The novelÃ¢ÂÂs source, no doubt, imbues it with authority, but its literary power derives from BockÃ¢ÂÂs elastic language, stretching from his detailed inventories of extreme medical procedures to the lyric melancholy of his descriptions of mood and place. The novel opens in 1993. Alice, a fashion designer, and Oliver, a software startup entrepreneur, have moved, at his insistence, to an industrial space in the   ungentrified Meatpacking District in New York. WeÃ¢ÂÂre told that the neighborhoodÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂevery daylight hour was dominated by dock thugs and frozen slabs after dark, rotted zombie addicts held court with   sex club slaves and transvestite streetwalkers . ..Ã¢ÂÂ Oliver, though, is handy with screwdrivers and power sanders, and he transforms the desolate living space into a soaring ultramodern loft. But hereÃ¢ÂÂs the kicker. After Alice is diagnosed, and Ã¢ÂÂwhen she was at her worst,Ã¢ÂÂ weÃ¢ÂÂre privy to this confession: [W]hen she needed to blame Oliver for something, for anything, she returned to the promise she couldnÃ¢ÂÂt forget, high on his list of guarantees: theyÃ¢ÂÂd be insulated the smells from the warehouses, frozen beef and lingering death, wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt reach them. But they did. BockÃ¢ÂÂs elegance as a writer belies his resolute focus on the elemental meatiness of the human body  Ã¢ÂÂ   its many vulnerabilities and humiliations. The novel follows Alice through her course of treatment for leukemia those readers fortunate enough to be unfamiliar with medical terms like Ã¢ÂÂinduction,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂconsolidationÃ¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂtransplantÃ¢ÂÂ are thrust into their baroque and brutal realities as Alice sheds hair and skin and even the energy to hold a thought. And always, on the other side of the Ã¢ÂÂsick and wellÃ¢ÂÂ dividing line, stands Oliver, guilty and oftentimes, just itching to escape hospital world. Early on in their ordeal, weÃ¢ÂÂre told that when relief arrives in the form of AliceÃ¢ÂÂs mother: [T]he clock started eating into [OliverÃ¢ÂÂs] holy and awaited break time. [HeÃ¢ÂÂd] hightail it [out] . .. grabbing a chicken sandwich from a sports bar [or] . .. some sad Chinese lunch from a buffet table of greased food rotting beneath heat lamps. . .. Overprocessed,    garbage: his official coping mechanism. He made sure to binge away from the hospital. . .. He wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt let her see anything that might cause her faith in him to waver. But as the months of torment drag on on, OliverÃ¢ÂÂs binges grow more varied and reckless. Bock is unflinching here in his depiction of failures of the body and the spirit. Alice  Oliver is both haunting and raw  Ã¢ÂÂ   a rare novel about cancer that, in this case, doesnÃ¢ÂÂt try to find meaning in serious illness, but rather gives its random malevolence its full due.
Title: This Novel DoesnÃ¢ÂÂt Find Meaning In Cancer, It Gives Its Malevolence Full Due

Content: The KQED podcast Love in the Digital Age  explores Ã¢ÂÂhow technology changes the way we experience love, friendship, intimacy and connection.Ã¢ÂÂ The most recent episode focuses on two people  Ã¢ÂÂ   a Los Angeles radio host and his wife  Ã¢ÂÂ   who have drawn great strength from their online communities and social media as they face his diagnosis of terminal cancer. You can listen to the podcast here. Felicia Friesema had seen the signs of brain cancer before. Her husband, Steve Julian, wasnÃ¢ÂÂt just forgetting his keys on the kitchen counter, or having another of the myriad brain farts we often associate with middle age. HeÃ¢ÂÂd stop in the middle of a sentence, like heÃ¢ÂÂd just hit a brick wall. And that was that. Ã¢ÂÂIt wasnÃ¢ÂÂt that kind of gradual onset that AlzheimerÃ¢ÂÂs is,Ã¢ÂÂ Friesema recalls. Ã¢ÂÂIt didnÃ¢ÂÂt sound or feel like dementia. This was so sudden  Ã¢ÂÂ   and it was very eerily similar to what happened to my aunt, my tia Gloria,Ã¢ÂÂ Friesema says. This time, the loved one with cancer was her husband. Over the years, theyÃ¢ÂÂve built a cozy life together in a sweet, spacious home in Highland Park, a neighborhood in northeast Los Angeles. SheÃ¢ÂÂs head of marketing for Foothill Transit. And Julian is one of a handful of trusted voices helping Angelenos navigate the freeways every day, as morning anchor for a public radio station,  . In his off hours, heÃ¢ÂÂd been active for years in local theater as an actor, writer and director. Now, he was having trouble navigating his way through a sentence. Ã¢ÂÂTechnically, all tumors are operable,Ã¢ÂÂ Friesema explains. Ã¢ÂÂThe question that comes into play is, what are you willing to sacrifice in order to get it out? The position and location of his tumor is such that you would have to completely destroy a lot of healthy brain tissue in order to remove it. You would be creating a situation of paralysis, major cognitive dysfunction, irreversible brain damage  Ã¢ÂÂ   and, ultimately, for possibly very little reward. ThereÃ¢ÂÂs no way of skirting it: I was looking at his death.Ã¢ÂÂ Around Thanksgiving last year, Julian was diagnosed with terminal brain cancer at the age of 57. They decided not to try to stretch his last months with chemo and radiation therapy. Julian has less time than he might have, but he can eat what he wants, sleep with their dogs, and squeeze the last juice out of the days that remain with his wife. SheÃ¢ÂÂs taking time off from work, thanks to a compassionate boss. In the 20 or more hours a day that Julian now sleeps, Friesema takes care of everything else  Ã¢ÂÂ   the meals, the housekeeping, the medicine, insurance and the emotional management. Of course, friends and family are helping. Larry Mantle, JulianÃ¢ÂÂs dearest pal, comes over for company and a wee dram of whiskey. Friends have delivered dozens of lasagnas to the doorstep and whipped out their credit cards to cover what insurance doesnÃ¢ÂÂt. But at the end of the day, Friesema is alone. And every morning, thereÃ¢ÂÂs a little bit less of Julian. Reaching Out Online, It was a few months into his diagnosis when we noticed Felicia FriesemaÃ¢ÂÂs journal on Caring Bridge, a website designed to help families and friends of someone who is ill give updates and get them, and offer and receive encouragement. We recognized a kindred spirit in Friesema  Ã¢ÂÂ   someone else in the special club of those who have lost or who are losing a close loved one. We had to fly down to Los Angeles and meet this woman who wrote so deeply and thoughtfully, and with such compassion, about a journey no one chooses. Ã¢ÂÂI know that this is treacherous ground we walk on and that time is of the essence. We wake up to the juxtaposition of joy in another day together and terror at what may come. Ã¢ÂÂThere is no detailed prognosis yet. But we do know that there is no outcome we like. And I have never been so scared. But I have also never been so completely full of love for him.Ã¢ÂÂ That was Dec. 2, 2015. At that point, Steve Julian could still help his wife craft a communique to friends: Ã¢ÂÂI miss being at work and in the studio. I miss being with all the people I love at KPCC. IÃ¢ÂÂm still good at traffic. We chose UCLA for the surgery and treatment, and navigating to the westside can be tricky. The tumor can take away what I had for dinner, but not my memory of the traffic jams IÃ¢ÂÂve sat in. Ã¢ÂÂI am sad. I feel the unfairness of all of this. But I also feel the love for my wife, which grows every day as she balances the technical work of our affairs with the emotional work of our daily life. Like making sure I eat three solid meals. And I mean really solid. Four, sometimes. She tells me IÃ¢ÂÂm loved about a hundred times a day  Ã¢ÂÂ   I remember a few of them. Larry [Mantle, host of Air Talk] my brother in all but blood, is a rock for both of us and has been by our side from diagnosis until now.Ã¢ÂÂ Many people facing down the gun barrel of something this awful retreat into family. But Friesema reached out from the beginning to friends online. Ã¢ÂÂWe kind of had to,Ã¢ÂÂ she explains. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂve kind of got a unique and peculiar situation. I mean, JulianÃ¢ÂÂs a very popular radio host in a very large market. HeÃ¢ÂÂs also incredibly involved in the theater community here. He also used to be a cop. So, you have these seemingly disparate communities that heÃ¢ÂÂs connected to. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs thousands of people  Ã¢ÂÂ   his most intimate friends all the way down to the casual listener.Ã¢ÂÂ From the peace and quiet of their home on the hill, when Julian is sleeping, Friesema can write about all the medical details that would exhaust her if she had to repeat them to people in one individual conversation after another. Friesema also uses the blog to process whatÃ¢ÂÂs happening in her world, Ã¢ÂÂto take this jumbled   of   notes and ideas and thoughts and put them together into something that is like, Ã¢ÂÂOh! OK.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂUsually, I donÃ¢ÂÂt know when IÃ¢ÂÂm going to conclude until I start writing,Ã¢ÂÂ she says, Ã¢ÂÂand by the end of it, IÃ¢ÂÂm like, Ã¢ÂÂOh, thatÃ¢ÂÂs my Ã¢ÂÂahaÃ¢ÂÂ moment. OK. All right.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ On Facebook, for a smaller, closer audience, Friesema shares   missives from her daily journey  Ã¢ÂÂ   proof the bees in the backyard are making Ã¢ÂÂSo. Much. Honey.Ã¢ÂÂ Or her desperate wish that MRI machines played Brian Eno instead of frightening clicks and buzzes. Her rage against the insurance company, or her pride in yet another crazy, beautiful meal made for Julian. And then there are the jokes. If anything, staring down death has heightened the coupleÃ¢ÂÂs sense of humor. Ã¢ÂÂFun with brain cancer: Ã¢ÂÂSteve: Jen! Me: Yeah, babe (knowing full well he was calling for me). Steve: Oh, IÃ¢ÂÂm sorry. I just called you Jen. Me: Yeah, I know, babe. ItÃ¢ÂÂs OK. WhatÃ¢ÂÂs up? Steve: (tells me some stuff he needs). Me: No problem. By the way (smiling) IÃ¢ÂÂd like to know who the hell Jen is. Steve: (chuckles) So would I!Ã¢ÂÂ The love has come pouring in from all corners. By Jan. 4, Friesema reported that more than 100 people had made deliveries, run errands or completed tasks around the house. JulianÃ¢ÂÂs had a sandwich named after him at Wax Paper, a local sandwich shop with a thing for public radio. Friends have blogged about Julian. Local Morning Edition hosts across the country recorded their well wishes on YouTube. People Ã¢ÂÂare grateful for being included,Ã¢ÂÂ Friesema says, Ã¢ÂÂor grateful just to know that SteveÃ¢ÂÂs OK for now. Or theyÃ¢ÂÂre grateful for an opportunity to help. IÃ¢ÂÂd been crying so hard just a few days ago. I just couldnÃ¢ÂÂt stop. I was so sad and so dejected. And, at the end of the day, my status update on Facebook was, Ã¢ÂÂThere just arenÃ¢ÂÂt enough tissues in the box.Ã¢ÂÂ So, the next day, what arrives on my doorstep but a case of Kleenex. And the message was, Ã¢ÂÂWe know that this isnÃ¢ÂÂt enough, but hopefully it helps.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂOne of the things weÃ¢ÂÂve been focusing on,Ã¢ÂÂ Friesema says, Ã¢ÂÂis making sure that every day is about some kind of pleasure  Ã¢ÂÂ   some kind of happy moment, some laugh, something in there that actually makes the day not a routine of caregiving.Ã¢ÂÂ Friesema sighs. Ã¢ÂÂYou know, something that reminds us that there are all these wonderful pieces to life and that living doesnÃ¢ÂÂt stop with a cancer diagnosis.Ã¢ÂÂ What remains online from this journey is a whole lot more than the testament to the love that people have for Steve Julian and Felicia Friesema. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a social network  Ã¢ÂÂ   in the best sense  Ã¢ÂÂ   that will be there for Friesema, waiting to engage and respond anytime she wants. This story was produced by The California Report at KQED, with production support from California ReportÃ¢ÂÂs LA Bureau Chief Steven Cuevas.
Title: Online Comfort For Real-World Cancer Can Be Surprisingly Sweet

Content: WeÃ¢ÂÂve made great progress treating people who are infected with HIV, but if they get cancer theyÃ¢ÂÂre less likely to get the care they need, a recent study found. Researchers examined treatment for a variety of cancers, including upper gastrointestinal tract, colorectal, prostate, lung, head and neck, cervix, breast, anal and two blood cancers. With the exception of anal cancer, treatment rates differed significantly between   people and those who werenÃ¢ÂÂt infected, according to the study published online Tuesday by the journal Cancer. For example, a third of patients with HIV and lung cancer failed to receive any treatment for the cancer, compared with 14 percent of those who were  . Similarly, 44 percent of people who were   didnÃ¢ÂÂt receive treatment for upper GI cancer versus 18 percent of those who werenÃ¢ÂÂt infected with HIV.   percent of men with prostate cancer who were   didnÃ¢ÂÂt get treatment, compared with 7 percent of men uninfected with HIV. Cancer treatment was defined as radiation, chemotherapy   surgery. Ã¢ÂÂTo have made such great strides with treating HIV only to have them succumb to cancer is devastating,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Gita Suneja, a radiation oncologist at the University of UtahÃ¢ÂÂs Huntsman Cancer Institute in Salt Lake City and the lead author of the study. The study used the National Cancer Data Base to analyze treatment for adults younger than 65 who were diagnosed with any of the 10 most common cancers to affect HIV patients between 2003 and 2011. The study included 10, 265   adults and 2. 2 million without HIV. The database, which is sponsored by the American Cancer Society and the American College of Surgeons, captures roughly 70 percent of newly diagnosed cancer cases in the United States. The study noted that more than a third of the patients with HIV had stage 4 cancer  Ã¢ÂÂ   cancer that has metastasized  Ã¢ÂÂ   when they were diagnosed, while only 19 percent of those without HIV did. Improvements in antiretroviral therapy to treat HIV have helped reduce the incidence of cancers such as Kaposi sarcoma that are closely linked to AIDS. But rates for other cancers often associated with normal aging have increased among HIV patients. In addition, people with HIV have a higher incidence of some   cancers, such as lung cancer, which could be linked to higher rates of smoking. Cancer is now the second most common cause of death among   people, behind   causes. HIV patients are more likely to be uninsured or underinsured, and lack of coverage can affect access to cancer care. But having insurance didnÃ¢ÂÂt eliminate the problem: Privately insured people with HIV were significantly more likely to be untreated for many cancers than were privately insured people without HIV, the study found. Ã¢ÂÂWe know that people with Medicaid or who are uninsured receive subpar cancer treatment, and thatÃ¢ÂÂs a big public health issue,Ã¢ÂÂ said Suneja. Ã¢ÂÂBut even factoring that in,   people are still less likely to receive cancer treatment. That means there are other drivers that we couldnÃ¢ÂÂt measure in the study.Ã¢ÂÂ Disparities in cancer treatment could exist for several reasons. For one thing, for most cancers there are no national treatment guidelines for   patients, Suneja said. One of the few exceptions is anal cancer, the only cancer for which the study found little discrepancy in treatment among   and uninfected patients. According to the research, the difference among those not receiving treatment was 4. 8 percent for HIV patients versus 3. 1 percent for others. For other cancers, Ã¢ÂÂthe oncologist may pause and ask, Ã¢ÂÂDoes the HIV infection mean they shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt get standard cancer treatment?Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Suneja added. Kaiser Health News is an editorially independent news service that is part of the nonpartisan Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. Michelle Andrews is on Twitter: @mandrews110.
Title: People With HIV Are Less Likely To Get Needed Cancer Treatment

Content: Sharon BelvinÃ¢ÂÂs nightmare with cancer began in 2004, when she was just 22. Belvin was an avid runner but said she suddenly found she couldnÃ¢ÂÂt climb the stairs without Ã¢ÂÂa lot of difficulty breathing.Ã¢ÂÂ Eventually, after months of fruitless treatments for lung ailments like bronchitis, she was diagnosed with melanoma  Ã¢ÂÂ   a very serious skin cancer. It had already spread to her lungs, and the prognosis was grim. She had about a   chance of surviving the next six months. Ã¢ÂÂYeah, that was the turning point of life, right there,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. What Belvin didnÃ¢ÂÂt know at the time was that a revolutionary treatment for melanoma had begun testing in clinical trials. An immunologist named Jim Allison, now at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, had figured out that if the immune system was tweaked just right, it could do a better job of killing the cancer than the usual treatments. (Joe Palca worked for Allison early in both menÃ¢ÂÂs careers.) AllisonÃ¢ÂÂs treatment was still experimental, but if it worked, it had the potential to save BelvinÃ¢ÂÂs life. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a new modality for treating cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Samuel Broder, a former director of the National Cancer Institute, says now of AllisonÃ¢ÂÂs pioneering research. Ã¢ÂÂIt used to be there were three basic treatment options for cancer  Ã¢ÂÂ   surgery, radiation and chemotherapy  Ã¢ÂÂ   or some combination of those three. ItÃ¢ÂÂs fair to say thereÃ¢ÂÂs now a fourth option.Ã¢ÂÂ AllisonÃ¢ÂÂs long search for this new kind of treatment  Ã¢ÂÂ   one that has since become a lifesaver for some cancer patients  Ã¢ÂÂ   began around a decade before Belvin got sick, when Allison was running a lab at the University of California, Berkeley. At the time, he was what you could call a research scientistÃ¢ÂÂs research scientist. He was fascinated by certain powerful cells of the immune system  Ã¢ÂÂ   T cells. A subset of white blood cells, T cells travel around the body and can Ã¢ÂÂprotect us against just about anything,Ã¢ÂÂ Allison says. T cells do recognize cancer cells, but not in a way that can eliminate the disease. Allison had been studying T cells for years, and thought that by tinkering with one key molecule on the outside of these cells, he could enhance their response to cancer, enough to eradicate the illness. He and one of his grad students ran an experiment to test the tweaked T cells on cancerous tumors in mice, and the initial results astounded them. The T cells seemed to be doing just what Allison had hoped they would do  Ã¢ÂÂ   shrink the tumors and kill the cancer. Allison repeated the experiment with more mice over his winter break. After a few tense days, the tumors again disappeared. Ã¢ÂÂThese mice were cured,Ã¢ÂÂ Allison says. Cancer cured? Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve been doing this sort of stuff for years, and IÃ¢ÂÂd never seen anything like that,Ã¢ÂÂ Allison says. Ã¢ÂÂAnd I thought, Ã¢ÂÂIf we could do that in people, this is going to be amazing.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Allison tried to persuade drugmakers to create a human version of the treatment that had worked in mice. He thought they would jump at the chance to try a new approach. But the biotech companies he met with didnÃ¢ÂÂt bite. In those days, most firms were focused on drugs that would target tumors directly, and Allison was asking them to try something very different. Ã¢ÂÂThis was targeting the immune system, not the cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂWe werenÃ¢ÂÂt trying to kill the cancer cells. We were letting the T cells kill the cancer cells.Ã¢ÂÂ Thanks, but no thanks, the companies told him. Ã¢ÂÂI got very depressed,Ã¢ÂÂ Allison says. He was sure this was the most important work of his career, but he had to get others on board. Eventually, a scientist attending one of AllisonÃ¢ÂÂs research talks was intrigued enough to contact a pal at the biotech firm Medarex. The company had recently developed technology that could make a human version of AllisonÃ¢ÂÂs therapy, and was willing to give it a try. It took a decade, but eventually AllisonÃ¢ÂÂs big idea was ready for testing in people. A clinical trial to study the drug  Ã¢ÂÂ   now called ipilimumab, or Ippy for short  Ã¢ÂÂ   was set up at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. Allison decided he wanted to be part of this next chapter in the testing of immunotherapy, so he packed up his California lab and moved it to Sloan Kettering. As it happens, Belvin was also in New York  Ã¢ÂÂ   a patient of Dr. Jedd Wolchok at Sloan Kettering. By the fall of 2004, Belvin had run through all the treatment options available to her. Nothing had worked to control the melanoma it continued to spread dangerously throughout her body. Belvin remembers feeling sick and depressed, and says she wasnÃ¢ÂÂt even paying much attention when Wolchok walked into the exam room and suggested one last treatment. Ã¢ÂÂSharon, we have an opportunity to participate in a clinical trial here. ItÃ¢ÂÂs something you should consider,Ã¢ÂÂ Wolchok told her. Belvin says she signed up without hesitation. After just four injections of Ippy across three months, her cancer was nearly gone. And at BelvinÃ¢ÂÂs   appointment a year later, Wolchok delivered news that was hard for her to take in: Ã¢ÂÂSharon, you no longer have cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ And in the next breath, Belvin recalls, Ã¢ÂÂhe goes, Ã¢ÂÂOh, the guy who invented this is upstairs. Do you want to meet him?Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂYes, of course I want to meet him!Ã¢ÂÂ she told her doctor. Wolchok called Allison, who was working nearby, and told him to drop everything and come to the clinic  Ã¢ÂÂ   a part of the hospital Allison had rarely seen. Though the research scientist couldnÃ¢ÂÂt imagine why Wolchok was in such a rush, he quickly figured it out as he opened the door and was greeted by Belvin with a huge hug. Belvin says she tried not to tackle him. Ã¢ÂÂIt was hard to control myself,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. Ã¢ÂÂI owe this man my life.Ã¢ÂÂ Belvin was the first recipient of the immunotherapy that Allison had ever met. Ã¢ÂÂIt really meant a lot,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂIt reminded me what itÃ¢ÂÂs all about at the end of the day.Ã¢ÂÂ That was in 2005 today, Sharon Belvin is still  . Ippy is now sold under the brand name Yervoy by   Squibb, which bought Medarex in 2009. Meanwhile, Jim Allison has become a bit of a celebrity in the cancer research world. Among other honors, he was a 2015 recipient of the prestigious Lasker Award for his achievements in medical science. HeÃ¢ÂÂs become   among patients, too. Now and again, Allison fields calls from patients yearning to learn from the master himself what it will take to cure their disease. Allison canÃ¢ÂÂt really answer them. Each case is different, and using a patientÃ¢ÂÂs own cells to destroy tumors wonÃ¢ÂÂt work in every patient or in every type of cancer. Still, the approach offers promise to some people that other therapies canÃ¢ÂÂt, and has transformed the way doctors think about cancer treatment. It might be too early to say weÃ¢ÂÂre going to cure cancer, Allison says, Ã¢ÂÂbut weÃ¢ÂÂre going to cure certain types of cancers. WeÃ¢ÂÂve got a shot at it now.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: A ScientistÃ¢ÂÂs Dream Fulfilled: Harnessing The Immune System To Fight Cancer

Content: In 1975, I was living in San Diego and needed a job. The roommate of a friend of mine was a scientist at Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation. He said a colleague of his was looking to hire a lab technician, so I applied and got the job. The scientist I worked for was some guy from a small town in Texas. His name? Jim Allison. Jim has invented a new kind of cancer therapy that enables patientsÃ¢ÂÂ own immune systems to fight off their disease. HeÃ¢ÂÂs won all kinds of awards for his work, and some say heÃ¢ÂÂll win the Nobel Prize before long. But in 1975, he was just my boss. I spent a year under JimÃ¢ÂÂs direction concentrating a protein called   from human serum. The idea was to get enough of it to see what amino acids it was made from.   is a part of the immune system thatÃ¢ÂÂs key to rejecting any foreign substances that enter the body. But Jim was also my pal. We ate lunch together almost every day. WeÃ¢ÂÂd go drinking together after work. We were regulars at a   called the Stingaree that had live music. Jim was particularly fond of outlaw country music  Ã¢ÂÂ   artists like Waylon Jennings, Jerry Jeff Walker, Kris Kristofferson, Gary P. Nunn and especially Willie Nelson. Jim was a nut about Nelson. One night, he crashed a record party being held in San Diego for NelsonÃ¢ÂÂs album Red Headed Stranger. Never shy, Jim went over and talked to Nelson, told him he was a fellow Texan and how much he liked his music. Nelson asked Jim if there was someplace he and the band could play after the party, so Jim took them up to the Stingaree, where it was open mic night. Nelson and the band played until the bar closed. They even let Jim sit in with his harmonica on a set or two. Jim was on cloud nine for at least a week after that night. Although Jim liked to party, he was all business at work. He was always ready to talk science. He was also competitive and was eager to publish results ahead of other scientists working on  . I left my job with Jim in 1976 to pursue my own doctorate degree. When I later became a science journalist, Jim and I would bump into each other occasionally. He once tried to explain to me about the work he was doing with the immune system and cancer, but I have to confess I didnÃ¢ÂÂt grasp its importance. When Rebecca Davis and I went to interview Jim in his lab at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, where he now works, he was keen to tell me about his work, but equally keen to tell me about something that had just landed in his lap. Mickey Raphael, who plays harmonica in Willie NelsonÃ¢ÂÂs band, had read about Jim (and his promising cancer therapy) in a Texas paper. The article mentioned JimÃ¢ÂÂs fondness for Nelson, and that he had once played with the band back in the Ã¢ÂÂ70s. Raphael was appreciative of JimÃ¢ÂÂs work because he had lost his wife to cancer, and wanted to do something nice for Jim. So in what Raphael described as Ã¢ÂÂa reverse Make a WishÃ¢ÂÂ move, he asked Jim to sit in again with the band when they played a gig in Houston. You can see the results. If Jim does win the Nobel Prize one of these days, I can tell you that appearing on stage with the king of Sweden to receive the prize is not likely to eclipse the pleasure Jim got from appearing on stage with Willie Nelson.
Title: Cancer Scientist Jams With Willie Nelson One More Time

Content: Ã¢ÂÂBig dataÃ¢ÂÂ is a very   kind of buzzword, which ambiguously invokes the idea of using large sets of data to draw   conclusions about trends, patterns and correlations, often about people and their behavior. But if you wanted to trace the origin of using big data for health research, youÃ¢ÂÂd have to go back  Ã¢ÂÂ   way back, to   England. There, youÃ¢ÂÂll find a haberdasher by the name of John Graunt, who undertook a peculiar project. He began to study   bills of mortality, death records kept during the   times, and compiled death details into tables, noting age, gender, cause, location and time. This vital statistics research later turned into a 1662 tome. It marked a seminal moment in demography, the statistical study of populations, but also in epidemiology, the study of what causes diseases and how they spread among different groups of people. Ã¢ÂÂIt was totally groundbreaking for its time. It was a much larger scale of looking at trends in disease than anyone had looked at previously,Ã¢ÂÂ says Stephen Mooney, an epidemiologist at Columbia UniversityÃ¢ÂÂs Mailman School of Public Health. Ã¢ÂÂAt some point you have to think about what it means to put together a table and look at patterns in  Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂFor the time, that was big data.Ã¢ÂÂ Of course, the groundbreaking big data of today is a far cry from   tables. It allows researchers to use   computers to query billions of digital records we leave in our wake on social media, on our wearable devices, in our search history  Ã¢ÂÂ   our Ã¢ÂÂdigital exhaust,Ã¢ÂÂ as Boston ChildrenÃ¢ÂÂs Hospital Chief Innovation Officer John Brownstein puts it. And isnÃ¢ÂÂt that a good thing? The promise of big data for modern health is much extolled. This week came the latest feat. Scientists at Microsoft published a study showing that Web search queries (on MicrosoftÃ¢ÂÂs Bing search engine) may hold clues to a future diagnosis of pancreatic cancer, one of the fastest and most fatal. In essence what Microsoft researchers did was this: They studied millions of anonymized searches on MicrosoftÃ¢ÂÂs Bing to find queries suggestive of a userÃ¢ÂÂs recent diagnosis, such as Ã¢ÂÂWhy did I get cancer in pancreasÃ¢ÂÂ or Ã¢ÂÂJust diagnosed with pancreatic cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ They then backtracked the digital footprints left by the same computer to locate searches for earlier symptoms of the disease, and to create a statistical model that they say could predict 5 percent to 15 percent of the ultimate diagnoses based on earlier search activity, with pretty low false positives. Ã¢ÂÂMy take is that itÃ¢ÂÂs exciting but preliminary,Ã¢ÂÂ says Mooney, who has studied the use of big data in public health. Ã¢ÂÂThe potential benefit is huge,Ã¢ÂÂ he says, but Ã¢ÂÂit would be easy to naively assume we know more about this than we do.Ã¢ÂÂ ItÃ¢ÂÂs one thing to detect early digital clues to a diagnosis, but another to actually prevent or delay a death. The Microsoft scientists themselves acknowledge this in the study. Ã¢ÂÂClinical trials are necessary to understand whether our learned model has practical utility, including in combination with other screening methods,Ã¢ÂÂ they write. Therein lies the crux of this big data future: ItÃ¢ÂÂs a logical progression for the modern   world, but one that will continue to require the solid grounding of a traditional health professional, to steer data toward usefulness, to avoid unwarranted anxiety or even unnecessary testing, and to zero in on actual causes, not just correlations within particular health trends. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs why I think, if you talk to a lot of epidemiologists, they may be suspicious of some of these big   approaches,Ã¢ÂÂ says Mooney, Ã¢ÂÂbecause theyÃ¢ÂÂd be concerned that thereÃ¢ÂÂs a loss of attention to causation.Ã¢ÂÂ The most   lesson in failed causation was Google Flu Trends. In 2008, Google researchers decided to measure flu activity, in real time, based on usersÃ¢ÂÂ Web searches. It was a   project and worked well  Ã¢ÂÂ   for a while. Academic researchers who later did a postmortem on the project, David Lazer and Ryan Kennedy, wrote in Wired magazine: Ã¢ÂÂGFT failed  Ã¢ÂÂ   and failed spectacularly  Ã¢ÂÂ   missing at the peak of the 2013 flu season by 140 percent. . .. Ã¢ÂÂWhile GoogleÃ¢ÂÂs efforts in projecting the flu were well meaning, they were remarkably opaque in terms of method and data  Ã¢ÂÂ   making it dangerous to rely on Google Flu Trends for any  . Ã¢ÂÂFor example, GoogleÃ¢ÂÂs algorithm was quite vulnerable to overfitting to seasonal terms unrelated to the flu, like Ã¢ÂÂhigh school basketball.Ã¢ÂÂ . .. There were bound to be searches that were strongly correlated by pure chance, and these terms were unlikely to be driven by actual flu cases or predictive of future trends.Ã¢ÂÂ The projectÃ¢ÂÂs failure, however, does not negate the promise of big data in health. Beyond analyses of   trends, capturing passively created data on peopleÃ¢ÂÂs sentiments, mental ups and downs, things you may not ever think to bring up with your physician can be Ã¢ÂÂvery powerful,Ã¢ÂÂ Brownstein says. (Of course, with proper privacy and security protections in mind.) Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs not data that can be used in a silo, itÃ¢ÂÂs one gear in the system,Ã¢ÂÂ he says, Ã¢ÂÂso itÃ¢ÂÂs not like this holy grail. ItÃ¢ÂÂs just data that can be used, that can be harnessed, in conjunction with other types of information strains.Ã¢ÂÂ To Mooney, Google Flu Trends was a case of a hype cycle, Ã¢ÂÂthis concept that technologies get overhyped and then are disappointing, but sometime after the disappointment, can often return to a sort of plateau of usefulness.Ã¢ÂÂ And in that is a lesson on big data in health: It deserves both enthusiasm and caution. Ã¢ÂÂIdeally, IÃ¢ÂÂd like people to embrace both of them,Ã¢ÂÂ says Mooney, Ã¢ÂÂto recognize that itÃ¢ÂÂs exciting and concerning at the same time. Because the world is messy and itÃ¢ÂÂs possible to be exciting and concerning at the same time.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Can Web Search Predict Cancer? Promise And Worry Of Big Data And Health

Content: If coffee is your favorite morning    read on. The World Health OrganizationÃ¢ÂÂs cancer research agency has given coffee the green light. The group concludes that coffee does not pose a cancer risk, and experts say a regular coffee habit may even be protective of good health. So, youÃ¢ÂÂd never heard that there had been concern of a cancer risk from coffee? Yeah, that makes lots of us. In 1991, the World Health OrganizationÃ¢ÂÂs International Agency for Research on Cancer listed coffee as a possible carcinogen. This classification was based on what the IARC says was Ã¢ÂÂlimited evidenceÃ¢ÂÂ that coffee was associated with a higher risk of bladder cancer. But over the past 25 years, the body of evidence has pointed in a new direction. Ã¢ÂÂMany epidemiological studies now available showed that coffee drinking had no carcinogenic effects for cancers,Ã¢ÂÂ the IARC statement concludes. Researchers reviewed more than 500 studies on more than 20 different types of cancers. The group concludes that coffee may in fact help protect against the risk of cancers of the liver and uterus. In addition, coffee consumption has been associated with a reduced risk of colorectal cancer in a number of studies. As weÃ¢ÂÂve reported, a regular coffee habit has also been linked to longevity and a reduced risk of diabetes. One word of caution: The agency warns that extremely hot beverages may increase the risk of cancer. For instance, the group looked at studies from South America where mate is consumed at very hot temperatures. Ã¢ÂÂEpidemiological studies found that cancer of the esophagus is associated with drinking mate at very hot temperatures but not with drinking mate warm or cold,Ã¢ÂÂ the IARC concludes. The researchers also point to studies of tea in Asian countries, including China, that found the risk of esophageal cancer may increase with temperature. The group concludes that the   effects probably occur at drinking temperatures of 150 degrees Fahrenheit and above. So, enjoy that cup of Joe  Ã¢ÂÂ   but not too hot.
Title: Java Lovers, Rejoice: Coffee DoesnÃ¢ÂÂt Pose A Cancer Risk, WHO Panel Says

Content: Growing up in South Carolina, soul singer Sharon Jones knew from the first time she sang in her churchÃ¢ÂÂs Christmas play that she would be a musician. Ã¢ÂÂI was, like, maybe 8, 9 years old . .. and I got to sing Ã¢ÂÂSilent Night,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ she tells Fresh Air host Terry Gross. Jones remembers audience members taking note of her performance. Ã¢ÂÂRight then and there,Ã¢ÂÂ she says, Ã¢ÂÂI knew that I was going to be a singer. God had blessed me with a gift.Ã¢ÂÂ Now the lead singer for the soul group, The   Jones is inspired by the classic soul and RB she grew up with. The band, which recorded its first album in 2001, is known for its energetic showmanship and Ã¢ÂÂ  soul revue shows. In 2013, Jones was forced to take a hiatus from performing after she was diagnosed with stage 2 pancreatic cancer. A new documentary, Miss Sharon Jones! by Academy   filmmaker Barbara Kopple, follows Jones in the first seven months following her diagnosis. Jones says that while extensive surgery and chemotherapy took a lot out of her, her desire to make music never faltered. After finishing chemo, recovering from the surgery and getting clean scans, she returned to the stage with The   in 2014. The cancer has since returned, but Jones wants to continue making music. Ã¢ÂÂThis cancer is here, and I have to take the chemo,Ã¢ÂÂ she says, Ã¢ÂÂbut I want to perform. I just want to be able to get onstage and move.Ã¢ÂÂ On not listening to music while she was sick, I didnÃ¢ÂÂt. I didnÃ¢ÂÂt. Because I couldnÃ¢ÂÂt sing. I couldnÃ¢ÂÂt get air because, people didnÃ¢ÂÂt realize, I was cut across the diaphragm, all the way up from right under the center under my breasts, all the way down to the top of my navel, almost. They had to cut through the diaphragm, through the stomach, remove stuff. They removed like 10 pounds of things . .. 10 pounds that I never gained back. On when she realized that she would eventually get back onstage  I had a February date, and my goal was to be back at that date. And everything in the filming, thereÃ¢ÂÂs a scene with the church scene, that was my first time even attempting to sing after months. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs when I knew, from the church scene, that I was ready. I was going to be ready for February. I knew I was going to have the strength. I knew that sickness wasnÃ¢ÂÂt unto to death. I thought I was going to die maybe a couple of hours after the doctor hit me with everything. You know, you go through that. So for a couple of hours I was on my deathbed. But other than that, I overcame that. Doing the film was also my therapy, and I knew that it would help someone out there with cancer, or going through it, as long as I inspired someone. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs where my health came from, my energy came from, knowing my fans was out there and IÃ¢ÂÂm getting back to them, and I wanted them to see what IÃ¢ÂÂm going through. On getting back onstage the first time after her treatment for pancreatic cancer, The night I went out there, it was a different Sharon, because the hair is gone. That energy, I mean, everyone said my energy was great, but I didnÃ¢ÂÂt feel it at all. Even now, the days on the stage IÃ¢ÂÂm just not myself, I donÃ¢ÂÂt have that energy. The legs doesnÃ¢ÂÂt lift up like I want to with the pain, the neuropathy from certain chemo. ItÃ¢ÂÂs a hinder, but I do the shows, but itÃ¢ÂÂs not the same. On how she and   songwriter Gabriel Roth create songs together  I just take the music and hear his idea and then I go with it from there. You know, basically he gives me what he thinks, but I have to do it my way, because IÃ¢ÂÂm the soul singer. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre not soul singers, so you canÃ¢ÂÂt teach me how to sing soul. You can tell me where to go, just allow me to be myself. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs what we have there with these guys. A couple of times they got in they thought they had to try to give me some tracks and stuff, and I nipped that in the bud right away. Listening to somebody else singing, IÃ¢ÂÂm trying to go where they goinÃ¢ÂÂ and thatÃ¢ÂÂs not where I would go. I would go nowhere, sing that song. You could get five singers in here and each one of us is going to sing that song differently. Just let me be me. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs how weÃ¢ÂÂve gotten where we are today, at Daptone [Records] by them letting me sing the way I feel it.
Title: Soul Singer Sharon Jones: Ã¢ÂÂThe Cancer Is Here, But I Want To PerformÃ¢ÂÂ

Content: A bone from a human ancestor that died between 1. 8 million and 1. 6 million years ago shows evidence of cancer, a newly published study finds. It is the oldest known example of a malignant tumor in a human ancestor. The bone belonged to a hominin, an extinct relative of modern humans that lived and died in what is now South Africa. The foot bone, specifically the metatarsal that runs between the ankle and the pinky toe, was originally excavated between 1960 and 1980 from the Swartkrans cave, part of a World Heritage Site in South Africa called the Cradle of Humankind for its many hominin bones. But a malignant tumor in the bone was not immediately apparent. A doctoral student in Florida originally examined the bone as part of an unpublished thesis and noticed the apparent tumor, but concluded it was just a kind of benign mass known as an osteoid osteoma. It wasnÃ¢ÂÂt until two scientists at the Radiography and Tomography Section of the South African Nuclear Energy Corp. examined the bone with a     technique that the conclusion was   the researchers write in their paper published today. They scanned the bone in sections, and another team at the University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg assembled the images of those sections into a detailed   image. In the   cross section, it was clear the mass was not benign. It was a malignant cancer with an Ã¢ÂÂirregular spongy woven bone texture with a   external appearance,Ã¢ÂÂ the authors write. As for what kind of bone cancer, exactly, this human ancestor suffered from, the researchers are not sure, but their best guess is that it was some variety of osteosarcoma. Today, the American Cancer Society says osteosarcoma is the most common type of cancer that develops in bones. This tumor is far from the earliest example of cancer. Evidence of malignant tumors has been found in dinosaur bones. Many scientists believe tumors, which are the result of uncontrolled cell growth, have been around as long as multicellular organisms. Nor is todayÃ¢ÂÂs study alone in its finding that cancer is an ancient affliction, rather than a modern scourge caused by polluted environments and poor diets. Egyptian mummies have turned up evidence of prostate cancer from thousands of years ago. Another osteosarcoma appeared in the skull of a medieval man in what is now the Czech Republic. The authors of the most recent study note in their study: Ã¢ÂÂWhilst most modern human malignancies are thought to be caused by environmental agents of a chemical nature, the evidence for this is not entirely conclusive. . .. Ã¢ÂÂWhilst the explosion of malignancy incidence [today] is clearly correlated with the hazards of the modern world and increased life expectancy, primary bone tumors evidently occurred throughout history.Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: Ancient Bone Shows Evidence Of Cancer In Human Ancestor

Content: A major study about the best way to treat   breast cancer reveals that Ã¢ÂÂprecision medicineÃ¢ÂÂ doesnÃ¢ÂÂt provide unambiguous answers about how to choose the best therapy. Ã¢ÂÂPrecision doesnÃ¢ÂÂt mean certainty,Ã¢ÂÂ says David Hunter, a professor of cancer prevention at HarvardÃ¢ÂÂs T. H. Chan School of Public Health. That point is illustrated in a large study published Wednesday in the New England Journal of Medicine, involving decisions about chemotherapy. As is true for many cancers, breast cancer responds best to treatment when it is caught early, before it has spread throughout the body. Dr. Fatima Cardoso, the studyÃ¢ÂÂs lead author and a breast cancer specialist at the Champalimaud Clinical Center in Lisbon, Portugal, says that creates a conundrum for doctors and patients alike. Because itÃ¢ÂÂs the only opportunity to cure the cancer, Ã¢ÂÂwhen in doubt we tend to treatÃ¢ÂÂ women with   breast cancer, she told Shots. Ã¢ÂÂSo we know that we overtreat the patients with early breast cancer.Ã¢ÂÂ That means that women could end up undergoing chemotherapy even if it wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt really improve their survival odds. Hoping to refine those treatment decisions, Cardoso helped organize a huge study throughout Europe to see whether a commercially available genetic test called MammaPrint could help reduce that overtreatment. More than 6, 600 women participated at 112 institutions in nine nations. Scientists identified women with breast cancer whose physical exams suggested they were at relatively high risk for having the cancer return eventually after surgery, but who seemed to be at low risk of recurrence based on the genetic test results. They were invited to participate in the study, which would randomly assign them to have chemotherapy or not. Ã¢ÂÂYou know that chemotherapy is a treatment that scares people, so overall and for the majority of patients, it was not difficult to convince them,Ã¢ÂÂ Cardoso says. The genomic test, which studies 70 distinct features of a tumor, did a pretty good job of predicting who was at low risk for recurrence of breast cancer and could therefore avoid the pain, discomfort and risks of chemotherapy. (The test, priced at $4, 200, is covered by some insurance in the United States.) The scientists found that 46 percent of women who were deemed to be at high risk of recurrence based on physical symptoms could actually skip chemotherapy with little consequence to their   survival. But the test results werenÃ¢ÂÂt always definitive. About 95 percent of women who skipped chemotherapy as a result of the genetic test results were free of metastasis five years later, but those who had the additional treatment did about 1. 5 percentage points better, give or take. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs possible that the benefit is zero, and itÃ¢ÂÂs possible thatÃ¢ÂÂs 2 percent or maybe even a little more, you canÃ¢ÂÂt be sure,Ã¢ÂÂ says Dr. Clifford Hudis, chief executive officer of the American Society of Clinical Oncology. He was not involved in the European study but   an editorial accompanying it. It would take another huge clinical trial to figure out whether chemotherapy does in fact add a small survival advantage. But the study raises a bigger point here: The genomic test, as precise as it is, offers only probabilities, not absolute guidance. And thatÃ¢ÂÂs a lesson that applies to the whole new realm of precision medicine, which is billed as potentially transformative for medical care. Ã¢ÂÂThe new tools will definitely be helpful, but they often will pose challenges about what the right decision is,Ã¢ÂÂ says Hunter, who wrote a perspective piece noting that people will need to develop a tolerance for uncertainty when using precision medicine tests. Is it worth all the trouble of chemotherapy for women who are found to be at low risk for recurrence in this genomic test? ThatÃ¢ÂÂs a tough call, because it requires grasping the rather abstract idea of improving survival odds by maybe just 1 percentage point. Ã¢ÂÂAs humans, weÃ¢ÂÂre notoriously poor at assessing risk and making those calculations,Ã¢ÂÂ Hunter says. He says doctors and patients need better tools to understand and communicate the subtleties that are inherent in precision medicine. Cardoso is already seeing this play out in her clinic. Women shown to be at low genetic risk on the MammaPrint test are usually opting not to have chemotherapy after their surgery. Ã¢ÂÂBut there always [are] some patients for whom 1 percent benefit is enough  Ã¢ÂÂ   and you need to respect the wishes of each individual patient.Ã¢ÂÂ She says the women clearly benefit from the new information, even though it doesnÃ¢ÂÂt provide an absolute answer.
Title: Study Of Breast Cancer Treatment Reveals Paradox Of Precision Medicine

Content: When DNA colon cancer screening tests find abnormalities, are patients discouraged about getting more diagnostic testing because of costs they will incur? And why do hospitals sometimes send a second bill for treatments given in a doctorÃ¢ÂÂs office? Here are the answers. A   DNA test to screen for colon cancer is available that is readily paid for by health plans, including Medicare. But if I have a positive Cologuard test result, IÃ¢ÂÂd have to pay several hundred dollars for a regular diagnostic colonoscopy. DoesnÃ¢ÂÂt this discourage people from getting screened for colon cancer, which is the goal, after all? Patient advocates point to several reasons people may be discouraged from getting tested for colorectal cancer, including the Ã¢ÂÂickÃ¢ÂÂ factor and the time it takes to prepare for and get a colonoscopy, the most common screening test. Ã¢ÂÂBut the No. 1 factor is always cost,Ã¢ÂÂ said Caroline Powers, director of federal relations at the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network. Commercial insurers and the Medicare program cover cancer screenings that are recommended by the U. S. Preventive Services Task Force without requiring any payment by patients. The task force, an independent panel of medical experts, recommends colorectal cancer screening for people from age 50 to 75. Several different types of tests get the thumbs up from the task force, including colonoscopy, in which a flexible tube with a camera is snaked through the colon from the rectum to look for polyps and other abnormalities, and   tests, including the DNA test you mention, which looks for genetic mutations associated with cancer or polyps. But, as you point out, thereÃ¢ÂÂs a potential hitch. If you get a positive test result from a DNA test or other screening method, youÃ¢ÂÂll need to get a   colonoscopy to check whether the test result was correct. Patient advocates have argued that the   colonoscopy should be provided without   by patients, and doctors tell them that some private insurers are beginning to handle the process that way, Powers said. But in Medicare that   test is still considered diagnostic, and seniors are responsible for any deductible and coinsurance charges. Patient advocates continue to lobby for a change to that policy. Ã¢ÂÂFrom a public health perspective, it goes against everything weÃ¢ÂÂre trying to do,Ã¢ÂÂ Powers said. I have carpal tunnel syndrome in both wrists. I visited a hand surgeon at his office who gave me a cortisone shot in my right wrist. His bill was $450, of which my insurance covered $420. But I also received another bill from the hospital with which his practice is affiliated that included a $1, 702 facility fee for which I have a $400  . This seems so unfair. What can I do to avoid owing that charge? There may not be much you can do after the fact. As hospitals continue recent efforts to purchase physician practices, hospital facility fees are increasingly common. In 2014, a third of doctors were either employed by a hospital or worked in practices that were at least partly owned by a hospital, an increase from 29 percent in 2012, according to a study by the American Medical Association. Even if the doctorÃ¢ÂÂs office is located across town, the physician practice essentially becomes part of the hospital, and patients are typically billed for both physician services and hospital facility charges. Starting next year, some hospital facility charges will no longer be allowed. Under the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2015, Medicare will no longer pay hospital facility fees for outpatient services at physician offices that arenÃ¢ÂÂt located on the hospital campus. However, the change will apply only to practices that hospitals acquire after Nov. 15, 2015, and doesnÃ¢ÂÂt affect commercial insurers at all. The best way to protect yourself from unexpected facility fees is to get details from the physicianÃ¢ÂÂs office before you visit, said Richard Gundling, senior vice president at the Healthcare Financial Management Association, a group for professionals in health care finance. That way, you can make an educated decision about whether to proceed before you get a surprise bill. Ã¢ÂÂThe patient should always ask, Ã¢ÂÂWhat is my    cost for this visit? Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ My husbandÃ¢ÂÂs family physician is a member of MDVIP, one of many Ã¢ÂÂconciergeÃ¢ÂÂ practices in which a doctor or group of doctors generally charge an annual fee for faster appointments, more access to the doctor, more time with him during appointments, and preventive services during the annual wellness visit that arenÃ¢ÂÂt included in a regular Medicare annual wellness visit. Is the annual fee of $1, 650 tax deductible? The annual fee is generally tax deductible, said Roy Harris, general counsel at MDVIP. That annual fee covers the cost of an executive physical every year for members, often a checkup with extra bells and whistles such as additional tests or screenings. If people itemize their medical expenses on their income taxes, they can generally deduct the expense as a physical exam. Even if they donÃ¢ÂÂt itemize, many people get reimbursed from their flexible spending accounts or health savings accounts for the annual fee after getting their physical, Harris said. Mark Luscombe, principal federal tax analyst at Wolters Kluwer Tax and Accounting, a software and information services company, agreed, although he noted that the Internal Revenue Service hasnÃ¢ÂÂt weighed in specifically on this issue. Kaiser Health News is an editorially independent news service supported by the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation. You can follow Michelle Andrews on Twitter: @mandrews110.
Title: When A Screening Test For Colon Cancer Leads To A Pricey Follow-Up

Content: What if doctors could call up a computerized map that would show them how a case of cancer is likely to progress? Tumor cells can mutate in unexpected ways. And cancers can suddenly grow. For doctors, anticipating cancerÃ¢ÂÂs next moves can help guide timely, effective patient treatment. A mapping program, called PiCnIc for short, aims to help physicians in staying a step ahead of cancer and preparing   treatment plans with fewer elements of surprise. How does it work? PiCnIc Ã¢ÂÂtakes in patient data, guesses potential scenarios and tells you the most likely scenario,Ã¢ÂÂ says Bud Mishra, a professor at New York UniversityÃ¢ÂÂs Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences who led a multinational team in developing the program. PiCnIc produces maps of cancer progression in much the same way historical explorers drew maps of the Earth without satellite imaging. The program, like the explorers, draws tiny regional maps and then pieces them together like a puzzle. The program extracts the simplest pieces of information from medical data, which Mishra calls Ã¢ÂÂlittle blocks of causality.Ã¢ÂÂ They describe one stage of cancer, along with a potential outcome. Once the blocks of causality are constructed, PiCnIc examines them to retain only the likeliest paths. This process is akin to discarding poorly drawn regional maps before attempting to put together a global map. The end result is a graphical representation of the possible scenarios a cancer patient might encounter. From it, physicians can hypothesize how cancer will progress and plan accordingly. Just like a good cartographer, PiCnIc is capable of drawing all kinds of maps, as long as appropriate medical data are available. Ã¢ÂÂ[PiCnIc] is quite flexible. It can incorporate pretty much any cancer type,Ã¢ÂÂ says Nicholas Navin, a professor at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center who wasnÃ¢ÂÂt involved in the creation of PiCnIc. Navin says that PiCnIc, at its current stage of development, Ã¢ÂÂalready gives [us] enough information to be clinically useful.Ã¢ÂÂ The program can also update the maps to factor in advances in cancer research as well, says Giulio Caravagna, a computational biologist at the University of Edinburgh who participated in the research project. As new medical data become available, researchers can rerun PiCnIc with ease to generate updated maps of cancer. Ã¢ÂÂAnd there is already a pretty good amount of data, like the Cancer Genome Atlas,Ã¢ÂÂ says Caravagna. The research work was published on the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences in late June. Mishra says that he plans to look into Ã¢ÂÂcommercial opportunitiesÃ¢ÂÂ for PiCnIc and collaborations with Ã¢ÂÂlarge research labsÃ¢ÂÂ to improve it. For now, though, the PiCnIc maps Ã¢ÂÂshouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be interpreted too much in making decisions for individual patient,Ã¢ÂÂ says Navin. Ã¢ÂÂWe are a little bit underpowered to comprehensively build these [maps of cancer]. .. there are still little ways to go,Ã¢ÂÂ says Ben Raphael, a computational biologist at Brown University. A cartographer is only as good as the measurements the explorers bring in, after all.
Title: A Map To Help Cancer Doctors Find Their Way

Content: Privately insured people with cancer were diagnosed earlier and lived longer than those who were uninsured or were covered by Medicaid, according to two recent studies. In one study, researchers examined data from more than 13, 600 adult patients who had glioblastoma multiforme, the most common type of malignant brain tumor, between 2007 and 2012. The other study analyzed data from more than 10, 200 adults who were diagnosed with testicular cancer between 2007 and 2011. Both studies, published online in the journal Cancer in August, relied on data from the National Cancer InstituteÃ¢ÂÂs Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results program. SEER tracks cancer incidence and survival in the United States. The two cancers generally progress very differently. Glioblastoma multiforme is very aggressive patients generally donÃ¢ÂÂt live much more than a year following diagnosis and the   survival rate is less than 5 percent. Conversely, testicular cancer responds well to chemotherapy even if it has spread to other parts of the body. The   survival rate overall is 95 percent. But regardless of cancer type, patients with private insurance had a survival advantage. In the testicular cancer study, uninsured patients were 26 percent more likely to be diagnosed with metastatic disease (meaning their cancer had spread elsewhere) than privately insured patients. Medicaid patients were 62 percent more likely to have metastatic disease. Though the Medicaid patients fared worse than the uninsured patients in this regard, that might be because, until recently, some of them, too, had been uninsured, the researchers say, and only enrolled in Medicaid after their cancer was diagnosed. Compared to privately insured men in the study, uninsured men were 88 percent more likely to die of the cancer, and Medicaid patients were 51 percent more likely to die of the disease. A similar pattern emerged in the glioblastoma multiforme study. Patients who were either uninsured or on Medicaid were more likely to have a larger tumor at the time of diagnosis. An uninsured patient was 14 percent more likely to have a shorter survival time than someone who was privately insured, while a patient on Medicaid was 10 percent more likely to have a shorter survival time, the study found. There were some treatment differences, as well, between the patients with private insurance, and those who either had Medicaid or were uninsured. And those treatment differences could affect survival. Ã¢ÂÂWe were expecting that the uninsured would do worse than insured patients, but we didnÃ¢ÂÂt expect that Medicaid patients would do significantly worse than [privately insured] patients,Ã¢ÂÂ said Dr. Wuyang Yang, a research fellow at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, who   the study about patients with brain tumors. Sarah C. Markt, the lead author on the testicular cancer study, says she found the Medicaid results in their study striking as well. The findings indicate that eliminating disparities in cancer care requires more than just expanding Medicaid coverage, says Markt, a research associate in cancer epidemiology at the Harvard T. H. Chan School of Public Health. Under the health law, roughly   of states and the District of Columbia have expanded Medicaid coverage to adults with incomes up to 138 percent of the federal poverty level (about $16, 400). Ã¢ÂÂThese are young men dying of a potentially curable disease,Ã¢ÂÂ Markt says. Ã¢ÂÂThere are many opportunities for improvement here.Ã¢ÂÂ Kaiser Health News is an editorially independent news service that is part of the nonpartisan Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. Michelle Andrews is on Twitter:@mandrews110.
Title: Studies Link Cancer PatientsÃ¢ÂÂ Survival Time To Insurance Status

Content: It was in 1909 that Nobel   German physician Paul Ehrlich proposed the idea that our bodies are fighting constant battles with cancer and that, thankfully, most of the time we win. Ehrlich was a visionary in recognizing the interaction between cancer and the immune system. Specifically, that cancerous cells are continuously arising in the body but that our immune defenses in many if not most cases keep them at bay. Now, after his and related ideas sputtered along for decades, the theory is at the core of one of oncologyÃ¢ÂÂs hottest areas, immunotherapy, or the mobilization of the human immune system to fight malignancy. Few would argue that in just the past few years this field has begun to transform cancer care. Newly approved immunotherapies have increased treatment options and improved patientsÃ¢ÂÂ odds for a variety of tumors, while also allowing many with cancer to avoid, cut back on or delay chemotherapy. Former President Jimmy CarterÃ¢ÂÂs successful treatment for melanoma, including a regimen of immunotherapy along with radiation therapy and surgery, helped push the approach into the public spotlight. Yet immunotherapy has faced some prominent setbacks. In August a clinical trial of the   Squibb drug Opdivo, or nivolumab, for a group of patients with newly diagnosed lung cancer, unexpectedly failed as a   therapy. The announcement shaved $20 billion off the value of   in a single day. Though immunotherapy is generally more tolerable than chemotherapy and radiation, there are side effects to consider. Immunotherapies can cause symptoms like fatigue, nausea and diarrhea and a recent case report review revealed a possible link between the medications and chronic arthritis. And then thereÃ¢ÂÂs the staggering cost, with some immunotherapies running well over $100, 000 a year. The immunotherapy drug Yervoy, also from   is priced at $157. 46 per milligram. Ã¢ÂÂTo put that into perspective, thatÃ¢ÂÂs approximately 4, 000 times the cost of gold,Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Leonard Saltz, of the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, said at last yearÃ¢ÂÂs American Society of Clinical Oncology Annual Meeting. Perhaps the biggest question of all about immunotherapies is why donÃ¢ÂÂt more people respond to them. Data presented at this yearÃ¢ÂÂs American Association for Cancer Research Annual Meeting in April showed that over   of patients with malignant melanoma who were treated with Opdivo were still alive after five years, more than double the   survival rate for metastatic melanoma patients diagnosed between 2005 and 2011 who were treated with standard cancer therapies of the day. Yet as the AACR points out on its blog, Ã¢ÂÂDespite the obvious cause for excitement, this means that about   of patients with metastatic melanoma who were treated with [Opdivo] had cancer that did not respond to the immunotherapeutic or progressed after initially responding.Ã¢ÂÂ And response rates for other tumors tend to be markedly lower: in lung cancer, for example, they hover around 20 percent. Oncologists and scientists are now faced with determining why some patients respond and others donÃ¢ÂÂt, and also how to better predict which treatments are best for which patients. Equally important is understanding how the new treatments should be used with surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation and whether or not, at least in some cases, immunotherapies can replace these more established options altogether. Mobilizing the immune system, In 2016, over a century after Ehrlich first proposed his ideas, immunotherapy takes many forms: There are cancer vaccines, antibody therapies, and drugs that drive the immune system to fight off cancer. But two newer immunotherapy approaches are generating particular buzz. The first involves engineering a patientÃ¢ÂÂs own white blood cells to recognize and attack tumor cells. Called Ã¢ÂÂCAR   therapy,Ã¢ÂÂ itÃ¢ÂÂs still experimental. But it has had some early success for blood cancers like leukemia. Further along are   checkpoint inhibitor therapies. Normally our bodies have what are called immune checkpoints, mechanisms that restrain immune activity so our bodies donÃ¢ÂÂt attack our own tissues or get overly aggressive when fighting infection. The only problem is that cancer can   these off switches by sending out molecular signals that shut down our defenses. Checkpoint inhibitor drugs interrupt the signals cancers use to shield them from the immune system. While earlier immunotherapies broadly activate the immune system, these newer agents specifically boost the activity of a subtype of white blood cell called   which when activated can zero in on and destroy cancer cells. The improved selectivity reduces collateral damage and side effects. There are now four checkpoint inhibitors approved for various cancers  Ã¢ÂÂ   including certain lung and kidney cancers, melanoma and most recently bladder cancer  Ã¢ÂÂ   with trials underway in nearly every major tumor type. In addition to Opdivo, trial data presented at this yearÃ¢ÂÂs ASCO annual meeting in June found another checkpoint inhibitor called Keytruda to be effective in advanced melanoma patients. Of the 655 patients in the study, 40 percent were still alive after three years. Other data presented at the meeting suggest that immunotherapies hold promise in a number of    cancers, including including advanced lung, kidney, bladder and head and neck cancers and Hodgkin lymphoma. Tailoring cancer care, But where do oncologists go from here? Can patient response rates go from improved to impeccable? One way is by identifying biological markers that can predict treatment response in a specific person. Researchers from the University of California, San Francisco recently reported that melanoma patients whose immune cells have higher levels of two checkpoint proteins called   and   respond significantly better to Keytruda therapy. The group is using the finding to determine which patients are more likely to respond to the treatment. Similarly, the 15 percent to 20 percent of colorectal cancer patients with what is called an Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ subtype of tumor respond especially well to immunotherapy. Another, perhaps more grueling method of improving patient response to immunotherapy is methodically determining how to use and sequence the new drugs with the vast armory of other cancer treatment options  Ã¢ÂÂ   and whether, in some cases, they could replace unpleasant stalwarts like chemo altogether. Ã¢ÂÂIn melanoma this has pretty much already happened in many cases. WeÃ¢ÂÂre often using these drugs as   therapy,Ã¢ÂÂ says Dr. Elizabeth Buchbinder, an oncologist at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. Ã¢ÂÂHowever in other tumors itÃ¢ÂÂs a lot more variable and I think in general these will be something to consider alongside the other treatments.Ã¢ÂÂ Buchbinder explains that while melanoma patients treated with a single checkpoint inhibitor see response rates between 30 percent and 40 percent, those rates climb to 60 percent when a second immunotherapy is added. Ã¢ÂÂI think these will become part of a combination of strategies,Ã¢ÂÂ concurs   oncologist Marcel van den Brink. Ã¢ÂÂJust look at chemo. There are almost no situations where one chemotherapy alone would even come close to curing a cancer of any type. The big breakthroughs here came when we carefully figured out combination therapies.Ã¢ÂÂ Improving cancer outcomes will involve personalizing care in a variety of ways. After all, each of our bodies operates  Ã¢ÂÂ   and falls ill  Ã¢ÂÂ   at the hands of its own exclusive biology. But van den Brink is hopeful about the possibility of profiling the microbiota to determine how certain bacteria in the gut can influence cancer immunotherapy. Ã¢ÂÂThe biome can stimulate   all over the body,Ã¢ÂÂ he explains. Ã¢ÂÂMaybe we can come up with a strategy to foster a particular type of bacteria in a particular patient that improves treatment response.Ã¢ÂÂ Genetic interventions will also play an increasing role in customizing cancer care. By sequencing not only the genomes of patients, but those of their tumors and even their immune cells specifically, oncologists will be better able to determine which treatments will work best in which patients. University of Chicago oncologist Jason Luke says oncologists are already trying this. Ã¢ÂÂEven now we can use genetic techniques to look at which genes are turned on in the cancer tissue and to tell us whether immunotherapy is likely to work or not,Ã¢ÂÂ he says, explaining that this technique could help identify patients whose immune system is already Ã¢ÂÂprimed for attackÃ¢ÂÂ and may need only an immunotherapeutic nudge, versus those that might also require chemo and radiation. Luke also believes that tinkering with DNA using genome editing technologies like CRISPR could help doctors not only excise   genes but also improve treatment efficacy. In fact, in June a federal biosafety panel approved the first study of the technique in humans  Ã¢ÂÂ   a study that aims to use the technique to augment cancer immunotherapy by genetically modifying immune cells. Ã¢ÂÂI think eventually weÃ¢ÂÂll get to the point where weÃ¢ÂÂll look at someoneÃ¢ÂÂs tumor, immune system and genetics and say, Ã¢ÂÂThis treatment is the way to go,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ foresees Buchbinder. Ã¢ÂÂI think with time, immunotherapy will be part of many, many cancer treatments.Ã¢ÂÂ Van den Brink encourages optimistic caution: Ã¢ÂÂWe need to be honest here. These therapies look very powerful and promising, but a fair number of patients donÃ¢ÂÂt respond to them upfront,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. Ã¢ÂÂThese arenÃ¢ÂÂt absolute cures for most people just yet.Ã¢ÂÂ Defeating one of humanityÃ¢ÂÂs oldest scourges, he says, has years of trial and error ahead. Bret Stetka is a writer based in New York and an editorial director at Medscape. His work has appeared in Wired, Scientific American and on The Atlantic. com. He graduated from University of Virginia School of Medicine in 2005. You can follow him on Twitter:@BretStetka.
Title: Cancer Immunotherapy At A Crossroads

Content: Tim Bauerschmidt left home when he was 19. He would call or visit his parents in Michigan occasionally. Decades went by. After his father died last year, he knew his mother couldnÃ¢ÂÂt live by herself. She was 90, and he realized he didnÃ¢ÂÂt know her that well. Ã¢ÂÂI had some stilted conversations,Ã¢ÂÂ says Bauerschmidt. Ã¢ÂÂSheÃ¢ÂÂd be on the other end of the phone when I talked to my dad. IÃ¢ÂÂd have to say, Ã¢ÂÂMom, are you there? Are you on the line?Ã¢ÂÂ [She would say] Ã¢ÂÂOh yeah, IÃ¢ÂÂm here.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Bauerschmidt says it was like his mom, Norma, lived in the shadow of his dad. The pair were married for 67 years. Two days after he died, Norma was diagnosed with endometrial cancer. The doctor recommended a hysterectomy and chemotherapy. Ã¢ÂÂShe said, Ã¢ÂÂNope, IÃ¢ÂÂm not doing any of that,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ says Ramie Liddle, BauerschmidtÃ¢ÂÂs wife. The couple offered to have Norma come live with them. But there was a catch  Ã¢ÂÂ   they live in an RV and travel full time. Liddle says Norma took about two minutes and gave them her answer. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm  Ã¢ÂÂ Liddle recalls Norma saying. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm hitting the road. LetÃ¢ÂÂs go have some fun. I donÃ¢ÂÂt want to spend another minute in the doctorÃ¢ÂÂs office.Ã¢ÂÂ Last summer, Norma, Ramie, Tim and the coupleÃ¢ÂÂs poodle, Ringo, embarked on a   adventure across the U. S. Before she was married, Norma served in the Navy. She was a nurse at a hospital in San Diego during World War II. After that, she lived in Michigan, rarely venturing far from home. When the foursome pulled away in the RV, Norma began to experience many firsts. Bauerschmidt says she had never even been to Wisconsin, the state next to Michigan. There were so many foods she never tried: buffalo burgers, fried green tomatoes, lobster and oysters. Ã¢ÂÂShe realized quickly that she loved key lime pie,Ã¢ÂÂ Liddle says. Over the course of the year, they traveled nearly 13, 000 miles and slept in over 75 locations in 32 states. They visited dozens of national parks, monuments and recreation areas. Norma even experienced some smaller things, like taking off in a hot air balloon, riding a horse and getting a pedicure. At the beginning of their trip, Liddle started to document their adventures. Ã¢ÂÂI decided to put it on Facebook,Ã¢ÂÂ Liddle says. Ã¢ÂÂI used to keep a travel blog because Tim and I were always on the road and honestly, I liked to let my mom, who lives in Pittsburgh, know where we were.Ã¢ÂÂ She named the Facebook page Ã¢ÂÂDriving Ms. Norma,Ã¢ÂÂ and after a few months, people beyond LiddleÃ¢ÂÂs mom started to take notice. A website picked up on it, and the page gained hundreds of thousands of followers. People around the world were in awe of Norma  Ã¢ÂÂ   the way Ramie and Tim were. Ã¢ÂÂI used to say Ã¢ÂÂNo,Ã¢ÂÂ to a lot of things,Ã¢ÂÂ Bauerschmidt says. Ã¢ÂÂMy knee jerk reaction to most things  Ã¢ÂÂ   no, no  Ã¢ÂÂ   but now I hold my tongue and I consider it, and IÃ¢ÂÂm saying Ã¢ÂÂYes,Ã¢ÂÂ to uncomfortable situations.Ã¢ÂÂ Norma died last week at the age of 91. Her memorial service was held on Friday in Friday Harbor, Wash.  Ã¢ÂÂ   on the other side of the country from where her RV adventures began.
Title: Driving Miss Norma: 91-Year-Old Who Hit The Road After Cancer Diagnosis Dies

Content: Mammography can prevent deaths from breast cancer, but itÃ¢ÂÂs not a perfect test. It misses some cancers, especially in women with dense breast tissue, and flags abnormalities for   tests that turn out to be benign, among other issues. So thereÃ¢ÂÂs a lot of interest in additional tests that might make screening more accurate in women who have dense breasts. Many of those women may be wondering about extra screening after receiving notification letters saying that their mammogram was clean, but that their dense breasts put them at higher risk of cancer. But there is no clear path for those women, who make up about 45 percent of women ages 40 to 74. The goal with breast imaging technology is not only to detect more cancers earlier, but to actually prevent deaths from breast cancer, says Dr. Otis Brawley, chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society. Ã¢ÂÂThatÃ¢ÂÂs a very separate and different question,Ã¢ÂÂ he says. And so far, only mammography has met that standard, he says. Investigating that question requires large, randomized clinical trials that follow women for many years to track whether the group screened with the extra technology has fewer deaths from breast cancer than the group screened with mammography alone. And that kind of trial is expensive and logistically tough. Because cancer isnÃ¢ÂÂt as common as many people think, Ã¢ÂÂthe number of women you have to screen to achieve statistical significance is huge,Ã¢ÂÂ says Barbara Monsees, a professor of radiology and womenÃ¢ÂÂs health at the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis. The full effects wonÃ¢ÂÂt be apparent for decades. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs a   commitment, and it costs a lot of money,Ã¢ÂÂ she says. So researcher, clinicians and policymakers who evaluate tests have to rely on studies of   outcomes like cancer detection rates and stage at detection  Ã¢ÂÂ   which may or may not translate to saved lives. They also look at what those studies say about false positive findings, since those can lead to invasive biopsies to see if cancer is actually present. The New England Comparative Effectiveness Public Advisory Council, whose members are from the fields of medicine, economics and policy, looked at the evidence supporting any kind of supplementary screening in women with dense breasts and a clear digital mammogram. Their conclusions, published in 2014, found that thereÃ¢ÂÂs not a ton of evidence on   outcomes, but that the available research suggests a net benefit depending on a personÃ¢ÂÂs underlying cancer risk from additional factors, namely age and family history of the disease. For otherwise   women with dense breasts, the New England group determined that there wasnÃ¢ÂÂt enough evidence to recommend extra screening. They mentioned the potential of overdiagnosis and overtreatment, since some percentage of breast cancers  Ã¢ÂÂ   and there is much controversy over how many  Ã¢ÂÂ   would likely never have caused a woman harm had they been left undiscovered. But for women with dense breasts who are at moderate or high risk of breast cancer according to family history and age, they voted that from the available evidence, the benefits of routine supplemental screening are more likely to outweigh the harms. If a woman and her doctor decide that supplemental screening is needed because of her risk factors, the next question is what kind of screening. There are pluses and minuses of each technology:   ultrasound devices use sound waves to visualize breast tissue. Ultrasound is often used in women with dense breasts. And research suggests that it can pick up more cancers in these women, ones missed by mammograms. Ã¢ÂÂBut thereÃ¢ÂÂs a price for that,Ã¢ÂÂ says Debra Monticciolo, chair of the American College of RadiologyÃ¢ÂÂs Commission on Breast Imaging and a professor of radiology at Texas AM University College of Medicine. There are many, many more false positives, she says, which in turn can lead to unneeded biopsies. And itÃ¢ÂÂs unclear how those benefits and harms balance out. Ã¢ÂÂDoes finding those cancers impact   outcomes? You canÃ¢ÂÂt really prove it, because all you know is that you found additional cancers,Ã¢ÂÂ says Monsees. Ã¢ÂÂCan you guess if those would translate into saved lives? Perhaps not all of them, but what percentage of them?Ã¢ÂÂ Magnetic resonance imaging, or MRI, uses magnetic waves to produce images of the breast. MRI finds more cancers, but it also leads to more false positive results than mammography, although fewer than ultrasound. It requires an intravenous catheter for the contrast agent used in the test, and is more expensive than ultrasound. Most of the members of the New England group said MRI was their first choice for women with dense breasts and a high risk of cancer, citing research on its utility among   women in general. And despite the lack of direct evidence that it saves lives, the American Cancer Society recommends it be added to mammography for women at very high risk of breast cancer, including women who carry certain genetic mutations. That group says thereÃ¢ÂÂs not enough evidence to say whether women who are moderate risk or who have dense breasts should get the test, and it recommends against its use in   women. Tomosynthesis is basically a   mammogram it uses the same   to generate multiple images. ItÃ¢ÂÂs sometimes called a   mammogram. And unlike the other technologies, itÃ¢ÂÂs being suggested for use in all women, says Dr. Janie Lee, associate professor of radiology at the University of Washington and director of breast imaging at the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance. (Lee was one of the authors of the New England groupÃ¢ÂÂs technology assessment but not a voting member.) It can be used along with a separate   digital mammogram or a virtual   image digital mammogram image can be derived from the   one.
