Title: More than two-thirds of cancer mutations are due to random DNA copying errors, study says

Content: Henrietta Lacks probably didnÃ¢ÂÂt seem so immortal to doctors when she was first diagnosed at Johns Hopkins Hospital in 1951. The poor    African American woman  Ã¢ÂÂ   the subject of a   book, Ã¢ÂÂThe Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks,Ã¢ÂÂ and a new HBO movie starring Oprah Winfrey  Ã¢ÂÂ   was suffering from cervical cancer.    Ã¢ÂÂIt was generally a death sentence then,Ã¢ÂÂ said Patricia Eifel, a professor of radiation oncology at the  MD Anderson Center in Houston. Today, the disease is considered a cancer success story. Routine screening and improved treatment have driven its rates down from a major cause of death among women to one the rarest: Cervical cancer ranks just 14th in cancer frequency, and deaths from the disease have fallen some 70 percent since the 1950s. But when Lacks, a mother of five, was being treated in East Baltimore during the Truman era, it was an illness clouded in secrecy, shame and dread. It wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt be until the 1980s that the sexually transmitted Human Papillomavirus (HPV) was identified as the cause of most cervical cancer, but it was still had whispered associations with sex, a disease of the poor and promiscuous. Ã¢ÂÂNuns famously didnÃ¢ÂÂt get cervical cancer, you would hear that in medical school,Ã¢ÂÂ said Eifel, who has worked in the field for 30 years. Lacks, in the public Ã¢ÂÂcolored wardsÃ¢ÂÂ of the   hospital, got the standard treatment for invasive cervical cancer at the time. Doctors stitched tubes and pouches filled with radium inside her cervix, sewing them and packing them in place. At the same time, without her knowledge or consent, the surgeon snipped a sample of her tumor for a research team down the hall. Those cells grew robustly in the lab and became the famous Ã¢ÂÂHeLaÃ¢ÂÂ line of cells that would transform medical research, even as LacksÃ¢ÂÂs children struggled to understand their motherÃ¢ÂÂs fate. That story of discovery, ethics and race is told in the HBO movie debuting Saturday.       HBO Films chronicles the story of Henrietta Lacks, a mother whose cells were harvested without her knowledge and then led to medical breakthroughs, and her familyÃ¢ÂÂs attempt to reclaim her legacy. (HBO)   As the HeLa cells thrived, Henrietta herself failed, dying in agony a few months after the treatment. Ã¢ÂÂShe really had her cancer at the wrong time,Ã¢ÂÂ Eifel said. One month after Lacks was buried, another woman whose name would live forever was wheeled into an operating room to be treated for cervical cancer, and she didnÃ¢ÂÂt even know it. Eva Peron, the glamorous and powerful wife of Argentinian President Juan Peron, was never told she had the disease. Evita thought she was having a procedure by a leading Buenos Aries surgeon to stop some cervical bleeding. Instead, after she was anesthetized, George Pack, a cancer specialist from New York who had been flown secretly to South America, entered the O. R. and performed a radical hysterectomy. There was a such a taboo around cancer that many doctors didnÃ¢ÂÂt want to use the   at all, lest the patient lose hope Ã¢ÂÂ  or commit suicide Ã¢ÂÂ  at a time when cancer seemed always to lead to a coffin. Ã¢ÂÂThere were a lot of euphemisms used at that time: Ã¢ÂÂYou have a tumor,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂYou have an inflammation that we need to take out,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ said Barron Lerner, a physician and medical historian at New York University who has written about the Peron case.    The body Eva Peron was publicly displayed after she died of cervical cancer in 1952. (  Images)  With Peron, of course, politics and power also played a role in the secrecy. But even when the surgery failed to stop the cancer, and she went into a painful decline, she was kept in the dark. Peron and Lacks fell to cervical cancer right at the beginning of a new age in fighting the disease. The biggest breakthrough was the introduction of a remarkably effective test for   cells developed by a   violin player and doctor named George Papanicolaou. His simple Ã¢ÂÂpap smear,Ã¢ÂÂ which allowed doctors to treat and cure the cancer before it became established, was just coming into general use as a screening tool when Lacks fell ill. By the early 1960s, radiation therapy was becoming more refined, too, with cobalt beams and linear accelerators allowing for targeted dosages that didnÃ¢ÂÂt wreak such damage in surrounding tissue. Better anesthesia and surgical techniques boosted survival rates. Procedures that spared a womanÃ¢ÂÂs ability to have children made many of them more willing to undergo treatment. And then came the drugs. Lerner noted that Peron was given a nitrogen mustard concoction in a   attempt to arrest her cancer, reportedly making her ArgentinaÃ¢ÂÂs first chemotherapy patient. Today, of course, the pharmacopoeia includes multiple agents capable of shrinking tumors. Cervical cancers are now considered one of the more treatable malignancies, but not everywhere. In poor areas, where screening and treatment remain    for many women, itÃ¢ÂÂs still 1951. Kathleen Schmeler, a gynecologic oncologist at the MD Anderson Center, often works outside the bubble of modern medicine. In the border region of Texas, cervical cancer rates are 30 percent higher than the national average. In Mozambique, Schmeler found only one practicing medical oncologist in the entire country. Ã¢ÂÂShe told me no one wants to go into the oncology. Ã¢ÂÂThey say we just take care of the dead,Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ Schmeler said. Ã¢ÂÂI didnÃ¢ÂÂt live in that [earlier] era, but I feel like I still see it in these countries. Ã¢ÂÂ Most promising perhaps, are the vaccines that can keep people from contracting the   HPV viruses in the first place. If enough children are immunized Ã¢ÂÂ  something that hasnÃ¢ÂÂt happened yet Ã¢ÂÂ  doctors predict another plunge in the rates of cervical cancer in women and the   head and neck carcinomas that are the fastest growing cancers in men. And yes, those vaccines that could have spared Henrietta Lacks were developed from her own cells. Read more on Retropolis: She was attacked 50 years ago for being a woman in the Boston Marathon. This week she ran it again at 70. HitlerÃ¢ÂÂs mother was Ã¢ÂÂthe only person he genuinely loved.Ã¢ÂÂ Cancer killed her decades before he became a monster. She was the first woman elected to Congress. Right away, she faced an agonizing vote on war.  Berkeley gave birth to the Free Speech Movement in the 1960s. Now, conservatives demand that it include them.
Title: When Henrietta Lacks had cervical cancer, it was a Ã¢ÂÂdeath sentence.Ã¢ÂÂ Her cells would help change that.

Content: Vice President Biden said in an interview broadcast Monday night that President Obama offered him financial help when his son Beau Biden was suffering from cancer. In the interview with CNN, the vice president said he had told Obama over one of their regular private lunches that if his son Beau were forced to step down his position as DelawareÃ¢ÂÂs attorney general and lose his income because of the brain cancer that ultimately killed him, the vice president and his wife Jill would have to sell their home to pay for BeauÃ¢ÂÂs medical expenses. He said Obama told him not to do that. Ã¢ÂÂHe said Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂll give you the money. Whatever you need, IÃ¢ÂÂll give you the money. DonÃ¢ÂÂt, Joe. Promise me. Promise me,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Biden told CNN.   [For all their political differences, Biden and Ryan share striking similarities]   Biden said that his son was worried he would have to resign if the cancer affected his cognitive abilities, and that it did affect his speech before he died. Biden had told Obama that if Beau resigned there would be Ã¢ÂÂnothing to fall back on.Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂI said, Ã¢ÂÂBut I worked it out,Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Biden recalled telling Obama. Ã¢ÂÂI said, Ã¢ÂÂBut    Jill and I will sell the house and be in good shape. Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Beau Biden served out his second term has DelawareÃ¢ÂÂs attorney general, leaving office in January 2015. He died in June that year at the age of 46. The emotional toll of his sonÃ¢ÂÂs death on the vice president was one reason the elder Biden, 73, decided against running for president this year. The vice president said he would Ã¢ÂÂnever forgetÃ¢ÂÂ the eulogy Obama delivered at BeauÃ¢ÂÂs funeral. Ã¢ÂÂObviously, the president and the vice president have developed the kind of personal relationship that just transcends their professional responsibilities,Ã¢ÂÂ Earnest told CNNÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂNew DayÃ¢ÂÂ on Tuesday.
Title: Vice President Biden: Obama offered financial help when his son Beau Biden was ill with brain cancer

Content: Kurt GodwinÃ¢ÂÂs obituaries in The Washington Post and on Legacy. com contained all the basics: He was the son of a CIA officer. He lived in Alexandria, Va. and was married. He taught art at Virginia Commonwealth and Catholic universities. He died Sept. 19, 2014, at the age of 58.  The cause of death was another matter. Ã¢ÂÂThe cause was cancer, said his wife, Karin Godwin,Ã¢ÂÂ the Post obituary noted. Ã¢ÂÂKurt Douglas Godwin passed away at INOVA Fairfax Hospital, due to stage 4 Cancer complications,Ã¢ÂÂ read a slightly more detailed death notice on Legacy. Godwin purposely withheld a salient fact: what kind of cancer. She didnÃ¢ÂÂt think her husband wanted others to know, she said. The same impulse was on display this month when rock legend David Bowie and actor Alan Rickman died of cancer and their families did not divulge the exact form of the disease in their announcements. Even in an era when cancer is discussed more openly and of   foundations, relatives of the ordinary and famous still omit the exact cause of death when it comes to the  .   Rock musician David Bowie passed away on Jan. 10, after a battle with cancer. The end to his influential,   career sparked hundreds of messages of grief and tribute. (Jenny   Washington Post)   Cancer will kill nearly 600, 000 Americans this year, according to the American Cancer Society. Experts say withholding the information about the type of cancer in obituaries only reinforces the diseaseÃ¢ÂÂs persistent stigma and can deprive researchers and advocates of opportunities to educate people about specific cancers and fundraise for their cures. Some relatives, though, say their loved ones would be embarrassed by disclosing which organ failed them, especially if the body part felt like too much information, or if it was the liver or lung, where cancers often originate because of smoking or drinking. Ã¢ÂÂThe cause was cancerÃ¢ÂÂ should suffice, they argue, because any more detail diverts attention from the personÃ¢ÂÂs life. Obituary writers at The Post and the New York Times estimate families resist naming specific cancers about 15 percent of the time. The news organizations typically ask for the type of cancer, particularly if the person who died was young, but an omission would never rule out an obituary. Ã¢ÂÂIf we push too much, it carries the risk of sounding to the family like we have a lurid obsession,Ã¢ÂÂ said Adam Bernstein, the PostÃ¢ÂÂs obituaries editor. Ã¢ÂÂBut Ã¢ÂÂcancerÃ¢ÂÂ is very general. ItÃ¢ÂÂs like saying someone died of a Ã¢ÂÂdisease.Ã¢ÂÂ Well, what kind of disease?Ã¢ÂÂ In the case of BowieÃ¢ÂÂs death on Jan. 11, it was announced on his official Facebook page that he died after a Ã¢ÂÂcourageous   battle with cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ Soon after, some of his fans began to wonder which cancer. Ã¢ÂÂI understand the value of privacy but now that we know that he was battling the cancer which ended his life after 18 months, the least David BowieÃ¢ÂÂs publicist can have the permission to do is disclose what type of cancer took BowieÃ¢ÂÂs life! !Ã¢ÂÂ wrote one fan, Richard Goldy. But GoldyÃ¢ÂÂs curiosity was not shared by other Bowie fans  Ã¢ÂÂ   his post only netted nine Facebook Ã¢ÂÂlikes. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂWhat does it matter what cancer he had? The man has battled it for 18 months and itÃ¢ÂÂs his and his familyÃ¢ÂÂs business not ours as fans. We donÃ¢ÂÂt need to know the details,Ã¢ÂÂ replied Jodie Riley Darlington, whose censure earned 688   from fellow Bowie fans. Days after BowieÃ¢ÂÂs death, some news outlets reported heÃ¢ÂÂd had liver cancer, based on a single source: his friend, the Belgian theater director Ivo van Hove, whose New York production of Ã¢ÂÂLazarusÃ¢ÂÂ featured the singerÃ¢ÂÂs music. According to Reuters, van Hove told Dutch NPO radio: Ã¢ÂÂHe told me more than a year and three months ago just after he had heard himself .Ã¢ÂÂ.Ã¢ÂÂ. he said it was liver cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ The purported revelation  Ã¢ÂÂ   never confirmed by BowieÃ¢ÂÂs family  Ã¢ÂÂ   set off a cycle of news stories around the world. Ã¢ÂÂDavid Bowie died of liver cancer, friend and collaborator says,Ã¢ÂÂ blared a New York Daily News headline. Ã¢ÂÂWhat could have David gone through during this horrible time? HereÃ¢ÂÂs five things to know,Ã¢ÂÂ read a story in Hollywoodlife. com, ticking off liver cancer symptoms and how liver cancer is diagnosed. When reached by The Post, however, van Hove recognized the sensitivity of his disclosure and tried to backtrack. Ã¢ÂÂI donÃ¢ÂÂt know if I can go into that. I am not a close friend, and I am not part of the family. I donÃ¢ÂÂt remember saying it. Perhaps I said it,Ã¢ÂÂ van Hove said. Ã¢ÂÂWhat I want to say officially was that it was cancer. I donÃ¢ÂÂt want to comment on liver cancer or brain tumors or whatever. I donÃ¢ÂÂt know. I donÃ¢ÂÂt know why that should be important at this moment. Ã¢ÂÂ Steve Martin, BowieÃ¢ÂÂs publicist, declined to comment. Richard Wender, the chief cancer control officer of the American Cancer Society, said when celebrities open up about their cancers, it can help educate people about getting colonoscopies or tests for hepatitis C.  Paul Goldberg, a District resident and novelist who runs a   Web publication called The Cancer Letter, cited Betty FordÃ¢ÂÂs divulgence in 1974 of her breast cancer diagnosis, which prompted women across the country to get mammograms. He also pointed to the more recent outpouring after Beau BidenÃ¢ÂÂs disclosure of his brain cancer, and how President Obama announced at his State of the Union address this month that Vice President Biden was now Ã¢ÂÂin charge of mission controlÃ¢ÂÂ for Ã¢ÂÂa new moonshotÃ¢ÂÂ to cure cancer. The disease exacts a nearly $75 billion toll in medical costs in the U. S.  Ã¢ÂÂAfter a lot of stagnation, now thereÃ¢ÂÂs a lot of money coming to cancer research. Look at whatÃ¢ÂÂs going to happen with the Ã¢ÂÂmoonshotÃ¢ÂÂ program,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. If ordinary families note the type of cancer their loved ones had in obituaries, then cancer patients can see how long someone lived since their diagnosis and perhaps find where they received treatment, Goldberg added. Ã¢ÂÂThe need for privacy is very personal, and you canÃ¢ÂÂt prescribe what the optimum amount of privacy is on something like this,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂThe argument for disclosing is that it makes people more aware of that disease and prompts them to think what can be done. Ã¢ÂÂ When Denise McQuighan died in March 2014 at the age of 55, Thomas McQuighan, a Maryland government contractor, made sure her obituary left out the exact kind of cancer. During her life, she only told two of her girlfriends that she had a combination of multiple myeloma and leukemia. She worried friends would treat her differently and had little interest in hearing anyone elseÃ¢ÂÂs   suggestions for treatments. Ã¢ÂÂThe cause of death was leukemia, but that leukemia came about from other therapies she had,Ã¢ÂÂ McQuighan said. Ã¢ÂÂItÃ¢ÂÂs an irrelevant question. She was a private person. What does the average person know about multiple myeloma? Nothing. Ã¢ÂÂ But when Bowie died, McQuighan immediately had questions: Ã¢ÂÂThe news said he had cancer, and I was like, Ã¢ÂÂWhich one?Ã¢ÂÂ But then I said, Ã¢ÂÂDoes it really matter?Ã¢ÂÂ If he had the same one my wife did, IÃ¢ÂÂd say, Ã¢ÂÂGee, I wish they had a cure for it.Ã¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂÃ¢ÂÂ Karin Godwin, a retired elementary art school teacher who lives in Alexandria, said her husband, Kurt, would have been happy with her decision to leave out his specific cancer in his obituary. He was always   about his colostomy bag and colon cancer diagnosis. Now that so much time has passed since his death in September 2014, she is comfortable speaking openly about his disease. Ã¢ÂÂHe didnÃ¢ÂÂt want everyone to know. It was a very embarrassing situation for him,Ã¢ÂÂ Godwin said. But when Bowie died earlier this month, Godwin, like McQuighan, said she instantly wanted to know the real truth. Which cancer claimed his life? Ã¢ÂÂI really did wonder. I have all his LPs,Ã¢ÂÂ Godwin said. Ã¢ÂÂI knew so much about Bowie, but theyÃ¢ÂÂre not going to tell how he died. ItÃ¢ÂÂs like thereÃ¢ÂÂs no closure to his life. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: What kind of cancer killed them? Obituaries for David Bowie and others donÃ¢ÂÂt say.

Content: Is a newly announced cancer therapy touted as Ã¢ÂÂunprecedentedÃ¢ÂÂ as   as itÃ¢ÂÂs said to be? ItÃ¢ÂÂs simply too soon to tell. At the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science on Sunday, Stanley Riddell, an immunotherapy researcher and oncologist at SeattleÃ¢ÂÂs Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, announced an exciting potential treatment. Ã¢ÂÂThe early data is unprecedented,Ã¢ÂÂ Riddell said during SundayÃ¢ÂÂs media conference in D. C. Riddell and his colleagues are working on immunotherapy. While chemotherapies attack tumors and cancer cells directly  Ã¢ÂÂ   usually causing significant damage to healthy tissues in the process  Ã¢ÂÂ   immunotherapy is about finding ways to help the human immune system fight off cancer cells the way it would attack foreign bacteria or a virus. Cancer cells are adept at outlasting or hiding from immune responses, so immunologists have to find ways to trigger the immune system to act out anyway.   [Cancer was killing her. She tried immunotherapy.]   Jill OÃ¢ÂÂ  chief executive of the Cancer Research Institute, said 2015 was Ã¢ÂÂa truly special year for cancer immunotherapyÃ¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂ   and more than half of active clinical cancer trials use some form of it. With the White House set to fund a cancer Ã¢ÂÂmoonshotÃ¢ÂÂ to the tune of $1 billion, many are looking to immunotherapy as the best hope for a cure  Ã¢ÂÂ   or at least a much better treatment  Ã¢ÂÂ   for cancer.    Positron emission tomography (PET) images showing large tumor mass in the kidney prior to therapy that completely regressed on a repeat PET scan performed two months after. (Fred Hutch News Service)  According to Riddell, his teamÃ¢ÂÂs studies on a technique called adoptive T cell therapy are seeing stupendous results. In this process, doctors take white blood cells called T cells from cancer patients and genetically modify them, giving them tags that will help them to target specific cancer cells in the body. The doctors then allow these cells to multiply and reintroduce them into the body, providing patients with a   immune system tailored to fight the cancerous cells inside of them. In theory, these cells could keep protecting the body from cancerous invasions long after the initial treatment.   [Personalized cancer vaccines have already helped treat three patients]   The research is yet to be published, which means it hasnÃ¢ÂÂt been   (vouched for by scientists outside of the study) and is tough to evaluate. But the data Riddell is reporting is indeed impressive. In one study, the therapy eliminated all symptoms in 94 percent of participants with acute lymphoblastic leukemia, with other blood cancers showing response rates greater than 80 percent. More than half the subjects reportedly experienced complete remission. And these patients are ones who seemed sick beyond all hope. Ã¢ÂÂWe have very high rates of complete responses in patients that have failed all other conventional therapies, including bone marrow transplantation,Ã¢ÂÂ Riddell said during the briefing. But the BBC reports that seven of the patients had immune responses so severe they ended up in intensive care  Ã¢ÂÂ   and two of those patients died as a result. These risks are the biggest hurdle for immunotherapy to overcome. But even ignoring the potentially fatal   which Riddell hopes could be avoided by using lower doses of the therapy, the treatment has a long way to go before we can hail it as a   cure for cancer. For now, it has only been used to treat cancers of the blood. Not even the excited researchers behind the findings really think this will be a cancer Ã¢ÂÂcure.Ã¢ÂÂ What they hope is that their therapy can finally usher immunotherapy into the ranks of standard cancer treatment  Ã¢ÂÂ   something that could be used routinely alongside chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgical interventions. The team will keep working on ways to make their technique safer and more effective for all types of cancer. And when their results are formally published, other researchers can assess just how revolutionary the therapy truly is. Read More: Scientists are using herpes to treat skin cancer  Ã¢ÂÂ   and itÃ¢ÂÂs working Sequencing the genome creates so much data we donÃ¢ÂÂt know what to do with it Can   pigeons help train human radiologists? An animal behaviorist weighs in. What cancer in clams might tell us about cancer in humans Why groundbreaking new cancer drugs still donÃ¢ÂÂt work for most patients
Title: Why itÃ¢ÂÂs too early to get excited about this Ã¢ÂÂunprecedentedÃ¢ÂÂ new cancer treatment

Content: ATLANTA  Ã¢ÂÂ   Jimmy Carter announced Sunday that he no longer needs treatment for cancer, less than seven months after revealing he had been diagnosed with melanoma that spread to his brain. Carter, 91, shared the news at one of his regular Sunday School classes at Maranatha Baptist Church in his hometown of Plains, Georgia. Carter always starts his lessons with a brief update on his recent activities. This week, Carter told the class, he received an MRI lasting more than 2 hours.  Ã¢ÂÂAnd then the doctors determined that I didnÃ¢ÂÂt need any more treatment,Ã¢ÂÂ Carter said in a video posted by  . Ã¢ÂÂSo IÃ¢ÂÂm not going to have any more treatment. Ã¢ÂÂ He smiled as the audience applauded. CarterÃ¢ÂÂs spokeswoman Deanna Congileo said in an email Sunday that his doctors will continue to perform scans to ensure cancer cells have not returned, and Carter will Ã¢ÂÂresume treatment if necessary. Ã¢ÂÂ A spokesman for Emory UniversityÃ¢ÂÂs Winship Cancer Institute, where Carter has been treated, declined to comment on Sunday, citing patient privacy. CarterÃ¢ÂÂs treatment plan for the aggressive form of cancer including a round of targeted radiation at several tumors on his brain and doses of an   drug every three weeks from August through February. The drug, Keytruda, was approved not long before CarterÃ¢ÂÂs announcement and helps his body seek out and destroy cancer cells. Medical experts have called Keytruda and similar immune therapy drugs Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ for patients with melanoma. But the drugs are relatively new, and doctors are still learning about how they should be used and for how long, said Dr. Len Lichtenfeld, deputy chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society. He is not involved in CarterÃ¢ÂÂs treatment.  Ã¢ÂÂSome people believe they should be continued as long as a patient is doing well, some feel the drugs should continue for a period of time and then be stopped,Ã¢ÂÂ Lichtenfeld said. Ã¢ÂÂThis is clearly a (decision) based on individual evidence specific to the president and made with his doctors. Ã¢ÂÂ Dr. Douglas Johnson, a melanoma specialist at   Cancer Center who is not treating Carter, said the FDA did not provide a specific   for patients who see improvement while taking the drugs. Patients who see results may want to stop but battle with fear that the cancer could return, he said.  Ã¢ÂÂThat has become a very difficult question,Ã¢ÂÂ Johnson said. Ã¢ÂÂWe can say that patients who have stopped treatment have continued to do very well, but the drug has been around less than 10 years. Whether all patients have the same results, we donÃ¢ÂÂt know. Ã¢ÂÂ Carter made another unexpected announcement about his health at a December class, telling the audience that a recent scan of his brain detected no sign of cancer. At the time, Carter told the group that he planned to continue receiving doses of Keytruda every three weeks. He has said the drug caused few side effects. Jill Stuckey, a Maranatha Baptist Church member, said in a phone interview that CarterÃ¢ÂÂs updates have become Ã¢ÂÂa pattern for our church. Ã¢ÂÂ  Ã¢ÂÂPresident Carter comes in, tells us phenomenal news and we all applaud,Ã¢ÂÂ Stuckey, also a close friend of the Carters, said. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre all on pins and needles wondering how things are going, because you never know from looking at somebody. Ã¢ÂÂ Carter has remained active throughout his treatment, including participating in a building project with Habitat for Humanity. He also continued work at the Carter Center, the human rights organization he founded after leaving the White House, contrary to his initial plans to step back during treatment. Tim Turnham, executive director of the Melanoma Research Foundation, said CarterÃ¢ÂÂs age or busy schedule may have been a factor in deciding to stop the treatment.  Ã¢ÂÂWhen you have a drug thatÃ¢ÂÂs working to keep cancer at bay, itÃ¢ÂÂs a hard decision to stop,Ã¢ÂÂ Turnham, who is not involved with CarterÃ¢ÂÂs treatment, said. Ã¢ÂÂIt really becomes a conversation between the patient and their doctor. Ã¢ÂÂ Copyright 2016 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.
Title: Jimmy Carter says he no longer needs cancer drug treatment

Content: NEW ORLEANS    New immunotherapy drugs are showing significant and extended effectiveness against a broadening range of cancers, including rare and intractable tumors often caused by viruses. Researchers say these advances suggest the treatment approach is poised to become a critical part of the nationÃ¢ÂÂs   strategy. Scientists reported Tuesday that the medications, which marshal the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs own immune defenses, are now proving effective against    head and neck cancer and an extremely lethal skin cancer called Merkel cell carcinoma. Both can be caused by viruses as well as DNA mutations, and the drugs help the immune system to recognize the   cancer and attack it. Since pathogens are responsible for more than 20 percent of all cancers, Ã¢ÂÂthese results have implications that go far beyond a rare cancerÃ¢ÂÂ like Merkel cell carcinoma, said Paul Ngheim, an investigator with the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle who led that study. The new data, plus research released Sunday that showed sharply higher survival rates among   patients who received immunotherapy, is prompting growing, albeit guarded, optimism among researchers attending the American Association for Cancer Research annual meeting here. In addition to melanoma, the infusion drugs already have been approved for use against lung and kidney cancers.   [  survival rates increase for patients treated with immunotherapy]   Ã¢ÂÂWe are in the midst of a sea change in how we are treating cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ said Louis Weiner, director of the Georgetown Lombardi Comprehensive Cancer Center, who wasnÃ¢ÂÂt involved in the studies. Ã¢ÂÂWeÃ¢ÂÂre really seeing the fruits of many years of research into what drives cancer and how it interacts with the immune system to defeat it and survive.Ã¢ÂÂ The latest findings, as well as hundreds of ongoing clinical trials across the country, suggest that immunotherapy could be beneficial for more than two dozen kinds of cancer    and maybe many more. One of the most prominent patients is former president Jimmy Carter, who last year was diagnosed with advanced melanoma that had spread to his brain. He was treated with one of the new drugs, Keytruda, as well as radiation. The combination worked so well, causing his tumors to disappear, that he was able to stop treatment in March. Ã¢ÂÂWhatÃ¢ÂÂs happening to Jimmy Carter is happening to many, many people,Ã¢ÂÂ Weiner said. At the same time, however, researchers caution that they have a long way to go in fully understanding the therapy and transforming it into a viable treatment for a majority of patients. Ã¢ÂÂThis period for immunotherapy is comparable to the 1960s for chemotherapy, when we were just beginning to use it,Ã¢ÂÂ said Roy Jensen, director of the University of Kansas Cancer Center. Ã¢ÂÂThere is so much to do and to figure out. WeÃ¢ÂÂre just at the start of this.Ã¢ÂÂ Scientists donÃ¢ÂÂt know why some patients benefit from immunotherapy and others donÃ¢ÂÂt. In some trials, for example, less than a third of patients have had a positive response. Researchers think that proportion can be increased by combining these Ã¢ÂÂcheckpoint inhibitorÃ¢ÂÂ drugs    three have been approved by the government, with several more in development    or by adding conventional treatments such as chemotherapy, radiation and surgery. Yet much work is needed on how exactly to do that and on how to better comprehend cancerÃ¢ÂÂs wide range of defenses. The research successes are emerging just as the Obama administration, as well as private philanthropists, focus on ways to radically accelerate progress against cancer. Former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg and tech billionaire Sean Parker have announced that they will invest hundreds of millions of dollars in immunotherapy research. On Wednesday, Vice President Biden will address the conference about the Obama administrationÃ¢ÂÂs   Ã¢ÂÂmoonshotÃ¢ÂÂ initiative.   [Cancer experts named to advise Obama administration on Ã¢ÂÂmoonshotÃ¢ÂÂ effort]   Head and neck cancer, a devastating disease that affects the patientÃ¢ÂÂs ability to eat, breathe and talk, can be caused by the human papillomavirus, or HPV. Data released as an abstract Tuesday showed the immunotherapy drug Opdivo led to improved overall survival for patients with advanced cancer who had not responded to chemotherapy. Such benefit had not been seen before, according to Maura Gillison of the Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center, who led the study. The scientists divided 361 patients into two groups: One got Opdivo, and the other received chemotherapy selected by individual researchers. At the end of a year, 36 percent of the Opdivo patients were still alive, compared to 17 percent of the chemotherapy group. The immunotherapy drug was beneficial regardless of whether a patient had been infected with HPV. Gillison said she hoped that the results would establish Opdivo Ã¢ÂÂas a new standard of care option for this patient population and thereby fulfill a huge unmet need.Ã¢ÂÂ With Merkel cell carcinoma, which almost always kills quickly, many more cases are triggered by a common virus than by exposure to ultraviolet light. And in the trial, slightly more than half of the 25   patients had a significant reduction in their tumors. The drug prompted the immune system Ã¢ÂÂto get up out of its rocking chairÃ¢ÂÂ and go attack the cancer, Ngheim said. More than 80 percent of the patients who responded are still experiencing Ã¢ÂÂexcellent disease controlÃ¢ÂÂ six months after starting treatment, and several patients have no sign of disease, he added. The study was published online Tuesday in the New England Journal of Medicine. Suzanne Topalian, a   of the study and associate director of Johns HopkinsÃ¢ÂÂ new   Institute for Cancer Immunology, said the results provide an Ã¢ÂÂopen doorÃ¢ÂÂ for considering immunotherapy for other cancers caused by viruses.    Stan Collender receives an immunotherapy drug as part of his treatment for rare Merkel cell carcinoma. (Robert   Hutch News Service)  Stan Collender, a   Washington budget expert and public relations executive, was facing the typically dire prognosis when he was diagnosed with Merkel cell carcinoma in 2012. He had three recurrences, with tumors under his chin and in his brain and chest. Ã¢ÂÂI was convinced I was going to die,Ã¢ÂÂ he recalled recently. Then in 2015, Collender became one of the patients enrolled in NghiemÃ¢ÂÂs trial. Last spring, he began flying to Seattle every three weeks to get a   infusion of Keytruda. A few months later, the doctors got the first scans of his body and brain. His oncologist at Hutchinson texted him the news: Ã¢ÂÂYour scans look fantastic. ..Ã¢ÂÂ That was almost 10 months ago, and the    Collender said he now feels Ã¢ÂÂmiraculously well.Ã¢ÂÂ He has gone Ã¢ÂÂfrom not being able to stop thinking about my cancer to not thinking about it at all.Ã¢ÂÂ Collender is hoping the benefit will last. Ã¢ÂÂIs it durable? I donÃ¢ÂÂt know,Ã¢ÂÂ he said. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm still a test pilot.Ã¢ÂÂ Read more:   scientists aim to make cancer a chronic illness Bloomberg, others make big donation to Hopkins for immunotherapy research 7 ways to avoid cancerÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂfinancial toxicityÃ¢ÂÂ
Title: The list of cancers being taken down by immunotherapy keeps growing

Content: It was clear from the first paragraph that this wasnÃ¢ÂÂt your typical consumer report. Ã¢ÂÂI write this from the hospital,Ã¢ÂÂ John Stossel of Fox wrote. Ã¢ÂÂSeems I have lung cancer. Ã¢ÂÂ This was quite the revelation  Ã¢ÂÂ   one all the more powerful for its delivery in terse,   prose. But Stossel, who said he Ã¢ÂÂwill barely notice that a fifth of my lung is goneÃ¢ÂÂ and that he will Ã¢ÂÂbe fine,Ã¢ÂÂ wasnÃ¢ÂÂt here for a meditation on mortality a la Oliver Sacks. Instead, from the highly regarded New   Hospital, the    consumer affairs reporter quickly transitioned into a discussion of why his Ã¢ÂÂhospitalÃ¢ÂÂs customer service stinks. Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂMy doctors tell me my growth was caught early and IÃ¢ÂÂll be fine,Ã¢ÂÂ he wrote. Ã¢ÂÂSoon I will barely notice that a fifth of my lung is gone. I believe them. After all, IÃ¢ÂÂm at New   Hospital. U. S. News & World Report ranked it No. 1 in New York. I get excellent medical care here. Ã¢ÂÂBut as a consumer reporter, I have to say, the hospitalÃ¢ÂÂs customer service stinks. Doctors keep me waiting for hours, and no one bothers to call or email to say, Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm running late.Ã¢ÂÂ Few doctors give out their email address. Patients canÃ¢ÂÂt communicate using modern technology. Ã¢ÂÂI get   EKG tests, echocardiograms, blood tests. Are all needed? I doubt it. But no one discusses that with me or mentions the cost. Why would they? The patient rarely pays directly. Government or insurance companies pay. Ã¢ÂÂ   [Video: This app allows unhappy patients to request refunds]   Ã¢ÂÂCustomer service is sclerotic because hospitals are largely socialist bureaucracies,Ã¢ÂÂ Stossel added. Ã¢ÂÂInstead of answering to consumers, which forces businesses to be nimble, hospitals report to government, lawyers and insurance companies. Ã¢ÂÂ StosselÃ¢ÂÂs opinion wasnÃ¢ÂÂt a surprise  Ã¢ÂÂ   heÃ¢ÂÂs known for his libertarian critiques of everything from school vouchers to pornography to euthanasia. Ã¢ÂÂGovernment Ã¢ÂÂhelpÃ¢ÂÂ encourages poor people to be dependent and passive,Ã¢ÂÂ he wrote last year. Ã¢ÂÂDependent, people stay poor. Also, most government handouts donÃ¢ÂÂt even go to the poor. They go to the middle class (college loans, big mortgage tax deductions, Medicare) and the rich (corporate welfare, bailouts to banks Ã¢ÂÂtoo big to failÃ¢ÂÂ). Instead of making government more powerful, letÃ¢ÂÂs get rid of those handouts. Left and right ought to agree on that. Ã¢ÂÂ But the widely shared Fox piece, in which Stossel praised nurses but criticized hospitalsÃ¢ÂÂ endless forms, antiquated machinery, ambiguity about costs and necessary fear of lawsuits, seemed to crystallize the problems with American health care for many. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂve been a hospital nurse for >30 yrs and patient a number of times,Ã¢ÂÂ one commenter on StosselÃ¢ÂÂs Facebook page wrote. Ã¢ÂÂAlways frustrated by having to repeat the same info on paper forms. Since [the Affordable Health Care Act] I have a high deductible plan and all the care I get comes out of my pocket. I find it extremely difficult to enter into a market negotiation for price or even find out what a cost will be before I get the services. Govt has distorted our system that I donÃ¢ÂÂt think I will will ever see a return to market forces in my lifetime. Ã¢ÂÂ Known for his love of University of Chicago economist and   guru Milton Friedman, Stossel has also faced charges that his reporting is inaccurate and biased. In 2013, for example, the liberal media watchdog Media Matters criticized a video series called Ã¢ÂÂStossel in the ClassroomÃ¢ÂÂ it said was funded by   donors. Ã¢ÂÂThe program now offers hundreds of free clips from StosselÃ¢ÂÂs shows and specials that claim to seriously address a range of academic subjects, including Art (Ã¢ÂÂWhy does Hollywood Hate Capitalism? Ã¢ÂÂ) Biology (Ã¢ÂÂDebunking Food MythsÃ¢ÂÂ) and History (Ã¢ÂÂThe Real Story of Thanksgiving,Ã¢ÂÂ which explains Ã¢ÂÂhow the Pilgrims were hurt by sharingÃ¢ÂÂ),Ã¢ÂÂ it wrote. StosselÃ¢ÂÂs criticism of his hospital stay, however, didnÃ¢ÂÂt demand a deep understanding of Austrian economics or a love of the Koch brothers. Ã¢ÂÂIÃ¢ÂÂm as happy as the next guy to have government or my insurance company pay, but the result is that thereÃ¢ÂÂs practically no free market,Ã¢ÂÂ he wrote. Ã¢ÂÂMarkets work when buyer and seller deal directly with each other. That doesnÃ¢ÂÂt happen in hospitals. Ã¢ÂÂ
Title: FoxÃ¢ÂÂs John Stossel: Ã¢ÂÂI write this from the hospital. Seems I have lung cancer Ã¢ÂÂ¦ Customer service stinksÃ¢ÂÂ

Content: DALLAS  In 2014, Diana visited our genetics clinic in Texas. She was only in her early 40s, but her mother had died of breast cancer at 42, and two of her aunts had received the same diagnosis at young ages. As we tested her for a panel of breast cancer gene mutations, she joked about her Irish heritage, of which she was clearly proud. But we discovered that Diana carried an Ashkenazi Jewish BRCA1 mutation that predisposed her to breast and ovarian cancer. During World War II, it turned out, her French Jewish family converted to Catholicism and made Ireland their home. Nobody had told her. The secrecy was understandable. But as an oncologist, I know it can carry major risks. One of the most important things I need to learn about my patients is their family medical history. Many illnesses  Ã¢ÂÂ   from diabetes and asthma to heart disease and dementia  Ã¢ÂÂ   are at least partly hereditary. One recent study found that 33 percent of cancer diagnoses can be explained by genes. Alcoholism is as much as 60 percent genetic; schizophrenia occurs in less than 1 percent of the general population but in 10 percent of people who have a sibling or parent with the disorder. Ã¢ÂÂWhat happens in your family is an approximation of what happens to you,Ã¢ÂÂ geneticist Joe Nadeau told New York magazine. Ã¢ÂÂThe conventional family history is still the best predictor of disease risk. Ã¢ÂÂ For many patients, sharing this information could save their lives. If a patientÃ¢ÂÂs family is peppered with alcoholics, I might advise him or her to avoid liquor. If a patientÃ¢ÂÂs relatives have suffered from colon cancer, IÃ¢ÂÂd know to look for gene mutations and prescribe frequent colonoscopies.  But few of us have an accurate understanding of what came before us,  . Only   of Americans have ever tried to collect their family medical histories from relatives. And even when they do, they can run into major problems. You probably know less than you think about your familyÃ¢ÂÂs predispositions. Part of that is the fault of the medical profession. Doctors spend very little time  Ã¢ÂÂ   just 15 minutes, in a lot of cases  Ã¢ÂÂ   with patients. We simply canÃ¢ÂÂt afford to construct a family tree. One study found that physicians devote just three minutes to asking   questions during a patientÃ¢ÂÂs first visit. Even when doctors ask, they may not get the right answers. Many patients donÃ¢ÂÂt really know their familiesÃ¢ÂÂ health histories. In some instances, relatives might never have revealed that they were sick, particularly if they struggled with a disease that carries a stigma. According to one study, 58 percent of psychiatrists said they wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt tell family and friends if they suffered from a mental illness. Cancer advocate Doug Ulman wrote that heÃ¢ÂÂs known many people to keep their illness under wraps because of Ã¢ÂÂfear, ostracism and shame. Ã¢ÂÂ IÃ¢ÂÂve seen this in my family, too. My    mother loves to talk about her fatherÃ¢ÂÂs daily visits to speakeasies and his 1931 imprisonment for drunken driving. But she would never describe him as an alcoholic.  Other times, patients are aware of only the outlines of their familiesÃ¢ÂÂ medical histories, or they interpret them incorrectly. One person visiting our genetics clinic denied that he had a family history of cancer because, he said, nobody had died. Another suggested that her sisterÃ¢ÂÂs breast cancer at age 38 was due to her divorce. One even told me her father had only Ã¢ÂÂa touch of melanoma. Ã¢ÂÂ And when we can look back at family records, we might not understand what weÃ¢ÂÂre reading. It wasnÃ¢ÂÂt so long ago that tuberculosis was known as Ã¢ÂÂconsumptionÃ¢ÂÂ and epilepsy was Ã¢ÂÂfalling sickness. Ã¢ÂÂ Strokes were Ã¢ÂÂapoplexy,Ã¢ÂÂ and Ã¢ÂÂbad bloodÃ¢ÂÂ was code for syphilis. Studies show just how widespread this problem is. In one study, researchers asked more than 1, 000 people about cancers in their relatives and then checked those responses against information in registries, Medicare databases, death certificates and other health records.   of the histories that patients reported had errors. Even with official health documents or family stories, we need to remain skeptical. Mistakes in records happen. And memory is not a factual accounting of past events but a construction of what we think happened. Lung cancer may have, in fact, been colon cancer; ovarian cancer perhaps was cervical cancer. This matters because different types of cancers put patients at risk for different kinds of diseases.  I had a colon cancer patient who was adopted at birth. Before starting a family, he wanted to learn more about his biological parents and their health histories. As a psychiatrist, he was concerned about mental disorders that have a hereditary component, such as schizophrenia. After much work with an adoption disclosure agency, he met his birth parents. He learned that they had been unmarried when he was born. He asked his biological parents about mental illnesses. None, he was assured. He didnÃ¢ÂÂt think to ask about cancer. He and his wife had two children. Then, at 42, he was diagnosed with colon cancer. He contacted his biological mother to let her know. She wasnÃ¢ÂÂt surprised. You should know, she told him, that others in the family had suffered from the same disease. When he pressed, he found out that Ã¢ÂÂothersÃ¢ÂÂ also included secret siblings. His biological parents had told him only about siblings who were born after they married. They hadnÃ¢ÂÂt shared the medical histories of the other children who had also been given up for adoption. Eventually, he met the rest of the family. One of his siblings was about to cancel her regular colonoscopy when she learned about the colon cancer in her newly discovered brother. She kept the date, and the gastroenterologist discovered polyps, a precursor to colon cancer. The polyps were removed, and her life was most likely saved. ItÃ¢ÂÂs rarely easy to learn about your familyÃ¢ÂÂs health history, but itÃ¢ÂÂs worth doing your research. (The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Institutes of Health have online guides to help people get started.) Knowing what you know  Ã¢ÂÂ   and donÃ¢ÂÂt  Ã¢ÂÂ   about your familyÃ¢ÂÂs medical history is one of the most important tools there is to save lives in predictable and, more often than not, unpredictable ways.  outlook@washpost. com   Read more from Outlook and follow our updates on Facebook and Twitter.
Title: Did your aunt have cancer? Knowing could save your life.

Content: Joe ScholtenÃ¢ÂÂs sister had already beaten breast cancer and was battling ovarian cancer when she tested positive for a genetic mutation linked to both. He responded by doing something unusual: He got tested, too. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs how the District resident discovered that he also carried the defective BRCA gene. He quickly told his brothers, other relatives and, hardest of all, his daughter. Ã¢ÂÂGetting tested was a Ã¢ÂÂ he said, wondering what steps his sister would have taken if sheÃ¢ÂÂd learned early on about her own genetic risk. She was 54 when the ovarian cancer killed her. He realizes now that not knowing your medical pedigree is Ã¢ÂÂclearly a danger. Ã¢ÂÂ Yet ScholtenÃ¢ÂÂs action makes him an outlier. Many women are acutely aware of the stark dangers posed by mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes  Ã¢ÂÂ   the kind that prompted actress Angelina Jolie to have her breasts and ovaries removed preemptively. Few men, however, know that the same genetic defects can have deadly consequences for them as well as their children. [New immunotherapy drugs hold promise for treating a variety of cancers] New research could prompt a major rethinking. BRCA mutations were already linked to prostate cancer, and a growing body of studies suggests they might play an even bigger role than early findings indicated. Men with these mutations are more likely than   to contract aggressive, lethal prostate cancer, to be diagnosed at a more advanced stage and to ultimately die of the disease, researchers say. Just last week, a new analysis showed that men with BRCA2 mutations had a higher rate of   prostate cancer at the time of diagnosis and worse outcomes. Ã¢ÂÂWe are only just beginning to truly understand how these genes could impact a manÃ¢ÂÂs risk,Ã¢ÂÂ said Brian Helfand, a urologic oncologist with NorthShore University HealthSystem in Evanston, Ill.   [What men need to know about the Angelina Jolie Ã¢ÂÂ  geneÃ¢ÂÂ]   The latest studies suggest that a manÃ¢ÂÂs BRCA status can be an important piece of information, especially at a time when many doctors are taking a less aggressive stance in screening and treating prostate cancer. The two genes produce proteins that help repair damaged DNA, and alterations in either diminish the bodyÃ¢ÂÂs defense against cancer. Besides being linked to breast, ovarian and prostate cancers, BRCA defects have been implicated in melanoma and pancreatic cancer. If a parent has the mutation, a child has a 50 percent chance of inheriting it. Although many people who have these mutations wonÃ¢ÂÂt ever get cancer, the risks are still much higher. They differ by individual cases, race and gender.   [Five daunting things you need to know about ovarian cancer]   An estimated 12 percent of women will develop breast cancer during their lifetimes, according to the National Cancer Institute. That proportion rises to as high as 65 percent of women who inherit a BRCA1 mutation and about 45 percent for those with a BRCA2 defect. Almost 40 percent of women with a BRCA1 mutation and up to 17 percent with a BRCA2 defect will get ovarian cancer. MenÃ¢ÂÂs risk of getting breast cancer, generally one in 1, 000, rises to about 7 percent for BRCA2 mutation carriers. ThatÃ¢ÂÂs Ã¢ÂÂsignificantly elevated,Ã¢ÂÂ said Marc Schwartz,   of the cancer prevention and control program at the Georgetown Lombardi Comprehensive Cancer Center. A BRCA1 mutation also appears to increase the risk, but itÃ¢ÂÂs not clear by how much. As for prostate cancer, the analysis presented last week at an American Urological Association meeting found that 17 percent of patients with BRCA2 mutations already had advanced disease, four times the rate of patients without the mutation. In a study on African American men, researchers at the Walter Reed National Military Medical Center examined more than 850 archived blood samples and found that blacks were more likely than whites to have a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation, as well as more aggressive disease.   [When the oncologist has the Ã¢ÂÂbreast cancer geneÃ¢ÂÂ]   Ã¢ÂÂThe problem is, everyone associates this with women and their cancers,Ã¢ÂÂ said Bruce Montgomery, an oncologist at the Seattle Cancer Care   of Washington Medical Center. Ã¢ÂÂIn menÃ¢ÂÂs minds, BRCA is about breast cancer, so they donÃ¢ÂÂt see it as relevant. Ã¢ÂÂ Bill Rotter, 63, of Mequon, Wis. wishes he had known earlier about his BRCA2 mutation. He probably wouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have ignored the   lump he discovered next to his right nipple in late 2013. When he finally had a mammogram, ultrasound and then biopsy, invasive ductal carcinoma was found, making him one of about 2, 200 American men diagnosed with breast cancer each year. About 400 die of the disease annually. Rotter had a mastectomy on his right side and a second surgery a few weeks later to remove 13 lymph nodes because the cancer had appeared in a Ã¢ÂÂsentinelÃ¢ÂÂ node. Chemotherapy and radiation followed. He learned of his genetic mutation in between the two surgeries and wonders if earlier action could have prevented the disease from spreading.    Bill Rotter only learned he had a BRCA genetic mutation after being diagnosed with breast cancer. He underwent a mastectomy and now urges other men to find out if theyÃ¢ÂÂre at risk. (Darren Hauck for the Washington Post)  In retrospect, he said, the finding shouldnÃ¢ÂÂt have been a surprise: His father died of prostate cancer at 64, and two of his fatherÃ¢ÂÂs brothers also died of the disease. A male first cousin he had never met died of breast cancer in his 30s. Plus, his familyÃ¢ÂÂs Ashkenazi Jewish heritage increases the chance of being a mutation carrier by tenfold. [  survival rates double for melanoma patients getting immunotherapy]  The father of two sons is now what Boston College sociologist Sharlene   calls a Ã¢ÂÂBRCA warrior,Ã¢ÂÂ one of a small group of men determined to alert others to the dangers of inherited genetic defects. Ã¢ÂÂMy passion is to create awareness about the genetic component of cancer,Ã¢ÂÂ said Rotter, who writes occasional blog posts for Ambry Genetics, a company that offers testing. Ã¢ÂÂIt is amazing how many people, even in the field of medicine, have no clue. Ã¢ÂÂ BRCA mutations have testing and treatment implications for men, who, for starters, should be screened for prostate cancer starting at age 40, according to Theodora Ross, director of the cancer genetics program at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center. In addition, drugs called PARP inhibitors, which have been shown to benefit some ovarian cancer patients with BRCA mutations, may be of use for prostate cancer patients with the gene defects. But if men embrace more genetic testing, theyÃ¢ÂÂll inevitably face the kind of questions women have been dealing with for years. Not all families want to discuss their health risks, as Vincent Moltisanti of Staten Island realized when his breast cancer was diagnosed in 2005. He put together a family medical history  Ã¢ÂÂ   no easy task  Ã¢ÂÂ   and underwent genetic counseling. Ã¢ÂÂIn Italian families, no one gives out information about their health; itÃ¢ÂÂs on a    basis,Ã¢ÂÂ said Moltisanti, who is now 68. Ã¢ÂÂYou have to kind of guess what your great aunts and uncles had and what caused their demise. Ã¢ÂÂ When testing showed he had a BRCA mutation, his daughter, Jaime, was tested and told she was positive as well. She planned to have her breasts and ovaries removed at some point but died of lung cancer in 2014. Moltisanti urged his two older brothers to take action. Neither was interested. Ã¢ÂÂYouÃ¢ÂÂd think they would want to know,Ã¢ÂÂ the retired longshoreman said, adding that he worries not only about both of them but about his nieces and nephews and their children. Scholten understands the risks of family secrets. His sister, a lawyer who lived in Alabama, contracted breast cancer in the early 2000s but kept it to herself because their mother had dementia and she didnÃ¢ÂÂt want to upset her. She didnÃ¢ÂÂt know that a male cousin had died of breast cancer. If her doctors had known about their cousin, maybe they would have ordered testing much earlier, Scholten said. As it happened, his sister didnÃ¢ÂÂt undergo testing until after her ovarian cancer was diagnosed. Ã¢ÂÂThe dots,Ã¢ÂÂ he said, Ã¢ÂÂdidnÃ¢ÂÂt get connected. Ã¢ÂÂ Read more: Biden urges cancer researchers to speed up progress against the disease Stupid Cancer: the edgy advocacy group for young patients   pollution associated with cancer, premature births You just heard another alarming health report. Should you be scared?
Title: Defective Ã¢ÂÂbreast cancerÃ¢ÂÂ genes arenÃ¢ÂÂt just dangerous for women. TheyÃ¢ÂÂre also linked to aggressive cancer in men.

Content: People with cancer that starts on the left side of their colon live significantly longer than those with   tumors, according to a new study that provides insights into how best to match drugs to patients with advanced disease. The retrospective analysis, released Wednesday, involved a federally funded clinical trial with more than 1, 100   patients. Overall, it found that those with   tumors survived for a median of 33. 3  months, while those with   tumors survived for 19. 4 months. Lead author Alan Venook, a professor of medicine at the University of California at San Francisco, said previous studies had suggested tumor location played a role in patientsÃ¢ÂÂ survival, but the effect shown by the new study was greater than he expected.   [HereÃ¢ÂÂs what men need to know about the Angelina Jolie Ã¢ÂÂ  geneÃ¢ÂÂ]   The data also turned up a striking difference in drug efficacy depending on the location of the tumors. Two therapies were used in the trial, in combination with chemotherapy, to see whether one worked better than the other. The answer was no based on initial results. But when the data was evaluated based on a tumorÃ¢ÂÂs location, things changed. Avastin was associated with longer survival times in cases of   tumors, while Erbitux was linked to longer survival with   malignancies. Specifically, patients with   tumors who were given Avastin survived for 24. 2 months compared to 16. 7 months for those treated with Erbitux. Patients with   tumors treated with Erbitux survived 36 months compared to 31. 4 months for those treated with Avastin. Venook said researchers now are looking for the underlying biological reasons for these findings. He noted that the left and right sides of the colon arise from different embryonic tissues and have different characteristics. Ã¢ÂÂAre there more bad actors on the right side?Ã¢ÂÂ he said, adding that the difference between   and   tumors could be Ã¢ÂÂa surrogate for some  Ã¢ÂÂ that scientists have yet to find.   [How this financial counselor saves patients from the toxic effects of high drug prices.]   Richard Kim, an associate professor in the department of gastrointestinal oncology at Moffitt Cancer Center in Tampa, said he wasnÃ¢ÂÂt surprised by the results because earlier studies had pointed to similar, if less definitive, conclusions. But Kim, who wasnÃ¢ÂÂt involved in the latest research, said it was still important because it retrospectively analyzed such a large group of patients. The findings underscore how different the two sides of the colon are and how tumors likely need to be treated differently depending on their location. Once the molecular reasons for that are determined, he said, physicians can apply the information in their choice of cancer drugs. The colon, also called the large intestine, is a strong, long muscle critical for the last phase of digestion. Its right side includes the cecum and the ascending colon, while the left side is made up of the descending colon, the sigmoid colon and the rectum.   [Defective Ã¢ÂÂ Ã¢ÂÂ genes are dangerous for men as well as women.]   Venook said that the results might not apply to patients who didnÃ¢ÂÂt have advanced cancer. The findings will be presented as an abstract at the American Society of Clinical Oncology next month.
