Content: Last April, my wife called me in tears from a hospital in Fairfax, Va., to tell me our 2-year-old daughter, Nusayba, had hepatoblastoma, a rare cancer that primarily affects children during the first 3 years of life. It was most likely stage 4, she said.
Title: My Toddler Survived Cancer. Then Came the Coronavirus.

Content: Sequestered during the pandemic, I find myself thinking that cancer patientsâ expertise in fear can help others heed its warnings. We all need tactics not only to overcome the destructive capacity of fear but also to tap its protective potential.
Title: What Cancer Has Taught Me About Fear

Content: As the coronavirus pandemic spreads, the normal touchstones of everyday life have vanished without so much as a warning. In their place are terrifying thoughts about the future, about loss and about mortality.

Content: Sundown marks the beginning of my motherâs third yahrzeit, the anniversary of her death. I light a candle whose flame will burn for 24 hours, to honor her memory. But I need no candle to remember Ma, who burned bright all on her own. And I have the scars to prove it.
Title: Maybe the Survivorâs Daughter Could Survive

Content: âHave you read this?â the 61-year-old man asked his newest doctor, Madan Jagasia, as they sat in an exam room in the cancer center at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville. The book, titled âDying Well,â prompted a concerned look from the oncologist. You know weâre not there yet, he said he told the patient.
Title: His Immune System Went Out of Whack. The Usual Treatment Didnât Work. Why?

Content: I know bad news is coming my way when my oncologist walks into the exam room with a nurse. It doesnât matter that he introduces her as a new nurse getting to know the system. In my more than six years of seeing my oncologist for metastatic colon cancer, he has never come in accompanied. He wants her in the room to learn how to give bad news.
Title: How to Give Bad News

Content: The new coronavirus is a serious threat to the elderly, as federal officials have been at pains to note recently. But they have stepped gingerly around advice for another group of Americans also at special risk from the infection: those with chronic health conditions.
Title: Coronavirus Threatens Americans With Underlying Conditions

Content: SEATTLE â On an overcast day in Seattle, a few dozen medical staff members, students and emergency workers with symptoms of the fast-spreading coronavirus spent their lunch break driving to a parking garage.
Title: Coronavirus Testing Goes Mobile in Seattle

Content: A shortage of nurses elevated the misery of a woman in my support group during a recent health crisis, she informed us. Because I participate in a clinical trial, in which I am vigilantly monitored in both Bloomington and Indianapolis hospitals, I was surprised. But I quickly began to realize that her ordeal could not possibly be unusual and then to fear that our current health care system is becoming more unfriendly, inhospitable to patients and to nurses as well.
Title: The Nursing Shortage Is Threatening Our Care

Content: Metformin, the worldâs most widely prescribed diabetes drug, might do more than control diabetes. A study in Scotland in 2005 found that people taking metformin were 23 percent less likely to get cancer, suggesting that it might also prevent cancer. Other studies are exploring metforminâs ability to treat cancer, alone and in combination with other therapies.
Title: Repurposing Drugs to Fight Cancer

Content: Howard Wolinsky is a medical journalist in Flossmoor, Ill., who knows better than to go forward with potentially life-changing surgery without first seeking a second opinion.
Title: Before Prostate Surgery, Consider âActive Surveillanceâ

Title: Modern Love Podcast: Lesley Manville Reads âThe Kindness, and Xanax, of Strangersâ

Content: Weâve long been schooled on the lifesaving value of early detection of a potentially deadly cancer. So when a simple blood test was introduced in 1994 that could detect the possible presence of prostate cancer, the second leading cause of cancer deaths among American men, itâs not hard to understand why it quickly became hugely popular.
Title: Debating the Value of PSA Prostate Screening

Content: My patient was brought to the emergency room by his friend because he could no longer catch his breath and had a cough that wouldnât extinguish. He lived with three other young men, all in their early 20s, in a small house located in what many of us considered the no-manâs land between Cleveland and Buffalo, the four of them suspended between spending some time in a community college and finding work that they might one day call a career.
Title: When the Teenager or Young Adult Has Cancer

Content: The conservative radio talk show host Rush Limbaugh said on his live show on Monday that he had advanced lung cancer.

Content: African-American men with prostate cancer are almost twice as likely to die from the illness as white men with the same disease. Disparities in medical care, rather than racial differences in the course of the cancer, may be a large part of the explanation, a new study suggests.
Title: Access to Care May Explain Disparities in Prostate Cancer Outcomes

Content: People who worked at ground zero after the World Trade Center attack in 2001 have higher rates of cancer than the general population, a new study has found.
Title: 9/11 Workers May Be at Higher Cancer Risk

Content: Men with early stage prostate cancer are often advised to increase their intake of vegetables to lower the risk for progression to more serious disease. But now a randomized trial has found that vegetables, whatever other health benefits they may confer, have no discernible effect on prostate cancer progression.
Title: Eating More Vegetables Did Not Affect Prostate Cancer Progression

Content: Do you know what to say or what to do when a friend, relative or acquaintance has cancer?

Content: Just when I needed it most, I learned a valuable life lesson from Lynda Wolters, who has a cancer that is currently incurable, diagnosed just after her 49th birthday. As an Idaho farm girl used to hard work, Ms. Wolters led a healthy life, enjoying ballroom dancing, horseback riding, rafting and hiking when not at work at a law firm. Then, as she wrote in her recently published book, âVoices of Cancerâ:
Title: When Life Throws You Curveballs, Embrace the âNew Normalâ

Content: When in distress with cancer and its treatments, I think of Shakespeare âin disgrace with fortune and menâs eyesâ and all alone lament my downcast state. I am not completely bereft, then, because his poem supports my complaint. Why are sonnets so bracing, I wonder as I launch into a neo-Shakespearean sort of pity party.
Title: When in Distress, Try Sonnets

Content: The cancer death rate in the United States fell 2.2 percent from 2016 to 2017 â the largest single-year decline in cancer mortality ever reported, the American Cancer Society reported on Wednesday. Since 1991 the rate has dropped 29 percent, which translates to approximately 2.9 million fewer cancer deaths than would have occurred if the mortality rate had remained constant.
Title: Cancer Death Rate in U.S. Sees Sharpest One-Year Drop

Content: Vaccines prevent diseases, and being unvaccinated carries a risk. Last year, the World Health Organization ranked vaccine hesitancy, a âreluctance or refusal to vaccinate despite the availability of vaccines,â among the top 10 health threats worldwide, alongside Ebola, H.I.V. and drug-resistant infections.
Title: You Are Unvaccinated and Got Sick. These Are Your Odds.

Content: Artificial intelligence can help doctors do a better job of finding breast cancer on mammograms, researchers from Google and medical centers in the United States and Britain are reporting in the journal Nature.

Content: I found myself unexpectedly back in the hospital last month, some 10 years after my last treatment for an aggressive prostate cancer. Fortunately, it had nothing to do with my cancer; my P.S.A. level, a measure of prostate cancer progression, has been undetectable  since 2009.
Title: Back in the Hospital Again

Content: WASHINGTON âÂ Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia and an icon of the civil rights movement, announced on Sunday that he had advanced pancreatic cancer, but planned to return to Washington to continue work and begin treatment.
Title: John Lewis, Congressman and Civil Rights Icon, Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Brain surgeons are bringing artificial intelligence and new imaging techniques into the operating room, to diagnose tumors as accurately as pathologists, and much faster, according to a report in the journal Nature Medicine.
Title: A.I. Comes to the Operating Room

Content: NASHVILLE â Dear Mr. Lewis, I write with a heavy heart. Stage 4 pancreatic cancer is a brutal diagnosis, so itâs no surprise that last Sunday night the internet erupted with anguish as news of your illness became public. Treatment may give you a âfighting chanceâ to continue working âfor the Beloved Community,â as you wrote in a statement, but itâs painful to think of what you will be called on to bear in the coming months. You have already borne so much for us.
Title: An Open Letter to John Lewis

Content: Amid mounting excitement about the kids flying in for a visit, I look around the apartment with trepidation. Why am I so nervous about their imminent arrival? It has been months since our last get-together and they can replace ceiling light bulbs too risky for me or my older husband to reach.
Title: Sticking to My Own Premises

Content: For decades, scientists have debated whether hair dyes frequently used by women might contribute to cancer. The research has been mixed and inconclusive, but now government investigators have turned up a disturbing new possibility.
Title: Hair Dyes and Straighteners May Raise Breast Cancer Risk for Black Women

Content: I recently was told by my doctor to go see a doctor at the Cancer Institute to be tested for cervical cancer. When I told my mother she freaked out and told me my vegetarian diet was to blame, and that all the soy in my diet was the leading cause of all of this. Could diet lead to cervical cancer?

Content: In the literary world, it has been a year of big, bold ambition. Novelists have stretched their canvases â writing a sentence that runs for a thousand pages; charting the fate of three families in Africa across four generations. Nonfiction writers have made riveting narrative from sprawling, difficult material: The Irish Troubles, the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl, the history of the Lakota tribe. And memoirists have confronted harrowing and profound subjects: Life in New Orleans during and after Hurricane Katrina; decades spent in solitary confinement; psychological abuse in intimate relationships. Below, The New York Timesâs three daily book critics â Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai â share their thoughts about their favorites among the books they reviewed this year, each list alphabetical by author.
Title: Times Criticsâ Top Books of 2019

Content: Thereâs no image in biology more iconic than our chromosomes â all 23 pairs of DNA bundles arrayed in a genetic lineup. But in a surprising number of cases, this picture leaves out something very important.
Title: Scientists Are Just Beginning to Understand Mysterious DNA Circles Common in Cancer Cells

Content: Efforts to reduce deaths from breast cancer in women have long focused on early detection and post-surgical treatment with drugs, radiation or both to help keep the disease at bay. And both of these approaches, used alone or together, have resulted in a dramatic reduction in breast cancer mortality in recent decades.

Content: How could a researcher in computer science improve future cancer care, I wondered, when a trip to Boston afforded me the opportunity to converse with Regina Barzilay, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the recipient in 2017 of a prestigious MacArthur Fellowship, known as a âgenius grant.â After a breast cancer diagnosis in 2014, Dr. Barzilay, who has a doctorate in computer science, began directing her work in artificial intelligence toward helping other patients.
Title: Using A.I. to Transform Breast Cancer Care

Content: By now, youâve probably heard that your body is teeming with bacteria. Some 100 trillion of them live on your skin, in your mouth and in the coils of your intestines. Some protect against infections and help you digest food, while others can make you seriously ill.

Content: THE FIRST CELLAnd the Human Costs of Pursuing Cancer to the LastBy Azra Raza
Title: An Oncologist Asks When Itâs Time to Say âEnoughâ

Content: Pancreatic cancer, which will be diagnosed in about 56,770 people in the United States this year, is the only cancer with a rising mortality rate through 2014, although five-year survival has begun to inch up, from 8 percent to 9 percent by 2016. It remains the nationâs third leading cause of cancer deaths, after cancers of the lung and colon, and it is on track to overtake colon cancer within a decade. Three-fourths of people who develop pancreatic cancer die within a year of diagnosis, and only about one in 10 live five years or longer.
Title: Why Canât We Stop Pancreatic Cancer?

Content: Mathew Knowles, the father and former manager of BeyoncÃ© and Solange, revealed this week that he received treatment for breast cancer this year, becoming one of the rare men to face the disease.
Title: BeyoncÃ©âs Father, Mathew Knowles, on His Breast Cancer Diagnosis

Content: The French drug maker Sanofi said Friday that it was recalling the over-the-counter heartburn drug Zantac in the United States and Canada, a month after the Food and Drug Administration first alerted the public that versions of the drug contained low levels of a cancer-causing contaminant.
Title: Zantac Recall Widens as Sanofi Pulls Its Drug Over Carcinogen Fears

Content: RADICALThe Science, Culture and History of Breast Cancer in AmericaBy Kate Pickert
Title: Want to Learn More About Breast Cancer? Read This Book

Content: The scientist at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston was hardly discreet. âHere is the bones and meet of what you want,â he wrote in a misspelled email to researchers in China.
Title: Vast Dragnet Targets Theft of Biomedical Secrets for China

Content: To the Editor:
Title: Grim Planning: Wills, Estates, Health Care Proxies â¦

Content: Getting a lot of vitamin A in your diet is tied to a lower risk for squamous cell carcinoma, a common form of skin cancer, a review of studies has found.
Title: Foods High in Vitamin A May Help Ward Off Skin Cancer

Content: Ongoing breakthroughs in cancer care involve personalized medicine, we are often informed. Because every malignancy is unique in terms of its genetics and genomics, one size (or protocol) cannot fit all.
Title: A Cancer Researcher Takes Cancer Personally

Content: I spent last week trying to hope for the recurrence of a malignancy, a tumor of at least 1.5 centimeters (a bit more than half an inch) that would be visible on a CT scan.
Title: Living With Cancer: The Trials of Cancer Trials

Content: Chronic drug shortages that threaten patient care are caused by rock-bottom prices for older generic medicines and a health care marketplace that doesnât run on the rules of supply and demand, among other factors, according to a federal report published on Tuesday.
Title: U.S. Blames Drug Shortages on Low Prices and a âBroken Marketplaceâ

Content: In a letter to colleagues announcing his departure as the director of the National Cancer Institute, Dr. Harold Varmus, 75, quoted Mae West. âIâve been rich and Iâve been poor,â he wrote, âand rich is better.â
Title: The Condition Cancer Research Is In

Content: Documentaries about innovative figures donât always offer correspondingly innovative filmmaking. But even coloring within the lines of conventional biographical storytelling, âJim Allison: Breakthroughâ provides an accessible introduction to James P. Allison, who, along with Tasuku Honjo of Japan, won a Nobel Prize in 2018 for discoveries in cancer immunotherapy.
Title: âJim Allison: Breakthroughâ Review: Taking On Cancer

Content: With cancer, there are generally two scenarios â you either have it or you donât. But I am somewhere in the middle, stuck inside a vortex. I donât have cancer, but as a notable breast surgeon told me, âFor you, itâs not a matter of if youâll get it, but when.â And so I find myself on permanent standbyâ¦ just waiting.
Title: Waiting for Cancer

Content: For decades, science has classified cancers by the organ or system in which they begin. That taxonomy is slowly being replaced â but itâs still the indispensable way to understand the odds.
Title: The Cancer Almanac

Content: I got a call from a friend last year. He had prostate cancer and wanted some help thinking through what to do. He had gone to his doctors for the details about his physical condition. He was calling me for help dealing with the other condition he knew he was facing â excessive fear of this dreaded disease that sometimes does more harm than good, what some have called âcancer phobia.â [1]
Title: Cancer on the Brain

Content: I am not a cancer survivor, and neither are the women in my cancer support group.
Title: Not a Cancer Survivor

Content: As the elderly man with an incurable cancer lay dying, he told his son he had only one regret. Rather than enjoying his last weeks of life with the people and places he loved, he had squandered them on drug treatments that consumed his days and made him miserable.
Title: Cancer Treatment at the End of Life

Content: Cancer is a terrible bedfellow. It tosses and turns, snorting and kicking and snatching more than its share of the covers. It never caresses or croons lullabies, but instead hisses innuendos into the wee hours, turning wakefulness into a wake. No wonder insomnia plagues cancer patients, often sending us to chemical aids. Ten years after diagnosis, could I finally dispense with them?
Title: Sleeping With Cancer

Content: Cancer is a disease of mutations. Tumor cells are riddled with genetic mutations not found in healthy cells. Scientists estimate that it takes five to 10 key mutations for a healthy cell to become cancerous.
Title: Researchers Explore a Cancer Paradox

Content: Nine years ago, Brenda Gray, a former schoolteacher in North Carolina, discovered she had Type 2 diabetes.
Title: Juggling Diabetes and Cancer

Content: As nations across Africa have made remarkable progress against infectious diseases, more people are living long enough to develop cancer.
Title: The Cancer Divide

Content: For more than a century, researchers were puzzled by the uncanny ability of cancer cells to evade the immune system. They knew cancer cells were grotesquely abnormal and should be killed by white blood cells. In the laboratory, in Petri dishes, white blood cells could go on the attack against cancer cells. Why, then, could cancers survive in the body?
Title: Breaking Through Cancerâs Shield

Content: Periodontal disease in older women is associated with an increased risk for cancer, a new study concludes.
Title: Gum Disease Tied to Cancer Risk in Older Women

Content: More breast cancers have been found at earlier â and potentially more treatable â stages since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act.
Title: With Obamacare, More Breast Cancers Diagnosed at Earlier Stages

Content: While dealing with lung cancer, my friend Nancy K. Miller seethed in her blog at pharmaceutical advertisements and hospital commercials that bombard us daily with pictures of joyous cancer patients supported by doting intimates. These jubilant characters have nothing to do with the frustrated people we know who periodically erupt in righteous indignation. I often must remind myself that anger needs to be understood as the flip side of the roiling fear that cancer instills in patients and also in caregivers.
Title: The Anger of Cancer

Content: A 17-year study has concluded that screening mammography â in which all women in certain age groups are routinely screened for breast cancer â does not reduce the incidence of advanced tumors, but does increase the diagnosis of lesions that would never have led to health problems.
Title: The Downside of Breast Cancer Screening

Content: Two decades ago, David Walmer went on a volunteer mission with his church to Haiti. He was sent to paint walls at a hospital in the seaside town of LÃ©ogÃ¢ne, but when the people there learned that Walmer was a doctor â he was a fertility specialist at Duke University â they asked him to spend the week with a local obstetrician-gynecologist named Jean-Claude Fertilien. Walmer was shocked by what he saw: Fertilien finishing a hysterectomy with the aid of a flashlight when the hospital generator failed to restart, for instance, or when an anesthesiologist wasnât available for an emergency C-section, the doctor just numbing the skin and cutting. At one point, Walmer was called to the bedside of a young woman in her mid-20s with undiagnosed cervical cancer who had gone into septic shock. There was nothing to be done for her, and she died right in front of him. Walmer was appalled. In the United States, cervical cancer is considered a preventable disease.
Title: The MacGyver Cure for Cancer

Content: During periods of hardship, laughter can lighten the load. Cracking up may be a better option than breaking down, or so the recent publications of three young adults with cancer suggest. Somewhat discomfiting, the jests of these authors serve as an antidote and alternative to the despairing negativity or fake positivity that plagues patients like me. Their punch lines zing with pleasure that offsets the pain of their edgy insights.
Title: Cancer Humor

Content: Ensconced in Babyland, I attend the relentless rhythms of soothing my visiting 3-month-old grandson, who cannot seem to sleep more than 40 minutes at a stretch. I have determined to jettison all other obligations with two exceptions: providing meals for my nursing daughter and reading a memoir lent to me by a friend who must have known how it would move me. In âThe Kitchen Congregation,â Nora Seton mourns the death of her mother, a novelist, from cancer at age 56.
Title: Mothers With Cancer

Content: The Japanese composer and keyboardist (and, occasionally, actor) Ryuichi Sakamoto posted a note on his website on Thursday saying that he has throat cancer, and has decided to cancel his performances at the Sapporo International Art Festival of which he is the guest director.
Title: Cancer Sidelines Japanese Composer

Content: Twenty years ago, the fight against cancer seemed as if it were about to take a dramatic turn.
Title: Why Arenât Cancer Drugs Better? The Targets Might Be Wrong

Content: PITTSBURGH â October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and I have breast cancer. The country is fully pinked out in support of breast cancer screening and research, and though I know all the pink is meant to make me feel good, to tell me that the entire country has my back, I actually find it profoundly alienating. Pink is not a serious color, though cancer is a very serious disease. Pink is about femininity; cancer is about staying alive.
Title: Breast Cancer Is Serious. Pink Is Not.

Content: WHO knew that carcinogens had their own lobby in Washington?
Title: The Cancer Lobby

Content: The teenage years can be tough enough under the best of circumstances. But when cancer invades an adolescentâs life, the challenges grow exponentially.
Title: Healing Teenage Cancerâs Scars

Content: Over the past few decades, changes in the treatment of breast cancer amount to a revolution in patient care. And itâs not over yet. There was a time when the standard approach was a radical mastectomy, which involved removal of not just the breast, but all the lymph nodes in the armpit and underlying muscles in the chest wall. This approach has been replaced by less extensive surgery that, through decades of clinical trials, has proved to be equally effective at treating patients, as well as safer and less disfiguring. Even simple mastectomies, in which most nodes and the muscles were left intact, have become far less common. Dr. J. Dirk Iglehart, director of the Susan F. Smith Center for Womenâs Cancers at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, estimated that he now performs a tenth of the number of mastectomies than when he entered the field in the 1970s.
Title: Outsmarting Breast Cancer With Evolving Therapies

Content: ITâS HIGH TIME a book did for epidemiology what Jon Krakauerâs best-selling âInto Thin Airâ did for mountain climbing: transform a long sequence of painfully plodding steps and missteps into a narrative of such irresistible momentum that the reader not only understands what propels enthusiasts forward, but begins to strain forward as well, racing through the pages to get to the heady views at the end.
Title: On the Trail of Cancer

Content: In recent years, health officials have pushed aggressively to include more women in clinical trials of new drugs. Gone is the ban that once excluded women of childbearing age from participating in studies. Even scientists who work with animals are now encouraged to include mice and rats of both sexes.
Title: Whoâs Missing From Breast Cancer Trials? Men, Says the F.D.A.

Content: ST. LOUIS â In 1966, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said, âOf all the forms of inequality, injustice in health care is the most shocking and inhuman.â While major advances have been made in health care, ethnic and racial disparities remain in the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of many illnesses, particularly prostate cancer.
Title: Prostate Cancer Isnât Colorblind

Content: Alcohol consumption is known to increase the risk for breast cancer. But a new study suggests that moderate drinking has little effect on survival after diagnosis, and may reduce deaths from cardiovascular disease.
Title: Alcohol and Breast Cancer Survival

Content: Susan Gubarâs column, Living With Cancer, recently addressed the challenges of finding clothes to accommodate a body altered by cancer surgery and treatment.
Title: Cancer Patients Tell Us About Clothing for Changing Bodies

Content: As it turns out, not even naked mole rats are totally immune to cancer.
Title: Two Naked Mole Rats, Seemingly Immune to Cancer, Got Cancer

Content: For most of my adult life I have answered the question âOccupation?â with one word: journalist. I still do, but now I am tempted to add a phrase.
Title: Tom Brokaw: Learning to Live With Cancer

Content: Eve Ensler is an activist, playwright and author with a reputation as a fearless champion of women â attesting to their pain and their joys, but most of all celebrating their stories. Enslerâs signature play, âThe Vagina Monologues,â is a series of soliloquies that seek not only to honor and demystify womenâs bodies but to reclaim that most intimate of possessions, a womanâs self seen through her own eyes. Its voices are tough, tender, hilarious and heartbreaking.
Title: The Cancer Monologue

Content: From a top view of the voice box (larynx) and vocal cords, this animation shows the formation of a malignant tumor on the right vocal cord.
Title: Throat Cancer

Content: Widespread screening for colorectal cancer has helped prevent an estimated half-million cases of the disease since the mid- 1970s, a new study suggests.
Title: Colon Cancer Screening Saves Lives

Content: A large new study has found no connection between vasectomy and prostate cancer.
Title: Vasectomy Not Tied to Prostate Cancer Risk

Content: A womanâs cancer risk appears to increase with her height, a new study shows.
Title: Cancer Risk Increases With Height

Content: Like many people, I attribute my cancer to bad luck. So the feature-length documentary âCompany Townâ shocked me. It contends that the economic consequences of racial discrimination increase cancer risk. Watching the movie led me to realize that wretched statistics on cancer mortalities are also linked to racial inequalities. Black cancer should matter, but has it mattered in the past and will it matter in the future?
Title: Black Cancer Matters

Content: For all its peculiar horror, cancer comes with a saving grace. If nothing else can stop a tumorâs mad evolution, the cancer ultimately dies with its host. Everything the malignant cells have learned about outwitting the patientâs defenses â and those of the oncologists â is erased. The next case of cancer, in another victim, must start anew.
Title: Scientists Ponder the Prospect of Contagious Cancer

Content: One of the great disconnects of our history is how a nation birthed on the premise that all men are created equal could enshrine an entire race of people as three-fifths of a human being. We tried to fix that, through our bloodiest war and a series of amendments that followed.
Title: The Cancer in the Constitution

Content: The latest cancer report from the World Health Organization provides persuasive evidence that eating meat can cause cancer, but the risk is very small for most people.
Title: Meat as a Cause of Cancer

Content: It may sound flippant to say that many cases of cancer are caused by bad luck, but that is what two scientists suggested in an article published last week in the journal Science. The bad luck comes in the form of random genetic mistakes, or mutations, that happen when healthy cells divide.
Title: Cancerâs Random Assault

Content: HISTORICALLY, the science of epidemiology was directed toward identifying and controlling epidemics of infectious disease. In a study just published in the New England Journal of Medicine, my colleagues and I highlight another important job for epidemiologists: identifying and controlling epidemics of medical care.
Title: An Epidemic of Thyroid Cancer?

Content: CLEVELAND â WHEN it airs on Monday, the Ken Burns-produced documentary âCancer: The Emperor of All Maladiesâ will emphasize how much more we now know about the genetic basis for cancer. This year, according to President Obama, cancer research and funding will focus on so-called precision, personalized or targeted medicine â using cancerâs molecular underpinnings to develop drugs that attack the genes or gene products that make up cancerâs factory while sparing normal cells. What a beautiful concept.
Title: Trying to Fool Cancer

Content: I thought about the boring self-absorption of illness during a queasy day after eating a breakfast of smoked salmon leftovers from a party for out-of-town visitors.
Title: Living With Cancer: Is It Back?

Content: If you live with breast cancer, love someone with breast cancer or worry about your risk for breast cancer, you are part of a global community of women and men whose lives have been touched by the disease.
Title: Faces of Breast Cancer

Content: Hannah Graffeo, 26, is a design researcher at IBM in New York.
Title: An Ethnographer of Cancer Care for IBM Watson

Content: BOSTON
Title: The Cancer of Optimism

Content: Many people take a daily low-dose aspirin to lower the risk of heart disease, and several studies have shown that regular aspirin use reduces the risk for some cancers. Now a long-term analysis has found that its population-wide benefits against cancer may be even greater than previously believed.
Title: Quantifying Aspirinâs Reduction in Cancer Risk

Content: A new federal study found that Americans are getting screened for three major cancers â breast, cervical and colorectal â at rates far below national targets. The shortfall is especially high among adults who lack insurance or regular access to a doctor, partly because the recession drove employers to lay off workers or cut health benefits.
Title: The Shortfall in Cancer Screening

Content: We have no shortage of dispatches from the cancer wars, what with doctors, patients, essayists, scientists and journalists in every possible combination and permutation all checking in at length from the front.
Title: Cancerâs Ordered Disorder

Content: Federal health officials took a reasonable and humane step last week when they proposed to add 50 cancers to the list of illnesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund to treat and compensate emergency workers and residents exposed to toxic fumes, dust and smoke from the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001.
Title: Ground Zero Cancers

Content: Cancer is on the rise around the world and poses a particular threat in many low- and middle-income countries. Death tolls globally far exceed those from such devastating infectious diseases like AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. According to recent reports from international health agencies, global mortality from those three diseases has, in fact, been cut substantially â by nearly half in the case of malaria â over the past decade.
Title: The Global Cancer Burden

Content: When my cancer support group visited a research lab, the discussion of proteomics, fibroblasts and microRNAs made about as much sense to me as Lewis Carrollâs nonsense rhymes. Yet the meeting confirmed my suspicion that the gulf between patients and researchers needs to be bridged.
Title: The Jabberwocky in a Cancer Lab

Content: A new study suggests there may be a link between the consumption of sugar-sweetened drinks and fruit juices and the development of cancer.
Title: Sugary Drinks Linked to Cancer Onset

Content: Dr. Harold E. Varmus, a Nobel Prize winner and former director of the National Institutes of Health, announced Wednesday that he would step down as head of the National Cancer Institute on March 31. Dr. Varmus, who presided over the institute during a government shutdown, cuts in funding and significant advances in cancer research, was appointed by President Obama in 2010, after advising Mr. Obamaâs campaign and serving on the White House Council of Advisors on Science and Technology. He said in a letter of resignation that he would establish a research laboratory at the Meyer Cancer Center at Weill Cornell Medical College in New York. His deputy, Dr. Douglas R. Lowy, will become acting director of the institute.
Title: Chief of National Cancer Institute Resigns

Content: After a Danish study last week reported finding more breast cancer cases among women who use hormone-based birth control methods, many women were left wondering: How significant is the risk, and what are the alternatives?
Title: Birth Control Pills Protect Against Cancer, Too

Content: Mammography has become a fighting word in recent years, with some researchers questioning its value and others staunchly defending it.
Title: Look for Cancer, and Find It

Content: While attending a young adult cancer conference, the Life, Interrupted columnist Suleika Jaouad reflects on how revealing her cancer experiences has helped her build a community.
Title: Going Public With Cancer

Content: Steve Cara expected to sail through the routine medical tests required to increase his life insurance in October 2014. But the results were devastating. He had lung cancer, at age 53. It had begun to spread, and doctors told him it was inoperable.
Title: Harnessing the Immune System to Fight Cancer

Content: For years, doctors have recommended daily aspirin to lower cardiovascular risk in certain men and women. Now, for the first time, an expert panel is recommending aspirin therapy to prevent heart attacks and colorectal cancer.
Title: In a First, Aspirin Is Recommended to Fight a Form of Cancer

Content: Three days after her double mastectomy for recurrent breast cancer, Elissa Bantug, then 25, needed to feel whole again. But when she expressed a desire for intimacy, her fiancÃ© (now her husband) walked away, leaving her feeling hurt and angry and worried about their future together.
Title: Battling Cancer Together

Content: Stories of misdiagnoses circulate throughout the testimonies of people contending with all sorts of cancers. Such errors, made by patients as well as doctors, bring in their wake a sense of betrayal, self-recrimination and anger. Should we accept them as inevitable?
Title: Missing a Cancer Diagnosis

Content: My patient came to see me every six months or so with his wife of 40 years, making the five-hour drive from West Virginia, where he managed a few businesses. He had myelodysplastic syndrome, a type of bone marrow cancer that in his case was indolent, requiring only regular shots with a hormone, but no chemotherapy â yet.
Title: Keeping Cancer a Secret

Content: In 2011, at age 28, the songwriter and performer Benjamin Scheuer was given a diagnosis of stage 4 Hodgkin lymphoma, a cancer of the lymph nodes. He recounted his experience, along with other family perplexities, when he played himself in his one-man autobiographical musical, âThe Lion,â which opened Off Broadway last year. In the new video âCure,â directed by Peter Baynton and premiered here on Well, Mr. Scheuer conveys the dread that brands cancer patients, whether or not their type of disease is treatable.
Title: An Artist Takes On Cancer

Content: Maybe it was in âsome warm little pond,â Charles Darwin speculated in 1871, that life on Earth began. A few simple chemicals sloshed together and formed complex molecules. These, over great stretches of time, joined in various combinations, eventually giving rise to the first living cell: a self-sustaining bag of chemistry capable of dividing and spawning copies of itself.
Title: Cellular âCheatersâ Give Rise to Cancer

Content: Hormone therapy for prostate cancer is associated with an increased risk for dementia, a new study has found.
Title: Hormone Therapy for Prostate Cancer Tied to Dementia

Content: My mom was given a diagnosis of lung cancer this past year. And whether I liked it or not, almost midway through my career, it put me squarely in the position of being re-educated about cancer from the other end of the biopsy needle. It also gave me the opportunity to approach my patients with a new resolve in the coming year.
Title: Resolutions of a Cancer Doctor

Content: Claudia Steinman saw her husbandâs BlackBerry blinking in the dark. It had gone untouched for several days, in a bowl beside his keys, the last thing on anybodyâs mind. But about an hour before sunrise, she got up to get a glass of water and, while padding toward the kitchen, found an e-mail time-stamped early that morning â âSent: Monday, Oct. 3, 2011, 5:23 a.m. Subject: Nobel Prize. Message: Dear Dr. Steinman, I have good news for you. The Nobel Assembly has today decided to award you the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2011.â Before she finished reading, Claudia was hollering at her daughter to wake up. âDad got the Nobel!â she cried. Alexis, still half-asleep, told her she was crazy. Her father had been dead for three days.
Title: Is the Cure for Cancer Inside You?

Content: âBleakâ is the predominant adjective in writing about Michael Herschâs music. âDark,â âsomberâ and âanguishedâ are also omnipresent. Little wonder, given that his subjects have included the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Danteâs âInferno,â the Holocaust and conditions found in a 1960s psychiatric ward.
Title: Cancer Haunts a Composerâs Life and Work

Content: Jessy Acen, 30, who has advanced breast cancer, contends with her own poverty and with Uganda's limited resources in her fight to stay alive.
Title: The Cancer Divide: Jessy

Content: âThereâs nothing makes us feel so much alive as to see others die,â exclaims a dying Ralph Touchett in Henry Jamesâs âPortrait of a Lady.â At my most snarky, it seems to me that thereâs nothing makes some people so invigorated as to see others debilitated by cancer or by medical responses to it. To my beloved friends, I hiss what must be tedious recriminations against off-the-wall reactions to my continuing treatments. But here Iâll simply wing it.
Title: Living With Cancer: For the Birds

Content: Cristie Kerr led from start to finish at last yearâs Lacoste Ladies Open de France, winning by four in a subdued setting as the European womenâs tour and Kerr reflected on losing friends to cancer.
Title: Cristie Kerr Is on a Mission to Fight Cancer

Content: Last year, right before the winter holidays, the nurse practitioner palpating my breast paused and returned to a certain spot.
Title: Tackling Cancer Anxiety

Content: Mary Singleton, 57, learned in July that she had Stage 4 breast cancer. After the diagnosis her son, George, moved home to Memphis to help take care of her and to help run her printing business.
Title: The Cancer Divide: Mary

Content: After remarks from the actor Michael Douglas attributing his throat cancer to a sexually transmitted virus, men are concerned that they, too, might be at risk.
Title: Throat Cancer and H.P.V.

Content: Some cancer patients adopt a âdonât ask, donât tellâ policy with their doctors. Either they are more afraid or more brave than I am. I keep on asking, though the telling sometimes jolts me.
Title: Living With Cancer: Truthiness

Content: The ocean contains a vast number of living things, including many, many pathogens â from bacteria that thrive on coral to fungi that infect lobsters. A drop of seawater may hold 10 million viruses.
Title: Cancer Is Contagious Among Clams. What About Us?

Content: An international panel of doctors has decided that a type of tumor that was classified as a cancer is not a cancer at all.
Title: Itâs Not Cancer: Doctors Reclassify a Thyroid Tumor

Content: A large study has found that body mass index, waist circumference and diabetes are all associated with an increased risk for liver cancer. Liver cancer is the sixth most common cancer, and its incidence has tripled since the mid-1970s in the United States.
Title: Obesity and Diabetes Tied to Liver Cancer

Content: Tzippy, 38, an Orthodox Jew and a mother of seven children, recounted the choices she faced after testing positive for a genetic mutation associated with breast cancer.
Title: The Cancer Divide: Tzippy

Content: Like most of the boys in his San Salvador neighborhood, Gabriel Alessandro Mayorga Hernandez â Gabo, to his family and friends â loves soccer. But in 2014, just before he turned 12, he found himself exhausted by even a short game. Eventually he became too tired to play at all and started having headaches so severe they made him vomit. When he developed chest pains and difficulty breathing, his grandmother took him to the doctor, where X-rays and blood work indicated that he had acute lymphoblastic leukemia, or A.L.L., a blood cancer that develops most often in young children.
Title: A Promising Step in Tackling Childhood Cancer

Content: Many people would be surprised to hear that grilling carries potential cancer risks. But each year, the American Institute for Cancer Research publishes guidance for âcancer-safe grilling,â cautioning consumers to avoid two types of compounds that have been tied to cancer. These compounds, called polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and heterocyclic amines, get generated when food, especially meat, is cooked on a grill. They have not been proven to cause cancer in people, but lab studies have shown they alter DNA in a way that could lead to cancer.
Title: 10 Ways to Lower the Cancer Risk of Grilling

Content: In October, Nancy Borowickâs photographs of her familyâs struggle with cancer appeared on Lens. The images were also published in The Timesâs Metropolitan section, along with a moving article by Michael Winerip that chronicled her parents as they received treatment â Howie for pancreatic cancer, Laurel for breast cancer â and prepared for Nancyâs October wedding to Kyle Grimm.
Title: Life, and Death, With Cancer

Content: In the United States the median age at which colon cancer strikes is 69 for men and 73 for women. In Chad the average life expectancy at birth is about 50. Children who survive childbirth â and then malnutrition and diarrhea â are likely to die of pneumonia, tuberculosis, influenza, malaria, AIDS or even traffic accidents long before their cells accumulate the mutations that cause colon cancer.
Title: In Developing World, Cancer Is a Very Different Disease

Content: THE war against cancer can be confusing, with providers, insurers and policy makers debating the effectiveness of treatments, prevention programs and research. But there is one significant victory within our grasp. There is, increasingly, a consensus that CT screening for lung cancer can save thousands of lives each year.
Title: A Cancer Battle We Can Win

Content: A photographer whose parents both faced cancer â and who both rallied to be present for her wedding â photographed the last two months of her fatherâs life since that wedding.
Title: Life, and Death, With Cancer

Content: Itâs time to renew my driverâs license! I never thought I would live to see the day. Back in 2008, when pressed to disclose my life expectancy, my oncologist estimated three to five years. Figuring that I was an average patient, I split the difference and believed I had four years left. Yet here I am, about to celebrate my fourth âcancerversaryâ with a trip to the dreary and backlogged bureau of motor vehicles, elated by the conviction that even if I expire within the next year or so, my license wonât.
Title: Living With Cancer: Itâs About Time

Content: Epidemiologists have long been puzzled by a strange pattern in their data: People living at higher altitudes appear less likely to get lung cancer.
Title: Unraveling the Ties of Altitude, Oxygen and Lung Cancer

Content: Like many adults who survived childhood cancer, Karen Cormier always assumed she would never get pregnant.
Title: After Cancer, Fertility Is Often Within Reach

Content: The powerful algorithm that has populated the earth with 10 million species, each occupying a different ecological niche, is an example of what computer scientists call ârandom generate and test.â
Title: Human Ingenuity Takes On Cancerâs Darwinian Ways

Content: In 1947, children who developed acute lymphocytic leukemia died. Dr. Sidney Farber, a pathologist at Boston Childrenâs Hospital, was so distressed doing autopsies on these children that he moved into the clinic and, against the advice of more conservative colleagues, began treating children with aminopterin, a highly toxic drug that starved their cancerous white blood cells of critical nutrients.
Title: The Road to Cancer Treatment Through Clinical Trials

Content: âIâd like to review some data with you,â my patient said to me as I sat down cater-corner from him at the small desk in the exam room.
Title: Numbers in the Cancer Fight

Content: Women in wealthy countries are more likely to be diagnosed with breast cancer, but much less likely to die than women in the developing world.
Title: Where Is Breast Cancer?

Content: WASHINGTON â The Obama administration announced on Monday that it hoped to spend $1 billion to fund a cancer âmoonshotâ in search of a cure. But in the costly world of biological research, such a sum may be better described as a cancer slingshot, researchers said.
Title: $1 Billion Planned for Cancer âMoonshotâ

Content: David Jayâs âMale Scar Projectâ shows an often unseen population of people affected by breast cancer.
Title: The Men of Breast Cancer
Breast Cancer Confusion

Content: We live in a big, diverse society. There are essentially two ways to maintain order and get things done in such a society â politics or some form of dictatorship. Either through compromise or brute force. Our founding fathers chose politics.
Title: The Governing Cancer of Our Time

Content: Cancer can, and sometimes does, strike twice. It famously happened to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court, who was successfully treated for colon cancer in 1999 and then for pancreatic cancer in 2011. If not for the regular checkups she underwent after colon cancer, it is quite likely that her pancreatic cancer, which is rarely found early, would not have been detected while still curable.
Title: When Cancer Strikes Twice

Content: Childhood exposure to indoor insecticides is associated with an increased risk for certain childhood cancers, a new study has found.
Title: Pesticides Tied to Childhood Cancers

Content: A review of more than a thousand studies has found solid evidence that being overweight or obese increases the risk for at least 13 types of cancer. The study was conducted by a working group of the International Agency for Research on Cancer, part of the World Health Organization.
Title: Obesity Is Linked to at Least 13 Types of Cancer

Content: PHILADELPHIA â Since Darren Daulton succumbed to brain cancer on Aug. 6, heartfelt tributes have honored the way he led a raucous Phillies team to the World Series in 1993.
Title: The Brain Cancer That Keeps Killing Baseball Players

Content: Many YouTube videos about prostate cancer are unreliable sources of information.
Title: Online Cancer Information Is Often Unreliable

Content: The detective work we do in my lab involves genes and cancer cells, not crimes. Or so I thought, until several years ago, when one of my graduate students at the University of Michigan emailed me to say that her research had been sabotaged.
Title: A Crime in the Cancer Lab

Content: I was so excited for what lay ahead, I nearly forgot to wave goodbye to my parents. Armed with a college diploma, my first job offer, a one-way ticket to Paris and a new pair of heels, I was ready to take on anything. Little did I know, I would be back in New York seven short months later. But my parents would not be taking pictures at the airport or chatting about my future plans. I would be in a wheelchair, too weak to walk.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Facing Cancer in Your 20s

Content: Everyone recognizes the pink ribbon of breast cancer, but fewer know the color of testicular (orchid), uterine (peach), lung (white), pancreatic (purple), or head and neck (burgundy/ivory) cancers. Given current research and treatment, as well as a commitment to equity, is it time to imagine a rainbow coalition?
Title: Living With Cancer: A Rainbow Coalition

Content: At a construction site on 126th Street in East Harlem, what is being built could be a matter of life and death to those who visit.
Title: The High-Tech, Big-Footprint Cancer Center

Content: Q. Should you be listed as an organ donor on your driverâs license if you are a cancer survivor?
Title: Cancer Survivor and Organ Donor: Can You Be Both?

Content: As an avid reader of obituaries, Iâve been struck by how many people these days are succumbing to pancreatic cancer, a cancer long considered rare.
Title: How to Minimize Pancreatic Cancer Risk

Content: Elephants ought to get a lot of cancer. Theyâre huge animals, weighing as much as eight tons. It takes a lot of cells to make up that much elephant.
Title: The âZombie Geneâ That May Protect Elephants From Cancer

Content: During her yearlong battle with leukemia, Suleika Jaouadâs diagnosis has tested and strengthened her relationship with her boyfriend, who stuck by her side throughout her treatments.
Title: Love in the Time of Cancer

Content: Misleading symptoms, difficult treatments and low survival rates: three men and women speak about living with lung cancer.
Title: Patient Voices: Lung Cancer

Content: A prominent cancer organization is for the first time recommending Americans initiate colorectal cancer screening at age 45 instead of waiting until age 50, a threshold long endorsed by many other medical groups. The new guidelines, from the American Cancer Society, would extend routine colorectal cancer screening to an additional 22 million American adults between the ages of 45 and 49 and send a clear message that colorectal cancer, which has been rising in young adults, is no longer just a disease of older people.
Title: Cancer Group Calls for Colorectal Cancer Screening Starting at Age 45

Content: A diagnosis of cancer, even an early-stage, highly curable cancer, can prompt some people to feel as if theyâve suddenly lost control of their future and that they must do whatever they can to regain it.
Title: The Risk of Alternative Cancer Treatments

Content: Oslo â EVER since Neil Armstrong walked on the moon, American politicians have promised âmoonshotsâ â huge programs, stocked with technology and experts, to solve presumably intractable problems. A common target is cancer: Earlier this year President Obama announced the National Cancer Moonshot Initiative, a $1 billion program led by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.
Title: We Wonât Cure Cancer

Content: As an alumna of Cornell who had been thrilled by the selection of the universityâs first female president, Elizabeth Garrett, last fall, I was deeply pained to learn of her untimely death from colon cancer at age 52 last month. May it be a teachable moment that could save many from a disease that will be diagnosed in an estimated 134,000 people and claim 49,000 lives in the United States this year.
Title: A Teachable Moment on the Need for Colon Cancer Screening

Content: What do you think is the most commonly asked question of a person who has, or has had, cancer? If you guessed, âHow are you?â you got it right.
Title: What Not to Say to a Cancer Patient

Content: Next week, as Washington braces for the Supreme Court health care ruling, Lisa Niemi Swayze, the widow of the actor Patrick Swayze, will hit Capitol Hill to advocate for a bill that seeks more federal attention â and presumably money â to combat pancreatic cancer, which killed her husband in 2009.
Title: A Celebrity Push on Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Teenagers who were overweight at 17 were at significantly increased risk for developing colon cancer later in adulthood, and those who were obese were at increased risk for rectal cancer as well, according to a new report.
Title: Overweight at 17? Your Colon Cancer Risk Rises

Content: A group of experts advising the nationâs premier cancer research institution has recommended changing the definition of cancer and eliminating the word from some common diagnoses as part of sweeping changes in the nationâs approach to cancer detection and treatment.
Title: Scientists Seek to Rein In Diagnoses of Cancer

Content: Peter Way, an engineer in Fort Collins, Colo., was devastated when his black Labrador, Prince, developed melanoma in his mouth shortly after turning 10. âHis upper palate was not looking so good, and he was getting worse,â Mr. Way said.
Title: Learning From Dogs With Cancer
Colon cancer - series

Content: Low survival rates make pancreatic cancer a tough disease to face. Three people speak about survival, loss and living with a diagnosis.
Title: Patient Voices: Pancreatic Cancer

Content: DALLAS â ON Aug. 6, researchers announced in The New England Journal of Medicine that they had found that mutations in a gene called PALB2 greatly increase the risk of breast cancer. This is one of the biggest developments since the discovery in the â90s of the role of mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes in breast and ovarian cancer.
Title: Cancer and the Secrets of Your Genes

Content: A troubling racial divide in breast cancer mortality continues to widen in most major cities around the country, suggesting that advances in diagnosis and treatment continue to bypass African-American women, according to new research.
Title: The Breast Cancer Racial Gap

Content: I FREQUENTLY care for patients with advanced cancer. A majority have already tried some combination of surgery, chemotherapy and radiation. Many have landed back in the hospital because the cancer has returned or spread widely and left them in intractable pain or struggling to breathe.
Title: The Problem With Miracle Cancer Cures

Content: As an ovarian cancer patient whose life is being extended by a clinical trial, I was delighted to learn this summer that research on gynecological cancers is undergoing an unusually productive period. But Iâm dismayed that at the same time there has been a steep decline in clinical trials available in the field.
Title: The Crisis in Gynecological Cancer Research

Content: At M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston, the world's largest stand-alone cancer hospital, patients and caregivers exist in a parallel universe where nothing but conquering cancer matters.
Title: On the Front Line of the War on Cancer

Content: African-American women in the United States have reached a dubious milestone. For the first time, the incidence of breast cancer among black women is equal to that of white women, according to a sweeping new report from the American Cancer Society.
Title: A Grim Breast Cancer Milestone for Black Women

Content: Working as a flight attendant may increase the risk for cancer.
Title: Airline Crew Have Higher Cancer Rates

Content: âItâs not a sprint, itâs a marathon.â I heard those words often during my years as a soccer player at Drexel University. The mantra reminded me of my goals, and helped me endure the pain of practice and the mental stress of competition.
Title: An Athlete Tackles Cancer

Content: My patient had first come to us two years earlier from another hospital, where he had been admitted with back pain so severe it prevented him from walking.
Title: Waiting to Treat the Cancer

Content: âDoes anyone know that September is Ovarian Cancer Month?â Antoinette Gallelli asks in âOvarian Cancer, My Walk With It,â a memoir self-published two years ago. A banner in an infusion room reminded her of the commemoration. âThe saddest thing was that I didnât hear it on the television; in fact, I personally didnât hear it anywhere. I would hope that in time this will change.â
Title: Living With Cancer: Teal Ribbons

Content: Last month, thousands of Marines and their families were blocked in federal court from pursuing their claim that the government had given them cancer. The decision, involving people exposed to contaminated drinking water while stationed at Camp Lejeune, a base in North Carolina, didnât consider the science.
Title: A Cancer Cluster Is Tough to Prove
The Promise of Precision Cancer Treatment

Content: CHICAGO â Women with ovarian cancer may be able to stave off relapses for an extra half-year or so by taking a drug already approved to treat kidney cancer, researchers reported here on Saturday. But it will not be clear whether the drug prolongs womenâs lives until the patients are followed longer.
Title: Drug Used to Treat Kidney Cancer May Hold Off Relapses of Ovarian Cancer

Content: In a memoir, âThe Summer of Her Baldness,â the visual artist and theorist Catherine Lord finds âthe cancer closet . . . at least as complicated as the sexuality closetâ: âYou can never get entirely out and you can never get entirely back in.â
Title: Living With Cancer: In and Out of the Closet

Content: When I was invited to attend a prostate cancer group called âUs Tooâ in my town, its members were meeting in a private room in our public library. About eight men, some accompanied by their wives, had great difficulty communicating their discomfort about urine leaks and diapers. They wanted to know what strategies my gynecological cancer group used to talk about sexual issues. To alleviate their daily problems, the participants needed professional help that I could not furnish.
Title: Living With Cancer: Collateral Damage

Content: CAMBRIDGE, England â A cancer research lab on the outskirts of Cambridge seems like an unlikely place to find innovations in gaming.
Title: Outsourced Cancer Research, by Spacecraft

Content: An unusually bold stand by doctors at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York has forced a big drug company to reduce the cost of an overpriced drug for treating colorectal cancer that was no better than a cheaper competitor and did almost nothing to extend a patientâs life. It is a heartening sign that alert and aggressive physicians can potentially play a major role in helping to reduce the escalating costs of health care for treatments of marginal value.
Title: Incredible Prices for Cancer Drugs

Content: The vocalist begins her song with people shocked by a diagnosis they cannot accept, women not yet ready to admit they have cancer.
Title: Living With Cancer: Dancing With N.E.D.

Content: Although Amgen is the worldâs biggest biotechnology company, the drug maker has been mostly absent from one of the industryâs biggest and fastest-growing markets: cancer drugs.
Title: Amgen Buys Producer of Drugs for Cancer

Content: MELBOURNE, Australia â Ross Hutchins is a cancer survivor, but he does not, he will not, define himself that way. He is not happy just to be here, back on a tennis court, back in a Grand Slam. He appreciates the sympathy, but please, enough.
Title: After Cancer âDisruption,â a Determined Comeback

Content: On a night several months ago, the digital clock blinked 11:53. My husband was asleep so I crept down the hall, only turning on a light when I got into my study. On a sheet on the floor were fabrics laid out for a new quilt in the tumbling block pattern. Pictures of my friends kept me company, but there was no photo of the woman over whom I was grieving.
Title: Living With Cancer: Tumbling Blocks

Content: Should weight loss be prescribed as a treatment for breast cancer?
Title: Putting Breast Cancer on a Diet

Content: New evidence that women are more likely to be harmed than helped by screening tests for ovarian cancer is disturbing. The tests do nothing to prevent healthy women from dying from the usually fatal disease. Yet they often lead doctors to perform needless surgeries that cause serious complications in many patients.
Title: False Promises on Ovarian Cancer

Content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that all adults aged 50 to 75 be screened for colorectal cancer, but the agency announced this week that one third of them â 23 million people â have never been properly tested.
Title: Colon Cancer Screening Lags

Content: Abnormal lipid levels are associated with an increased risk for recurrence of prostate cancer, researchers report.
Title: Prostate Cancer Recurrence Risk Tied to Lipid Levels

Content: In his 2010 book âThe Emperor of All Maladies,â Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee lamented the gap between âthe new scienceâ going on in research laboratories and âthe old medicineâ most cancer patients receive. Yet for almost two years, I have benefited from the new medicine derived from the new science, much to my surprise.
Title: Living With Cancer: The New Medicine

Content: While I recover from a fractured pelvis, I have time to remember the day after a less ruinous fall two years ago. No bones broken then, but I quickly developed a shiner and then slowly an insight into the color of cancer.
Title: Living With Cancer: Being Erased

Content: People who carry the stomach bacteria known as Helicobacter pylori are at increased risk for ulcers and stomach cancer. But even when antibiotic treatment has eliminated the bacterium, stomach cancer may still arise. A new study suggests that one reason may be the long-term use of proton pump inhibitors, or P.P.I.s, acid-reducing medicines sold under brand names such as Prilosec and Prevacid.
Title: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Stomach Cancer Risk

Content: When my husband learned he had advanced lung cancer, he didnât even want to speak to an oncologist about chemotherapy. He saw no point in treatment that could not cure him and might make him feel worse.
Title: When Treating Cancer Is Not an Option

Content: Now that Brazil has introduced vaccines against cervical cancer, more than 80 percent of girls in the Americas can get them, the Pan American Health Organization announced last month.
Title: Expansion in Use of Cancer Vaccine

Content: I DID not know I have the BRCA mutation. I did not know I would likely get breast cancer when I was still young, when the disease is a wild animal. I caught it fast and I acted fast, but I must have looked away: By the time of my double mastectomy, the cancer had spread to five lymph nodes.
Title: The Breast Cancer Gene and Me

Content: You smoked for years. Maybe you still do. Now that Medicare promises to begin covering lung cancer screening, should you sign up?
Title: On Medicare and Assessing the Value of Lung Cancer Screening

Content: A consortium of research institutions reports that while cancer death rates have continued to decline since the 1990s, the incidence of some cancers associated with human papillomavirus, or HPV, has increased.
Title: Some Cancers Linked to HPV on the Rise

Content: At the end of yoga sessions for cancer patients, we are told to say to ourselves, âI am whole, healed and healthy in this and every moment.â Perversely, since in yoga we express aspirations as if they were already so, the sentence reminds me of people who congratulate me on being âcancer free.â Stable disease often goes unrecognized.
Title: Living With Cancer: Chronic, Not Cured

Content: The actor Michael Douglas has done for throat cancer what Rock Hudson did for AIDS and Angelina Jolie did for prophylactic mastectomy. By asserting last week that his cancer was caused by a virus transmitted during oral sex, Mr. Douglas pushed the disease onto the front pages and made millions of Americans worry about it for the first time.
Title: Oral Cancer Sneaks Up

Content: Sophisticated new prostate cancer tests are coming to market that might supplement the unreliable P.S.A. test, potentially saving tens of thousands of men each year from unnecessary biopsies, operations and radiation treatments.
Title: New Prostate Cancer Tests Could Reduce False Alarms

Content: The relationship between exercise and cancer has long both intrigued and puzzled oncologists and exercise physiologists.
Title: How Exercise May Lower Cancer Risk

Content: Like many people with advanced-stage cancer, I wonder when I will decide about treatment, âEnough is enough.â In helping me formulate an answer to this question, Atul Gawandeâs latest book, âBeing Mortal,â will now play an indispensable part.
Title: Living With Cancer: Being Mortal

Content: Hanover, N.H.
Title: Cancer Survivor or Victim of Overdiagnosis?

Content: Studies have shown that male infertility is associated with a slightly increased risk for various types of cancer, including testicular cancer, possibly because of shared genetic factors. About one in six infertile men have azoospermia, or no viable sperm in their ejaculate, and these men may be at the highest cancer risk, a new study shows.
Title: Male Infertility Linked to Cancer

Content: Aerobic fitness seems to alter the interior workings of cells in ways that may substantially lower the risk of breast cancer.
Title: Fitness May Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: American women face conflicting advice about whether to be screened for breast cancer, at what age and how often. The decisions they make are often more strongly influenced by fear or a friendâs experience than by a thorough understanding of the benefits and risks of mammography.
Title: Retesting Breast Cancer Axioms

Content: In the 1970s, womenâs health advocates were highly suspicious of mastectomies. They argued that surgeons â in those days, pretty much an all-male club â were far too quick to remove a breast after a diagnosis of cancer, with disfiguring results.
Title: Facing Cancer, a Stark Choice

Content: This weekâs Ask an Expert features Julia Bucher, a registered nurse and an author of a caregiving book, who will answer questions on handling a family memberâs new illness, specifically cancer. âSandwich generationâ baby boomers, thrust into the role of home caregivers to spouses, partners, parents or children, need to know how to begin solving problems, when to ask for help and what to do about the physical and emotional side effects of cancer treatment.
Title: Advice for Caregivers of Relatives With Cancer

Content: An unimaginable diagnosis is followed by worry, fear and tough decisions. Five people speak about how childhood cancer changed their lives.
Title: Patient Voices: Childhood Cancer

Content: Frequent heartburn increases the risk for throat cancer, a new study has found, and over-the-counter antacids may provide protection.
Title: Heartburn Tied to Throat Cancer

Content: After the drama of diagnosis passes and the preliminary offers of assistance dissipate, a few hardy souls hang in with cancer patients for the long haul. If we are lucky, they tender surprisingly creative acts and gifts.
Title: Imaginative Caregiving for the Cancer Patient

Content: The use of aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs significantly reduces the risk for cancer, but no one has been able to explain why. Now researchers have found that these drugs slow the accumulation of a type of DNA change called somatic genome abnormalities, or S.G.A.âs, that lead to uncontrolled cell growth.
Title: How Aspirin Might Stem Cancer

Content: AT Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, we recently made a decision that should have been a no-brainer: we are not going to give a phenomenally expensive new cancer drug to our patients.
Title: In Cancer Care, Cost Matters

Content: On Monday evening I stood on a stage in front of a thousand people and talked about what Iâve learned since my diagnosis with cancer two years ago at the age of 22.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Changed by Cancer

Content: Depression is not cancer. Itâs a completely different disease. Yet when I look back on my husbandâs depression and death by suicide three years ago, it sure looks a lot like cancer to me.
Title: When Depression Is Like a Cancer

Content: CARACAS, Venezuela â President Hugo ChÃ¡vez is receiving chemotherapy or radiation treatments in the aftermath of his most recent cancer surgery, a government official said for the first time on Friday.
Title: Venezuelan Official Confirms ChÃ¡vez Receiving Cancer Treatments

Content: When my husband, incapacitated by knee surgery, was placed in a rehabilitation facility, I lost my caregiver. Don can no longer drive me to the cancer center or undertake the chores he used to do for both of us, and he must consider his own overriding physical problems, not mine. With the good luck of my relatively stable physical condition, I struggle to meet our basic needs. However, an unluckier member of my support group found herself in dire circumstances after her partner traveled overseas on a business trip.
Title: Living With Cancer: Alone and Ghosted

Content: As if confined in a sinister maze, cancer patients often discover that some routes lead to forking branches. It may be impossible to find a way through the bewildering medical labyrinth without feeling lost. My oncologist Dr. Matei, pointing out treatment paths, tells me to choose: âItâs up to you,â she says.
Title: Living With Cancer: Difficult Choices

Content: A large review of available data has confirmed what many experts have long suspected: Taking small amounts of aspirin over long periods of time reduces the risk of colon cancer and certain other cancers.
Title: Aspirin May Cut Cancer Risk

Content: CARACAS, Venezuela â President Hugo ChÃ¡vez of Venezuela arrived in Cuba early Monday to have surgery for what appears to be an aggressive form of cancer, leaving behind a nation hanging on the outcome of his treatment.
Title: ChÃ¡vez in Cuba for Cancer Surgery

Content: A study by researchers at Stanford suggests that additional cancer-related deaths from radioactive materials released in last yearâs accident at the Fukushima Daiichi plant could be as low as 15 cases and as high as 1,300 â a range that highlights the uncertainties associated with any attempts to predict the disasterâs health effects. Among the factors complicating an assessment: the governmentâs estimates of how much radioactive material leaked from the plant could change again. An earlier World Health Organization study said the amount of radiation exposure fell below what it said were cancer-causing levels. The latest study was conducted by the meteorologist John E. Ten Hoeve and the environmental engineering professor Mark Z. Jacobson, who said that deaths might have been higher if winds had not blown most of the radioactive material out to sea. The studyâs best estimate was that the disaster would cause 130 additional cancer deaths among the public, almost all in Japan.
Title: Japan: Estimate of a Cancer Toll

Content: Many studies have found that obesity is associated with an increased risk for prostate cancer. Now a new study suggests that the degree of risk may depend on where in the body the fat is.
Title: Excess Body Fat Tied to Fatal Prostate Cancers

Content: Like someone with bipolar disorder, I see-saw between irritability and elation, depression and euphoria. As a cancer patient, I cycle through curses and blessings at a hectic rate.
Title: Living With Cancer: Curses and Blessings

Content: Three years.
Title: Life Beyond the Cancer Clinic

Content: The psychological fallout from a false positive mammogram test result can last up to three years, a new study has found.
Title: Stress of Cancer Scare May Last Years

Content: âNo thanks, I already have cancer,â I said to the radiologist. Since the magnified images of calcifications in my right breast looked neither obviously benign nor obviously malignant, he had just recommended a biopsy. Even after I explained that I have been dealing with advanced ovarian cancer since 2008, he must have judged me daft. But I was thinking: Who needs another?
Title: Who Needs Another Cancer?

Content: When I blow out my birthday candles next month, Iâll celebrate being alive. But my 25th birthday will also mark a one-year countdown to the date when I will no longer have health insurance.
Title: Life, Interrupted: The Cost of Cancer

Content: A new study has found widespread failure among doctors to follow clinical guidelines for treating ovarian cancer, which kills 15,000 women a year in this country. This disturbing news shows the kind of challenge that health care reformers are up against in improving medical care â even when cost is not the issue.
Title: Inadequate Treatment of Ovarian Cancer

Content: Most women with ovarian cancer receive inadequate care and miss out on treatments that could add a year or more to their lives, a new study has found.
Title: Widespread Flaws Found in Ovarian Cancer Treatment

Content: Using large national cancer registries, researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have found vast racial disparities in breast cancer severity, treatment and mortality.
Title: Racial Differences in Breast Cancerâs Toll

Content: On a bright, cold Sunday in mid-January, I returned home from visiting a frail member of my cancer support group and opened the garage to haul the recyclables up the steep driveway to the street. After a few steps, my feet started to slip and I fell with a thud on my bottom. The big bin toppled over me, scattering plastic containers and cardboard boxes, as my hands reached down to feel a sheet of ice that had been invisible on the asphalt.
Title: Living With Cancer: A Farewell to Legs

Content: BERKELEY, Calif. â ONE of the nastier aspects of breast cancer is that it doesnât have the five-year sell-by date of some other malignancies: youâre not considered âcuredâ until you die of something else. Although it becomes less likely, the disease can come back eight, 10, even 20 years after treatment. I fell on the wrong side of those odds.
Title: The Wrong Approach to Breast Cancer

Content: Obesity is linked to prostate cancer, scientists know, but itâs not clear why. On Monday, researchers reported a surprising connection.
Title: High-Fat Diet May Fuel Spread of Prostate Cancer

Content: When I decided to undergo a lumpectomy earlier this month after a diagnosis of D.C.I.S., I learned a new word that makes me grateful for my privileges but also worried about the privations of others. The word is lagniappe, a bonus, like the 13th doughnut in the purchased dozen. As I went through yet another operation, my way was eased by the kindness of friends and relatives.
Title: The Haves and Have-Nots of Cancer Care

Content: When I consider what happened to an esteemed friend and colleague, I fume at the mayhem that ovarian cancer wreaks and at the deficient care she received at a university hospital in another town. Do instances of medical negligence sometimes go unnoticed because patients are so debilitated that they cannot testify â especially if they are still in treatment?
Title: Living With Cancer: Careless Care

Content: This year, more than 1.6 million Americans â 0.5 percent of the population â will receive a diagnosis of cancer. Their treatment will consume at least 5 percent of the countryâs health care spending, at a cost that is growing faster than all other areas of medicine. Doctors and patients recognize that this is unsustainable and that we need to change the way we deliver care.
Title: A Plan To Fix Cancer Care

Content: A cutting-edge cancer treatment can also cure certain kinds of heart failure in mice, scientists reported on Wednesday.
Title: This Treatment Can Cure Cancer. Can It Mend the Heart?

Content: Q. Are cruciferous vegetables really helpful for fighting cancer?
Title: Do Cruciferous Vegetables Really Fight Cancer?

Content: DESPITE great strides in prevention and treatment, cancer rates remain stubbornly high and may soon surpass heart disease as the leading cause of death in the United States. Increasingly, we and many other experts believe that an important culprit may be our own medical practices: We are silently irradiating ourselves to death.
Title: We Are Giving Ourselves Cancer

Content: Each year more than four million CT scans are performed on children, and they are increasing the risk for future cancer, a new study suggests.
Title: The Possible Cancer Toll of CT Scans

Content: At times, I was so encased in the stoicism needed to endure cancer treatments that I could not feel much of anything unless someone else felt sorry for me.
Title: Living With Cancer: Shedding Tears

Content: A new study has reignited a debate about whether men should use a baldness drug to prevent prostate cancer.
Title: New Debate on Prostate Cancer Drug

Content: Reducing testosterone levels with androgen deprivation therapy, or A.D.T., is a common treatment for prostate cancer. But a new study has found that it more than doubles the risk of dementia.
Title: Prostate Cancer Treatment Can Raise Dementia Risk

Content: When I called on readers to submit the blogs they loved for the Motherlode blogroll, one name came up more than any other: Lisa B. Adams. And I can understand why. The best personal blogs come from people on a journey through something that is as intense as anything theyâve ever experienced, and Lisa is on a journey none of us want to be on. She has breast cancer, and last fall she learned that the cancer had metastasized to her bones, becoming Stage 4 breast cancer.
Title: Blogging Her Life With Cancer

Content: In her book âMy Poets,â Maureen McLane reminded me of a poetic form called the cento. It consists of snippets of verse composed by other writers.
