Title: Living With Cancer: A Quilt of Poetry

Content: When I started clearing my closet a few weeks after the 18th chemo infusion, I struggled against bitterness about my changed body. After all, someone else could wear the clothes that no longer fit me. Then why not bundle them up, along with jackets, shirts, pants and shoes unworn because they were a professional uniform no longer needed?
Title: Living With Cancer: Making Room

Content: It is our luck that we are seven women grappling with various stages and types of gynecological cancer in a small group that no one in his or her right mind would want to join.
Title: Living With Cancer: We Are Seven

Content: A tense moment at a meeting of my support group convinced me that cancer patients have wildly divergent needs for information about their condition. This is especially true when the disease is considered chronic, rather than curable.
Title: Living With Cancer: Nude Mice

Content: Andrew gave his mother, Regina Hensley, a reason to live. We follow the pair as she fights a history of addiction and he fights an aggressive form of cancer.
Title: Caring for a Son With Cancer, and for Herself

Content: WASHINGTON â President Obama signed a presidential memorandum on Thursday creating a White House task force on cancer, the first step in what Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has called a âmoonshotâ to cure the disease, administration officials said.
Title: Obama Takes First Step in a Cancer âMoonshotâ

Content: It was a big deal for Melanie Kennedy, a former accountant from Bangor, Northern Ireland, to indulge in a massage at the spa at Culloden Estate and Spa, in Belfast, earlier this year. Ms. Kennedy has stage four incurable breast cancer, and getting spa treatments have been a challenge ever since she was diagnosed almost six years ago at the age of 35. The lymph nodes she had removed in her arm meant that an overly aggressive massage could lead to painful swelling called lymphedema, and on top this risk, she was self-conscious about the scars from her mastectomy.
Title: At These Hotels and Spas, Cancer Is No Obstacle to Quality Care

Content: Investigators released preliminary results from a clinical trial of T-DM1, a drug that targets and kills a type of cell that appears in some breast cancers.
Title: Ferrying a Drug Into a Cancer Cell

Content: Too little of the money the federal government spends on breast cancer research goes toward finding environmental causes of the disease and ways to prevent it, according to a new report from a group of scientists, government officials and patient advocates established by Congress to examine the research.
Title: Report Faults Priorities in Studying Breast Cancer

Content: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has recently drawn criticism for proposing a long list of cuts to higher education programs. Congress must mull those potentially traumatic trims while reauthorizing standard financing for students and colleges, but thereâs one positive change that might sneak by in the process: the bipartisan Deferment for Active Cancer Treatment Act, which would let borrowers defer their student loan payments when they get a cancer diagnosis â and for six more months after their active treatment is completed. Itâs a courtesy Congress extends now to borrowers who are unemployed, deployed in the military or volunteering with the Peace Corps.
Title: Give Cancer Patients a Break on Student Loans

Content: Sarah DeBord was 24 when she first noticed blood in her stool. She saw a gastroenterologist who did a procedure called a flexible sigmoidoscopy to examine her lower colon and rectum, then gave her a diagnosis of hemorrhoids.
Title: What Young People Need to Know About Colon Cancer

Content: IâM a climate scientist who has just been told I have Stage 4 pancreatic cancer.
Title: Cancer and Climate Change

Content: The skirmishing over Herceptin and other cancer medicines is part of a long-running struggle to make drugs affordable to the worldâs poorest people.
Title: Fighting Breast Cancer in India

Content: Fewer than 10 percent of the 100,000 men each year who get a diagnosis of early-stage prostate cancer and have the option of leaving the cancer in place while watching it actually do so. The rest want to just get rid of it, with surgery or radiation. But those treatments can have serious side effects like impotence and incontinence.
Title: Drug Seen to Curtail Cancer Left in Prostate

Content: Eating processed meat is associated with an increased risk for breast cancer, a review of studies found.
Title: Eating Processed Meats Tied to Breast Cancer Risk

Content: âBut what caused it?â my patient asked, referring to the failure of her bone marrow to make the blood cells the rest of her organs craved. She was profoundly anemic and seemed to tire from even asking the question.
Title: Wondering What Caused the Cancer

Content: Every time I sign a consent form, I wonder how informed I really am. Do physicians â can physiciansâ convey the consequences of their treatments to cancer patients? Or is this where artists step in?
Title: Living With Cancer: An Artistâs View

Content: DUBLIN â The Irish government announced on Monday that it was opening an official inquiry and setting up phone help lines and emergency testing after it emerged that a publicly funded smear test program had mistakenly cleared at least 208 women who later received diagnoses of cervical cancer.
Title: Ireland Investigates Cervical Cancer Screening Scandal

Content: Since a cancer diagnosis in 2008, I have always taken reading material with me on all hospital trips. For one visit, which took nine hours, my reading material included a posthumously published memoir: Paul Kalanithiâs âWhen Breath Becomes Air.â
Title: A Cancer Memoir of Literature and Science

Content: The fear of diagnosis, the risks of treatment and coping with a diagnosis of cancer â seven men talk about their experiences with prostate cancer.
Title: Patient Voices: Prostate Cancer

Content: The risk of developing obesity-related cancer is increasing in successive generations, along with increasing rates of obesity.
Title: Obesity Tied to Higher Cancer Rates in Younger People

Content: MY identical twin sister, Karen, and I have two older brothers. We were raised in Blue Bell, Pa., where my father was a family physician and my mother was a nurse. We spent summers on Long Beach Island, N.J., where both of us were waitresses at a busy seafood restaurant.
Title: Two Wars Against Cancer

Content: Disease has a way of invading your social space, forcing your hand. Will you tell your family and close friends only? What about acquaintances and work mates? Will you share your diagnosis on Facebook? Who knew cancer needed a social consultant?
Title: Life, Interrupted: Cancer Is Awkward

Content: A study of cancer patients in Washington State has found they were twice as likely to file for bankruptcy as people without cancer. The study, led by researchers from the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, linked bankruptcy court records and information from the regional cancer registry on about 200,000 cancer patients, and compared them with a similar group of people from the same area who did not have cancer. Young people with cancer experienced the highest bankruptcy rates, the study found, up to 10 times the rate of bankruptcy filings among older age groups.
Title: Washington: Cancer Patients More Prone to Bankruptcy

Content: Scientists have used genetically reprogrammed bacteria to destroy tumors in mice. The innovative method one day may lead to cancer therapies that treat the disease more precisely, without the side effects of conventional drugs.
Title: New Weapons Against Cancer: Millions of Bacteria Programmed to Kill

Content: A vaccine that protects women against cervical cancer also appears to protect them against throat cancers caused by oral sex, and presumably would protect men as well, according to a study released Thursday.
Title: HPV Vaccine Found to Help With Cancers of Throat

Content: Obesity is linked to an increased risk for colorectal cancer in younger women, new research has found.
Title: Obesity Tied to Colon Cancer Risk in Younger Women

Content: The skirmishing over Herceptin and other cancer medicines is part of a long-running struggle to make drugs affordable to the worldâs poorest people.
Title: Fighting Breast Cancer in India

Content: When I was diagnosed in November 2008, I began counting forward, assuming I would die by November 2013, at the latest. Prognosis for late-stage ovarian cancer is three to five years, even with state-of-the-art treatment. November, which happens to be the month of my birthday, became a memento mori: an annual observance of my projected end. A statistical approximation, the prognosis tolled in my ears like a death sentence.
Title: Living With Cancer: Gravy Days

Content: The former president Jimmy Carter publicly talked about his health at a news conference in Atlanta on Thursday, eight days after he said that he had cancer.
Title: Carter Discusses Cancer Diagnosis

Content: Cancer immunotherapy drugs, which spur the bodyâs own immune system to attack tumors, hold great promise but still fail many patients. New research may help explain why some cancers elude the new class of therapies, and offer some clues to a solution.
Title: Cancerâs Trick for Dodging the Immune System

Content: Higher vitamin D levels may be linked to longer breast cancer survival, a new study reports, and the effect is particularly strong among premenopausal women.
Title: Vitamin D Linked to Longer Breast Cancer Survival

Content: I was sitting at my desk in our clinic workroom when my fellow walked in to discuss our new patient, whom he had just seen. I grabbed a pen and piece of paper to take notes and pulled up the patientâs chart on the computer.
Title: Transgender at the Cancer Clinic

Content: After a series of conflicting reports about whether vitamin pills can stave off chronic disease, researchers announced on Wednesday that a large clinical trial of nearly 15,000 older male doctors followed for more than a decade found that those taking a daily multivitamin experienced 8 percent fewer cancers than the subjects taking dummy pills.
Title: Multivitamin Use Linked to Lowered Cancer Risk

Content: After many rounds of chemo, radiation and surgery, Christine Bray was told she had one month to live. Then, doctors looked at her cancerâs DNA â and found its Achillesâ heel. FoundationOneÂ®, FoundationOneÂ®Heme, and FoundationOne CDxâ¢ are diagnostic tests to identify genomic mutations associated with your cancer. This information, along with other information, may be used by your physician to identify potential treatment options. But these diagnostic tests do not confer any therapeutic benefit. The tests might not identify therapies that could be of benefit to you and you might not have positive outcomes with therapies identified through these tests. The outcomes described in this video are not typical and you should not expect to experience similar results. Consult your doctor about whether diagnostic testing is appropriate for you. Treatment decisions are the responsibility of your physician. These tests are available by prescription only. FoundationOne CDxâ¢ is a next-generation sequencing based in vitro diagnostic device for detection of substitutions, insertion and deletion alterations, and copy number alterations in 324 genes and select gene rearrangements, as well as genomic signatures including microsatellite instability (MSI) and tumor mutational burden (TMB) using DNA isolated from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor tissue specimens. For the complete intended use statement, including companion diagnostic indications and warnings and limitations, please see the FoundationOne CDx Technical Information, www.foundationmedicine.com/f1cdx.
Title: The Promise of Precision Cancer Treatment

Content: Higher levels of vitamin D have been associated with a reduced risk of colon cancer in many observational studies. A new analysis has found a possible reason.
Title: How Vitamin D May Fight Colon Cancer

Content: The soul singer Sharon Jones has been diagnosed with cancer and has postponed a tour and the release of her next album, she announced on her bandâs Web site. The singer said she has stage 1 bile duct cancer, which has yet to spread, and will have surgery immediately to remove the tumor.
Title: Sharon Jones Postpones Tour to Seek Cancer Treatment

Content: Alex Trebek, the long-time âJeopardy!â host, announced on Wednesday that he has pancreatic cancer. Mr. Trebek acknowledged that the disease has a low survival rate but said he plans to beat it.
Title: Trebek Reveals Cancer Diagnosis

Content: A simple mouthwash rinse may be able to predict the dangerous recurrence of a kind of throat cancer that is rapidly increasing in heterosexual men, according to a new study.
Title: A Mouthwash Rinse May Predict Throat Cancer Recurrence

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved the second in a radically new class of treatments that genetically reboot a patientâs own immune cells to kill cancer.
Title: F.D.A. Approves Second Gene-Altering Treatment for Cancer

Content: Celgeneâs drug Abraxane prolonged the lives of patients with advanced pancreatic cancer by almost two months in a clinical trial, researchers reported Tuesday, signifying an advance in treating a notoriously difficult disease but not as big a leap as some doctors and investors had hoped.
Title: Drug Is Shown to Help Pancreatic Cancer Cases

Content: Readers were invited to ask Julia Bucher, a registered nurse and an author of a caregiving book, about handling a family memberâs new illness, specifically cancer. Dr. Bucher is an associate professor of nursing at York College of Pennsylvania, in York, Pa., where she has taught community health nursing, research and health policy since 2006. She also works as an advanced practice nurse at one of York Collegeâs nurse-managed centers. Her research focus is problem solving and coaching the family caregivers of people with cancer. For eight years she was a regional planner for the American Cancer Society. She received her Ph.D. in community systems planning and development from Penn State University in 1992.
Title: Advice for Caregivers of Relatives With Cancer

Content: Nearly half of women who had lumpectomies for breast cancer had second operations they may not have needed because surgeons have been unable to agree on guidelines for the most common operation for breast cancer, a new study finds. It also hints that some women who might benefit from further surgery may be missing out on it.
Title: Breast Cancer Surgery Rules Are Called Unclear

Content: A decision by the nationâs leading breast cancer advocacy group, Susan G. Komen for the Cure, to largely cut off financing for breast cancer screenings at Planned Parenthood set off howls of outrage last week. Once again, it seemed, political gamesmanship was jeopardizing womenâs health.
Title: Real Race in Cancer Is Finding Its Cause

Content: Young women who regularly drink alcohol before their first pregnancy may be increasing their risk for breast cancer, a new study reports.
Title: Drinking When Young Increases Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Nine women share their experiences with breast cancer.
Title: Fighting Breast Cancer, and Winning

Content: When you travel to cancer central, you may find yourself more perplexed by the currency, language, customs, costumes, cuisine and time zone than you would have been if you had landed in Timbuktu. In Hospital City, you can lose your way as well as your confidence in everything you took for granted.
Title: Living With Cancer: Hospital City

Content: Sometimes sessions with my oncologist resemble meetings with a therapist. Why am I entranced with a woman who continues to prescribe procedures that distress me? The attraction was instantaneous, maybe because I had been so dismayed by her predecessor.
Title: A Cancer Doctor of Oneâs Own

Content: Men with vasectomies may be at an increased risk for the most lethal form of prostate cancer, researchers have found. But aggressive cancer nonetheless remains rare in these patients.
Title: A Vasectomy May Increase Prostate Cancer Risk

Content: When Texas voters approved the creation of the $3 billion Cancer Prevention and Research Institute of Texas in 2007, state officials said they hoped it would help Texas become an epicenter of cancer research, accelerate the development of lifesaving treatments and expand prevention programs.
Title: Waiting for Cloud to Lift on State Cancer Institute

Content: After many rounds of chemo, radiation and surgery, Christine Bray was told she had one month to live. Then, doctors looked at her cancerâs DNA â and found its Achillesâ heel. FoundationOneÂ®, FoundationOneÂ®Heme, and FoundationOne CDxâ¢ are diagnostic tests to identify genomic mutations associated with your cancer. This information, along with other information, may be used by your physician to identify potential treatment options. But these diagnostic tests do not confer any therapeutic benefit. The tests might not identify therapies that could be of benefit to you and you might not have positive outcomes with therapies identified through these tests. The outcomes described in this video are not typical and you should not expect to experience similar results. Consult your doctor about whether diagnostic testing is appropriate for you. Treatment decisions are the responsibility of your physician. These tests are available by prescription only. FoundationOne CDxâ¢ is a next-generation sequencing based in vitro diagnostic device for detection of substitutions, insertion and deletion alterations, and copy number alterations in 324 genes and select gene rearrangements, as well as genomic signatures including microsatellite instability (MSI) and tumor mutational burden (TMB) using DNA isolated from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor tissue specimens. For the complete intended use statement, including companion diagnostic indications and warnings and limitations, please see the FoundationOne CDx Technical Information, www.foundationmedicine.com/f1cdx.
Title: The Promise of Precision Cancer Treatment

Content: The prospect of a party frightened me â probably because the enforced isolation of cancer treatments has rendered me hypersensitive. It was raining outside and festivities would not begin until after 8 p.m. But my husband and I had promised to attend the celebration of a book publication. So we dragged ourselves to Judith and Aidanâs house where I hoped to find a comfortable chair in which I would not look like the battle-ax at Mrs. Dallowayâs party whom everyone had thought long dead.
Title: Living With Cancer: Life of the Party

Content: Aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs taken orally may reduce the risk for squamous cell carcinoma, a review of studies has found.
Title: Pain Relievers Tied to Reduced Skin Cancer Risk
A Woman's Guide To Understanding Gynecologic Cancers

Content: Like a man on a flying trapeze, K.T. Jones has leapt from one medical study to another during his 15-year struggle with cancer, and he has no doubt that the experimental treatments he has received have saved his life.
Title: In Cancer Trials, Minorities Face Extra Hurdles

Content: Julia put a glass jar of turkey-tail mushrooms on the restaurant table. Drinking home-brewed tea helps her combat the side effects of treatment. The day before a blood test â which would reveal whether or not an experimental drug was working â I placed one delicate bit on the center of my palm. The ridged striations and concentric ruffles reminded me of the tiny angel-wing shells that Leslieâs partner had collected on Sanibel Island for our cancer support group.
Title: Living With Cancer: Keep On Cooking

Content: Sean Parker discusses his support of immunotherapy research.
Title: Sean Parker on Cancer Research

Content: A recent CT scan made me realize that the clinical trial extending my life effectively excludes all but the most privileged cancer patients.
Title: Living With Cancer: The Cost of Trials

Content: For decades, Patricia Lewis toiled as a security guard for NYC Health & Hospitals, a duty she performed along with a second, and sometimes a third, job.
Title: As She Fights Cancer, a Woman Strives for Normalcy

Content: Men with high-risk prostate cancer treated with only 18 months of hormone therapy live just as long as those treated for a more standard 36 months, a new study has found.
Title: Study Points to Shorter Treatments for Prostate Cancer

Content: Glen Sather, the Rangersâ president and general manager, had surgery to treat prostate cancer on Thursday at Weill-Cornell Medical Center in New York and was expected to be off the job for a few days.
Title: Sather Has Surgery to Treat Prostate Cancer

Content: To the shock of many cancer experts, the most common cancer in South Korea is not lung or breast or colon or prostate. It is now thyroid cancer, whose incidence has increased fifteenfold in the past two decades. âA tsunami of thyroid cancer,â as one researcher puts it.
Title: Study Points to Overdiagnosis of Thyroid Cancer

Content: When I was growing up, my dream was to one day become a veterinarian. In fourth and fifth grade, I volunteered every day after school at a veterinarianâs clinic. I didnât view it as an âinternshipâ â in my mind, I was apprenticing for a certain future in the field. When I was 10, I asked for an incubator for Christmas. By spring, I was carting around a dozen baby chicks in my purple doll stroller. In middle school I walked dogs at the local animal shelter. But as I got older, there was college, summer travel, then my first real job, at a law firm in France. I was entering the âreal world,â as they say in commencement speeches. And there was no room in my adult life for a dog.
Title: A Cancer Patientâs Best Friend

Content: Gov. Jerry Brown of California is undergoing treatment for localized prostate cancer caught in its early stages, his office announced on Wednesday. Dr. Eric Small, Mr. Brownâs oncologist, said that the cancer would be treated with a short course of conventional radiotherapy. âThe prognosis is excellent, and there are not expected to be any significant side effects,â he said in a statement released by Mr. Brownâs office. The treatment is expected to be completed by the first week of next year, the statement said. Mr. Brownâs office said the governor, who is 74, would continue to work a full schedule.
Title: California: Governor Being Treated for Prostate Cancer

Content: Cancers of the colon and rectum have been declining in older adults in recent decades and have always been considered rare in young people. But scientists are reporting a sharp rise in colorectal cancers in adults as young as their 20s and 30s, an ominous trend.
Title: Colon and Rectal Cancers Rising in Young People

Content: Men treated for prostate cancer who took aspirin regularly for other medical conditions were less likely to die of their cancer than patients who werenât taking aspirin, according to a new study published on Tuesday in The Journal of Clinical Oncology.
Title: Aspirin May Aid Cancer Recovery

Content: Breast cancer is not always pink.
Title: When Men Get Breast Cancer

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved a new immunotherapy drug from Roche to treat bladder cancer, a form of cancer for which there have been no significant new medicines in years.
Title: F.D.A. Approves an Immunotherapy Drug for Bladder Cancer

Content: âI think itâs time to switch therapies,â I told my patient, as he and his wife sat next to each other by the wall of my exam room.
Title: The Punishing Cost of Cancer Care

Content: EVERY New Year when the government publishes its Report to the Nation on the Status of Cancer, it is followed by a familiar lament. We are losing the war against cancer.
Title: Why Everyone Seems to Have Cancer

Content: TOKYO â A man who developed leukemia after working on a cleanup crew at the ruined Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant has been awarded workersâ compensation by the Japanese government, in what amounts to the first official acknowledgment that exposure to radiation at the disaster site may have caused cancer.
Title: Japan to Pay Cancer Bills for Fukushima Worker

Content: TOWSON, Md. â Two days into a long-dreamed-of family vacation to Italy in August 2013, my wife, Ronna, became nauseated, unusually tired and short of breath. One of the great non-complainers in American history, she insisted that it was no big deal and valiantly tried to join in on various outings in the Italian countryside. But, after a few increasingly difficult days, even Ronna knew that it was time to go to the emergency room.
Title: Cancer-Drug Ads vs. Cancer-Drug Reality

Content: Raylene Hollrah was 33, with a young daughter, when she learned she had breast cancer. She made a difficult decision, one she hoped would save her life: She had her breasts removed, underwent grueling chemotherapy and then had reconstructive surgery.
Title: A Shocking Diagnosis: Breast Implants âGave Me Cancerâ

Content: In every cup of coffee, there is a chemical linked to cancer.
Title: Should Coffee Come With Cancer Warnings? California Says No

Content: BETHESDA, Md. â The young surgeon was mystified. A fist-size tumor had been removed from the stomach of his patient 12 years earlier, but his doctors had not been able to cut out many smaller growths in his liver. The cancer should have killed him, yet here he lay on the table for a routine gallbladder operation.
Title: Setting the Bodyâs âSerial Killersâ Loose on Cancer

Content: Married cancer patients live longer than single people who have the disease, suggesting that logistical and emotional support from a loved one may be far more critical to cancer care than previously recognized.
Title: Married Cancer Patients Live Longer

Content: This year more than 1.4 million women around the world will learn they have breast cancer. The disease is the biggest cancer killer of women in developed regions like North America and Europe as well as the developing world, like Africa, where many women are diagnosed at a late stage of the disease.
Title: Faces of Breast Cancer: A Global Community

Content: This weekâs Retro Report video examines the âwar on cancerâ â a federal research initiative authorized by President Richard M. Nixon in 1971. Many anticipated quick results, in part because of the public relations campaign, complete with ads suggesting we could cure cancer by the bicentennial, that successfully pushed Mr. Nixon into making the commitment.
Title: Hopeful Glimmers in Long War on Cancer

Content: In February, the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center asked the textile and carpet designer Madeline Weinrib to transform its charity thrift shop on the Upper East Side into an occasional pop-up boutique for designer sample sales. âWith all the consignment shops around, and people selling their furniture on eBay, it has taken a lot of business away from the charity thrift shops,â said Ms. Weinrib, who is based in Manhattan. From May 3 to 5, she will fill the 2,500-square-foot space at 1440 Third Avenue with pillows, rugs, rolls of fabric to be sold by the yard, clothing, handbags, totes, napkins and furniture. Products will be sold at 40 to 70 percent off retail. Eighteen-inch-square pillows, shown above and below, originally $350 to $575, will be $179 to $299. Home delivery is not available, but even rugs and furniture pieces will be small enough to carry. The sale will take place from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (212) 535-1250.Â
Title: Brightening Up a Cancer Centerâs Thrift Shop

Content: Being in a cancer support group eventually means losing a friend. On the first day of November, Leslie informed the six of us that she would not attend our next meeting: âI am so tired and I think all the tricks and treats are done.â
Title: Living With Cancer: Parting Gifts

Content: WE believe that it might be possible to treat breast cancer â the leading cause of female cancer death â with a drug that can already be found in nearly every medicine cabinet in the world: Aspirin.
Title: A Cancer Treatment in Your Medicine Cabinet?

Content: The targeted cancer drug extending my life is killing my hair. Especially at the top of my head, a beige scalp gleams through sparse black and white wires. For obvious reasons, Iâm not complaining.
Title: Living With Cancer: Wigged Out

Content: A slant of light bifurcates the bedroom ceiling. Its source, a night light in the bathroom, slices through the ceiling fixture, slivering all the way to the far corner over my side of the bed. Before cancer, I slept through the night. Now, I wake in the dark because of the pull of stitches, the pain of drains or the need to empty some bulb or bag attached to my body.
Title: Living With Cancer: Waking in the Dark

Content: Low survival rates make pancreatic cancer a tough disease to face. Seven men and women speak about survival, loss and living with a diagnosis.
Title: Patient Voices: Pancreatic Cancer

Content: There were subscriptions to dating websites, meals at Hooters and purchases at Victoriaâs Secret â not to mention jet ski joy rides and couplesâ cruises to the Caribbean.
Title: 4 Cancer Charities Are Accused of Fraud

Content: SINCE the early 1970s, studies have shown that black Americans have a higher death rate from cancer than any other racial or ethnic group. This is especially true when it comes to breast cancer. A study published last week in the journal Cancer Epidemiology found that, in a survey of 41 of Americaâs largest cities, black women with breast cancer are on average 40 percent more likely to die than their white counterparts.
Title: Why Black Women Die of Cancer

Content: Colorectal cancer is typically considered a disease of aging â most new cases are diagnosed in people over age 50. But even as the rates decrease in older adults, scientists have documented a worrisome trend in the opposite direction among patients in their 20s and 30s.
Title: Colorectal Cancer Rises Among Younger Adults

Content: Can we agree to stop calling it the cancer moonshot?
Title: âMoonshotâ Metaphor on Cancer Is a Failure to Communicate

Content: To Dr. Susan Domchek, an oncologist at the University of Pennsylvania, the phone call from Jon and Mindy Gray last summer was no different from many others she has received from people seeking information about genetic mutations that can cause cancer. She spoke with the couple for an hour or so, and afterward gave it little thought.
Title: Research Center to Focus on Cancer Genes

Content: I often find my most interesting stories in unusual places. Last year I went to Duluth, Minn., from my home in Britain to film Chris Plys, an Olympic curler. On my last evening, Chris began telling a story about his young friend Mike Marz, an amateur storm chaser in Minneapolis. Another local man had just reached out to Mike to see a tornado after heâd found out he had lung cancer. The man, Mark Zabawa, was a divorced, 60-year-old former serviceman and a recovering alcoholic. When I came back to Britain, I was determined to follow up and tracked Mike down on Facebook to discuss making a film about his experience of chasing storms with his new friend as he fought cancer.
Title: Fighting Cancer by Chasing Tornadoes

Content: Dr. Nikhil Wagle thought he had a brilliant idea to advance research and patient care.
Title: New Cancer Treatments Lie Hidden Under Mountains of Paperwork

Content:
An experimental immunotherapy could help T-cells, a type of white
blood cell, recognize and destroy cancer cells.
Title: Helping T-Cells Fight Cancer

Content: As commissioner of the Mayorâs Office of Immigrant Affairs, Nisha Agarwal would often lobby legislators on behalf of vulnerable New Yorkers. On Monday she was lobbying again â but for herself.
Title: âItâs My Lifeâ: Brain Cancer Motivates City Commissionerâs Activism

Content: About two-thirds of smokers will die early from cigarette-based illnesses. Cigarettes are also very addictive. Because of this, it seems reasonable to place warnings on their labels.
Title: California, Coffee and Cancer: One of These Doesnât Belong

Content: Before the visit, I had been split in two not by fear of death but by dread of dying â in anxiety, dementia, but mostly in pain from recurrent ovarian cancer.
Title: Living With Cancer: A Tour of Hospice

Content: PHILADELPHIA â McBaine, a bouncy black and white springer spaniel, perks up and begins his hunt at the Penn Vet Working Dog Center. His nose skims 12 tiny arms that protrude from the edges of a table-size wheel, each holding samples of blood plasma, only one of which is spiked with a drop of cancerous tissue.
Title: Training Dogs to Sniff Out Cancer

Content: âI want you to talk to me like Iâm one of your patients, not like Iâm your mother.â
Title: When the Doctorâs Mother Has Cancer

Content: In California, young patients can lose themselves in a digital dreamworld during their grueling treatments.
Title: Infusing Fun Into Cancer Treatment

Content: When Dr. Nicholas Gonzalez died in July, there was not much notice. He did not get an obituary in The New York Times or in most other major media outlets.
Title: Straddling Conventional and Alternative Cancer Treatment

Content: In findings that are fundamentally reshaping the scientific understanding of breast cancer, researchers have identified four genetically distinct types of the cancer. And within those types, they found hallmark genetic changes that are driving many cancers.
Title: Study Divides Breast Cancer Into Four Distinct Types

Content: Pancreatic cancer has a bad reputation. It is a terrible disease, but most people do not realize there are ways that early detection can help.
Title: Early Detection Is Possible for Pancreatic Cancer

Content: The difference in mortality rates between black women and white women with breast cancer has widened since 1975, in part because black women have not benefited as much from improvements in screening and treatment. Among the states with available data, Tennessee has the largest gap. Massachusetts, where the rates have converged, has the smallest.
Title: A Stark Gap in Breast Cancer Deaths

Content: Barbara Brenner, who led the group Breast Cancer Action and shaped it in her own combative image, pillorying the medical establishment, industrial polluters and even other cancer research advocates, died on May 10 at her home in San Francisco. She was 61.
Title: Barbara Brenner, Breast Cancer Iconoclast, Dies at 61

Content: African-Americans who live in highly segregated counties are considerably more likely to die from lung cancer than those in counties that are less segregated, a new study has found.
Title: Segregation Linked in Study With Lung Cancer Deaths

Content: More than 200 researchers investigating colon cancer tumors have found genetic vulnerabilities that could lead to powerful new treatments. The hope is that drugs designed to strike these weak spots will eventually stop a cancer that is now almost inevitably fatal once it has spread.
Title: Genetic Aberrations Seen as Path to Stop Colon Cancer

Content: James P. Allison is the chairman of the immunology department at the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. His seminal research opened up a new field in cancer treatment: immunotherapy. Instead of poisoning a tumor or destroying it with radiation, Dr. Allison has pioneered ways to unleash the immune system to destroy a cancer.
Title: Arming the Immune System Against Cancer

Content: A new study shows that prostate cancer surgery, which often leaves men impotent or incontinent, does not appear to save the lives of men with early-stage disease, who account for most cases, and many of these men would do just as well to choose no treatment at all.
Title: Questioning Surgery for Early Prostate Cancer

Content: New drugs for breast cancer and multiple myeloma won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Friday, expanding options for patients in advanced stages of those diseases.
Title: F.D.A. Approves Drugs for Cancer and Myeloma

Content: Cancer rates among rescue and recovery workers were not statistically higher than those in the general populaiton.
Title: Cancer Among 9/11 Workers

Content: People who buy organic food are usually convinced itâs better for their health, and theyâre willing to pay dearly for it. But until now, evidence of the benefits of eating organic has been lacking.
Title: Can Eating Organic Food Lower Your Cancer Risk?

Content: The headline had some of my friends in a panic.
Title: A Link Between Alcohol and Cancer? Itâs Not Nearly as Scary as It Seems

Content: âCancer is not something that makes you want to share. Itâs something that makes you want to hide,â Suleika Jaouad says in the latest installment of the âLife, Interruptedâ video series. In âGoing Public With Cancer,â Ms. Jaouad offers a glimpse of her new life as an advocate for young adults with cancer as well as the friendships she has made as a result of going public with her illness.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Going Public With Cancer

Content: Mutations in a gene called PALB2 raise the risk of breast cancer in women by almost as much as mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2, the infamous genes implicated in most inherited cases of the disease, a team of researchers reported Wednesday.
Title: Study Shows Third Gene as Indicator for Breast Cancer

Content: Although I sob during sappy movies, I did not cry as I staggered through the numerous surgeries, radiological procedures and chemotherapies that followed a cancer diagnosis four years ago. That is why I am grateful to yoga.
Title: Living With Cancer: Patient Yoga

Content: In a large prospective study, researchers have found an association between aspirin use and a reduced risk of liver cancer.
Title: Aspirin Tied to Reduced Risk of Liver Cancer

Content: When I get tired of being told to juice carrots, I remember that the essayist Anatole Broyard took tap-dancing lessons as he underwent treatment for prostate cancer. Sick people need all sorts of strategies, alongside medical ones, to deal with disease.
Title: Living With Cancer: The Lure of Alternative Remedies

Content: My Sunday column looks at what I call âthe cancer lobbyâ â a term that will have said lobby writing in indignation about now. But Iâm pretty indignant, too.
Title: Information About Cancer? Suppress It!

Content: President Bush's decision to cut the budget for a cancer detection program makes no sense. In human terms, it is cruel. From a budget standpoint, it is self-defeating.
Title: NYT: Illogical Cutbacks on Cancer

Content: It is probably safe to say that in the history of bill signings by governors in the State of New York, few, if any, featured the entrance that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made on Monday.
Title: Cuomo and Billy Joel Ride for Breast Cancer Awareness

Content: A rural resident in China is 30 percent more likely to die after a cancer diagnosis than an urban resident. Three rural families trying to beat these odds â âcancer refugeesâ â share their stories of battling the disease far from home and the financial ruin it causes.
Title: How China Creates Cancer Refugees

Content: A major European study has shown that blood test screening for prostate cancer saves lives, but doubts remain about whether the benefit is large enough to offset the harms caused by unnecessary biopsies and treatments that can render men incontinent and impotent.
Title: Prostate Cancer Screening Still Not Recommended for All

Content: When Eddie Carrillo, a Los Angeles contractor, was found to have prostate cancer at the age of 52, his primary care doctor and his urologist both urged him to have his prostate removed. But after hearing about a âwatchful waitingâ program on talk radio, Mr. Carrillo decided to simply monitor his disease rather than treat it.
Title: Choosing âWatchful Waitingâ for Prostate Cancer

Content: If you live with breast cancer, love someone with breast cancer or worry about your risk for breast cancer, you are part of a global community of women and men whose lives have been touched by the disease.
Title: Share Your Breast Cancer Stories

Content: âCancer books suck,â says 16-year-old Hazel Grace Lancaster. But she has a favorite and so do I. Mine is the novel John Green wrote about her.
Title: Living With Cancer: âThe Fault in Our Starsâ

Content: The disc jockey Carol Miller talks to Jo Maeder about staying relevant in the music business.
Title: Carol Miller on Work and Cancer

Content: Microsoft scientists have demonstrated that by analyzing large samples of search engine queries they may in some cases be able to identify internet users who are suffering from pancreatic cancer, even before they have received a diagnosis of the disease.
Title: Microsoft Finds Cancer Clues in Search Queries

Content: Taking low-dose aspirin is a daily routine for many people because it may lower the risk for heart attacks and strokes, and some research has tied it to a lower risk of colorectal cancer. Now a new study in JAMA Oncology suggests it may lower the risk for ovarian cancer as well.
Title: Daily Baby Aspirin May Lower Ovarian Cancer Risk

Content: Not long before Mihir Shah was to be married in 2007, his soon-to-be mother-in-law got a diagnosis of breast cancer. She underwent chemotherapy and survived, wearing a wig to the wedding.
Title: A New Way to Detect Breast Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON â Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will announce on Friday a corporate executive to lead his âmoonshotâ cancer initiative, selecting an expert who began work in 2003 to lower barriers between science and cures.
Title: Biden Names Leader for âMoonshotâ Cancer Campaign

Content: Suleika Jaoaudâs style evolution.
Title: Finding My Cancer Style

Content: At times when I consider my losses, I feel like a loser in the battle against self-pity. Like many diseases, cancer has everything to do with loss: of a breast or a leg, of a chunk of liver or lung, of continence, of mental capacity, of life itself.
Title: Living With Cancer: Practicing Loss

Content: A new study adds to evidence that obese men may have an increased risk for future prostate cancer.
Title: Obesity Tied to Prostate Cancer Risk

Content: This past winter, my friend Jan embarked on two unrelated quests. While tracing her ancestry, she was attempting to find out whether she had cancer. A visual artist, not a word person, Jan enlisted me as her scribe in the hope that her story might be useful. Iâm glad she did. Her efforts at detection suggest that although many of us remain quite limited in what we know about our bodies and ourselves, we can nevertheless steer our way toward even the most startling discoveries.
Title: Tracking Cancer and Ancestry, With Mysteries in Each

Content: The older a woman is when she gives birth, the lower her risk for endometrial cancer, a new study reports.
Title: Later Pregnancy, Lower Risk of a Cancer

Content: There is a dreadful routine to chemotherapy. My life has been synched to a chemotherapy calendar ever since my leukemia diagnosis last year. I have become an expert at predicting when side effects and symptoms will set in. Itâs a ghoulish monthly party, and the guests always arrive on time: nausea, vomiting, chills, exhaustion, fever, mouth sores, pain, infections and emergency hospitalizations.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Fighting Cancer, and Myself

Content: I HAVE a very rare and aggressive type of skin cancer â Merkel cell carcinoma â for which there is no approved cure, and Iâm participating in a clinical trial to deal with it. If successful, the trial will show that the drug Iâm being given at least manages what is now an often fatal disease.
Title: Clinical Trials Need Cancer Patients

Content: Recounting her fatherâs struggle with cancer was difficult for the young woman, even several years after his death. Heâd endured first surgery and then chemotherapy and radiation, she told me, and the cancer had gone into remission. He was thrilled, but the aggressive treatment left him with chronic, debilitating pain. Once active, he struggled to get around in his own home.
Title: Poor Pain Control for Cancer Patients

Content: My wig (I named her Sally) was looking worse for wear. I decided to use a trip to visit my grandchildren in Manhattan as an opportunity to get another so-called âcranial prosthesis.â That way I could give Sally a much needed shampoo.
Title: Living With Cancer: Hiding Under a Wig?

Content: With prostate cancer, as with other diseases, there has been a vigorous debate about who should be tested. Screening too many people leads to unnecessary treatment, too few and you miss cancers that could have been stopped. A new study points to what may be a better approach: âscreen smarter.â
Title: A Better Way to Screen for Prostate Cancer

Content: Women considering surgery to receive breast implants should be warned of the risk of serious complications, including fatigue, joint pain and the possibility of a rare type of cancer, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday.
Title: Women Should Be Warned of Breast Implant Hazards, F.D.A. Says

Content: Dr. Peter Scardino of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center says current prostate cancer screening is painful and imprecise but vastly improving.
Title: Cancer Diagnosis: Less Can Be More

Content: Former President Jimmy Carter, who has been undergoing treatment for cancer that was removed from his liver but had spread to his brain, said on Sunday that he was free of the disease.
Title: Former President Jimmy Carter Says He Is Free of Cancer

Content: Sunlight and the sound of traffic from Fort Hamilton Parkway streamed through the windows of Beata Bienâs second-floor studio apartment on a recent morning in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. The rays illuminated the tears in her green eyes and the pink Hello Kitty decorations adorning the small room.
Title: Facing Cancer and Financial Burdens, an Immigrant Finds Aid

Content: Like the other women in my cancer support group, I have been trying to salvage aspects of the person I had been before the diagnosis.
Title: Living With Cancer: Bedtime Issues

Content: From the shock of the cancer diagnosis onward, depression can take its well-documented toll on patients. Even patients who appear to pack away their fears during the grinding treatment journey to becoming cancer-free concede that when the regimen ends, they unspool emotionally.
Title: Anxiety Lingers Long After Cancer

Content: Scientists have long known that increasing age is the strongest risk for a diagnosis of late-stage cervical cancer. Now a new study suggests that the next strongest risk is the patientâs insurance status.
Title: Insurance Sways Risk of Cancer Diagnosis

Content: We commonly assume that cancer afflicts the aging or aged, but approximately 16 percent of breast cancer deaths involve women under the age of 50. How can or should an alarming death sentence be confronted in midlife? The personal challenges posed by incurable disease unfold in an absorbing documentary about movie-making, âA Woman Like Me,â which opened in New York in October and became available on Netflix this January.
Title: Living With Cancer: A Woman Like Me

Content: Nancy G. Brinker, the founder of Susan G. Komen for the Cure, will leave her post as chief executive, and its president will resign, the group announced on Wednesday in the most significant leadership shake-up to follow its short-lived attempt to cut financing for breast cancer services provided by Planned Parenthood.
Title: Breast Cancer Group Changes Leaders

Content: On an assignment in Uganda reporting on early breast cancer detection, Lynsey Addario photographed a cancer ward that serves four countries â as the region is scarce of expertise and supplies.
Title: Breast Cancer as Death Sentence in Uganda

Content: A week or so after a procedure, I found a sticker on my body. Not a Disney sticker or a Dora the Explorer sticker, put there maybe by a godchild or nephew, but a 1 1/4-by-1-inch white rectangle with a steel nipple at the center.
Title: Living With Cancer: Seeking Intimacy

Content: After years of treatment and two relapses of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Dr. Lukas Wartman had exhausted all conventional approaches to his disease. A group at Washington University in St. Louis spent a month decoding his genetic information, a process called whole genome sequencing, in hopes of determining the genetic cause of his leukemia. The team found an overactive gene that was treatable with a drug for advanced kidney cancer. Here is how the process works.
Title: Searching for a Cancerâs Vulnerable Target

Content: Every Sunday evening, I phone a friend in another college town who has not yet found a cancer support group in her community. Letâs call her Melanie. Melanie had recovered from surgery and completed chemotherapy. Physically, she had gained strength. Yet she continued to feel overwhelmed by negative thoughts.
Title: Living With Cancer: Finding Calm in the Storm

Content: CHICAGO â A commonly used drug can help young women with breast cancer retain the ability to have babies, apparently protecting their ovaries from the damage caused by chemotherapy, researchers reported here on Friday.
Title: Drug Saves Fertility for Women With Cancer

Content: Despite good news about my cancer treatment, it has been a hard winter, so I am looking forward to Passover. By retelling the story of the Jewish peopleâs escape from slavery in Egypt, the Haggadah â the text recited at the annual Seder â celebrates deliverance and springtime renewal. How would its rituals and prayers resonate for me this year, when cancer concerns were unexpectedly supplanted by other tribulations?
Title: A Bittersweet Passover: Cancer, Remission and Change

Content: Updated findings from one of the largest studies of prostate cancer screening show that the commonly used P.S.A. blood test did not save lives, although questions remain about whether younger men or those at very high risk for the disease might benefit.
Title: Prostate Cancer Screening Shows No Benefit

Content: ATLANTA â Former President Jimmy Carter announced on Wednesday that he had been given a diagnosis of a spreading cancer that was detected by recent liver surgery.
Title: Former President Jimmy Carter Says He Has Cancer

Content: Alarmed by the rapid escalation in the price of cancer drugs, the nationâs leading oncology society unveiled on Monday a new way for doctors and patients to evaluate different treatments â one that pointedly includes a medicineâs cost as well as its effectiveness and side effects.
Title: Cancer Doctors Offer Way to Compare Medicines, Including by Cost

Content: After being nursed and handed over, the babyâs wails rise to a tremolo, but I am determined to give my exhausted daughter and son-in-law a respite on this wintry evening. Commiserating with the little guyâs discomfort â gas, indigestion, colic, ontological insecurity â I swaddle, burp, bink, then cradle him in my arms. I begin walking around the house, swinging and swaying while cooing in soothing cadences: âYes, darling boy, another one bites the dust, another one bites the dust.â
Title: Living With Cancer: Arrivals and Departures

Content: A food safety journal has decided to retract a paper that seemed to show that genetically modified corn and the herbicide Roundup can cause cancer and premature death in rats.
Title: Paper Tying Rat Cancer to Herbicide Is Retracted

Content: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter described main objectives of the United Statesâ military campaign in Iraq and Syria against the Islamic State.
Title: Carter Compares ISIS to a Cancer

Content: In April 2010, we asked Well readers to share their stories of cancer survival. Over the following weeks and months, more than 1,150 people submitted their photos and stories, creating an inspiring collage of the life that is possible after cancer.
Title: A Picture Collage of Life After Cancer

Content: As a cancer patient whose life has been miraculously extended by a clinical trial, I was shocked by Charles Pillerâs Dec. 13 essay âLaw Ignored, Patients at Riskâ in STAT News on lapses in reporting the results of such trials. My first response was to ask: Is he a reputable journalist? Is the online venue in which the article appears legit? When the answer to each of these questions came back a resounding yes, I began worrying that cancer doctors and patients have been imperiled by irresponsible researchers.
Title: Living With Cancer: A Broken Covenant With Patients

Content: A new study testing B vitamins and omega-3 fatty acids for cancer prevention has found no beneficial effect and â at least for women â some possibility of harm.
Title: Regimens: No Cancer Benefits Seen in Supplements

Content: A hostile letter from a reader made me stop and think about the torments of waiting that cancer patients endure: waiting for a doctor, waiting for radiation, waiting for the delivery of chemotherapy drugs, waiting through interminable infusions or transfusions, waiting for a scan or a biopsy, waiting for the results of a scan or a biopsy, waiting (sometimes starved and unclothed on a gurney in a hall) for surgery.
Title: Living With Cancer: Hurry Up and Wait

Content: Before there was Betty Ford, the outspoken first lady who brought breast cancer awareness to the wider public, there was Babette Rosmond, a diminutive New York City writer and editor who went public with her diagnosis of breast cancer 40 years ago, three and a half years before the first lady. If Mrs. Ford is remembered for her grace and honesty, we should remember Ms. Rosmond for her courage and persistence. What Ms. Rosmond demanded of her doctors â the right to choose her cancer treatment â is now the minimum that cancer patients deserve.
Title: The Right to Choose Your Cancer Treatment

Content: âIâm scheduling your orchiectomy in two days,â my oncologist told me, only minutes after handing me a diagnosis of testicular cancer. With that, he added a new word to my vocabulary: âOrÂ·chiÂ·ecÂ·toÂ·my: Excision of one or both testicles. Castration.â
Title: Young, Gay and Blaming Myself for Cancer

Content: Many people associate palliative care with hospice care, but medical professionals are offering it to children and adolescents living with cancer as well as to those dying from it.
Title: For Kids With Cancer, Focusing on Quality of Life

Content: Lynsey Addario, a contract photographer for The New York Times, went to Uganda in July on assignment with Denise Grady, who was pursuing a story about early cancer detection and treatment in Uganda. An interactive feature, where you can share your own stories about surviving breast cancer or stories about someone you know who has or had breast cancer, is viewable here, and Ms. Gradyâs story appears in Wednesdayâs paper. Ms. Addario, reached via phone from London, where she lives, spoke with James Estrin. Their conversation has been edited.
Title: Breast Cancer as Death Sentence in Uganda

Content: On a hot July day last summer, I was lying on the beach at Coney Island with my younger brother when he noticed a dark mole on the back of my arm. âYou should really get that checked at the dermatologist,â he said in a worried tone.
Title: Skin Cancer on the Rise in Young Women

Content: In January, 2011, I wrote a piece, âBehind Toxic Headlines,â examining a burst of overwrought news coverage of a study finding traces of synthetic chemicals in blood and tissue samples from pregnant women.
Title: Meat, Cancer, Fear and Carcinogenic Headlines

Content: Children who undergo chemotherapy treatments for cancer have an increased risk of developing early heart disease, a new study suggests.
Title: Childhood Cancer Tied to Heart Risks

Content: The vigilant man who has taken care of me for five years of cancer treatment slipped on a step three days ago. It was like seeing an eagle shot down. He had to have the tendon in his left knee repaired. Hunched on a chair in our kitchen, he glares at me like a wild thing trapped.
Title: Living With Cancer: Becoming a Caregiver

Content: ATLANTIC CITY â Successful trials of a blood test to detect cancer were reported here yesterday [April 14] by a U.S. Public Health Service doctor. The test, which depends on labeling red blood cells with a radioactive isotope, was given to 79 subjects. It should cost less than $10 to administer, according to Dr. John M. Vogel, of San Francisco, who has been testing it. Dr. Vogel reported the results of the cancer test before a session of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology. â New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 16, 1965.
Title: 1965: Blood Test for Cancer Is Cited

Content: Enthusiasm for cancer immunotherapy is soaring, and so is Arie Belldegrunâs fortune.
Title: Harnessing the U.S. Taxpayer to Fight Cancer and Make Profits

Content: More than 7 percent of cancer cases in the United States are attributable to excess body weight, a new study reports.
Title: Excess Weight Contributes to More Than 7 Percent of Cancers

Content: The Environmental Protection Agencyâs revised rule on arsenic contamination in drinking water has resulted in fewer lung, bladder and skin cancers.
Title: Arsenic Reductions in Drinking Water Tied to Fewer Cancer Deaths

Content: I first met my patient, a man in his late 80s, in 2012, when he had been living with myelodysplastic syndromes, a form of bone marrow cancer, for five years â longer than the average survival for those diagnosed with the condition. He was a former high school math teacher who was unerringly precise about his laboratory values. He also had a spark to him that no cancer could extinguish.
Title: A âSentimental Journeyâ in the Cancer Clinic

Content: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. declared he wanted to âend cancer as we know it.â
Title: Biden Calls for a Cancer âMoon Shotâ

Content: Fifty-five years ago, when I was 15, my mother made me promise that I would not commit suicide. I intend to keep that promise if and when I ask a doctor for passive assistance â ending life-sustaining support â or for active help: palliative sedation or a lethal prescription. To my mind, treating cancer pain aggressively even when it accelerates the dying process should not be equated with suicide.
Title: Living With Cancer: Deciding About Dying

Content: A new version of a screening test for ovarian cancer may reduce deaths from the disease, but it needs more study to determine whether the benefits hold up, researchers reported on Thursday.
Title: Early Detection of Ovarian Cancer May Become Possible

Content: Recent research has been interpreted as suggesting that cellphones cause cancer. But Gina Kolata explains that the overwhelming evidence suggests that there is no link between the devices and the disease.
Title: Will Your Cellphone Give You Cancer?

Content: It is among the most delicate and difficult dilemmas in medicine: Should a pregnant woman who has received a cancer diagnosis begin treatment before her child is born? Some hesitant doctors counsel women to deliver preterm or even terminate the pregnancy first.
Title: Study Offers Support for Cancer Treatment During Pregnancy

Content: Seemingly overnight, treatment of men with early-stage prostate cancer has undergone a sea change. Five years ago, nearly all opted for surgery or radiation; now, nearly half are choosing no treatment at all.
Title: More Men With Early Prostate Cancer Are Choosing to Avoid Treatment

Content: Eating substantial amounts of fruits and vegetables may lower the risk for breast cancer, a new study has found, and some kinds may be more effective than others.
Title: Cauliflower, Kale and Carrots May Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Two women in my cancer support group died last year; both were considerably younger than I am. Furious at the disease, Iâm starting the new year with a yowl.
Title: A Cancer Rap, With Thanks to Nina Simone

Content: Two years ago, I spent a week in Houston helping my stepbrother while he underwent treatment for Stage 4 lymphoma at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. I sat with him while a nurse cleaned his chemo port and made records of her work, to keep his medical team updated. I accompanied him for the blood tests that determined his readiness for the next treatment. I stayed by his bed as his stem cells were harvested for a transplant, one of the cutting-edge, evidence-based therapies that ultimately saved his life.
Title: Treat Addiction Like Cancer

Content: One of the most respected and influential groups in the continuing breast-cancer screening debate said on Tuesday that women should begin mammograms later and have them less frequently than it had long advocated.
Title: American Cancer Society, in a Shift, Recommends Fewer Mammograms

Content: âHow are you doing?â is a complicated question for a cancer patient.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Keeping Cancer at Bay

Content: Genentech won federal approval Friday for a new drug to treat advanced breast cancer. But the company said it was experiencing manufacturing problems that could lead to a shortage of the drug.
Title: Genentech Wins Approval for New Breast Cancer Drug

Content: When Kyle Potvin learned she had breast cancer at the age of 41, she tracked the details of her illness and treatment in a journal. But when it came to grappling with issues of mortality, fear and hope, she found that her best outlet was poetry.
Title: Finding Poetry in Cancer

Content: The first question many cancer patients are asked at a doctorâs office or an infusion center is âDo you have a port?â I shake my head no, but add the words ânot yet.â To port or not to port: That is the question facing me when I arrive on the hospital hall dedicated to clinical trials.
Title: Needles or Port? A Cancer Patient Decides

Content: About five years ago, Patricia Workmanâs bones started breaking, and she was found to have multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow. At the same time, her skin cancer started to proliferate, leaving her face so scarred that she needed reconstructive surgery and still hides it with dark glasses.
Title: Logistics Hang Over a Ruling on 9/11 Cancer

Content: People with incurable cancer do sometimes receive good news, as I have. Why is it harder for me to share good news than bad news? During treatment, good news produces elating highs, but also anxious lows.
Title: Living With Cancer: Good News Soup

Content: A new drug that unleashes the bodyâs immune system to attack tumors can prolong the lives of people with the most common form of lung cancer, doctors reported on Friday, the latest example of the significant results being achieved by this new class of medicines.
Title: New Class of Drugs Shows More Promise in Treating Cancer

Content: Cancer experts said Tuesday that the actress and filmmaker Angelina Jolie Pitt was wise to have had her ovaries and fallopian tubes removed last week because she carries a genetic mutation, BRCA1, that significantly increases the risk of ovarian cancer, a disease so difficult to detect that it is often found only at an advanced, untreatable stage.
Title: Experts BackÂ Angelina Jolie Pitt in Choices for Cancer Prevention

Content: Prickly, frozen, cramped, numb: my feet ache as if they were tightly bound in plastic wrap or affixed on cardboard, or I donât feel them at all. Several years ago I was infused with a standard form of chemotherapy that causes what oncologists call peripheral neuropathies. Side effects have turned into permanent after-effects.
Title: Living With Cancer: Chemo-Feet

Content: A medical device that can add years to the lives of cancer patients is about to become unavailable, because its manufacturer has decided to stop producing it.
Title: A Lifesaving Pump for Cancer Patients Is Being Phased Out

Content: MORE than one million people in the Chinese city of Handan awoke last week to the alarming news that an essential source of their drinking water, the Zhouzhang River, had been dangerously contaminated by a 39-ton chemical spill in the nearby city of Changzhi. What made the news even more shocking was that the leak, from a factory pipe, had started at least five days earlier but had been kept secret by government officials, who allowed millions of their neighbors to keep drinking.
Title: A Cancer Cycle, From Here to China

Content: With the cost of some lifesaving cancer drugs exceeding $100,000 a year, more than 100 influential cancer specialists from around the world have taken the unusual step of banding together in hopes of persuading some leading pharmaceutical companies to bring prices down.
Title: Doctors Denounce Cancer Drug Prices of $100,000 a Year

Content: As surprised researchers have discovered, some people with autism have mutated cancer or tumor genes that apparently caused their brain disorder.
Title: Autism's Unexpected Link to Cancer Genes

Content: Chemotherapy failed to thwart Erika Hurwitzâs rare cancer of white blood cells. So her doctors offered her another option, a drug for melanoma. The result was astonishing.
Title: A Faster Way to Try Many Drugs on Many Cancers

Content: Fear of breast cancer is widespread, yet many women donât realize that adopting protective living habits may help keep it at bay. The habits described below may also help to ward off other life-threatening ills, like heart disease and diabetes.
Title: You Can Take Steps to Lower Your Breast Cancer Risk

Content: The incidence of mouth and throat cancers caused by the human papillomavirus in men has now surpassed the incidence of HPV-related cervical cancers in women, researchers report.
Title: 7 Million American Men Carry Cancer-Causing HPV

Content: The Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation awards â often called the âAmerican Nobelsâ in medical science â were announced Monday morning, and one of the winners used the spotlight to call for greatly widening the use of genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer.
Title: Lasker Winner Calls for More Genetic Testing for Cancer

Content: As Chuck Peal lay in a Waterbury, Conn., emergency room one Sunday in early September, doctors furiously tried to make sense of his symptoms. Mr. Peal, 61, appeared to be dying, and they were not sure why.
Title: Immune System, Unleashed by Cancer Therapies, Can Attack Organs

Content: Over the past few months, a number of headlines in The New York Times have stumped me.
Title: Living With Cancer: Brains on Chemo

Content: When the nationâs pre-eminent breast cancer advocacy group, the Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation, decided to stop most of its financing of Planned Parenthood in December, Komenâs leaders hoped to quietly distance the foundation from a politically controversial organization that they feared was costing them support and donations, a board member said.
Title: Cancer Group Backs Down on Cutting Off Planned Parenthood

Content: The first immune-based treatment for lung cancer won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, and it could displace more conventional chemotherapy for certain patients, at least.
Title: Lung Cancer Treatment Using Immune System Wins F.D.A. Approval

Content: MALIGNANT Medical Ethicists Confront Cancer.
Title: Assumptions and Attitudes Donât Survive Cancer

Content: For the first time ever, three pharmaceutical companies are poised to test whether new drugs can work against a wide range of cancers independently of where they originated â breast, prostate, liver, lung. The drugs go after an aberration involving a cancer gene fundamental to tumor growth. Many scientists see this as the beginning of a new genetic age in cancer research.
Title: Drugs Aim to Make Several Types of Cancer Self-Destruct

Content: When people choose to have their leukemia treated aggressively, itâs a big commitment, more so than for almost any other cancer.
Title: Seeking Calm on the Cancer Ward

Content: People have been searching for new medicines for thousands of years, and yet we have barely explored the universe of possibilities. Recently chemists at the University of Bern in Switzerland tried to estimate how many promising molecules have yet to be tested. In June they published their best guess: over a million billion billion billion billion billion billion. Blindly testing those molecules one at a time is not practical, and most of them will turn out to be useless anyway. So many scientists are looking for strategies they can use to zero in more quickly on promising candidates.
Title: Gene Tests in Yeast Aid Work on Cancer

Content: Through two seasons, âVice,â the newsmagazine assembled by Vice Media and carried by HBO, has been a travelogue for the gonzo armchair tourist. It circles the globe to report on every variety of crisis â wars, drugs, the environment, rape in India, desperate bachelors in China.
Title: Enlisting Viruses as Commandos in a War on Cancer

Content: Former President Jimmy Carter announced to his church in Plains, Ga., on Sunday that his latest brain scan showed no signs of cancer.
Title: Carter Says He Is Free of Cancer

Content: Although scientific studies have linked the consumption of meat to cancer, in London, at least, people are skeptical about the findings.
Title: Some Doubt Meatâs Ties to Cancer

Content: When I consider how this Hanukkah will be different from all other Hanukkahs, I wonder if my giddiness can be attributed to cancer and the treatments that have governed my life for the past five years.
Title: Living With Cancer: Giving Thanks and Latkes

Content: A new drug used to treat advanced prostate cancer may also help men if used early in the course of the disease, before an operation, researchers reported Wednesday.
Title: Trial Supports Earlier Use of a Prostate Cancer Drug

Content: Leap Year Day, 1986: I drove up to a ramshackle house in Berkeley to pick out my first dog. It was a month before my two-year cancer anniversary, at which point I would be considered âcured,â and I was ready to make a commitment â to life, longevity and a puppy.
Title: Committing to a Dog After Cancer

Content: BETHESDA, Md. â Mary Pazdur had exhausted the usual drugs for ovarian cancer, and with her tumors growing and her condition deteriorating, her last hope seemed to be an experimental compound that had yet to be approved by federal regulators.
Title: F.D.A. Regulator, Widowed by Cancer, Helps Speed Drug Approval

Content: Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter says he has cancer but won't make a more complete public statement until the "facts are known." Gavino Garay reports.
Title: Jimmy Carter suffering from cancer

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a new type of drug that combines the widely used breast cancer medicine Herceptin with a powerful toxin to more effectively kill cancer cells while potentially reducing side effects.
Title: F.D.A. Approves a New Drug for Advanced Breast Cancer

Content: Recalling that moment four years ago, when Gertrudis Torres learned she had Stage 3 breast cancer, still causes her breathing to become heavy and tears to well up. The unthinkable diagnosis was another blow to Ms. Torresâs family. Two years before, in 2010, her husband, Pedro Ayala, was told that he had throat cancer.
Title: Despite Cancer Diagnosis and Husbandâs Death, Keeping a Positive Outlook

Content: CHICAGO â An experimental drug from Merck that unleashes the bodyâs immune system significantly shrank tumors in 38 percent of patients with advanced melanoma, putting the company squarely in the race to bring to market one of what many experts view as the most promising class of drugs in years.
Title: Merck Has Solid Results in a Cancer Drug Trial

Content: Sydney, Australia â I OFTEN wondered what it would be like to have a cancer growing inside your body. To suddenly discover you are carrying something that is eating you away, growing in an ugly, consuming mass in or around your bones or organs. To be blithely stepping through life, unaware that your insides are betraying you.
Title: Was It Cancer? Getting the Diagnosis

Content: The nationâs leading breast cancer advocacy organization confronted the growing furor Thursday over its decision to largely end its decades-long partnership with Planned Parenthood, with rising dissension in its own ranks and a roiling anger on the Internet showing the power of social media to harness protest.
Title: Outcry Is Fierce to Cut in Funds by Cancer Group

Content: New research tries to break through cancerâs protective shield and women with breast cancer in Uganda face terrible challenges; the weather turns on North Americaâs forest giant.
Title: Two Windows Into Cancer, the Imperiled Moose

Content: New tests that supplement the prostate-specific antigen (P.S.A.) test.
Title: New Ways to Assess Prostate Cancer

Content: "We know that Beau's spirit will live on in all of us..." said Vice President Joe Biden in a statement released after his son, Beau Biden, died from cancer. Jillian Kitchener reports.
Title: Beau Biden dies of brain cancer

Content: Because ovarian cancer initiated a stealthy assault before I discovered it, it seems the clear aggressor, and I the injured party. Yet as my physicians use their weapons to counterattack, collateral damages mount. Fatigue envelops me.
Title: When Your Personal War on Cancer Is Exhausting

Content: Cancer is a disease of genes gone wrong. When certain genes mutate, they make cells behave in odd ways. The cells divide swiftly, they hide from the immune system that could kill them and they gain the nourishment they need to develop into tumors.
Title: A Catalog of Cancer Genes Thatâs Done, or Just a Start

Content: The American Society of Clinical Oncology, which represents many of the nationâs top cancer doctors, is calling attention to the ties between alcohol and cancer. In a statement published Tuesday in the Journal of Clinical Oncology, the group cites evidence that even light drinking can slightly raise a womanâs risk of breast cancer and increase a common type of esophageal cancer.
Title: Cancer Doctors Cite Risks of Drinking Alcohol

Content: On my way to a meeting on cancer and personalized medicine a few weeks ago, I found myself thinking, improbably, of the Saul Steinberg New Yorker cover illustration âView From Ninth Avenue.â Steinbergâs drawing (yes, youâve seen it â in undergraduate dorm rooms, in subway ads) depicts a mental map of the world viewed through the eyes of a typical New Yorker. Weâre somewhere on Ninth Avenue, looking out toward the water. Tenth Avenue looms large, thrumming with pedestrians and traffic. The Hudson is a band of gray-blue. But the rest of the world is gone â irrelevant, inconsequential, specks of sesame falling off a bagel. Kansas City, Chicago, Las Vegas and Los Angeles are blips on the horizon. Thereâs a strip of water denoting the Pacific Ocean, and faraway blobs of rising land: Japan, China, Russia. The whole thing is a wry joke on self-obsession and navel gazing: A New Yorkerâs world begins and ends in New York.
Title: The Search for Cancer Treatment Beyond Mutant-Hunting

Content: MELBOURNE, Australia â Cervical cancer could be eliminated in Australia within the next two decades because of a government program to vaccinate children against the cancer-causing human papillomavirus, according to a new report.
Title: In Australia, Cervical Cancer Could Soon Be Eliminated

Content: I had to take my husband back to the hospital for a second operation on a torn tendon, but the pills from the cancer trial had not yet arrived. Surely doing without one or two days of the drug would not necessarily lead to a recurrence, I told myself in an effort to still rising waves of anxiety. There were more pressing matters to attend, namely righting wrongful care.
Title: Living With Cancer: Patients on Our Own

Content: WASHINGTON â One day last winter, desperate as his son fought for his life against a killer brain cancer, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his family reached out to one of Americaâs most famous, and controversial, doctors for help.
Title: If Cancer Becomes Bidenâs Cause, a Bold but Polarizing Doctor Is On Call

Content: A decision by the nationâs leading breast cancer advocacy group to largely cut off financing for breast cancer screenings at Planned Parenthood set off howls of outrage last week.
Title: A Better Way to Spend Breast Cancer Funds?

Content: Current cancer therapies attempt to find, test and treat specific genetic mutations that are shared by groups of patients. A new method is based on the idea that many cancers differ from patient to patient, and may have different genetic causes.
Title: Conventional Cancer Therapy and Whole Genome Sequencing

Content: Unlike Ebola, flu or polio, cancer is a disease that arises from within â a consequence of the mutations that inevitably occur when one of our 50 trillion cells divides and copies its DNA.
Title: Random Chanceâs Role in Cancer

Content: "We know that Beau's spirit will live on in all of us..." said Vice President Joe Biden in a statement released after his son, Beau Biden, died from cancer. Jillian Kitchener reports.
Title: Beau Biden dies of brain cancer

Content: Fifty cancers will be officially added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to treat and compensate people exposed to the dust, smoke and fumes of the collapsing World Trade Center, the federal administrator of the World Trade Center Health Program said Monday.
Title: 9/11 Fund to Cover 50 Cancers

Content: This is a story about cancer, and baseball, and how they intersected over a week in the life of the Mets.
Title: A Shared History of Cancer, a Love of Baseball and a Cubs-Mets Game

Content: The idea that infectious cancer cells are drifting in the ocean, spreading a devastating leukemia-like disease may sound like a dystopian fantasy. But scientists say that is exactly what is happening â in clams.
Title: A Clam Cancer Outbreak, Spread by One Set of Cells

Content: Removal of the ovaries â a procedure known as oophorectomy â may increase the risk for colorectal cancer, a new study concludes.
Title: Ovary Removal Tied to Colon Cancer Risk

Content: More cases of an unusual cancer linked to breast implants have been reported to the Food and Drug Administration, the agency said on Wednesday.
Title: More Cases Are Reported of Unusual Cancer Linked to Breast Implants

Content: A medical researcher from Columbia University, Dr. Perry Hudson, made the skid row alcoholics in Lower Manhattan an offer: If they agreed to surgical biopsies of their prostates, they would get a clean bed and three square meals for a few days, plus free medical care and treatment if they had prostate cancer.
Title: Decades Later, Condemnation for a Skid Row Cancer Study
