Content: When Kelley Oliver Douglass got breast cancer, a genetic counselor posed an odd question: Do you and your children have trouble finding hats that fit?
Title: A Rare Genetic Mutation Leads to Cancer. The Fix May Already Be in the Drugstore.

Content: Q. What is D.C.I.S.?
Title: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Answers to Questions About New Findings

Content: A new study suggests that men with prostate cancer who take statins may have a lower risk of dying from the disease than those who do not.
Title: Statins Tied to Better Prostate Cancer Outcomes

Content: Stuffed inside cookie tins and between the pages of books in Diane Fieldsâs kitchen are multitudes of recipes. Ms. Fields has clipped them from newspapers and kept them for years, intent on preparing and sampling them all.
Title: Cancer Patient Awaits Day She Can Return to the Kitchen

Content: Q. My father died of pancreatic cancer, and my understanding is that one of the reasons it is so deadly is that it is usually found when it is fairly advanced. Is there a routine screening for this cancer?
Title: Can You Screen for Early Pancreatic Cancer?

Content: WASHINGTON â Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is cancer free and on the mend after her recent surgery for the disease, a Supreme Court spokeswoman said on Friday.
Title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Is Cancer Free After Surgery, Supreme Court Says

Content: Alex Trebek, the longtime host of the classic trivia television show âJeopardy!â, announced in a video on Wednesday that he has Stage IV pancreatic cancer.
Title: Alex Trebek, âJeopardy!â Host, Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: McGill University in Montreal announced last week a new $58 million collaboration between the Rossy Cancer Network and its teaching hospitals: the McGill University Health Center, Jewish General and St. Maryâs.
Title: McGillâs Hospitals Join Forces With Cancer Network

Content: Scientists have discovered that the most dangerous cancer of the uterine lining closely resembles the worst ovarian and breast cancers, providing the most telling evidence yet that cancer will increasingly be seen as a disease defined primarily by its genetic fingerprint rather than just by the organ where it originated.
Title: Cancers Share Gene Patterns, Studies Affirm

Content: When people hear the words âYou have cancer,â life is suddenly divided into distinct parts. There was their life before cancer, and then there is life after cancer.
Title: New Meaning and Drive in Life After Cancer

Content: The death rate from ovarian cancer declined in the United States by 16 percent from 2002 to 2012, among the largest reductions in the world.
Title: Some Good News on Ovarian Cancer

Content: For a number of Times readers, receiving a cancer diagnosis was just the beginning of a long sojourn through the world of new cancer treatments. Some readers found great success with advanced therapies, while others struggled to see whether the treatments offered better results than conventional ones.
Title: How New Cancer Treatments Are Shaping Lives

Content: In the spring of 2008, I had symptoms of what I thought was a heart condition. It made sense because I had a family history of heart disease. After several sleepless nights, I went to the doctor.
Title: When a Business Owner Gets Cancer

Content: The first large and comprehensive study of the genetics of a common lung cancer has found that more than half the tumors from that cancer have mutations that might be treated by new drugs that are already in the pipeline or that could be easily developed.
Title: Cancer Study Points to Tighter Pairing of Drugs and Patients

Content: As a 28-year-old who had just learned she had breast cancer in 2001, Rochelle Shoretz founded a support group for cancer patients while sitting in her oncologistâs office awaiting chemotherapy. She called it Sharsheret, Hebrew for chain. In 2009, the cancer returned.
Title: Rochelle Shoretz, Founder of Cancer Support Group, Dies at 42

Content: Every few weeks I host a âgirlsâ nightâ at my apartment in Lower Manhattan with a group of friends who are at various stages in their cancer treatments. Everyone brings something to eat and drink, and we sit around my living room talking to one another about subjects both heavy and light, ranging from post-chemo hair styling tips, fears of relapse or funny anecdotes about a recent hospital visit. But one topic that doesnât come up as often as you might think â particularly at a gathering of women in their early 20s and 30s â is sex.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Crazy, Unsexy Cancer Tips

Content: A new study suggests that what you eat may affect your chances of surviving colon cancer.
Title: Can Foods Affect Colon Cancer Survival?

Content: WASHINGTON â Harry Reid, the former Senate Democratic leader from Nevada, underwent surgery on Monday to remove a cancerous tumor from his pancreas.
Title: Harry Reid Has Surgery for Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Two new studies have found that people with sleep apnea, a common disorder that causes snoring, fatigue and dangerous pauses in breathing at night, have a higher risk of cancer. The new research marks the first time that sleep apnea has been linked to cancer in humans.
Title: Sleep Apnea Tied to Increased Cancer Risk

Content: My grandfather was a statistician, and from a young age he taught me to always consider the odds. A pragmatic man, he couldnât help teaching me when to hedge my bets, especially when it came to playing Uno. Unfortunately, he never could have prepared me for the odds I would face in the years to come.
Title: After a Cancer Diagnosis, Playing the Odds

Content: Lloyd Blankfein shares his experience dealing with treatment after his diagnosis of lymphoma. "It was all pretty manageable," the Goldman chairman said of his hours of chemotherapy.
Title: Goldman Sachs Chief on Cancer Treatment

Content: SAN FRANCISCO â In Silicon Valley, being a unicorn is no guarantee of financial success. But an eight-year-old drug maker focused on novel cancer treatments has landed itself and its investors a windfall by selling itself to a bigger competitor.
Title: AbbVie to Buy Cancer Treatment Start-Up

Content: A federal health officialâs ruling has cleared the way for 50 different types of cancer to be added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to compensate and treat people exposed to the toxic smoke, dust and fumes in the months after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.
Title: Sept. 11 Health Fund Given Clearance to Cover Cancer

Content: Representative Dave Camp, the powerful chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, disclosed Saturday that he had early-stage blood cancer but that he intended to undergo treatment while continuing his work in the House.
Title: Camp Diagnosed With Early-Stage Cancer

Content: CHICAGO â Drugs that unleash the bodyâs immune system to combat tumors could allow patients with advanced melanoma to live far longer than ever before, researchers gathered at the nationâs largest cancer conference say.
Title: New System for Treating Cancer Seen as Hopeful

Content: Carcinogens abounded 1.7 million years ago in Early Pleistocene times when a nameless protohuman wandered the South African countryside in what came to be known as the Cradle of Humankind.
Title: The Known: Cancer Is Really, Really Old. The Unknown: How Common It Was.

Content: For decades, millions of men with early prostate cancer have been placed on drug therapy to suppress their production of testosterone, despite such significant side effects as impotence, diabetes and bone loss. Now a large new analysis has concluded that so-called androgen deprivation therapy does not extend the lives of these patients.
Title: Study Discounts Testosterone Therapy for Early Prostate Cancer

Content: Two types of bacteria commonly found in the gut work together to fuel the growth of colon tumors, researchers reported on Thursday.
Title: Gut Microbes Combine to Cause Colon Cancer, Study Suggests

Content: For people with cancer or suspected cancer, the biopsy is a necessary evil â an uncomfortable and somewhat risky procedure to extract tissue for diagnosis or analysis.
Title: Sidestepping the Biopsy With New Tools to Spot Cancer

Content: Some Israeli doctors want Israel to conduct a national screening campaign to test all Jewish Israeli women of Ashkenazi descent for harmful genetic mutations that heighten the risk of breast and ovarian cancer. The debate is detailed in the article, âIn Israel, a Push to Screen for Cancer Gene Leaves Many Conflicted.â
Title: Ask Well: Genetic Testing for Breast Cancer

Content: Dr. Ronald A. DePinho likes to call the HPV shot series a âcancer vaccine.â
Title: An Improved Vaccination Against a Virus â and Some Cancers

Content: At a time when genetic testing and genetically personalized treatments for cancer are proliferating, buoyed by new resources like President Obamaâs $215 million personalized medicine initiative, women with breast cancer are facing a frustrating reality: The genetic data is there, but in many cases, doctors do not know what to do with it.
Title: When Gene Tests for Breast Cancer Reveal Grim Data but No Guidance

Content: Suleika Jaouad was just starting her adult life when leukemia struck. Her diagnosis and her brotherâs role as her bone marrow donor have affected her entire family.
Title: Life, Interrupted: A Family Gets Cancer

Content: Less than two weeks after Angelina Jolie described her decision to have a double mastectomy to avoid breast cancer in an Op-Ed article in The New York Times, her aunt, Debbie Martin, has died of the disease in Escondido, Calif., The Associated Press reported. She was 61 and died on Sunday.
Title: Angelina Jolieâs Aunt Dies of Breast Cancer

Content: People are always giving advice to cancer patients. Whether it is nutritional advice or doctor recommendations or tips on how to quell the nausea that accompanies chemotherapy, just as soon as people hear you are sick they usually want to find a way to help. Most of the advice is welcome and encouraging, though in some cases youâre just not in the mood to hear what someone has learned because youâre too busy treading water.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Six Ways to Cope With Cancer

Content: A new study adds to the evidence that low-dose aspirin, known to reduce the risk for heart disease, may also reduce the risk for pancreatic cancer.
Title: Aspirin May Cut Pancreatic Cancer Risk

Content: When researchers reported earlier this year that colorectal cancer rates were rising in adults as young as their 20s and 30s, some scientists were skeptical. The spike in figures, they suggested, might not reflect a real increase in disease incidence but earlier detection, which can be a good thing.
Title: More Young People Are Dying of Colon Cancer

Content: CHICAGO â One of the great frustrations for researchers in the war on cancer is that the bodyâs own defense system does not do a better job fighting the disease. Tumors, it turns out, have a molecular shield that repels attacks from the immune system.
Title: Drug Helps Defense System Fight Cancer

Content: Odds of survival can greatly improve for people with the most common type of lung cancer if they are given a new drug that activates the immune system along with chemotherapy, a major new study has shown.
Title: Lung Cancer Patients Live Longer With Immune Therapy

Content: Most people would agree that it would be better to prevent cancer, if we could, than to treat it once it developed. Yet economic incentives encourage researchers to focus on treatment rather than prevention.
Title: Why Preventing Cancer Is Not the Priority in Drug Development

Content: While I continue taking an experimental drug to keep my cancer at bay, I cannot claim to be in either a remission or a recurrence, and the word âmaintenanceâ does not shed much light on the situation. The paucity of the language at my disposal stymies me, as does its obfuscations. I am grateful that patients , hungry for more fortifying formulations, have begun to create them.
Title: Living With Cancer: Coming to Terms

Content: TWO patients, Iâll call them Sara and Janine, both learned that they had ductal carcinoma in situ (D.C.I.S.), often referred to as Stage 0 breast cancer. Both underwent lumpectomies in their early 50s. Told that worrisome cells were found, both had another surgery. Then a third surgery was recommended.
Title: Let Fear Guide Early Stage Breast-Cancer Decisions

Content: NEW DELHI â More women die from cervical cancer every year in India than anywhere else in the world, according to the Cervical Cancer-Free Coalition, an American research and advocacy group that released a âcervical cancer global crisis cardâ Friday.
Title: India Ranks No. 1 in Cervical Cancer Deaths

Content: Women undergoing in vitro fertilization have long worried that the procedure could raise their risk for breast cancer.
Title: I.V.F. Does Not Raise Breast Cancer Risk, Study Shows

Content: The widely prescribed drug tamoxifen already plays a major role in reducing the risk of death from breast cancer. But a new study suggests that women should be taking the drug for twice as long as is now customary, a finding that could upend the standard that has been in place for about 15 years.
Title: Bigger Role Seen for Breast Cancer Drug

Content: âI thought I was completely healthy.â
Title: With Cancer in the Past, Ryuichi Sakamoto Returns to His Calling

Content: I first met my patient, a former truck driver, in 2009, when he was in his mid-50s and had just been diagnosed with acute lymphocytic leukemia, or A.L.L. Often when my patients first learn that they have acute leukemia, they ask me: âDo I have the good one?â
Title: When Doctors Withdraw Cancer Treatment

Content: In mid-January, after a fall on invisible ice, I was informed by an emergency room doctor that my fractured pelvis would heal in six to eight weeks. To help me recover from the injury, therapists started coming to my house. Their ministrations posed a question that nagged at me: why arenât trained professionals made available to cancer outpatients in the way occupational and physical therapists are routinely assigned to orthopedic patients?
Title: After Physical Therapy, Why Not Cancer Therapy?

Content: A new noninvasive screening test can detect most cases of colorectal cancer and also many precancerous polyps, potentially helping to sharply reduce the death toll from the disease, according to results of a study released on Thursday.
Title: Noninvasive Cancer Test Is Effective, Study Finds

Content: The Food and Drug Administration for the first time has authorized a genetic testing company to offer screenings for three breast cancer mutations common in Ashkenazi Jews, giving consumers the ability to initiate testing at home and see results without talking to a doctor or counselor.
Title: F.D.A. Approves First Home Testing for 3 Breast Cancer Mutations, With Caveats

Content: MEMPHIS â After her doctor told her two months ago that she had breast cancer, Debrah Reid, a 58-year-old dance teacher, drove straight to a funeral home. She began planning a burial with the funeral director and his wife, even requesting a pink coffin.
Title: Tackling a Racial Gap in Breast Cancer Survival

Content: Millions of Americans will be wondering how Senator John McCain is coping with the news that he has an aggressive form of brain cancer known as glioblastoma. I certainly am: I found out that I had the same type of deadly tumor 18 months ago.
Title: John McCainâs Brain Cancer, and Mine

Content: When Robert B. Darnell was a graduate student in the early 1980s, he spent a year sequencing a tiny fragment of DNA. Now Dr. Darnell is an oncologist and the president of the New York Genome Center, where the DNA-sequencing machines can decode his grad-school fragment in less than a ten-thousandth of a second.
Title: Enlisting a Computer to Battle Cancers, One by One

Content: This article was reported and written in collaboration with ProPublica, the nonprofit journalism organization.
Title: Top Cancer Doctor Resigns as Editor of Medical Journal

Content: LONDON â AstraZeneca announced on Thursday that a cancer drug in development had not shown as much progress as expected, a setback for the pharmaceutical company, which is grappling with weak sales and competition from manufacturers of generics.
Title: AstraZenecaâs Cancer Drug Trial Disappoints, Sending Shares Lower

Content: CT scans in children can cause small but significant increases in the risk of leukemia and brain cancer, a new study finds.
Title: CT Scans Increase Childrenâs Cancer Risk, Study Finds

Content: Guilt, like cancer, is a greedy guest feasting on its host. It is nondiscriminatory. We have all felt it, wondered what it was doing there, willed it to go away.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Feeling Guilty About Cancer

Content: Incidences of colorectal cancer have been decreasing by about 1 percent a year since the mid 1980s, but incidences among people under 50 â the recommended screening age â has been increasing sharply, and these younger patients are more likely to present with advanced disease.
Title: Colon Cancer Rates Rising in Young Adults

Content: Bad news for men popped up in news media all over the country this week, based on a study from Northwestern University reporting that cases of advanced, aggressive prostate cancer had risen sharply from 2004 to 2013.
Title: Flawed Study of Advanced Prostate Cancer Spreads False Alarm
Reacting to Angelina Jolieâs Breast Cancer News

Content: Recently, I lost a day at work when my Upshot colleague Austin Frakt emailed me first thing in the morning to tell me that headlines were appearing declaring that an âexplosive new cellphone-cancerâ study was making the rounds. As I have long been interested in this topic, I started to read the headlines and news.
Title: Why Itâs Not Time to Panic About Cellphones and Cancer

Content: A new implant tries to anticipate seizures before they happen â and stop them; a new test could help cut down on colonoscopy visits; you may think you can spot someone in a lie, but science says different.
Title: Progress on Epilepsy and Cancer, To Catch a Lie

Content: An article Thursday on the results of a study indicating that aggressive surgical treatment of a possible precursor to breast cancer may be unnecessary prompted a wide range of responses from readers, among them anger, sadness and relief.
Title: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Readers React

Content: A new implant tries to anticipate seizures before they happen; a new test to limit colonoscopy visits; and spotting a liar.
Title: Progress on Epilepsy and Cancer, To Catch a Lie

Content: In a new study involving mice, aerobic exercise slowed the growth of breast cancer tumors and made the cancer more sensitive to chemotherapy. The results raise the possibility that exercise may change the biology of some malignant tumors, potentially making them easier to treat.
Title: How Exercise May Aid Cancer Treatment

Content: The lyrical Southern novelist Pat Conroy, whose books include âThe Prince of Tidesâ and âThe Great Santini,â announced Monday that he had pancreatic cancer.
Title: The Author Pat Conroy Announces He Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Hormone therapy, a common treatment for prostate cancer, is associated with an increased risk for Alzheimerâs disease, a new study has found.
Title: Prostate Cancer Treatment Tied to Alzheimerâs Risk

Content: WASHINGTON â Cancer researchers say there has been a substantial increase in women under the age of 26 who have received a diagnosis of early-stage cervical cancer, a pattern that they say is most likely an effect of the Affordable Care Act.
Title: Rise in Early Cervical Cancer Detection Is Linked to Affordable Care Act

Content: A new digital ad campaign from Priorities USA, a âsuper PACâ supporting Hillary Clinton, equates fighting bigotry with stopping the presidential candidacy of Donald J. Trump. Priorities is spending $500,000 â a large amount for an online ad â on the first commercial, âDante,â which portrays Mr. Trump as biased against the disabled.
Title: A Young Cancer Survivor Scolds Donald Trump

Content: Doctors have taken an important step toward a long-sought goal: harnessing a personâs own immune system to fight cancer.
Title: Patientâs Cells Deployed to Attack Aggressive Cancer

Content: President Obamaâs initiative to advance personalized medicine depends on the sort of breakthroughs in cell biology that have produced cancer drugs like the one extending my life. Yet very few adults with cancer enroll in clinical trials. Why do many trials fail to enroll sufficient patients, when scientists now test less debilitating therapies than those commonly used?
Title: Living With Cancer: Clinical Trials Looking for Patients

Content: A vegetarian diet, especially one that includes fish, significantly reduces the risk of colorectal cancer, a large new study reports.
Title: Vegetarian Diet May Cut Colon Cancer Risk

Content: CARACAS, Venezuela â President Hugo ChÃ¡vez of Venezuela said on Tuesday that doctors had found a new lesion that could indicate a return of his cancer, and that he would undergo an operation to have it removed.
Title: ChÃ¡vez Says His Cancer Shows Sign of Return

Content: CHICAGO â Many men with prostate cancer put off using chemotherapy as long as possible, fearing its side effects.
Title: Study May Alter Approach to Prostate Cancer

Content: A new study has found that high bodily levels of the trace elements nickel and selenium may be associated with reduced risk for pancreatic cancer, and that high levels of arsenic, cadmium and lead may increase the risk.
Title: Patterns: Trace Elements and Pancreatic Cancer Risk

Content: Even as Herceptin has become a hugely successful breast cancer drug, doctors have been troubled by a nagging question that has billion-dollar implications: How long should patients be treated with it?
Title: Studies Back Length of Herceptin Cancer Treatment

Content: Vaccines against cervical cancer work well even in sexually active women with H.I.V., a new study has found. It also found that women who already have one or two strains of the cancer-causing virus can be protected against others.
Title: Cancer Vaccine Proves Effective in H.I.V. Patients

Content: In 2006, the National Cancer Institute took the rare step of issuing a âclinical announcement,â a special alert it holds in reserve for advances so important that they should change medical practice.
Title: Effective Ovarian Cancer Treatment Is Underused, Study Finds

Content: President Jimmy Carter, who disclosed Thursday that he has metastatic melanoma, is in a position to benefit from promising new approaches to attacking cancer, including a drug approved less than a year ago.
Title: New Methods for Cancer May Benefit Jimmy Carterâs Fight

Content: A day after Warren Buffett announced he had prostate cancer, the question on the minds of many men and their doctors is this: âWhy was an 81-year-old man screened for the disease in the first place?â
Title: Why Was Warren Buffett Screened for Prostate Cancer?

Content: Suleika Jaouad, 23, is chronicling her return to her parentsâ home, and to a life of being cared for, in a post on The Timesâs Well blog. Her âboomerangâÂ  back toward her childhood house came about as a result of her diagnosis ofÂ  leukemia last year, and now, waiting for a bone marrow transplant, her life has become, she writes, a âslow emergency,â her world âa waiting room.â
Title: When Cancer âBoomerangsâ the Adult Child

Content: Tests commonly recommended to screen healthy women for ovarian cancer do more harm than good and should not be performed, a panel of medical experts said on Monday.
Title: Ovarian Cancer Screenings Are Not Effective, Panel Says

Content: Americans seem very afraid of cancer, with good reason. Unlike other things that kill us, it often seems to come out of nowhere.
Title: Helpless to Prevent Cancer? Actually, Quite a Bit Is in Your Control

Content: Mary Elizabeth Williamsâs latest book, âA Series of Catastrophes and Miracles,â starts with the spoiler: This is a cancer memoir with a happy ending, where one of those post-scan phone calls comes, at last, with good news.
Title: When âHaving It Allâ Includes Having Cancer

Content: There may yet be hope for the Tasmanian devil.
Title: New Hope for Tasmanian Devils in Fight Against Contagious Cancer

Content: Loose pieces of DNA course through our veins. As cells in our body die, they cast off fragments of genes, some of which end up in the bloodstream, saliva and urine.
Title: Searching for Cancer Maps in Free-Floating DNA

Content: FOR the first 18 years of my life, I was raised as a vegetarian. My father was convinced of the perils of red meat after my paternal grandmother died on the operating table from late-stage colon cancer. While my father would no doubt be pleased by the news last week that a panel convened by the World Health Organization declared processed meats a cause of colorectal cancer â and red meat a probable one â Iâm not convinced.
Title: So Will Processed Meat Give You Cancer?

Content: LONDON â Adaptimmune, a biotechnology company, said on Monday that it had reached a deal that could be worth more than $350 million to develop an early stage cancer drug with the pharmaceutical maker GlaxoSmithKline.
Title: GlaxoSmithKline in $350 Million Cancer Drug Venture

Content: Is you is or is you ainât my cancer? I was in a funk about what to do about a possible cancer diagnosis until Beethoven came to the rescue.
Title: While Facing a Cancer Choice, Beethoven to the Rescue

Content: The Times's Sheryl Gay Stolberg on the announcement that Tony Snow's cancer has spread to his liver.
Title: Back Story on the White House Spokesman's Cancer

Content: After receiving a diagnosis of prostate cancer, Scott Blackmun, the chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, announced he would not travel to South Korea for the opening ceremony of the Olympics next month.
Title: U.S.O.C. Chief Executive Has Cancer

Content: A new cancer drug that has attracted considerable attention from doctors and investors won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday.
Title: Imbruvica, Drug to Treat Blood Cancer, Gains F.D.A. Approval

Content: The Pap test, which has prevented countless deaths from cervical cancer, may eventually help to detect cancers of the uterus and ovaries as well, a new study suggests.
Title: Pap Test Could Help Find Cancers of Uterus and Ovaries

Content: Annie Krause moved into a nursing home in Detroit in 2015, when she was 98 years old. She had grown frail. Arthritis, recurrent infections and hypertension had made it difficult for her to manage on her own.
Title: For Elderly Women With Breast Cancer, Surgery May Not Be the Best Option

Content: It was the annual fund-raising event for the Hope Lodge, my temporary home after a bone marrow transplant. The host asked all the survivors to step forward from the crowd. I froze. I didnât know if that word applied to me. What does it mean to be a survivor? I certainly didnât feel like one. Not yet, anyway.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Am I a Cancer Survivor?

Content: More than 10 months after state leaders halted grant operations at the Cancer Prevention and Research Institute of Texas, known as Cprit, amid allegations of cronyism and misspent money, the $3 billion enterprise is getting back to the business of fighting cancer,Â with restructured leadership.
Title: Cancer Agency Is Back in Business, Writing Checks

Content: While packing up scarves and hats to mail to a member of my cancer support group, I remember her lament. âAfter the major loss of body parts, why do I weep over my lost hair?â she wondered. âI know it will grow back, but somehow it feels like the last straw â figuratively and literally!â
Title: Living With Cancer: Living Without Hair

Content: WASHINGTON â On March 29, Georgetown University Hospital opened a proton-therapy cancer unit that is expected to treat about 300 patients a year at premium prices using what its proponents promote as the most advanced radiology for attacking certain tumors.
Title: For Cancer Centers, Proton Therapyâs Promise Is Undercut by Lagging Demand

Content: Iâm the only mother I know who is happy to see her daughter cry. Not because she deserves to, but because after everything she has faced, her tears are our first glimpse of emotions that have been missing for a very long time.
Title: After Cancerâs Calm, a Daughterâs Emotional Storm

Content: Selections from Miriam Engelbergâs comic memoir.
Title: âCancer Made Me a Shallower Personâ

Content: THE FACTS
Title: Really? The Claim: Eating Soy Increases the Risk of Breast Cancer

Content: Every summer as Americans slather on sun lotion, they are reminded of the dangers of skin cancer.
Title: Should You Get Screened for Skin Cancer?

Content: I began to walk to counter the adverse side effects of cancer treatment â and to stay alive. Some days I could hardly get out of bed. But if I was able to summon the energy to get up and walk, I found I had less physical pain and far less fear and anxiety.
Title: Walking 800 Miles Away From Cancer

Content: On Oct. 15 at 8 a.m., Andy Lindsay stood atop 21,247-foot Mera Peak in Nepal, a wildly improbable place for him to be both athletically and medically.
Title: When the Lung Cancer Patient Climbs Mountains

Content: One year ago, almost to the day, I asked my hairdresser to cut off 16 inches of my hair. It was a pre-emptive strike. A few days later I would be admitted to the oncology unit at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan to undergo chemotherapy to treat leukemia. Everyone knows that chemo takes your hair. I wanted to take control of what I could before the poison did its damage. But I left the hair salon in tears, my braids in a plastic bag.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Finding My Cancer Style

Content: A new study shows that patients are far less likely to undergo screening for colon cancer if their doctors recommend only colonoscopy, rather than offering other screening options.
Title: Giving Patients Choices in Colon Cancer Screening

Content: A drug that scientists hoped might be a safe new way to prevent breast cancer appears to pose a risk after all: significant bone loss.
Title: Cancer-Deterring Drug Found to Harm Bones

Content: President Juan Manuel Santos said Monday that he would undergo surgery for prostate cancer this week. The president, 61, said that the cancer had been detected at an early stage and that doctors told him that he had a 97 percent chance of a full recovery. One of his doctors was quoted in Colombian media reports as saying that neither chemotherapy nor radiation therapy would be needed after the surgery, which will remove Mr. Santosâs prostate. Meanwhile, the Colombian government is preparing to open peace talks this month with the countryâs largest guerrilla group. The talks are to begin in Oslo and later move to Havana.
Title: Colombia: President to Undergo Surgery for Prostate Cancer

Content: The New York Times would like to hear from doctors and patients who have experience giving or receiving immunotherapy treatment for cancer.
Title: Have You Received Immunotherapy Treatment for Cancer?

Content: WASHINGTON â The federal Medicare program and private health insurers waste nearly $3 billion every year buying cancer medicines that are thrown out because many drug makers distribute the drugs only in vials that hold too much for most patients, a group of cancer researchers has found.
Title: Waste in Cancer Drugs Costs $3 Billion a Year, a Study Says

Content: WASHINGTON â Representative Carolyn McCarthy, a Democrat from Long Island, announced on Monday that she has a treatable form of lung cancer.
Title: L.I. Representative Faces Treatment for Lung Cancer

Content: In May 2011, Cassandra Caton, an 18-year-old with honey-colored hair and the soft features of a child, suddenly went blind in her right eye. Five months later, an ophthalmologist noticed something disturbing. A large growth in the back of her eye had ripped her retina, destroying her vision.
Title: A Life-Death Predictor Adds to a Cancerâs Strain

Content: The two companies that make vaccines against cervical cancer announced Thursday that they would cut their prices to the worldâs poorest countries below $5 per dose, eventually making it possible for millions of girls to be protected against a major deadly cancer.
Title: Cancer Vaccines Get a Price Cut in Poor Nations

Content: Many studies have found that regular aspirin use reduces the risk for colon cancer. Now scientists have found that aspirin may benefit some people far more than others.
Title: Aspirin Benefits Some at Risk for Colon Cancer

Content: Gerard Mortier, the opera impresario with a penchant for shaking things up in some of Europeâs most storied opera houses and music festivals, is being treated for cancer, the Spanish newspaper El PaÃ­s reported this week.
Title: Gerard Mortier Undergoing Cancer Treatment

Content: Youâd think that when parents are told of a vaccine that could prevent future cancers in their children, theyâd leap at the chance to protect them. Alas, that is hardly the case for a vaccine that prevents infections with cancer-causing human papillomavirus, or HPV. The vaccine, best given at age 11 to 12, is currently the most underutilized immunization available for children.
Title: The Underused HPV Vaccine

Content: WASHINGTON â Dr. Norman E. (Ned) Sharpless, director of the National Cancer Institute, will serve as acting commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Alex M. Azar III, secretary of health and human services, announced on Tuesday.
Title: National Cancer Chief, Ned Sharpless, Named F.D.A.âs Acting Commissioner

Content: Researchers report that eating red meat is associated with an increased risk for breast cancer, and eating white meat with a reduced risk.
Title: Eating Red Meat Tied to Increased Breast Cancer Risk

Content: The October breeze felt exhilarating on my scalp as a hairdresser shaved my head. With mixed feelings, I watched my wild, frizzy brown locks fall away and leave behind a clean, neat half-inch buzz.
Title: Hiding My Cancer Under the Hijab

Content: Ellen Stovall, a three-time cancer survivor and, as the president of the National Coalition for Cancer Survivorship, a prominent advocate for patients dealing with a host of problems during and after their cancer treatment, died on Tuesday in Rockville, Md. She was 69.
Title: Ellen Stovall, Three-Time Cancer Survivor and Advocate, Dies at 69

Content: From 1991 to 2015, the cancer death rate dropped about 1.5 percent a year, resulting in a total decrease of 26 percent â 2,378,600 fewer deaths than would have occurred had the rate remained at its peak.
Title: Cancer Deaths Continue a Steep Decline

Content: In the world of social media, we are our own self-portraitists. Our digital identity is doctored to show the best version of our lives. (Maybe a more apt name for Facebook would have been âBest Faceâ book.) Itâs not a new observation to point out the disparities between our online identities and our real selves, but for me, as a cancer patient, that gap has never felt larger.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Posting Your Cancer on Facebook

Content: Electric fans growl like airplanes taking off and banks of green lights wink in a basement at Mount Sinaiâs medical school, where a new $3 million supercomputer makes quick work of huge amounts of genetic and other biological information.
Title: Cancer Centers Racing to Map Patientsâ Genes

Content: Time-lapse video shows the White House turning pink as night falls on the U.S. capital to highlight Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Rough Cut (no reporter narration).
Title: White House glows pink for breast cancer awareness

Content: THE FACTS
Title: Really?: Gum Disease Tied to Pancreatic Cancer Risk

Content: Does a widening waistline put you at risk for cancer? Apparently so. According to a new study, nearly 6 percent of cancers are attributable at least in part to  obesity and diabetes.
Title: Two Hidden Cancer Causes: Diabetes and Obesity

Content: Santas march through Moscow to collect gifts for children who will have to spend New Year's Eve at a cancer clinic. Gavino Garay reports.
Title: Russian Santas collect toys for cancer patients

Content: Rosie Swale Pope is running 5, 425km across the U.S. at the age of 68 in memory of her husband who died from cancer. Rough cut (no reporter narration).
Title: Cancer death drives pan-US run

Content: A crucial medicine to treat childhood leukemia is in such short supply that hospitals across the country may exhaust their stores within the next two weeks, leaving hundreds and perhaps thousands of children at risk of dying from a largely curable disease, federal officials and cancer doctors say.
Title: Supply of a Cancer Drug May Run Out Within Weeks

Content: ORURO, Bolivia â President Hugo ChÃ¡vez of Venezuela announced Saturday in Caracas that he would have to undergo another operation for cancer, and he designated his vice president, NicolÃ¡s Maduro, as his successor if he should prove unable to continue to lead the country.
Title: ChÃ¡vez Says His Cancer Has Returned and Names His Successor

Content: The British newspaper The Guardian on Monday removed from its website a controversial column by one of its writers that discussed a womanâs use of Twitter to chronicle her struggle with cancer. In removing it, The Guardian cited an investigation into the column.
Title: Guardian Deletes Column About a Cancer Patient

Content: When her parents faced cancer together, Nancy Borowick chronicled their daily struggles and everyday moments. The book she is seeking to publish chronicles not just their illnesses and deaths, but also their lives as a family.
Title: Cancer Family: Documenting Life Before Death

Content: As a cancer patient, I think a lot about how we talk about illness â or more often, how we talk around it. Even the word âcancerâ is ugly, scary, burdensome â a roadblock for a conversation before it even starts. Who wants to go there? Much of the time, Iâd rather not bring it up if I donât have to â and Iâm the one with the disease!
Title: Life, Interrupted: Putting a Positive Spin on Cancer

Content: James F. Holland, a founding father of chemotherapy who helped pioneer a lifesaving drug treatment for pediatric leukemia patients, died on Thursday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 92.
Title: James F. Holland, Trailblazing Cancer Researcher, Dies at 92

Content: Breast cancer survival is, over all, three years shorter for black women compared with white women, mostly because their cancer is often more advanced when they first seek medical care, new research shows.
Title: Black-White Divide Persists in Breast Cancer

Content: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded on Monday to James P. Allison of the United States and Tasuku Honjo of Japan for their work on unleashing the bodyâs immune system to attack cancer, a breakthrough that has led to an entirely new class of drugs and brought lasting remissions to many patients who had run out of options.
Title: 2018 Nobel Prize in Medicine Awarded to 2 Cancer Immunotherapy Researchers

Content: The first drug for an advanced form of the most common type of skin cancer won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Monday.
Title: F.D.A. Approves Drug for an Advanced Skin Cancer

Content: Despite my best efforts, I remain bewildered about the surgical mishap I suffered in 2008. It was a debulking operation â the removal of all organs affected by a cancer that originated in my ovaries. The procedure was undertaken by the proper specialist, a gynecologic oncologist, but as I recounted in my memoir, the surgery did not go well for me.
Title: Living With Cancer: Not Talking About Medical Mistakes

Content: AbbVie is to buy Pharmacyclics Inc for about $21 billion.  As Hayley Platt reports it continues a growing M&A trend in the sector and will give the drugmaker access to what is expected to be one of the world's top-selling cancer drugs.
Title: Cancer drug key to $21bln pharma deal

Content: Purveyors of pop culture have a way of discovering a subject simultaneously. This is apparently the moment for the realization that young people can get cancer just like older ones. The top film at the box office over the weekend was âThe Fault in Our Stars,â a weeper about two teenagers with cancer, and on Tuesday night ABC Family introduces âChasing Life.â
Title: A Reporter Fits Cancer Into Her Busy Schedule

Content: People with swollen gums, missing teeth and other signs of poor dental health are more likely to be infected orally with the human papillomavirus, researchers reported on Wednesday.
Title: Study Ties Poor Oral Health to Cancer-Causing Virus

Content: Q. Does eating smoked fish, such as smoked salmon or whitefish, increase the risk of colorectal cancer or other cancers, the way processed and deli meats do?
Title: Do Lox and Other Smoked Fish Increase Cancer Risk?

Content: KFAR SABA, Israel â Ever since she tested positive for a defective gene that causes breast cancer, Tamar Modiano has harbored a motherâs fear: that she had passed it on to her two daughters. Ms. Modiano had her breasts removed at 47 to prevent the disease and said that the day she found out her older daughter tested negative was one of the happiest of her life.
Title: In Israel, a Push to Screen for Cancer Gene Leaves Many Conflicted

Content: A 68-year-old woman is running from New York to San Francisco to honor her late husband and others who have lost their lives to cancer. Linda So reports.
Title: Woman embarks on cancer run across U.S.

Content: LONDON â The Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis said on Monday that it had offered to buy Advanced Accelerator Applications of France for $3.9 billion in cash, as it seeks to bolster its portfolio of cancer treatments.
Title: Novartis Looks to Buy French Firm to Bolster Cancer Portfolio

Content: 65 percent
Title: More Americans Are Dying of Cirrhosis and Liver Cancer

Content: Levon Helm, the drummer with the Band, has reached the final stages of his battle with cancer, according to a note posted on the musicianâs Web site.Â Mr. Helm, 71, received a diagnosis of throat cancer in 1998 and nearly lost his voice, though he has continued to sing on albums and at concerts.Â The note, signed by his daughter and wife, asked fans to send âprayers and love to him as he makes his way through this part of his journey.âÂ
Title: Levon Helm in Final Stages of Cancer Battle

Content: When President Nixon signed the National Cancer Act many expected quick results, comparing the effort to the one that put man on the moon. After 42 years, what progress have we made?
Title: The War on Cancer: From Nixon Until Now

Content: LOS ANGELES â Sean Parker was a pioneer in music sharing when he co-founded Napster and in social media as the early president of Facebook. Now he wants to pioneer in a field that is already jumping with activity: cancer immunotherapy.
Title: Sean Parker, a Facebook and Napster Pioneer, to Start Cancer Immunotherapy Effort

Content: In a decision that is inflaming passions on both sides of the abortion debate, the worldâs largest breast cancer organization, Susan G. Komen for the Cure, is cutting off its financing of breast cancer screening and education programs run by Planned Parenthood affiliates.
Title: Cancer Group Halts Financing to Planned Parenthood

Content: Jim Kelly, the Hall of Fame quarterback who led the Buffalo Bills to four consecutive Super Bowl appearances in the 1990s, announced on Thursday that he had again received a diagnosis of cancer.
Title: Hall of Famer Jim Kelly Announces His Cancer Has Returned

Content: Several studies have found that being married improves survival in cancer patients. Now a new study suggests that it may largely be the social and emotional support of marriage, rather than any economic advantages, that produces the effect.
Title: Social Support of Marriage May Improve Cancer Survival

Content: Anyone who still needs motivation to move more may find it in a new study showing that, in addition to its other health benefits, exercise appears to substantially reduce the risk of developing 13 different varieties of cancer. That is far more types than scientists previously thought might be impacted by exercise. The comprehensive study also suggests that the potential cancer-fighting benefits of exercise seem to hold true even if someone is overweight.
Title: Exercise Tied to Lower Risk for 13 Types of Cancer

Content: A rare cancer first linked to breast implants in 2011 has now been associated with nine deaths, the Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday.
Title: 9 Deaths Are Linked to Rare Cancer From Breast Implants

Content: I have a severe intestinal condition known as ulcerative colitis. For some time, Iâve taken an immunosuppressant to control the flare-ups. Like all drugs, this one comes with side effects. While Iâm on it, I have an increased risk of developing myelosuppression, a condition in which my bone marrow might stop producing blood cells and platelets. I also have an increased risk of developing skin cancer.
Title: Birth Control and Breast Cancer: Putting the Risk in Perspective

Content: U.S. regulators on Friday approved a new drug for an aggressive type of breast cancer thatâs spread in the body â including into the brain, where itâs especially tough to treat.
Title: FDA Approves Pill for Aggressive Breast Cancer That's Spread

Content: I remember when being good seemed strategic.
Title: Living With Cancer: The Good Patient Syndrome

Content: A change in diet for just two weeks alters gut bacteria in ways that may reduce risk of colon cancer, according to a new study in Nature Communications.
Title: African Diet May Lead Away From Colon Cancer

Content: When my oncologist told me about her various job offers, she laughed and reassured me that the only position that could lure her away would be a professorship named for Princess Diana. Of course I knew she was kidding.
Title: Living With Cancer: My Doctor, My Friend

Content: A month after his 2009 graduation from Yale Law School, Seun Adebiyi learned he had not one but two lethal blood cancers and began an odyssey to find a bone-marrow donor. Mr. Adebiyi, 28, who came to this country from Nigeria as a child, made appeals through Yale, on radio stations, in a YouTube video and even on a trip to Nigeria to ask law students to volunteer.
Title: Finding a Match, and a Mission: Helping Blacks Survive Cancer

Content: Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to have many health benefits. But they may have risks as well, including an increased risk for prostate cancer.
Title: Omega-3s May Raise Prostate Cancer Risk

Content: Q. CAN PLANTS GET CANCER? IF NOT, WHAT WOULD CAUSE A BULBOUS GROWTH ON A TREE?
Title: Can Plants Get Cancer?

Content: Amy Robach, an anchor on ABCâs âGood Morning America,â had avoided her doctorâs recommendation for a mammogram screening for a year, when a producer for the show called at the end of September and asked her to consider undergoing a televised mammogram.
Title: Amy Robach of ABC Says On-Air Mammogram Found Breast Cancer

Content: On Sept. 11, 2001, Police Officer Alonzo Harris rushed to the World Trade Center to try to evacuate people from the burning towers. When the first tower collapsed, he dove beneath a parked car as thick plumes of dust and debris blotted out the sun. Later, he said, he sealed the grit-covered uniform he had worn that day in a plastic bag.
Title: Police Union Seeks Data for Cancer Links to 9/11

Content: Colon cancer patients who were heavy coffee drinkers had a far lower risk of dying or having their cancer return than those who did not drink coffee, with significant benefits starting at two to three cups a day, a new study found. Patients who drank four cups of caffeinated coffee or more a day had half the rate of recurrence or death than noncoffee drinkers.
Title: Daily Coffee May Boost Colon Cancer Survival

Content: When Nancy Borowickâs parents Howie and Laurel both faced stage-four cancer together three years ago, the young photographer confronted the family crisis with her camera. She documented not just their struggles, deaths and funerals, but also the many ordinary, everyday moments that had taken on a special urgency.
Title: Cancer Family: Documenting Life Before Death

Content: Elena Altemus is 89 and has dementia. She often forgets her childrenâs names, and sometimes canât recall whether she lives in Maryland or Italy.
Title: Too Many Older Patients Get Cancer Screenings

Content: Can going for a walk improve cancer survivorsâ long-term prognosis? It may, according to new research showing that exercise can lower survivorsâ risk of premature death, not only from cancer but from any cause. The findings are likely to resonate widely at a time when about 14 million Americans, and many more worldwide, have survived cancer.
Title: Cancer Survivors Who Stay Active Live Longer

Content: A man whose penis was removed because of cancer has received the first penis transplant in the United States, at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
Title: Cancer Survivor Receives First Penis Transplant in the United States

Content: For many years, smoking and drinking were considered the dominant risk factors for cancers of the throat. But on Monday, The Guardian, a British newspaper, reported that the actor Michael Douglas believed that his throat cancer was caused by an infection acquired during oral sex, highlighting a trend that has alarmed many scientists.
Title: Throat Cancer Link to Oral Sex Gains Notice

Content: Who might benefit from a clinical trial for an experimental cancer treatment?
Title: How to Find Clinical Trials for Experimental Cancer Treatments

Content: BEIJING â For millions of Chinese, the new year opened under an oppressive shroud of smog that has closed highways, delayed or canceled hundreds of flights and shut down schools, forcing some students to follow their lessons from home through online streaming.
Title: A Poem Praises Smog, and Why Not? Itâs From Cancerâs Perspective

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Age, Exercise and Cancer

Content: Nancy Borowick decided to have her wedding in October because her parents, Laurel and Howie, both have cancer.
Title: Walking a Daughter Down the Aisle, In Spite of Cancer

Content: Textured breast implants made by Allergan that have been linked to an unusual cancer are being recalled in the United States at the request of the Food and Drug Administration, and will also be recalled globally, the agency announced on Wednesday.
Title: Breast Implants Linked to Rare Cancer Are Recalled Worldwide

Content: Although I usually refrain from writing columns linked to national health observances, I believe that Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month, in March, is too important to ignore. There are simply too many people who are still getting and dying from this preventable disease because they failed to get screened for it, including people without excuses like ignorance, lack of health insurance or poor access to medical services.
Title: Colon Cancer Screening Can Save Your Life

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Alternative Therapies, Cancer and Cholesterol

Content: An influential panel of experts convened by the World Health Organization concluded on Wednesday that regularly drinking coffee could protect against at least two types of cancer, a decision that followed decades of research pointing to the beverageâs many health benefits. The panel also said there was a lack of evidence that it might cause other types of cancer.
Title: Coffee May Protect Against Cancer, W.H.O. Concludes

Content: A baby girl who was close to dying from cancer has been rescued by a cell therapy envisioned as a âone size fits allâ treatment that had never been tested in people, doctors reported on Thursday.
Title: A Cell Therapy Untested in Humans Saves a Baby With Cancer

Content: The man was 23 when the delusions came on. He became convinced that his thoughts were leaking out of his head and that other people could hear them. When he watched television, he thought the actors were signaling him, trying to communicate. He became irritable and anxious and couldnât sleep.
Title: He Got Schizophrenia. He Got Cancer. And Then He Got Cured.

Content: Dan Woska was weighing his treatment options after he was found to have prostate cancer two years ago when a friend mentioned a new genomic test that could gauge how lethal his tumor was.
Title: New Diagnostic Tools for Prostate Cancer

Content: A new radiation therapy can extend the lives of men with the most advanced form of prostate cancer, a large new study has found.
Title: New Radiation Therapy Prolongs Prostate Cancer Survival

Content: In my recent Raw Data column about whether fruits and vegetables are crucial to avoiding cancer, I referred to two thick reports, published in 1997 and 2007 by the American Institute for Cancer Research and its affiliate, the World Cancer Research Fund. Sitting side by side on my desk, the books look similar: One cover is blue and the other green, and both are adorned with images of fruits, vegetables, legumes and grains interspersed with people working and playing, all apparently enjoying good health. Presiding over the scene is an image of Mother Earth.
Title: From an Apple a Day to âEnergy Balanceâ in Cancer Research

Content: THE FACTS
Title: Really? Drinking Coffee Lowers Colon Cancer Risk

Content: After I finished eight months of treatment for testicular cancer in my mid-20s, my psychologist said, âWell, that was like having five years of therapy all at once.â What he meant was that you learn a lot about yourself in weekly talk sessions, but during a life-threatening illness, the âissuesâ come at you nonstop. I relished the slow unfolding of myself in the first, but I resented â no, hated â every step of the second. Nearly two decades later, when confronted with the same diagnosis, I finally understood the benefits of that earlier trial by fire, much as I did the wisdom of Ralph Waldo Emerson when he wrote, âThe years teach much which the days never knew.â
Title: Taking On Cancer Again, This Time With the Wisdom of Age

Content: Two new studies revealed bad news about minimally invasive surgery for cervical cancer, a widely used procedure performed through small slits in the abdomen instead of a big incision.
Title: Studies Warn Against Minimally Invasive Surgery for Cervical Cancer

Content: Iâm driving my mother to her second week of radiation on a glorious spring day. Pale green leaf-lace froths on the trees, a verdant scribble working its way up the foothills of Mt. Greylock. Spring is an irrepressible fact in New England, not a clichÃ©. And the weather is our favorite subject now that Mom has moderate Alzheimerâs.
Title: Dementiaâs Gift: Facing Cancer Without the Fear

Content: When the essayist and novelist Jenny Diski, who died last week at 68, learned she had inoperable lung cancer, her first impulse was to make a âBreaking Badâ joke. She turned to her husband and said, in front of her doctor, âWeâd better get cooking the meth.â
Title: Review: Jenny Diskiâs âIn Gratitude,â an Uphill Life on and Off Cancer Road

Content: With the arrival of two revolutionary treatment strategies, immunotherapy and personalized medicine, cancer researchers have found new hope â and a problem that is perhaps unprecedented in medical research.
Title: A Cancer Conundrum: Too Many Drug Trials, Too Few Patients

Content: The incidence of advanced breast cancer among younger women, ages 25 to 39, may have increased slightly over the last three decades, according to a study released Tuesday.
Title: Study Sees More Breast Cancer at Young Age

Content: Katherine Russell Rich, whose gritty, darkly comic memoir of her protracted battle with breast cancer became a beacon for other patients, died of the disease on Tuesday. She was 56, and against all predictions had lived with cancer for nearly a quarter-century.
Title: Katherine Russell Rich, Who Wrote of Battle With Cancer, Dies at 56

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved Celgeneâs drug Abraxane for use in treating advanced pancreatic cancer, supplementing the thin arsenal available to fight the disease.
Title: F.D.A. Approves a Drug for Late-Stage Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Watching Robin Roberts tear up in front of millions of viewers on âGood Morning Americaâ last month, I cried, too.
Title: New Cancer Threat Lurks Long After Cure

Content: The waters of Flushing Bay, within view of La Guardia Airport, are some of the more polluted around New York City. The bay has poor circulation, and during heavy rainfalls sewers spew raw waste into the water from nearby homes and businesses.
Title: Cancer Survivors Apply Tenacious Spirit to Bay Cleanup

Content: In the usual cancer biopsy, a surgeon cuts out a piece of the patientâs tumor, but researchers in labs across the country are now testing a potentially transformative innovation. They call it the liquid biopsy, and it is a blood test that has only recently become feasible with the latest exquisitely sensitive techniques. It is showing promise in finding tiny snippets of cancer DNA in a patientâs blood.
Title: New Blood Test Shows Promise in Cancer Fight

Content: A large study has found that drinking coffee is associated with a reduced risk of death from oral cancer.
Title: Risks: Coffee Linked to Fewer Oral Cancer Deaths

Content: Women with metastatic breast cancer are living longer.
Title: Women With Aggressive Breast Cancer Are Living Longer

Content: WASHINGTON â A top official of the American Cancer Society has resigned in part because of concern over some of the organizationâs fund-raising partnerships.
Title: Cancer Society Executive Resigns Amid Upset Over Corporate Partnerships

Content: The Broadway star Marin Mazzie brings the same exuberance to living with late-stage ovarian cancer that she displays in her performances. Or perhaps the roles she has undertaken in musicals like âRagtime,â âKiss Me Kateâ and âThe King and Iâ have contributed to her proactive efforts to improve the fate of other women who will have to cope with the disease.
Title: How the Broadway Star Marin Mazzie Confronts Cancer

Content: Kenneth P. Thompson, the first black district attorney of Brooklyn and a voice for racial justice at a moment of tension between law enforcement and minority communities, died on Sunday from cancer, his family said. He was 50.
Title: Ken Thompson, Brooklyn District Attorney, Dies After Disclosing Cancer

Content: NEW DELHI â Prime Minister Sushil Koirala of Nepal is undergoing radiation therapy in New York to treat a cancerous tumor found on his lung, and his indefinite absence could further paralyze Nepalese politics.
Title: Nepalâs Premier Is Being Treated for Lung Cancer

Content: Amgen is halting a late-stage clinical trial of an experimental drug for pancreatic cancer after an outside monitoring panel concluded that the drug was unlikely to improve the survival of patients with an advanced form of the disease.
Title: Amgen, Citing Weak Results, Halts Study of a Cancer Drug

Content: Women with an aggressive type of breast cancer lived longer if they received immunotherapy plus chemotherapy, rather than chemo alone, a major study has found.
Title: Immune-Based Treatment Helps Fight Aggressive Breast Cancer, Study Finds

Content: The attendant walked into the hospital waiting room and called my name. I took a deep breath and hurried through the door. âIâm always surprised when my name is pronounced properly at a doctorâs office,â I said.
Title: Cancer Survivors Celebrate Their Cancerversary

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Marriage, Nuts and a Cancer Breakthrough

Content: An international panel of experts convened by the World Health Organization concluded Monday that eating processed meat like hot dogs, ham and bacon raises the risk of colon cancer and that consuming other red meats âprobablyâ raises the risk as well. But the increase in risk is so slight that experts said most people should not be overly worried about it.
Title: Meat Is Linked to Higher Cancer Risk, W.H.O. Report Finds

Content: âYou are being deported,â a surgeon announced to me last fall. Thatâs a scary thing for a child of two immigrants to hear. But he was referring to the removal of my port, a medical device implanted just beneath my right collarbone â a gateway for the dozens of rounds of chemotherapy, antibiotics and blood transfusions that have entered my body since I received a leukemia diagnosis at age 22.
Title: Lost in Transition After Cancer

Content: Diesel fumes cause lung cancer, the World Health Organization declared Tuesday, and experts said they were more carcinogenic than secondhand cigarette smoke.
Title: W.H.O. Declares Diesel Fumes Cause Lung Cancer

Content: The death rate from cervical cancer in the United States is considerably higher than previously estimated and the disparity in death rates between black women and white women is significantly wider, according to a study published Monday in the journal Cancer.
Title: Wider Racial Gap Found in Cervical Cancer Deaths

Content: Dr. Alfred G. Knudson, who deduced how certain cancers strike a family generation after generation, died on Sunday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 93.
Title: Dr. Alfred G. Knudson, the âMendel of Cancer Genetics,â Dies at 93

Content: Vaccines against the human papillomavirus have sharply reduced infections, genital and anal warts, and precancerous lesions in young women and girls in more than a dozen wealthy countries, a major new study has found â powerful evidence that these vaccines will ultimately cause major drops in cervical cancer.
Title: HPV Vaccines Are Reducing Infections, Warts â and Probably Cancer

Content: A campaign to change attitudes about people with a familiar form of cancer is proving to be provocative enough that some posters are being torn down â and those behind the campaign could not be more pleased.
Title: Cancer Campaign Tries Using Shock to Change Attitudes

Content: Dr. Carolyn M. Kaelin, a breast cancer surgeon who continued her research and advocacy for patients after her own diagnosis of breast cancer ended her surgical career, died on July 28 at her home in Charlestown, Mass. She was 54.
Title: Carolyn Kaelin, Breast Cancer Surgeon, Patient Advocate and Patient, Dies at 54

Content: My grandfather received a diagnosis of brain cancer a week before I had to hand in my masterâs thesis. The very first chapter discussed a scientific paper about his type of brain tumor. I found comfort in losing myself in the work: I sat by his hospital bed as he slept, and analyzed cancer data, typing out equations filled with Greek symbols that he had joked were some kind of sorcery.
Title: Seeking a Cancer-Free World

Content: On Tuesday, I got an e-mail from JAMA Oncology, a leading medical journal, saying that it planned to publish a paper and editorial on ductal carcinoma in situ, or D.C.I.S., a condition that has become increasingly controversial over the years. As many as 60,000 women are told each year that they have it: tiny clusters of abnormal breast cells, confined to a milk duct and too small to be felt. Itâs often called stage 0 cancer, and it almost never was detected before the early 1980s when mammograms came into widespread use.
Title: Aggressive Treatment for Early Breast Cancer: Reporterâs Notebook

Content: A Chinese hospital treating the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Liu Xiaobo has invited cancer experts from the United States, Germany and other nations to join his team of doctors, judicial officials said in a brief statement Wednesday.
Title: Chinese Hospital Invites Cancer Experts to Help Treat Nobel Laureate

Content: NEWARK â Devils center Brian Boyle said he had plenty of things on his mind besides his battle with chronic myeloid leukemia when he stepped onto the ice Nov. 1 for his first shift of the season. More than anything, he wanted to help his new team win.
Title: After a Cancer Diagnosis, the Devilsâ Brian Boyle Is Thriving

Content: Nice but noisy
Title: Waging the Cancer War, Surrounded by Signs of Life

Content: The Mediterranean diet â rich in vegetables, fruits, whole grains and olive oil, and low in dairy products and red meat â is linked to a reduced risk for breast cancer, according to a randomized trial.
Title: Mediterranean Diet Linked to Reduced Breast Cancer Risk

Content: In the documentary âBaring it All,â a young woman declares, âThe scar represents everything Iâve been through. Iâm proud of what Iâve been through.â The film focuses on the fashion photographer David Jay, who created a pictorial series about breast cancer called âThe Scar Project.â
Title: Living With Cancer: The Scar Project

Content: Physical activity, even including walking, can substantially reduce a womanâs risk of developing breast cancer, encouraging new science shows, in part, it seems, by changing how her body deals with estrogen.
Title: How Walking May Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: It can be hard for physicians to follow current thinking of experts on medical care. It must be exponentially harder for the public to make sense of it. Recently, the United States Preventive Services Task Force changed its recommendation on prostate cancer screening from a D (that is, donât do it) to a C (discuss it with your doctor).
Title: The ABCs and Ds of Whether to Get Prostate Cancer Screening

Content: SAN FRANCISCO â Some leading pharmaceutical companies are joining forces in an effort to speed the testing of new types of cancer drugs that harness the bodyâs immune system to battle tumors.
Title: Drug Companies to Try a Unified Front Against Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON â In a major test case, Medicare is poised to cover a promising but expensive new type of cancer treatment, with significant restrictions meant to hold down the cost.
Title: Medicare Aims to Expand Coverage of Cancer Care. But Is It Enough?

Content: Help contribute to The New York Times Magazineâs special Health Issue.
Title: Share Your Story About the New Science of Cancer

Content: Excitement over a promise of a new type of cancer treatment ignited a frenzy on Wall Street Friday as a little-known year-old company pulled off one of the largest initial public stock offerings in the biotechnology sector.
Title: I.P.O. of Juno Therapeutics, Developer of a Cancer Treatment, Excites Investors

Content: Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson, who has been undergoing cancer treatments, joined a contingent of club executives at the New York Athletic Club on Thursday for Mike Piazzaâs Hall of Fame news conference.
Title: Sandy Alderson, Recovering From Cancer, Defends Metsâ Moves

Content: The laboratory of Vera Gorbunova and Andrei Seluanov, a husband-and-wife team of biologists at the University of Rochester, has the feel of a petting zoo. They maintain colonies of several species of rodents â some familiar, like mice and guinea pigs, and some much more exotic, like blind mole rats from Israel and naked mole rats from East Africa.
Title: A Homely Rodent May Hold Cancer-Fighting Clues

Content: BEIJING â Living in China these days, weâre bombarded with scary accounts of rising cancer rates that are partly linked to some of the worldâs worst pollution.
Title: As Cancer Rates Rise in China, Trust Remains Low

Content: Julia Louis-Dreyfus has breast cancer, she announced on Thursday, less than two weeks after her record-setting Emmy win for âVeep.â
Title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Shares Breast Cancer Diagnosis

Content: âI am waiting for test and scan results, laying low after a busy and stressful week,â Lisa Bonchek Adams wrote on her blog in 2013, one of hundreds of posts to go along with thousands of Twitter messages documenting her life after she learned she had breast cancer in 2007, when she was 37.
Title: Lisa Bonchek Adams Dies at 45; Chronicled Fight With Breast Cancer

Content: The pink ribbon, that ubiquitous emblem of breast cancer awareness, has long been an object of controversy and derision, but the poet and essayist Anne Boyer doesnât just pull it loose, unfastening its dainty loop; she feeds it through a shredder and lights it on fire, incinerating its remains.
Title: âThe Undying,â an Extraordinary and Furious New Memoir About Cancer

Content: David Carr, the New York Times media columnist who died unexpectedly Thursday night, had lung cancer, and died of complications from the disease, according to the results of an autopsy released Saturday evening.
Title: Autopsy Cites Cancer as Cause in Death of David Carr, Times Reporter

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first of an eagerly awaited new class of cancer drugs that unleashes the bodyâs immune system to fight tumors.
Title: F.D.A. Allows First Use of a Novel Cancer Drug

Content: A genetic variant that is particularly common in some Hispanic women with indigenous American ancestry appears to drastically lower the risk of breast cancer, a new study found.
Title: Genetic Variant May Shield Latinas From Breast Cancer

Content: In a small, preliminary study, an experimental vaccine provoked a strong immune response against precancerous cells in women treated for cervical lesions that can progress to cancer.
Title: Therapeutic Vaccine Shows Potential in Fighting Cervical Cancer

Content: A drug used to treat advanced breast cancer has had what appears to be unprecedented success in prolonging lives in a clinical trial, researchers reported on Sunday.
Title: Roche Breast Cancer Drug Perjeta Appears to Greatly Extend Patientsâ Lives

Content: Compared with women who have never given birth, those who recently had babies may have a slight increased risk of breast cancer that peaks after about five years and then gradually declines, according to a study published this week.
Title: Breast Cancer Risk May Rise After Childbirth, but Is Still Low

Content: Elwood V. Jensen, a medical researcher whose studies of steroid hormones led to new treatments for breast cancer that have been credited with saving or extending hundreds of thousands of lives, died on Dec. 16 in Cincinnati. He was 92.
Title: Elwood V. Jensen, Pioneer in Breast Cancer Treatment, Dies at 92

Content: Michael Mercado, 20, has made a bargain with fate. He would finish school and find a good job working on cars if only, he says, âthe cancer stays away.â
Title: At 20, Surviving Battle With Cancer on His Own

Content: Members of the news media gathered in a conference room at Citi Field on Friday for the annual off-season luncheon with Mets executives, including the chief operating officer Jeff Wilpon, the assistant general manager John Ricco and the top front-office aide J. P. Ricciardi.
Title: Metsâ Sandy Alderson Needs Treatment for Cancer

Content: The Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation has canceled half of its â3-Dayâ fund-raising races around the country next year as it struggles to regain support nearly 18 months after its 2012 decision to withdraw funding for breast cancer screening at some Planned Parenthood affiliates.
Title: Komen Breast Cancer Charity Cancels Races in 7 Cities

Content: Many women with early-stage breast cancer who would receive chemotherapy under current standards do not actually need it, according to a major international study that is expected to quickly change medical treatment.
Title: Good News for Women With Breast Cancer: Many Donât Need Chemo

Content: THE BREAKTHROUGH Immunotherapy and the Race to Cure Cancer By Charles Graeber Illustrated. 302 pp. Twelve. $28.
Title: Could Immunotherapy Offer a Cure for Cancer?

Content: ISTANBUL/ANKARA â Demet Isil Yilmaz was halfway through a debilitating chemotherapy course when the coronavirus pandemic erupted, intensifying her struggle for health which she has chronicled for her thousands of Instagram followers.
Title: 'This Will Pass': Turkish Cancer Blogger Hopeful Despite Coronavirus
A Revolutionary Cancer Therapy Made From Patientsâ Cells

Content: Last Friday a group of 15 cancer researchers cut short a meeting at the Food and Drug Administration. The reason: They had been invited to Vice President Joseph R. Bidenâs office to discuss his âmoonshotâ to cure cancer.
Title: âMoonshotâ to Cure Cancer, to Be Led by Biden, Relies on Outmoded View of Disease

Content: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chaseâs chief executive, announced to his staff on Friday that his doctors had found no evidence of cancer in his body, a few months after he concluded treatment for throat cancer.
Title: Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase Says, âNo Evidence of Cancerâ

Content: Venezuela will create a scientific panel to investigate the illness of Hugo ChÃ¡vez, after an accusation by the interim president last week that the former presidentâs cancer was mysteriously caused by his enemies. âWe have this intuition that our Commander ChÃ¡vez was poisoned by dark forces that wanted to get rid of him to destroy the Bolivarian revolution and strike at Latin America and the Caribbean,â NicolÃ¡s Maduro, the interim president, said Monday night. Mr. ChÃ¡vez, a charismatic leftist, died last week after 14 years in office. The government has refused to say what type of cancer Mr. ChÃ¡vez had, but Mr. Maduro said that it had behaved in a very unusual way. Mr. Maduro said that the United States and other countries had developed programs in the 1940s and 1950s to experiment with intentionally causing cancer, but he added, âIâm not accusing the United States at this moment.â He did not say when the scientific panel would be created or who would be on it.
Title: Venezuela: Panel Will Investigate Roots of Cancer That Killed ChÃ¡vez

Content: A friend in my cancer support group suggested a call to Look Good Feel Better when I arrived at lunch looking bad and feeling worse. The program had given her eyebrows. Eyebrows, I thought, would be good. Eyebrows seem like something it might be reasonable to want.
Title: Living With Cancer: Look Good, Feel Better

Content: Computers were as good or better than doctors at detecting tiny lung cancers on CT scans, in a study by researchers from Google and several medical centers.
Title: A.I. Took a Test to Detect Lung Cancer. It Got an A.

Content: They are among the most challenging prostate cancer patients to treat: about 150,000 men worldwide each year whose cancer is aggressive enough to defy standard hormonal therapy, but has not yet spread to the point where it can be seen on scans.
Title: Two Prostate Cancer Drugs Delay Spread of the Disease by Two Years

Content: When scientists tested people for a genetic mutation that increases the risk for colon cancer, they thought that telling people of their increased risk would encourage them to get the recommended screening. They were wrong.
Title: Knowing Cancer Risk May Not Affect Screening Rates

Content: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new life-prolonging drug for men with late-stage prostate cancer on Friday, adding to an increasingly crowded field.
Title: New Drug For Prostate Cancer Gets F.D.A. Nod

Content: CHICAGO â Women with early-stage breast cancer could benefit from taking an estrogen-suppressing drug for 10 years rather than the standard five, researchers reported here on Sunday, citing the results of a new study.
Title: Extending Estrogen Suppressor May Aid Breast Cancer Patients, Study Says

Content: HOUSTON â Ronald DePinho, the president of the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center, part of the University of Texas, becomes animated when he talks about his ambitious plans in leading the instituteâs efforts to combat the disease.
Title: Leader of Cancer Center Works on Changes After Feedback

Content: When I caught up with Nancy Borowick on Thursday morning, she was running around East Harlem shooting a neighborhood feature for AM New York, a free newspaper distributed in the subways. Earlier this week, she worked fund-raisers for a charter school and a humanitarian relief organization. She is 28, a freelance photographer, and often rises at 6 a.m. to call assignment editors at newspapers around the city looking for day work â a politician campaigning, a news conference by the mayor, a good perp walk.
Title: Side by Side, Battling Cancer and Sending Off the Bride

Content: Gov. Tom Wolf of Pennsylvania has a treatable form of prostate cancer that was âthankfully detected early,â he announced on Wednesday. He will continue to serve as governor while undergoing treatment that will last several months.
Title: Pennsylvania Governor, Tom Wolf, Says He Has Prostate Cancer

Content: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has throat cancer and will begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, he said in a note to the bankâs employees and shareholders late Tuesday.
Title: JPMorganâs Jamie Dimon Has Throat Cancer That He Calls âCurableâ

Content: Lindsey Wilkerson was given a tour when she first began working in the event and patient-liaison department at St. Jude Childrenâs Research Hospital in Memphis more than 14 years ago.
Title: Love Not Lost: Two Childhood Cancer Survivors Marry at St. Jude

Content: Taking aspirin every day may significantly reduce the risk of many cancers and prevent tumors from spreading, according to two new studies published on Tuesday.
Title: Studies Link Daily Doses of Aspirin to Reduced Risk of Cancer

Content: On a lab bench in Philadelphia sits a tiny box lined with nearly invisible nanotubes and gold. A clear plastic pipe runs through it, and a thicket of pins, each sprouting a red or blue wire, protrudes from its end. As air from the pipe wafts over the nanotubes, electrical signals surge out of the box along the wire threads. The whole apparatus is situated near a vial of blood, âsniffingâ the air above it through the pipe.
Title: What Does Cancer Smell Like?

Content: âCancer doesnât just put your life on hold,â says Suleika Jaouad, Well columnist, in a new video that documents her experiences as a 23-year-old woman with cancer. âItâs not like you get to skip back a few months and pick up exactly where you left off. I wasnât going to get my old life back.â
Title: Life, Interrupted: A Video Portrait of Cancer in Young Adulthood

Content: Should healthy women take drugs to lower their risk of breast cancer?
Title: Breast Cancer Drugs Urged for Healthy High-Risk Women

Content: Noreen Fraser, a television producer who used her broadcasting skills to raise money and public awareness in a national campaign against breast cancer, died on Monday at her home in Brentwood, Calif., more than 15 years after she learned she had the disease. She was 63.
Title: Noreen Fraser, Who Led a Public Fight Against Cancer, Dies at 63
