Content: When Nancy M. Cappello learned that she had breast cancer, and that mammography could not find it, she turned her misfortune into a tireless campaign that led 36 states to require fuller disclosure to women about their mammogram results and the limitations of the test.
Title: Nancy Cappello, Breast Cancer Activist, Is Dead at 66

Content: Over the weekend, I heard from a New York Times picture editor, Soo-Jeong Kang, who was involved in the publication of a photograph that generated a great deal of discussion when it appeared on The Timesâs front page (PDF) last Wednesday. Ms. Kang assigned the photo shoot that resulted in that much-discussed image of an Israeli womanâs upper torso, including incision scars, a portion of her areola and her Star of David tattoo. It did not show her face.
Title: The Woman in the Breast Cancer Photo Responds to Times Readers

Content: TOKYO â More than seven years after a devastating earthquake and tsunami caused meltdowns at a nuclear power plant in Fukushima, Japan acknowledged for the first time this week that a worker died from cancer after being exposed to radiation.
Title: In a First, Japan Says Fukushima Radiation Caused Workerâs Cancer Death

Content: Many men 75 years and older, who are far more likely to be harmed than helped by prostate cancer screening, continue to be tested for the disease, despite federal guidelines strongly advising against the practice.
Title: Older Men Still Being Screened for Prostate Cancer

Content: Dr. Alan S. Rabson, who helped define the field of cancer pathology, who figured out why shingles and recurrent cold sores occur, and who helped lead the National Cancer Institute into new eras over several decades, died on July 4 in Skillman, N.J. He was 92.
Title: Dr. Alan S. Rabson, Influential Cancer Researcher, Is Dead at 92

Content: FLORENCE, Italy â The black-and-white checkered floor of the taxi looks a bit like home flooring. The seats are yellow, purple and orange leather, while the pea-green interiors are plastered with daisy stickers. When riding in the cab, passengers can play with plastic swords and a megaphone, or make soap bubbles.
Title: âTaxi Therapyâ for Young Cancer Patients in Italy

Content: Dr. Peter C. Nowell, who with a colleague discovered the first genetic defect proven to cause cancer, died on Dec. 26 in Newtown Square, Pa. He was 88.
Title: Dr. Peter Nowell, Who Helped Transform Cancer Research, Dies at 88

Content: If anything about my mother was conventional, it was the smoking. Like many of her generation she smoked early and often, and I swear she waited to light up until we were hermetically sealed in our familyâs Ford Country Squire. My brother, sister and I hated it â we tried over and over to get her to quit. She made some attempts: Patches and gum, even hypnosis by a Russian. She had some short-term successes, but soon enough I could smell the smoke on her breath or see the burnt-out butts hidden in her desk drawer ashtray.
Title: After a Cancer Diagnosis, Reversing Roles With My Mother

Content: VATICAN CITY â Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. came to this tiny city-state to talk about two of his deepest passions: his Roman Catholic faith and curing cancer.
Title: Joe Biden Speaks About Faith and Curing Cancer at the Vatican

Content: New research strongly suggests that the HPV vaccine works.
Title: Will Parents Still Turn Down an âAnti-Cancer Vaccineâ?

Content: A mother stands in front of my camera. âI donât know what Iâm supposed to do,â she says anxiously, so she smiles stiffly, as you might in a school picture. âJust be yourself,â I encourage. When she leaves my makeshift studio, set up at the Prudential Center in Boston for the occasion, I feel Iâve failed. The images reveal nothing about how she was feeling. Instead, Iâve taken a smiling portrait of a woman with no indication that she was about to undergo a serious, emotional transformation.
Title: To Aid Childrenâs Cancer Care, Mothers Go Bald

Content: âThe world is not a wish-granting factory.â That line, from âThe Fault in Our Stars,â is undoubtedly true, and it is also true that the movie, like the book before it, is an expertly built machine for the mass production of tears. Directed by Josh Boone (âStuck in Loveâ) with scrupulous respect for John Greenâs best-selling young-adult novel, the film sets out to make you weep â not just sniffle or choke up a little, but sob until your nose runs and your face turns blotchy. It succeeds.
Title: Young Love, Complicated by Cancer

Content: Michael Olexa, a patient with terminal cancer whose marriage to Angela Sclafani was the subject of a Vows column in The New York Times on Sunday, died on Wednesday in Perth Amboy, N.J. He was 42.
Title: Michael Olexa, Newlywed Truck Driver Who Had Cancer, Dies at 42

Content: YONKERS â Miguel Ramosâs mother, Mirna, set off for the United States when he was almost 4. She was both running away from a violent domestic situation and running toward the same opportunities that have drawn generations of immigrants toward Americaâs borders.
Title: Mother and Son Reunite Only to Face Her Cancer Diagnosis

Content: In 2010, Dr. Pamela Munster mailed her saliva to 23andMe, a relatively new DNA testing company, and later opted in for a BRCA test. As an oncologist, she knew a mutation of this gene would put her at high risk for breast and ovarian cancer. She was relieved by the negative result.
Title: Donât Count on 23andMe to Detect Most Breast Cancer Risks, Study Warns

Content: As fears grow among residents of Chinaâs cities that heavy air pollution is contributing to a rise in lung cancer, a major conference on the disease over the weekend in Beijing focused on a more familiar culprit: smoking.
Title: Role of Smoking Cited in Chinaâs Rising Lung Cancer Deaths

Content: The woman was terminally ill with advanced cancer, and the oncologist who had been treating her for three years thought the next step might be to deliver chemotherapy directly to her brain. It was a risky treatment that he knew would not, could not, help her.
Title: Aiding the Doctor Who Feels Cancerâs Toll

Content: Last year, one of my best friends learned he had cancer.
Title: My Friendâs Cancer Taught Me About a Hole in Our Health System

Content: Women who rely on birth control pills or contraceptive devices that release hormones face a small but significant increase in the risk for breast cancer, according to a large study published on Wednesday.
Title: Birth Control Pills Still Linked to Breast Cancer, Study Finds

Content: Dr. Lee W. Wattenberg, a medical researcher who helped jump-start the field of cancer prevention, finding weapons in the food people eat â including chemical compounds in broccoli, cabbage, coffee and garlic â died on Dec. 9 in Minneapolis. He was 92.
Title: Lee W. Wattenberg, Who Saw Cancer Fighters in Foods, Dies at 92

Content: Human rights groups, supporters and legal teams who have worked for the rights of the so-called Angola 3 prisoners over the years welcomed on Wednesday the release of one of the men, Herman Wallace, who has advanced liver cancer. He had served decades in solitary confinement in Louisiana prisons.
Title: Another âAngola 3â Prisoner, With Cancer, Is Released

Content: One in three breast cancer patients under 45 removed the healthy breast along with the breast affected by cancer in 2012, a sharp increase from the one in 10 younger women with breast cancer who had double mastectomies eight years earlier, a new study reports.
Title: More Women With Breast Cancer Opt to Remove Healthy Breast

Content: The story of modern cancer research begins, somewhat improbably, with the sea urchin. In the first decade of the 20th century, the German biologist Theodor Boveri discovered that if he fertilized sea-urchin eggs with two sperm rather than one, some of the cells would end up with the wrong number of chromosomes and fail to develop properly. It was the era before modern genetics, but Boveri was aware that cancer cells, like the deformed sea urchin cells, had abnormal chromosomes; whatever caused cancer, he surmised, had something to do with chromosomes.
Title: An Old Idea, Revived: Starve Cancer to Death

Content: Gabriele Grunewald, the elite runner who gained the support of thousands of followers on social media for her perseverance in competing while facing a rare metastatic cancer, died on Tuesday in Minneapolis. She was 32.
Title: Gabriele Grunewald, Runner Who Chronicled Journey With Cancer, Dies at 32

Content: In 2012, a study published in Health Affairs argued that the big money we spend on health care in the United States is worth it, at least when it comes to cancer. The researchers found that the survival gains seen in the United States equated to more than $550 billion in additional value, more than the difference in spending.
Title: Why Survival Rate Is Not the Best Way to Judge Cancer Spending

Content: âWithout the experience of cancer, I might not have taken the time to be an ice climber, risked being a sculptor or upended my life to move closer to my granddaughter,â writes Amy, of Baltimore, one of hundreds of women and men around the world who tell their stories on the Faces of Breast Cancer project â The New York Timesâs newly redesigned and enhanced interactive feature for those whose lives have been touched by the disease.
Title: Faces of Breast Cancer: Find Your Story, Join the Conversation

Content: Some people see it as the holy grail in oncology â a simple blood test that can detect any kind of cancer at an early stage, when it is easiest to treat and possibly cure.
Title: Illumina Creating Company to Develop Early-Stage Cancer Detection Test

Content: Researchers have found that a diagnosis of cancer in a high-profile person sharply increases efforts to quit smoking.
Title: Celebrity Cancer Diagnosis Spurs Smokers to Try to Quit

Content: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Well reporter Roni Caryn Rabin reflects on why the women whom she and photographer BÃ©atrice de GÃ©a featured in a recent story about âgoing flatâ after mastectomies were surprisingly eager to reveal themselves to the world.
Title: The Women Who Showed Their Breast Cancer Scars

Content: U.S. President Barack Obama addresses the United Nations General Assembly, laying out his case for tackling "the cancer of violent extremism." Rough Cut (no reporter narration).
Title: Obama targets "cancer of violent extremism" in UN address

Content: Japanese companiesâ overseas shopping sprees tend to be overpriced. Takeda Pharmaceutical is the latest acquirer to pay over the odds. Takeda, a $34 billion drug maker, is spending $5.2 billion, a 75 percent premium, for Ariad Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company with a middling cancer drug.
Title: Takedaâs Bid for Cancer Drug Maker Looks Expensive

Content: A federal advisory committee cleared the way on Thursday for the first approval of a cancer drug that would be used to treat patients before surgery to remove their tumors.
Title: F.D.A. Panel Backs Pre-Surgery Drug for Breast Cancer

Content: ALBANY â Sandra Lee, the television host and longtime girlfriend of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, said on Tuesday that she has breast cancer and would undergo a double mastectomy this week.
Title: Sandra Lee, TV Host and Gov. Cuomoâs Girlfriend, Has Breast Cancer

Content: The stars may have been shining in Berkeley that late summerâs night, but I couldnât see them. I was doubled over in my backyard, puking, with the gut-searing spasms of a chemo patient.
Title: After a Cancer Diagnosis, Learning to Let Go

Content: WASHINGTON â Senator John McCain, the 2008 Republican presidential nominee known for his independent streak over more than three decades representing Arizona in the Senate, has brain cancer, his office disclosed Wednesday night in a statement from the Mayo Clinic.
Title: John McCain Has Brain Cancer, Senatorâs Office Says

Content: Answers to a few questions about a report that linked colorectal cancer to the consumption of processed meats and red meat.
Title: Meat and Cancer: The W.H.O. Report and What You Need to Know

Content: You donât think twice about getting multiple bids for a construction or plumbing project, so why hesitate on multiple âbidsâ for your health?
Title: Love Your Cancer Doctor? Get a Second Opinion

Content: A drug that fights inflammation can reduce the risk of heart attacks and strokes, and possibly lung cancer, in people who have already had one heart attack and are at high risk for another, a new study finds.
Title: Drug Aimed at Inflammation May Lower Risk of Heart Disease and Cancer

Content: It was just a tiny speck, a single cell that researchers had marked with a fluorescent green dye. But it was the very first cell of what would grow to be a melanoma, the deadliest form of skin cancer. Never before had researchers captured a cancer so early.
Title: A Single Cell Shines New Light on How Cancers Develop

Content: SAN DIEGO â On the two driving holes Thursday on Torrey Pinesâ North Course â the 434-yard par-4 fourth and the 547-yard par-5 ninth â Bubba Watsonâs shots off the tees traveled 314 and 370 yards. His booming drives are a boon for the âBubba & Friends: Drive to a Millionâ charity campaign he started this week.
Title: With Every Big Drive, Watson Helps Fight Cancer

Content: A New Jersey jury ruled unanimously for Johnson & Johnson on Wednesday in the latest lawsuit to reach a verdict over accusations that the companyâs talc-based powder products contained asbestos and caused a consumerâs cancer.
Title: Johnson & Johnson Cleared by New Jersey Jury in Latest Talc Cancer Trial

Content: Warren E. Buffett disclosed on Tuesday that he had prostate cancer, a development that would probably heighten the questions over his successor as the chief executive of his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway.
Title: Revealing Prostate Cancer, Buffett Plays Down Effect

Content: Folic acid enrichment of grain products has significantly reduced the rates of neural tube defects in infants. Now a new study suggests a further possible benefit: a reduction in rates of two types of childhood cancer.
Title: Folic Acid Tied to Lower Rate of Two Childhood Cancers

Content: The scene is a wild cocktail party in Washington at the tail end of the Kennedy administration. Our innocent young narrator, new to the rituals of power, watches in fascination as one of his superiors dances by with a half-undressed woman slung over a shoulder. By the end of the evening, he has helped hoist another of his bosses, dead drunk, out of a bathtub.
Title: Review: Science and Politics Collide in âThe Death of Cancerâ

Content: WASHINGTON â The nationâs top doctor called on Tuesday for immediate action to reduce the rate of skin cancer, the most commonly diagnosed cancer in the country and one that is often preventable.
Title: Surgeon General Calls for Action to Reduce Skin Cancer Rate

Content: Children are dying less often from cancer, with substantial declines in all races and age groups, according to a new report from the National Center for Health Statistics.
Title: Cancer in Retreat on One Front: Fewer Children Are Dying

Content: BEIJING â China has many dedicated oncologists who care deeply about their patients, and as cancer rates rise â partly as the result of environmental pollution, but also because of factors like an aging society â they have their work cut out for them.
Title: In China, Questions About Cancer Care as Rates Rise

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Fats, Bones and Surviving Cancer

Content: Six months after the federal government added cancer to the list of sicknesses covered by the $4.3 billion World Trade Center fund, a New York City health department study has found no clear link between cancer and the dust, debris and fumes released by the burning wreckage of the twin towers.
Title: No Clear Link Between Cancer and 9/11 Debris, Study Finds

Content: Earlier this week, an influential medical panel issued new draft recommendations about taking aspirin to prevent heart disease and colon cancer. It was the first time a major medical organization has recommended using low-dose aspirin to ward off a type of cancer, but the guidelines from the United States Preventive Services Task Force arenât for everyone. Here are answers to some of the questions people are asking.
Title: Answering Your Questions About Aspirin, Heart Attack and Colon Cancer

Content: CHICAGO â New drugs that boost the immune systemâs ability to fight tumors may be one of the greatest medical advances in years, cancer doctors say, pulling some patients from deathâs door and keeping them in remission for years.
Title: Doctors Seek Test for Deploying New Life-Extending Cancer Drugs

Content: A new report suggests that breast-feeding, which has been associated with a reduced breast cancer risk, may have another benefit. In mothers who later develop breast cancer, breast-feeding may reduce the risk of cancer recurrence.
Title: Breast-Feeding May Cut Breast Cancer Recurrence Risk

Content: Dr. Kenneth A. Forde, a pioneering surgeon who helped educate the public about cancer risks by performing a colonoscopy on Katie Couric that was later televised, died on June 2 at his home in Scarborough, N.Y. He was 85.
Title: Dr. Kenneth Forde, Surgeon Who Fostered Cancer Screening, Dies at 85

Content: This article was reported and written in a collaboration with ProPublica, the nonprofit journalism organization.
Title: Cancer Centerâs Board Chairman Faults Top Doctor Over âCrossed Linesâ

Content: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. â Shortly after Nancy Borowickâs boyfriend got down on one knee and popped the question, she began to worry about the wedding. If everything had been normal, Ms. Borowick and her husband-to-be, Kyle Grimm, would have waited a year, until the spring of 2014. Sheâs 28, heâs 27 and they would have liked the extra time to build their careers and get used to living together. Ms. Borowick works as a freelance photographer and is often up by 6 a.m., calling newspaper photo desks around the city in hopes of getting an assignment. Mr. Grimm is a junior lawyer at a corporate firm who is already married, to his job.
Title: In Sickness and in Health: A Wedding in the Shadow of Cancer

Content: In retrospect, I should have taken a last look at the nose I was born with. This was on the first Wednesday of November in 2011, the day of a scheduled appointment with a dermatological surgeon for Mohs micrographic surgery, the purpose of which was to carefully remove some previously discovered skin cancer from the lower left side of my nose. But it was also the fourth day after a surprise autumn snowstorm that had left our home in north central Connecticut without heat or electricity and the surrounding landscape devastated by thousands of fallen trees. On the morning of my procedure I washed my hair and sponged my body with a few quarts of water heated in a stockpot on a gas barbecue grill outside the house, threw on some clothes and rushed out the door. The entire exercise felt like an inconvenience. Looking back, taking proper care of my freckled, reddish skin, descended from somewhere on the moors of Ireland, had always felt like an inconvenience.
Title: For a Boomer,  Sunscreens Came Late and Cancer Too Soon

Content: Powerful drugs that enlist the immune system to fight cancer can, in rare cases, cause heart damage, doctors are reporting.
Title: Lifesaving Cancer Drugs May in Rare Cases Threaten the Heart

Content: HANOVER, N.H. â A COUPLE of months ago, JAMA Internal Medicine, a journal of the American Medical Association, published the findings of a brief online survey of middle-aged Americans.Most had previously been screened for either breast or prostate cancer. But the study found that about half said they would not choose to start screening if the test resulted in more than one overtreated person per one cancer death averted.
Title: Breast Cancer Screenings: What We Still Donât Know

Content: The news about Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburgâs operation for two cancerous lung nodules is encouraging but incomplete.
Title: Cancer Doctors See Encouraging Signs for Ruth Bader Ginsburg

Content: A drug that can slow the progression of advanced breast cancer has been shown for the first time to lengthen survival in women whose disease started before or during menopause, researchers reported on Saturday.
Title: A Drug Prolonged Life in Younger Women With Advanced Breast Cancer

Content: It is National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and the disease is a major cause of the cosmetics industry. Here are some products intended to raise awareness and some money.Â
Title: Cosmetics Sending Some Money Toward Breast Cancer Causes

Content: Studies have shown that the use of oral contraceptives lowers the risk for endometrial cancer, and now a new study has found that the protection continues for many years after women stop using them.
Title: Contraceptives May Lower Endometrial Cancer Risk Long-Term

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Cellphones, Cancer and Broken-Heart Syndrome

Content: A half-century ago, when researchers said cancers were caused by exposure to toxins in the environment, Dr. Henry T. Lynch begged to differ.
Title: Dr. Henry Lynch, 91, Dies; Found Hereditary Link in Cancer

Content: Dr. John Mendelsohn, who led the prestigious University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center through an era of substantial growth, and who, as a scientist, helped pioneer a new type of cancer therapy, died on Jan. 7 at his home in Houston. He was 82.
Title: Dr. John Mendelsohn, 82, Researcher Who Led Top Cancer Center, Dies

Content: Cancer researchers are growing increasingly enthusiastic about harnessing the bodyâs own immune system to fight tumors. And new research shows that two drugs that use this approach may be even better than one.
Title: Melanoma Treatment Harnesses Immune System to Combat Cancer Cells

Content: KAMPALA, UGANDA â Dr. Henry Ddungu held the hand of a thin, frail-looking woman as he led her into the outpatient clinic at the Uganda Cancer Institute. Scowling, he said, âwe are having an epidemic of breast cancer and pain.â
Title: Ugandaâs Neglected Epidemic of Breast Cancer

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Cancer, Alzheimer's and Vitamins Gone Gummy

Content: An eagerly awaited federal ruling on whether to include cancer among the illnesses that will be treated and result in compensation using money set aside by Congress for victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center has been delayed by several days, federal officials said Tuesday.
Title: Ruling Delayed on Adding Cancer to 9/11 Fund Illnesses

Content: I used to believe that a mammogram saved my life. I even wrote that in the pages of this magazine. It was 1996, and I had just turned 35 when my doctor sent me for an initial screening â a relatively common practice at the time â that would serve as a base line when I began annual mammograms at 40. I had no family history of breast cancer, no particular risk factors for the disease.
Title: Our Feel-Good War on Breast Cancer

Content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Hereâs the sign-up.)
Title: Your Friday Briefing: Syria, China, Breast Cancer

Content: A tumor, as strange as it may sound, is a little society. The cancer cells that make it up cooperate with one another, and together they thrive.
Title: In the Way Cancer Cells Work Together, a Possible Tool for Their Demise

Content: A new study offers a glint of hope to people in a desperate situation: Patients with melanoma, the most serious form of skin cancer, that has spread to the brain.
Title: Immunotherapy Drugs Slow Skin Cancer That Has Spread to the Brain

Content: A new study offers a glint of hope to people in a desperate situation: Patients with melanoma, the most serious form of skin cancer, that has spread to the brain.
Title: Immunotherapy Drugs Slow Skin Cancer That Has Spread to the Brain

Content: In the months after Karen Watson learned she had breast cancer, she tried to shield her three daughters from the daily pain and uncertainty she was living with.
Title: Seizing a Second Chance After a Bout With Cancer

Content: By this point, most football fans have probably noticed the N.F.L.âs pink theme â including everything from socks to towels to the refereeâs whistle â that is in place as part of Octoberâs National Breast Cancer Awareness month.
Title: A New Twist to N.F.L. Breast Cancer Awareness: A Pink Tutu

Content: Dr. Renato Dulbecco, a virologist who shared a Nobel Prize in 1975 for his role in drawing a link between genetic mutations and cancer, died on Sunday at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He would have turned 98 on Wednesday.
Title: Renato Dulbecco, 97, Dies; Won Prize for Cancer Study

Content: Sometimes cancer and its treatments make me feel as if I have entered a time machine that accelerates aging.
Title: Living With Cancer: Feeling Older Than My Age

Content: At diagnosis, quite a few cancer patients spy Eros rushing out the door. I know I did. For some, eroticism vanishes during or after treatment. Anhedonia, the inability to feel pleasure, can afflict both men and women with cancer. We often get more help from one another than from the medical specialists who are beginning to address this challenge.
Title: Sex After Cancer

Content: Iâm trying to put into words how I feel nothing about the knowledge that I am going to get cancer.
Title: Thereâs Cancer In My Future. How Am I Supposed to Feel?

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Organic Food, Risky Weather and Cancer

Content: Researchers have made new discoveries about the in-between spaces in the human body, and some say itâs time to rewrite the anatomy books.
Title: Is This Tissue a New Organ? Maybe. A Conduit for Cancer? It Seems Likely.

Content: Women with a false positive mammogram or breast biopsy result have an increased risk of breast cancer over the next 10 years compared with those with a true negative result, a new report has found.
Title: False Positive Breast Tests Tied to Increased Cancer Risk

Content: Robin Gibb, one of the three singing brothers of the Bee Gees, the long-running Anglo-Australian pop group whose chirping falsettos and hook-laden disco hits like âJive Talkinâ and âYou Should Be Dancingâ shot them to worldwide fame in the 1970s, died on Sunday. He was 62.
Title: Robin Gibb of the Bee Gees Dies of Cancer at 62

Content: Harvard Medical School sends out an email when an esteemed faculty member passes away, and more often than not I delete it without clicking. I feel shame for not taking the time to read about the death of colleague whose life was devoted to medicine or science, but I do think about death a lot for someone my age â perhaps too much.
Title: Chasing My Shadow as a Cancer Patient in Talk Therapy

Content: Coffee sellers are mulling how to fight a California judgeâs ruling that would require the beverage to be branded with cancer warning labels.
Title: Coffee Drinkers Need Cancer Warning, Judge Rules, Giving Sellers the Jitters

Content: Adding a newer test to digital mammograms can increase the detection rate for breast cancer and decrease nerve-racking false alarms, in which suspicious findings lead women to get extra scans that turn out normal, a study found.
Title: 3-D Mammography Test Appears to Improve Breast Cancer Detection Rate

Content: A diagnosis of breast cancer at age 27 is shattering for anyone. But for Eli Oberman, it came with extra layers of anxiety. He is a transgender man, who was born female but began taking male hormones when he was 19 to change gender.
Title: Living as a Man, Fighting Breast Cancer: How Trans People Face Care Gaps

Content: After Diana Colbert died of leukemia in 2011, her husband, the novelist Charles Bock, began reading through the journals she kept when she was sick. Ms. Colbert had hoped to write an inspirational book about her experience, and she took notes while she was undergoing grueling chemotherapy and transplant procedures, often through the haze of medication.
Title: In Charles Bockâs âAlice & Oliver,â Cancer Is a Highly Personal Villain

Content: Getting a positive mammogram result, then learning on follow-up that nothing is really wrong, is good news. But a false positive mammogram has a dangerous downside: It may reduce the likelihood that a woman returns for later screenings, increasing her risk for a late-stage cancer.
Title: Mammogram Results Can Be Misleading

Content: The Lasker awards, among the most respected prizes in medicine, will go to three scientists who made groundbreaking discoveries in cancer and genetics, and to the aid group Doctors Without Borders, the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation announced Tuesday.
Title: Lasker Prizes Given for Discoveries in Cancer and Genetics, and for Ebola Response

Content: Researchers studying two seemingly unrelated conditions â autism and cancer â have unexpectedly converged on a surprising discovery. Some people with autism have mutated cancer or tumor genes that apparently caused their brain disorder.
Title: Autismâs Unexpected Link to Cancer Genes

Content: Matthew Knowles, the father of the artists BeyoncÃ© and Solange, recently announced that he had been told that he has a breast cancer caused by a BRCA2 gene mutation and that his children have a 50 percent chance of inheriting it.
Title: BeyoncÃ©âs Dad Has a Mutation More African-Americans Should Be Tested For

Content: BEIJING â Liu Xiaobo, the jailed Chinese dissident who received the Nobel Peace Prize for his writings promoting democracy, has been given medical parole to be treated for late-stage cancer, his lawyers and the prison authorities said on Monday.
Title: Liu Xiaobo, Chinese Nobel Laureate, Leaves Prison for Cancer Care

Content: AbbVie announced late Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Pharmacyclics, maker of a cancer drug that some analysts predict will eventually become one of the best-selling treatments for the disease, for about $21 billion.
Title: AbbVie to Pay $21 Billion for Pharmacyclics, Maker of a Promising Cancer Drug

Content: Fleetwood Mac announced on its Facebook page on Sunday that it was canceling a monthlong, 14-concert tour of New Zealand and Australia, set to start Nov. 10, because its bassist, John McVie, was scheduled to undergo cancer treatment during that period. The statement did not say what form of cancer the 67-year-old Mr. McVie had, and Liz Rosenberg, the groupâs spokeswoman, said she had no further information.
Title: Fleetwood Mac Cancels Tour as John McVie Undergoes Cancer Treatment

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Weight Loss, Memory and a Cancer Cure

Content: When Rhonda Beyâs appendiceal cancer did not respond to typical treatments, her doctor turned to genomic testing. Her cancerâs DNA revealed what was driving the growth of the tumor. FoundationOneÂ®, FoundationOneÂ®Heme, and FoundationOne CDxâ¢ are diagnostic tests to identify genomic mutations associated with your cancer. This information, along with other information, may be used by your physician to identify potential treatment options. But these diagnostic tests do not confer any therapeutic benefit. The tests might not identify therapies that could be of benefit to you and you might not have positive outcomes with therapies identified through these tests. The outcomes described in this video are not typical and you should not expect to experience similar results. Consult your doctor about whether diagnostic testing is appropriate for you. Treatment decisions are the responsibility of your physician. These tests are available by prescription only. FoundationOne CDxâ¢ is a next-generation sequencing based in vitro diagnostic device for detection of substitutions, insertion and deletion alterations, and copy number alterations in 324 genes and select gene rearrangements, as well as genomic signatures including microsatellite instability (MSI) and tumor mutational burden (TMB) using DNA isolated from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor tissue specimens. For the complete intended use statement, including companion diagnostic indications and warnings and limitations, please see the FoundationOne CDx Technical Information, www.foundationmedicine.com/f1cdx.
Title: How Decoding Cancerâs DNA Can Revolutionize Patient Treatment

Content:
We look at how far nuclear fusion has come â and how far it has yet to go; contemplating the frightful parallels between a growing embryo and a runaway tumor; what is the science behind side-splitting, tear-inducing humor?
Subscribe to the Podcast Â»
Title: Future of Fusion, Cancer as Demon Baby, Laughing for Science

Content: NAPA, Calif. â Jarrod Lyleâs caddie reached into Lyleâs golf bag after their round was over and popped a cough lozenge into his mouth. Of all the threats lurking on the Silverado course, the site of this past weekâs Frys.com Open, perhaps none pose a greater hazard to Lyle than his caddieâs sore throat.
Title: After a Cancer Battle, Golfer Fights to Regain His Form

Content: A federal jury on Wednesday ordered Monsanto to pay more than $80 million in damages to a California man whose cancer it determined was partly caused by his use of the popular weedkiller Roundup.
Title: Monsanto Ordered to Pay $80 Million in Roundup Cancer Case

Content: Many Times readers were disturbed and offended by the front-page photograph of an Israeli womanâs upper torso in Wednesdayâs newspaper. It was the dominant image on the page, and it accompanied an article in a series called âThe Cancer Divide,â which is examining âhow the treatment of breast cancer is shaped by wealth and poverty, culture and values.â
Title: A âPowerfulâ Image of Breast Cancer Offends Some Times Readers

Content: Siddhartha Mukherjee, whoseÂ article on depression appears in this weekâs health issue, is an assistant professor of medicine in the division of medical oncology at Columbia University. His book, âThe Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer,â a portion of which was adapted in the magazine as âThe Cancer Sleeper Cell,â won the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in general nonfiction. Mukherjee has also written for the magazine on whether the use of cellphones can cause cancer.
Title: Behind the Story: A Cancer Doctor on Depression and the Possible Next Antidepressant

Content: Breast implants made by Allergan that have been linked to an uncommon form of cancer are being taken off the market in Europe, French authorities announced on Tuesday.
Title: Allergan Halts Sales in Europe of Textured Breast Implants Linked to Rare Cancer

Content: Men whose prostate cancer comes back after surgery are more likely to survive if, along with the usual radiation, they also take drugs to block male hormones.
Title: Hormone Blockers Can Prolong Life if Prostate Cancer Recurs

Content: When Angela Durden found out that she had tested positive for the breast cancer gene mutation, she decided to share the information with her daughter, Alexis, who was 14 at the time. That meant telling the teenager about her own future risk â that she had a 50 percent chance of carrying a mutation that had already riddled their extended family â both male and female â with the disease.
Title: When to Tell Daughters About a Genetic Breast Cancer Risk

Content: If you are dealt a crummy hand, you might find yourself playing the cancer card â even if other people object. Iâve come to believe that in certain cases, I not only could but should play the C card.
Title: Living With Cancer: Playing the C Card

Content: BEIJING â Liu Xiaobo, the political prisoner and Nobel laureate who is on medical parole in a Chinese hospital to treat late-stage liver cancer, is fit to travel abroad to receive medical care, doctors from the United States and Germany said on Sunday.
Title: Doctors Say Chinese Dissident Is Fit to Travel for Cancer Treatment

Content: CHICAGO â Two new studies have found that the widely used cancer drug Avastin does not prolong the lives of patients with a deadly form of brain cancer, raising questions about the role of the drug in treating that disease.
Title: Two Studies Challenge Avastinâs Effectiveness Against a Rare Brain Cancer

Content: Women of Ashkenazi Jewish descent who tested positive for cancer-causing genetic mutations during random screenings have high rates of breast and ovarian cancer even when they have no family history of the disease, researchers reported Thursday.
Title: Study of Jewish Women Shows Link to Cancer Without Family History

Content: WASHINGTON â The Food and Drug Administration on Friday proposed barring everyone under 18 from using tanning beds, a sweeping move that medical experts say is a major step toward reducing the risk of skin cancer in the United States.
Title: F.D.A. Proposes Ban on Indoor Tanning for Minors to Fight Skin Cancer

Content: Nancy Borowickâs parents were receiving chemotherapy together when she realized all she wanted on her wedding day was to have them walk her down the aisle, together.
Title: Side by Side, Battling Cancer and Sending Off the Bride

Content: As filmmaking has become technologically easier, more and more documentaries have sprung up that chronicle personal loss: a loved oneâs struggle with cancer or dementia, for instance. âThank You for Playingâ isnât as coherent and impactful as the best of these films, but itâs certainly unusual.
Title: Review: âThank You for Playingâ Is About Making âThat Dragon, Cancerâ

Content: In 2011, a year after my husband Richard died of lung cancer, a major national study documented the potential ability to detect this disease when it might still be amenable to cure.
Title: For Lung Cancer Screening, a Small Dose of Hope

Content: A Neanderthal who lived more than 120,000 years ago had a tumor in a bone, the earliest of its kind in the human fossil record, a new study reports. The tumor, which was discovered in the rib of a Neanderthal specimen found in present-day Croatia, is described in the journal PLoS One.
Title: 120,000 Years of Tumors

Content: In a leap forward in understanding the basic science of one of the most lethal cancers, two groups of researchers have found mutations in most melanomas that are unlike any they have seen before in cancer. The changes are in regions that control genes, not in the genes themselves. The mutations are exactly the type caused by exposure to ultraviolet light, indicating they might be among the first DNA changes in a cellâs path to melanoma.
Title: Mutations Found in Melanomas May Shed Light on How Cancers Grow

Content: Dean Baquet, the executive editor of The New York Times, had a malignant tumor removed from his kidney on Saturday and will spend about a week away from the office while recovering, he said in an email to the newspaperâs staff on Monday morning.
Title: Executive Editor of The New York Times Is Treated for Cancer

Content: Marc Rybczyk admits that before he met Aloysia Jaques in January 2014, he had some misguided ideas about womenâs basketball.
Title: The Coachesâ Game Plan: Beat Cancer, Get Married

Content: The news that Senator John McCain has brain cancer appears â at least momentarily â to have unified sharply divided Republican and Democratic politicians in support of a man some praised on Wednesday night as an âAmerican hero.â
Title: Lawmakers Unite in Support for John McCain After Cancer Diagnosis

Content: Exercise could improve the life expectancy of adults who survive cancer as children, even if the activity begins years after treatments end, according to an inspiring new study.
Title: For Survivors of Childhood Cancer, Walk

Content: ANNAPOLIS, Md. â Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland, a little-known former real estate executive whose upset victory in November thrust this overwhelmingly Democratic state into Republican hands for the first time in nearly a decade, announced Monday that he had a âvery advancedâ cancer of the lymphatic system but would continue to serve while undergoing treatment.
Title: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland to Stay in Office While âAdvancedâ Cancer Is Treated

Content: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this story, the science reporter Denise Grady provides human backstory about her  article about a woman who, remarkably, recovered from colon cancer after treatment with cells from her own immune system.
Title: Cancer-Free: One Recovery Inspires Another â and Could Help Thousands

Content: As Kathleen Emmets was undergoing cancer treatment in New York over the past few years, her weight began to drop. Even though she was often nauseated and paralyzed by chemotherapy-induced neuropathy, she joked that thinness was the âbonus of cancer,â and found herself looking in the mirror and admiring her deep and hollow collarbone.
Title: When Cancer Triggers (or Hides) an Eating Disorder

Content: VAN NUYS, Calif. â She strolled slowly through the neighborhood, a down-to-earth sprawl of sun-blasted ranch houses, and Sandra Lee was in her element.
Title: Cancer Pushes New Yorkâs âFirst Girlfriend,â Sandra Lee, Onto Political Stage

Content: Melissa Mark-Viverito, the speaker of the New York City Council, said on Friday that a biopsy had shown she was cancer-free.
Title: New York Council Speaker Says Biopsy Shows She Doesnât Have Cancer

Content: An inexpensive vitamin can help reduce the occurrence of common skin cancers in people prone to that disease, researchers reported on Wednesday.
Title: B Vitamin Is Found to Help People Prone to Some Types of Skin Cancer

Content: PANAJACHEL, Guatemala â If someone had come to her community in western Guatemala sooner to offer cervical cancer screening, perhaps Micaela Yac Jeteya, 56, wouldnât be fighting for her life. Now Yac Jeteya, a mother of six whose youngest son is 16, is suffering from a disease that is both very common and highly preventable.
Title: We Have the Resources to Prevent Cervical Cancer. Do We Have the Will?

Content: Thousands of women across the country are suing the consumer goods giant Johnson & Johnson over its baby powder, claiming that talcum particles in the popular product caused their ovarian cancer.
Title: Risk on All Sides as 4,800 Women Sue Over Johnsonâs Baby Powder and Cancer

Content: Andrew Levyâs parents knew that the rare and deadly cancer in his blood could not be beaten, so they began to prepare for the worst. Then something mysterious happened.
Title: When Do You Give Up on Treating a Child With Cancer?

Content: Ken Thompson, the Brooklyn district attorney, said on Tuesday that he had recently learned he has cancer and would take a sick leave.
Title: Ken Thompson, Brooklyn District Attorney, Says He Has Cancer and Will Take Leave

Content: Johnson & Johnson said Thursday that its new drug for prostate cancer was effective when used earlier during treatment than it is now, potentially broadening its use and also posing a competitive threat to a rival drug, Dendreonâs Provenge.
Title: Trial Shows Benefit in Using Prostate Cancer Drug Early

Content: Good morning.
Title: California Today: Cancer Worries Over a Common Weedkiller

Content: Alex Trebek, the longtime host of âJeopardy!,â appeared on âGood Morning Americaâ on Wednesday for a frank interview about his experience with Stage 4 pancreatic cancer, including his struggle with depression during chemotherapy.
Title: Alex Trebek Talks Cancer and Depression: âI Just Take It as It Comesâ

Content: Ten years ago, David Jones stopped working so he could look after his son, who has autism and needed constant care.

Content: They treaded water for seven hours before a neighbor heard their screams.
Title: âTo Hell and Backâ as a Cancer Survivor, Storm Victim and Caregiver

Content: Sport has no refuge from two possibly related human conditions: stress and sickness.
Title: Dealing With Cancer Amid Elite Soccerâs Pressure Cooker

Content: (Reuters) - AstraZeneca Plc said on Tuesday it would start a clinical trial of its cancer drug Calquence to assess its potential to control the exaggerated immune system response associated with COVID-19 infection in severely ill patients.
Title: AstraZeneca to Test Impact of Cancer Drug Calquence on Coronavirus Patients

Content: When Tracy Dunbrook, a bioethicist in Sherman, Conn., tested positive for the BRCA gene mutation, she was told she had a 40 to 60 percent chance of developing ovarian cancer in her lifetime. Doctors advised her to have her ovaries removed.
Title: Weighing Surgeries in Light of a Breast Cancer Gene

Content: WASHINGTON â There are two foes capable of bringing together members of Congress: breast cancer and the press.
Title: Women of Congress and the Press Battle Breast Cancer, and for Bragging Rights

Content: Concerns are increasing among doctors about the safety of a procedure performed on tens of thousands of women a year in the United States who undergo surgery to remove fibroid tumors from the uterus, or to remove the entire uterus.
Title: Uterine Surgical Technique Is Linked to Abnormal Growths and Cancer Spread

Content: Dr. Frederick P. Li, who helped prove to a doubting medical establishment that heredity and genetics play a major role in some forms of cancer, died on June 12 at his home in Brookline, Mass. He was 75.
Title: Frederick P. Li, Who Proved a Genetic Cancer Link, Dies at 75

Content: What does it really cost to bring a drug to market?
Title: What Does It Cost to Create a Cancer Drug? Less Than Youâd Think

Content: CHICAGO â Taking periodic breaks from a commonly used treatment for prostate cancer could shorten menâs lives, researchers reported here on Saturday.
Title: Interrupting Prostate Cancer Treatment Could Shorten Life, Study Finds

Content: âI had spent the past six years going to the oncologist every three months trying to keep cancer away, and here was something I had put in my body to try to help me feel more like a woman, and it gave me cancer.â
Title: Quotation of the Day: They Got Breast Implants, Then a Rare Cancer

Content: HONG KONG â The death rate from lung cancer in the heavily industrialized province surrounding Beijing has more than quadrupled in the last four decades, with researchers pointing to worsening air pollution as a likely culprit, according to a local cancer hospital and a report published Friday in an influential Chinese news outlet.
Title: Lung Cancer Deaths Soar in Chinaâs Steel Country, Report Says

Content: PARIS â France has banned several types of textured breast implants that have been linked to a rare form of cancer.
Title: France Is First to Ban Breast Implants Linked to Rare Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON â Medicare will cover annual screenings for lung cancer for older Americans with long histories of heavy smoking, the federal government said Monday in a proposal that would cover an estimated four million people, many of whom are at greatest risk for the disease.
Title: Medicare Proposes Paying for Lung Cancer Screenings for Older Longtime Smokers

Content: In what may be the largest award so far in a lawsuit tying ovarian cancer to talcum powder, a Los Angeles jury on Monday ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $417 million in damages to a medical receptionist who developed ovarian cancer after using the companyâs trademark Johnsonâs Baby Powder on her perineum for decades.
Title: $417 Million Awarded in Suit Tying Johnsonâs Baby Powder to Cancer

Content: An 8-year-old girl in Jiangsu Province is the youngest person in China to have received a diagnosis of lung cancer, which a doctor treating her has attributed to air pollution, according to an official news report.
Title: An 8-Year-Old Girlâs Lung Cancer Is Blamed on Air Pollution

Content: Max Ritvo, an accomplished poet who spent much of his life under the cloud of cancer while gaining wide attention writing and speaking about it, died of the disease on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 25.
Title: Max Ritvo, Poet Who Chronicled His Cancer Fight, Dies at 25

Content: CHICAGO â The early success of a new class of cancer drugs, revealed in test results released here over the last several days, has raised hope among the worldâs top cancer specialists that they may be on the verge of an important milestone in the fight against the disease.
Title: Promising New Cancer Drugs Empower the Bodyâs Own Defense System

Content: Myriad Genetics, which lost a closely watched Supreme Court case last year involving the patenting of genes, has suffered another setback in its efforts to protect its main genetic test from competition.
Title: Patentholder on Breast Cancer Tests Denied Injunction in Lawsuit

Content: SAN DIEGO â Researchers say that a new type of drug can help prevent advanced breast cancer from worsening, potentially providing an important new treatment option for women and a blockbuster product for Pfizer.
Title: Guarded Optimism After Breast Cancer Drug Shows Promising Results

Content: Dr. LaSalle D. Leffall Jr., a surgeon and educator who as the first black president of the American Cancer Society was a leader in promoting awareness of the risks of cancer, particularly among African-Americans, died on May 25 in Washington. He was 89.
Title: LaSalle Leffall Jr., 89, Dies; Cancer Societyâs First Black Leader

Content: Pink ribbons have for decades been a symbol of resolve and compassion in the face of the deadly disease of breast cancer. Now, that nearly ubiquitous icon has many women seeing red.
Title: Uproar as Breast Cancer Group Ends Partnership With Planned Parenthood

Content: Dr. Janet D. Rowley, a physician who four decades ago became the first person to show a conclusive link between certain genetic abnormalities and certain cancers, died on Tuesday at her home in Chicago. She was 88.
Title: Janet D. Rowley, Who Discovered Cancer Can Be Genetic, Dies at 88

Content: WASHINGTON â Senator John McCain of Arizona, who has been battling brain cancer for more than a year, will no longer be treated for his condition, his family announced on Friday, a sign that the Republican war hero is most likely entering his final days.
Title: John McCain to Discontinue Treatment for Brain Cancer, Family Says

Content: The brutal brawl broke out in Cullenâs Tavern, a throwback under the elevated tracks in the Bronx, old and worn as a smooth backyard stump.
Title: Fighting Cancer, but Killed by âDisease of the Streetâ After Stopping a Brawl

Content: Many men with an early sign of a prostate cancer relapse can safely wait before starting hormone therapy, avoiding side effects without shortening their lives, according to the results of a study released on Wednesday.
Title: A Study on Prostate Cancer Relapses Suggests That Hormone Therapy Can Wait

Content: Charles Jencks, whose writing on architecture helped define the field after Modernism, and who put his ideas into practice both in memorable landscape architecture and in overseeing the creation of Maggieâs Centers, buildings specifically designed for cancer patients, died on Sunday at his home in London. He was 80.
Title: Charles Jencks, 80, Dies; Helped Define Postmodern Architecture

Content: After the artist Prune Nourry received a diagnosis of breast cancer in 2016 at age 31, her experiences of treatment began to inform her art. âSerendipityâ is both a document and an extension of that process â a self-portrait in which Nourry showcases past projects and explores how her artistic impulses evolved.
Title: âSerendipityâ Review: Turning a Cancer Diagnosis Into Art

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Skin, Brain Injuries and a New Cancer Treatment

Content: CHICAGO â A drug that delivers a powerful poison to tumors without some of the side effects of traditional treatments can delay the worsening of breast cancer and also appears to substantially prolong lives, according to results of a study presented here Saturday.
Title: In Study, Drug Delays Worsening of Breast Cancer, With Fewer Side Effects

Content: The final day of Englandâs Premier League season, labeled âSurvival Sundayâ by the broadcasters because clubs risk elimination from the richest league on earth, was settled by a player for whom this season has literally been about survival.
Title: Cancer Survivor Helps Newcastle Survive Relegation Threat

Content: This article was reported and written in a collaboration with ProPublica, the nonprofit investigative journalism organization.
Title: Top Sloan Kettering Cancer Doctor Resigns After Failing to Disclose Industry Ties

Content: WASHINGTON â The Obama administration has decided that Medicare will pay for one of the newest, most expensive cancer medications, which costs about $178,000 for a standard course of treatment.
Title: Medicare, Reversing Itself, Will Pay More for an Expensive New Cancer Drug

Content: Dr. Donald L. Morton, a son of an Appalachian coal miner who gained renown as a surgeon for helping to develop a widely used technique for detecting and treating certain kinds of cancer, died on Jan. 10 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 79.
Title: Dr. Donald Morton Dies at 79; Melanoma Expert Pioneered a Cancer Technique

Content: A new test can help distinguish aggressive prostate cancer from less threatening ones, potentially saving many men from unneeded operations for tumors that would never hurt them, researchers are reporting.
Title: New Test Improves Assessment of Prostate Cancer Risk, Study Says

Content: A Silicon Valley start-up with some big-name backers is threatening to upend genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer by offering a test on a sample of saliva that is so inexpensive that most women could get it, Andrew Pollack writes.
Title: Daily Report: New Genetic Tests for Breast Cancer Hold Promise

Content: Last month, you went onstage at Largo in Los Angeles and did a very unusual set. You told the audience how four months ago you contracted a life-threatening infection. Days after your release from the hospital, your mother died after a freak fall in her house. Shortly after that, you were given a diagnosis of Stage 2 breast cancer. You opened your set saying, âThank you, I have cancer, thank you.â The crowd laughed. Did they know?  I donât think a lot did, no. People were laughing, and I remember being onstage thinking, Weâre all standing on this bridge and only I know that itâs about to collapse. And it did.
Title: Tig Notaro Has Cancer. Go Ahead, Laugh.

Content: BEIJING â The Chinese authorities have refused permission for Liu Xiaobo, a Nobel Peace laureate paroled from prison for cancer treatment, to go abroad for care, one of his lawyers said on Thursday.
Title: China Wonât Let Liu Xiaobo, Nobel Laureate, Get Cancer Treatment Abroad

Content: Breast cancer is the most common cancer in American women except for skin cancers.`
Title: Researchers Predict a Quarter-Million New Cases of Breast Cancer in the U.S.

Content: Cindy Stowell had Stage 4 colon cancer when she recorded episodes of âJeopardy!â in August and September, competing on painkillers and developing a fever that caused makeup artists to rush onstage during commercial breaks to clean up her sweat.
Title: âJeopardy!â Run Ends for Cindy Stowell, Cancer-Stricken Champion

Content: Two years ago, when I was in the midst of treatment for breast cancer, Susan, a dear friend, showed up on my doorstep with a bag of yarn and two wooden needles. âI am going to teach you to knit,â she announced. âThis is what got me through my own horrible year of treatment.â
Title: Why Should Cancer Make Me Want to Knit?

Content: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, said on Tuesday in a note to the bankâs employees and shareholders that he had throat cancer and would begin treatment shortly at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, DealBookâs Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes. Doctors discovered the cancer at an early stage, Mr. Dimon said, noting that his condition was âcurable.â Moreover, he said doctors had confirmed that the cancer had not spread beyond the âoriginal siteâ and the adjacent lymph nodes on the right side of his neck. He described the prognosis from the doctors as âexcellent.â
Title: Morning Agenda: JPMorgan Chief Has âCurableâ Cancer

Content: A type of breast implant linked to a rare cancer can still be sold in the United States, even though it has been banned in many other countries, the Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday.
Title: F.D.A. Wonât Ban Sales of Textured Breast Implants Linked to Cancer

Content: For decades, health experts have struggled to determine whether or not cellphones can cause cancer. On Thursday, a federal agency released the final results of what experts call the worldâs largest and most costly experiment to look into the question. The study originated in the Clinton administration, cost $30 million and involved some 3,000 rodents.
Title: Study of Cellphone Risks Finds âSome Evidenceâ of Link to Cancer, at Least in Male Rats

Content: A new study offers help to patients and doctors who are trying to deal with mammogram results that many women consider troubling and confusing: the finding of âdenseâ breast tissue.
Title: Study Suggests Dense Breast Tissue Isnât Always a High Cancer Risk

Content: I had to admit I was more than a little excited to see my next patient. This was a big day, for both of us.
Title: Cured From Cancer, Almost

Content: The mother was in a grocery store on the North Side of Chicago when she got the news. âI talked to a doctor who might be able to help figure out whatâs wrong with your son,â her friend said. The words were a relief; she had been searching for months.
Title: Scans Suggested the Boy Had Cancer. But No Doctor Could Prove It. Why?

Content: Two-thirds of women who have lumpectomies for breast cancer are receiving radiation treatment that lasts nearly twice as long as necessary, a new study reports.
Title: Long Radiation Treatments Called Unnecessary in Many Breast Cancer Cases

Content: PARAMUS, N.J. â As Jimmy Walker stood on the tee at the fifth hole at Ridgewood Country Club, sun peered through the clouds, and a refrain popped into his head: reapply, reapply.
Title: For a Skin Cancer Survivor, the Sand Isnât Nearly as Menacing as the Sun

Content: âIâm so jealous. Youâve lost so much weight, you look amazing,â a friend says to me. âIâd love to catch the stomach bug this year and lose a few pounds myself.â
Title: Cancer in the Family: Compliments on Being Thin

Content: The United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague has proposed a temporary release for Vojislav Seselj, a Serbian nationalist leader with cancer, whose health has seriously deteriorated during his long-running trial. In a decision published on Wednesday, the judge in charge of his case suggested that âto avoid the worst-case scenarioâ Mr. Seselj should return to Serbia for treatment. Mr. Seselj, a firebrand politician, has been charged with inciting others to commit war crimes in Bosnia and Croatia in the 1990s by creating a militia and sending its members off with incendiary speeches. He has also been convicted of contempt of court. Mr. Seselj surrendered to the tribunal in 2003, and his enduring presence during his much-delayed trial has become an embarrassment for the Yugoslavia tribunal. He has often harangued judges and has taken pride in provoking prosecutors.
Title: The Hague: Serbian Nationalist Leader With Cancer May Be Freed Temporarily

Content: A heart attack or stroke may be an early sign of cancer.
Title: Heart Attack May Be Early Sign of Cancer

Content: Your appointment is at 2:00 on a Tuesday afternoon. Itâs your first visit to the cancer center. Youâre probably wondering what we are going to say to you. A tumor was recently detected in your left lung and has spread to your bones and liver. A biopsy was performed.
Title: How Much Do You Want to Know About Your Cancer?

Content: In âYoung Love, Complicated by Cancer,â A. O. Scott reviews the film âThe Fault in Our Stars.â
Title: 6 Qâs About the News | Young Love, Complicated by Cancer

Content: Test your knowledge of this weekâs health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Baseball, Cancer Treatment and the Early Benefits of Exercise

Content: Psychological distress may increase your chances of dying from cancer.
Title: Depression and Anxiety Tied to Cancer Deaths

Content: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and on our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.
Title: Wednesday Reading: Giving Patients Choices in Colon Cancer Screening

Content: PORTLAND, Ore. â Oregon resident George Polas learned in March he had an aggressive type of prostate cancer that would require surgical removal - just as the coronavirus pandemic began spreading rapidly in the United States.
Title: 'Waiting Game' for Oregon Patient Needing Cancer Surgery Amid Coronavirus

Content: After a clamor from some patients and doctors, the Food and Drug Administration announced on Friday that it would allow sales to resume of a leukemia drug that was temporarily withdrawn from the market for causing potentially deadly side effects.
Title: After Brief Halt, F.D.A. Allows Sales of Drug for Cancer to Resume

Content: Drugs that free the bodyâs immune system to fight cancer have shown strong preliminary results in treating Hodgkinâs lymphoma, shrinking tumors in well over half of patients who had exhausted many other treatment options, researchers reported on Saturday.
Title: Cancer Drugs That Free Brake on Immune System Show Promise for Hodgkinâs

Content: Takeda Pharmaceutical has agreed to pay $2.4 billion to settle thousands of lawsuits from patients and their family members who said that the companyâs diabetes drug Actos caused bladder cancer, it announced on Tuesday.
Title: Takeda Agrees to Pay $2.4 Billion to Settle Suits Over Cancer Risk of Actos

Content: Henning Mankell, a master of Scandinavian crime literature, has been diagnosed with cancer, he said Wednesday in a Swedish newspaper.
Title: Crime Writer Henning Mankell Says He Has Cancer

Content: Some of the most promising advances in cancer research in recent years involve treatments known as immunotherapy. These advances are spurring billions of dollars in investment by drug companies, and are leading to hundreds of clinical trials. Here are answers to some basic questions about this complex and rapidly evolving field.
Title: What Is Immunotherapy? The Basics on These Cancer Treatments

Content: Myriad Genetics has essentially given up trying to stop other companies from offering tests for increased risk of breast cancer, ending a dispute that was the subject of a landmark Supreme Court ruling that human genes cannot be patented.
Title: Myriad Genetics Ending Patent Dispute on Breast Cancer Risk Testing

Content: HONG KONG â Chinese regulators have begun an investigation into the Internet giant Baidu after the death of a college student who said he received distorted information on cancer treatment from the companyâs search engine.
Title: China Investigates Baidu After Studentâs Death From Cancer

Content: [View the story âTuesdayâs Wall St. Eventsâ on Storify]
Title: Wall Streetâs A-List Turns Out to Fight Skin Cancer

Content: His empty apartment had been cast in darkness.
Title: Former Drug Addict Beats Cancer, and Aims to Follow His Dreams

Content: Before I travel to my motherâs funeral, I need to deliver the husks of a weekâs-worth of blister packs to the Indiana University Simon Cancer Center. Every Tuesday I bring the empty packets in a paper bag to be exchanged for the next weekâs-worth of pills. After a number of tests, the nurse-administrator of the clinical trial reminds me to down four capsules in the airport and not to eat until I get inside the nonstop plane taking me toward the cemetery, where my father and maternal grandparents are buried.
Title: Living With Cancer: The Husks

Content: The folks at Retro Report, which takes a fresh look at past events that garnered lots of media attention, have taken on âPower Line Fearsâ in their latest video report. The piece examines a burst of media coverage and public panic after some studies hinted at raised childhood leukemia risk near power lines nearly a quarter century ago. Paul Brodeurâs âAnnals of Radiationâ coverage in the New Yorker was a memorable part of the story. But the networks enthusiastically jumped on board, as well.
Title: A Fresh Look at Power Lines, Cancer and the Dread-to-Risk Ratio

Content: Bunched on the kitchen counter, the bananas glowered. “Eat me, drink me, suck my juices,” they taunted, like the tempting fruit in Christina Rossetti’s kinky poem “Goblin Market.” I was flummoxed since I loathe the mushy texture of bananas. (Sorry, Chiquita!) But how else could I ingest more of the magnesium I need in order to not get thrown out of my cancer clinical trial?
Title: Raising a Glass to Chronic Disease

Content: After anxious weeks since learning that he had cancer, a man prepares for an operation that he hopes will give him a longer life. Then, days before, his surgeon tells him that plans have changed. His surgery will be put off because of concerns about the spread of the coronavirus.
Title: Will the Coronavirus Delay My Cancer Surgery?

Content: I miss the intimacy, and the innocence, of my visits with patients.
Title: Coronavirus and the Cancer Patient

Content: Last April, my wife called me in tears from a hospital in Fairfax, Va., to tell me our 2-year-old daughter, Nusayba, had hepatoblastoma, a rare cancer that primarily affects children during the first 3 years of life. It was most likely stage 4, she said.
Title: My Toddler Survived Cancer. Then Came the Coronavirus.

Content: Sequestered during the pandemic, I find myself thinking that cancer patients’ expertise in fear can help others heed its warnings. We all need tactics not only to overcome the destructive capacity of fear but also to tap its protective potential.
Title: What Cancer Has Taught Me About Fear

Content: A diet high in fiber may help reduce the risk for breast cancer, researchers report.
Title: High-Fiber Foods Linked to Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: As the coronavirus pandemic spreads, the normal touchstones of everyday life have vanished without so much as a warning. In their place are terrifying thoughts about the future, about loss and about mortality.
Title: How to Live in the Face of Fear: Lessons From a Cancer Survivor

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday asked companies to stop selling all forms of the heartburn drug Zantac, after concluding that a potential cancer-causing contaminant can build up in the drug when stored for long periods.
Title: Zantac Products Should Not Be Sold or Used, F.D.A. Warns, Citing Cancer Danger

Content: This guide was originally published on July 26, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
Title: Know Your Uterus

Content: This story was originally published on Jan. 16, 2020 in NYT Parenting.
Title: Black Women Are Hit Hardest by Fibroid Tumors

Content: This story was originally published on June 20, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
Title: Uterine Fibroids Can Wreak Reproductive Havoc. What Are They?

Content: SEATTLE — One in four U.S. households have a smart speaker and 81 percent of adults own a smartphone. These devices might seem to be unlikely medical instruments, yet their computing capability, storage and sensor quality is often superior to the clinical-grade equipment used to monitor patients in an intensive care unit.
Title: Alexa, Do I Have Coronavirus?

Content: Omega-3 fatty acids have almost no effect, good or bad, on the risk for cardiovascular disease or cancer.
Title: Omega-3s Show No Overall Benefits for Heart Health or Cancer Prevention

Content: Sundown marks the beginning of my mother’s third yahrzeit, the anniversary of her death. I light a candle whose flame will burn for 24 hours, to honor her memory. But I need no candle to remember Ma, who burned bright all on her own. And I have the scars to prove it.
Title: Maybe the Survivor’s Daughter Could Survive

Content: “Have you read this?” the 61-year-old man asked his newest doctor, Madan Jagasia, as they sat in an exam room in the cancer center at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville. The book, titled “Dying Well,” prompted a concerned look from the oncologist. You know we’re not there yet, he said he told the patient.
Title: His Immune System Went Out of Whack. The Usual Treatment Didn’t Work. Why?

Content: When Janet Halloran last saw her primary care physician, the doctor asked whether she had undergone her annual mammogram. Yes, she replied, she had.
Title: Aging Out of the Mammogram

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Coronavirus, Exercise and Prostate Cancer

Content: I know bad news is coming my way when my oncologist walks into the exam room with a nurse. It doesn’t matter that he introduces her as a new nurse getting to know the system. In my more than six years of seeing my oncologist for metastatic colon cancer, he has never come in accompanied. He wants her in the room to learn how to give bad news.
Title: How to Give Bad News

Content: The new coronavirus is a serious threat to the elderly, as federal officials have been at pains to note recently. But they have stepped gingerly around advice for another group of Americans also at special risk from the infection: those with chronic health conditions.
Title: Coronavirus Threatens Americans With Underlying Conditions

Content: SEATTLE — On an overcast day in Seattle, a few dozen medical staff members, students and emergency workers with symptoms of the fast-spreading coronavirus spent their lunch break driving to a parking garage.
Title: Coronavirus Testing Goes Mobile in Seattle

Content: A shortage of nurses elevated the misery of a woman in my support group during a recent health crisis, she informed us. Because I participate in a clinical trial, in which I am vigilantly monitored in both Bloomington and Indianapolis hospitals, I was surprised. But I quickly began to realize that her ordeal could not possibly be unusual and then to fear that our current health care system is becoming more unfriendly, inhospitable to patients and to nurses as well.
Title: The Nursing Shortage Is Threatening Our Care

Content: Metformin, the world’s most widely prescribed diabetes drug, might do more than control diabetes. A study in Scotland in 2005 found that people taking metformin were 23 percent less likely to get cancer, suggesting that it might also prevent cancer. Other studies are exploring metformin’s ability to treat cancer, alone and in combination with other therapies.
Title: Repurposing Drugs to Fight Cancer

Content: Howard Wolinsky is a medical journalist in Flossmoor, Ill., who knows better than to go forward with potentially life-changing surgery without first seeking a second opinion.
Title: Before Prostate Surgery, Consider ‘Active Surveillance’

Content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher
Title: Modern Love Podcast: Lesley Manville Reads ‘The Kindness, and Xanax, of Strangers’

Content: We’ve long been schooled on the lifesaving value of early detection of a potentially deadly cancer. So when a simple blood test was introduced in 1994 that could detect the possible presence of prostate cancer, the second leading cause of cancer deaths among American men, it’s not hard to understand why it quickly became hugely popular.
Title: Debating the Value of PSA Prostate Screening

Content: My patient was brought to the emergency room by his friend because he could no longer catch his breath and had a cough that wouldn’t extinguish. He lived with three other young men, all in their early 20s, in a small house located in what many of us considered the no-man’s land between Cleveland and Buffalo, the four of them suspended between spending some time in a community college and finding work that they might one day call a career.
Title: When the Teenager or Young Adult Has Cancer

Content: The conservative radio talk show host Rush Limbaugh said on his live show on Monday that he had advanced lung cancer.
Title: Rush Limbaugh Reveals He Has Advanced Lung Cancer

Content: African-American men with prostate cancer are almost twice as likely to die from the illness as white men with the same disease. Disparities in medical care, rather than racial differences in the course of the cancer, may be a large part of the explanation, a new study suggests.
Title: Access to Care May Explain Disparities in Prostate Cancer Outcomes

Content: People who worked at ground zero after the World Trade Center attack in 2001 have higher rates of cancer than the general population, a new study has found.
Title: 9/11 Workers May Be at Higher Cancer Risk

Content: Men with early stage prostate cancer are often advised to increase their intake of vegetables to lower the risk for progression to more serious disease. But now a randomized trial has found that vegetables, whatever other health benefits they may confer, have no discernible effect on prostate cancer progression.
Title: Eating More Vegetables Did Not Affect Prostate Cancer Progression

Content: Do you know what to say or what to do when a friend, relative or acquaintance has cancer?
Title: What to Say to Someone With Cancer

Content: Just when I needed it most, I learned a valuable life lesson from Lynda Wolters, who has a cancer that is currently incurable, diagnosed just after her 49th birthday. As an Idaho farm girl used to hard work, Ms. Wolters led a healthy life, enjoying ballroom dancing, horseback riding, rafting and hiking when not at work at a law firm. Then, as she wrote in her recently published book, “Voices of Cancer”:
Title: When Life Throws You Curveballs, Embrace the ‘New Normal’

Content: When the American Cancer Society reported that the United States had experienced the sharpest one-year drop in cancer death rate ever recorded, it quickly caught the attention of President Trump.
Title: Trump Took Credit for Lower Cancer Death Rates. Advocates Say Not So Fast.

Content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, whose health has become a preoccupation of the American public as the Supreme Court hews rightward under President Trump, announced this week that she was cancer-free.
Title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Says She No Longer Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Running, Body Temperature and a Deadly New Virus

Content: When in distress with cancer and its treatments, I think of Shakespeare “in disgrace with fortune and men’s eyes” and all alone lament my downcast state. I am not completely bereft, then, because his poem supports my complaint. Why are sonnets so bracing, I wonder as I launch into a neo-Shakespearean sort of pity party.
Title: When in Distress, Try Sonnets

Content: The cancer death rate in the United States fell 2.2 percent from 2016 to 2017 — the largest single-year decline in cancer mortality ever reported, the American Cancer Society reported on Wednesday. Since 1991 the rate has dropped 29 percent, which translates to approximately 2.9 million fewer cancer deaths than would have occurred if the mortality rate had remained constant.
Title: Cancer Death Rate in U.S. Sees Sharpest One-Year Drop

Content: Vaccines prevent diseases, and being unvaccinated carries a risk. Last year, the World Health Organization ranked vaccine hesitancy, a “reluctance or refusal to vaccinate despite the availability of vaccines,” among the top 10 health threats worldwide, alongside Ebola, H.I.V. and drug-resistant infections.
Title: You Are Unvaccinated and Got Sick. These Are Your Odds.

Content: Artificial intelligence can help doctors do a better job of finding breast cancer on mammograms, researchers from Google and medical centers in the United States and Britain are reporting in the journal Nature.
Title: A.I. Is Learning to Read Mammograms

Content: I found myself unexpectedly back in the hospital last month, some 10 years after my last treatment for an aggressive prostate cancer. Fortunately, it had nothing to do with my cancer; my P.S.A. level, a measure of prostate cancer progression, has been undetectable  since 2009.
Title: Back in the Hospital Again

Content: WASHINGTON — Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia and an icon of the civil rights movement, announced on Sunday that he had advanced pancreatic cancer, but planned to return to Washington to continue work and begin treatment.
Title: John Lewis, Congressman and Civil Rights Icon, Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Brain surgeons are bringing artificial intelligence and new imaging techniques into the operating room, to diagnose tumors as accurately as pathologists, and much faster, according to a report in the journal Nature Medicine.
Title: A.I. Comes to the Operating Room

Content: NASHVILLE — Dear Mr. Lewis, I write with a heavy heart. Stage 4 pancreatic cancer is a brutal diagnosis, so it’s no surprise that last Sunday night the internet erupted with anguish as news of your illness became public. Treatment may give you a “fighting chance” to continue working “for the Beloved Community,” as you wrote in a statement, but it’s painful to think of what you will be called on to bear in the coming months. You have already borne so much for us.
Title: An Open Letter to John Lewis

Content: BOSTON — Zaosong Zheng was preparing to board Hainan Airlines Flight 482, nonstop from Boston to Beijing, when customs officers pulled him aside.
Title: Stolen Research: Chinese Scientist Is Accused of Smuggling Lab Samples

Content: Advice from Well on ways to minimize risks and increase your longevity.
Title: Five Tips for Living Longer in 2020

Content: Even moderate alcohol consumption may increase the risk for cancer.
Title: Even a Little Alcohol May Raise Cancer Risk

Content: Amid mounting excitement about the kids flying in for a visit, I look around the apartment with trepidation. Why am I so nervous about their imminent arrival? It has been months since our last get-together and they can replace ceiling light bulbs too risky for me or my older husband to reach.
Title: Sticking to My Own Premises

Content: For decades, scientists have debated whether hair dyes frequently used by women might contribute to cancer. The research has been mixed and inconclusive, but now government investigators have turned up a disturbing new possibility.
Title: Hair Dyes and Straighteners May Raise Breast Cancer Risk for Black Women

Content: I recently was told by my doctor to go see a doctor at the Cancer Institute to be tested for cervical cancer.
