Title: Study Links Obesity to Ovarian Cancer

Content: Most lung cancer patients who undergo surgery are still alive three years later, compared with just 10 percent of those who do not. Yet at least one-third of patients choose not to have the operation. Why not?
Title: Prognosis: When Cancer Patients Opt for Surgery

Content: Barbara Brenner, who led the group Breast Cancer Action and shaped it in her own combative image, pillorying the medical establishment, industrial polluters and even other cancer research advocates, died on May 10 at her home in San Francisco. She was 61.
Title: Barbara Brenner, Breast Cancer Iconoclast, Dies at 61

Content: Amgen said it agreed to buy BioVex, a closely held maker of experimental cancer drugs, for $425 million and as much as $575 million in milestone payments.
Title: Amgen Buys a Cancer Drug Maker

Content: If you stop smoking, does your increased cancer risk eventually return to zero? Can eating carrots protect against lung cancer? Should a recovering cancer patient test for radon, and are there other risks to be aware of in the home? Is there an estrogen-lung cancer link? These are among the questions readers recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. Derek Raghavan, director of the Taussig Cancer Institute at the Cleveland Clinic, responds.
Title: Cutting Your Lung Cancer Risk

Content: African-Americans who live in highly segregated counties are considerably more likely to die from lung cancer than those in counties that are less segregated, a new study has found.
Title: Segregation Linked in Study With Lung Cancer Deaths

Content: Smoking is a recognized risk factor for cancer of the pancreas, but do other forms of tobacco use increase your risk? What about what you eat or drink, or your exposure to certain chemicals? Dr. Eileen O’Reilly, a pancreatic cancer expert at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, responds to readers who had questions on the Consults blog.
Title: Alcohol, Diet and Pancreatic Cancer Risks

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Approval for 2nd Genentech Cancer Drug

Content: IN the not-so-distant past, Dr. Arthur G. Lerner said, people were often afraid even to say the ''C'' word. An aunt, it might be whispered among family members, was ''very ill.'' A grandfather was being treated, but no one said for what. Only in the last 20 years or so has it become truly common for someone to say openly, to anyone who will listen, ''I had cancer, I had surgery and chemotherapy and radiation, and I have survived.''
Title: Survivors of Cancer Celebrate Their Status

Content: More than 200 researchers investigating colon cancer tumors have found genetic vulnerabilities that could lead to powerful new treatments. The hope is that drugs designed to strike these weak spots will eventually stop a cancer that is now almost inevitably fatal once it has spread.
Title: Genetic Aberrations Seen as Path to Stop Colon Cancer

Content: Breast implants — both saline- and silicone-filled, and whether for reconstruction after cancer surgery or for cosmetic enlargement of the breasts — may cause a small but significant increase in the risk of an extremely rare type of cancer, writes the New York Times health reporter Denise Grady.
Title: Breast Implants Linked to Rare Cancer

Content: JENNIFER McLAUGHLIN of Brewster, N.Y., is not an athlete.
Title: For Cancer Survivor, An Olympic Moment

Content: James P. Allison is the chairman of the immunology department at the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. His seminal research opened up a new field in cancer treatment: immunotherapy. Instead of poisoning a tumor or destroying it with radiation, Dr. Allison has pioneered ways to unleash the immune system to destroy a cancer.
Title: Arming the Immune System Against Cancer
A diet to ward off cancer? Maybe not

Content: A new study shows that prostate cancer surgery, which often leaves men impotent or incontinent, does not appear to save the lives of men with early-stage disease, who account for most cases, and many of these men would do just as well to choose no treatment at all.
Title: Questioning Surgery for Early Prostate Cancer

Content: If you read just one newspaper article this weekend, I recommend David Kirkpatrick’s piece in Sunday’s Times. The brief summary:
Title: The Prostate Cancer Test: An Update
A Passion for Art, Through Cancer

Content: Millions of men belong to a fraternity that they neither wanted to join nor can easily quit. Nor can they avoid paying dues. It is a fraternity of husbands (and fiancés and boyfriends) of women with breast cancer.
Title: Travel Companion on the Breast Cancer Journey

Content: New drugs for breast cancer and multiple myeloma won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Friday, expanding options for patients in advanced stages of those diseases.
Title: F.D.A. Approves Drugs for Cancer and Myeloma

Content: Cancer patients often talk about the right and wrong things to say to someone with the disease. Well-meaning friends and family members might describe cancer patients as upbeat, strong and ready for battle, but patients themselves are often annoyed by the metaphor.
Title: Does Cancer Make You Strong?

Content: “Don’t forget to check your neck,” says an advertising campaign encouraging people to visit doctors for exams to detect thyroid cancer.
Title: In Push for Cancer Screening, Limited Benefits

Content: ''Most research is failure,'' says Judah Folkman, a world-renowned cancer researcher whose career would most generally be seen as a success. A professor at Harvard Medical School and director of the surgical research laboratories at Children's Hospital in Boston, he created a new field of medicine and challenged orthodox thinking about cancer treatment.
Title: A 'Heretic,' He Starves Cancer Cells

Content: Over the Memorial Day weekend, a 9-year-old Bronx girl named Lauren went grocery shopping with her mom. In an aisle, a man banged into Lauren’s left arm with his cart, tearing away part of a big mole. She bled heavily.
Title: Cancer Care, With a Dose of Insurance Bureaucracy

Content: New findings that excite cancer researchers often ring hollow to cancer patients. The reason is that the two groups have different expectations.
Title: Expanding Horizons, and Expectations, in Cancer Care

Content: Cancer rates among rescue and recovery workers were not statistically higher than those in the general populaiton.
Title: Cancer Among 9/11 Workers

Content: The Cancer
Title: A Protein That Fuels Cancer, and a Drug to Fight It

Content: Oct. 21, 2010 2:49 p.m. | Updated Thanks for all your questions. See Dr. Tuttle’s first set of responses in “Toxins, Genes and Thyroid Cancer.”
Title: Ask an Expert About Thyroid Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 - The Supreme Court announced on Monday that William H. Rehnquist, the 80-year-old chief justice, had been hospitalized since Friday for treatment of thyroid cancer and that he had undergone a tracheotomy "in connection with" the cancer diagnosis.
Title: Rehnquist Treated for Thyroid Cancer, Supreme Court Says

Content: A new method of attacking cancer cells, developed by researchers in Australia, has proved surprisingly effective in animal tests.
Title: New Cancer Treatment Shows Promise in Testing

Content: Scientists have identified two genetic variations that account for 57 percent of cases of thyroid cancer, a finding that could lead to earlier detection among people at high risk for the disease.
Title: Gene Study Finds Link to Cancer of Thyroid

Content: In the late 1980's, a blood test for prostate cancer came into widespread use. The test, the P.S.A., can find cancers when they are too small to feel and before they have spread. It is only now being evaluated in clinical trials to see if it reduces the risk of dying from the disease. Gina Kolata asked two experts to assess national data on prostate cancer.
Title: Prostate Cancer: Death Rate Shows a Small Drop. But Is It Treatment or Testing?

Content: For nearly a year, Times editor Dana Jennings has been coping with an aggressive form of prostate cancer. Recently, one of his good friends was diagnosed with the disease and is soon scheduled for surgery.  (Photo: Dana Jennings. (Lonnie Schlein/The New York Times))    Instead of a get-well present for his friend, Dana decided to wrap up some fresh cancer wisdom, based on his own experiences after surgery. Some of his advice is small: don't walk the dog, take out the trash or shovel the drive.  And some of his advice is big:  Don't rush. Having cancer is, perhaps, the beginning of wisdom. You're vulnerable, and suddenly wrestling with deep questions about love and death and the meaning of this life. But if you're rushing — to return to work, for example — you won't even notice.  Read Dana's full column, "Post-Op Strategies: Painkillers, to Start,'' from Tuesday's Science Times. And then join the discussion below. What's your best advice for someone recovering from prostate surgery or another major medical procedure?
Title: Soft Pillows and Other Cancer Wisdom

Content: Two specials for young audiences -- one this afternoon, the other on Tuesday -- explore the same subject: breast cancer.
Title: Daughters, Mothers and Breast Cancer

Content: People who buy organic food are usually convinced it’s better for their health, and they’re willing to pay dearly for it. But until now, evidence of the benefits of eating organic has been lacking.
Title: Can Eating Organic Food Lower Your Cancer Risk?

Content: The headline had some of my friends in a panic.
Title: A Link Between Alcohol and Cancer? It’s Not Nearly as Scary as It Seems

Content: Mickey Mantle's cancer has spread beyond his lungs and his condition has worsened, the hospital treating him said today.
Title: Mantle Worsens as His Cancer Spreads

Content: “Cancer is not something that makes you want to share. It’s something that makes you want to hide,” Suleika Jaouad says in the latest installment of the “Life, Interrupted” video series. In “Going Public With Cancer,” Ms. Jaouad offers a glimpse of her new life as an advocate for young adults with cancer as well as the friendships she has made as a result of going public with her illness.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Going Public With Cancer

Content: A government-sponsored study has found that annual CT scans could reduce the mortality rate from lung cancer in very heavy smokers and former smokers by 20 percent. Its leaders suggest that many thousands of lives could be saved annually. This exciting advance still raises serious questions for individuals and their doctors and for the economics of the health care system.
Title: CT Scans for Lung Cancer

Content: Ovarian cancer has long been known as the "silent killer," growing imperceptibly inside victims until the disease has spread too far to be stopped.
Title: Defining warning signs for ovarian cancer

Content: Paulette Crowther’s three children were grown and she was plotting a midlife career change when a routine colonoscopy picked up cancer, but not of the colon — of the anus.
Title: Saving Lives From Anal Cancer

Content: A man’s risk for prostate cancer appears to increase with his height, a new study shows.
Title: Height Linked With Prostate Cancer Risk

Content: Smokers have much higher odds of developing bladder cancer than previously believed, and the changing makeup of cigarettes may be a factor, new research shows.
Title: Bladder Cancer a Growing Concern for Smokers

Content: Mutations in a gene called PALB2 raise the risk of breast cancer in women by almost as much as mutations in BRCA1 and BRCA2, the infamous genes implicated in most inherited cases of the disease, a team of researchers reported Wednesday.
Title: Study Shows Third Gene as Indicator for Breast Cancer

Content: Although I sob during sappy movies, I did not cry as I staggered through the numerous surgeries, radiological procedures and chemotherapies that followed a cancer diagnosis four years ago. That is why I am grateful to yoga.
Title: Living With Cancer: Patient Yoga

Content: It is the middle of April 2006, and I am seated on an examining table on the third floor of the New York University Clinical Cancer Center, waiting to hear about my future.
Title: In Breast Cancer, There Is a Single Agenda: Stay Alive

Content: In a large prospective study, researchers have found an association between aspirin use and a reduced risk of liver cancer.
Title: Aspirin Tied to Reduced Risk of Liver Cancer

Content: The drug maker AstraZeneca has asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve Iressa, a cancer treatment that the company predicts will have sales of more than $1 billion. The filing asks the regulator to approve the drug to treat advanced non-small-cell lung cancer. AstraZeneca is looking for a way to make up for lower revenue from Prilosec, an ulcer treatment that accounts for about 40 percent of its sales. Prilosec may soon face cheaper generic rivals. Iressa is being studied for the treatment of breast, colo-rectal and gastric cancers, the company said. The F.D.A. has given Iressa a fast-track designation, which may allow the agency to expedite its review.
Title: ASTRAZENECA SEEKS APPROVAL OF CANCER DRUG

Content: When I get tired of being told to juice carrots, I remember that the essayist Anatole Broyard took tap-dancing lessons as he underwent treatment for prostate cancer. Sick people need all sorts of strategies, alongside medical ones, to deal with disease.
Title: Living With Cancer: The Lure of Alternative Remedies

Content: My Sunday column looks at what I call “the cancer lobby” — a term that will have said lobby writing in indignation about now. But I’m pretty indignant, too.
Title: Information About Cancer? Suppress It!

Content: How did your life change after cancer?
Title: Picture Your Life After Cancer

Content: President Bush's decision to cut the budget for a cancer detection program makes no sense. In human terms, it is cruel. From a budget standpoint, it is self-defeating.
Title: NYT: Illogical Cutbacks on Cancer

Content: A man's risk for prostate cancer appears to increase with his height, a new study shows.  Height appears to play less of a role than other known prostate cancer risk factors like age, family history and race. As a result, men shouldn't make screening or treatment decisions based on their height. But the findings may open up a new line of scientific inquiry into the causes of prostate cancer.  Researchers from four universities in England studied more than 9,000 men with and without prostate cancer and found that the tallest men had a 19 percent higher risk of developing prostate cancer than shorter men. Using the shortest men as a baseline, the study showed that risk increased 6 percent for every additional 4 inches in height. The report, published in the September issue of Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers & Prevention, showed an even stronger association between height and aggressive cancers.  "Compared to other risk factors, the magnitude of the additional risk of being taller is small, and we do not believe that it should interfere with preventive or clinical decisions in managing prostate cancer," said the study's lead author, Luisa Zuccolo, of the department of social medicine at the University of Bristol. "But the insight arising from this research is of great scientific interest.''  The increased risk likely is explained by factors associated with height, such as the insulin-like growth factor-1 system, which stimulates cell growth and has been shown to be involved in prostate cancer incidence and progression. The researchers also analyzed 58 other studies and found evidence that greater stature is associated with a modest increase in prostate cancer risk.  A woman's height also is associated with breast cancer risk. Women who are 5-feet-9 or taller have a small increase in risk of both premenopausal and postmenopausal breast cancer compared to women 5-feet-3 or shorter.
Title: Height Linked With Prostate Cancer Risk

Content: An amazing statistic emerged just weeks ago that seems to have gotten somewhat lost in the news about the weather, the Inauguration and the aftermath of the tsunami. Heart disease is no longer the leading killer of Americans under age 85. Cancer is.
Title: How Cancer Rose to the Top of the Charts

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Slowly, Cancer Genes Tender Their Secrets

Content: It is probably safe to say that in the history of bill signings by governors in the State of New York, few, if any, featured the entrance that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo made on Monday.
Title: Cuomo and Billy Joel Ride for Breast Cancer Awareness

Content: A rural resident in China is 30 percent more likely to die after a cancer diagnosis than an urban resident. Three rural families trying to beat these odds — “cancer refugees” — share their stories of battling the disease far from home and the financial ruin it causes.
Title: How China Creates Cancer Refugees

Content: Sometimes what you don’t know might end up being better for you.
Title: Early Test for Cancer Isn’t Always Best Course

Content: Drinking alcohol can increase the risk of developing breast cancer, and a study suggests that breast cancer survivors who consume just a few drinks a week may be more likely to experience a recurrence than nondrinkers.
Title: Risks: Study Ties Alcohol to Recurrence of Breast Cancer

Content: It is rare indeed for commercial television to produce a program of such high quality and importance as the two-and-a-half-hour documentary, ''Cancer: Evolution to Revolution,'' to be shown at 8 p.m. Eastern time this Thursday on HBO. Produced and directed by Joseph F. Lovett, five of whose family members had cancer and four of whom died of it, the film is at once realistic and hopeful about the life-and-death battles being waged daily against this disease.
Title: Documentary Lifts Shroud From Cancer

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday moved to revoke the approval of the widely used drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer, saying that new studies did not confirm that the medicine was helping patients.
Title: F.D.A. Rejects Use of Drug in Cases of Breast Cancer

Content: A major European study has shown that blood test screening for prostate cancer saves lives, but doubts remain about whether the benefit is large enough to offset the harms caused by unnecessary biopsies and treatments that can render men incontinent and impotent.
Title: Prostate Cancer Screening Still Not Recommended for All

Content: When Eddie Carrillo, a Los Angeles contractor, was found to have prostate cancer at the age of 52, his primary care doctor and his urologist both urged him to have his prostate removed. But after hearing about a “watchful waiting” program on talk radio, Mr. Carrillo decided to simply monitor his disease rather than treat it.
Title: Choosing ‘Watchful Waiting’ for Prostate Cancer

Content: The Corixa Corporation and GlaxoSmithKline said they faced another regulatory delay for their cancer medicine Bexxar, which the Food and Drug Administration first refused to consider in 1999. The companies reapplied for F.D.A. approval and predicted they would receive an answer by May 1. The agency extended the review and now will probably make its decision by Aug. 1, the companies said. Bexxar is intended to be a treatment for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a cancer of the immune system.
Title: ANOTHER REGULATORY DELAY FOR CANCER DRUG

Content: LOS ANGELES  To doctors visiting his company’s booth at a recent medical meeting, Scott Phillips extolled the medical virtues of the company’s equipment for treating cancer with protons. But he also appealed to their financial interests.
Title: The For-Profit Side of Cancer Treatment

Content: There is a new nuclear arms race under way  in hospitals.
Title: Hospitals Look to Nuclear Tool  to Fight Cancer

Content: There is an epidemic of cancer today. One in three Americans will be diagnosed with cancer, often before the age of 65. I have been on the wrong side of this statistic since I was 31 years old, when I discovered I had brain cancer.
Title: We can stop the cancer epidemic

Content: There is an epidemic of cancer today. One in three Americans will be diagnosed with cancer, often before the age of 65. I have been on the wrong side of this statistic since I was 31 years old, when I discovered I had brain cancer.
Title: We can stop the cancer epidemic

Content: At Babe Ruth Day at Yankee Stadium in 1947, the baseball hero of the generation stood before an admiring crowd, deep in pain and emaciated from advancing cancer, not yet aware of what ailed him. In the dugout moments before, clad in a topcoat and golf hat, he suffered a coughing spell, then, pulling himself together, walked to home plate, mentally recalling the day Lou Gehrig had made the same trip.
Title: Ruth's Other Record: Cancer Pioneer

Content: “Cancer books suck,” says 16-year-old Hazel Grace Lancaster. But she has a favorite and so do I. Mine is the novel John Green wrote about her.
Title: Living With Cancer: ‘The Fault in Our Stars’

Content: The disc jockey Carol Miller talks to Jo Maeder about staying relevant in the music business.
Title: Carol Miller on Work and Cancer

Content: A dire government report on cancer risks from chemicals and other hazards in the environment has drawn criticism from the American Cancer Society, which says government experts are overstating their case.
Title: U.S. Panel Criticized as Overstating Cancer Risks

Content: A drug already in widespread use to prevent bone thinning in women past menopause can also reduce their risk of invasive breast cancer, researchers reported yesterday.
Title: Drug Found to Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 22 — John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat, said Thursday that his wife’s cancer had returned in incurable form. He proclaimed that he would continue his bid for the presidency, saying, “The campaign goes on strongly.”
Title: Edwards Says Wife’s Cancer Has Returned

Content: An article in Wednesday’s Times describes how a routine procedure for the treatment of early breast cancer — the surgical removal of cancerous lymph nodes from the armpit — has been found unnecessary for many patients. The finding turns 100 years of standard medical practice on its head.
Title: Breast Cancer and Lymph Nodes: Q. and A.

Content: Microsoft scientists have demonstrated that by analyzing large samples of search engine queries they may in some cases be able to identify internet users who are suffering from pancreatic cancer, even before they have received a diagnosis of the disease.
Title: Microsoft Finds Cancer Clues in Search Queries

Content: A major study tracking the eating habits of 478,000 Europeans suggests that consuming lots of fruits and vegetables has little if any effect on preventing cancer.
Title: Eating Vegetables Doesn’t Stop Cancer

Content: (Photo: Joseph Ho/Guardian Protesters at the University of California, San Diego, are lobbying school administrators to address a "cancer cluster" linked to a campus building.)   A building on the University of California, San Diego, campus is being blamed for a cluster of breast cancer cases, raising new questions about the risks of exposure to electromagnetic fields.  Last week, students and professors marched and carried signs to protest what they called a "crisis of safety,'' claiming that the university has failed to address worries that the campus literature building is the site of an inordinate number of cancer cases. The protesters delivered a petition signed by more than 1,300 people to the university chancellor, Marye Anne Fox, according to a report in the university's newspaper, The Guardian.   At least eight workers in the campus building have been diagnosed with breast cancer since 2000, and a handful of other cancers, including ovarian and salivary gland cancers, have also been reported. The number of breast cancer cases alone is significantly more than would have been expected by chance, according to a June analysis by Cedric Garland, an epidemiologist at the university. In that report, he notes that the risk of invasive breast cancer for employees in the literature building appears to be four to five times higher than that of the general California population. To read the full report, click here.  Building workers and researchers are concerned the source of the problem may be the building's elevators, which rest on the first floor and emit an electromagnetic field. According to the report from Dr. Garland:  The issue of the etiological role of EMF in breast cancer is still not resolved with final scientific certainty, despite decades of research. However, the lack of such certainty should not be a reason to avoid taking moderate measures to minimize needless exposure of workers to power frequency EMF.  According to The Guardian, the University "has vacated areas with risk of exposure to high EMF levels" and replaced elevator motor devices and other fixtures to reduce generation of electromagnetic fields. A University of California, Los Angeles, researcher, Leeka Kheifets, has been asked to continue the investigation, although critics are wary of her ties to the Electric Power Research Institute, an arm of the electric utility industry, according to a report in Microwave News.   The university has created a Web site where it summarizes the literature building study as well as the interim safety measures it has taken, as well as links to scientific literature on electromagnetic fields and cancer. Click here to see the site.   In 2003, scientists reported that they found no link between a much publicized breast cancer cluster on Long Island and exposure to electromagnetic fields.
Title: Campus Building Blamed for Cancer Cluster

Content: Rarely is it said that someone is lucky to have had cancer. But Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court might be one such person.
Title: Small Advances Against Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Until recently, the nation’s cancer surveillance program was humming along. In every state, investigators were getting reports from every hospital describing every cancer patient they had seen.
Title: States and V.A. at Odds on Cancer Data

Content: (Photo: Senator John McCain in Sparks, Nev., on Tuesday. A biopsy of a spot removed from his right cheek showed no evidence of skin cancer. (Photo: Max Whittaker/Getty Images)) The McCain campaign issued a statement this evening from the Mayo Clinic in Arizona, where Senator John McCain had a small spot on his face removed and biopsied on Monday.  According to his campaign, Michael Yardley, chairman of the public affairs department at the clinic, issued this statement:     "Senator McCain visited the Mayo Clinic in Scottsdale, Arizona, yesterday for a routine check of his dermatological health. The biopsy that was performed did not show any evidence of skin cancer. No further treatment is necessary."   The senator has a history of melanoma and undergoes routine screenings.
Title: Mayo Clinic: McCain's Biopsy Cancer-Free

Content: In 1971, flush with the nation’s success in putting a man on the Moon, President Richard M. Nixon announced a new goal. Cancer would be cured by 1976, the bicentennial.
Title: Advances Elusive in the Drive to Cure Cancer

Content: Taking low-dose aspirin is a daily routine for many people because it may lower the risk for heart attacks and strokes, and some research has tied it to a lower risk of colorectal cancer. Now a new study in JAMA Oncology suggests it may lower the risk for ovarian cancer as well.
Title: Daily Baby Aspirin May Lower Ovarian Cancer Risk

Content: Not long before Mihir Shah was to be married in 2007, his soon-to-be mother-in-law got a diagnosis of breast cancer. She underwent chemotherapy and survived, wearing a wig to the wedding.
Title: A New Way to Detect Breast Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will announce on Friday a corporate executive to lead his “moonshot” cancer initiative, selecting an expert who began work in 2003 to lower barriers between science and cures.
Title: Biden Names Leader for ‘Moonshot’ Cancer Campaign

Content: Gavin Snow found out he had stage 3 melanoma two months before meeting Haley Tanner. Together they have endured the ups and downs of living with a tragic disease.
Title: Love Endures Even Cancer

Content: At times when I consider my losses, I feel like a loser in the battle against self-pity. Like many diseases, cancer has everything to do with loss: of a breast or a leg, of a chunk of liver or lung, of continence, of mental capacity, of life itself.
Title: Living With Cancer: Practicing Loss

Content: The American Cancer Society is caught between a cardinal of the Roman Catholic Church and a Nobel laureate over the society's position on human embryonic stem cell research.
Title: Cancer Group In Controversy On Stem Cells

Content: At times when I consider my losses, I feel like a loser in the battle against self-pity. Like many diseases, cancer has everything to do with loss: of a breast or a leg, of a chunk of liver or lung, of continence, of mental capacity, of life itself.
Title: Living With Cancer: Practicing Loss

Content: Correction Appended
Title: China Approves a Selective Cancer Drug

Content: A new study adds to evidence that obese men may have an increased risk for future prostate cancer.
Title: Obesity Tied to Prostate Cancer Risk

Content: Infertility in men may signal a higher risk for aggressive prostate cancer, a new study suggests.
Title: Male Infertility Linked With Prostate Cancer

Content: In a clinical trial, an experimental vaccine extended the lives of men with advanced prostate cancer, the therapy's developer, the Dendreon Corporation, announced yesterday.
Title: Vaccine Useful Against Cancer in Clinical Trial

Content: For those of us with dozens of moles, the spots speckling our skin can seem no more significant than freckles. But it turns out, each mole is a tumor of pigment cells that started on a path to cancer and then stopped. The cells do not divide again. A mole is an incipient cancer that halted in its tracks.
Title: The Tumor That Isn’t: Blocking a Path to Cancer

Content: This past winter, my friend Jan embarked on two unrelated quests. While tracing her ancestry, she was attempting to find out whether she had cancer. A visual artist, not a word person, Jan enlisted me as her scribe in the hope that her story might be useful. I’m glad she did. Her efforts at detection suggest that although many of us remain quite limited in what we know about our bodies and ourselves, we can nevertheless steer our way toward even the most startling discoveries.
Title: Tracking Cancer and Ancestry, With Mysteries in Each

Content: The older a woman is when she gives birth, the lower her risk for endometrial cancer, a new study reports.
Title: Later Pregnancy, Lower Risk of a Cancer

Content: People with lung cancer, the leading cancer killer in the United disease, are commonly assumed to have brought it upon themselves by smoking, explains Jane Brody, the Personal Health columnist, in this week’s Science Times. Yet “one-tenth of men and one-fifth of women with lung cancer have never been smokers,” she writes, “and in some parts of the country — Northern California, for example — as many as 35 percent of women with lung cancer never smoked or lived with smokers.”
Title: Ask an Expert About Lung Cancer

Content: Can radiation therapy for childhood conditions raise the risk of thyroid cancer in later life? Does a history of thyroid cancer have long-term risks? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. R. Michael Tuttle, an endocrinologist at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City, responds.
Title: The Long-Term Risks of Thyroid Cancer

Content: A few years ago, an independent group that issues guidelines on cancer screening decided to review its recommendations for breast cancer. It had last issued guidelines in 2002, but things had changed  there was new science and researchers had become more sophisticated in analyzing existing data.
Title: Behind Cancer Guidelines, Quest for Data

Content: Tuesday’s Cases column explores the world of late-stage cancer patients who don’t die. It’s written by Katherine Russell Rich, who was given two years to live after a diagnosis of stage IV breast cancer. She’s now on year 17.
Title: Living for Years With Late-Stage Cancer

Content: When a famous person is found to have a serious and potentially fatal disease, it often serves as a wake-up call for the rest of us. Just as Nancy Reagan's breast cancer stimulated a rush for mammography, the recently diagnosed colon cancer of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court should jolt all women (and men) over 50 -- and some younger people as well -- to take advantage of the tests that can detect this disease while it is still curable, perhaps even before it has become cancer.
Title: Detecting Colon Cancer When It Is Curable

Content: There are no marathons to raise money to find a cure for the disease, nor are there celebrities raising its profile. But bladder cancer has become the fourth leading type of cancer in men.
Title: Doctors Call Attention to Bladder Cancer
Walking to keep cancer in check

Content: THE plumber did it for his brother, who died eight years ago at age 41. The general contractor was thinking of a fraternity brother, who died 25 years ago at only 20. One of the electricians lost a brother last year, and another lost his father earlier this month.
Title: A Tangible Gift to Cancer Patients

Content: Simone Weinstein’s ordeal with cancer started in the most banal way: she was tired. She had a hard time getting up in the morning, and did not even have the energy to hang out with her friends.
Title: In Cancer Fight, Teenagers Don’t Fit In

Content: There is a dreadful routine to chemotherapy. My life has been synched to a chemotherapy calendar ever since my leukemia diagnosis last year. I have become an expert at predicting when side effects and symptoms will set in. It’s a ghoulish monthly party, and the guests always arrive on time: nausea, vomiting, chills, exhaustion, fever, mouth sores, pain, infections and emergency hospitalizations.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Fighting Cancer, and Myself

Content: Now, before you again don warm clothes, is a good time to note how much sun damage you incurred this summer. Are body parts that were not covered darker or more freckled than the skin you were born with? If so, you failed to cover your exposed skin and protect it adequately with sunscreen when out on both sunny and cloudy days.
Title: Updating the Rules for Skin Cancer Checks

Content: Much has been written about “chemo brain,” the foggy thinking and forgetfulness that afflicts many cancer patients after treatment. Now, new research suggests the cognitive problems associated with chemotherapy may also be caused by other types of treatment or even the disease itself.
Title: Is Chemo Brain Really Cancer Brain?

Content: I HAVE a very rare and aggressive type of skin cancer — Merkel cell carcinoma — for which there is no approved cure, and I’m participating in a clinical trial to deal with it. If successful, the trial will show that the drug I’m being given at least manages what is now an often fatal disease.
Title: Clinical Trials Need Cancer Patients

Content: ORLANDO, Fla.  In a finding that is likely to shake up medical practice, researchers reported here that early detection of a relapse of ovarian cancer with a widely used blood test does not help women live longer.
Title: Doubts on Ovarian Cancer Relapse Test

Content: Mike Gallo was 63 years old when he joined one of the world's fastest-growing fraternities.
Title: New Approach About Cancer And Survival

Content: Why do people who never smoke get lung cancer?
Title: Never Smoked, but at Risk for Lung Cancer?

Content: Recounting her father’s struggle with cancer was difficult for the young woman, even several years after his death. He’d endured first surgery and then chemotherapy and radiation, she told me, and the cancer had gone into remission. He was thrilled, but the aggressive treatment left him with chronic, debilitating pain. Once active, he struggled to get around in his own home.
Title: Poor Pain Control for Cancer Patients

Content: My wig (I named her Sally) was looking worse for wear. I decided to use a trip to visit my grandchildren in Manhattan as an opportunity to get another so-called “cranial prosthesis.” That way I could give Sally a much needed shampoo.
Title: Living With Cancer: Hiding Under a Wig?

Content: With prostate cancer, as with other diseases, there has been a vigorous debate about who should be tested. Screening too many people leads to unnecessary treatment, too few and you miss cancers that could have been stopped. A new study points to what may be a better approach: “screen smarter.”
Title: A Better Way to Screen for Prostate Cancer

Content: Long before Ralph Branca and Bobby Thomson ended the evening with a song they sang nearly 50 years ago, Todd Stottlemyre told the audience in a crowded hotel ballroom in Midtown that his father, the Yankees pitching coach Mel Stottlemyre, no longer had cancer.
Title: Stottlemyre Is Free Of Cancer, Son Says

Content: Walking is the family station wagon in the world of exercise, about as cool as great-grandma doing the Electric Slide at her favorite Club Med resort. There’s no gear except for a practical pair of shoes, no need for a chiseled coach or trainer and Under Armour is optional. You want cool? Try mountain-biking or in-line skating or climbing K2.
Title: Walking Away From Cancer

Content: Women considering surgery to receive breast implants should be warned of the risk of serious complications, including fatigue, joint pain and the possibility of a rare type of cancer, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday.
Title: Women Should Be Warned of Breast Implant Hazards, F.D.A. Says

Content: Dr. Peter Scardino of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center says current prostate cancer screening is painful and imprecise but vastly improving.
Title: Cancer Diagnosis: Less Can Be More

Content: St. John’s basketball Coach Steve Lavin will have prostate cancer surgery on Thursday. With practice beginning Oct. 15, it is unknown how much time, if any, the 47-year-old Lavin will miss while recovering. The operation will take place at Sloan-Kettering in New York.
Title: Cancer Surgery for Red Storm’s Lavin

Content: Devils Coach Pat Burns disclosed Sunday that he had colon cancer and that he would begin treatment immediately.
Title: Devils' Burns Will Be Treated for Colon Cancer

Content: STATISTICS are dry, so first a snapshot, if you are of sturdy stuff, to help explain the work of Dr. Harold P. Freeman, the longtime cancer fighter who has just been named president of Harlem's North General Hospital:
Title: A Cancer Fighter Keeps Fighting Injustice

Content: Former President Jimmy Carter, who has been undergoing treatment for cancer that was removed from his liver but had spread to his brain, said on Sunday that he was free of the disease.
Title: Former President Jimmy Carter Says He Is Free of Cancer

Content: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.
Title: What to Ask About Prostate Cancer

Content: WHEN Joan Borgatti's doctor told her that he wanted to do a bone marrow transplant to treat her breast cancer, she thought she was going to die. After he explained the procedure to her, it made sense: who was a better candidate for the latest cancer treatment than a 30-year-old mother of two?
Title: In Yonkers, the Cancer Fight Broadens

Content: In July 2005, Jeff Carenza and his girlfriend were enjoying a getaway weekend in Miami when food poisoning landed them both in the hospital. Blood tests showed that Carenza, then 29, had iron-deficiency anemia.
Title: The perplexing issues of cancer before 40

Content: Genentech’s drug Avastin did not help women with breast cancer live meaningfully longer, and it caused significant side effects, including a few deaths, the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday in a review of the drug.
Title: F.D.A. Criticizes Avastin Use for Breast Cancer

Content: If the spectacle of 1,000 gleaming boats filling a space that covers five and a half football fields is not quite dazzling enough, the New York National Boat Show is offering Twiggy, the amazing water-skiing squirrel, and Lawrence Gregory, a magician who plans to make a 17-foot boat disappear.
Title: Help for Breast-Cancer Patients Is on the Agenda

Content: Death rates from cancer have been dropping by an average of 2.1 percent a year recently in the United States, a near doubling of decreases that began in 1993, researchers are reporting.
Title: U.S. Cancer Death Rates Are Found to Be Falling

Content: For the first time, researchers have decoded all the genes of a person with cancer and found a set of mutations that may have caused the disease or aided its progression.
Title: Scientists decode set of cancer genes

Content: Medicare confirmed on Thursday that it would pay for Provenge, the prostate cancer drug whose $93,000 price had set off debate about the cost of cancer treatments.
Title: Medicare Will Pay for Prostate Cancer Drug

Content: Sunlight and the sound of traffic from Fort Hamilton Parkway streamed through the windows of Beata Bien’s second-floor studio apartment on a recent morning in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. The rays illuminated the tears in her green eyes and the pink Hello Kitty decorations adorning the small room.
Title: Facing Cancer and Financial Burdens, an Immigrant Finds Aid

Content: Like the other women in my cancer support group, I have been trying to salvage aspects of the person I had been before the diagnosis.
Title: Living With Cancer: Bedtime Issues

Content: The Cytyc Corporation said this week that the Food and Drug Administration had cleared its Thinprep 2000 system for cervical cancer screening.
Title: Approval Given For Cancer Test

Content: The term can come as a rude surprise. Cancer survivor. How can it be that the moment you receive a diagnosis you get that tag? What if you only live for a day, or even just a few hours? That's being a survivor?
Title: In One Word, an Entire Debate on Cancer

Content: The nearly 240,000 men in the United States who will learn they have prostate cancer this year have one more thing to worry about: Are their doctors making treatment decisions on the basis of money as much as medicine?
Title: Profit and Questions on Prostate Cancer Therapy

Content: From the shock of the cancer diagnosis onward, depression can take its well-documented toll on patients. Even patients who appear to pack away their fears during the grinding treatment journey to becoming cancer-free concede that when the regimen ends, they unspool emotionally.
Title: Anxiety Lingers Long After Cancer

Content: TOKYO  Seiji Ozawa, the Japanese conductor, said Thursday that he has esophageal cancer and will cancel his concerts for the next six months to focus on treatment.
Title: Ozawa Discloses Cancer and Cancels Concerts for 6 Months

Content: Women with lung cancer survive slightly longer than men with the disease, respond differently to at least one cancer drug and show higher levels of tobacco-induced genetic damage in their lungs, researchers are reporting today.
Title: Lung Cancer Affects Sexes Differently

Content: ''The Journey Through Cancer'' by Dr. Jeremy Geffen (Crown Publishers, 2000).
Title: A Doctor Redefines Traditional Cancer Care

Content: Scientists have long known that increasing age is the strongest risk for a diagnosis of late-stage cervical cancer. Now a new study suggests that the next strongest risk is the patient’s insurance status.
Title: Insurance Sways Risk of Cancer Diagnosis

Content: Last week, I wrote a column and a related blog post about women who started businesses that were inspired by their experience with breast cancer. The column and post generated a lot of discussion, and I wanted to share some of that here.
Title: Revisiting Breast Cancer’s Effect on Careers

Content: One-fifth of American women ages 50 to 74 have fallen behind on mammography screenings for breast cancer, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are reporting.
Title: Screening: Gaps Found in Breast Cancer Testing

Content: We commonly assume that cancer afflicts the aging or aged, but approximately 16 percent of breast cancer deaths involve women under the age of 50. How can or should an alarming death sentence be confronted in midlife? The personal challenges posed by incurable disease unfold in an absorbing documentary about movie-making, “A Woman Like Me,” which opened in New York in October and became available on Netflix this January.
Title: Living With Cancer: A Woman Like Me

Content: In 1990 Wendy Schlessel Harpham was a 36-year-old family physician and mother of three young children -- Rebecca, 6, Jessica, 4, and William, almost 2 -- when she learned that the swollen lymph nodes in her groin were malignant, an indolent form of a cancer called non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, or NHL, for which there was no known cure.
Title: Fighting Back Against Lymphatic Cancer

Content: An experimental vaccine has proved highly effective at preventing cervical cancer in a two-year study involving more than 12,000 women, researchers reported yesterday.
Title: Vaccine Prevents Most Cervical Cancer

Content: Young black women with breast cancer are more prone than white or older black women to develop a type of tumor with genetic traits that make it especially deadly and hard to treat, a study has found.
Title: Young Black Women Prone to Deadly Cancer

Content: Nancy G. Brinker, the founder of Susan G. Komen for the Cure, will leave her post as chief executive, and its president will resign, the group announced on Wednesday in the most significant leadership shake-up to follow its short-lived attempt to cut financing for breast cancer services provided by Planned Parenthood.
Title: Breast Cancer Group Changes Leaders

Content: On an assignment in Uganda reporting on early breast cancer detection, Lynsey Addario photographed a cancer ward that serves four countries — as the region is scarce of expertise and supplies.
Title: Breast Cancer as Death Sentence in Uganda

Content: A week or so after a procedure, I found a sticker on my body. Not a Disney sticker or a Dora the Explorer sticker, put there maybe by a godchild or nephew, but a 1 1/4-by-1-inch white rectangle with a steel nipple at the center.
Title: Living With Cancer: Seeking Intimacy

Content: After years of treatment and two relapses of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Dr. Lukas Wartman had exhausted all conventional approaches to his disease. A group at Washington University in St. Louis spent a month decoding his genetic information, a process called whole genome sequencing, in hopes of determining the genetic cause of his leukemia. The team found an overactive gene that was treatable with a drug for advanced kidney cancer. Here is how the process works.
Title: Searching for a Cancer’s Vulnerable Target

Content: Every Sunday evening, I phone a friend in another college town who has not yet found a cancer support group in her community. Let’s call her Melanie. Melanie had recovered from surgery and completed chemotherapy. Physically, she had gained strength. Yet she continued to feel overwhelmed by negative thoughts.
Title: Living With Cancer: Finding Calm in the Storm

Content: Every week, New York Times editor Dana Jennings shares his experiences coping with prostate cancer.   By Dana Jennings   I have prostate cancer, and sometimes I get mad. Not upset. Not annoyed. Not nettled. Mad. This isn't mere "why me" moaning. My rage is pure and primal, like that of a wolf caught in a steel trap.   (Photo: Dana Jennings. (Lonnie Schlein/The New York Times))   My anger, though, doesn't arrive when and where you'd think it would. Gliding into the radiation machine, getting a hormone shot and wearing mini-man-pads don't set me off. It's smaller, less expected, things, like a fellow customer being mean and rude to the server behind the counter at Starbucks, or a car busting a red light as I walk to my New York office.   That kind of behavior has always bothered me on some level. But since I learned that I have cancer, I react differently. I've walked the streets of New York for decades, and not thought twice about the cars that run red lights and nearly nail me and other pedestrians. It's a fact of life in the big city, like rats on the subway tracks. I used to shrug and keep walking.   Prostate Cancer Journal  One Man's Story
Title: Getting Angry About Prostate Cancer
Stem cells: A route to cancer's source?

Content: Women in the sunniest countries seem to get endometrial cancer less often than those who live far from the equator.
Title: Prevention: Sun May Lower Risk of Endometrial Cancer

Content: Cancer patients often talk about the right and wrong things to say to someone with the disease. Well-meaning friends and family members might describe cancer patients as upbeat, strong and ready for battle, but patients themselves are often annoyed by the metaphor.
Title: Does Cancer Make You Strong?

Content: A new study reports that overweight men with advanced prostate cancer seem not to live as long as those with normal body mass.
Title: Regimens: Weight Found to Affect Prostate Cancer Outcome

Content: Like all the Giants' coaches, their new offensive line coach, Pat Flaherty, had a routine physical provided by the team when he joined Tom Coughlin's staff. But the results were anything but routine.
Title: A Giants Assistant Has Cancer

Content: CHICAGO — A commonly used drug can help young women with breast cancer retain the ability to have babies, apparently protecting their ovaries from the damage caused by chemotherapy, researchers reported here on Friday.
Title: Drug Saves Fertility for Women With Cancer

Content: WIMBLEDON, England  Martina Navratilova arrived here, at the tennis tournament where she won nine singles titles, free in every sense that mattered. Free of cancer. Free of the radiation treatments she had before, during and after the French Open. Free to resume the life the diagnosis briefly, and only slightly, interrupted.
Title: After Facing Cancer, Navratilova Is Eyeing the Next Mountain

Content: Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign began televising this 30-second advertisement, ''Marie K.,'' in the New York City area on Saturday.
Title: Lazio's Breast Cancer Efforts Assessed

Content: Despite good news about my cancer treatment, it has been a hard winter, so I am looking forward to Passover. By retelling the story of the Jewish people’s escape from slavery in Egypt, the Haggadah — the text recited at the annual Seder — celebrates deliverance and springtime renewal. How would its rituals and prayers resonate for me this year, when cancer concerns were unexpectedly supplanted by other tribulations?
Title: A Bittersweet Passover: Cancer, Remission and Change

Content: THE FACTS
Title: The Claim: Tattoos Can Increase the Risk of Skin Cancer

Content: “A diagnosis of advanced cancer is usually difficult for you and your family,” the booklet says.  There’s an understatement.
Title: When the Battle With Cancer Can’t Be Won

Content: FOR the last seven years that Kairol Rosenthal, 35, has battled thyroid cancer with hormone pills, radiation, surgery and grit, she has had to contend with 101-degree fevers, heart palpitations and a lack of appetite so pronounced she has to force herself to eat.
Title: Cancer-Specific Products: An Unnecessary Balm?

Content: ONE RENEGADE CELL
Title: The Cancer Battle: A Revolution Still in Progress

Content: In June, after completing treatment for an early breast cancer, I sought genetic counseling. I opted to have my blood tested, to find out whether my cancer might have been inherited, the result of a mutation in one of the two known tumor suppressor genes, BRCA-1 and BRCA-2.
Title: Choosing to Test for Cancer's Genetic Link

Content: Updated findings from one of the largest studies of prostate cancer screening show that the commonly used P.S.A. blood test did not save lives, although questions remain about whether younger men or those at very high risk for the disease might benefit.
Title: Prostate Cancer Screening Shows No Benefit

Content: What does it take to get smokers to give up the habit? For some, not even lung cancer surgery does the trick.
Title: Addictions: Smoking Again After Lung Cancer Surgery

Content: ATLANTA — Former President Jimmy Carter announced on Wednesday that he had been given a diagnosis of a spreading cancer that was detected by recent liver surgery.
Title: Former President Jimmy Carter Says He Has Cancer

Content: Alarmed by the rapid escalation in the price of cancer drugs, the nation’s leading oncology society unveiled on Monday a new way for doctors and patients to evaluate different treatments — one that pointedly includes a medicine’s cost as well as its effectiveness and side effects.
Title: Cancer Doctors Offer Way to Compare Medicines, Including by Cost

Content: After being nursed and handed over, the baby’s wails rise to a tremolo, but I am determined to give my exhausted daughter and son-in-law a respite on this wintry evening. Commiserating with the little guy’s discomfort — gas, indigestion, colic, ontological insecurity — I swaddle, burp, bink, then cradle him in my arms. I begin walking around the house, swinging and swaying while cooing in soothing cadences: “Yes, darling boy, another one bites the dust, another one bites the dust.”
Title: Living With Cancer: Arrivals and Departures

Content: A food safety journal has decided to retract a paper that seemed to show that genetically modified corn and the herbicide Roundup can cause cancer and premature death in rats.
Title: Paper Tying Rat Cancer to Herbicide Is Retracted

Content: New cancer drugs are approved in just six months on average in the United States, half the time it takes for the same drugs to be approved in Europe, a new report finds.
Title: Perceptions: Cancer Drugs Get on a Faster Track in U.S.

Content: An experimental vaccine has proved highly effective at preventing cervical cancer in a two-year study involving more than 12,000 women, researchers reported today.
Title: Cervical Cancer Vaccine Is Found Effective

Content: I WANT to see the tobacco industry brought to its knees,'' said Dr. William G. Cahan, a cancer surgeon at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and an anti-smoking advocate. ''I want to see the lies of these pudgy-fingered 'tobcos,' their callousness and indifference to the havoc they have caused and continue to cause exposed.''
Title: Cancer Doctor Fights Smoking

Content: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter described main objectives of the United States’ military campaign in Iraq and Syria against the Islamic State.
Title: Carter Compares ISIS to a Cancer

Content: The Starr Foundation, one of the country’s largest philanthropies, pledged $100 million yesterday to cancer research involving collaboration among four institutions in New York and one in Massachusetts.
Title: A Donation of $100 Million to Promote Cancer Research

Content: In April 2010, we asked Well readers to share their stories of cancer survival. Over the following weeks and months, more than 1,150 people submitted their photos and stories, creating an inspiring collage of the life that is possible after cancer.
Title: A Picture Collage of Life After Cancer

Content: As a cancer patient whose life has been miraculously extended by a clinical trial, I was shocked by Charles Piller’s Dec. 13 essay “Law Ignored, Patients at Risk” in STAT News on lapses in reporting the results of such trials. My first response was to ask: Is he a reputable journalist? Is the online venue in which the article appears legit? When the answer to each of these questions came back a resounding yes, I began worrying that cancer doctors and patients have been imperiled by irresponsible researchers.
Title: Living With Cancer: A Broken Covenant With Patients

Content: If you read just one newspaper article this weekend, I recommend David Kirkpatrick's piece in Sunday's Times. The brief summary:
Title: The Prostate Cancer Test: An Update

Content: A new study of women with the earliest form of breast cancer offers clues into which patients may need aggressive therapy and who can be spared unnecessary treatment.
Title: Clues for Personalizing Breast Cancer Treatment

Content: A new drug being developed by Sanofi-Aventis extended the lives of men with advanced prostate cancer in a clinical trial and could become a new last-ditch treatment, researchers reported Wednesday.
Title: Positive Test for Sanofi Prostate Cancer Drug

Content: A new study testing B vitamins and omega-3 fatty acids for cancer prevention has found no beneficial effect and — at least for women — some possibility of harm.
Title: Regimens: No Cancer Benefits Seen in Supplements

Content: A hostile letter from a reader made me stop and think about the torments of waiting that cancer patients endure: waiting for a doctor, waiting for radiation, waiting for the delivery of chemotherapy drugs, waiting through interminable infusions or transfusions, waiting for a scan or a biopsy, waiting for the results of a scan or a biopsy, waiting (sometimes starved and unclothed on a gurney in a hall) for surgery.
Title: Living With Cancer: Hurry Up and Wait

Content: This has been a bad year for proponents of early detection of breast cancer. Not only have we seen debates about the effectiveness of mammography but last week a study published in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute found that breast self-examination did not prevent deaths from breast cancer.
Title: Detecting Breast Cancer Before It Starts

Content: BALTIMORE — The room lights were dimmed, and all eyes turned to the grainy pictures on a pair of overhead monitors in a small room at Johns Hopkins Hospital.
Title: Trading a lethal form of cancer for diabetes

Content: In an example of the dangers of untested and unregulated herbal products, doctors are reporting that a Chinese herb, already linked to kidney failure, may cause cancer as well.
Title: Chinese Herb Is Suspected in Cancer

Content: The use of cancer drugs is expanding, and the price is soaring  some individual drugs cost thousands of dollars a month. To the extent that patients benefit, the expense is often justified. But there are worries that the nation is spending much more than is warranted.
Title: Medicare and ‘Off-Label’ Cancer Drugs

Content: A building on the University of California, San Diego, campus is being blamed for a cluster of breast cancer cases, raising new questions about the risks of exposure to electromagnetic fields.
Title: Campus Building Blamed for Cancer Cluster

Content: The links will spawn new windows .
Title: Women's Health Resources: Breast Cancer

Content: The debate about cellphone safety was reignited yet again last week when a panel of the World Heath Organization declared that it was “possible” the phones could cause cancer.
Title: Piercing the Fog Around Cellphones and Cancer

Content: AN epidemic is raging in this country, and no one seems to be paying much attention to it. It is an epidemic of lung cancer in women.
Title: A Fatal Shift in Cancer's Gender Gap

Content: Before there was Betty Ford, the outspoken first lady who brought breast cancer awareness to the wider public, there was Babette Rosmond, a diminutive New York City writer and editor who went public with her diagnosis of breast cancer 40 years ago, three and a half years before the first lady. If Mrs. Ford is remembered for her grace and honesty, we should remember Ms. Rosmond for her courage and persistence. What Ms. Rosmond demanded of her doctors — the right to choose her cancer treatment — is now the minimum that cancer patients deserve.
Title: The Right to Choose Your Cancer Treatment

Content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg underwent surgery at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York on Thursday for what was apparently early-stage pancreatic cancer, according to a statement released by the Supreme Court.
Title: Ginsburg Has Surgery for Pancreatic Cancer

Content: “I’m scheduling your orchiectomy in two days,” my oncologist told me, only minutes after handing me a diagnosis of testicular cancer. With that, he added a new word to my vocabulary: “Or·chi·ec·to·my: Excision of one or both testicles. Castration.”
Title: Young, Gay and Blaming Myself for Cancer

Content: Lung cancer is such a remorseless killer that any gain against it is reason for applause. That is why the latest news about startling improvements in treating early-stage victims of the most common form of lung cancer is especially heartening.
Title: Better Odds for Lung Cancer Victims

Content: THIS is a scary story with a happy ending. So far.
Title: Fighting Cancer, and the Bean-Counters

Content: Addressing a major unknown in the longstanding debate over mammograms, a new study sponsored by the National Cancer Institute found that the screening test contributed to a pronounced drop in the death rate from breast cancer.
Title: Mammograms Validated as Key In Cancer Fight

Content: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had radioactive seeds implanted in his prostate gland early yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center, then appeared six hours later at a news conference with the relief and good humor of a patient who had gone through a cancer treatment that was not as bad as he had feared.
Title: MAYOR UNDERGOES CANCER TREATMENT

Content: Many people associate palliative care with hospice care, but medical professionals are offering it to children and adolescents living with cancer as well as to those dying from it.
Title: For Kids With Cancer, Focusing on Quality of Life

Content: Lynsey Addario, a contract photographer for The New York Times, went to Uganda in July on assignment with Denise Grady, who was pursuing a story about early cancer detection and treatment in Uganda. An interactive feature, where you can share your own stories about surviving breast cancer or stories about someone you know who has or had breast cancer, is viewable here, and Ms. Grady’s story appears in Wednesday’s paper. Ms. Addario, reached via phone from London, where she lives, spoke with James Estrin. Their conversation has been edited.
Title: Breast Cancer as Death Sentence in Uganda

Content: MaryBeth Zea of Little Falls, Minn., was only 28, married but childless, when breast cancer struck in 1988. The surgeon who performed her mastectomy told her that because her cancer was not hormone-sensitive, pregnancy would probably not make much difference to her chances of a recurrence. He told her that pregnancy was a personal choice.
Title: Cancer and Childbirth: Mutually Exclusive No Longer

Content: Elliot was 83 when a routine checkup that included a digital rectal exam suggested prostate cancer. A biopsy then revealed that he had an aggressive form of the disease. His doctor recommended treatment despite Elliot’s age and several existing problems, including mild cases of high blood pressure, Type 2 diabetes, depression and angina, all of which were being treated with medication.
Title: No Single Path for Cancer Care in Elderly

Content: Married cancer patients live longer than single ones, presumably because they have a built-in support system, are more likely to stick to their treatment regimens, and may even be in better health to begin with. But among single patients, those who are separated at the time of diagnosis have the worst life expectancy, a new study reports.
Title: Patterns: Cancer Is Hardest on Separated Patients

Content: THE FACTS
Title: The Claim: Grapefruit Can Increase the Risk of Breast Cancer

Content: On a hot July day last summer, I was lying on the beach at Coney Island with my younger brother when he noticed a dark mole on the back of my arm. “You should really get that checked at the dermatologist,” he said in a worried tone.
Title: Skin Cancer on the Rise in Young Women

Content: In January, 2011, I wrote a piece, “Behind Toxic Headlines,” examining a burst of overwrought news coverage of a study finding traces of synthetic chemicals in blood and tissue samples from pregnant women.
Title: Meat, Cancer, Fear and Carcinogenic Headlines

Content: Women who gain weight shortly before or after menopause may increase their risk for breast cancer, a new study suggests, but losing weight after menopause may decrease their risk.
Title: Linking Menopause, Weight and Breast Cancer

Content: For the first time, researchers have decoded all the genes of a person with cancer and found a set of mutations that may have caused the disease or aided its progression.
Title: Scientists Decode Set of Cancer Genes

Content: For the last decade cancer research has been guided by a common vision of how a single cell, outcompeting its neighbors, evolves into a malignant tumor.
Title: Cancer’s Secrets Come Into Sharper Focus

Content: Children who undergo chemotherapy treatments for cancer have an increased risk of developing early heart disease, a new study suggests.
Title: Childhood Cancer Tied to Heart Risks

Content: Dr. George E. Moore, a versatile cancer researcher who found an early association between chewing tobacco and mouth cancer while directing the Roswell Park Cancer Institute, a state-financed research center in Buffalo, died on May 19 in Evergreen, Colo. He was 88 and lived in Conifer, Colo.
Title: George E. Moore, 88, Cancer Researcher, Is Dead

Content: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.
Title: What to Ask About Lung Cancer

Content: A new study suggests that having many siblings may increase the risk for certain stomach cancers and that younger siblings may be more at risk than older ones.
Title: At Risk: Some Cancers May Be Tied to Family Size

Content: The vigilant man who has taken care of me for five years of cancer treatment slipped on a step three days ago. It was like seeing an eagle shot down. He had to have the tendon in his left knee repaired. Hunched on a chair in our kitchen, he glares at me like a wild thing trapped.
Title: Living With Cancer: Becoming a Caregiver

Content: A new study on the artificial sweetener aspartame may make diet soda lovers breathe a little easier.
Title: Study Finds No Cancer Link to Sweetener

Content: CLEMSON, S.C. — Clemson Coach Oliver Purnell and his wife, Vicky, presented a $100,000 check to the Coaches vs. Cancer on the floor of Littlejohn Coliseum before a 78-68 loss to undefeated Wake Forest on Saturday.
Title: Clemson Coach Reflects on Cancer’s Reach

Content: ATLANTIC CITY — Successful trials of a blood test to detect cancer were reported here yesterday [April 14] by a U.S. Public Health Service doctor. The test, which depends on labeling red blood cells with a radioactive isotope, was given to 79 subjects. It should cost less than $10 to administer, according to Dr. John M. Vogel, of San Francisco, who has been testing it. Dr. Vogel reported the results of the cancer test before a session of the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 16, 1965.
Title: 1965: Blood Test for Cancer Is Cited

Content: People whose faces turn red when they drink alcohol may be facing more than embarrassment. The flushing may indicate an increased risk for a deadly throat cancer, researchers report.
Title: Drinkers’ Red Face May Signal Cancer Risk

Content: Hormone treatment after menopause, already known to increase the risk of breast cancer, also makes it more likely that the cancer will be advanced and deadly, a study finds.
Title: Breast Cancer Seen as Riskier With Hormone

Content: Death so often seems senseless  except on television.
Title: It’s Hello Cancer, Goodbye Inhibitions

Content: Enthusiasm for cancer immunotherapy is soaring, and so is Arie Belldegrun’s fortune.
Title: Harnessing the U.S. Taxpayer to Fight Cancer and Make Profits

Content: Tom Glavine played host to several children with cancer yesterday at the Mets-Padres game at Shea Stadium and disclosed how he has helped to make fighting the disease a priority in the Commissioner's Initiative for Kids Program.
Title: Glavine Helps Fight Pediatric Cancer

Content: Oncology nurse Theresa Brown is a regular contributor to the Well blog.
Title: Treatment for Cancer Might Kill You

Content: This week in my Shifting Careers column, I wrote about businesses that owe their existence to their founders’ experiences with breast cancer. Most entrepreneurs start a business because they want to take control of their lives or solve a problem, and that was the case with all of the women I talked to for this story. Some, like Banu Ozden and Rachel Troxell, were far from putting their cancer behind them. Yet they choose to spend their days working on something that they believe will make life easier for others battling illness.
Title: Businesses and Blogs in Breast Cancer’s Wake
2nd look at prostate cancer test

Content: The nearly 240,000 men in the United States who will learn they have prostate cancer this year have one more thing to worry about: Are their doctors making treatment decisions on the basis of money as much as medicine?
Title: Profit and Questions on Prostate Cancer Therapy

Content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg underwent surgery at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York on Thursday for what was apparently early-stage pancreatic cancer, according to a statement released by the Supreme Court.
Title: Ginsburg has surgery for pancreatic cancer

Content: More than 7 percent of cancer cases in the United States are attributable to excess body weight, a new study reports.
Title: Excess Weight Contributes to More Than 7 Percent of Cancers

Content: Scientists have discovered a previously unknown virus and strongly linked it with the most aggressive form of skin cancer, they reported in a scientific journal on Thursday.
Title: Virus Is Linked to a Powerful Skin Cancer

Content: Ten thousand dollars once seemed a lot to pay for a few months' supply of a drug.
Title: Cancer Drugs Offer Hope, butat a Huge Expense

Content: Even a small amount of exercise -- as little as three hours of walking a week -- significantly extends survival among breast cancer patients, a study in the May 25 issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association has found.
Title: Regimens: Another Stride Against Cancer

Content: This past weekend, the N.F.L. swirled pink into their sweat bands and quarterback hats, shoes and jerseys to raise awareness of breast cancer.
Title: High School Raises Cancer Awareness

Content: A survey of 500 cancer survivors found that more than half of them delayed seeking treatment for two months or more despite having symptoms of their disease.
Title: Fear and Procrastination Delay Cancer Diagnoses

Content: After a Long Island advocate for breast cancer research was quoted as saying she was sorry she made a commercial criticizing Senator John McCain's votes on research programs, Gov. George E. Pataki's office released a letter last night from the woman defending her involvement in electoral politics.
Title: Breast Cancer and Politics II

Content: The Environmental Protection Agency’s revised rule on arsenic contamination in drinking water has resulted in fewer lung, bladder and skin cancers.
Title: Arsenic Reductions in Drinking Water Tied to Fewer Cancer Deaths

Content: GlaxoSmithKline won permission yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration to sell a tumor-growth inhibitor called Tykerb to treat breast cancer.
Title: F.D.A. Approves Glaxo Cancer Drug

Content: I first met my patient, a man in his late 80s, in 2012, when he had been living with myelodysplastic syndromes, a form of bone marrow cancer, for five years — longer than the average survival for those diagnosed with the condition. He was a former high school math teacher who was unerringly precise about his laboratory values. He also had a spark to him that no cancer could extinguish.
Title: A ‘Sentimental Journey’ in the Cancer Clinic

Content: In a marriage of the nation's two largest cancer-management companies, American Oncology Resources Inc. has agreed to acquire Physician Reliance Network Inc. for $655 million plus assumed debt of $60 million. The combined company will have exclusive contracts with 700 oncologists and other cancer specialists, or more than 9 percent of the 7,500 cancer physicians in the country. The combined company will be based in Houston. Under the agreement, each Physician Reliance share will be exchanged for 0.94 share of American Oncology. Shareholders of each company will own about 50 percent of the company.
Title: LARGEST CANCER-MANAGEMENT COMPANIES TO MERGE

Content: Long-term use of aspirin was linked to an increased risk of pancreatic cancer in an 18-year study of more than 88,000 women, researchers reported yesterday.
Title: Long Aspirin Use Tied to a Cancer

Content: A Princeton, N.J., biotechnology company, Medarex, said it had begun clinical trials of a drug to treat prostate cancer only 12 months after identifying the target in the body on which the drug will act. It usually takes several years to formulate a drug and test it on animals before starting trials in people. Medarex's unusual speed stems from its use of genetically altered mice that can produce human antibodies in as little as two to three months. The antibody, which then is tested in animals, is used as the drug. Shares of Medarex rose $5.94, to $88.31. Andrew Pollack
Title: FAST TRACK FOR CANCER DRUG

Content: Senator John McCain of Arizona sailed through five and a half hours of surgery for two malignant melanomas today without complications and with no immediate indication that the cancer had spread, his doctors said.
Title: No Complications in McCain Cancer Surgery

Content: The links will spawn new windows.
Title: Men's Health Resources: Colorectal Cancer

Content: Each October, Madison Avenue not only thinks pink, it turns pink, as marketers seek to show how much they support the fight against breast cancer. Products are re-dressed in pink packaging, appliances are sold with pink tints, pink ribbons festoon apparel and some newspapers even tint their pages pink.
Title: Fight Breast Cancer? I’ll Drink to That

Content: The links will spawn new windows .
Title: Women's Health Resources: Ovarian Cancer

Content: The Lubrizol Corporation, a maker of additives for lubricants and fuels, said yesterday that its chief executive, James L. Hambrick, 49, would begin treatment for testicular cancer. Mr. Hambrick plans to maintain daily responsibility for the company during his treatment, with assistance from the chairman, William Bares, Lubrizol said. Mr. Hambrick will undergo seven weeks of chemotherapy expected to eradicate the early-stage cancer, a spokesman said. The treatment will have no impact on the proposed acquisition of the closely held Noveon International Inc., the company said.
Title: Lubrizol Chief Executive Is Battling Cancer

Content: One senior banker, sipping his cup of espresso, sighed deeply when asked about the trust deficit in the financial industry these days.
Title: Subprime: The Lung Cancer of Banking?

Content: Brain tumors, often in the news, raise a frightening specter for the public. Recent reports that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is suffering from a brain tumor has raised the level of angst. To add to the anxiety, we are now being told that cellphones might be responsible for the increase in this type of cancer.
Title: Readers’ Questions: Options for Brain Cancer

Content: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. declared he wanted to “end cancer as we know it.”
Title: Biden Calls for a Cancer ‘Moon Shot’

Content: By using radio waves and magnetic fields to produce richly detailed images of soft tissue, magnetic resonance imaging can uncover breast abnormalities that cannot be seen with an ordinary mammogram.
Title: In New Cancer Guideline, a Host of Uncertainties

Content: Jeffrey C. Allen, 65, is a professor of pediatrics and neurology and the director of the division of neuro-oncology at the New York University Cancer Institute. He has helped train many specialists in his relatively new and small field.
Title: A Commitment to Fighting Childhood Cancer

Content: Why are so many mastectomies performed, when less invasive lumpectomies are often an alternative? A new study reports that part of the answer may lie with the patients.
Title: Choosing Breast Cancer Surgery

Content: A former nursing home owned by Essex County will be converted into the state's first freestanding cancer research and treatment center. Under the deal, the county will sell the Essex County Geriatric Center for $5 million to the Garden State Cancer Center, which now occupies space at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark. The cancer center is scheduled to open in 1999.
Title: New Home for Cancer Center

Content: When a woman finds out that she has breast cancer, fear and depression may be quickly followed by overwhelming confusion. There are so many decisions to make about surgery, radiation, types of chemotherapy and hormonal treatment that women may wonder how to make sure they really are getting the best, most up-to-date advice.
Title: Centers Publish Breast Cancer Guide

Content: The links will spawn new windows .
Title: Women's Health Resources: Colorectal Cancer

Content: Scientists are reporting today that they have created the first vaccine that appears able to prevent cervical cancer. The vaccine works by making people immune to a sexually transmitted virus that causes many cases of the disease.
Title: Vaccine Appears to Prevent Cervical Cancer

Content: An experimental vaccine to prevent cervical cancer, first proved effective in preliminary testing two years ago, has continued to provide protection against the disease, researchers reported yesterday.
Title: Vaccine Works to Prevent Cervical Cancer

Content: Fifty-five years ago, when I was 15, my mother made me promise that I would not commit suicide. I intend to keep that promise if and when I ask a doctor for passive assistance — ending life-sustaining support — or for active help: palliative sedation or a lethal prescription. To my mind, treating cancer pain aggressively even when it accelerates the dying process should not be equated with suicide.
Title: Living With Cancer: Deciding About Dying

Content: If his mother hadn’t struck up a conversation with a stranger in a waiting room, Dan Shapiro would never have become the biological father of Alexandra, 13, and Abigail, 9. Dan was a 20-year-old junior in college when doctors diagnosed stage 2 Hodgkin’s disease. His treatment was to be six cycles of highly toxic chemotherapy followed by radiation.
Title: Family Planning When Cancer Intrudes

Content: Lance Armstrong, the star American bicycle racer and former world champion, said from his home in Austin, Tex., yesterday that he has testicular cancer, that it has spread to his abdomen and lungs and that he started 12 weeks of chemotherapy on Monday.
Title: Armstrong Acknowledges Cancer Battle
