Content: The State Health Department today published breast cancer rates by ZIP code for the entire state, the first time such widespread mapping of a cancer has been produced in such detail.
Title: Breast Cancer Is Pinpointed By ZIP Code

Content: Several insurers have decided in recent weeks to pay for experimental treatments for cancer, but only for policyholders who participate in clinical trials sanctioned by federal health agencies.
Title: Insurers Are Covering Cancer Experiments

Content: Nonsmoking women in an area of China’s Yunnan province die of lung cancer at a rate 20 times that of their counterparts in other regions of the country  and higher than anywhere else in the world.
Title: Coal Is Linked to Cancer in China Province

Content: Some cancer patients on a common medication are being warned to stay away from St. John's wort, the herbal supplement often used as an antidepressant.
Title: Hazards: Keeping Cancer Drug Effective

Content: In a long-delayed harvest from the human genome project, researchers say they have found six new sites of variation in the genome that increase the risk of breast cancer.
Title: Scientists Explore Genetic Risk of Breast Cancer

Content: Listening to music may reduce anxiety and pain in cancer patients, new research suggests.
Title: Regimens: Soothing Melodies for Cancer Patients

Content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg underwent surgery at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York on Thursday for what was apparently early-stage pancreatic cancer, according to a statement released by the Supreme Court.
Title: Ginsburg has surgery for pancreatic cancer

Content: If doctors began a broad screening program for early signs of melanoma, they might find any number of cases soon enough to save lives. But would it be worth the cost?
Title: Screening: Making a Case for Early Testing for Skin Cancer

Content: In Science Times today, Denise Grady explores the usefulness of breast cancer screening. Ms. Grady writes:
Title: Breast Cancer: Who Should Be Screened?

Content: Gestational diabetes may be associated with a substantially increased risk for pancreatic cancer, a new study has found.
Title: At Risk: Gestational Diabetes May Be Tied to Type of Cancer

Content: Scientific evidence has not shown that women can avoid the breast cancer risk from hormone replacement therapy by taking the drugs for only a short time, researchers said today. It also has not shown that the risk disappears as soon as the drugs are stopped.
Title: Cancer Risk Of Hormones May Linger

Content: Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.
Title: What to Ask about Cervical Cancer

Content: Two widely used treatments for breast cancer -- radiation and the drug Herceptin -- can cause heart problems, researchers are reporting.
Title: Treatments For Cancer Are Linked To Heart Ills

Content: Aspirin may help reduce the risk of colon cancer, a new study suggests, when taken in large doses over long periods of time.
Title: Nostrums: Aspirin May Reduce Risk of Colon Cancer

Content: The widely used genetic test for breast cancer risk can miss mutations that help cause the disease, according to a new study, a finding that is likely to increase the pressure to develop more thorough testing methods.
Title: Flaw Seen in Genetic Test for Breast Cancer Risk

Content: A new version of a screening test for ovarian cancer may reduce deaths from the disease, but it needs more study to determine whether the benefits hold up, researchers reported on Thursday.
Title: Early Detection of Ovarian Cancer May Become Possible

Content: You're a man, 65 years old, and you've been having trouble urinating. Your doctor tells you that you have a cancer in your prostate making the gland press on the tube that carries urine. The good news is that the cancer seems confined to your prostate; there is no evidence that it has spread.
Title: Dilemma on Prostate Cancer Treatment Splits Experts

Content: On the same day that some of Europe’s top teams in its most glamorous leagues will play in the lucrative UEFA Champions League, the continental federation cited five teams in four countries for fixing matches.
Title: UEFA Cites ‘Cancer’ in Soccer

Content: Shares of British Biotech P.L.C. soared 88 percent yesterday after the company said an interim look at early clinical results suggested that its drug might inhibit the growth of cancerous tumors.
Title: Biotech Surges On Cancer Trial

Content: The Pharmacia Corporation is ending clinical trials of a colorectal cancer drug under development by its subsidiary Sugen Inc., the company said yesterday. An interim analysis of trial data showed patients receiving the drug, semaxanib, along with chemotherapy showed no increased survival rate in advanced-stage colorectal cancer compared with those who received chemotherapy alone, Sugen's president, Laura K. Shawver, said. Semaxanib was a pioneer drug in a class of compounds that cause tumors to starve. Ms. Shawver said the company would not try to redevelop semaxanib but would apply lessons learned to two other compounds it is developing.
Title: PHARMACIA STOPS TRIALS ON A CANCER DRUG

Content: The links will spawn new windows.
Title: Men's Health Resources: Prostate Cancer

Content: The taller a woman is, the greater her risk for cancer, a large study has found.
Title: Risks: Women’s Cancer Risk Increases With Height, Study Finds

Content: How aggressively to treat cancer in the elderly is a difficult question, but researchers from the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan who reviewed data on chemotherapy for colon cancer patients suggest that caution may be overdone.
Title: Fewer Options for Older Cancer Patients

Content: The links will spawn new windows .
Title: Women's Health Resources: Lung Cancer

Content: Recent research has been interpreted as suggesting that cellphones cause cancer. But Gina Kolata explains that the overwhelming evidence suggests that there is no link between the devices and the disease.
Title: Will Your Cellphone Give You Cancer?

Content: It is among the most delicate and difficult dilemmas in medicine: Should a pregnant woman who has received a cancer diagnosis begin treatment before her child is born? Some hesitant doctors counsel women to deliver preterm or even terminate the pregnancy first.
Title: Study Offers Support for Cancer Treatment During Pregnancy

Content: In contrast to the often repeated warnings about tanning and skin cancer, some scientists have been exploring an almost heretical notion: sunlight may actually protect against other cancers.
Title: Sunlight, a Cancer Protector in the Guise of a Villain?

Content: When Johana Calvache’s husband received a cancer diagnosis, she did not panic. Even though her daughter had lost her eyesight to the disease at age 4, she did not descend into self-pity. Her first instinct was to fight.
Title: A Couple Joined by Cancer, Bound by Love

Content: Seemingly overnight, treatment of men with early-stage prostate cancer has undergone a sea change. Five years ago, nearly all opted for surgery or radiation; now, nearly half are choosing no treatment at all.
Title: More Men With Early Prostate Cancer Are Choosing to Avoid Treatment

Content: BEIJING
Title: Living With Cancer, and Swimming in Its Shadow

Content: The logic has long sounded so compelling that few have questioned it: A particular protein seeps out of the prostate of a man who has prostate cancer. The more of that protein in the bloodstream, then, the worse it must be for the cancer patient.
Title: Marker For Cancer Of Prostate May Fight It

Content: Several years ago, I cared for a middle-aged doctor with colon cancer. The cancer was found in a routine physical examination. During an exploratory operation, the surgeons discovered that the cancer had spread to his liver. Like many cancer patients with no family history of the disease, the doctor experienced shock and disbelief. These emotions then gave way to a profound sense of guilt.
Title: Your Cancer Isn't Your Fault

Content: Researchers have discovered a way to identify drugs that can specifically attack and kill cancer stem cells, a finding that could lead to a new generation of anticancer medicines and a new strategy of treatment.
Title: Screening Could Lead to More Potent Cancer Drugs

Content: Finding out I had breast cancer came as a shock. But the really rude awakening was learning I’m not middle class anymore.
Title: Cancer I Can’t Afford

Content: THE calendar says summer is drawing to a close, but the Pediatric Cancer Foundation here is just beginning to celebrate the season.
Title: Swimming and Raising Money for Pediatric Cancer

Content: Eating substantial amounts of fruits and vegetables may lower the risk for breast cancer, a new study has found, and some kinds may be more effective than others.
Title: Cauliflower, Kale and Carrots May Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Two women in my cancer support group died last year; both were considerably younger than I am. Furious at the disease, I’m starting the new year with a yowl.
Title: A Cancer Rap, With Thanks to Nina Simone

Content: Psychologists are beginning to verify what many breast cancer survivors have long suspected: chemotherapy can, in some cases, cause problems with memory and concentration.
Title: Memory Problems Linked to Cancer Treatment

Content: WAYNE, Pa. — Before Mark Herzlich became the linebacker who overcame cancer, he was another football prodigy with a familiar dream.
Title: After Cancer, an Ex-Prodigy Was Undrafted but Unbowed

Content: SAN DIEGO  Pfizer’s fortunes in the past were built on cardiovascular drugs, like the cholesterol buster Lipitor and the blood pressure pill Norvasc.
Title: For Profit, Industry Seeks Cancer Drugs

Content: A new genetic test that tries to predict whether a woman with breast cancer will have a relapse won approval yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration, marking a step toward an era in which medical treatments are personalized for each patient.
Title: Test to Predict Breast Cancer Relapse Is Approved

Content: WOMEN flock to his lectures, buy out benefits honoring him, contrive to throw him fund-raising parties. The well and the sick, the wealthy and the accomplished, they worship him. He has treated Linda Ellerbee and Linda McCartney. At one dinner to honor him this month, Carly Simon sat at his table and Bette Midler yanked him onstage for a jitterbug. As Evelyn H. Lauder, whose Breast Cancer Research Foundation was the beneficiary of that dinner, put it, ''The Larry Norton groupies were coming out of the walls!''
Title: A Cancer Doctor Mindful of Body and Soul

Content: Two years ago, I spent a week in Houston helping my stepbrother while he underwent treatment for Stage 4 lymphoma at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. I sat with him while a nurse cleaned his chemo port and made records of her work, to keep his medical team updated. I accompanied him for the blood tests that determined his readiness for the next treatment. I stayed by his bed as his stem cells were harvested for a transplant, one of the cutting-edge, evidence-based therapies that ultimately saved his life.
Title: Treat Addiction Like Cancer

Content: Not long ago, I asked a respected cancer researcher if he could send me raw data from a trial he had recently published. He refused. Sharing data would make the study team members “uncomfortable,” he said, as I might use this to “cast doubt” on their results.
Title: Cancer Data? Sorry, Can’t Have It

Content: It was a desperate measure, for a desperate disease. Fourteen months ago, Dennis Sugrue let doctors thread a fine tube through his blood vessels and up into his head, so they could spray the drug Avastin directly into the part of his brain where a tumor had been cut out. It was an experiment, devised mainly to find out whether the procedure was safe, and to gauge how much Avastin the brain could tolerate. But Mr. Sugrue, then 50, was hoping the experiment would also free him of cancer.
Title: A Direct Hit of Drugs to Treat Brain Cancer

Content: It was a slow day on the floor and my patient, whose hair was falling out from chemo, had just asked me to shave his head.
Title: Shaving the Head of a Cancer Patient

Content: One of the most respected and influential groups in the continuing breast-cancer screening debate said on Tuesday that women should begin mammograms later and have them less frequently than it had long advocated.
Title: American Cancer Society, in a Shift, Recommends Fewer Mammograms

Content: Women who gain weight shortly before or after menopause may increase their risk for breast cancer, a new study suggests, but losing weight after menopause may decrease their risk.
Title: Linking Menopause, Weight and Breast Cancer

Content: “How are you doing?” is a complicated question for a cancer patient.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Keeping Cancer at Bay

Content: Genentech won federal approval Friday for a new drug to treat advanced breast cancer. But the company said it was experiencing manufacturing problems that could lead to a shortage of the drug.
Title: Genentech Wins Approval for New Breast Cancer Drug

Content: Thousands of people who have cancer, who have overcome it, who have lost friends and relatives to the disease or are working in laboratories to conquer it marched in the nation's capital today to seek more money for research.
Title: Rallying to Increase Aid for Cancer Research

Content: The chairman of Samsung Group, Lee Kun Hee, who is currently staying in Houston, has lung cancer, South Korean media reported. News reports said Mr. Lee has been undergoing chemotherapy in the United States since Sunday. The chairman checked in at the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston in early December of last year and underwent a series of tests early this year.
Title: SAMSUNG CHAIRMAN HAS CANCER

Content: When Kyle Potvin learned she had breast cancer at the age of 41, she tracked the details of her illness and treatment in a journal. But when it came to grappling with issues of mortality, fear and hope, she found that her best outlet was poetry.
Title: Finding Poetry in Cancer

Content: Cities often undertake campaigns to fight crime or litter.
Title: Boston Battles Cancer With a Citywide Mailing

Content: IT'S not every day that Donna Karan acts as a stylist for anyone but a runway model. But on an August afternoon on Terry Lane in East Hampton, Ms. Karan found herself at the home of Elizabeth Tilberis, the editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, counseling women on what to buy and how to wear it, and draping her sweaters over Hamptons-tan passers-by with the ardor of a SoHo street vendor. The event was a garage sale to benefit the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, an organization presided over by Ms. Tilberis.
Title: Making a Fight Against Cancer Fashionable

Content: More than five years after Medicare began paying for screenings for colon cancer, many people are still not being tested, especially those who are not white.
Title: Screening: Many Still Forgoing Tests for Colon Cancer

Content: The first question many cancer patients are asked at a doctor’s office or an infusion center is “Do you have a port?” I shake my head no, but add the words “not yet.” To port or not to port: That is the question facing me when I arrive on the hospital hall dedicated to clinical trials.
Title: Needles or Port? A Cancer Patient Decides

Content: In a radio advertisement playing in New Hampshire and in speeches along the campaign trail, Rudolph W. Giuliani has cited statistics to cut at the heart of his Democratic rivals’ health care proposals, which he has derided as European-style “socialist” plans that will lower the standard of care in the United States.
Title: Giuliani’s Prostate Cancer Figure Is Disputed

Content: The search for environmental causes for a supposed breast cancer epidemic on Long Island is beginning to look like a wild goose chase. The cornerstone study in a $30 million federal effort to unravel the contentious issue reported this month that it could find no link between breast cancer and the prime environmental suspects, such as DDT and PCB's. It identified only a modest link, possibly due to chance, to pollutants in car exhaust and cigarette smoke. More results are still to be published, and breast cancer activists are calling for yet more investigations into a wider array of chemicals. But the negative findings suggest it is time to rein in this fruitless quest. There may simply be no significant environmental cause of breast cancer on Long Island, or if there is, it may be undetectable.
Title: Breast Cancer Mythology on Long Island

Content: About five years ago, Patricia Workman’s bones started breaking, and she was found to have multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow. At the same time, her skin cancer started to proliferate, leaving her face so scarred that she needed reconstructive surgery and still hides it with dark glasses.
Title: Logistics Hang Over a Ruling on 9/11 Cancer

Content: Though more than one-third of patients 85 or older in veterans hospitals receive tests for prostate-specific antigen, or P.S.A., the cancer marker, researchers report, no professional associations or advocacy groups recommend the test for that age group. And there is no evidence that such patients benefit from treatment of prostate cancer if it is found by the test.
Title: Testing: V.A. Hospitals May Screen Needlessly for Cancer

Content: Every week, Times editor Dana Jennings writes about coping with the treatment and side effects of prostate cancer.
Title: After Prostate Cancer Treatment, Uncertainty

Content: People with incurable cancer do sometimes receive good news, as I have. Why is it harder for me to share good news than bad news? During treatment, good news produces elating highs, but also anxious lows.
Title: Living With Cancer: Good News Soup

Content: A new drug that unleashes the body’s immune system to attack tumors can prolong the lives of people with the most common form of lung cancer, doctors reported on Friday, the latest example of the significant results being achieved by this new class of medicines.
Title: New Class of Drugs Shows More Promise in Treating Cancer

Content: About 1 in 400 women carry genetic mutations that put them at high risk for breast and ovarian cancer. For these women, doctors may recommend prophylactic mastectomy and oophorectomy, or removal of the ovaries  even before there is any sign of cancer.
Title: Prevention: Surgery Sharply Reduces Risk of 2 Cancers

Content: Every week, New York Times editor Dana Jennings shares his experiences coping with prostate cancer.
Title: Getting Angry About Prostate Cancer

Content: With more older Americans needing cancer therapy, oncologists are having increasing difficulty in determining the safest and most effective drug regimens for them, experts reported here today.
Title: Treating Cancer in Elderly Baffles Experts

Content: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 8 - Lt. Gov. Winthrop Paul Rockefeller returned to his home here on Saturday after months of treatment at a Seattle cancer clinic, including two bone marrow transplants that failed to cure a blood disease that can lead to leukemia, a spokesman for his family said.
Title: Arkansas Official Leaves Cancer Clinic

Content: Cancer experts said Tuesday that the actress and filmmaker Angelina Jolie Pitt was wise to have had her ovaries and fallopian tubes removed last week because she carries a genetic mutation, BRCA1, that significantly increases the risk of ovarian cancer, a disease so difficult to detect that it is often found only at an advanced, untreatable stage.
Title: Experts Back Angelina Jolie Pitt in Choices for Cancer Prevention

Content: Prickly, frozen, cramped, numb: my feet ache as if they were tightly bound in plastic wrap or affixed on cardboard, or I don’t feel them at all. Several years ago I was infused with a standard form of chemotherapy that causes what oncologists call peripheral neuropathies. Side effects have turned into permanent after-effects.
Title: Living With Cancer: Chemo-Feet

Content: A medical device that can add years to the lives of cancer patients is about to become unavailable, because its manufacturer has decided to stop producing it.
Title: A Lifesaving Pump for Cancer Patients Is Being Phased Out

Content: For years, newspaper columnist Al Martinez has shared stories about his children with readers. In today’s Los Angeles Times, Mr. Martinez is asking his readers to share their own stories of hope.
Title: A Father Struggles With His Daughter’s Cancer

Content: From today’s mailbag, another response to Pogue’s Imponderables. I’m sure some readers still won’t be convinced–that’s why it’s an imponderable–but the two medical studies cited here are pretty darned convincing to me. (p.s… The excerpts from the studies are filled with medical jargon; I added the boldface formatting.)
Title: Cellphones and Brain Cancer: A Doctor Weighs In

Content: MORE than one million people in the Chinese city of Handan awoke last week to the alarming news that an essential source of their drinking water, the Zhouzhang River, had been dangerously contaminated by a 39-ton chemical spill in the nearby city of Changzhi. What made the news even more shocking was that the leak, from a factory pipe, had started at least five days earlier but had been kept secret by government officials, who allowed millions of their neighbors to keep drinking.
Title: A Cancer Cycle, From Here to China

Content: With the cost of some lifesaving cancer drugs exceeding $100,000 a year, more than 100 influential cancer specialists from around the world have taken the unusual step of banding together in hopes of persuading some leading pharmaceutical companies to bring prices down.
Title: Doctors Denounce Cancer Drug Prices of $100,000 a Year

Content: Fear of developing an asbestos-related cancer should not be the basis for awarding damages even to those workers who have already contracted a noncancerous lung disease from their exposure to the toxic substance, a lawyer representing defendants in asbestos lawsuits told the Supreme Court today.
Title: Asbestos Appeal Centers on Fear of Cancer

Content: As surprised researchers have discovered, some people with autism have mutated cancer or tumor genes that apparently caused their brain disorder.
Title: Autism's Unexpected Link to Cancer Genes

Content: Chemotherapy failed to thwart Erika Hurwitz’s rare cancer of white blood cells. So her doctors offered her another option, a drug for melanoma. The result was astonishing.
Title: A Faster Way to Try Many Drugs on Many Cancers

Content: Many women at risk for breast cancer refuse to undergo M.R.I. screening, often saying they have claustrophobia and cannot tolerate the closed machines required for breast imaging, a new study says.
Title: Screening: Skipping M.R.I. Tests for Breast Cancer

Content: Fear of breast cancer is widespread, yet many women don’t realize that adopting protective living habits may help keep it at bay. The habits described below may also help to ward off other life-threatening ills, like heart disease and diabetes.
Title: You Can Take Steps to Lower Your Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Seeking to better understand the origins of breast cancer, researchers have begun to look as far back as the womb to identify prenatal factors and childhood experiences, including birth weight, diet and exercise patterns, that may affect a woman's risk of developing breast cancer.
Title: Risks For Cancer Can Start In Womb

Content: Many Americans take aspirin to lower their risk of heart disease, but a new study suggests a remarkable added benefit, reporting that patients who took aspirin regularly for a period of several years were 21 percent less likely decades later to die of solid tumor cancers, including cancers of the stomach, esophagus and lung.
Title: Aspirin Helps in Reducing Cancer Deaths, a Study Finds

Content: DOCTORS doing a needle biopsy to analyze tissue for cancer may one day add a second step to the procedure: depositing a tiny device at the site to report on growth of a tumor  and even the effects of chemotherapy.
Title: Beyond the Biopsy: A Tiny Monitor for Cancer

Content: The incidence of mouth and throat cancers caused by the human papillomavirus in men has now surpassed the incidence of HPV-related cervical cancers in women, researchers report.
Title: 7 Million American Men Carry Cancer-Causing HPV

Content: AS regional competition for cancer patients increases and cancer care rapidly evolves, North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System is taking steps to solidify its position as Long Island's largest health organization and a center for cancer treatment.
Title: Hospital System Strengthens Cancer Care

Content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court was operated on for colon cancer here today, the Supreme Court announced.
Title: Ruth Ginsburg Has Surgery For Cancer

Content: Cancer survivors often complain about “chemo brain,” a mental fog and inability to concentrate that persist long after treatment. But the problem may not be limited to cancer patients who undergo chemotherapy, a study suggests.
Title: Mental Health: Fog May Be From Cancer, Not the Chemo

Content: The Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation awards — often called the “American Nobels” in medical science — were announced Monday morning, and one of the winners used the spotlight to call for greatly widening the use of genetic screening for breast and ovarian cancer.
Title: Lasker Winner Calls for More Genetic Testing for Cancer

Content: The widely used genetic test for breast cancer risk can miss mutations that help cause the disease, according to a new study, a finding that is likely to increase the pressure to develop more thorough testing methods.
Title: Flaw Seen in Genetic Test for Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Amy Langford was utterly surprised when, at 42, she found out she was pregnant. Her joy dissipated a few weeks later, when she and her husband were told that a suspicious lump in her right breast was cancerous.
Title: New Notions on Pregnant Women With Cancer

Content: In a new radio ad, Rudolph W. Giuliani takes a swipe at two of his favorite targets: Hillary Rodham Clinton and health care in Europe.
Title: Giuliani Discusses Cancer in Radio Ad

Content: Shares of the Dyax Corporation, a developer of drugs to treat cancer and inflammation, plunged after the company said its recombinant protein DX-88 had been put on clinical suspension by the Food and Drug Administration. Shares of Dyax, based in Cambridge, Mass., tumbled $4.15, or 29 percent, to $10.26 a share. The suspension will be in effect until the company answers questions related to results of animal studies, Dyax said. The company is developing DX-88 in a venture with the Genzyme Corporation for the treatment of hereditary angioedema, a genetic disorder that leads to swelling and inflammation in body parts. The protein is in the second of three stages of human testing for F.D.A. review.
Title: F.D.A. SUSPENDS DYAX CANCER TREATMENT

Content: Updated, 6:32 p.m.
Title: Expert on Asbestos and Cancer Takes Questions

Content: Children being treated for cancer are far more resilient psychologically and socially than most adults, including oncologists, would expect. In fact, they seem to function better socially and do as well emotionally as healthy children.
Title: Children With Cancer Found Well Adjusted

Content: As Chuck Peal lay in a Waterbury, Conn., emergency room one Sunday in early September, doctors furiously tried to make sense of his symptoms. Mr. Peal, 61, appeared to be dying, and they were not sure why.
Title: Immune System, Unleashed by Cancer Therapies, Can Attack Organs

Content: Molecular Insight Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology development company, reported positive results from a clinical trial of a treatment that detects prostate cancer, setting off a 65 percent gain in its share price. The company released the results of the early stage trial of the treatment, called Trofex, after the market closed Thursday. On Friday, shares of Molecular Insight, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., rose 50 cents, to $1.27. The news came a week after Nasdaq told Molecular Insight that it was in danger of being delisted because the company’s stock had remained below $1 a share for 30 consecutive business days. Also on Friday, the company said it had reached an agreement to extend a waiver with bondholders to allow debt restructuring negotiations to continue until next Friday.
Title: Biotech Company Gains on Prostate Cancer Trial

Content: Over the past few months, a number of headlines in The New York Times have stumped me.
Title: Living With Cancer: Brains on Chemo

Content: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 8 — Lt. Gov. Winthrop Paul Rockefeller returned to his home here on Saturday after months of treatment at a Seattle cancer clinic, including two bone marrow transplants that failed to cure a blood disease that can lead to leukemia, a spokesman for his family said.
Title: Arkansas Official Leaves Cancer Clinic

Content: STONY BROOK, N.Y. — Yan Leyfman was born in Belarus in 1989, three years after the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. His family lived only about 75 miles from the nuclear plant, and as a toddler, Mr. Leyfman had a constellation of mysterious symptoms: cysts that covered his entire body, fingernails that fell out, limbs that were swollen and skin that itched torturously.
Title: Chernobyl Behind Him, Student Takes on Cancer

Content: Hormone therapy to shrink or slow the growth of prostate cancer is one of the most common treatments for the disease. New York Times editor Dana Jennings, who was diagnosed with prostate cancer earlier this year, talks about his own treatment with the drug Lupron.
Title: Real Men Get Prostate Cancer

Content: When talking to patients about a rare type of cancer linked to breast implants, plastic surgeons should call it “a condition” and avoid using the words cancer, tumor, disease or malignancy, the president of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons advised members during an online seminar on Feb. 3.
Title: Dispute Over Cancer Tied to Implants

Content: When the nation’s pre-eminent breast cancer advocacy group, the Susan G. Komen for the Cure foundation, decided to stop most of its financing of Planned Parenthood in December, Komen’s leaders hoped to quietly distance the foundation from a politically controversial organization that they feared was costing them support and donations, a board member said.
Title: Cancer Group Backs Down on Cutting Off Planned Parenthood

Content: The first immune-based treatment for lung cancer won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday, and it could displace more conventional chemotherapy for certain patients, at least.
Title: Lung Cancer Treatment Using Immune System Wins F.D.A. Approval

Content: MALIGNANT Medical Ethicists Confront Cancer.
Title: Assumptions and Attitudes Don’t Survive Cancer

Content: For the first time ever, three pharmaceutical companies are poised to test whether new drugs can work against a wide range of cancers independently of where they originated — breast, prostate, liver, lung. The drugs go after an aberration involving a cancer gene fundamental to tumor growth. Many scientists see this as the beginning of a new genetic age in cancer research.
Title: Drugs Aim to Make Several Types of Cancer Self-Destruct

Content: LAST April, Thomas Bolduc, 65, called his brother Ernie, 72, from the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. Mr. Bolduc had prostate cancer. He was recovering from radiation on his prostate -- the walnut-shaped gland located just beneath his bladder.
Title: Support Group for Men With Prostate Cancer

Content: Researchers have found that combining a new drug with the standard ones can more effectively slow end- stage colorectal cancer and slightly prolong victims' lives.
Title: Mix of Drugs Slows Cancer of the Colon

Content: PHILADELPHIA — A year ago, when chemotherapy stopped working against his leukemia, William Ludwig signed up to be the first patient treated in a bold experiment at the University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Ludwig, then 65, a retired corrections officer from Bridgeton, N.J., felt his life draining away and thought he had nothing to lose.
Title: An Immune System Trained to Kill Cancer

Content: HOUSTON, Feb. 2 — Texas on Friday became the first state to require all 11- and 12-year-old girls entering the sixth grade to be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer.
Title: Texas Is First to Require Cancer Shots for Schoolgirls

Content: When people choose to have their leukemia treated aggressively, it’s a big commitment, more so than for almost any other cancer.
Title: Seeking Calm on the Cancer Ward

Content: A cancer patient underwent the Hipec treatment, a controversial process that involves surgery to remove visible tumors in the abdomen, followed by the dousing of the abdominal cavity in a hot chemotherapy bath.
Title: A Controversial Cancer Treatment, Step by Step

Content: An estimated 30,000 men who have had surgery for prostate cancer will relapse this year, and half of them will die. But many of those patients can be saved, a new study says, if doctors treat them with radiation therapy at the earliest signs of recurrence.
Title: Advice for Treating Prostate Cancer Revival

Content: Hormone therapy to shrink or slow the growth of prostate cancer is one of the most common treatments for the disease. New York Times editor Dana Jennings, who was diagnosed with prostate cancer earlier this year, talks about his own treatment with the drug Lupron.  By Dana Jennings   The day after my most recent hormone injection for prostate cancer, I told my wife, Deb, that I had a headache, hot flashes, cramps and was very, very hungry.  (Photo: Dana Jennings. (Lonnie Schlein/The New York Times))   She said, "Sweetie, you're having your period." We both laughed. (Laughter is a crucial therapy in my treatment.)   Those are just a few of the side effects I've been experiencing on Lupron, which is part of the hormonal treatment for my advanced case of prostate cancer. Lupron is a testosterone suppressant, designed to starve hormone-dependent cancer cells of the fuel (testosterone) that they crave in order to grow. My doctors believe, and studies indicate, that using hormonal therapy to complement my radiation treatments, which are scheduled to start next month, will give me a better chance of being cured, of survival.   In the past couple weeks, I've also had back, joint and muscle aches, random itchiness: that spider-crawling-on-your-skin feeling, cotton mouth, sudden fatigue and fleeting bursts of pain in my jaw, chest and armpits. These are not complaints, just observations.   Oh, and my testicles are shrinking. There's also intermittent testicle tenderness and, sometimes, they get so warm they feel as if they're on simmer. And the most unexpected side effect, so far, is that sometimes during sex, a Lupron headache suddenly descends and hammers at my skull.   Essentially, my Lupron shots are inducing biochemical (but reversible) castration. Besides the hot flashes and shrinking testicles, another potential side effect is that a man's breasts grow larger and more sensitive. Now, I'll tell you straight up, no doctor ever sits you down and says, "Son, to cure you, we might have to kind of turn you into a woman." I suspect that some men would almost rather die than have hot flashes and larger breasts.    Prostate Cancer Journal  One Man's Story
Title: Real Men Get Prostate Cancer

Content: I’ve been thinking a lot about gratitude lately, trying to put my finger on what exactly I’m grateful for in the year since I had surgery to remove my cancerous prostate.
Title: After Cancer, Gratitude for Simple Pleasures

Content: People have been searching for new medicines for thousands of years, and yet we have barely explored the universe of possibilities. Recently chemists at the University of Bern in Switzerland tried to estimate how many promising molecules have yet to be tested. In June they published their best guess: over a million billion billion billion billion billion billion. Blindly testing those molecules one at a time is not practical, and most of them will turn out to be useless anyway. So many scientists are looking for strategies they can use to zero in more quickly on promising candidates.
Title: Gene Tests in Yeast Aid Work on Cancer

Content: Through two seasons, “Vice,” the newsmagazine assembled by Vice Media and carried by HBO, has been a travelogue for the gonzo armchair tourist. It circles the globe to report on every variety of crisis — wars, drugs, the environment, rape in India, desperate bachelors in China.
Title: Enlisting Viruses as Commandos in a War on Cancer

Content: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, maker of the No. 1 cancer drug, Taxol, said yesterday that it was seeking Federal approval for the use of Taxol with Herceptin, made by Genentech Inc., in the treatment of breast cancer.
Title: Metro Business; Combining Cancer Drugs

Content: Amy Langford was utterly surprised when, at 42, she found out she was pregnant. Her joy dissipated a few weeks later, when she and her husband were told that a suspicious lump in her right breast was cancerous.
Title: New Notions on Pregnant Women With Cancer

Content: Former President Jimmy Carter announced to his church in Plains, Ga., on Sunday that his latest brain scan showed no signs of cancer.
Title: Carter Says He Is Free of Cancer

Content: As a medical student 20 years ago, I learned all about anatomy, physiology and pharmacology. My professors also taught me, implicitly, how to put on the white doctor coat as a shield against human vulnerability. With the coat on, you could get right up close to frailty, even touch it, and it wouldn’t be able to reach out and pull you in.
Title: When the Doctor’s Wife Has Cancer

Content: Genentech said yesterday that approval of its colon cancer drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer would be delayed by at least a year because the Food and Drug Administration had asked for more data on safety and efficacy.
Title: Longer Delay for Genentech on New Use of Cancer Drug

Content: THE FACTS
Title: The Claim: Darker Skin Protects Against Skin Cancer

Content: IN June 1999, an otherwise healthy John Shea had a seizure at his home in Meriden. He was rushed to the hospital. The diagnosis: a rare form of cancer known as a glioblastoma multiforme.
Title: Rare Cancer Found in Workers

Content: Although scientific studies have linked the consumption of meat to cancer, in London, at least, people are skeptical about the findings.
Title: Some Doubt Meat’s Ties to Cancer

Content: Bikers found a worthy cause to rally for on Sunday when the Turpin Foundation held its first annual Graham Turpin Memorial Motorcycle Rally to support pancreatic cancer research.
Title: Engines Revved to Fight Pancreatic Cancer

Content: When I consider how this Hanukkah will be different from all other Hanukkahs, I wonder if my giddiness can be attributed to cancer and the treatments that have governed my life for the past five years.
Title: Living With Cancer: Giving Thanks and Latkes

Content: A new drug used to treat advanced prostate cancer may also help men if used early in the course of the disease, before an operation, researchers reported Wednesday.
Title: Trial Supports Earlier Use of a Prostate Cancer Drug

Content: Avon is doing more than calling these days. Charles Perrin, the company's chairman and chief executive, plans to lead hundreds of Avon employees, from senior management to sales people, who are walking, marching or jogging 55 miles in three days to raise money to fight breast cancer.
Title: Avon Joins the Fight Against Cancer

Content: Leap Year Day, 1986: I drove up to a ramshackle house in Berkeley to pick out my first dog. It was a month before my two-year cancer anniversary, at which point I would be considered “cured,” and I was ready to make a commitment – to life, longevity and a puppy.
Title: Committing to a Dog After Cancer

Content: Researchers have found the first direct evidence that a cancer-causing substance from tobacco is transmitted to fetuses by pregnant smokers.
Title: Cancer Agent Seen in Fetuses Of Smokers

Content: Marketers are signing up to support the second Stand Up to Cancer telethon, scheduled to be presented by multiple television networks and channels on Sept. 10.
Title: Marketers Take a ‘Stand’ Against Cancer

Content: The maps issued this month by the state Department of Health showing the incidence of breast cancer by ZIP Code described only one area in Nassau -- Oyster Bay -- where the cases exceeded the ''expected'' rate by more than 50 percent. This was in sharp contrast with Suffolk, where 11 areas showed such elevated incidence. (Details of the survey of Suffolk were published in the Long Island section last Sunday.)
Title: Breast Cancer in Nassau, 1993-97

Content: BETHESDA, Md. — Mary Pazdur had exhausted the usual drugs for ovarian cancer, and with her tumors growing and her condition deteriorating, her last hope seemed to be an experimental compound that had yet to be approved by federal regulators.
Title: F.D.A. Regulator, Widowed by Cancer, Helps Speed Drug Approval

Content: Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter says he has cancer but won't make a more complete public statement until the "facts are known." Gavino Garay reports.
Title: Jimmy Carter suffering from cancer

Content: It is an idea that women find either irresistible, or unbearable: a computer program that estimates a woman's personal risk of developing breast cancer.
Title: Software to Compute Women's Cancer Risk

Content: What do brain surgeons know about cellphone safety that the rest of us don't?
Title: Scientists revive the debate on cellphones and cancer

Content: When is a person too old to benefit from cancer screening tests? The answer, experts say, depends less on age than on the type of cancer, the test and individual characteristics of the person to be screened.
Title: Debating Cancer Screening: Too Old to Test?

Content: It is the middle of April 2006, and I am seated on an examining table on the third floor of the New York University Clinical Cancer Center, waiting to hear about my future.
Title: In Breast Cancer, There Is a Single Agenda: Stay Alive

Content: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19  The White House on Tuesday defended a decision by the office of the first lady, Laura Bush, not to disclose the removal of a skin cancer tumor on her shin for several weeks, saying she had no duty to do so because she did not hold elected office.
Title: White House Defends Not Disclosing First Lady’s Skin Cancer

Content: Pharmaceutical companies are beginning to contemplate new collaborative efforts to lower the cost and speed the development of drugs for cancer, according to executives involved in the effort.
Title: An Early Step on Collaboration on Cancer Drugs

Content: Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida, kicked off a breast cancer awareness campaign today with disclosures of her own that hadn’t been widely known before now.
Title: Fla. Congresswoman Reveals Cancer Surgeries

Content: TELEVISION NEWSWOMEN have been indispensable in transforming breast cancer from a source of private shame into a very public, very political crusade.
Title: Scheduling Breast Cancer in Prime Time

Content: I suppose I should get a new pair of shoes. The soles have come unmoored, the sides are scuffed and water-warped, dirt and dust cling to their seams (some of them ruptured), and the rawhide laces look as if they’ve been gnawed at by sly rodents.
Title: Still Walking in My Cancer Shoes

Content: With vinegar and a little training, great strides are being taken in preventing cervical cancer globally.
Title: A Simple Solution to Prevent Cervical Cancer

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved a new type of drug that combines the widely used breast cancer medicine Herceptin with a powerful toxin to more effectively kill cancer cells while potentially reducing side effects.
Title: F.D.A. Approves a New Drug for Advanced Breast Cancer

Content: Everyone remembers the first time. Everything sticks in your mind.
Title: A Physician's Challenge: Cancer Surgery, but 'No Blood'

Content: Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, the second-oldest member of the United States Senate, has a curable form of stomach cancer and will undergo chemotherapy, his office and doctor said on Friday.
Title: Lautenberg’s Cancer Is Curable, Doctor Says

Content: Recalling that moment four years ago, when Gertrudis Torres learned she had Stage 3 breast cancer, still causes her breathing to become heavy and tears to well up. The unthinkable diagnosis was another blow to Ms. Torres’s family. Two years before, in 2010, her husband, Pedro Ayala, was told that he had throat cancer.
Title: Despite Cancer Diagnosis and Husband’s Death, Keeping a Positive Outlook

Content: A federal advisory panel began wrestling yesterday with whether to remove from the market a lung cancer drug that was rapidly approved for use by desperate patients but has now failed to prolong lives in a large clinical trial.
Title: F.D.A. Panel Weighs Fate of a Drug for Cancer

Content: CHICAGO — An experimental drug from Merck that unleashes the body’s immune system significantly shrank tumors in 38 percent of patients with advanced melanoma, putting the company squarely in the race to bring to market one of what many experts view as the most promising class of drugs in years.
Title: Merck Has Solid Results in a Cancer Drug Trial

Content: Isa Mae Astute, via Getty Images Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz was interviewed by Robin Roberts on "Good Morning America" on Monday. Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz, Democrat of Florida, kicked off a breast cancer awareness campaign today with disclosures of her own that hadn't been widely known before now.  The congresswoman revealed over the weekend that for the last year, she had battled breast cancer and had undergone seven major surgeries, including a double mastectomy and removal of her ovaries, all without skipping most beats on Capitol Hill or public events at home during her re-election in campaign. She disclosed her battle -- including her decisions to have such cancer-prone areas removed because of a genetic predisposition -- to the Miami Herald on Saturday, and during an interview this morning on ABC's "Good Morning America."  Ms. Wasserman Schultz, who is in her early 40s, said she didn't release the news publicly for a few reasons. "I really wanted to make sure that I could protect my children; they were 8 and 4," she said in the interview She has twins who are now 9.    Elected to her third term while she was privately dealing with the illness and surgeries, she also didn't want her identifying "tag line" to be "congresswoman battling breast cancer," she said. Much of her surgery was scheduled during congressional breaks, she said in the interviews, indicating that she's well now but would be taking Tamoxifen for several years.   Rather, she waited until just before rolling out her initiative today to promote an educational campaign aimed at younger women, in their 20s and 30s, in an effort to counter the prevailing 40-plus emphasis on when to get mammograms regularly. Younger women tend to think they're invincible, she said, so she hopes that she can push for legislation that would enhance knowledge among younger women, too.
Title: Fla. Congresswoman Reveals Cancer Surgeries

Content: Nelson Mandela, South Africa's first black president and revered leader of the anti-apartheid struggle, has been found to have prostate cancer and is undergoing treatment, his office announced today.
Title: Mandela Is Being Treated for Prostate Cancer

Content: On March 21, 1973, John Dean told President Nixon that there was a cancer on his presidency. There was, Dean said, a metastasizing criminal conspiracy spreading through the White House.
Title: The Prosecutor's Diagnosis: No Cancer Found

Content: A new and experimental treatment for breast cancer means that patients and doctors must choose treatments based on incomplete research.
Title: Tough Choices for Treating Breast Cancer

Content: A group of new drugs is promising to prolong the lives and relieve the symptoms of men with advanced prostate cancer, but could also add billions of dollars to the nation’s medical bills.
Title: New Drugs Fight Prostate Cancer, but at High Cost

Content: In today's New York Times, Walt Bogdanich offers alarming revelations about a common form of prostate cancer treatment called brachytherapy.
Title: Treatment Errors for Men With Prostate Cancer

Content: Sydney, Australia — I OFTEN wondered what it would be like to have a cancer growing inside your body. To suddenly discover you are carrying something that is eating you away, growing in an ugly, consuming mass in or around your bones or organs. To be blithely stepping through life, unaware that your insides are betraying you.
Title: Was It Cancer? Getting the Diagnosis

Content: ATLANTA, June 4 - Big Pharma has discovered cancer.
Title: New Drugs for Cancer Could Soon Flood Market

Content: The world's largest group of physicists, the American Physical Society, has taken a stance on a contentious public health issue by saying it can find no evidence that the electromagnetic fields that radiate from power lines cause cancer.
Title: Cancer Fear Is Unfounded, Physicists Say

Content: The nation’s leading breast cancer advocacy organization confronted the growing furor Thursday over its decision to largely end its decades-long partnership with Planned Parenthood, with rising dissension in its own ranks and a roiling anger on the Internet showing the power of social media to harness protest.
Title: Outcry Is Fierce to Cut in Funds by Cancer Group

Content: New research tries to break through cancer’s protective shield and women with breast cancer in Uganda face terrible challenges; the weather turns on North America’s forest giant.
Title: Two Windows Into Cancer, the Imperiled Moose

Content: A third of American women who had lumpectomies or other breast-conserving operations for early-stage breast cancer from 1990 to 1995 did not receive other needed treatments, a new study says.
Title: Incomplete Breast Cancer Care Found

Content: FOR Joan Winer Brown, the medical setbacks began in August 1984, when a stray bullet came barreling into her Bronx home, shattering an arm bone.
Title: Conquering Cancer, but Depleting Her Savings

Content: A billionaire chemical industry executive whose family has been plagued by cancer said yesterday that he would donate $100 million to a cancer research center at the University of Utah, an amount roughly equal to the total distributed to researchers by the American Cancer Society last year.
Title: In Cancer Fight, a $100 Million Bullet

Content: New tests that supplement the prostate-specific antigen (P.S.A.) test.
Title: New Ways to Assess Prostate Cancer

Content: Are we outsmarting cancer? Or just ourselves?
Title: Add Patience to a Leap of Faith to Discover Cancer Signatures

Content: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 25 (AP)  Representative Julia Carson, Democrat of Indiana, has terminal lung cancer, a newspaper reported Sunday.
Title: An Indiana Representative Has Terminal Cancer

Content: Correction Appended
Title: To the Hopeless, a Cancer 'Cure' Beckons

Content: "We know that Beau's spirit will live on in all of us..." said Vice President Joe Biden in a statement released after his son, Beau Biden, died from cancer. Jillian Kitchener reports.
Title: Beau Biden dies of brain cancer

Content: A Medtronic product, when used in high doses during spinal fusion procedures, might increase patient cancer risks, according to data released Thursday at a national conference of spine surgeons.
Title: Data Links High Doses of Bone Drug to Cancer

Content: Black women with uterine cancer are more likely to die than white women, even when the progression of the disease is equal and they are given identical treatments, researchers report. The reasons for the disparity are unclear.
Title: Despite Equal Cancer Care, a Racial Disparity Persists

Content: Chemotherapy that preserves a patient's voice box and ability to speak is just as effective as surgery in treating some types of throat cancer, a study suggests.
Title: Hope for Saving Voice Box in Cancer

Content: Because ovarian cancer initiated a stealthy assault before I discovered it, it seems the clear aggressor, and I the injured party. Yet as my physicians use their weapons to counterattack, collateral damages mount. Fatigue envelops me.
Title: When Your Personal War on Cancer Is Exhausting

Content: To John Sirmans, the CT scan that doctors showed him last December looked like a pair of socks full of golf balls.
Title: Kidney Cancer Experiment Appears Promising

Content: Researchers say they have developed a simple method for estimating the risk that prostate cancer will recur and turn deadly in men who have already had their cancerous prostates removed.
Title: New Hope in Prostate Cancer Therapy

Content: Update | 4:57 p.m. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the 65-year-old five-term Democratic senator from Connecticut, has early stage prostate cancer, which he announced during a news conference Friday afternoon in Hartford.
Title: Senator Dodd Has Prostate Cancer

Content: Scientists have uncovered more evidence that a diet high in wheat bran or calcium may lower the risk of colorectal cancer, by soaking up acids that doctors believe stimulate growth of the tumors.
Title: Bran and Calcium May Fight Cancer

Content: My friend’s mother got terrifying news after she had a mammogram. She had Stage 0 breast cancer. Cancer. That dreadful word. Of course she had to have surgery to get it out of her breast, followed by hormonal therapy.
Title: ‘Cancer’ or ‘Weird Cells’: Which Sounds Deadlier?

Content: One day after learning that he had prostate cancer, an upbeat Don Nelson stood oncourt tonight, directing his Mavericks through a pregame shoot-around without a hint of anxiety.
Title: Nelson Stays Upbeat In the Face of Cancer

Content: Dr. David A. Karnofsky was a brilliant oncologist working hard at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to provide the best possible therapies for cancer patients. My mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 1958, was one of them. And while he could not save her, we were ever so grateful for the caring way he treated her.
Title: The Shock of Lung Cancer, When It Strikes Nonsmokers

Content: A major study of nearly 360,000 cellphone users in Denmark found no increased risk of brain tumors with long-term use.
Title: No Cellphone-Cancer Link in Large Study

Content: A cellular control gene whose restraints are flung off by rampant cancer cells in advanced forms of several common tumors has been isolated by two independent teams of researchers.
Title: Control Gene Affected by Cancers Is Isolated

Content: Within the next few months, researchers at three medical centers expect to start the first test in patients of one of the most promising  and contentious  ideas about the cause and treatment of cancer.
Title: Scientists Weigh Stem Cells’ Role as Cancer Cause

Content: PAT COMBS, standing arm in arm with her husband, Ted, surveyed the crowd seated under the white tent. It was not a group Mrs. Combs had ever envisioned being part of. But now that she was, she wanted to remain so, because these were survivors.
Title: Celebrations of Life After Battling Cancer

Content: The young woman in the American Cancer Society advertisement holds up a photograph of a smiling blonde. “My sister accidentally killed herself. She died of skin cancer,” reads the headline.
Title: Doctors Balk at Cancer Ad, Citing Lack of Evidence

Content: Cancer is a disease of genes gone wrong. When certain genes mutate, they make cells behave in odd ways. The cells divide swiftly, they hide from the immune system that could kill them and they gain the nourishment they need to develop into tumors.
Title: A Catalog of Cancer Genes That’s Done, or Just a Start

Content: Dana Reeve, an actress who became an advocate for the disabled after her husband Christopher Reeve became paralyzed, died on Monday night of lung cancer at the age of 44, said Kathy Lewis, the president and chief executive officer of the Christopher Reeve Foundation.
Title: Widow of Christopher Reeve Dies of Cancer

Content: In today’s New York Times, Walt Bogdanich offers alarming revelations about a common form of prostate cancer treatment called brachytherapy.
Title: Treatment Errors for Men With Prostate Cancer

Content: Christopher Hitchens, the author, Vanity Fair contributing editor and frequent television pundit, has suspended a tour to promote his new book while he receives chemotherapy.
Title: Christopher Hitchens to Begin Cancer Treatment

Content: Aubrey Jonsson/Getty Images Finnish researchers recently concluded that, if you wish to ward off lung or gastrointestinal cancer, you might want to spend your leisure time jogging instead of picking berries, mushroom gathering or fishing. In the study, published in late July on the Web site of the British Journal of Sports Medicine, scientists studied the health of a group of 2,560 middle-aged Finns over the course of about 17 years. The subjects, all men living in eastern Finland, kept diaries of their daily activities for a year and then went about them.
Title: Does Exercise Reduce Your Cancer Risk?

Content: For women with a high risk of breast cancer because of genetic mutations or family history, yearly M.R.I. scans in addition to mammograms and breast exams may save lives, a new study finds.
Title: M.R.I.’s Help Fight High Risk of Cancer

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Cancer Therapy Dropped in U.S. Is Revived in China

Content: Anew study has confirmed earlier reports that the drug thalidomide can significantly extend the lives of people with advanced multiple myeloma, a cancer of the blood.
Title: Remedies: Thalidomide Validated as Cancer Fighter

Content: CHICAGO — For many women with early-stage breast cancer, treatment may become considerably less arduous, researchers say.
Title: Findings May Alter Care for Early Breast Cancer

Content: One in five breast cancer patients ages 65 and older postponed radiation therapy or did not complete the full radiation regimen after breast-conserving surgery, and the lapses in care took a significant toll on their health, a new study reports.
Title: Delay in cancer treatment is found to raise recurrence

Content: The American Society of Clinical Oncology, which represents many of the nation’s top cancer doctors, is calling attention to the ties between alcohol and cancer. In a statement published Tuesday in the Journal of Clinical Oncology, the group cites evidence that even light drinking can slightly raise a woman’s risk of breast cancer and increase a common type of esophageal cancer.
Title: Cancer Doctors Cite Risks of Drinking Alcohol

Content: On my way to a meeting on cancer and personalized medicine a few weeks ago, I found myself thinking, improbably, of the Saul Steinberg New Yorker cover illustration “View From Ninth Avenue.” Steinberg’s drawing (yes, you’ve seen it — in undergraduate dorm rooms, in subway ads) depicts a mental map of the world viewed through the eyes of a typical New Yorker. We’re somewhere on Ninth Avenue, looking out toward the water. Tenth Avenue looms large, thrumming with pedestrians and traffic. The Hudson is a band of gray-blue. But the rest of the world is gone — irrelevant, inconsequential, specks of sesame falling off a bagel. Kansas City, Chicago, Las Vegas and Los Angeles are blips on the horizon. There’s a strip of water denoting the Pacific Ocean, and faraway blobs of rising land: Japan, China, Russia. The whole thing is a wry joke on self-obsession and navel gazing: A New Yorker’s world begins and ends in New York.
Title: The Search for Cancer Treatment Beyond Mutant-Hunting

Content: New guidelines for cervical cancer screening say women should delay their first Pap test until age 21, and be screened less often than recommended in the past.
Title: Guidelines Push Back Age for Cervical Cancer Tests

Content: In the moment when a woman is told that she has breast cancer, two simultaneous and contradictory impulses arise: She has an immediate need for more information and a mental block against seeking it. Thirty-eight-year-old Lori Plager described that moment of truth when she learned her diagnosis as the beginning of Mr. Toad's wild ride.
Title: Making Sense of Breast Cancer Treatments

Content: Ten of the state's largest health insurers have agreed to cover experimental cancer drug treatments for more than 25,000 patients. Now, only 3 percent of the state's 275,000 cancer victims, or about 8,200, are in clinical trials, which test the effectiveness of drugs. Such treatments are rarely covered by insurance.
Title: Insurers Agree to Cover Cancer Drug Trials

Content: IT may never have occurred to most people, but men can get breast cancer, too. Although only 1 in 800 to 1,200 men will be told they have the disease, compared with 1 in 8 women, the disease is exactly the same as female breast cancer.
Title: When Men Get Cancer Of Breast

Content: One year ago today I had surgery to remove my cancerous prostate. Then came radiation and hormone therapy because my cancer was more aggressive than expected — Gleason 9, Stage T3B — and had breached the prostate.
Title: With Cancer, You Can’t Hurry Recovery

Content: Women with breast cancer who seek alternative therapies like herbs or acupuncture in addition to standard treatment may be unusually worried and depressed and in need of extra help in coping with their fears about the disease, a study says.
Title: Breast Cancer Study on Alternative Therapy

Content: Rates of the most common form of breast cancer dropped a startling 15 percent from August 2002 to December 2003, researchers reported yesterday.
Title: Reversing Trend, Big Drop Is Seen in Breast Cancer

Content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Cervical cancer could be eliminated in Australia within the next two decades because of a government program to vaccinate children against the cancer-causing human papillomavirus, according to a new report.
Title: In Australia, Cervical Cancer Could Soon Be Eliminated

Content: In January 1964, when the surgeon general of the Public Health Service issued the first report on smoking and health, linking tobacco to a host of serious diseases, including and especially lung cancer, the most common statement from the many smokers I interviewed was, ''By the time I get lung cancer, they'll know how to cure it.''
Title: Lung Cancer Cure? Try Prevention Instead

Content: I had to take my husband back to the hospital for a second operation on a torn tendon, but the pills from the cancer trial had not yet arrived. Surely doing without one or two days of the drug would not necessarily lead to a recurrence, I told myself in an effort to still rising waves of anxiety. There were more pressing matters to attend, namely righting wrongful care.
Title: Living With Cancer: Patients on Our Own

Content: WASHINGTON — One day last winter, desperate as his son fought for his life against a killer brain cancer, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his family reached out to one of America’s most famous, and controversial, doctors for help.
Title: If Cancer Becomes Biden’s Cause, a Bold but Polarizing Doctor Is On Call

Content: Genentech said yesterday that approval of its colon cancer drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer would be delayed by at least a year because the Food and Drug Administration had asked for more data on safety and efficacy.
Title: Longer Delay for Genentech on New Use of Cancer Drug

Content: I continue to find reasons to be hopeful that one day, though probably not within my lifetime, medical researchers will overcome the challenges that thwart efforts to cure or at least contain most cancers, especially the more common ones.
Title: Cancer Survival Demands Steady Progress

Content: THE politicization of diseases is an old story by now. Public officials so routinely enlist in a fight against the most high-profile malady of the day that even those offended by such transparent tactics have come to accept them. After all, political attention raises awareness and money -- good things, whatever the motivation.
Title: Metro Matters; Positioning For Credit On Cancer

Content: New Jersey had the seventh highest mortality rate for all forms of cancer in 1996, and consistently ranks in the top 10, according to the American Cancer Society. And yet only 1 to 3 percent of cancer patients in New Jersey are estimated to participate in clinical studies of potential treatments, while the national average is 3 to 6 percent, said Ann Marie Hill, Executive Director of the State Commission on Cancer Research. Women, along with minorities and the elderly, have especially low participation rates, she said.
Title: Hearing on Low Participation In Cancer Treatment Trials

Content: ATLANTA, June 4 — Big Pharma has discovered cancer.
Title: New Drugs for Cancer Could Soon Flood Market

Content: Just a week and a half after his boss, the mayor, made the same announcement, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that he had prostate cancer. That two high-profile officials were told within days of each other that they had the disease illustrates the prevalence of prostate cancer, the second most common type of cancer in men.
Title: Police Commissioner Has Prostate Cancer

Content: Two-thirds of general surgeons fail to mention the possibility of breast reconstruction before their patients choose between mastectomy and breast-conserving surgery, researchers have found. When that talk does occur, it sharply increases a woman’s willingness to consider mastectomy.
Title: Treatments: Talking Out the Choices for Breast Cancer Surgery

Content: A decision by the nation’s leading breast cancer advocacy group to largely cut off financing for breast cancer screenings at Planned Parenthood set off howls of outrage last week.
Title: A Better Way to Spend Breast Cancer Funds?

Content: Current cancer therapies attempt to find, test and treat specific genetic mutations that are shared by groups of patients. A new method is based on the idea that many cancers differ from patient to patient, and may have different genetic causes.
Title: Conventional Cancer Therapy and Whole Genome Sequencing

Content: This week, Dr. John Mulhall, director of the Male Sexual and Reproductive Medicine Program at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, has been taking questions on the Well blog about what to expect following treatment for prostate cancer. Today, Dr. Mulhall, author of Saving Your Sex Life: A Guide for Men With Prostate Cancer, answers questions about exploring treatment options, effects of treatment on erectile function and penile rehabilitation after cancer treatments. Next week, Dr. Mulhall will answer questions about testosterone, alternative remedies and implants, and other treatments to restore sexual function.  My husband was just diagnosed with prostate cancer today. His cancer is localized in the prostate and his Gleason score is low. He is 63. What course of treatment do you recommend? -- Naomi  The vast majority of men, when they are diagnosed with prostate cancer, have Gleason scores of 5, 6 or 7. Scores of 8, 9 and 10 are aggressive, but if you have a score of 7 or less, you have time -- months -- to make your decision. You do not need to be wracked with fear.   There are some key messages we need to transmit to patients, one of which is to start looking at medical evidence. If you go to a surgeon, he will almost certainly recommend having the prostate removed. If you see a radiation oncologist, you'll most likely be offered radiation. So, it's difficult for patients to sift through the data.   My recommendation is to sit down and talk to more than one surgeon and more than one radiation oncologist. If you're on the fence and can't make a decision, go see somebody like me or an oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer -- someone who doesn't do the surgery and who doesn't do the radiation. That person can give you a rational approach for how you should look at that data.    Why don't we hear more about proton therapy as a treatment for prostate cancer? -- Teresa  I have heard a lot of advertising about a treatment device called the CyberKnife. Should a patient consider this alternative? -- John  Proton beam therapy and CyberKnife are both forms of radiation therapy. There is absolutely no evidence that erection function is better when patients have proton therapy or Cyberknife compared to standard radiation approaches like seed implantation (brachytherapy) or external beam radiation (3D-CRT or IMRT).   There is a lot of marketing going on. A good radiation oncologist combined with modern technology is what will get you the best result. Furthermore, there is no evidence that robotic prostatectomy has better outcomes than open prostatectomy. American men appear enthralled with gadgetry. They think lasers must be better and that using a robot must be better than standard surgery.   Choose your surgeon, not the approach he or she uses. There is no doubt the figures on hospital stay, blood loss and return to work are better for robotic prostatectomy, but at this time there is no evidence that robotic prostatectomy has better outcomes for erectile function or urinary function than open surgery.  What I tell patients who come to see me who are trying to decide between surgery and radiation is as follows: If you look at the data at three years after treatment, surgery or radiation, based on available evidence, there appears to be no significant difference in erectile dysfunction (ED) rates between the two. After surgery, virtually everyone has significant erectile dysfunction for the first 6 to 12 months. Then it improves. After radiation, very few men have ED in the first year, then between years one and three there is likely to be a reduction in erectile function. At about three years, both treatments have approximately the same rates of ED.  The key factors for patients to appreciate are to find physicians who have a high volume of procedures, and a surgeon or radiation oncologist who has been doing this for a while. Outcomes after radical prostatectomy, for example, are better when a surgeon has done 250 procedures and is likely doing more than 50 per year. Experience is important. Of note, surgeons who used to do open prostatectomy and who now do robotic surgery reset the clock, that is, their learning curve starts from close to zero again. So, if a surgeon experienced in open surgery starts to do robotic surgery it may take him or her more than 100 cases to get to the same level of expertise that he or she had when doing open surgery.    My husband had Robot Assisted Laparoscopic Prostatectomy in February and is using Viagra on nights he does not use injections. I can't understand why, when drugs like Viagra are prescribed post-prostatectomy, prescription insurance plans refuse to pay for the drugs. -- G.H.  The evidence shows that the concept called penile rehabilitation provides some benefit to the recovery of erectile function. This approach involves the use of medications (pills or injections) to increase blood flow and oxygen going into the penis. Oxygen is critically important for the health of erectile tissue. When you're not getting erections, you're not oxygenating the penis and not preserving erectile tissue health.   As men, we get three erections every night of our lives before surgery. After surgery, this is not the case for at least the first year. You should think of your penis like you would your biceps. It's predominantly a muscle. If you're not using it, atrophy may occur, and atrophy in the penis is a permanent problem. There is evidence that half of men who go a year without any erection have irreversible structural damage to their erectile tissue.   The vast majority of urologists are doing penile rehabilitation in some form or fashion. Insurance coverage is a huge problem. The general figures are that about one third of men have coverage for Viagra -- the average number of pills per month is six. One-third have no coverage, and one-third have minimal coverage where they have to pay most of the cost of the drug anyway. Men using the drugs for penile rehabilitation use 10 to 15 pills per month.  I would encourage patients to be proactive before surgery or radiation and ask their doctors about rehabilitation and erectile tissue preservation. Before your treatment, set up a plan for how you are going to do rehab. We now start treating patients before surgery and before radiation.    I understand the doctor's foremost goal is to cure you of cancer. My question is, why are doctors so loathe to discuss the virtually inevitable changes in sexual abilities post cancer treatment? I personally found it was one of the larger black-holes of information from my medical professionals. I had to become educated by my own personal experiences over time -- Thomas  Most physicians want to help their patients. They want to do the right thing. However, most physicians are pretty uncomfortable talking about sexual problems. On average, there are less than one to two hours of sexual health education in most medical schools in the United States.   Another problem is many physicians use "ballpark" figures based on data in the literature from major centers. And so they say, "We know 90 percent of men retain erectile function.'' But that's only true in very select centers and certain men.   I would say to any patient or partner who speaks to a physician who is evasive about the data on urinary function and sexual function: they are not a good match for you. That's a warning sign you should be seeking another opinion.   Do you think pretreatment counseling about erectile dysfunction would ease the potential sexual/relationship problems that may arise as a consequence of having radical prostatectomy? -- Leah  Unquestionably. I don't think patients necessarily have to see a mental health professional, but what patients need are realistic expectations.   One of the travesties I see in my practice is patients aren't given realistic expectations. Many patients are told that "in six months, you'll be fine." But if you're been told it will be six months, and you get to month nine and you're not functioning, you get depressed and a sense of hopelessness sets in. For a man, when his erections aren't working, he becomes avoidant of all physical contact. Many wives say, "He doesn't even hold my hand. He doesn't even sit on the couch with me anymore.'' And so, there is an interruption in the couple's physical intimacy, which if it lasts for a prolonged period of time may be difficult to reestablish.  It's important for doctors to have a conversation up-front with people, informing them that it could take 18 to 24 months after prostatectomy to return to normal function or that it may take three-plus years after radiation before maximum erectile dysfunction is experienced. There are things we can do, but it may take time for erections to come back.   Another thing that is important for the prostatectomy patient to know: one in four men we see are not aware that they will never ejaculate after surgery, again highlighting the reticence of many physicians to discuss sexual issues.
Title: Answers to Your Prostate Cancer Questions

Content: Unlike Ebola, flu or polio, cancer is a disease that arises from within — a consequence of the mutations that inevitably occur when one of our 50 trillion cells divides and copies its DNA.
Title: Random Chance’s Role in Cancer

Content: Breast cancer patients often experience pain that persists long after surgery, and a new Danish study has found that the problem affects a large proportion of women. Almost half the patients reported chronic pain two to three years after treatment, and more than half reported discomfort.
Title: Prognosis: Lingering Pain After Surgery for Breast Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 - The White House on Tuesday defended a decision by the office of the first lady, Laura Bush, not to disclose the removal of a skin cancer tumor on her shin for several weeks, saying she had no duty to do so because she did not hold elected office.
Title: White House Defends Not Disclosing First Lady’s Skin Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON  Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut announced on Friday that he had prostate cancer, in an early, treatable form, and that he would press ahead with his re-election campaign.
Title: Dodd to Have Surgery for Prostate Cancer

Content: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts has developed a serious new complication of the therapy he received for cancer 10 years ago and was admitted to a Boston hospital yesterday, the hospital said.
Title: Tsongas Has Complication of Cancer Therapy

Content: Spike Lee may have a problem with Tyler Perry — the two have been having a public war of words — but Mr. Perry’s longtime studio, Lionsgate, certainly doesn’t. It just signed him to another three years. It’s not surprising: Mr. Perry has consistently shown Hollywood the magnitude of an underserved black female audience as no other director has, and now studios are struggling to keep up (for example the coming “Jumping the Broom”). The relationship between Mr. Lee and Mr. Perry is fascinatingly inverse: male-skewing perspective versus female; Northern sensibility versus Southern; jazz-rap orientation versus gospel-R&B. Fortunately it’s a big movie tent. But in box office Mr. Perry is winning.
Title: A Fractious Family With Cancer on the Agenda

Content: Colon cancer patients who took aspirin regularly after having surgery were half as likely as other patients to have a recurrence of the disease, researchers have found.
Title: Prevention: Aspirin May Fight Colon Cancer

Content: "We know that Beau's spirit will live on in all of us..." said Vice President Joe Biden in a statement released after his son, Beau Biden, died from cancer. Jillian Kitchener reports.
Title: Beau Biden dies of brain cancer

Content: Fifty cancers will be officially added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to treat and compensate people exposed to the dust, smoke and fumes of the collapsing World Trade Center, the federal administrator of the World Trade Center Health Program said Monday.
Title: 9/11 Fund to Cover 50 Cancers

Content: Not long ago, at a meeting of an advisory group established by Congress to monitor the war on cancer, participants were asked how to speed progress.
Title: Lack of Study Volunteers Hobbles Cancer Fight

Content: This is a story about cancer, and baseball, and how they intersected over a week in the life of the Mets.
Title: A Shared History of Cancer, a Love of Baseball and a Cubs-Mets Game

Content: Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankees' pitching coach and a three-time 20-game winner for the team in the 1960's, revealed today that he has cancer of the bone marrow, or multiple myeloma.
Title: Yankees' Stottlemyre Has Cancer Of Marrow

Content: Shares in the Geron Corporation, a biotechnology company, rose sharply yesterday after it said that its method for developing a vaccine against cancer may be useful against different types of the disease.
