Shares rose $2.47, or 143 percent, to close at $4.20. Geron's technology is designed to stimulate the body's defenses to attack tumors by aiming at telomerase, a human protein linked to cancer-cell growth. In laboratory tests, the method killed three types of cancer cells. Geron, based in Menlo Park, Calif., is evaluating a telomerase vaccine in early studies of patients with prostate cancer.
Title: BIOTECHNOLOGY SHARES RISE ON CANCER VACCINE NEWS

Content: THE young woman notices a lump the size of a pebble in her breast. The doctor verifies the obvious: "You have a lump; why don't you stay off of caffeine and take vitamin E and, ah, come back in about a month."
Title: THEATER;Cancer, Medicine, Comedy

Content: Adam Yauch of the Beastie Boys announced Monday, by way of a homemade video placed without fanfare on the band's Web site, that he would be receiving treatment for cancer and that as a result the group would cancel some future shows and push back the release of a new album.
Title: Adam Yauch of Beastie Boys Has Cancer

Content: International Business Machines Corp. will work with Emory University and NuTec Sciences Inc. to allow doctors use of supercomputers to quickly find the right cancer treatment based on a patient's genetic makeup.
Title: Tech Brief:IBM COMPUTERIZES CANCER FIGHT:

Content: PATIENTS with prostate cancer may be able to avoid radical surgery and subsequent incontinence and impotence with radioactive ''seeds,'' no bigger than grains of rice, that are strategically implanted in the prostate, says a Seattle doctor who has monitored 152 cancer patients over the last decade.
Title: Radioactive 'Seeds' Check Cancers In Prostate

Content: WHEN Cecilia Chadderton began having trouble breathing during her seventh month of pregnancy she was worried. A visit to North Shore Hospital in Manhasset intensified her fears when doctors found a five-inch tumor growing on her sternum. The pressure from the baby and the tumor had collapsed her lungs. Doctors delivered her baby girl two months early, and Mrs. Chadderton went into chemotherapy for four months.
Title: More Hospitals Providing Cancer Care

Content: The idea that infectious cancer cells are drifting in the ocean, spreading a devastating leukemia-like disease may sound like a dystopian fantasy. But scientists say that is exactly what is happening — in clams.
Title: A Clam Cancer Outbreak, Spread by One Set of Cells

Content: ImClone Systems and Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday they would delay seeking federal approval for a new use of the Erbitux cancer drug until the second half of this year, when they finish analyzing results. The companies planned to file an application by June for clearance to use the drug against cancers of the head and neck. Erbitux won Food and Drug Administration approval in February 2004 as a treatment for colon cancer.
Title: MAKERS DELAY SEEKING APPROVAL FOR CANCER DRUG

Content: Cervical cancer has been perhaps the biggest success story in the long-running war against cancer.
Title: Pap Test, Champion Against Cervical Cancer

Content: Removal of the ovaries — a procedure known as oophorectomy — may increase the risk for colorectal cancer, a new study concludes.
Title: Ovary Removal Tied to Colon Cancer Risk

Content: Doctors say that disastrous accidental overdoses of cancer drugs are rare but that they can and do occur, despite elaborate checks to avoid them or detect them before it is too late.
Title: Cancer Drug Overdoses: Rare but Deadly

Content: LAST year, when Greta Carl, a 55-year-old lawyer in Chicago, was told by her doctor that she was nearly 100 percent clean from her bout with ovarian cancer, she grew her hair to her shoulders for the first time in her life, and dyed her gray hair Goldilocks blond. ''I love it,'' she said. ''It's flattering. It's sexier. It's a way of shouting, 'Hey, I'm alive!' ''
Title: After Cancer, A New Self-Image

Content: More cases of an unusual cancer linked to breast implants have been reported to the Food and Drug Administration, the agency said on Wednesday.
Title: More Cases Are Reported of Unusual Cancer Linked to Breast Implants

Content: WASHINGTON, June 8 — Federal drug officials announced today that they had approved a vaccine against cervical cancer that could eventually save thousands of lives in the United States each year and hundreds of thousands in the rest of the world.
Title: U.S. Approves Cervical Cancer Vaccine

Content: Update | 4:57 p.m. Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the 65-year-old five-term Democratic senator from Connecticut, has early stage prostate cancer, which he announced during a news conference Friday afternoon in Hartford.
Title: Senator Dodd Has Prostate Cancer

Content: This week, Dr. John Mulhall, director of the Male Sexual and Reproductive Medicine Program at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, has been taking questions on the Well blog about what to expect following treatment for prostate cancer. Today, Dr. Mulhall, author of Saving Your Sex Life: A Guide for Men With Prostate Cancer, answers questions about exploring treatment options, effects of treatment on erectile function and penile rehabilitation after cancer treatments. Next week, Dr. Mulhall will answer questions about testosterone, alternative remedies and implants, and other treatments to restore sexual function.
Title: Answers to Your Prostate Cancer Questions

Content: HERBERT IRVING, a food distribution executive who lives in Old Westbury, has donated $10 million for cancer research to the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. The cancer research and treatment programs at the hospital will be known as the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center.
Title: From Food Distribution to Cancer Aid

Content: Cancer steals much from the people it afflicts. For Anna Stoessinger, a gastronome, stomach cancer meant giving up a lifelong celebration of food.
Title: When Cancer Steals the Joy of Food

Content: In results from a widely watched clinical trial, the drug Avastin failed to show a significant effect on preventing the recurrence of colon cancer, the drug’s maker, Genentech, said early Wednesday.
Title: Avastin Falls Short in Test as Colon Cancer Medicine

Content: A medical researcher from Columbia University, Dr. Perry Hudson, made the skid row alcoholics in Lower Manhattan an offer: If they agreed to surgical biopsies of their prostates, they would get a clean bed and three square meals for a few days, plus free medical care and treatment if they had prostate cancer.
Title: Decades Later, Condemnation for a Skid Row Cancer Study

Content: IT started with a sip of soda that wasn't.
Title: Cancer Walk Draws Westchester Marchers

Content: No man has shaped the National Conference of Catholic Bishops more than its onetime general secretary and later president, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago. But when the conference opens its fall meeting in Washington next Monday, he will not be there.
Title: A Cardinal's Cancer Saddens All Chicago

Content: When Kelley Oliver Douglass got breast cancer, a genetic counselor posed an odd question: Do you and your children have trouble finding hats that fit?
Title: A Rare Genetic Mutation Leads to Cancer. The Fix May Already Be in the Drugstore.

Content: WAS it really news to anybody, as headlines proclaimed a little more than a week ago, that smoking causes lung cancer?
Title: So, Smoking Causes Cancer: This Is News?

Content: A new procedure for testing the lymph nodes of women with early-stage breast cancer is so promising and is gaining in popularity so rapidly that leaders in the field are concerned that some surgeons may try it without being properly trained. And any errors that result can be fatal.
Title: Procedure Helps Detect Cancers Of Breast

Content: In today’s Cases column, Well contributor Dana Jennings writes about a surprising “side effect” of cancer treatment.
Title: After Cancer, a Post-Treatment Letdown

Content: Q. What is D.C.I.S.?
Title: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Answers to Questions About New Findings

Content: A new study suggests that men with prostate cancer who take statins may have a lower risk of dying from the disease than those who do not.
Title: Statins Tied to Better Prostate Cancer Outcomes

Content: Stuffed inside cookie tins and between the pages of books in Diane Fields’s kitchen are multitudes of recipes. Ms. Fields has clipped them from newspapers and kept them for years, intent on preparing and sampling them all.
Title: Cancer Patient Awaits Day She Can Return to the Kitchen

Content: The early promise of thalidomide as an anti-cancer drug apparently is holding up, according to findings disclosed today at the meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology here.
Title: Thalidomide's Anti-Cancer Use Supported

Content: People with a family history of colon cancer carry the emotional burden of knowing they have twice the risk of developing the disease themselves. But now, a new study may ease some of their anxiety. Patients with a family history of colon cancer are also more likely to survive the disease.
Title: Colon Cancer in Family Predicts Better Survival

Content: Pregnant women diagnosed with breast cancer once felt they had to choose either the toxic doses of chemotherapy or a healthy baby, but never both.
Title: Cancer Regimen Found Safe in Pregnancy

Content: Extending the idea of ''cause computing,'' Intel said it was joining with the American Cancer Society, the National Foundation for Cancer Research, the University of Oxford and United Devices Inc. to develop a system permitting home and work PC users to donate excess processing power on their desktop machines to try to solve scientific and medical computing problems. The idea of using the Internet to weave together thousands of independent PC's is not new. It has already been used by the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence project, known as SETI, and by Juno, the Internet service provider, and several start-up companies. As part of the Intel project, computer users will be able to donate computer time to build a virtual supercomputer. The first program to be run will involve research on tailoring drug treatments for leukemia. John Markoff
Title: INTEL JOINS CANCER RESEARCH EFFORT

Content: Q. My father died of pancreatic cancer, and my understanding is that one of the reasons it is so deadly is that it is usually found when it is fairly advanced. Is there a routine screening for this cancer?
Title: Can You Screen for Early Pancreatic Cancer?

Content: Two big developments in breast cancer research are making headlines and generating buzz among scientists: one a new diagnostic option, the second a potential way to reduce the time patients must spend in radiation treatment. Each is promising, but there are some important points that are not yet clear.
Title: Two Advances for Breast Cancer Patients

Content: ATLANTA, June 3 — For women with a certain type of breast cancer, the drug Herceptin has represented a major advance, extending lives and preventing tumor recurrence. But for some of those women, the drug never works, and it eventually stops working for others.
Title: New Drug Holds Promise for Type of Breast Cancer

Content: Hamilton Jordan, the former White House chief of staff for President Jimmy Carter, was a well-known force in the health community. During the past 24 years he battled four different forms of cancer and urged cancer patients to empower themselves with information.  (Photo: Hamilton Jordan, left, walked the White House grounds with President Jimmy Carter in this undated photo. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times))   After bouts with non-Hodgkins lymphoma, prostate cancer and skin cancer, Mr. Jordan, 63, yesterday died as a result of mesothelioma, another form of cancer. Mr. Jordan often speculated that his lymphoma may have resulted from exposure to the chemical Agent Orange while serving as a volunteer during the Vietnam War. Mesothelioma also has been linked to the chemical.  In his 2001 memoir, "No Such Thing as a Bad Day,'' Mr. Jordan outlined his "Top 10 Tips for Cancer Patients.'' He spoke about them during this undated interview with WebMD. Here they are:  No. 1: Be an active partner in the medical decisions that are made about your life.   Don't be passive. Learn about your disease, and participate in the decisions that are made....For example with my lymphoma, if I would have accepted the first treatment offered, I'd be dead today. It was assumed that I only had a mass in my chest. I later learned that the lymphoma was all through my body.    No. 2: Seek and know the truth about your illness, and prognosis.    If you don't have the facts, and don't know the truth, you won't make good decisions. It takes courage to ask questions about statistics and your prognosis.     No. 3: Get a second opinion.     We wouldn't buy the first computer or cellphone we looked at. Shop around when your life is at stake....I got second opinions on all of my cancers.    No. 4: Determine upfront how broad or narrow your physicians' experience is.    If you have something that your doctor says, "I've never seen this before," get another doctor. You want your doctor to be very familiar with your disease.    No. 5: If you have a poor prognosis, or a rare form of cancer, try to get to a center of excellence.    If your doctor doesn't believe he or she can cure you, you won't believe you'll be cured.     No. 6: Do not allow your caregivers to project their values, goals and expectations onto you.    In my book I tell the story of a 68-year-old man who was diagnosed with PCa (prostate cancer). And this man is in very good health other than the PCa. His 35-year-old doctor reasoned that since his life expectancy was only five or six years, that he recommended that the man do nothing for his PCa and told him it would take the PCa four or five years to kill him. This man wanted to live to be 80 or 85. He didn't accept that. He had his prostate removed, and many years later he's in good health, and probably will live to be 80 or 85. Don't let your doctor project his or her expectations in life out on you.    No. 7: Understand the economics of cancer care.    You don't want to be in a situation where your doctor wants to run a $150 test that your insurance doesn't cover, but it contains critical information for making your diagnosis or deciding treatment. You need to understand what your insurance covers, and let your doctor know what you're willing to do to supplement that coverage to get a good diagnosis, and the best possible treatment. If your doctor says that he wants to run another test, but insurance won't pay for it, find out what it is. Why does he want to run it? Find out the cost, and determine whether you should pay it yourself. It might save your life.    No. 8: Ultimately, find a doctor that you trust and believe in.    Find a doctor with a fighting spirit, and who thinks that they can cure you. You tend to find doctors that reflect your own attitude. I always found doctors that liked the fact I was aggressive and going to fight for my life. They didn't object to my asking a lot of questions.    No. 9: Treat your mind as well as your body.    Just because we can't quantify, and don't understand the power of the mind, to deal with disease, it doesn't mean that attitude and the will to live is not a powerful, powerful force in the course of an illness.    No. 10: Your attitude and beliefs are your most powerful weapon against cancer.     I believe that deeply. There have been studies that show when you are happy and engaged and positive, your immune system is at its strongest. When you are depressed or unhappy, your immune system is weakened.     To read the full interview, click here.
Title: One Man’s Advice From Four Cancer Battles

Content: When Todd Hendrickson developed an uncommon intestinal cancer in 1997, he traveled to medical centers around the country from his home in Minnetonka, Minn., seeking effective therapy. But five different therapeutic combinations failed as the painful cancer grew to the size of two footballs, spread to his liver and so weakened him that his wife had to lift him out of bed.
Title: Cancer Doctors See New Era of Optimism

Content: Scientists say they have made a discovery that may help explain the racial gap in cancer survival, providing clues to why white patients often outlive blacks even when they have what appear to be the same cancers.
Title: Findings May Explain Gap in Cancer Survival

Content: (Photo: A standard mammogram, left, and molecular breast imaging (M.B.I.), right, of a patient's dense breast tissue. A tumor is visible on the M.B.I., as in indicated by the arrow, but not on the mammogram. (AP))   Two big developments in breast cancer research are making headlines and generating buzz among scientists: one a new diagnostic option, the second a potential way to reduce the time patients must spend in radiation treatment. Each is promising, but there are some important points that are not yet clear.  Let's start with diagnosis. The problem with diagnosing breast cancer as early as possible is that the breast itself is not a completely uniform structure. It has several components -- fat, fibers, ducts and water, among them -- that give it a rather complex appearance when viewed by mammography (x-rays of the breast), ultrasound or MRI scans. Tumors also vary in appearance, some of them closely resembling normal breast tissue.  Diagnosing breast cancer becomes particularly difficult when the tumor is small or when the breast tissue itself is very variable in its consistency. It can be surprisingly difficult for a physician to decide whether a particular area with an "odd" appearance represents tumor, scar tissue, fat or something else.  New technology, called molecular breast imaging, appears to detect some tumors that were previously unseen. With this technique, small breast cancers absorb a type of radioactive molecule that can then be detected by a special camera. Molecular breast imaging has been used successfully in some screening studies (that is, in well women without known symptoms or breast lumps) to detect unsuspected small tumors, which in some cases had been missed by mammography.  Unfortunately this technology also requires a small radiation dose, and that may present hazards, too. Doctors working with molecular breast imaging also have reported that the technique occasionally may miss a tumor that would have been picked up on routine mammography.   At present, then, it seems that this screening method may be most useful as an adjunct to established techniques, rather than as a replacement for them. Since there is a small amount of radiation associated with molecular breast imaging, as there is also in mammography, patients also will have to be followed carefully to ensure that there are no after-effects.  The Times also reports today that the duration of radiation treatment in early-stage breast cancer can perhaps be shortened for many patients. Recent studies from Canada and Japan have suggested that instead of the usual five to seven weeks of treatment, patients may survive just as long if they are treated with larger individual doses of radiotherapy each day for just a few weeks. This finding applies only to patients with small tumors that have not spread to the lymph nodes.  Shorter duration of radiotherapy seems like a good idea, as it would reduce the time away from work or from family duties. What's the downside?   Larger individual doses of radiation can sometimes cause more side effects, such as inflammation of breast tissue, hardening of the skin over the breast and local discomfort during the radiation. Unfortunately, some of these complications may occur well after treatment is complete. It may be premature to call this strategy a complete success, although it is worth noting that patients were followed for 12 years in the recently published Canadian study.  Cancer cells may protect and repair themselves after radiation, and some are actually more efficient at this repair process after shorter courses of radiotherapy. While these recent studies suggest that equivalent results can be obtained by either short- or long- course radiation, more studies will be required, focusing on cure rates and late effects.   So what should patients make of all this? Molecular breast imaging is a work in progress, and the centers investigating it will have to continue to monitor women to see whether tumors are missed, and whether those small doses of radiation are in some way harmful.   With regard to short-course radiotherapy, I think that a reasonable approach is to consider the context. Women who have important reasons for trying to spend less time on radiotherapy (the single parent who is the sole financial support for her family, or the woman who must travel long distances to a treatment facility) might reasonably choose this option, recognizing that there MAY be more risk, but that the level of risk is reasonable, based on these recent studies.  On the other hand, for women for whom time saved merely relates to convenience, it would probably be smart to stick with tried-and-true techniques until more data are available. The benefit of the established treatment programs is that they are very well anchored, with lots of information about safety, side effects and cure rates.
Title: Two Advances for Breast Cancer Patients

Content: In December 2005, a series of mysterious symptoms  night sweats, easy bruising, swollen ankles and breathlessness upon exertion  prompted Barry to see his doctor. Only six months earlier, a physical exam had found nothing abnormal. But now Barry’s white blood cell count was through the roof.
Title: Living With a Formerly Fatal Blood Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is cancer free and on the mend after her recent surgery for the disease, a Supreme Court spokeswoman said on Friday.
Title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Is Cancer Free After Surgery, Supreme Court Says

Content: When it comes to advocacy and research funds, the leading cancer killer in the United States  lung cancer  clearly gets short shrift. People with the disease are commonly assumed to have brought it upon themselves by smoking. And the 10 to 15 percent of lung cancer patients who never smoked are typically tarred with the same brush. One-tenth of men and one-fifth of women with lung cancer have never been smokers, and in some parts of the country  Northern California, for example  as many as 35 percent of women with lung cancer never smoked or lived with smokers.
Title: Blame’s Net Catches Lung Cancer Patients

Content: Alex Trebek, the longtime host of the classic trivia television show “Jeopardy!”, announced in a video on Wednesday that he has Stage IV pancreatic cancer.
Title: Alex Trebek, ‘Jeopardy!’ Host, Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: IF Paul Lupinacci has done his very best work, the result will be unremarkable. That is his goal.
Title: Specialty That Aids Cancer Patients

Content: Many people gobble big doses of vitamin C in hopes of boosting their immune system and warding off illness. But new research shows that in people with cancer, the vitamin may do more harm than good.
Title: Vitamin C May Interfere With Cancer Treatment

Content: She remembers hearing the word thalidomide half a lifetime ago, when she was a young mother in Queens and it was a pharmaceutical scourge that maimed children.
Title: Geraldine Ferraro Fights Blood Cancer

Content: Most cancer survivors are just as overweight and inactive as everyone else, a new study shows.
Title: Surviving Cancer Doesn’t Lead to Healthier Lifestyle

Content: McGill University in Montreal announced last week a new $58 million collaboration between the Rossy Cancer Network and its teaching hospitals: the McGill University Health Center, Jewish General and St. Mary’s.
Title: McGill’s Hospitals Join Forces With Cancer Network

Content: One of the nation’s largest clinical laboratory companies has halted sales of a controversial blood test aimed at early detection of ovarian cancer after receiving a warning from the Food and Drug Administration.
Title: Sales of Test for Ovarian Cancer Halted

Content: SILVER SPRING, Md., May 10  Bowing to safety concerns, government medical advisers urged on Thursday that additional restrictions be put on the use of drugs that treat anemia in cancer patients.
Title: F.D.A. Panel Seeks Limits on Cancer Patient Drugs

Content: New York Times writer Dana Jennings blogs each week about his experiences coping with an advanced form of prostate cancer.
Title: A Summer Job, Toxic Chemicals and Cancer

Content: Genentech reported on Tuesday that sales of its cancer drug Avastin topped Wall Street estimates, even though third-quarter earnings fell short of analyst expectations because of higher costs.
Title: Sales of Genentech's cancer drug climb

Content: Black women with uterine cancer are more likely to die than white women, even when the progression of the disease is equal and they are given identical treatments, researchers report. The reasons for the disparity are unclear.
Title: Despite Equal Cancer Care, a Racial Disparity Persists

Content: Adam Yauch of the Beastie Boys announced Monday, by way of a homemade video placed without fanfare on the band’s Web site, that he would be receiving treatment for cancer and that as a result the group would cancel some future shows and push back the release of a new album.
Title: Adam Yauch of Beastie Boys Has Cancer

Content: Scientists have discovered that the most dangerous cancer of the uterine lining closely resembles the worst ovarian and breast cancers, providing the most telling evidence yet that cancer will increasingly be seen as a disease defined primarily by its genetic fingerprint rather than just by the organ where it originated.
Title: Cancers Share Gene Patterns, Studies Affirm

Content: Coulter Pharmaceutical Inc. and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. have agreed to jointly market Coulter's Bexxar treatment for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. For Coulter, a developer of cancer treatments based in Palo Alto, Calif., the agreement could be worth up to $132 million plus shared profits and royalties. Coulter said that in Phase 3 trials Bexxar had been more effective than conventional chemotherapy in lengthening remissions in non-Hodgkin's lymphoma patients in 78 percent of cases. Phase 3 trials test drugs for safety and efficacy on human subjects. Under the agreement, SmithKline will make an up-front payment of $41.5 million to Coulter. SmithKline will also provide Coulter with a $15 million credit line and make additional payments of as much as $76 million as milestones are reached.
Title: COULTER AND SMITHKLINE IN CANCER DRUG PACT

Content: ATLANTA — A study has found that the uninsured and those covered by Medicaid in the United States are more likely than those with private insurance to receive a diagnosis of cancer in the late stages of the disease, often diminishing their chances of survival.
Title: Uninsured and underinsured at risk for late cancer diagnoses

Content: Taxol, a drug originally derived from the bark of the Pacific yew tree, helps those with ovarian cancer to live longer when it is combined with the drug cisplatin, a study has found.
Title: New Blend Fights a Cancer Better

Content: When people hear the words “You have cancer,” life is suddenly divided into distinct parts. There was their life before cancer, and then there is life after cancer.
Title: New Meaning and Drive in Life After Cancer

Content: The death rate from ovarian cancer declined in the United States by 16 percent from 2002 to 2012, among the largest reductions in the world.
Title: Some Good News on Ovarian Cancer

Content: With desperate breast cancer patients imploring the Food and Drug Administration to change its mind, the agency’s staff calmly argued Tuesday that the drug Avastin should lose its approval as a treatment for that disease.
Title: Breast Cancer Patients Plead for Avastin Approval

Content: Pittsburgh's struggles weigh on Mario Lemieux, but that has not stopped him from sharing the experiences of his battle against Hodgkin's lymphoma with others who are fighting the disease. On Friday, the NBC series "Three Wishes" showed a segment in which he spends time with 9-year-old Mitch Konkle of Marshall, Mich., whose diagnosis was made in June.
Title: Lemieux Makes Time for Cancer Victims

Content: Pharmacyclics, an unprofitable developer of heart and cancer drugs, said federal regulators had agreed to a speedier review of its experimental brain-cancer medicine. Shares of the company surged 25 percent. The Food and Drug Administration granted a so-called fast-track review for the medicine, Xcytrin, which treats patients with lung cancer that has spread to the brain, the company said. The status allows Pharmacyclics to file data on drug studies as it is collected for faster processing by the agency. Pharmacyclics, which has not yet filed an application for F.D.A. approval, is conducting trials comparing patients treated using radiation with or without Xcytrin. Shares of Pharmacyclics rose $1.62, to $8.17.
Title: F.D.A. SPEEDS UP REVIEW OF A CANCER DRUG

Content: For a number of Times readers, receiving a cancer diagnosis was just the beginning of a long sojourn through the world of new cancer treatments. Some readers found great success with advanced therapies, while others struggled to see whether the treatments offered better results than conventional ones.
Title: How New Cancer Treatments Are Shaping Lives

Content: THE FACTS
Title: Really? The Claim: Allergies Reduce the Risk of Cancer

Content: Genentech Inc., the biotechnology company, said yesterday that it had filed an application with the Food and Drug Administration for approval of its Avastin medicine as a treatment for colon cancer. The company said it had asked for a decision within about six months, a so-called priority review that the agency often grants for cancer medicines. Colon cancer causes more than 50,000 deaths a year in the United States, the National Institutes of Health estimates. Avastin could become the first approved drug that stops tumors by preventing them from building blood vessels, a process known as angiogenesis. Shares fell 39 cents to $80.
Title: GENENTECH SEEKS F.D.A. APPROVAL OF CANCER TREATMENT

Content: In the spring of 2008, I had symptoms of what I thought was a heart condition. It made sense because I had a family history of heart disease. After several sleepless nights, I went to the doctor.
Title: When a Business Owner Gets Cancer

Content: Times editor Dana Jennings writes each week about living with an advanced form of prostate cancer.
Title: Living With Incontinence After Prostate Cancer

Content: Jeff Jacobson’s new book project, “The Last Roll,” emerged from a low point in his life. Recovering from lymphoma and the chemotherapy used to treat it, he faced his own mortality in 2005. Then he faced the end of Kodachrome 200, a medium he’d used for more than 20 years.
Title: A Cancer Survivor and His Kodachrome

Content: Although this place looks like any small farming village in central Anatolia, people in the area believe it bears a special curse.
Title: In Anatolia, Town Curse Is a Legacy Of Cancer

Content: The Genzyme Corporation, which sells treatments for rare genetic diseases, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Ilex Oncology for about $1 billion in stock. Shareholders will get Genzyme stock valued at $26 for each Ilex share, Genzyme said. In buying Ilex, based in San Antonio, Genzyme, based in Cambridge, Mass., will gain the Campath leukemia treatment and experimental cancer drugs. Ilex is developing clofarabine, a treatment for bladder cancer, and synthadotin, a drug for skin and lung cancers. Campath had sales of $72 million last year, up from $44 million in 2002, according to a company regulatory filing.
Title: GENZYME AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF CANCER DRUGS

Content: Advances in screening, diagnosis and treatment of colon cancer mean fewer people are dying of the disease today than they were 20 years ago. But not everyone is benefiting equally.
Title: Gains in Colon Cancer Show a Racial Gap

Content: While millions of Americans suffer from heartburn and gastric reflux, only a small number develop more severe ailments that can lead to esophageal cancer. Scientists trying to understand what may protect against these conditions have identified an unlikely agent: wine.
Title: Wine May Lower the Risk of a Rare Esophageal Cancer
Peter Jennings Diagnosed With Lung Cancer

Content: The first large and comprehensive study of the genetics of a common lung cancer has found that more than half the tumors from that cancer have mutations that might be treated by new drugs that are already in the pipeline or that could be easily developed.
Title: Cancer Study Points to Tighter Pairing of Drugs and Patients

Content: As part of the N.F.L.’s support of Breast Cancer Awareness Month in October, players will be wearing hot pink gear starting Sunday: gloves, sweatbands, towels. And cleats. At least 100 players are expected to wear pink shoes. Think sprinter Michael Johnson’s Olympic-era gold shoes, but more neon.
Title: Pink Cleats to Show Support of Breast Cancer Awareness

Content: WALK into the Shoprite Supermarket in West Haven on a Thursday afternoon and you'll see more than just groceries. Standing in the doorway right before the produce aisle are Gerry Anderson and Nilsa Cogdell, missionaries of sorts, whose calling is women's health.
Title: Getting Out the Message on Breast Cancer

Content: The Food and Drug Administration appears to have postponed an expected decision on whether to revoke the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer.
Title: F.D.A. Postpones Rule on Breast Cancer Drug

Content: Elida Fernández, 53, is being treated for breast cancer. The Neediest Cases Fund helped to pay $500 towards the monthly cost of her medication.
Title: The Neediest Cases | Fighting Cancer, but Not Alone

Content: People with a family history of colon cancer carry the emotional burden of knowing they have twice the risk of developing the disease themselves. But a new study may ease some of their anxiety. Patients with a family history of colon cancer, the researchers found, are also more likely to survive it.
Title: Surviving Colon Cancer Is Tied to Family History of It

Content: As a 28-year-old who had just learned she had breast cancer in 2001, Rochelle Shoretz founded a support group for cancer patients while sitting in her oncologist’s office awaiting chemotherapy. She called it Sharsheret, Hebrew for chain. In 2009, the cancer returned.
Title: Rochelle Shoretz, Founder of Cancer Support Group, Dies at 42

Content: Asian-Americans, both those born in the United States and new immigrants, have distinctive patterns of cancer incidence that doctors should consider when treating them, researchers have found.
Title: Distinctive patterns of cancer found in Asian-Americans

Content: The Duke University School of Medicine has suspended a researcher and stopped patient enrollment in three cancer studies upon learning of reports that the researcher had overstated his academic credentials.
Title: Duke Suspends Researcher and Halts Cancer Studies

Content: Dana Jennings
Title: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Cancer Clinic

Content: A collage of photos and insights submitted by readers.
Title: Picture Your Life After Cancer

Content: Women can cut their risk of breast cancer by almost half if they watch their weight, exercise daily, breast-feed their babies and limit alcoholic beverages, according to a new report by the American Institute for Cancer Research.
Title: Regimens: Habits Help in Avoiding Breast Cancer, Study Finds

Content: For the second time in the history of one of the nation's largest research programs to study treatments for breast cancer, Federal investigators are reporting that they have found fraudulent data.
Title: Fraud Found In Analyzing Breast Cancer

Content: A diagnosis of prostate cancer is scary enough. But just as scary is that nobody can tell a man the best way to treat it.
Title: A lack of data hinders  treatment of prostate cancer

Content: Every few weeks I host a “girls’ night” at my apartment in Lower Manhattan with a group of friends who are at various stages in their cancer treatments. Everyone brings something to eat and drink, and we sit around my living room talking to one another about subjects both heavy and light, ranging from post-chemo hair styling tips, fears of relapse or funny anecdotes about a recent hospital visit. But one topic that doesn’t come up as often as you might think — particularly at a gathering of women in their early 20s and 30s — is sex.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Crazy, Unsexy Cancer Tips

Content: A new study suggests that what you eat may affect your chances of surviving colon cancer.
Title: Can Foods Affect Colon Cancer Survival?

Content: A diagnosis of prostate cancer is scary enough. But just as scary is that nobody can tell a man the best way to treat it.
Title: A Review of Prostate Cancer Leaves Men in a Muddle

Content: WASHINGTON — Harry Reid, the former Senate Democratic leader from Nevada, underwent surgery on Monday to remove a cancerous tumor from his pancreas.
Title: Harry Reid Has Surgery for Pancreatic Cancer

Content: A print advertisement for prostate cancer surgery at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan is typical of the way many elite research and teaching hospitals sell hope to the public.
Title: Cancer Center Ads Use Emotion More Than Fact

Content: Two new studies have found that people with sleep apnea, a common disorder that causes snoring, fatigue and dangerous pauses in breathing at night, have a higher risk of cancer. The new research marks the first time that sleep apnea has been linked to cancer in humans.
Title: Sleep Apnea Tied to Increased Cancer Risk

Content: A woman who took her life in the presence of Dr. Jack Kevorkian in early November after battling breast cancer also had cancer in her spine, the medical examiner's office has found.
Title: Cancer Finding In Suicide Case Of Kevorkian

Content: THE real winners in the third race at Yonkers Raceway here Thursday night will not even be in it.
Title: Race to Help in Breast Cancer Fight

Content: Lloyd Blankfein shares his experience dealing with treatment after his diagnosis of lymphoma. "It was all pretty manageable," the Goldman chairman said of his hours of chemotherapy.
Title: Goldman Sachs Chief on Cancer Treatment

Content: My grandfather was a statistician, and from a young age he taught me to always consider the odds. A pragmatic man, he couldn’t help teaching me when to hedge my bets, especially when it came to playing Uno. Unfortunately, he never could have prepared me for the odds I would face in the years to come.
Title: After a Cancer Diagnosis, Playing the Odds

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the use of Amgen’s bone drug denosumab as a treatment for cancer patients whose disease has spread to their bones.
Title: F.D.A. Approves a Bone Drug for Cancer Patients

Content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s former president, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, has throat cancer and will begin chemotherapy soon, his hospital said Saturday in a statement.
Title: Former Leader of Brazil Is Said to Have Throat Cancer

Content: The number of cancer deaths in the United States dropped in 2004 for a second straight year, the American Cancer Society reported today.
Title: Cancer Deaths Decline for Second Straight Year

Content: Cancer researchers have known for years that it was possible in rare cases for some cancers to go away on their own. There were occasional instances of melanomas and kidney cancers that just vanished. And neuroblastoma, a very rare childhood tumor, can go away without treatment.
Title: Some cancers disappear untreated, study finds

Content: Joe Girardi sat silently at the front of a Yankees team bus this morning, an island among teammates who cheerfully anticipated the return of Darryl Strawberry to baseball this afternoon in an exhibition game against the Red Sox. This was supposed to be a good day.
Title: Yankees Learn Torre Has Prostate Cancer

Content: SAN FRANCISCO — In Silicon Valley, being a unicorn is no guarantee of financial success. But an eight-year-old drug maker focused on novel cancer treatments has landed itself and its investors a windfall by selling itself to a bigger competitor.
Title: AbbVie to Buy Cancer Treatment Start-Up

Content: A federal health official’s ruling has cleared the way for 50 different types of cancer to be added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to compensate and treat people exposed to the toxic smoke, dust and fumes in the months after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.
Title: Sept. 11 Health Fund Given Clearance to Cover Cancer

Content: ORLANDO, Fla., May 15 - New studies show that Americans generally receive high-quality cancer care but that closer monitoring is needed to explain significant geographic variations in practices.
Title: Studies Find Disparity in U.S. Cancer Care

Content: Call it the arrow of cancer. Like the arrow of time, it was supposed to point in one direction. Cancers grew and worsened.
Title: Cancers Can Vanish Without Treatment, but How?

Content: Representative Dave Camp, the powerful chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, disclosed Saturday that he had early-stage blood cancer but that he intended to undergo treatment while continuing his work in the House.
Title: Camp Diagnosed With Early-Stage Cancer

Content: On a sunny San Francisco morning in the University of California's gleaming new Cancer Center, Frank McCormick is listening to the complaints of David Jablons, a thoracic surgeon. Jablons is describing the lack of good remedies for lung cancer with a candor that few patients get to hear.
Title: Can the Common Cold Cure Cancer?

Content: New digital-imaging techniques may soon help doctors search for early signs of melanoma, the most deadly form of skin cancer.
Title: Using Computers to Zoom In on Skin Cancer

Content: Carcinogens abounded 1.7 million years ago in Early Pleistocene times when a nameless protohuman wandered the South African countryside in what came to be known as the Cradle of Humankind.
Title: The Known: Cancer Is Really, Really Old. The Unknown: How Common It Was.

Content: CHICAGO — Drugs that unleash the body’s immune system to combat tumors could allow patients with advanced melanoma to live far longer than ever before, researchers gathered at the nation’s largest cancer conference say.
Title: New System for Treating Cancer Seen as Hopeful

Content: A damaged gene found in many lung cancer tumors appears to play a critical role in developing the disease, say researchers who took part in a new study.
Title: Damaged Gene Is Linked to Lung Cancer

Content: For decades, millions of men with early prostate cancer have been placed on drug therapy to suppress their production of testosterone, despite such significant side effects as impotence, diabetes and bone loss. Now a large new analysis has concluded that so-called androgen deprivation therapy does not extend the lives of these patients.
Title: Study Discounts Testosterone Therapy for Early Prostate Cancer

Content: Two types of bacteria commonly found in the gut work together to fuel the growth of colon tumors, researchers reported on Thursday.
Title: Gut Microbes Combine to Cause Colon Cancer, Study Suggests

Content: Two types of bacteria commonly found in the gut work together to fuel the growth of colon tumors, researchers reported on Thursday.
Title: Gut Microbes Combine to Cause Colon Cancer, Study Suggests

Content: For people with cancer or suspected cancer, the biopsy is a necessary evil — an uncomfortable and somewhat risky procedure to extract tissue for diagnosis or analysis.
Title: Sidestepping the Biopsy With New Tools to Spot Cancer

Content: Updated: Medicare will continue to pay for the drug Avastin as a treatment for breast cancer even if the Food and Drug Administration revokes the drug’s approval as a treatment for that disease, a Medicare spokesman said on Thursday.
Title: Medicare Will Pay for Avastin in Treating Breast Cancer

Content: Dozens of readers recently posed questions about pancreatic cancer to the Consults blog. Here, Dr. Eileen O’Reilly, a pancreatic cancer expert at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, addresses concerns about the role of genetics in pancreatic cancer and who should be screened for the disease.
Title: Expert Answers on Pancreatic Cancer: Genetics and Screening

Content: Shares of the Geron Corporation, a biotechnology company, rose 15 percent yesterday after it won a patent for technology to develop immune-system-based cancer therapies. Shares of Geron rose 59 cents, to close at $4.44, on Nasdaq. The patent covers Geron technology for stimulating the body's immune system to attack cancer cells by aiming at telomerase, a protein linked to cancer growth. The technology may be used to develop vaccines against a wide range of cancers, the company said. Geron is evaluating a telomerase vaccine in early studies in patients with prostate cancer, the company said. Geron, based in Menlo Park, Calif., is also developing drugs to block telomerase directly.
Title: GERON SHARES RALLY ON PATENT FOR CANCER TREATMENT

Content: Though costly, prostate cancer drugs have helped patients live longer.
Title: Promising Treatments for Prostate Cancer Patients

Content: Some Israeli doctors want Israel to conduct a national screening campaign to test all Jewish Israeli women of Ashkenazi descent for harmful genetic mutations that heighten the risk of breast and ovarian cancer. The debate is detailed in the article, “In Israel, a Push to Screen for Cancer Gene Leaves Many Conflicted.”
Title: Ask Well: Genetic Testing for Breast Cancer

Content: Michael Douglas said in an interview with David Letterman on Tuesday evening that he had started treatment for Stage 4 throat cancer, and offered cautious optimism that he would recover from it. Appearing on Mr. Letterman’s “Late Show” on CBS to promote his coming film, “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps,” Mr. Douglas, above left with Mr. Letterman, said he was given the diagnosis earlier in the summer after seeing several doctors for a nagging sore throat. Asked by Mr. Letterman about the severity of his condition  a Stage 4 cancer is defined as one that has spread to other parts of the body  Mr. Douglas replied: “The big thing you’re always worried about is it spreading, so I am head and neck. I am above the neck, so nothing’s gone down, and the expectations are good.” Mr. Douglas, 65, said he had completed the first week of an eight-week chemotherapy regimen. When asked by Mr. Letterman if he smoked, Mr. Douglas said he smoked and drank, adding, “This particular type of cancer is caused by alcohol and drinking.” When asked about his chances for recovery, Mr. Douglas replied: “The percentages are very good. I would hate to say, but right now it looks like it should be 80 percent, and with certain hospitals and everything, it does improve.”
Title: Michael Douglas Discusses His Cancer on ‘Late Show’

Content: Dr. Ronald A. DePinho likes to call the HPV shot series a “cancer vaccine.”
Title: An Improved Vaccination Against a Virus — and Some Cancers

Content: At a time when genetic testing and genetically personalized treatments for cancer are proliferating, buoyed by new resources like President Obama’s $215 million personalized medicine initiative, women with breast cancer are facing a frustrating reality: The genetic data is there, but in many cases, doctors do not know what to do with it.
Title: When Gene Tests for Breast Cancer Reveal Grim Data but No Guidance

Content: Bobby Murcer, the Yankees outfielder and broadcaster, died on Saturday at age 62. He had been battling brain cancer since being found to have a tumor on Christmas Eve in 2006.
Title: Murcer Loses His Fight With Cancer

Content: Seeking to rein in medical costs, a commission in Michigan on Wednesday moved to prevent hospitals in the state from each spending $100 million or more to provide a new form of radiation treatment for cancer.
Title: States Limit Costly Sites for Cancer Radiation

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first treatment that uses a so-called cancer vaccine, a drug that trains the body’s own immune system to fight the disease.
Title: F.D.A. Approves ‘Vaccine’ to Fight Prostate Cancer

Content: Suleika Jaouad was just starting her adult life when leukemia struck. Her diagnosis and her brother’s role as her bone marrow donor have affected her entire family.
Title: Life, Interrupted: A Family Gets Cancer

Content: Less than two weeks after Angelina Jolie described her decision to have a double mastectomy to avoid breast cancer in an Op-Ed article in The New York Times, her aunt, Debbie Martin, has died of the disease in Escondido, Calif., The Associated Press reported. She was 61 and died on Sunday.
Title: Angelina Jolie’s Aunt Dies of Breast Cancer

Content: People are always giving advice to cancer patients. Whether it is nutritional advice or doctor recommendations or tips on how to quell the nausea that accompanies chemotherapy, just as soon as people hear you are sick they usually want to find a way to help. Most of the advice is welcome and encouraging, though in some cases you’re just not in the mood to hear what someone has learned because you’re too busy treading water.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Six Ways to Cope With Cancer

Content: Shares of the biotechnology company ImClone Systems jumped Monday as investors responded to better-than-expected results of a study of its Erbitux cancer drug that were reported over the weekend at the annual cancer-care conference.
Title: Annual Cancer Conference Becomes Laboratory for Stocks

Content: A new study adds to the evidence that low-dose aspirin, known to reduce the risk for heart disease, may also reduce the risk for pancreatic cancer.
Title: Aspirin May Cut Pancreatic Cancer Risk

Content: The moment when a cancer begins to spread throughout the body — metastasis — has always been the most dreaded turning point of the disease.
Title: Scientists Begin to Grasp the Stealthy Spread of Cancer

Content: CHICAGO — One of the great frustrations for researchers in the war on cancer is that the body’s own defense system does not do a better job fighting the disease. Tumors, it turns out, have a molecular shield that repels attacks from the immune system.
Title: Drug Helps Defense System Fight Cancer

Content: When researchers reported earlier this year that colorectal cancer rates were rising in adults as young as their 20s and 30s, some scientists were skeptical. The spike in figures, they suggested, might not reflect a real increase in disease incidence but earlier detection, which can be a good thing.
Title: More Young People Are Dying of Colon Cancer

Content: Funny stuff happens when you have cancer. Seriously.
Title: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Cancer Clinic

Content: Odds of survival can greatly improve for people with the most common type of lung cancer if they are given a new drug that activates the immune system along with chemotherapy, a major new study has shown.
Title: Lung Cancer Patients Live Longer With Immune Therapy

Content: Most people would agree that it would be better to prevent cancer, if we could, than to treat it once it developed. Yet economic incentives encourage researchers to focus on treatment rather than prevention.
Title: Why Preventing Cancer Is Not the Priority in Drug Development

Content: ORLANDO, Fla.  The breast cancer drug Herceptin may now have a role in treating stomach cancer as well, according to study results announced here on Sunday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology.
Title: Promising Results in Stomach and Breast Cancer Drugs

Content: FOR sheer energy, few performers -- perhaps few people -- can match George Carlin, the prince of outrage, a man for whom the hypocrisy of politicians, the callowness of the masses and of course the absurd details of modern life have served as comedic rocket fuel for more than 40 years. So it's a little disconcerting when on a wet early winter day in Manhattan, Mr. Carlin shuffles into a Midtown hotel, unravels himself from his hat, coat, dark glasses and scarf, and rushes to sit down.
Title: Cancer? Suicide? Politics? That's Hilarious!

Content: Genentech Inc.'s cancer drug Avastin prolonged the lives of patients with advanced lung cancer in a clinical trial, a result that sent the company's shares soaring and could pave the way for wider use of what is widely considered the company's most promising product.
Title: Genentech Drug Shows Effect on a 2nd Cancer

Content: Personal Health columnist Jane E. Brody writes about healthy tans, “A Healthy Glow That’s Truly Healthy,” in this week’s Science Times.
Title: Readers Ask: Sun Safety and Skin Cancer

Content: While I continue taking an experimental drug to keep my cancer at bay, I cannot claim to be in either a remission or a recurrence, and the word “maintenance” does not shed much light on the situation. The paucity of the language at my disposal stymies me, as does its obfuscations. I am grateful that patients , hungry for more fortifying formulations, have begun to create them.
Title: Living With Cancer: Coming to Terms

Content: TWO patients, I’ll call them Sara and Janine, both learned that they had ductal carcinoma in situ (D.C.I.S.), often referred to as Stage 0 breast cancer. Both underwent lumpectomies in their early 50s. Told that worrisome cells were found, both had another surgery. Then a third surgery was recommended.
Title: Let Fear Guide Early Stage Breast-Cancer Decisions

Content: NEW DELHI — More women die from cervical cancer every year in India than anywhere else in the world, according to the Cervical Cancer-Free Coalition, an American research and advocacy group that released a “cervical cancer global crisis card” Friday.
Title: India Ranks No. 1 in Cervical Cancer Deaths

Content: Women undergoing in vitro fertilization have long worried that the procedure could raise their risk for breast cancer.
Title: I.V.F. Does Not Raise Breast Cancer Risk, Study Shows

Content: About a dozen women with breast cancer, some tearful, beseeched the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday to retain the approval of the drug Avastin as a treatment for the disease.
Title: Cancer Survivors Appeal to F.D.A. Over Avastin

Content: The widely prescribed drug tamoxifen already plays a major role in reducing the risk of death from breast cancer. But a new study suggests that women should be taking the drug for twice as long as is now customary, a finding that could upend the standard that has been in place for about 15 years.
Title: Bigger Role Seen for Breast Cancer Drug

Content: “I thought I was completely healthy.”
Title: With Cancer in the Past, Ryuichi Sakamoto Returns to His Calling

Content: I first met my patient, a former truck driver, in 2009, when he was in his mid-50s and had just been diagnosed with acute lymphocytic leukemia, or A.L.L. Often when my patients first learn that they have acute leukemia, they ask me: “Do I have the good one?”
Title: When Doctors Withdraw Cancer Treatment

Content: Men who have been screened for prostate cancer by the most commonly used tests have no greater chance of surviving the disease than those who have not been screened at all, new research has found.
Title: Report Casts Fresh Doubts on Prostate Cancer Testing

Content: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today that doctors had found cancer in his prostate and that he was undergoing tests to determine whether he would be treated with surgery or radiology.
Title: Washington Mayor Reveals Cancer Diagnosis

Content: In mid-January, after a fall on invisible ice, I was informed by an emergency room doctor that my fractured pelvis would heal in six to eight weeks. To help me recover from the injury, therapists started coming to my house. Their ministrations posed a question that nagged at me: why aren’t trained professionals made available to cancer outpatients in the way occupational and physical therapists are routinely assigned to orthopedic patients?
Title: After Physical Therapy, Why Not Cancer Therapy?

Content: The risk posed by certain gene mutations linked to breast cancer may be lower than commonly believed, a new study shows.
Title: Breast Cancer Gene Risk May Be Overstated

Content: A new noninvasive screening test can detect most cases of colorectal cancer and also many precancerous polyps, potentially helping to sharply reduce the death toll from the disease, according to results of a study released on Thursday.
Title: Noninvasive Cancer Test Is Effective, Study Finds

Content: The Food and Drug Administration for the first time has authorized a genetic testing company to offer screenings for three breast cancer mutations common in Ashkenazi Jews, giving consumers the ability to initiate testing at home and see results without talking to a doctor or counselor.
Title: F.D.A. Approves First Home Testing for 3 Breast Cancer Mutations, With Caveats

Content: MEMPHIS — After her doctor told her two months ago that she had breast cancer, Debrah Reid, a 58-year-old dance teacher, drove straight to a funeral home. She began planning a burial with the funeral director and his wife, even requesting a pink coffin.
Title: Tackling a Racial Gap in Breast Cancer Survival

Content: People with pancreatic cancer are more likely than those without the disease to have been infected with the hepatitis B virus, a study has shown for the first time.
Title: Study Links Hepatitis B and Cancer of Pancreas

Content: Millions of Americans will be wondering how Senator John McCain is coping with the news that he has an aggressive form of brain cancer known as glioblastoma. I certainly am: I found out that I had the same type of deadly tumor 18 months ago.
Title: John McCain’s Brain Cancer, and Mine

Content: The moment when a cancer begins to spread throughout the body -- metastasis -- has always been the most dreaded turning point of the disease.
Title: Scientists Begin to Grasp the Stealthy Spread of Cancer

Content: Vitamin use is common among the nation’s 10 million cancer survivors, despite little evidence that supplements help and worries that some may actually fuel the disease.
Title: Despite Risks, Vitamins Popular With Cancer Patients

Content: When Robert B. Darnell was a graduate student in the early 1980s, he spent a year sequencing a tiny fragment of DNA. Now Dr. Darnell is an oncologist and the president of the New York Genome Center, where the DNA-sequencing machines can decode his grad-school fragment in less than a ten-thousandth of a second.
Title: Enlisting a Computer to Battle Cancers, One by One

Content: This article was reported and written in collaboration with ProPublica, the nonprofit journalism organization.
Title: Top Cancer Doctor Resigns as Editor of Medical Journal

Content: LONDON — AstraZeneca announced on Thursday that a cancer drug in development had not shown as much progress as expected, a setback for the pharmaceutical company, which is grappling with weak sales and competition from manufacturers of generics.
Title: AstraZeneca’s Cancer Drug Trial Disappoints, Sending Shares Lower

Content: Dr. Harold E. Varmus, the Nobel Prize-winning molecular biologist who has presided over the National Institutes of Health during the greatest expansion in its 112-year history, told President Clinton yesterday that he would resign at the end of the year to become president and chief executive of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.
Title: Nobel Winner Is to Head Cancer Center

Content: In a cancer patient, lymph nodes are the closest thing to a crystal ball. Gaze into them after removing a tumor. The presence of malignant cells may be a sign that the cancer will recur, leading to more tests and intensive treatment.
Title: Tiny bit of cancer poses treatment puzzle

Content: CT scans in children can cause small but significant increases in the risk of leukemia and brain cancer, a new study finds.
Title: CT Scans Increase Children’s Cancer Risk, Study Finds

Content: People with pancreatic cancer are more likely than those without the disease to have been infected with the hepatitis B virus, a study has shown for the first time.
Title: Study links pancreatic cancer to hepatitis B

Content: Guilt, like cancer, is a greedy guest feasting on its host. It is nondiscriminatory. We have all felt it, wondered what it was doing there, willed it to go away.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Feeling Guilty About Cancer

Content: Incidences of colorectal cancer have been decreasing by about 1 percent a year since the mid 1980s, but incidences among people under 50 — the recommended screening age — has been increasing sharply, and these younger patients are more likely to present with advanced disease.
Title: Colon Cancer Rates Rising in Young Adults

Content: The breast cancer drug letrozole reduces the chances that a woman’s cancer will return and improves her odds of survival to a greater degree than tamoxifen, a widely used estrogen blocker, according to a new analysis.
Title: Regimens: Better Blocker of Breast Cancer Recurrence

Content: Mina Bissell will never forget the reception she got from a prominent scientist visiting Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, where she worked. She gave him a paper she had just published on the genesis of cancer.
Title: Old Ideas Spur New Approaches in Cancer Fight

Content: ''Dr. Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer,'' by Patrick C. Walsh and Janet Farrar Worthington, Warner Books, $25.95.
Title: Fighting Back When Foe Is Prostate Cancer

Content: Bad news for men popped up in news media all over the country this week, based on a study from Northwestern University reporting that cases of advanced, aggressive prostate cancer had risen sharply from 2004 to 2013.
Title: Flawed Study of Advanced Prostate Cancer Spreads False Alarm

Content: President Clinton is missing an opportunity to promote breast and cervical cancer awareness, Representative Rick A. Lazio said today, by deciding to privately sign a bill that Mr. Lazio had backed.
Title: Lazio Criticizes President on Cancer Bill
Reacting to Angelina Jolie’s Breast Cancer News

Content: Recently, I lost a day at work when my Upshot colleague Austin Frakt emailed me first thing in the morning to tell me that headlines were appearing declaring that an “explosive new cellphone-cancer” study was making the rounds. As I have long been interested in this topic, I started to read the headlines and news.
Title: Why It’s Not Time to Panic About Cellphones and Cancer

Content: A combination of common and minor variations in five regions of DNA can help predict a man’s risk of getting prostate cancer, researchers are reporting today.
Title: New Genetic Risks for Prostate Cancer Identified

Content: BOSTON — Researchers have developed a test that can identify minute amounts of tumor cells floating in the blood of cancer patients, a discovery that could lead to better treatments with fewer side effects.
Title: New technology could improve cancer treatments

Content: AS the group of women trickled into the aerobics studio at the Bendheim Integrative Medicine Center in Manhattan on a recent Thursday morning, there were subtle signs that this was no ordinary fitness class.
Title: Said the Doctor to the Cancer Patient: Hit the Gym

Content: A new implant tries to anticipate seizures before they happen — and stop them; a new test could help cut down on colonoscopy visits; you may think you can spot someone in a lie, but science says different.
Title: Progress on Epilepsy and Cancer, To Catch a Lie

Content: A federal advisory committee voted Wednesday that Genentech’s drug Avastin should not be approved as a treatment for breast cancer. The drug is already on the market as a treatment for lung and colon cancer.
Title: FDA Panel Votes Against Cancer Drug

Content: An article Thursday on the results of a study indicating that aggressive surgical treatment of a possible precursor to breast cancer may be unnecessary prompted a wide range of responses from readers, among them anger, sadness and relief.
Title: Breast Cancer Treatment and D.C.I.S.: Readers React

Content: A new implant tries to anticipate seizures before they happen; a new test to limit colonoscopy visits; and spotting a liar.
Title: Progress on Epilepsy and Cancer, To Catch a Lie

Content: A new implant tries to anticipate seizures before they happen; a new test to limit colonoscopy visits; and spotting a liar.
Title: Progress on Epilepsy and Cancer, To Catch a Lie

Content: When a co-worker of my husband's found out she had breast cancer, many of her duties were distributed to her peers to allow her time for treatment. In September, it was revealed that she'd been faking the illness, but she continues on the job as usual. My husband and many of his colleagues feel betrayed and angry by her deception and management's inaction. What should be done?
Title: Cancer Chicanery

Content: ATLANTA, June 3 - For women with a certain type of breast cancer, the drug Herceptin has represented a major advance, extending lives and preventing tumor recurrence. But for some of those women, the drug never works, and it eventually stops working for others.
Title: New Drug Holds Promise for Type of Breast Cancer

Content: With ingredients like bloodroot, shark cartilage and Cat’s Claw and assertions like “causes cancer cells to commit suicide,” it’s no wonder the Food and Drug Administration is taking notice.
Title: F.D.A. Takes Aim at Herbal Cancer ‘Cures’

Content: ''Breast Cancer: The Complete Guide'' (third edition), by Dr. Yashar Hirshaut and Dr. Peter I. Pressman (Bantam Books, $15.95).
Title: A Place to Turn When Breast Cancer Strikes

Content: Though relatively rare, it is one of the easiest cancers to spot and diagnose. And if treated early, it is usually curable. So why do experts find oral cancer so vexing?
Title: New Oral Cancer Tests: Crucial or Wasteful?

Content: In a new study involving mice, aerobic exercise slowed the growth of breast cancer tumors and made the cancer more sensitive to chemotherapy. The results raise the possibility that exercise may change the biology of some malignant tumors, potentially making them easier to treat.
Title: How Exercise May Aid Cancer Treatment

Content: Women who undergo hysterectomies often have both ovaries removed along with the uterus in order to prevent ovarian cancer. But a new study suggests ovary removal may increase the risk of another seemingly unrelated ailment, lung cancer.
Title: Risks: Ovary Removal Linked to Increased Lung Cancer Risk

Content: The lyrical Southern novelist Pat Conroy, whose books include “The Prince of Tides” and “The Great Santini,” announced Monday that he had pancreatic cancer.
Title: The Author Pat Conroy Announces He Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Which of These Foods Will Stop Cancer? (Not So Fast)

Content: The lyrical Southern novelist Pat Conroy, whose books include “The Prince of Tides” and “The Great Santini,” announced Monday that he had pancreatic cancer.
Title: The Author Pat Conroy Announces He Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: I have survived over 40 years of ill health. Even so I have learned to live a life of chronic patienthood where I am not dominated by illness. I have managed to focus on goals that have nothing to do with illness. Living life for me is learning to surf above the uneven terrain of my health.
Title: When Cancer Changes Your Appearance

Content: Dec. 19, 1996 -- I got my first mammogram today at a place called the Breast Health Center in San Francisco. I've never really considered whether I had healthy breasts. Healthy knees, yes. Healthy gums, maybe. But healthy breasts? I don't even do self-exams, except when I read something about cancer in the paper.
Title: 35 and Mortal: A Breast Cancer Diary

Content: News reports and TV shows have showcased stories of healthy women who have had both breasts removed because of their high risk for breast cancer, but relatively few women who have not had cancer actually take this radical step, a new study of New York state data has found.
Title: More Women With Breast Cancer Choosing Double Mastectomies, Study Finds

Content: Genentech Inc., the biotechnology company, said the Food and Drug Administration gave the experimental cancer medicine Avastin its ''fast track'' designation. The status means the F.D.A. will help the company to more quickly submit its application for approval. The designation also leads to a quicker review. Genentech, which is based in South San Francisco, Calif., said last month that Avastin helped patients with colon cancer live longer. Genentech says that Avastin may reach the market next year.
Title: GENENTECH CANCER DRUG TO GET ACCELERATED REVIEW

Content: For years, many doctors and patients thought colonoscopies, the popular screening test for colorectal cancer, were all but infallible. Have a colonoscopy, get any precancerous polyps removed, and you should almost never get colon cancer.
Title: Colonoscopies Miss Many Cancers, Study Finds

Content: American Pharmaceutical Partners won approval for its new form of a drug for advanced breast cancer, setting off a 28 percent gain in its share price yesterday. The Food and Drug Administration cleared the drug, Abraxane, on Friday for use in women whose breast cancer has spread and who were not helped by other chemotherapy combinations, the agency said. Shipments of the drug, also cleared for patients who relapsed within six months of initial surgery and chemotherapy, will start within 45 days, the company said. Stock in American Pharmaceutical, based in Los Angeles, rose $11.01, to $49.72 a share.
Title: F.D.A. APPROVES AMERICAN PHARMACEUTICAL'S CANCER DRUG

Content: Times writer Dana Jennings blogs each week about being diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer.
Title: Running to Reclaim Your Body From Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON — Cancer researchers say there has been a substantial increase in women under the age of 26 who have received a diagnosis of early-stage cervical cancer, a pattern that they say is most likely an effect of the Affordable Care Act.
Title: Rise in Early Cervical Cancer Detection Is Linked to Affordable Care Act

Content: The results of a new study are tempering hopes that a drug used to treat bone loss might also help stave off relapses of breast cancer, especially for younger women, researchers said Thursday.
Title: Mixed Result for Bone Drug in Cancer Study

Content: Is fear holding you back from a potentially lifesaving screening test?
Title: Why People Aren’t Screened for Colon Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON  Annual CT scans of current and former heavy smokers reduced their risk of death from lung cancer by 20 percent, a huge government-financed study has found. Even more surprising, the scans seem to reduce the risks of death from other causes as well, suggesting that the scans could be catching other illnesses.
Title: CT Scans Cut Lung Cancer Deaths, Study Finds

Content: WASHINGTON — U.S. and Canadian researchers have taken steps toward developing a gene test to determine whether a patient's lung cancer is especially aggressive or whether radical treatment can be avoided.
Title: Gene test would assess lung cancer

Content: In sobering detail, a surgeon outlined for Daniel L. Lawrence what would be a 19-hour operation to remove his cancerous vocal cords and reconstruct a new tongue with tissue taken from his armpit.
Title: Cancer Survivor Finds a 'Lifeboat'

Content: A new digital ad campaign from Priorities USA, a “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton, equates fighting bigotry with stopping the presidential candidacy of Donald J. Trump. Priorities is spending $500,000 — a large amount for an online ad — on the first commercial, “Dante,” which portrays Mr. Trump as biased against the disabled.
Title: A Young Cancer Survivor Scolds Donald Trump

Content: My internist warned me that nobody understands enough about prostate cancer to make easy decisions about how to treat it, but he didn’t prepare me for the barrage of numbers that kept pretending that all is known.
Title: In Prostate Cancer, Pick a Number, Any Number

Content: WASHINGTON, April 29  Tony Snow, press secretary to President Bush, has a message for people with cancer: “Don’t think about dying. Think about living.”
Title: Bush Spokesman to Return and Start Cancer Treatment

Content: ImClone Systems said yesterday that its cancer drug Erbitux failed to help pancreatic cancer patients live longer in a study, a setback for the company’s plan to expand the market for its only product.
Title: ImClone’s Drug Fails in Pancreatic Cancer Study

Content: Cancer rates among New Jerseyans 65 and older are nearly 13 percent higher than the national average, according to statistics released this week by the state Department of Health and Human Services. Officials said they did not know the reason for the rates. Wendy Ginsburg
Title: Breifing: Health; CANCER AMONG ELDERLY

Content: Wading into the health care debate, First Lady Michelle Obama said on Friday that a health care overhaul would ease the struggles faced by women with breast cancer.
Title: First Lady Talks About Breast Cancer

Content: If someone invented a pill to cut a cancer risk in half, would you take it?
Title: When Lowering the Odds of Cancer Isn’t Enough

Content: There is new evidence that breast-feeding is associated with a lower incidence of breast cancer among a group of younger women who are at particularly high risk: those with breast cancer in the family.
Title: Breast-Feeding Linked to Lower Cancer Risk

Content: A combination of common and minor variations in five regions of DNA can help predict a man's risk of getting prostate cancer, researchers reported Wednesday.
Title: Only $300 to learn risk of prostate cancer

Content: Doctors have taken an important step toward a long-sought goal: harnessing a person’s own immune system to fight cancer.
Title: Patient’s Cells Deployed to Attack Aggressive Cancer

Content: There is a new nuclear arms race under way  in hospitals.
Title: Cancer Fight Goes Nuclear, With Heavy Price Tag
Melatonin, sleep aid that may fight cancer

Content: Genentech Inc. said yesterday that it had entered into an agreement with the Idec Pharmaceuticals Corporation of San Diego to jointly develop the Idec drug for the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, a type of cancer. The potential value of the deal to Idec is $57 million. The Idec drug, a monoclonal antibody based on a natural protein, is expected to enter the third of three phases of clinical trials needed to apply for approval by the Food and Drug Administration in the middle of this year. Genentech, based in San Francisco, and Idec will promote the drug in the United States and Canada, with Idec receiving a share of profits. Shares of Idec rose 87.5 cents, to $4.50, in Nasdaq trading.
Title: GENENTECH AND IDEC TO DEVELOP CANCER DRUG

Content: President Obama’s initiative to advance personalized medicine depends on the sort of breakthroughs in cell biology that have produced cancer drugs like the one extending my life. Yet very few adults with cancer enroll in clinical trials. Why do many trials fail to enroll sufficient patients, when scientists now test less debilitating therapies than those commonly used?
Title: Living With Cancer: Clinical Trials Looking for Patients

Content: A vegetarian diet, especially one that includes fish, significantly reduces the risk of colorectal cancer, a large new study reports.
Title: Vegetarian Diet May Cut Colon Cancer Risk

Content: CARACAS, Venezuela — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela said on Tuesday that doctors had found a new lesion that could indicate a return of his cancer, and that he would undergo an operation to have it removed.
Title: Chávez Says His Cancer Shows Sign of Return

Content: CHICAGO — Many men with prostate cancer put off using chemotherapy as long as possible, fearing its side effects.
Title: Study May Alter Approach to Prostate Cancer

Content: The Food and Drug Administration stopped just short of withdrawing the lung cancer pill Iressa from the market yesterday, restricting access to the drug to existing or previous users and to patients in clinical trials.
Title: F.D.A. Restricts Access to Cancer Drug, Citing Ineffectiveness

Content: WASHINGTON  The Nevada Cancer Institute, in Las Vegas, may not have a national reputation as a clinic or a research facility. But it does have the ear of its state’s senior senator, Harry Reid, the Democratic leader. And that is why the four-year-old institute could reap a big gain in federal reimbursements as part of the health care overhaul.
Title: Health Bill Could Assist Four Cancer Centers

Content: A new study has found that high bodily levels of the trace elements nickel and selenium may be associated with reduced risk for pancreatic cancer, and that high levels of arsenic, cadmium and lead may increase the risk.
Title: Patterns: Trace Elements and Pancreatic Cancer Risk

Content: Years ago, a friend and co-worker of mine with ovarian cancer lost all of her blonde hair during treatment. She donned a red wig and declared, “I’m going to do cancer as a redhead!”
Title: Cancer Emotions: Upbeat, Stoic or Just Scared?

Content: CHICAGO — Women who have a history of migraine headaches are far less likely to develop breast cancer than other women, U.S. researchers said Thursday.
Title: Migraines associated with lower risk of breast cancer

Content: Women who have more than two alcoholic drinks a day double their risk of endometrial cancer compared with those who drink less, a new study finds.
Title: Hazards: Heavy Drinking May Raise Risk of Endometrial Cancer

Content: Four major studies reported yesterday show that high-dose chemotherapy followed by a bone-marrow transplant, a grueling procedure held out as a hope to many women with advanced breast cancer, does not prolong their survival over all. But the medical group that announced the findings cautioned that it was still too soon to pass final judgment on the procedure.
Title: Doubts Raised on a Breast Cancer Procedure

Content: Even as Herceptin has become a hugely successful breast cancer drug, doctors have been troubled by a nagging question that has billion-dollar implications: How long should patients be treated with it?
Title: Studies Back Length of Herceptin Cancer Treatment

Content: Men whose results are normal on a popular screening test for prostate cancer may have cancer nevertheless, a new study finds. The result, medical experts say, raises questions about what a normal test score should be and whether the cancers in these men, discovered with biopsies, are better off left alone or treated.
Title: Flaws Seen in Popular Test for Prostate Cancer

Content: Before penicillin came along, syphilis was known in medical circles as “the great mimicker,” a stealthy disease able to mangle the human body in virtually all known ways. “Know syphilis and you know medicine,” professors would tell their students.
Title: Breast Cancer Tales: The Inspirational vs. the Actual
