Content: Vaccines against cervical cancer work well even in sexually active women with H.I.V., a new study has found. It also found that women who already have one or two strains of the cancer-causing virus can be protected against others.
Title: Cancer Vaccine Proves Effective in H.I.V. Patients

Content: I have survived over 40 years of ill health. Even so I have learned to live a life of chronic patienthood where I am not dominated by illness. I have managed to focus on goals that have nothing to do with illness. Living life for me is learning to surf above the uneven terrain of my health.
Title: When Cancer Changes Your Appearance

Content: The Tasmanian devil, the spaniel-size marsupial found on the Australian island of Tasmania, has been hurtling toward extinction in recent years, the victim of a bizarre and mysterious facial cancer that spreads like a plague.
Title: Scientists Discover Origin of a Cancer in Tasmanian Devils

Content: A new study finds that many women with early breast cancer do not need a painful procedure that has long been routine: removal of cancerous lymph nodes from the armpit.
Title: Lymph Node Study Shakes Pillar of Breast Cancer Care

Content: In 2006, the National Cancer Institute took the rare step of issuing a “clinical announcement,” a special alert it holds in reserve for advances so important that they should change medical practice.
Title: Effective Ovarian Cancer Treatment Is Underused, Study Finds

Content: 12/9/11 | Updated to correct references to data on disease progression and to the statistical significance.
Title: New Setback for Avastin as Breast Cancer Treatment

Content: As Don Baylor drove across the country last week, from Southern California to South Florida, alone with so many thoughts, he noticed that every car was passing him on the right.
Title: Baylor Is Back at Camp After Cancer Treatment

Content: Breast cancer rates fell sharply in 2003, and the lower rate remained in 2004, researchers are reporting today.
Title: Sharp Drop in Rates of Breast Cancer Holds

Content: A Distinct Grace
Title: Confronting the Specter of Breast Cancer

Content: SEOUL, South Korea  The North Korean leader Kim Jong-il, who suffered a stroke last August, was also found to have “life-threatening” pancreatic cancer around the same time, a South Korean cable television network reported on Monday.
Title: N. Korean Leader Dying of Cancer, Report Says
Screening proves itself in breast cancer fight

Content: Only about one-quarter of invasive ovarian cancers are detected in the early stages, when the disease is most treatable. Now, preliminary results from a large, continuing trial indicate that postmenopausal women who are screened for ovarian cancer either by transvaginal ultrasound scan or by a blood test followed by a scan are more likely to have their cancers detected at early stages, with almost half the cancers picked up before they had spread beyond the pelvis.
Title: Screening Can Detect Early Ovarian Cancer

Content: After blessing the opening of a new cancer center, John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he did not apply the word ''cancer'' to himself.
Title: Cardinal Avoids 'Cancer' in Citing Tumor

Content: Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco is about to begin construction of a $20 million cancer treatment and wellness center, part of which is expected to open late next year, said Joel Seligman, the institution's president and chief executive officer.
Title: Hospital to Build Center To Treat Cancer Patients

Content: A biotechnology cancer drug cuts in half the risk that one type of breast cancer will recur after surgery, the National Cancer Institute and the drug's manufacturer announced yesterday.
Title: Breast Cancer Recurrence Is Cut in Half by a Drug

Content: Cancer of the throat took away Peter Broomfield’s natural voice. “I sound like a robot,” he said, pressing the tiny microphone-like instrument, called a Servox, against his neck above the trachea. A listener can slightly imagine how his Caribbean accent sounded before the cancer operation in 1990 that removed his larynx.
Title: The Consequences of Surviving Throat Cancer at 37

Content: If a movie were made about Dr. Donald L. Morton, its plot would go like this: A coal miner's son grows up in West Virginia in a house without electricity and running water. He becomes a top cancer surgeon and helps develop a technique that spares countless patients arduous operations. He also develops melanoma, the deadly skin cancer he specializes in treating. He survives.
Title: Cancer Pioneer Aims To Market a Vaccine

Content: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 1 - Wellington Mara, an owner of the Giants for more than 70 years and one of the patriarchs of the National Football League, is being treated for cancer, team officials said Wednesday.
Title: Giants' Longtime Owner in Treatment for Cancer

Content: Suleika Jaouad, 23, is chronicling her return to her parents’ home, and to a life of being cared for, in a post on The Times’s Well blog. Her “boomerang”  back toward her childhood house came about as a result of her diagnosis of  leukemia last year, and now, waiting for a bone marrow transplant, her life has become, she writes, a “slow emergency,” her world “a waiting room.”
Title: When Cancer ‘Boomerangs’ the Adult Child

Content: A day after Warren Buffett announced he had prostate cancer, the question on the minds of many men and their doctors is this: “Why was an 81-year-old man screened for the disease in the first place?”
Title: Why Was Warren Buffett Screened for Prostate Cancer?

Content: Suleika Jaouad, 23, is chronicling her return to her parents’ home, and to a life of being cared for, in a post on The Times’s Well blog. Her “boomerang”  back toward her childhood house came about as a result of her diagnosis of  leukemia last year, and now, waiting for a bone marrow transplant, her life has become, she writes, a “slow emergency,” her world “a waiting room.”
Title: When Cancer ‘Boomerangs’ the Adult Child

Content: Tests commonly recommended to screen healthy women for ovarian cancer do more harm than good and should not be performed, a panel of medical experts said on Monday.
Title: Ovarian Cancer Screenings Are Not Effective, Panel Says

Content: What does it take to get smokers to give up the habit? For some, not even lung cancer surgery does the trick.
Title: Smoking Again After Lung Cancer Surgery

Content: With equal access to the latest therapy, African-American children with cancer can recover and survive as long as white children with the disease, according to researchers at a major children's treatment center.
Title: A Hospital Sees Gain For Blacks On Cancer

Content: New details emerging from an investigation into research fraud in a South African breast cancer study suggest that the deception and violations of ethics were even more serious than initially recognized and may have included patients' being given experimental treatment without their knowledge or consent.
Title: More Deception Is Suspected In Cancer Study

Content: When J. W. received a diagnosis of metastatic colon cancer on her 30th birthday, she and her family were in such a state of shock that they did what the first doctor recommended: having a stent installed to relieve the blockage in her colon and undergoing months of chemotherapy to shrink the tumors, which had already spread to her ovaries and abdomen.
Title: What's a Cancer Patient to Do When Even the Experts Can't Agree?

Content: The links will spawn new windows .
Title: Women´s Health Resources: Ovarian Cancer

Content: Some women so strongly prefer a female colonoscopist that they are willing to delay the procedure for a month or pay up to $200 extra to have a woman perform it.
Title: Testing: Choosing a Costly Wait for Cancer Screening

Content: Dr. David A. Karnofsky was a brilliant oncologist working hard at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center to provide the best possible therapies for cancer patients. My mother, who died of ovarian cancer in 1958, was one of them. And while he could not save her, we were ever so grateful for the caring way he treated her.
Title: The Shock of Lung Cancer, When It Strikes Nonsmokers

Content: In a cancer patient, lymph nodes are the closest thing to a crystal ball. Gaze into them after removing a tumor. The presence of malignant cells may be a sign that the cancer will recur, leading to more tests and intensive treatment.
Title: With a Tiny Bit of Cancer, Debate on How to Proceed

Content: Americans seem very afraid of cancer, with good reason. Unlike other things that kill us, it often seems to come out of nowhere.
Title: Helpless to Prevent Cancer? Actually, Quite a Bit Is in Your Control

Content: The Dendreon Corporation said its Provenge vaccine for prostate cancer might not make the goals set for a late-stage study, according to an interim analysis of results, setting off a 38 percent fall in its share price. Shares of Dendreon, a developer of cancer-vaccine candidates, fell $3.05, to $5, on Nasdaq, where it led the list of percentage losers. Provenge, Dendreon's leading experimental product, may not be as effective as researchers had hoped in slowing the progression of prostate cancer, said the company, which is based in Seattle. The drug is in the last of three stages of testing generally required for Food and Drug Administration approval. The study findings indicate ''that it is possible, but not probable, that the primary endpoint of the study will be achieved,'' Dendreon's chief executive, Christopher S. Henney, said in a statement.
Title: DENDREON SAYS ITS CANCER VACCINE IS IN DOUBT

Content: Disease seems to be stalking Norma Hedgepeth’s family.
Title: Surrounded by Cancer, and Then Needing Help Herself

Content: Genentech Inc. and Roche Holding have won a bidding contest for the rights to a promising cancer drug from its developer, a small Long Island biotechnology company, the three companies announced today.
Title: Cancer Drug Developer Gets Partners

Content: Mary Elizabeth Williams’s latest book, “A Series of Catastrophes and Miracles,” starts with the spoiler: This is a cancer memoir with a happy ending, where one of those post-scan phone calls comes, at last, with good news.
Title: When ‘Having It All’ Includes Having Cancer

Content: An experimental treatment tripled the survival rate of men with advanced prostate cancer in a clinical trial, doctors said yesterday, a result they said represents perhaps the first significant success for therapies known as cancer vaccines.
Title: Prostate Cancer Vaccine Shows Promise in a Trial

Content: Genentech’s drug Avastin did not help women with breast cancer live meaningfully longer, and it caused significant side effects, including a few deaths, the Food and Drug Administration said today in a review of the drug.
Title: F.D.A. Cites Risks in a Genentech Cancer Drug

Content: There may yet be hope for the Tasmanian devil.
Title: New Hope for Tasmanian Devils in Fight Against Contagious Cancer

Content: Loose pieces of DNA course through our veins. As cells in our body die, they cast off fragments of genes, some of which end up in the bloodstream, saliva and urine.
Title: Searching for Cancer Maps in Free-Floating DNA

Content: A scientific panel appointed by the director of the National Cancer Institute has concluded that there is no evidence that having an abortion increases the risk of breast cancer later in life, a suggestion raised earlier on the agency's Web site.
Title: Panel Finds No Connection Between Cancer and Abortion

Content: In July 2005, Jeff Carenza and his girlfriend were enjoying a getaway weekend in Miami when food poisoning landed them both in the hospital. Blood tests showed that Dr. Carenza, then 29, had iron-deficiency anemia.
Title: Too Young for This: Facing Cancer Under 40

Content: Walda Lyons’s life has been marked by hardship, but it is not obvious from her demeanor. She survived polio as a child and cancer as an adult and at 62 is determined to resume working for a living.
Title: Regaining Independence After Polio and Cancer

Content: A prostate cancer drug developed by the Seattle biotechnology company Dendreon prolonged the lives of men in a decisive clinical trial, the company announced Tuesday morning.
Title: Promising Test for Dendreon’s Prostate Cancer Drug

Content: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 - With the help of powerful new drugs and surgical treatments, millions of Americans survive cancer, but doctors often ignore the patients' needs after saving their lives, the National Academy of Sciences said on Monday.
Title: Study Faults Follow-Up for Cancer Patients

Content: NEW YORK — A rarely used treatment that pumps chemotherapy directly into the abdominal cavity can add 16 months or more to the lives of many women with advanced cases of ovarian cancer, doctors are reporting.
Title: New treatment makes gains on ovarian cancer

Content: Doctors who treat women with breast cancer are glimpsing the possibility of a vastly different future. After years of adding more and more to the regimen — more drugs, shorter intervals between chemotherapy sessions, higher doses, longer periods of a harsh therapy — they are now wondering whether many women could skip chemotherapy altogether.
Title: Shift in Treating Breast Cancer Is Under Debate

Content: For the first time, researchers have decoded all the genes of a person with cancer and found a set of mutations that may have caused the disease or aided its progression.
Title: One woman's genome hints at causes of cancer

Content: In October 2006, Dr. Claudia Henschke of Weill Cornell Medical College jolted the cancer world with a study saying that 80 percent of lung cancer deaths could be prevented through widespread use of CT scans.
Title: Cigarette Company Paid for Lung Cancer Study

Content: "Chasing Daylight: How My Forthcoming Death Transformed My Life," by Eugene O'Kelly, McGraw-Hill, $19.95.
Title: When Cancer Strikes, a High Achiever Plans

Content: Dr. Bernard Fisher, a senior researcher at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, has been cleared by a Federal research ethics office on charges of scientific misconduct in a landmark breast cancer study.
Title: Cancer Researcher Cleared On Charges of Misconduct

Content: If someone invented a pill to cut a cancer risk in half, would you take it?
Title: When Lowering the Odds of Cancer Isn’t Enough

Content: How do you support a friend or loved one with breast cancer?
Title: Care Package for a Breast Cancer Patient

Content: THE CLAIM -- Hair dye causes cancer.
Title: The Claim: Hair Dye Causes Cancer

Content: For those of us who attended a breast cancer fund-raising golf outing in New Jersey a week ago, the announcement soon after that Amy Mickelson has the disease seemed especially poignant.
Title: After a Cancer Benefit, Especially Troubling News

Content: FOR the first 18 years of my life, I was raised as a vegetarian. My father was convinced of the perils of red meat after my paternal grandmother died on the operating table from late-stage colon cancer. While my father would no doubt be pleased by the news last week that a panel convened by the World Health Organization declared processed meats a cause of colorectal cancer — and red meat a probable one — I’m not convinced.
Title: So Will Processed Meat Give You Cancer?

Content: LONDON – Adaptimmune, a biotechnology company, said on Monday that it had reached a deal that could be worth more than $350 million to develop an early stage cancer drug with the pharmaceutical maker GlaxoSmithKline.
Title: GlaxoSmithKline in $350 Million Cancer Drug Venture

Content: Diane Raymond of Columbia, S.C., was just 45 when she started taking Prempro, the most popular hormone therapy for menopause. Ms. Raymond had not yet entered menopause, but her doctor encouraged her to take the drug anyway. His words, she recalls, were, “We’ll keep the wolves from the door, so when you do go into menopause, the transition will be much smoother.”
Title: Breast Cancer News Brings a Range of Reactions

Content: Lobbying over the issue of human embryonic stem cell research has generated so much controversy that the American Cancer Society has withdrawn its sponsorship of Patients' Cure, a group founded to publicize the medical benefits of stem cell research.
Title: Cancer Society Quits Group on Cell Research

Content: Reuters reports:
Title: Christina Applegate Is Cancer Free After Surgery

Content: Times writer Dana Jennings blogs each week about being diagnosed with an aggressive form of prostate cancer.
Title: Running to Reclaim Your Body From Cancer

Content: Most books about breast cancer are focused on a woman’s immediate crisis, helping them learn more about the disease and make urgent treatment decisions. But what happens to women after all the decisions are made, the treatment is finished and life is supposed to go back to normal?
Title: How to Live Well Beyond Breast Cancer

Content: Is you is or is you ain’t my cancer? I was in a funk about what to do about a possible cancer diagnosis until Beethoven came to the rescue.
Title: While Facing a Cancer Choice, Beethoven to the Rescue

Content: The links will spawn new windows .
Title: Women´s Health Resources: Lung Cancer

Content: Grandma was right when she recommended ginger for an upset stomach  at least for cancer patients.
Title: Ginger Found to Ease Nausea of Cancer Treatment
In cancer battle, U.S. to crack genome codes

Content: The Times's Sheryl Gay Stolberg on the announcement that Tony Snow's cancer has spread to his liver.
Title: Back Story on the White House Spokesman's Cancer

Content: After receiving a diagnosis of prostate cancer, Scott Blackmun, the chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, announced he would not travel to South Korea for the opening ceremony of the Olympics next month.
Title: U.S.O.C. Chief Executive Has Cancer

Content: A new cancer drug that has attracted considerable attention from doctors and investors won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday.
Title: Imbruvica, Drug to Treat Blood Cancer, Gains F.D.A. Approval

Content: Obesity makes ovarian cancer more deadly, a new study reports. Obese women with advanced ovarian cancer have a shorter time to recurrence and a shorter overall survival time than women of ideal weight — and not because obese people often have other medical problems. Obesity itself, the researchers suggest, is the problem.
Title: Obesity Is Found to Make Ovarian Cancer Deadlier

Content: Childhood cancer survivors are at much greater risk of developing diabetes than their siblings, especially if their treatment involved radiation of the abdomen or total body, a new study reports.
Title: Childhood: Early Cancers Increase Diabetes Risk

Content: HARTFORD, Dec. 27 - Gov. M. Jodi Rell underwent what her doctors called successful surgery to remove breast cancer on Monday, her office said.
Title: Connecticut Governor Undergoes Surgery for Breast Cancer

Content: A few simple questions may help women identify the early, often quiet, symptoms of ovarian cancer.
Title: Six Questions to Find Ovarian Cancer Early

Content: For the past year, Dana Jennings, a writer with The New York Times, has shared his personal story of prostate cancer, offering wisdom, humor and insights after learning he had a particularly aggressive form of the disease.
Title: A Dog, a Buzz Cut and Other Cancer Stories

Content: One in five breast cancer patients ages 65 and older postponed radiation therapy or did not complete the full radiation regimen after breast-conserving surgery, and the lapses in care took a significant toll on their health, a new study reports.
Title: Delay in Cancer Treatment Is Found to Raise Recurrence

Content: When Genae Girard received a diagnosis of breast cancer in 2006, she knew she would be facing medical challenges and high expenses. But she did not expect to run into patent problems.
Title: Cancer Patients Challenge the Patenting of a Gene

Content: OVARIAN cancer is an insidious disease: it often produces no symptoms until the tumor has spread far beyond a curable size. The five-year survival rates are "very low," said Dr. Arthur G. Lerner, medical director of White Plains Hospital Center's cancer program.
Title: New Plan to Halt Ovarian Cancer

Content: Darryl Strawberry, the 36-year-old Yankee outfielder, was found today to have cancer of the colon and will undergo surgery, perhaps on Saturday. According to the team and Strawberry's wife, Charisse, doctors say his prognosis for recovery is excellent.
Title: Strawberry to Have Surgery for Colon Cancer

Content: In Dr. Siddhartha Mukherjee’s lab, a Stanley Kubrick-like space at the Herbert Irving Comprehensive Cancer Center at Columbia University, enormous white freezers with digital temperature readouts keep tissue at 80 below zero. Sterile work stations with transparent hoods and bacteria-scattering blowers emit an unearthly blue light. And there is a bountiful supply of mice that, thanks to the addition of a jellyfish gene, literally glow either red or green in the dark.
Title: How Cancer Acquired Its Own Biographer

Content: The Pap test, which has prevented countless deaths from cervical cancer, may eventually help to detect cancers of the uterus and ovaries as well, a new study suggests.
Title: Pap Test Could Help Find Cancers of Uterus and Ovaries

Content: The links will spawn new windows .
Title: Women´s Health Resources: Colorectal Cancer

Content: Annie Krause moved into a nursing home in Detroit in 2015, when she was 98 years old. She had grown frail. Arthritis, recurrent infections and hypertension had made it difficult for her to manage on her own.
Title: For Elderly Women With Breast Cancer, Surgery May Not Be the Best Option

Content: The retired tennis champion Martina Navratilova, who remains a remarkably active 53-year-old, said Wednesday that she was found to have noninvasive breast cancer in February and had undergone a lumpectomy, with radiation treatment to come in May.
Title: Navratilova Says She Has Breast Cancer

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Dogs Excel on Smell Test to Find Cancer

Content: The Coaches vs. Cancer Classic, once a series of preseason games, will start tomorrow as a 16-team tournament. No. 6 Syracuse, ranked sixth in the Associated Press preseason poll, No. 12 Mississippi State and No. 24 Memphis head the field. The competition will begin with four-team regionals over the next three nights:
Title: Coaches vs. Cancer Starts Tomorrow

Content: A drug being developed by Roche Holding, Genentech and OSI Pharmaceuticals helped patients with pancreatic cancer live longer when combined with chemotherapy, a late-stage study showed. About 26 percent of patients treated with the experimental drug, Tarceva, lived at least a year, compared with about 20 percent of patients who received only chemotherapy, the companies said. Roche, which is based in Basel, Switzerland, has filed for approval of the drug in the United States for lung cancer. Genentech, based in South San Francisco, and OSI, based in Melville, N.Y., will jointly market the drug in the United States and share revenue. Roche, which holds a majority stake in Genentech, will sell Tarceva in Europe and pay royalties to OSI, which invented the drug.
Title: ROCHE SAYS DRUG FOR PANCREATIC CANCER IS PROMISING

Content: Lori Siegel did not wait for her hair to grow back. Still feeling the effects of radiation treatments, she sent her résumé to potential employers, bought a new suit and a wig that does not look like a wig, and started going on job interviews.
Title: Cancer survivors at significantly higher risk for joblessness

Content: Lori Siegel did not wait for her hair to grow back. Still feeling the effects of radiation treatments, she sent her résumé to potential employers, bought a new suit and a wig that does not look like a wig, and started going on job interviews.
Title: Cancer survivors at significantly higher risk for joblessness

Content: LONDON — Cancer is the fastest-growing sector of the drug market, but developing new treatments is only half the battle. Persuading payers to use them, particularly in Europe, is another matter.
Title: In Europe, cancer treatments face price hurdles

Content: Yet another experimental drug has shown it can extend the lives of men with advanced prostate cancer.
Title: Prostate Cancer Drug Shows Promise in Study

Content: The breath of people with lung cancer is different from that of healthy people  it contains higher concentrations of alkanes and other volatile organic compounds.
Title: Breath Sensor Identifies Signs of Lung Cancer

Content: DIESEL exhaust probably does not cause cancer in humans, at least not at the concentrations that are common on the streets, according to a re-analysis of previous studies by the Health Effects Institute, an independent scientific organization financed by the Environmental Protection Agency and private industry.
Title: Diesel Link To Cancers In Humans Is Doubted

Content: A long-awaited federal study on possible links between pollution and high rates of breast cancer on Long Island has failed to show any connection between the disease and pesticides that were once widely used on the island. It also found only a very slight correlation between cancer rates and exposure to other pollutants, like car exhaust and cigarette smoke.
Title: L.I. Study Sees No Cancer Tie To Pesticides

Content: Cancer did not slow Matt Higgins. If anything, it affirmed the depth of his resolve. He took one day off for surgery and plunged back into work, crying only when he had to tell his bosses.
Title: Dealing With Cancer, Jets Executive Slows Down by Running

Content: Brett Smith, the father of two young children, was only 26 three years ago when he was found to have advanced melanoma, a deadly skin cancer. Several drugs failed to stop the cancer, while leaving him frail, depleted and ill.
Title: Drugs May Turn Cancer Into Manageable Disease

Content: Government to Launch AIDS Awareness Campaign
Title: Skin Cancer, Health Insurance and Generic Drugs

Content: The drug Herceptin, already used to treat advanced breast cancer, has been approved for early cases as well, the Food and Drug Administration said. The drug is used only for patients with a certain type of breast cancer, called HER-2 positive  about 25 percent of all breast cancer patients. The approval means that women whose cancer has not spread beyond the breast or lymph nodes can now take Herceptin after a lumpectomy or mastectomy. Two studies found that women taking Herceptin for early breast cancers had fewer relapses than women who did not take it. But it is too soon to tell whether the drug prolongs life.
Title: Breast Cancer Drug Is Approved for Early Cases

Content: It was the annual fund-raising event for the Hope Lodge, my temporary home after a bone marrow transplant. The host asked all the survivors to step forward from the crowd. I froze. I didn’t know if that word applied to me. What does it mean to be a survivor? I certainly didn’t feel like one. Not yet, anyway.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Am I a Cancer Survivor?

Content: More than 10 months after state leaders halted grant operations at the Cancer Prevention and Research Institute of Texas, known as Cprit, amid allegations of cronyism and misspent money, the $3 billion enterprise is getting back to the business of fighting cancer, with restructured leadership.
Title: Cancer Agency Is Back in Business, Writing Checks

Content: Christopher Hitchens, the author, Vanity Fair contributing editor and frequent television pundit, has suspended a tour to promote his new book while he receives chemotherapy.
Title: Cancer Causes Hitchens to Cancel Book Tour

Content: While packing up scarves and hats to mail to a member of my cancer support group, I remember her lament. “After the major loss of body parts, why do I weep over my lost hair?” she wondered. “I know it will grow back, but somehow it feels like the last straw — figuratively and literally!”
Title: Living With Cancer: Living Without Hair

Content: In a review of scientific data, the Food and Drug Administration has found almost no evidence that tomatoes or the antioxidant lycopene have any effect in cancer prevention.
Title: Outcomes: Lycopene as Cancer Blocker? Review Says Evidence Is Scant

Content: Diane Raymond of Columbia, S.C., was just 45 when she started taking Prempro, the most popular hormone therapy for menopause. Ms. Raymond had not yet entered menopause, but her doctor encouraged her to take the drug anyway. His words, she recalls, were, "We'll keep the wolves from the door, so when you do go into menopause, the transition will be much smoother."
Title: Breast Cancer News Brings a Range of Reactions

Content: An unsettling fact about lung cancer is that not even clean living can guarantee a free pass. A significant proportion of cases  10 to 15 percent  occur in people who never smoked, and just in the United States, 16,000 to 24,000 a year die.
Title: A Look at Nonsmokers Who Get Lung Cancer

Content: The President’s Cancer Panel is the Mount Everest of the medical mainstream, so it is astonishing to learn that it is poised to join ranks with the organic food movement and declare: chemicals threaten our bodies.
Title: New Alarm Bells About Chemicals and Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON — On March 29, Georgetown University Hospital opened a proton-therapy cancer unit that is expected to treat about 300 patients a year at premium prices using what its proponents promote as the most advanced radiology for attacking certain tumors.
Title: For Cancer Centers, Proton Therapy’s Promise Is Undercut by Lagging Demand

Content: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela declared on Thursday that he had beaten cancer, less than five months after he stunned Venezuelans by revealing that he had undergone emergency surgery to remove a tumor while in seclusion in Cuba.
Title: Hugo Chávez Says His Cancer Is Gone

Content: Opening a new front in the battle against cancer, federal officials are planning to compile a complete catalog of the genetic abnormalities that characterize it.
Title: Huge Genome Project Is Proposed to Fight Cancer

Content: I’m the only mother I know who is happy to see her daughter cry. Not because she deserves to, but because after everything she has faced, her tears are our first glimpse of emotions that have been missing for a very long time.
Title: After Cancer’s Calm, a Daughter’s Emotional Storm

Content: WASHINGTON — Tony Snow, the White House news secretary who has spoken frequently of his battle with colon cancer, has suffered a recurrence, and the disease has spread to his liver, White House officials said Tuesday.
Title: White House spokesman faces new battle with cancer

Content: Selections from Miriam Engelberg’s comic memoir.
Title: “Cancer Made Me a Shallower Person”

Content: Jim Calhoun, the highly successful men's basketball coach at Connecticut, said yesterday that he had an early stage of prostate cancer. He will have surgery Thursday to remove the prostate and said his doctors expected he would return to coaching in three to four weeks.
Title: Cancer Surgery to Sideline UConn Coach Calhoun

Content: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 — A surgeon who was appointed by President Bush this week to lead the National Cancer Institute said Wednesday that he had great hopes for finding new nontoxic cancer drugs but that given a shrinking of resources, some of the institute’s programs would probably have to be phased out.
Title: Cancer Institute’s New Chief Talks of Cutbacks

Content: A treatment rarely used for ovarian cancer, pumping chemotherapy directly into the abdominal cavity, can add 16 months or more to the lives of many women with advanced cases of the disease, doctors report in a study.
Title: Treatment Is Found to Stave Off Ovarian Cancer

Content: Scientists have created the first vaccine that appears able to prevent cervical cancer. The vaccine works by making people immune to a sexually transmitted virus that causes many cases of the disease.
Title: Experimental Vaccine Appears to Prevent Cervical Cancer

Content: AS the group of women trickled into the aerobics studio at the Bendheim Integrative Medicine Center in Manhattan on a recent Thursday morning, there were subtle signs that this was no ordinary fitness class.
Title: Said the doctor to the cancer patient: Hit the gym

Content: THE FACTS
Title: Really? The Claim: Eating Soy Increases the Risk of Breast Cancer

Content: A less invasive surgical technique for removing colon cancers is superior to the standard operation because it can reduce the risk of the cancer recurring and improve a patient's chances for survival, according to a new study by Spanish doctors.
Title: Newer Colon Cancer Surgery Shows Benefits

Content: On a visit to Bangalore, India, in 1998, Robert Weinberg, one of the leading cancer researchers in the United States, met a voraciously curious young doctoral student from a South Indian village so remote that he grew up without phones or television, studying by kerosene lamp. He had no Western-style last name, only a first - Mani.
Title: Breakthroughs seen in cancer spread and stem cells

Content: Obesity makes ovarian cancer more deadly, a new study reports. Obese women with advanced ovarian cancer have a shorter time to recurrence and a shorter overall survival time than women of ideal weight -- and not because obese people often have other medical problems. Obesity itself, the researchers suggest, is the problem.
Title: Obesity Is Found to Make Ovarian Cancer Deadlier

Content: Every summer as Americans slather on sun lotion, they are reminded of the dangers of skin cancer.
Title: Should You Get Screened for Skin Cancer?

Content: PUERTO VALLARTA, Mexico  Some weekends, more than a dozen American men wait at beachfront hotels, anxious for their turns in the treatment room at a small private hospital here.
Title: Despite Doubts, Cancer Therapy Draws Patients

Content: Results of 230 tests on the Toms River water supply, including samples taken from 23 schools, found no harmful contaminants, the State Health Commissioner, Leonard Fishman, said today.
Title: Water Tests Find No Link With Cancers

Content: Most research on prostate cancer focuses on cure rates, but increasingly researchers are paying attention to the quality of a man’s life after prostate cancer treatment.
Title: Taking Time to Decide on Prostate Cancer Treatments

Content: Several new drugs are showing unprecedented promise in treating kidney cancer, a form of cancer that has been particularly hard to treat, doctors said on Sunday.
Title: Drugs Show New Hope in Fighting Cancer

Content: Robert A. Swanson, who co-founded Genentech and is considered a father of the biotechnology industry, was only 52 when he died in 1999, one year after a diagnosis of brain cancer.
Title: Hints of Progress in Drugs Treating Brain Cancer

Content: Giants running back LeShon Johnson smiled when he referred to his wife of six weeks as ''a computer geek.''
Title: Giants' Back Optimistic in Cancer Fight

Content: Provisional state data for January show that the overall incidence of cancers in Nassau fell 3.4 percent from a year earlier; the incidence of breast cancer fell 2.1 percent. Overall, cancers fell one-tenth of 1 percent in Suffolk, but the incidence of breast cancer there rose 1.8 percent.
Title: In Brief; Cancer Cases Decline In Nassau and Suffolk

Content: The Internet is filled with unreliable health information and bogus claims. But sites dedicated to breast cancer information appear to have a high level of accuracy, a new study shows.
Title: Most Breast Cancer Sites Get It Right

Content: The links will spawn new windows .
Title: Women´s Health Resources: Breast Cancer

Content: I began to walk to counter the adverse side effects of cancer treatment – and to stay alive. Some days I could hardly get out of bed. But if I was able to summon the energy to get up and walk, I found I had less physical pain and far less fear and anxiety.
Title: Walking 800 Miles Away From Cancer

Content: On Oct. 15 at 8 a.m., Andy Lindsay stood atop 21,247-foot Mera Peak in Nepal, a wildly improbable place for him to be both athletically and medically.
Title: When the Lung Cancer Patient Climbs Mountains

Content: One year ago, almost to the day, I asked my hairdresser to cut off 16 inches of my hair. It was a pre-emptive strike. A few days later I would be admitted to the oncology unit at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan to undergo chemotherapy to treat leukemia. Everyone knows that chemo takes your hair. I wanted to take control of what I could before the poison did its damage. But I left the hair salon in tears, my braids in a plastic bag.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Finding My Cancer Style

Content: If that’s java in your cup, drink up. A new study says that men who are heavy coffee drinkers are at lower risk for prostate cancer.
Title: Prevention: Coffee Lowers Risk of Prostate Cancer, Harvard Study Says

Content: Wading into the health care debate, First Lady Michelle Obama said on Friday that a health care overhaul would ease the struggles faced by women with breast cancer.
Title: First Lady Talks About Breast Cancer

Content: An easily overlooked type of abnormality in the colon is the most likely type to turn cancerous, and is more common in this country than previously thought, researchers are reporting.
Title: Easily Overlooked Lesions Tied to Colon Cancer

Content: For years, anecdotal evidence has suggested that Long Island has an unusually high rate of cancer. Now, the state has allocated money to find out whether the same holds true for Long Islanders' pets.
Title: State to Assist A L.I. Study Of Pet Cancers

Content: Treatments for prostate cancer take a significant toll on male potency, leaving a surprisingly high percentage of men unable to have a normal sex life, new research shows.
Title: Predicting Sex Life After Prostate Cancer

Content: A new study shows that patients are far less likely to undergo screening for colon cancer if their doctors recommend only colonoscopy, rather than offering other screening options.
Title: Giving Patients Choices in Colon Cancer Screening

Content: Using questionnaires, Italian researchers have found some evidence of an association between kidney cancer and the consumption of large amounts of bread, although the significance of the finding remains unclear.
Title: At Risk: Kidney Cancer Study: Too Much Bread and Pasta?

Content: IT is a word that until a few months ago Anne Mann had never heard of -- let alone knew how to pronounce or spell it. Now, Mrs. Mann, a resident of Chappaqua, has learned how to live with it and is doing her best to help others with it as well.
Title: Fighting Cancer's Prophecy of Doom

Content: A 32-year-old woman in Belgium has become the first woman ever to give birth after having ovarian tissue removed, frozen and then implanted back in her body, doctors are reporting.
Title: Report of First Birth for Cancer Survivor in a Tissue Implant

Content: NeoPharm Inc. said it regained ownership of two cancer compounds after a unit of Pfizer stopped developing them more than two years ago. NeoPharm, based in Lake Forest, Ill., and Pfizer, of New York, ended a pact covering liposome-encapsulated paclitaxel and liposome-encapsulated doxorubicin. Both treatments use a technology that combines fats with the drugs to cut side effects and possibly increase effectiveness. Taking full ownership allows NeoPharm to seek federal approval by early 2007 of its formulation of paclitaxel, a compound that has been cleared for ovarian, breast and lung cancers, the company's chief financial officer, Larry Kenyon, said.
Title: NEOPHARM REGAINS OWNERSHIP OF 2 CANCER COMPOUNDS

Content: A drug that scientists hoped might be a safe new way to prevent breast cancer appears to pose a risk after all: significant bone loss.
Title: Cancer-Deterring Drug Found to Harm Bones

Content: For as long as I can remember, a diagnosis of lung cancer has been virtually a death sentence. Most victims die within a year or two, and some 95 percent ultimately succumb to the disease. So it is hard not to be intrigued by a bold claim that most lung cancers could be cured through a screening program to detect tumors early and remove them promptly.
Title: To Screen or Not for Lung Cancer: Does It Make a Difference?

Content: Maria Friedman, the star of the new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical, "The Woman in White," stood at the center of the stage of the Marquis Theater on Thursday night, accepting a sustained standing ovation for her performance as the show's plucky Victorian heroine.
Title: Musical Really Does Go On as Star Is Treated for Cancer

Content: Reaching back to his home state of Texas, President Bush today named Dr. Andrew C. von Eschenbach, an oncologist who is himself a two-time cancer survivor, to lead the National Cancer Institute.
Title: Texas Oncologist to Lead U.S. Cancer Institute

Content: President Juan Manuel Santos said Monday that he would undergo surgery for prostate cancer this week. The president, 61, said that the cancer had been detected at an early stage and that doctors told him that he had a 97 percent chance of a full recovery. One of his doctors was quoted in Colombian media reports as saying that neither chemotherapy nor radiation therapy would be needed after the surgery, which will remove Mr. Santos’s prostate. Meanwhile, the Colombian government is preparing to open peace talks this month with the country’s largest guerrilla group. The talks are to begin in Oslo and later move to Havana.
Title: Colombia: President to Undergo Surgery for Prostate Cancer

Content: A drug of a class commonly used to combat bone loss may reduce by a third the chance that some breast cancers will spread or recur, a large study has found.
Title: Bone Drugs May Help Fight Breast Cancer

Content: As Chad Kingsbury watches his daughter playing in the sandbox behind their suburban Chicago house, the thought that has flashed through his mind a million times in her two years of life comes again: Chloe will never be sick.
Title: Couples Cull Embryos to Halt Heritage of Cancer

Content: The Federal Bureau of Prisons said Monday that the convicted swindler Bernard L. Madoff had not been diagnosed with cancer and was not terminally ill.
Title: Bureau of Prisons Denies Madoff Has Cancer

Content: The New York Times would like to hear from doctors and patients who have experience giving or receiving immunotherapy treatment for cancer.
Title: Have You Received Immunotherapy Treatment for Cancer?

Content: Whitey Ford, the Yankees Hall of Fame pitcher, who missed spring training this year for the first time in 49 years, acknowledged today that he has cancer, although he declined to provide details.
Title: Whitey Ford Acknowledges That He Is a Cancer Patient

Content: WASHINGTON — The federal Medicare program and private health insurers waste nearly $3 billion every year buying cancer medicines that are thrown out because many drug makers distribute the drugs only in vials that hold too much for most patients, a group of cancer researchers has found.
Title: Waste in Cancer Drugs Costs $3 Billion a Year, a Study Says

Content: There's the war on cancer, and there's the war over cancer -- or what the cancer cognoscenti call ''oncopolitics,'' the high-stakes competition over money, medicine and policy.
Title: Newsletter Trains Muckraking Eye on Cancer World

Content: Responding to a call to improve the quality of cancer care in the United States, a leading cancer organization said here today that it was working with other groups to develop a national system to monitor how well each cancer patient is treated.
Title: Study to Develop Way to Monitor Cancer Care

Content: A fourth kind of cancer has proved to be treatable by Gleevec, a drug that first came to attention because of the remarkable remissions it causes in many patients with a form of leukemia known as C.M.L., for chronic myelogenous leukemia.
Title: Drug Shows Promise in at Least 4 Cancers

Content: WASHINGTON — Representative Carolyn McCarthy, a Democrat from Long Island, announced on Monday that she has a treatable form of lung cancer.
Title: L.I. Representative Faces Treatment for Lung Cancer

Content: The head of a prominent cancer research institute has warned his faculty and staff to limit cellphone use because of a possible cancer risk, The Associated Press reports.
Title: Prominent Cancer Doctor Warns About Cellphones

Content: Congress appears likely to provide coverage for cancer drugs under Medicare this year, lawmakers and lobbyists say, even as it remains unable to agree on a plan to offer comprehensive drug benefits.
Title: MEDICARE PAYMENT FOR CANCER DRUGS IS SEEN AS LIKELY

Content: In May 2011, Cassandra Caton, an 18-year-old with honey-colored hair and the soft features of a child, suddenly went blind in her right eye. Five months later, an ophthalmologist noticed something disturbing. A large growth in the back of her eye had ripped her retina, destroying her vision.
Title: A Life-Death Predictor Adds to a Cancer’s Strain

Content: Fumes from oil burned by spill-response teams in the Gulf of Mexico did not contain enough cancer-causing chemicals to pose a risk to human health, two new studies from the Environmental Protection Agency conclude.
Title: A Verdict on Controlled Oil Burns and Cancer Risk

Content: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — John Edwards said Thursday his wife's cancer has returned, but said he will continue his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination.
Title: John Edwards to continue campaign, despite wife's cancer

Content: The two companies that make vaccines against cervical cancer announced Thursday that they would cut their prices to the world’s poorest countries below $5 per dose, eventually making it possible for millions of girls to be protected against a major deadly cancer.
Title: Cancer Vaccines Get a Price Cut in Poor Nations

Content: Plain, plodding and relentlessly expositive, “Burzynski” tries to wrestle medical clarity from a snarl of science and human suffering. The price paid, however, is a documentary as visually arid as it is topically fertile.
Title: A Texas Doctor With a Possible Cancer Cure

Content: WASHINGTON  The plan for broad use of X-ray body scanners to detect bombs or weapons under airline passengers’ clothes has rekindled a debate about the safety of delivering small doses of radiation to millions of people  a process some experts say is certain to result in a few additional cancer deaths.
Title: Cancer Risks Debated for Type of X-Ray Scan

Content: A simple pill to treat cancer sounds too good to be true. But striking results with the drug known as STI-571, or Gleevec, have shown how effective a custom-designed cancer drug can be. And Gleevec is only one of many such agents now under development.
Title: Scientists View New Wave of Cancer Drugs

Content: Many studies have found that regular aspirin use reduces the risk for colon cancer. Now scientists have found that aspirin may benefit some people far more than others.
Title: Aspirin Benefits Some at Risk for Colon Cancer

Content: ImClone Systems and Bristol-Myers Squibb, under criticism from cancer patients for not moving swiftly enough, said yesterday that they would soon begin several clinical trials aimed at winning approval for their cancer drug, Erbitux. By the end of the year, they said, they also hope to begin a program to provide the drug to desperately ill cancer patients who are not in a trial.
Title: Partners Promise New Tests of Cancer Drug

Content: The final round of the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic, to be held Nov. 18 and 19 at Madison Square Garden, will feature Pitt, Texas, Maryland and Illinois, organizers said. Tickets go on sale Tuesday at noon and are available through Ticketmaster at (866) 448-7849 or Ticketmaster.com.
Title: Coaches vs. Cancer Final Round Is Set

Content: Karen Young-Levi has gone for a mammogram every year since she turned 40, and she would not skip the procedure any more than she would skip her spin classes at the gym or stop wearing her seat belt. “It’s my security blanket,” said Ms. Young-Levi, 43, of Medford, N.J.
Title: New Guidelines on Breast Cancer Draw Opposition

Content: In a serendipitous discovery that grew out of the pleas of a Manhattan lawyer whose young husband was dying of cancer, scientists will report on Thursday that thalidomide, the sedative that maimed thousands of babies in the 1960's, can slow the course of a deadly bone cancer. Some experts say it may become the most effective new drug for the disease in decades.
Title: Thalidomide Found to Slow a Bone Cancer

Content: The broadcaster Don Imus said he had prostate cancer, the Web site of the New York television station WCBS (wcbstv.com) reported. Mr. Imus, 68, right, made the remarks during the Monday broadcast of his syndicated radio program “Imus in the Morning,” which in New York is on WABC-AM. He said he had Stage 2 prostate cancer, giving no further details of his prognosis, but added he was confident his doctors would beat it. According to FoxNews.com, Mr. Imus said on the air that the cancer could be a result of stress. Discussing his reaction to the diagnosis, Mr. Imus said: “The day you find out is fine. But the next morning when you get up, your knees are shaking. I didn’t think I could make it to work.”
Title: Don Imus Says He Has Cancer

Content: Gerard Mortier, the opera impresario with a penchant for shaking things up in some of Europe’s most storied opera houses and music festivals, is being treated for cancer, the Spanish newspaper El País reported this week.
Title: Gerard Mortier Undergoing Cancer Treatment

Content: Reversing a policy that dates back almost a decade, one of the nation's largest insurers has decided to stop paying for a grueling and controversial breast cancer treatment that has not been proved to work.
Title: Insurer Drops a Therapy for Breast Cancer

Content: In today’s Science Times, I write about new research on preventing the symptoms of lymphedema, the painful swelling that can occur after lymph nodes have been removed or damaged during cancer treatment.
Title: Ask Questions About Cancer, Lymphedema and Exercise

Content: Cytoclonal Pharmaceutics Inc. said it received a patent for a gene that codes an enzyme used in producing the key ingredient in the cancer drug Taxol. The company, based in Dallas, said the patent covers the gene that makes an enzyme needed to produce paclitaxel, the active ingredient in Taxol, a cancer drug sold by Bristol-Myers Squibb, with $1.5 billion in annual sales. The patent also covers the enzyme produced by the gene, and the method used to isolate the gene. The company is working with Bristol-Myers to develop a cost-effective way to produce paclitaxel using genetic engineering, said Arthur Bollon, chief executive of Cytoclonal. Cytoclonal's shares were up $1, to $8.88.
Title: CYTOCLONAL GETS PATENT RELATED TO CANCER DRUG

Content: NEW YORK — The widely used genetic test for breast cancer risk can miss mutations that help cause the disease, according to a new study in the United States, a finding that is likely to increase the pressure to develop more thorough testing methods.
Title: Study finds limitations of gene test for cancer

Content: You’d think that when parents are told of a vaccine that could prevent future cancers in their children, they’d leap at the chance to protect them. Alas, that is hardly the case for a vaccine that prevents infections with cancer-causing human papillomavirus, or HPV. The vaccine, best given at age 11 to 12, is currently the most underutilized immunization available for children.
Title: The Underused HPV Vaccine

Content: Researchers have found a genetic signature in breast tumors that seems to be a powerful predictor of whether the cancer will spread and kill or whether it can easily be cured by surgery, causing no further harm.
Title: Breast Cancer: Genes Are Tied To Death Rates

Content: A few minutes before Ronald DePinho was to give a speech to his graduating class at Fordham College in the Bronx, he sat with his father in a student lounge. It was May 1977. His father had been in the United States for nearly 40 years. The son was on his way to a career in medicine and research that would bring him to the presidency of the biggest cancer center in the country. It was a time for the father, Alvaro DePinho, to pass along some history.
Title: Leader in the Cancer Fight, and Son of an Illegal Immigrant

Content: Doctors who treat women with breast cancer are glimpsing the possibility of a vastly different future. After years of adding more and more to the regimen -- more drugs, shorter intervals between chemotherapy sessions, higher doses, longer periods of a harsh therapy -- they are now wondering whether many women could skip chemotherapy altogether.
Title: Shift in Treating Breast Cancer Is Under Debate

Content: Every winter in the frigid town of South Bend, Ind., Dr. Rafat Ansari notices a definite increase in the number of his breast cancer patients who choose to have mastectomies rather than lumpectomies. The reason, he says, is quite simple.
Title: New Emphasis in Cancer Drug Tests: The Elderly

Content: NO, don't pat it on, press it on,'' the certified cosmetician said to the woman in the chair. ''That way it will hold better to your skin.''
Title: Beauty Treatments Aid Cancer Patients

Content: Circumcising men may significantly reduce the rate of cervical cancer in women by decreasing the spread of a sexually transmitted virus that causes nearly all cases of cervical cancer, researchers are reporting.
Title: Male Circumcision Is Found To Reduce Cervical Cancer

Content: NEW YORK — The way cancer doctors are paid may influence the choice of drugs they use in chemotherapy, a study published Tuesday concluded.
Title: Study links cancer doctors' pay and their treatment

Content: The bone loss caused by gum disease is associated with an increased risk for tongue cancer, and the more the bone loss, the greater the risk, researchers report.
Title: At the Dentist’s: Vicious Cycle of Gum Disease, Bone Loss and Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON — Dr. Norman E. (Ned) Sharpless, director of the National Cancer Institute, will serve as acting commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Alex M. Azar III, secretary of health and human services, announced on Tuesday.
Title: National Cancer Chief, Ned Sharpless, Named F.D.A.’s Acting Commissioner

Content: CHICAGO — Her latest mammogram was clean. But Deborah Lindner, 33, was tired of constantly looking for the lump.
Title: Cancer free at age 33, but weighing a mastectomy

Content: Every two weeks, Kevin Hall, a top-ranking small-boat sailor, injects a vial of testosterone into his upper thigh. Mr. Hall and his doctors say that because of his struggle with testicular cancer, he needs the injections to maintain normal levels of the male hormone in his body.
Title: After Cancer Struggle, Olympic Nightmare

Content: Gov. M. Jodi Rell of Connecticut underwent surgery for breast cancer today, her office announced.
Title: Connecticut Governor Undergoes Surgery for Breast Cancer

Content: For women with a high risk of breast cancer, an experimental procedure that retrieves cells from the milk ducts may help guide difficult decisions about preventive treatment.
Title: A New Test For Women At High Risk For Cancer

Content: Researchers report that eating red meat is associated with an increased risk for breast cancer, and eating white meat with a reduced risk.
Title: Eating Red Meat Tied to Increased Breast Cancer Risk

Content: The October breeze felt exhilarating on my scalp as a hairdresser shaved my head. With mixed feelings, I watched my wild, frizzy brown locks fall away and leave behind a clean, neat half-inch buzz.
Title: Hiding My Cancer Under the Hijab

Content: Ellen Stovall, a three-time cancer survivor and, as the president of the National Coalition for Cancer Survivorship, a prominent advocate for patients dealing with a host of problems during and after their cancer treatment, died on Tuesday in Rockville, Md. She was 69.
Title: Ellen Stovall, Three-Time Cancer Survivor and Advocate, Dies at 69

Content: From 1991 to 2015, the cancer death rate dropped about 1.5 percent a year, resulting in a total decrease of 26 percent — 2,378,600 fewer deaths than would have occurred had the rate remained at its peak.
Title: Cancer Deaths Continue a Steep Decline

Content: Dr. Jeanne Petrek, a cancer researcher known for her investigations into the aftermath of breast cancer surgery, especially its impact on fertility, was killed in an accident in Manhattan on Monday. She was 57 and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.
Title: Jeanne Petrek, Surgeon Known for Cancer Research, Dies at 57

Content: Cancer insists on its own time. If you try to defy it, it can break you, physically and spiritually.
Title: Time Is a Trickster When Cancer Runs the Clock

Content: A study of 46,355 women has confirmed earlier findings that long-term use of hormone replacement after menopause can increase the risk of breast cancer.
Title: Study Backs Hormone Link To Cancer For Women

Content: Jill Doimer's mother died in 2002 from ovarian cancer, detected too late to be effectively treated.
Title: New Cancer Test Stirs Hope and Concern

Content: Two important studies being published today challenge conventional thoughts about treating and avoiding breast cancer.
Title: Studies Challenge Traditional Breast Cancer Treatments

Content: As one treatment after another failed to beat back her lung cancer, Kate Robbins began writing her thoughts and feelings in journals to leave her children ''something tangible that they could read and refer back to'' after she died.
Title: Genetic Link Seen in Cancer Drug's Power

Content: THE CLAIM: Grilled meat causes cancer.
Title: The Claim: Grilled Meat Causes Cancer

Content: In the world of social media, we are our own self-portraitists. Our digital identity is doctored to show the best version of our lives. (Maybe a more apt name for Facebook would have been “Best Face” book.) It’s not a new observation to point out the disparities between our online identities and our real selves, but for me, as a cancer patient, that gap has never felt larger.
Title: Life, Interrupted: Posting Your Cancer on Facebook

Content: Doctors who screen women to determine their risk for breast cancer should question them more closely about the history of the disease on their father’s side of the family, researchers say.
Title: Screening: Breast Cancer History Is a Two-Sided Family Tree

Content: “I have plans, and cancer is interfering with my plans!” Karen Pasqualetto said by e-mail a few months ago.
Title: As Cancer Lingered, She Lived a Bold Life

Content: Two important studies being published today challenge conventional thoughts about treating and avoiding breast cancer.
Title: Studies Challenge Traditional Breast Cancer Treatments

Content: Doctors in Dallas said yesterday that the former Yankee star Mickey Mantle was suffering from liver cancer and had only several weeks to live unless he gets a liver transplant.
Title: Mantle Has Cancer and Needs a Transplant

Content: A new class of cancer drugs is showing promise in treating patients who have not responded to chemotherapy, researchers at a major cancer conference said this weekend.
Title: New Class of Cancer Drugs Shows Promise

Content: It has been nearly two years now since I learned I had prostate cancer, and 11 months since my last treatment. The surgical scar on my gut is fading, the radiation and hormones have leached from my body — and my soul — and my post-treatment depression is gradually lifting.
Title: Feeling Like Myself Again After Cancer

Content: Two important studies being published today challenge conventional thoughts about treating and avoiding breast cancer.
Title: New Breast Cancer Studies Yield Surprises

Content: Cancer was once thought to be a single disease that attacked different tissues. Then it was recognized to be a hundred different diseases as determined by the particular tissue involved and the kind of cells within that tissue that were growing out of control.
Title: Cancer Trailblazer Follows the Genetic Fingerprints

Content: New York Times columnist Jane Brody addresses the important topic of chemo brain, the sometimes prolonged mental fogginess and problems with memory and concentration that can follow cancer chemotherapy, in her Personal Health columns, ““The Fog That Follows Chemotherapy” and “Taking Steps to Cope With Chemo Brain.”
Title: When Cancer Treatment Affects Memory

Content: Researchers at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York have found that a protein seems to predict which prostate cancers are likely to be deadly and warrant aggressive treatment and which can be controlled with less treatment or perhaps none at all.
Title: A Protein Is Said to Predict Prostate Cancer's Virulence

Content: For women who are facing difficult decisions because they carry a gene that heightens their risk of breast cancer, doctors have developed a bracingly rational, cut-to-the chase method of helping them weigh the pros and cons of various strategies for reducing risk.
Title: Scientists Do the Math to Fight Breast Cancer

Content: The Nobel Prize in Medicine was awarded Monday to three European scientists who had discovered viruses behind two devastating illnesses, AIDS and cervical cancer.
Title: Discoverers of AIDS and Cancer Viruses Win Nobel

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Prostate Cancer Decisions Often Based on Fallacies

Content: Drugs that completely block estrogen can lower the risk of breast cancer recurrence in postmenopausal women after surgery, according to the latest study to suggest that some women can improve their chances of recovering from breast cancer with aromatase inhibitors.
Title: Treatment Is Seen to Cut Breast Cancer Recurrence

Content: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 - A surgeon who was appointed by President Bush this week to lead the National Cancer Institute said Wednesday that he had great hopes for finding new nontoxic cancer drugs but that given a shrinking of resources, some of the institute's programs would probably have to be phased out.
Title: Cancer Institute's New Chief Talks of Cutbacks

Content: Updated | 4:59 p.m. The broadcaster Don Imus said that he has prostate cancer, the Web site of New York's WCBS television station reported. Mr. Imus, 68, made the remarks during the Monday morning broadcast of his syndicated "Imus in the Morning" radio program, which in New York is broadcast on WABC-AM radio; he said that he had stage II prostate cancer, giving no further details of his prognosis, but added that he was confident his doctors would beat it.  According to FoxNews.com, Mr. Imus speculated on air that the cancer could be a result of stress. Discussing his diagnosis on the show, Mr. Imus said, "The day you find out is fine. But the next morning when you get up, your knees are shaking. I didn't think I could make it to work."   In a statement, a spokesman for Mr. Imus said: "Don appreciates the good wishes he's already received from his listeners and viewers. After years at the Imus Ranch surrounded by inspirational children battling cancer, Don is well-prepared to fight this. And no, this does not make him eligible for the kids' rodeo competition."   Mr. Imus was heavily criticized in 2007 for making disparaging remarks on air about the Rutgers women's basketball team; his shows on CBS Radio and MSNBC were canceled, but he resumed broadcasting on ABC later that year.
Title: Don Imus Says He Has Prostate Cancer

Content: A cancer pill licensed last week for its striking benefits against one kind of cancer also works exceedingly well against a different and incurable cancer, American and European scientists reported today at a cancer meeting here.
Title: New Drug Fights Second Kind of Cancer

Content: The American Cancer Society has issued new guidelines for cervical cancer screening that will allow some women to skip Pap tests entirely or have them less often.
Title: Less Cervix-Cancer Screening Urged for Some

Content: All forms of the hormone estrogen, including those used in birth control pills and in hormone replacement therapy for post-menopausal women, should be included on the government's list of cancer-causing substances, a panel of scientific advisers said yesterday.
Title: Scientists Say Estrogen Belongs on Cancer List

Content: Women who took the hormone estrogen after menopause for 10 years or more starting in the 1970's or early 1980's had a higher risk of dying from ovarian cancer than women who did not use it, a study has found.
Title: Study Links Estrogen Use to Cancer Risk

Content: The rock band Depeche Mode resumed its world tour on Monday night after coming off the road so that its lead singer, Dave Gahan, could recuperate from cancer surgery, BBC News reported. In May, the band canceled a scheduled performance in Athens, Greece, just before show time, when Mr. Gahan, 47, fell ill in his dressing room. Initially the singer was given a diagnosis of severe gastroenteritis, but later learned that he had a malignant tumor in his bladder. The band subsequently postponed or canceled 12 dates in Europe to accommodate Mr. Gahan's surgery and recovery. On Monday night, Depeche Mode played its first show since Mr. Gahan's operation in Leipzig, Germany, where the singer thanked his fans and "all of the doctors who looked after me so well," according to the BBC.
Title: After Singer's Cancer Surgery, Depeche Mode Returns to Tour

Content: Federal health officials announced last fall that smokers screened for cancer by low-dose spiral CT scans were 20 percent less likely to die of lung cancer than those who had chest X-rays. But the study’s final results, published online Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine, also describe the downsides of screening, including a high rate of false-positive scares.
Title: Prevention: Many False Alarms in Scans That Cut Cancer Deaths

Content: When they are asked to identify the greatest threat to their health, most American women name breast cancer. Most of them are wrong.
Title: In Breast Cancer Data, Hope, Fear and Confusion

Content: The band Depeche Mode has canceled additional concerts after announcing that its lead singer, Dave Gahan, had had surgery to remove a malignant tumor from his bladder, Agence France-Presse reported. Earlier this month, the group canceled a scheduled concert in Athens, Greece, hours before showtime as Mr. Gahan was taken to a hospital. The singer was initially given a diagnosis of severe gastroenteritis and the band postponed further appearances in Europe while he recovered. But in a statement Thursday, the band said that while Mr. Gahan was hospitalized, “further medical tests revealed a low-grade malignant tumor in Dave’s bladder, which has since been successfully removed.” Depeche Mode has rescheduled or canceled further performances in Britain, Germany and the Netherlands, and is presently slated to resume its tour in Leipzig on June 8.
Title: Depeche Mode Singer Has Cancer Surgery
Obituary:Richard Doll, 92, linked smoking and cancer

Content: Electric fans growl like airplanes taking off and banks of green lights wink in a basement at Mount Sinai’s medical school, where a new $3 million supercomputer makes quick work of huge amounts of genetic and other biological information.
Title: Cancer Centers Racing to Map Patients’ Genes

Content: Time-lapse video shows the White House turning pink as night falls on the U.S. capital to highlight Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Rough Cut (no reporter narration).
Title: White House glows pink for breast cancer awareness

Content: Gerald Patrick Murphy, a urologist whose research led to the P.S.A. test, widely used to help in the early detection of prostate cancer, died on Friday in Tel Aviv while attending a conference on cancer. He was 65 and lived in Seattle.
Title: Gerald Murphy, 65, Developer of Cancer Test

Content: THE FACTS
Title: Really?: Gum Disease Tied to Pancreatic Cancer Risk

Content: Dr. Ernst Ludwig Wynder, who was the founding president of the American Health Foundation and who posted early warnings of cancers for smokers, died on Wednesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 77 and lived on the East Side of Manhattan and in Westport, Conn.
Title: Ernst Wynder, 77, a Cancer Researcher, Dies

Content: There is only “moderate’’ evidence that the newly approved prostate cancer drug Provenge helps patients, according to an analysis done for Medicare that was made public on Wednesday.
Title: Prostate Cancer Drug Gets Lukewarm Review

Content: Many drugs work well at first against cancer, but the tumor cells quickly develop resistance. A concept for getting around the resistance problem has now been proved, at least in laboratory mice, and may well prove relevant to the treatment of human cancer.
Title: Tests on Mice Block a Defense by Cancer

Content: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new kind of anti-cancer drug yesterday after a swift, two-and-a-half-month review of clinical data.
Title: Swift Approval For a New Kind Of Cancer Drug

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Sorting Out Pills to Reduce Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Does a widening waistline put you at risk for cancer? Apparently so. According to a new study, nearly 6 percent of cancers are attributable at least in part to  obesity and diabetes.
Title: Two Hidden Cancer Causes: Diabetes and Obesity

Content: PUERTO VALLARTA, Mexico — Some weekends, more than a dozen American men wait at beachfront hotels, anxious for their turns in the treatment room at a small private hospital here.
Title: Despite doubts, cancer therapy draws patients

Content: PUERTO VALLARTA, Mexico — Some weekends, more than a dozen American men wait at beachfront hotels, anxious for their turns in the treatment room at a small private hospital here.
Title: Despite doubts, cancer therapy draws patients

Content: For the past year, Alexa Weitzman, 29, has worked as a research coordinator, licensed acupuncturist and chef at the Integrative Therapies Program for Children With Cancer at Columbia University Medical Center. She comes to the job with a master’s degree in Oriental medicine from Touro College and a lifelong love of cooking.
Title: Finding Ways to Help Children With Cancer

Content: Theodore J. Forstmann is tired.
Title: Philanthropy Given Focus by Brain Cancer

Content: Rosie Swale Pope is running 5, 425km across the U.S. at the age of 68 in memory of her husband who died from cancer. Rough cut (no reporter narration).
Title: Cancer death drives pan-US run

Content: A crucial medicine to treat childhood leukemia is in such short supply that hospitals across the country may exhaust their stores within the next two weeks, leaving hundreds and perhaps thousands of children at risk of dying from a largely curable disease, federal officials and cancer doctors say.
Title: Supply of a Cancer Drug May Run Out Within Weeks

Content: ORURO, Bolivia — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela announced Saturday in Caracas that he would have to undergo another operation for cancer, and he designated his vice president, Nicolás Maduro, as his successor if he should prove unable to continue to lead the country.
Title: Chávez Says His Cancer Has Returned and Names His Successor

Content: The British newspaper The Guardian on Monday removed from its website a controversial column by one of its writers that discussed a woman’s use of Twitter to chronicle her struggle with cancer. In removing it, The Guardian cited an investigation into the column.
Title: Guardian Deletes Column About a Cancer Patient

Content: CHICAGO, June 3 — A new drug looks poised to become the first effective treatment for liver cancer, one of the most common and deadliest cancers in the world and one whose incidence has been rising in the United States, doctors said here Sunday.
Title: New Liver Cancer Drug Is Promising, Doctors Say

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Prostate Cancer Decisions Often Based on Fallacies

Content: When her parents faced cancer together, Nancy Borowick chronicled their daily struggles and everyday moments. The book she is seeking to publish chronicles not just their illnesses and deaths, but also their lives as a family.
Title: Cancer Family: Documenting Life Before Death

Content: Women who have children living at home and single women have higher levels of depression in the months after treatment than other breast cancer patients, new research shows.
Title: More Depression for Mothers and Singles With Breast Cancer

Content: BREAST CANCER groups said last week they were disappointed and frustrated by a recently published study that found no apparent link between breast cancer rates on Long Island and women's past exposure to DDT, certain other pesticides and PCB's.
Title: Breast Cancer Groups Question New Study

Content: As a cancer patient, I think a lot about how we talk about illness — or more often, how we talk around it. Even the word “cancer” is ugly, scary, burdensome — a roadblock for a conversation before it even starts. Who wants to go there? Much of the time, I’d rather not bring it up if I don’t have to — and I’m the one with the disease!
Title: Life, Interrupted: Putting a Positive Spin on Cancer

Content: Researchers have identified a new risk factor for prostate cancer that may be present in as many as 25 percent of men. Those men, with high blood levels of a certain hormone, have four times the risk of prostate cancer as men with lower levels, though the high readings do not mean that men are certain to develop the disease.
Title: Hormone Seen As Risk Factor For Cancer Of the Prostate

Content: An analysis of six long-term studies conducted among a total of more than 300,000 women has confirmed that drinking alcohol can raise a woman's risk of developing breast cancer. But the increase in risk is very small for those who consume no more than one drink a day.
Title: Studies Confirm Relationship Of Alcohol to Breast Cancer

Content: More than a year has passed since Lynne F. Stewart, a defense lawyer who proudly calls herself a radical, was convicted of aiding terrorists in a high-profile federal trial in New York. But she still has not been sentenced.
Title: Breast Cancer Delays Sentencing of Lawyer Convicted in Terrorism Case

Content: Several large health insurers, including UnitedHealthcare and Aetna, are focusing on one of the country’s most costly diseases: cancer.
Title: Insurers Test New Cancer Pay Systems

Content: The Food and Drug Administration said Wednesday that it was investigating whether four drugs used to treat rheumatoid arthritis and other immune system diseases might increase the risk of cancer in children.
Title: F.D.A. Reviews Arthritis Drugs for Links to Cancer

Content: Evelyn H. Lauder, a refugee of Nazi-occupied Europe who married into an illustrious family in the beauty business and became an ardent advocate for breast cancer awareness, raising millions for research, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 75.
Title: Evelyn H. Lauder, Champion of Breast Cancer Research, Dies at 75

Content: James F. Holland, a founding father of chemotherapy who helped pioneer a lifesaving drug treatment for pediatric leukemia patients, died on Thursday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 92.
Title: James F. Holland, Trailblazing Cancer Researcher, Dies at 92

Content: When Renée Parcover found out there was a name for the disease that left her so weak she needed a wheelchair to get to doctors’ appointments, she was so relieved she started sobbing.
Title: An Elusive Diagnosis, and One That Comes With a Risk of Cancer

Content: Scientists are reporting that they have detected a variant gene associated with prostate cancer, a finding that may make possible a diagnostic test to help decide which patients are the best candidates for aggressive treatment. The discovery by Decode Genetics, a gene-finding company based in Iceland, may also help explain why African-Americans, in whom the variant is more common, have a greater incidence of the disease.
Title: Study Finds Gene Associated With Prostate Cancer

Content: Black patients with treatable lung cancer are less likely to be thoroughly examined and less likely to undergo surgery than white patients with the same severity of illness, even when they have similar access to specialized medical care, a new study has found.
Title: Black-White Differences Found in Cancer Care

Content: An advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously yesterday to recommend approval of the drug tamoxifen to reduce women's risk of developing breast cancer.
Title: Drugs to Fight Breast Cancer Near Approval

Content: Breast cancer survival is, over all, three years shorter for black women compared with white women, mostly because their cancer is often more advanced when they first seek medical care, new research shows.
Title: Black-White Divide Persists in Breast Cancer

Content: Regular aspirin use may significantly reduce the incidence of both cancer and heart disease, according to a large new study, but other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or Nsaids, have no effect.
Title: Patterns: Aspirin Linked to Lower Risk of Cancer and Heart Disease

Content: The anti-breast cancer drug tamoxifen significantly reduces the rates of recurrence and death from the disease among a surprisingly wide range of women but is being prescribed to far too few patients, researchers reported yesterday in the world's largest analysis of any cancer treatment.
Title: Drug Is Found to Fight Return of Breast Cancer

Content: AFTER five years of meetings, symposiums and throat-clearing, the Long Island Breast Cancer Study Project seems to be moving ahead as a deadline nears for proposals for the development of a program to investigate relationships between breast cancer and environmental contamination on Long Island.
Title: Proposals Awaited for L.I. Breast Cancer Study

Content: Dr. Arnold J. Levine, president of Rockefeller University, yesterday was named the first winner of the $500,000 Albany Medical Center Prize in Medicine and Biomedical Research for his discovery of a gene that normally protects against cancer but fails when a tiny change occurs in the gene. It is the richest American medical prize.
Title: Scientist Wins Prize for Work on Cancer Gene

Content: ImClone Systems and Bristol-Myers Squibb said yesterday that they would begin to provide their cancer drug, Erbitux, to a limited number of colorectal cancer patients who have exhausted other treatment options.
Title: Cancer Drug to Be Provided To Limited Number of Patients

Content: HEWLETT HOUSE faced a steady stream of obstacles as Nassau County transformed it into a breast cancer resource center. The old landmark, a 1720's farmhouse built by the area's original white settlers, was more dilapidated than it looked, and the renovations that began in 1998 wound up costing $1.5 million, triple the estimate.
Title: Breast Cancer Service Finds Few to Serve

Content: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded on Monday to James P. Allison of the United States and Tasuku Honjo of Japan for their work on unleashing the body’s immune system to attack cancer, a breakthrough that has led to an entirely new class of drugs and brought lasting remissions to many patients who had run out of options.
Title: 2018 Nobel Prize in Medicine Awarded to 2 Cancer Immunotherapy Researchers
