Content: Correction Appended
Title: U.S. Approves Use of Vaccine for Cervical Cancer

Content: The first drug for an advanced form of the most common type of skin cancer won approval from the Food and Drug Administration on Monday.
Title: F.D.A. Approves Drug for an Advanced Skin Cancer

Content: ImClone Systems Inc. and the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that United States regulators will review a second application for Erbitux, the cancer medicine at the center of an insider trading scandal involving Samuel D. Waksal, the founder of ImClone.
Title: F.D.A. to Review ImClone Cancer Drug

Content: A Bosnian Serb army general, Djordje Djukic, who was released by the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague last month for ill health, died here on Saturday.
Title: War Crimes Suspect Succumbs to Cancer

Content: Cancer experts are recommending a major change in the treatment of advanced cervical cancer, urging that chemotherapy be added to the standard treatment, radiation.
Title: Experts Urge Chemotherapy For Invasive Cervical Cancer

Content: A Spanish surgeon who examined Fidel Castro last week said today the 80-year-old Cuban leader does not have cancer and could return to work after he recovers from intestinal surgery he underwent last summer.
Title: Castro Does Not Have Cancer, Spanish Doctor Says

Content: Prostate cancer takes a unique toll on the private lives of men with the disease as well as their wives and partners. But sometimes, couples have a difficult time talking about it or even posing questions to the doctor.
Title: Ask Your Questions About Prostate Cancer

Content: Despite my best efforts, I remain bewildered about the surgical mishap I suffered in 2008. It was a debulking operation — the removal of all organs affected by a cancer that originated in my ovaries. The procedure was undertaken by the proper specialist, a gynecologic oncologist, but as I recounted in my memoir, the surgery did not go well for me.
Title: Living With Cancer: Not Talking About Medical Mistakes

Content: AbbVie is to buy Pharmacyclics Inc for about $21 billion.  As Hayley Platt reports it continues a growing M&A trend in the sector and will give the drugmaker access to what is expected to be one of the world's top-selling cancer drugs.
Title: Cancer drug key to $21bln pharma deal

Content: Purveyors of pop culture have a way of discovering a subject simultaneously. This is apparently the moment for the realization that young people can get cancer just like older ones. The top film at the box office over the weekend was “The Fault in Our Stars,” a weeper about two teenagers with cancer, and on Tuesday night ABC Family introduces “Chasing Life.”
Title: A Reporter Fits Cancer Into Her Busy Schedule

Content: King Solomon’s choice was easy compared with  the one faced by the North Carolina judge Nancy E. Gordon. The custody dispute before her recently was between Alaina Giordano and her ex-husband, Kane Snyder, and the fight was over whether their children — 11-year-old Sofia and 5-year-old Bud — should live with their mother, in Durham, or their father, in Chicago.
Title: Losing Custody Because She Has Cancer

Content: DE CAPRIO. In Fairfield County, at least, the name was associated with looking good way before Leonardo -- with a ''di'' spelling -- became a celluloid sensation. In fact, beauty has been Noel de Caprio's business for more than 40 years. And she needed no starpower, riding instead on the inspirations of fire, air, water, earth and heaven.
Title: Building a Spa, Despite Fire and Cancer

Content: Even the most conscientious health officials cannot keep the sun from rising; so in response to an unexplained increase in skin cancer among young people, some have fixed their sights on a more governable suspect: the $5 billion-a-year indoor tanning industry.
Title: Skin Cancer Is Up; Tanning Industry a Target

Content: Scientists at the University of North Carolina have made an important discovery about how defects in one of the two breast cancer genes, BRCA1, raise the risk of the disease: They leave cells without the normal ability to correct certain mistakes that commonly occur in their genetic machinery.
Title: Disclosure of How a Gene Causes Breast Cancer

Content: Even the most conscientious health officials cannot keep the sun from rising; so in response to an unexplained increase in skin cancer among young people, some have fixed their sights on a more governable suspect: the $5 billion-a-year indoor tanning industry.
Title: Skin Cancer Is Up; Tanning Industry a Target

Content: It had been 10 years since Don Decker donated blood, but on Wednesday he was preparing to roll up his sleeve. He was one of about 30 people who signed up to give blood at the Center for Cancer and Hematologic Disease in Cherry Hill. It's a place he is familiar with; his wife, Jeanne, who has had cancer for 13 years, sometimes has treatment there.
Title: Cancer Treatment Center Starts a Blood Drive

Content: People with swollen gums, missing teeth and other signs of poor dental health are more likely to be infected orally with the human papillomavirus, researchers reported on Wednesday.
Title: Study Ties Poor Oral Health to Cancer-Causing Virus

Content: Q. Does eating smoked fish, such as smoked salmon or whitefish, increase the risk of colorectal cancer or other cancers, the way processed and deli meats do?
Title: Do Lox and Other Smoked Fish Increase Cancer Risk?

Content: Doctors are excited about the prospect of Avastin, a drug already widely used for colon cancer, as a crucial new treatment for breast and lung cancer, too. But doctors are cringing at the price the maker, Genentech, plans to charge for it: about $100,000 a year.
Title: A Cancer Drug Shows Promise, at a Price That Many Can't Pay

Content: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to set aside the same hour of prime-time television on the first Friday night in September for a live, joint telethon benefiting cancer research, representatives for the networks said in interviews. Among those who encouraged the networks to put aside their competitive instincts, albeit temporarily, was Katie Couric, anchor of the “CBS Evening News,” who will appear on the fund-raiser alongside her principal rivals, Brian Williams of NBC and Charles Gibson of ABC. All three have had immediate family members die of the disease, and another principal, Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC and Ms. Couric’s former boss, is a colon cancer survivor.
Title: Anchors to Stage Live Cancer Benefit

Content: The Breast Examination Center of Harlem was designed as a cheery place, with toys to entertain patients' children and a billing policy as inviting as the atmosphere: mammograms, free of charge. But when the newly expanded center opened four years ago, its doctors were dismayed to discover that the women of Harlem were not banging down the doors to take advantage of their offer.
Title: Cultural Issues Pose Obstacles In Cancer Fight

Content: Novartis, the drug maker, said yesterday that federal regulators would speed their review of the company's request for approval of a new use of Femara, a drug used to treat breast cancer, to reduce the risk of a relapse after women complete therapy with tamoxifen. The Food and Drug Administration granted a priority review for the expanded Femara claim, requiring the agency to make a decision in six months of the April application date, Novartis said. The F.D.A. aims to complete its review of drug applications in 10 months. Approval would give women a way to extend prevention therapy after tamoxifen, which studies have shown loses effect after five years.
Title: F.D.A. TO SPEED REVIEW OF NOVARTIS CANCER DRUG

Content: Are lung cancer scans really ready for prime time?
Title: The Downside of a Cancer Study Extolling CT Scans

Content: The drug Xeloda is as effective as intravenous chemotherapy for colon cancer after surgery and has fewer side effects, a study financed by the drug's maker, Roche Holding, found. The company used the results to win regulatory approval of Xeloda this month. Xeloda is an alternative to generic intravenous drugs, allowing at-home care with less severe diarrhea, nausea and drops in white blood-cells. Xeloda or the Sanofi-Aventis drug Eloxatin should be considered for colon cancer patients, said the researchers, led by Chris Twelves of the University of Glasgow. The New England Journal of Medicine published the study.
Title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Cancer Therapy

Content: In an unusual collaboration, an order of Franciscan friars that runs the Church of St. Francis of Assisi on West 31st Street and two major real estate developers are joining forces to build a 58-story skyscraper that will loom large over its Midtown surroundings.
Title: A New Midtown Skyscraper to Include Housing for Cancer Patients

Content: WASHINGTON, June 8 — Federal drug officials on Thursday announced the approval of a vaccine against cervical cancer that could eventually save thousands of lives each year in the United States and hundreds of thousands in the rest of the world.
Title: U.S. Approves Use of Vaccine for Cervical Cancer

Content: An easily overlooked type of abnormality in the colon is the most likely type to turn cancerous, and is more common in this country than previously thought, researchers are reporting.
Title: Easily overlooked lesions tied to colon cancer

Content: The pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca said today that it would make a warning on the label of its lung cancer drug Iressa more prominent after several patients in Japan suffered pneumonia and some died.
Title: AstraZeneca Alters Cancer Drug Label

Content: KFAR SABA, Israel — Ever since she tested positive for a defective gene that causes breast cancer, Tamar Modiano has harbored a mother’s fear: that she had passed it on to her two daughters. Ms. Modiano had her breasts removed at 47 to prevent the disease and said that the day she found out her older daughter tested negative was one of the happiest of her life.
Title: In Israel, a Push to Screen for Cancer Gene Leaves Many Conflicted

Content: A single faulty gene appears to cause a significant share of breast cancer in young women, especially Jews, in whom it may trigger more than one-fourth of all such cases under the age of 40.
Title: Breast Cancer In Young Tied To Faulty Gene

Content: A 68-year-old woman is running from New York to San Francisco to honor her late husband and others who have lost their lives to cancer. Linda So reports.
Title: Woman embarks on cancer run across U.S.

Content: Most women who have breast cancer and are past menopause should take a type of hormone-blocking drug known as an aromatase inhibitor to prevent cancer recurrence, experts said yesterday.
Title: Another Way to Fight Breast Cancer Relapse

Content: In the 1950's, doctors were bitterly divided about an issue that seems eerily modern. What, they asked, is the point of finding breast cancer early?
Title: Early Detection of Cancer: Nothing Is Black and White

Content: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 22  John Edwards, the Democratic candidate for president, said today that his wife Elizabeth Edwards was once again suffering from breast cancer, this time in an incurable form.
Title: Edwards to Continue ’08 Bid Despite Wife’s Cancer

Content: Could cigarette smoking account for the mysteriously rising incidence of breast cancer among American women? Although previous studies had failed to find a clear-cut relationship, new, more exacting research in Switzerland has suggested that both active and passive exposure to tobacco smoke can triple a woman's risk of developing breast cancer. Still, other researchers remain skeptical.
Title: In Smoking, Study Sees Risk of Cancer Of the Breast

Content: LONDON — The Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis said on Monday that it had offered to buy Advanced Accelerator Applications of France for $3.9 billion in cash, as it seeks to bolster its portfolio of cancer treatments.
Title: Novartis Looks to Buy French Firm to Bolster Cancer Portfolio

Content: Handing a deck of cards to Sarah Ludwig, the psychologist said, ''I want you to put the cards in order by suit, but keep in a separate pile those cards with the letter T in their names.''
Title: Young Survivors of Cancer Battle Effects of Treatment

Content: Shares of Applied Digital Solutions and of its publicly traded subsidiary VeriChip, which makes an implanted microchip for identifying people, fell sharply yesterday as investors reacted to a report this weekend linking the tiny radio device to cancer.
Title: Report of Cancer Hurts Maker of Chip Implants

Content: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to broadcast a cancer research fund-raiser in September to be hosted by the evening news anchors at each network. The event, “Stand Up to Cancer,” is a sequel; the first such telethon took place in September 2008 and helped to raise more than $100 million, according to the organizers at the nonprofit Entertainment Industry Foundation. This year’s telethon, on the night of Sept. 10, will be hosted by Brian Williams of NBC, Diane Sawyer of ABC and Katie Couric, above, of CBS. “The broadcast is a way of saying, ‘Together, we can do this,’ ” Ms. Sawyer said in a statement. The three networks are donating an hour of prime time for the commercial-free, celebrity-heavy event, and they will be joined by HBO, E!, Discovery Health and the MLB Network, among others. The original event in 2008 wound up being shown in 170 countries, the foundation said.
Title: TV Networks Plan Cancer Fund-Raiser

Content: 65 percent
Title: More Americans Are Dying of Cirrhosis and Liver Cancer

Content: Updated | 4:59 p.m. The broadcaster Don Imus said that he has prostate cancer, the Web site of New York’s WCBS television station reported. Mr. Imus, 68, made the remarks during the Monday morning broadcast of his syndicated “Imus in the Morning” radio program, which in New York is broadcast on WABC-AM radio; he said that he had stage II prostate cancer, giving no further details of his prognosis, but added that he was confident his doctors would beat it.
Title: Don Imus Says He Has Prostate Cancer

Content: SIX years ago, Bob Stafford of Teegarden, Ind., was buying a car. He joked to the salesman that he should be able to pay for the sky-blue Chevrolet Corsica before he died of cancer.
Title: For Men With Breast Cancer, Loneliness Follows Surprise

Content: New York Times columnist Jane Brody addresses the important topic of chemo brain, the sometimes prolonged mental fogginess and problems with memory and concentration that can follow cancer chemotherapy, in her Personal Health columns, ""The Fog That Follows Chemotherapy" and "Taking Steps to Cope With Chemo Brain."
Title: When Cancer Treatment Affects Memory

Content: Advocacy groups have won overwhelming bipartisan support in Congress and passage of a bill to provide health care to thousands of women with breast cancer. Now they are pleading with President Clinton to sign the bill he supports in a public ceremony at the White House, to publicize the benefits that will become available to low-income women.
Title: Quiet Signing for Cancer Bill That Was Backed by Lazio

Content: Levon Helm, the drummer with the Band, has reached the final stages of his battle with cancer, according to a note posted on the musician’s Web site. Mr. Helm, 71, received a diagnosis of throat cancer in 1998 and nearly lost his voice, though he has continued to sing on albums and at concerts. The note, signed by his daughter and wife, asked fans to send “prayers and love to him as he makes his way through this part of his journey.”
Title: Levon Helm in Final Stages of Cancer Battle

Content: Mary Guettel had smoked cigarettes for 35 years before she quit six years ago. Like many smokers, she worried about the damage her habit might have done to her lungs.
Title: What an Extra Eye on Cancer Can Do for You

Content: Nearly two years into the planning of a head-to-head federal test of two expensive widely used cancer drugs, not a single patient has been enrolled in the study. But in a sense there is no hurry: Congress has barred the government from using the results in deciding how much to pay for the drugs.
Title: 2 Cancer Drugs, No Comparative Data

Content: When President Nixon signed the National Cancer Act many expected quick results, comparing the effort to the one that put man on the moon. After 42 years, what progress have we made?
Title: The War on Cancer: From Nixon Until Now

Content: Correction Appended
Title: Gene Called Link Between Life Span and Cancers

Content: LOS ANGELES — Sean Parker was a pioneer in music sharing when he co-founded Napster and in social media as the early president of Facebook. Now he wants to pioneer in a field that is already jumping with activity: cancer immunotherapy.
Title: Sean Parker, a Facebook and Napster Pioneer, to Start Cancer Immunotherapy Effort

Content: World Health Organization experts began meeting yesterday in Geneva to examine new studies showing that a cancer-causing substance, acrylamide, can be found in potato chips, french fries and certain other fried or baked starchy foods. Jorgen Schlundt, coordinator of the organization's food safety division, said: ''If what we know from water and animal experiments is true, it could be a very significant source of cancer in humans. It is not just another food scare.'' Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
Title: World Briefing | World: Chips, Fries And Cancer

Content: In a study that may put to rest a longstanding concern, Danish researchers who reviewed the fates of more than 1.5 million women found no overall increased risk of breast cancer among those who had had induced abortions.
Title: Big Study Finds No Link In Abortion and Cancer

Content: When Zora Brown got word that her pregnant, 29-year-old niece, Lea, had breast cancer, she decided it was high time for a serious family meeting.
Title: Breast Cancer in Blacks Spurs Hunt for Answers

Content: One year after a major study linked postmenopausal hormone therapy to an increased risk of breast cancer, new findings from the same study paint an even more ominous picture of the hormones' role in the disease.
Title: Study Reinforces Hormones' Link to Breast Cancer

Content: The Food and Drug Administration accused SuperGen Inc. of making misleading claims about a cancer therapy, Mitozytrex, and the company's shares fell. SuperGen said it learned of the F.D.A.'s concern yesterday and would issue a statement by Monday. The agency called SuperGen's promotion ''particularly egregious,'' saying that the company had failed to explain the risks of the medicine and suggested that it offered benefits like fewer reactions near the site of injection. SuperGen, which is based in Dublin, Calif., has not started to sell the medication because it is looking for a marketing partner. Shares in SuperGen closed at $2.55, down 54 cents, a drop of 17 percent.
Title: F.D.A. CALLS CLAIMS FOR CANCER DRUG MISLEADING

Content: RICHARD PETTY underwent surgery for prostate cancer Tuesday at a hospital in Greensboro, N.C.
Title: Petty Has Surgery for Prostate Cancer

Content: The Bayer Group and Onyx Pharmaceuticals said Food and Drug Administration regulators had agreed to work with them to hasten approval of an experimental drug to treat kidney cancer. The F.D.A. added the medication, known as BAY 43-9006, to its fast-track program, intended to speed development of treatments for fatal diseases, the companies said. The companies said the designation meant that they could file parts of the application as study results became available, instead of waiting to complete all of the research. BAY 43-9006, which could become Onyx's first approved product, is in the third and last stage of testing usually required for approval of a medicine, the companies said. Onyx is based in Richmond, Calif., and Bayer is based in Leverkusen, Germany.
Title: F.D.A. AGREES TO SPEED APPLICATION FOR A CANCER DRUG

Content: Don Hewitt, the founder and founding executive producer of "60 Minutes," said in a telephone interview Wednesday afternoon that he had a small, cancerous growth on his pancreas, and that he would be admitted to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on Friday to begin treatment of it.  Mr. Hewitt, 86, said that he and his doctors had yet to determine whether he would be treated with radiation or surgery, but that the cancer was not believed to have spread to any other organs. Asked if his prognosis was good, he said, "They tell me it is.'' He added, "I have faith in Sloan-Kettering.''  Mr. Hewitt joined CBS News in 1948, and grudgingly retired from "60 Minutes'' in 2004.
Title: Don Hewitt Says He Has Cancer
Flesh-eating paste promoted as cancer cure

Content: The Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center, which developed some of the standard techniques now used in personal computing, is moving into biotechnology.
Title: Center Uses Laser Method To See Cancer

Content: The band Depeche Mode has canceled additional concerts after announcing that its lead singer, Dave Gahan, had had surgery to remove a malignant tumor from his bladder, Agence France-Presse reported. Earlier this month, the group canceled a scheduled concert in Athens, Greece, hours before showtime as Mr. Gahan was taken to a hospital. The singer was initially given a diagnosis of severe gastroenteritis and the band postponed further appearances in Europe while he recovered. But in a statement Thursday, the band said that while Mr. Gahan was hospitalized, "further medical tests revealed a low-grade malignant tumor in Dave's bladder, which has since been successfully removed." Depeche Mode has rescheduled or canceled further performances in Britain, Germany and the Netherlands, and is presently slated to resume its tour in Leipzig on June 8.
Title: Depeche Mode Singer Has Cancer Surgery

Content: In a decision that is inflaming passions on both sides of the abortion debate, the world’s largest breast cancer organization, Susan G. Komen for the Cure, is cutting off its financing of breast cancer screening and education programs run by Planned Parenthood affiliates.
Title: Cancer Group Halts Financing to Planned Parenthood

Content: BEFORE she went to preschool on a recent morning, Molly Guarton, 2 1/2, stopped at the Schneider Children's Hospital in New Hyde Park for her daily dose of intravenous chemotherapy. A short while later, with a bounce in her step and a gleeful expression on her face, Molly pranced into her classroom at the Morgan Center in Plainview and began whipping up a make-believe meal in the play kitchen.
Title: Preschool Gives Cancer Children Normalcy

Content: DIANE SACKETT NANNERY of Manorville, N.Y., found activism when breast cancer found her seven years ago. Since then she has won approval of a postage stamp championing breast cancer awareness, co-written a book on an aspect of the disease, even been criticized for appearing in a campaign ad for Alfonse M. D'Amato in 1998.
Title: Metro Matters; Exploiting Breast Cancer For Politics

Content: Right at 9:30, punctual as usual, Jessica Kuebler padded down the hallway and into the ninth-floor lounge at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Anne Marie Cicciu was already waiting, her 5-foot-10 frame bent into a child-size chair, beneath a sign announcing, “Class in Session.”
Title: In a Children’s Cancer Ward, Lessons Beyond A B C’s

Content: Jim Kelly, the Hall of Fame quarterback who led the Buffalo Bills to four consecutive Super Bowl appearances in the 1990s, announced on Thursday that he had again received a diagnosis of cancer.
Title: Hall of Famer Jim Kelly Announces His Cancer Has Returned

Content: Molecular biologists have finally succeeded in a seemingly simple task: to turn a normal human cell into a cancerous one. In the end, it took just three genes, two that are associated with cancers and a third that allows cells to keep doubling without limits. Scientists hope to use these precisely engineered human cancer cells to find better ways to detect and treat cancer. GINA KOLATA
Title: July 25-31; Making Cancer Grow

Content: While many people suffer from heartburn and gastric reflux disease, only a small number develop more severe ailments that can lead to esophageal cancer. Scientists who have been trying to understand what may protect against these conditions have identified an unlikely agent: wine.
Title: Wine is seen as guarding against esophageal cancer

Content: Several studies have found that being married improves survival in cancer patients. Now a new study suggests that it may largely be the social and emotional support of marriage, rather than any economic advantages, that produces the effect.
Title: Social Support of Marriage May Improve Cancer Survival

Content: ABOUT one in every nine women will develop breast cancer, said Dr. Arthur G. Lerner, chief of surgery and medical director of the Cancer Program at White Plains Hospital Center.
Title: Detecting Breast Cancer More Accurately

Content: While many people suffer from heartburn and gastric reflux disease, only a small number develop more severe ailments that can lead to esophageal cancer. Scientists who have been trying to understand what may protect against these conditions have identified an unlikely agent: wine.
Title: Wine is seen as guarding against esophageal cancer

Content: A large study concluding that anti-inflammatory drugs reduce the risk of oral cancer was based on fabricated data, according to The Lancet, the prominent British medical journal that published the report last year.
Title: Cancer Study Was Made Up, Journal Says

Content: Don Hewitt, the founder and founding executive producer of “60 Minutes,” said in a telephone interview Wednesday afternoon that he had a small, cancerous growth on his pancreas, and that he would be admitted to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on Friday to begin treatment of it.
Title: Don Hewitt Says He Has Cancer

Content: Anyone who still needs motivation to move more may find it in a new study showing that, in addition to its other health benefits, exercise appears to substantially reduce the risk of developing 13 different varieties of cancer. That is far more types than scientists previously thought might be impacted by exercise. The comprehensive study also suggests that the potential cancer-fighting benefits of exercise seem to hold true even if someone is overweight.
Title: Exercise Tied to Lower Risk for 13 Types of Cancer

Content: Women 55 to 69 years old who ate red meat frequently appear to be more likely to develop a certain type of lymph cancer than those who ate less red meat, a study in Iowa has found.
Title: Study Links Cancer Risk To Red Meat

Content: Despite animal and human studies that suggested that aspirin might lower the risk of breast cancer, a new study indicates that it offers no protection.
Title: Study Rebuts Aspirin as Anti-Cancer Agent

Content: A rare cancer first linked to breast implants in 2011 has now been associated with nine deaths, the Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday.
Title: 9 Deaths Are Linked to Rare Cancer From Breast Implants

Content: AUSTIN, Tex. — Barry Bonds. Marion Jones. Alex Rodriguez. Roger Clemens. There is no shortage of athletes who have fallen from grace, their achievements on the playing field and their public stature compromised by accusations of cheating or revelations of criminal or otherwise repugnant behavior.
Title: A Champion Against Cancer, Now Under Siege

Content: Anyone who has recently lost a loved one to cancer may be inclined to think that little progress has been made in conquering this complex disease. That would be very wrong.
Title: Success Stories Abound in Efforts to Prevent and Control Cancer

Content: President Hugo Chávez said Friday that he would return to Cuba to begin a new phase of cancer treatment including chemotherapy. Mr. Chávez, 56, said he would go to Havana on Saturday “to begin what we’ve called the second phase.” He had surgery in Cuba last month to remove a cancerous tumor from his pelvic region. He acknowledged Wednesday that he required further treatment for cancer but has not said what kind of cancer he has. On Friday, he said he was sending a letter to the president of the National Assembly to secure authorization for his trip, as required by the Constitution.
Title: Venezuelan Leader to Return to Cuba for Next Phase of Cancer Treatment

Content: More than 10 years ago, scientists discovered that mutations in a gene called BRCA1 lead to a particularly deadly type of breast cancer. Now an international group of researchers has found at least one reason why. BRCA1 inactivates a tumor suppressor gene known as PTEN.
Title: In the Lab: Gene Study Helps Explain Link to Breast Cancer

Content: ABC, CBS and NBC have agreed to broadcast a cancer research fund-raiser in September to be hosted by the evening news anchors at each network. The event, “Stand Up To Cancer,” is a sequel; the first such telethon took place in September 2008 and helped to raise more than $100 million, according to the organizers at the nonprofit Entertainment Industry Foundation.
Title: Networks and Anchors to Join Again to Fight Cancer

Content: Dr. I. Bernard Weinstein, a researcher and top administrator at Columbia University who advanced the study of how pollutants and other environmental factors can cause cancer, died on Nov. 3 in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 78.
Title: I. Bernard Weinstein, Who Studied Causes of Cancer, Dies at 78

Content: The Starr Foundation, one of the country's largest philanthropies, pledged $100 million yesterday to cancer research involving collaboration among four institutions in New York and one in Massachusetts.
Title: A Donation of $100 Million To Promote Cancer Research

Content: Don Hewitt, who changed the course of broadcast history with the revolutionary newsmagazine "60 Minutes," died Wednesday at his home in Bridgehampton, N.Y. The cause was cancer.
Title: Don Hewitt, Creator of '60 Minutes,' Dies of Cancer

Content: I have a severe intestinal condition known as ulcerative colitis. For some time, I’ve taken an immunosuppressant to control the flare-ups. Like all drugs, this one comes with side effects. While I’m on it, I have an increased risk of developing myelosuppression, a condition in which my bone marrow might stop producing blood cells and platelets. I also have an increased risk of developing skin cancer.
Title: Birth Control and Breast Cancer: Putting the Risk in Perspective

Content: David Alvra Wood, who headed the Cancer Research Institute at the University of California at San Francisco from 1951 to 1972, died on Nov. 6 at the California Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 91 and lived in San Francisco.
Title: David A. Wood, 91; Led a Cancer Institute

Content: U.S. regulators on Friday approved a new drug for an aggressive type of breast cancer that’s spread in the body — including into the brain, where it’s especially tough to treat.
Title: FDA Approves Pill for Aggressive Breast Cancer That's Spread

Content: For the past 15 years, Scott Hamilton said, he has felt more at home on the ice than at home. He was the 1984 men's Olympic figure skating champion, an effervescent entertainer on tour and in professional competitions. His trademark was a back flip performed on skates. But late last winter, Hamilton found it difficult to even stand up straight.
Title: His Cancer in Remission, Hamilton Is Back on Ice

Content: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, the 65-year-old five-term Connecticut Democrat, said on Friday that the cancer was discovered six weeks ago and that he will have surgery during the Senate recess in August. (Video: MSNBC)
Title: Dodd Has Early Stage Prostate Cancer

Content: Yesterday morning at Giants Stadium, Giants Coach Jim Fassel gathered his players around him as he always does at the conclusion of practice, but on this occasion, Fassel did not discuss football.
Title: Giants' New Running Back Has Cancer

Content: Elida Fernández, 53, is spending her first Christmas away from the Dominican Republic, her homeland. Unfortunately, this holiday season is not a joyous one for her, nor for her daughter Judy Gabot, 30, who is working two jobs in an effort to keep her mother alive.
Title: Cancer Returns, and the Bills Pile Up

Content: Optimism and a fighting attitude may help breast cancer patients cope with their illnesses, but positive thinking is unlikely to increase their chances of survival, according to a study by British researchers.
Title: 'Fighting Spirit' Little Help in Cancer Fight

Content: More than a year ago, when President Bush chose the Houston urologist Dr. Andrew von Eschenbach, then 60, to direct the National Cancer Institute, with its $4.6 billion annual budget, politicians from all parties cheered the appointment.
Title: Director Tries to Untangle Web of Cancer Controversies

Content: Raquel and Tony Rivas had their life in order. They had married, built a house and were ready to start having children. But a visit to the gynecologist led to frightening news: Ms. Rivas had cervical cancer.
Title: Preserving Fertility While Treating Cervical Cancer

Content: Dr. Stanley J. Korsmeyer, a cancer researcher at Harvard who helped discover and investigate a gene that interferes with the natural regeneration of body tissue and creates conditions that often lead to cancer, died on March 31 in Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 54.
Title: S. J. Korsmeyer, Researcher of a Gene Linked to Cancer, Dies at 54

Content: At a time when cancer death rates are generally falling, different ethnic groups and the poor are more prone to certain cancers and less likely to survive, says an expert committee from the Institute of Medicine.
Title: January 17-23; Differences in Cancer Rates

Content: The rapper Adam Yauch, below, said that he was “feeling healthy, strong and hopeful” that he had beaten cancer after returning from a recent trip to India, but a coming album by his band, the Beastie Boys, remains without a release date. Mr. Yauch, better known by his stage name, MCA, made his announcement in an e-mail message sent to fans and also posted on the band’s Web site. He announced in July that he had received a diagnosis of cancer, and underwent surgery and began radiation treatment. In a statement Wednesday, publicists for the Beastie Boys said that Mr. Yauch “underwent surgery to remove a cancerous tumor in his left parotid (salivary) gland” that was found “in a location that will not affect Yauch’s vocal chords.” The statement said that a new release date for the Beastie Boys album “Hot Sauce Committee Part 1” had not been determined. The album had originally been planned for Sept. 15 but was postponed after Mr. Yauch disclosed the diagnosis.
Title: Beastie Boy Updates His Cancer Report

Content: Bunched on the kitchen counter, the bananas glowered. “Eat me, drink me, suck my juices,” they taunted, like the tempting fruit in Christina Rossetti’s kinky poem “Goblin Market.” I was flummoxed since I loathe the mushy texture of bananas. (Sorry, Chiquita!) But how else could I ingest more of the magnesium I need in order to not get thrown out of my cancer clinical trial?
Title: Raising a Glass to Chronic Disease

Content: After anxious weeks since learning that he had cancer, a man prepares for an operation that he hopes will give him a longer life. Then, days before, his surgeon tells him that plans have changed. His surgery will be put off because of concerns about the spread of the coronavirus.
Title: Will the Coronavirus Delay My Cancer Surgery?

Content: I miss the intimacy, and the innocence, of my visits with patients.
Title: Coronavirus and the Cancer Patient

Content: Last April, my wife called me in tears from a hospital in Fairfax, Va., to tell me our 2-year-old daughter, Nusayba, had hepatoblastoma, a rare cancer that primarily affects children during the first 3 years of life. It was most likely stage 4, she said.
Title: My Toddler Survived Cancer. Then Came the Coronavirus.

Content: Sequestered during the pandemic, I find myself thinking that cancer patients’ expertise in fear can help others heed its warnings. We all need tactics not only to overcome the destructive capacity of fear but also to tap its protective potential.
Title: What Cancer Has Taught Me About Fear

Content: A diet high in fiber may help reduce the risk for breast cancer, researchers report.
Title: High-Fiber Foods Linked to Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: As the coronavirus pandemic spreads, the normal touchstones of everyday life have vanished without so much as a warning. In their place are terrifying thoughts about the future, about loss and about mortality.
Title: How to Live in the Face of Fear: Lessons From a Cancer Survivor

Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday asked companies to stop selling all forms of the heartburn drug Zantac, after concluding that a potential cancer-causing contaminant can build up in the drug when stored for long periods.
Title: Zantac Products Should Not Be Sold or Used, F.D.A. Warns, Citing Cancer Danger

Content: This guide was originally published on July 26, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
Title: Know Your Uterus

Content: This story was originally published on Jan. 16, 2020 in NYT Parenting.
Title: Black Women Are Hit Hardest by Fibroid Tumors

Content: This story was originally published on June 20, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
Title: Uterine Fibroids Can Wreak Reproductive Havoc. What Are They?

Content: SEATTLE — One in four U.S. households have a smart speaker and 81 percent of adults own a smartphone. These devices might seem to be unlikely medical instruments, yet their computing capability, storage and sensor quality is often superior to the clinical-grade equipment used to monitor patients in an intensive care unit.
Title: Alexa, Do I Have Coronavirus?

Content: Omega-3 fatty acids have almost no effect, good or bad, on the risk for cardiovascular disease or cancer.
Title: Omega-3s Show No Overall Benefits for Heart Health or Cancer Prevention

Content: Sundown marks the beginning of my mother’s third yahrzeit, the anniversary of her death. I light a candle whose flame will burn for 24 hours, to honor her memory. But I need no candle to remember Ma, who burned bright all on her own. And I have the scars to prove it.
Title: Maybe the Survivor’s Daughter Could Survive

Content: “Have you read this?” the 61-year-old man asked his newest doctor, Madan Jagasia, as they sat in an exam room in the cancer center at Vanderbilt University Medical Center in Nashville. The book, titled “Dying Well,” prompted a concerned look from the oncologist. You know we’re not there yet, he said he told the patient.
Title: His Immune System Went Out of Whack. The Usual Treatment Didn’t Work. Why?

Content: When Janet Halloran last saw her primary care physician, the doctor asked whether she had undergone her annual mammogram. Yes, she replied, she had.
Title: Aging Out of the Mammogram

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Coronavirus, Exercise and Prostate Cancer

Content: I know bad news is coming my way when my oncologist walks into the exam room with a nurse. It doesn’t matter that he introduces her as a new nurse getting to know the system. In my more than six years of seeing my oncologist for metastatic colon cancer, he has never come in accompanied. He wants her in the room to learn how to give bad news.
Title: How to Give Bad News

Content: The new coronavirus is a serious threat to the elderly, as federal officials have been at pains to note recently. But they have stepped gingerly around advice for another group of Americans also at special risk from the infection: those with chronic health conditions.
Title: Coronavirus Threatens Americans With Underlying Conditions

Content: SEATTLE — On an overcast day in Seattle, a few dozen medical staff members, students and emergency workers with symptoms of the fast-spreading coronavirus spent their lunch break driving to a parking garage.
Title: Coronavirus Testing Goes Mobile in Seattle

Content: A shortage of nurses elevated the misery of a woman in my support group during a recent health crisis, she informed us. Because I participate in a clinical trial, in which I am vigilantly monitored in both Bloomington and Indianapolis hospitals, I was surprised. But I quickly began to realize that her ordeal could not possibly be unusual and then to fear that our current health care system is becoming more unfriendly, inhospitable to patients and to nurses as well.
Title: The Nursing Shortage Is Threatening Our Care

Content: Metformin, the world’s most widely prescribed diabetes drug, might do more than control diabetes. A study in Scotland in 2005 found that people taking metformin were 23 percent less likely to get cancer, suggesting that it might also prevent cancer. Other studies are exploring metformin’s ability to treat cancer, alone and in combination with other therapies.
Title: Repurposing Drugs to Fight Cancer

Content: Howard Wolinsky is a medical journalist in Flossmoor, Ill., who knows better than to go forward with potentially life-changing surgery without first seeking a second opinion.
Title: Before Prostate Surgery, Consider ‘Active Surveillance’

Content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher
Title: Modern Love Podcast: Lesley Manville Reads ‘The Kindness, and Xanax, of Strangers’

Content: We’ve long been schooled on the lifesaving value of early detection of a potentially deadly cancer. So when a simple blood test was introduced in 1994 that could detect the possible presence of prostate cancer, the second leading cause of cancer deaths among American men, it’s not hard to understand why it quickly became hugely popular.
Title: Debating the Value of PSA Prostate Screening

Content: My patient was brought to the emergency room by his friend because he could no longer catch his breath and had a cough that wouldn’t extinguish. He lived with three other young men, all in their early 20s, in a small house located in what many of us considered the no-man’s land between Cleveland and Buffalo, the four of them suspended between spending some time in a community college and finding work that they might one day call a career.
Title: When the Teenager or Young Adult Has Cancer

Content: The conservative radio talk show host Rush Limbaugh said on his live show on Monday that he had advanced lung cancer.
Title: Rush Limbaugh Reveals He Has Advanced Lung Cancer

Content: African-American men with prostate cancer are almost twice as likely to die from the illness as white men with the same disease. Disparities in medical care, rather than racial differences in the course of the cancer, may be a large part of the explanation, a new study suggests.
Title: Access to Care May Explain Disparities in Prostate Cancer Outcomes

Content: People who worked at ground zero after the World Trade Center attack in 2001 have higher rates of cancer than the general population, a new study has found.
Title: 9/11 Workers May Be at Higher Cancer Risk

Content: Men with early stage prostate cancer are often advised to increase their intake of vegetables to lower the risk for progression to more serious disease. But now a randomized trial has found that vegetables, whatever other health benefits they may confer, have no discernible effect on prostate cancer progression.
Title: Eating More Vegetables Did Not Affect Prostate Cancer Progression

Content: Do you know what to say or what to do when a friend, relative or acquaintance has cancer?
Title: What to Say to Someone With Cancer

Content: Just when I needed it most, I learned a valuable life lesson from Lynda Wolters, who has a cancer that is currently incurable, diagnosed just after her 49th birthday. As an Idaho farm girl used to hard work, Ms. Wolters led a healthy life, enjoying ballroom dancing, horseback riding, rafting and hiking when not at work at a law firm. Then, as she wrote in her recently published book, “Voices of Cancer”:
Title: When Life Throws You Curveballs, Embrace the ‘New Normal’

Content: When the American Cancer Society reported that the United States had experienced the sharpest one-year drop in cancer death rate ever recorded, it quickly caught the attention of President Trump.
Title: Trump Took Credit for Lower Cancer Death Rates. Advocates Say Not So Fast.

Content: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, whose health has become a preoccupation of the American public as the Supreme Court hews rightward under President Trump, announced this week that she was cancer-free.
Title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Says She No Longer Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Running, Body Temperature and a Deadly New Virus

Content: When in distress with cancer and its treatments, I think of Shakespeare “in disgrace with fortune and men’s eyes” and all alone lament my downcast state. I am not completely bereft, then, because his poem supports my complaint. Why are sonnets so bracing, I wonder as I launch into a neo-Shakespearean sort of pity party.
Title: When in Distress, Try Sonnets

Content: The cancer death rate in the United States fell 2.2 percent from 2016 to 2017 — the largest single-year decline in cancer mortality ever reported, the American Cancer Society reported on Wednesday. Since 1991 the rate has dropped 29 percent, which translates to approximately 2.9 million fewer cancer deaths than would have occurred if the mortality rate had remained constant.
Title: Cancer Death Rate in U.S. Sees Sharpest One-Year Drop

Content: Vaccines prevent diseases, and being unvaccinated carries a risk. Last year, the World Health Organization ranked vaccine hesitancy, a “reluctance or refusal to vaccinate despite the availability of vaccines,” among the top 10 health threats worldwide, alongside Ebola, H.I.V. and drug-resistant infections.
Title: You Are Unvaccinated and Got Sick. These Are Your Odds.

Content: Artificial intelligence can help doctors do a better job of finding breast cancer on mammograms, researchers from Google and medical centers in the United States and Britain are reporting in the journal Nature.
Title: A.I. Is Learning to Read Mammograms

Content: I found myself unexpectedly back in the hospital last month, some 10 years after my last treatment for an aggressive prostate cancer. Fortunately, it had nothing to do with my cancer; my P.S.A. level, a measure of prostate cancer progression, has been undetectable  since 2009.
Title: Back in the Hospital Again

Content: WASHINGTON — Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia and an icon of the civil rights movement, announced on Sunday that he had advanced pancreatic cancer, but planned to return to Washington to continue work and begin treatment.
Title: John Lewis, Congressman and Civil Rights Icon, Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: Brain surgeons are bringing artificial intelligence and new imaging techniques into the operating room, to diagnose tumors as accurately as pathologists, and much faster, according to a report in the journal Nature Medicine.
Title: A.I. Comes to the Operating Room

Content: NASHVILLE — Dear Mr. Lewis, I write with a heavy heart. Stage 4 pancreatic cancer is a brutal diagnosis, so it’s no surprise that last Sunday night the internet erupted with anguish as news of your illness became public. Treatment may give you a “fighting chance” to continue working “for the Beloved Community,” as you wrote in a statement, but it’s painful to think of what you will be called on to bear in the coming months. You have already borne so much for us.
Title: An Open Letter to John Lewis

Content: BOSTON — Zaosong Zheng was preparing to board Hainan Airlines Flight 482, nonstop from Boston to Beijing, when customs officers pulled him aside.
Title: Stolen Research: Chinese Scientist Is Accused of Smuggling Lab Samples

Content: Advice from Well on ways to minimize risks and increase your longevity.
Title: Five Tips for Living Longer in 2020

Content: Even moderate alcohol consumption may increase the risk for cancer.
Title: Even a Little Alcohol May Raise Cancer Risk

Content: Amid mounting excitement about the kids flying in for a visit, I look around the apartment with trepidation. Why am I so nervous about their imminent arrival? It has been months since our last get-together and they can replace ceiling light bulbs too risky for me or my older husband to reach.
Title: Sticking to My Own Premises

Content: For decades, scientists have debated whether hair dyes frequently used by women might contribute to cancer. The research has been mixed and inconclusive, but now government investigators have turned up a disturbing new possibility.
Title: Hair Dyes and Straighteners May Raise Breast Cancer Risk for Black Women

Content: I recently was told by my doctor to go see a doctor at the Cancer Institute to be tested for cervical cancer. When I told my mother she freaked out and told me my vegetarian diet was to blame, and that all the soy in my diet was the leading cause of all of this. Could diet lead to cervical cancer?
Title: Your Mom Is Wrong: Your Vegetarian Diet Did Not Cause Cancer

Content: KEY WEST, Fla. — It was a photo of a photo, and it was too good to resist: an image of a buzz-haired woman using her cellphone to capture a bruised banana stuck to the wall with a piece of duct tape at Art Basel in Miami Beach.
Title: A Woman, a Banana and a $120,000 Question About What a Life Is Worth

Content: The Senate voted 72 to 18 to confirm Dr. Stephen Hahn as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, as the agency faces pressure to reduce teenage vaping and weighs competing interests on a long-delayed proposal to ban flavored e-cigarettes.
Title: Senate Confirms Stephen Hahn to Head F.D.A.

Content: In 2019, measles cases in the U.S. have been on the rise, much of it driven by false claims about the safety of the vaccine.
Title: Terminally Ill at 25 and Fighting Fake News on Vaccines

Content: We’ll need more than facts to fight medical misinformation.
Title: Terminally Ill at 25 and Fighting Fake News on Vaccines

Content: Many women who have mammograms get normal results that come with a caveat: They are told they have dense breast tissue, which can make their scans harder to read and could leave cancer undetected.
Title: M.R.I.s Can Better Detect Cancer in Women With Dense Breasts, Study Finds

Content: In the literary world, it has been a year of big, bold ambition. Novelists have stretched their canvases — writing a sentence that runs for a thousand pages; charting the fate of three families in Africa across four generations. Nonfiction writers have made riveting narrative from sprawling, difficult material: The Irish Troubles, the nuclear disaster at Chernobyl, the history of the Lakota tribe. And memoirists have confronted harrowing and profound subjects: Life in New Orleans during and after Hurricane Katrina; decades spent in solitary confinement; psychological abuse in intimate relationships. Below, The New York Times’s three daily book critics — Dwight Garner, Parul Sehgal and Jennifer Szalai — share their thoughts about their favorites among the books they reviewed this year, each list alphabetical by author.
Title: Times Critics’ Top Books of 2019

Content: There’s no image in biology more iconic than our chromosomes — all 23 pairs of DNA bundles arrayed in a genetic lineup. But in a surprising number of cases, this picture leaves out something very important.
Title: Scientists Are Just Beginning to Understand Mysterious DNA Circles Common in Cancer Cells

Content: Efforts to reduce deaths from breast cancer in women have long focused on early detection and post-surgical treatment with drugs, radiation or both to help keep the disease at bay. And both of these approaches, used alone or together, have resulted in a dramatic reduction in breast cancer mortality in recent decades.
Title: Shifting the Focus of Breast Cancer to Prevention

Content: How could a researcher in computer science improve future cancer care, I wondered, when a trip to Boston afforded me the opportunity to converse with Regina Barzilay, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the recipient in 2017 of a prestigious MacArthur Fellowship, known as a “genius grant.” After a breast cancer diagnosis in 2014, Dr. Barzilay, who has a doctorate in computer science, began directing her work in artificial intelligence toward helping other patients.
Title: Using A.I. to Transform Breast Cancer Care

Content: Doctors have for the first time in the United States tested a powerful gene-editing technique in people with cancer.
Title: Crispr Takes Its First Steps in Editing Genes to Fight Cancer

Content: At the age of 41, Jenny Rose Ryan was shocked to learn she had breast cancer.
Title: ‘No Longer a Disease for Our Moms and Grandmas’: Women on Early Breast Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg was admitted to Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore on Friday night after experiencing chills and fever earlier in the day, a Supreme Court spokeswoman said on Saturday.
Title: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Hospitalized
How 2 Survivors Find Strength in Vulnerability

Content: President Trump said Friday that he intended to nominate Dr. Stephen M. Hahn, a top executive at The University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, to be the next commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.
Title: Trump to Nominate Stephen Hahn, Cancer Researcher, to Head F.D.A.

Content: Humans have spread a contagious form of cancer around the world.
Title: Humans Shipped an Awful Cargo Across the Seas: Cancer

Content: Eating yogurt and fiber may lower the risk for lung cancer.
Title: Fiber and Yogurt Tied to Lower Lung Cancer Risk

Content: When you find out you have breast cancer, you might be pulling ramen from water with a pasta fork. Your son might be watching “SpongeBob,” so you might hear that dull drone of Patrick Star the starfish in your mind as you fall.
Title: Surprise, You Have Early Breast Cancer

Content: Even a little exercise may help people avoid and survive many types of cancer, according to new exercise guidelines released today that focus on how exercise affects cancer outcomes.
Title: Exercise Advice for Surviving Cancer, and Maybe Avoiding It

Content: Having psoriasis is associated with an increased risk of cancer, a new review of studies concludes.
Title: Psoriasis Tied to Increased Cancer Risk
Dr. Bernard Fisher, Who Revolutionized Breast Cancer Treatment, Dies at 101

Content: A critical drug that serves as the backbone of treatment for most childhood cancers, including leukemias, lymphomas and brain tumors, has become increasingly scarce, and doctors are warning that they may soon be forced to consider rationing doses.
Title: Faced With a Drug Shortfall, Doctors Scramble to Treat Children With Cancer

Content: “If you see something, say something,” a catchy warning from the Department of Homeland Security about possible terrorist threats, applies as well to skin lesions that, if ignored, could become fatal.
Title: Staying on Guard Against Skin Cancer

Content: This week, the Huntsman family — one of the most philanthropic in the United States — made a $150 million gift to the University of Utah to establish the Huntsman Mental Health Institute.
Title: A New Generation Stakes Out a New Path for Charitable Giving

Content: By now, you’ve probably heard that your body is teeming with bacteria. Some 100 trillion of them live on your skin, in your mouth and in the coils of your intestines. Some protect against infections and help you digest food, while others can make you seriously ill.
Title: In the Pancreas, Common Fungi May Drive Cancer

Content: THE FIRST CELLAnd the Human Costs of Pursuing Cancer to the LastBy Azra Raza
Title: An Oncologist Asks When It’s Time to Say ‘Enough’

Content: Pancreatic cancer, which will be diagnosed in about 56,770 people in the United States this year, is the only cancer with a rising mortality rate through 2014, although five-year survival has begun to inch up, from 8 percent to 9 percent by 2016. It remains the nation’s third leading cause of cancer deaths, after cancers of the lung and colon, and it is on track to overtake colon cancer within a decade. Three-fourths of people who develop pancreatic cancer die within a year of diagnosis, and only about one in 10 live five years or longer.
Title: Why Can’t We Stop Pancreatic Cancer?

Content: Mathew Knowles, the father and former manager of Beyoncé and Solange, revealed this week that he received treatment for breast cancer this year, becoming one of the rare men to face the disease.
Title: Beyoncé’s Father, Mathew Knowles, on His Breast Cancer Diagnosis

Content: The French drug maker Sanofi said Friday that it was recalling the over-the-counter heartburn drug Zantac in the United States and Canada, a month after the Food and Drug Administration first alerted the public that versions of the drug contained low levels of a cancer-causing contaminant.
Title: Zantac Recall Widens as Sanofi Pulls Its Drug Over Carcinogen Fears

Content: RADICALThe Science, Culture and History of Breast Cancer in AmericaBy Kate Pickert
Title: Want to Learn More About Breast Cancer? Read This Book

Content: The scientist at M.D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston was hardly discreet. “Here is the bones and meet of what you want,” he wrote in a misspelled email to researchers in China.
Title: Vast Dragnet Targets Theft of Biomedical Secrets for China

Content: To the Editor:
Title: Grim Planning: Wills, Estates, Health Care Proxies …

Content: Getting a lot of vitamin A in your diet is tied to a lower risk for squamous cell carcinoma, a common form of skin cancer, a review of studies has found.
Title: Foods High in Vitamin A May Help Ward Off Skin Cancer

Content: Ongoing breakthroughs in cancer care involve personalized medicine, we are often informed. Because every malignancy is unique in terms of its genetics and genomics, one size (or protocol) cannot fit all.
Title: A Cancer Researcher Takes Cancer Personally

Content: Chronic drug shortages that threaten patient care are caused by rock-bottom prices for older generic medicines and a health care marketplace that doesn’t run on the rules of supply and demand, among other factors, according to a federal report published on Tuesday.
Title: U.S. Blames Drug Shortages on Low Prices and a ‘Broken Marketplace’

Content: Documentaries about innovative figures don’t always offer correspondingly innovative filmmaking. But even coloring within the lines of conventional biographical storytelling, “Jim Allison: Breakthrough” provides an accessible introduction to James P. Allison, who, along with Tasuku Honjo of Japan, won a Nobel Prize in 2018 for discoveries in cancer immunotherapy.
Title: ‘Jim Allison: Breakthrough’ Review: Taking On Cancer

Content: As the elderly man with an incurable cancer lay dying, he told his son he had only one regret. Rather than enjoying his last weeks of life with the people and places he loved, he had squandered them on drug treatments that consumed his days and made him miserable.
Title: Cancer Treatment at the End of Life

Content: Cancer is a terrible bedfellow. It tosses and turns, snorting and kicking and snatching more than its share of the covers. It never caresses or croons lullabies, but instead hisses innuendos into the wee hours, turning wakefulness into a wake. No wonder insomnia plagues cancer patients, often sending us to chemical aids. Ten years after diagnosis, could I finally dispense with them?
Title: Sleeping With Cancer

Content: Cancer is a disease of mutations. Tumor cells are riddled with genetic mutations not found in healthy cells. Scientists estimate that it takes five to 10 key mutations for a healthy cell to become cancerous.
Title: Researchers Explore a Cancer Paradox

Content: Periodontal disease in older women is associated with an increased risk for cancer, a new study concludes.
Title: Gum Disease Tied to Cancer Risk in Older Women

Content: More breast cancers have been found at earlier — and potentially more treatable — stages since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act.
Title: With Obamacare, More Breast Cancers Diagnosed at Earlier Stages

Content: A 17-year study has concluded that screening mammography — in which all women in certain age groups are routinely screened for breast cancer — does not reduce the incidence of advanced tumors, but does increase the diagnosis of lesions that would never have led to health problems.
Title: The Downside of Breast Cancer Screening

Content: During periods of hardship, laughter can lighten the load. Cracking up may be a better option than breaking down, or so the recent publications of three young adults with cancer suggest. Somewhat discomfiting, the jests of these authors serve as an antidote and alternative to the despairing negativity or fake positivity that plagues patients like me. Their punch lines zing with pleasure that offsets the pain of their edgy insights.
Title: Cancer Humor

Content: Twenty years ago, the fight against cancer seemed as if it were about to take a dramatic turn.
Title: Why Aren’t Cancer Drugs Better? The Targets Might Be Wrong

Content: PITTSBURGH — October is Breast Cancer Awareness Month, and I have breast cancer. The country is fully pinked out in support of breast cancer screening and research, and though I know all the pink is meant to make me feel good, to tell me that the entire country has my back, I actually find it profoundly alienating. Pink is not a serious color, though cancer is a very serious disease. Pink is about femininity; cancer is about staying alive.
Title: Breast Cancer Is Serious. Pink Is Not.

Content: In recent years, health officials have pushed aggressively to include more women in clinical trials of new drugs. Gone is the ban that once excluded women of childbearing age from participating in studies. Even scientists who work with animals are now encouraged to include mice and rats of both sexes.
Title: Who’s Missing From Breast Cancer Trials? Men, Says the F.D.A.

Content: Susan Gubar’s column, Living With Cancer, recently addressed the challenges of finding clothes to accommodate a body altered by cancer surgery and treatment.
Title: Cancer Patients Tell Us About Clothing for Changing Bodies

Content: Like many people, I attribute my cancer to bad luck. So the feature-length documentary “Company Town” shocked me. It contends that the economic consequences of racial discrimination increase cancer risk. Watching the movie led me to realize that wretched statistics on cancer mortalities are also linked to racial inequalities. Black cancer should matter, but has it mattered in the past and will it matter in the future?
Title: Black Cancer Matters

Content: One of the great disconnects of our history is how a nation birthed on the premise that all men are created equal could enshrine an entire race of people as three-fifths of a human being. We tried to fix that, through our bloodiest war and a series of amendments that followed.
Title: The Cancer in the Constitution

Content: Hannah Graffeo, 26, is a design researcher at IBM in New York.
Title: An Ethnographer of Cancer Care for IBM Watson

Content: When my cancer support group visited a research lab, the discussion of proteomics, fibroblasts and microRNAs made about as much sense to me as Lewis Carroll’s nonsense rhymes. Yet the meeting confirmed my suspicion that the gulf between patients and researchers needs to be bridged.
Title: The Jabberwocky in a Cancer Lab

Content: A new study suggests there may be a link between the consumption of sugar-sweetened drinks and fruit juices and the development of cancer.
Title: Sugary Drinks Linked to Cancer Onset

Content: After a Danish study last week reported finding more breast cancer cases among women who use hormone-based birth control methods, many women were left wondering: How significant is the risk, and what are the alternatives?
Title: Birth Control Pills Protect Against Cancer, Too

Content: Hormone therapy for prostate cancer is associated with an increased risk for dementia, a new study has found.
Title: Hormone Therapy for Prostate Cancer Tied to Dementia

Content: My mom was given a diagnosis of lung cancer this past year. And whether I liked it or not, almost midway through my career, it put me squarely in the position of being re-educated about cancer from the other end of the biopsy needle. It also gave me the opportunity to approach my patients with a new resolve in the coming year.
Title: Resolutions of a Cancer Doctor

Content: “Bleak” is the predominant adjective in writing about Michael Hersch’s music. “Dark,” “somber” and “anguished” are also omnipresent. Little wonder, given that his subjects have included the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Dante’s “Inferno,” the Holocaust and conditions found in a 1960s psychiatric ward.
Title: Cancer Haunts a Composer’s Life and Work

Content: Cristie Kerr led from start to finish at last year’s Lacoste Ladies Open de France, winning by four in a subdued setting as the European women’s tour and Kerr reflected on losing friends to cancer.
Title: Cristie Kerr Is on a Mission to Fight Cancer

Content: Last year, right before the winter holidays, the nurse practitioner palpating my breast paused and returned to a certain spot.
Title: Tackling Cancer Anxiety

Content: Like most of the boys in his San Salvador neighborhood, Gabriel Alessandro Mayorga Hernandez — Gabo, to his family and friends — loves soccer. But in 2014, just before he turned 12, he found himself exhausted by even a short game. Eventually he became too tired to play at all and started having headaches so severe they made him vomit. When he developed chest pains and difficulty breathing, his grandmother took him to the doctor, where X-rays and blood work indicated that he had acute lymphoblastic leukemia, or A.L.L., a blood cancer that develops most often in young children.
Title: A Promising Step in Tackling Childhood Cancer

Content: Many people would be surprised to hear that grilling carries potential cancer risks. But each year, the American Institute for Cancer Research publishes guidance for “cancer-safe grilling,” cautioning consumers to avoid two types of compounds that have been tied to cancer. These compounds, called polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and heterocyclic amines, get generated when food, especially meat, is cooked on a grill. They have not been proven to cause cancer in people, but lab studies have shown they alter DNA in a way that could lead to cancer.
Title: 10 Ways to Lower the Cancer Risk of Grilling

Content: Cancer can, and sometimes does, strike twice. It famously happened to Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court, who was successfully treated for colon cancer in 1999 and then for pancreatic cancer in 2011. If not for the regular checkups she underwent after colon cancer, it is quite likely that her pancreatic cancer, which is rarely found early, would not have been detected while still curable.
Title: When Cancer Strikes Twice

Content: PHILADELPHIA — Since Darren Daulton succumbed to brain cancer on Aug. 6, heartfelt tributes have honored the way he led a raucous Phillies team to the World Series in 1993.
Title: The Brain Cancer That Keeps Killing Baseball Players

Content: Many YouTube videos about prostate cancer are unreliable sources of information.
Title: Online Cancer Information Is Often Unreliable

Content: The detective work we do in my lab involves genes and cancer cells, not crimes. Or so I thought, until several years ago, when one of my graduate students at the University of Michigan emailed me to say that her research had been sabotaged.
Title: A Crime in the Cancer Lab

Content: At a construction site on 126th Street in East Harlem, what is being built could be a matter of life and death to those who visit.
Title: The High-Tech, Big-Footprint Cancer Center

Content: As an avid reader of obituaries, I’ve been struck by how many people these days are succumbing to pancreatic cancer, a cancer long considered rare.
Title: How to Minimize Pancreatic Cancer Risk

Content: Elephants ought to get a lot of cancer. They’re huge animals, weighing as much as eight tons. It takes a lot of cells to make up that much elephant.
Title: The ‘Zombie Gene’ That May Protect Elephants From Cancer

Content: Misleading symptoms, difficult treatments and low survival rates: three men and women speak about living with lung cancer.
Title: Patient Voices: Lung Cancer

Content: A prominent cancer organization is for the first time recommending Americans initiate colorectal cancer screening at age 45 instead of waiting until age 50, a threshold long endorsed by many other medical groups. The new guidelines, from the American Cancer Society, would extend routine colorectal cancer screening to an additional 22 million American adults between the ages of 45 and 49 and send a clear message that colorectal cancer, which has been rising in young adults, is no longer just a disease of older people.
Title: Cancer Group Calls for Colorectal Cancer Screening Starting at Age 45

Content: A diagnosis of cancer, even an early-stage, highly curable cancer, can prompt some people to feel as if they’ve suddenly lost control of their future and that they must do whatever they can to regain it.
Title: The Risk of Alternative Cancer Treatments

Content: Teenagers who were overweight at 17 were at significantly increased risk for developing colon cancer later in adulthood, and those who were obese were at increased risk for rectal cancer as well, according to a new report.
Title: Overweight at 17? Your Colon Cancer Risk Rises

Content: Low survival rates make pancreatic cancer a tough disease to face. Three people speak about survival, loss and living with a diagnosis.
Title: Patient Voices: Pancreatic Cancer

Content: I FREQUENTLY care for patients with advanced cancer. A majority have already tried some combination of surgery, chemotherapy and radiation. Many have landed back in the hospital because the cancer has returned or spread widely and left them in intractable pain or struggling to breathe.
Title: The Problem With Miracle Cancer Cures

Content: As an ovarian cancer patient whose life is being extended by a clinical trial, I was delighted to learn this summer that research on gynecological cancers is undergoing an unusually productive period. But I’m dismayed that at the same time there has been a steep decline in clinical trials available in the field.
Title: The Crisis in Gynecological Cancer Research

Content: Working as a flight attendant may increase the risk for cancer.
Title: Airline Crew Have Higher Cancer Rates

Content: My patient had first come to us two years earlier from another hospital, where he had been admitted with back pain so severe it prevented him from walking.
Title: Waiting to Treat the Cancer
The Promise of Precision Cancer Treatment

Content: People who carry the stomach bacteria known as Helicobacter pylori are at increased risk for ulcers and stomach cancer. But even when antibiotic treatment has eliminated the bacterium, stomach cancer may still arise. A new study suggests that one reason may be the long-term use of proton pump inhibitors, or P.P.I.s, acid-reducing medicines sold under brand names such as Prilosec and Prevacid.
Title: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Stomach Cancer Risk

Content: Aerobic fitness seems to alter the interior workings of cells in ways that may substantially lower the risk of breast cancer.
Title: Fitness May Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: An unimaginable diagnosis is followed by worry, fear and tough decisions. Five people speak about how childhood cancer changed their lives.
Title: Patient Voices: Childhood Cancer

Content: After the drama of diagnosis passes and the preliminary offers of assistance dissipate, a few hardy souls hang in with cancer patients for the long haul. If we are lucky, they tender surprisingly creative acts and gifts.
Title: Imaginative Caregiving for the Cancer Patient

Content: Depression is not cancer. It’s a completely different disease. Yet when I look back on my husband’s depression and death by suicide three years ago, it sure looks a lot like cancer to me.
Title: When Depression Is Like a Cancer

Content: Many studies have found that obesity is associated with an increased risk for prostate cancer. Now a new study suggests that the degree of risk may depend on where in the body the fat is.
Title: Excess Body Fat Tied to Fatal Prostate Cancers

Content: “No thanks, I already have cancer,” I said to the radiologist. Since the magnified images of calcifications in my right breast looked neither obviously benign nor obviously malignant, he had just recommended a biopsy. Even after I explained that I have been dealing with advanced ovarian cancer since 2008, he must have judged me daft. But I was thinking: Who needs another?
Title: Who Needs Another Cancer?

Content: Obesity is linked to prostate cancer, scientists know, but it’s not clear why. On Monday, researchers reported a surprising connection.
Title: High-Fat Diet May Fuel Spread of Prostate Cancer

Content: When I decided to undergo a lumpectomy earlier this month after a diagnosis of D.C.I.S., I learned a new word that makes me grateful for my privileges but also worried about the privations of others. The word is lagniappe, a bonus, like the 13th doughnut in the purchased dozen. As I went through yet another operation, my way was eased by the kindness of friends and relatives.
Title: The Haves and Have-Nots of Cancer Care

Content: A cutting-edge cancer treatment can also cure certain kinds of heart failure in mice, scientists reported on Wednesday.
Title: This Treatment Can Cure Cancer. Can It Mend the Heart?

Content: Q. Are cruciferous vegetables really helpful for fighting cancer?
Title: Do Cruciferous Vegetables Really Fight Cancer?

Content: Andrew gave his mother, Regina Hensley, a reason to live. We follow the pair as she fights a history of addiction and he fights an aggressive form of cancer.
Title: Caring for a Son With Cancer, and for Herself

Content: It was a big deal for Melanie Kennedy, a former accountant from Bangor, Northern Ireland, to indulge in a massage at the spa at Culloden Estate and Spa, in Belfast, earlier this year. Ms. Kennedy has stage four incurable breast cancer, and getting spa treatments have been a challenge ever since she was diagnosed almost six years ago at the age of 35. The lymph nodes she had removed in her arm meant that an overly aggressive massage could lead to painful swelling called lymphedema, and on top this risk, she was self-conscious about the scars from her mastectomy.
Title: At These Hotels and Spas, Cancer Is No Obstacle to Quality Care

Content: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos has recently drawn criticism for proposing a long list of cuts to higher education programs. Congress must mull those potentially traumatic trims while reauthorizing standard financing for students and colleges, but there’s one positive change that might sneak by in the process: the bipartisan Deferment for Active Cancer Treatment Act, which would let borrowers defer their student loan payments when they get a cancer diagnosis — and for six more months after their active treatment is completed. It’s a courtesy Congress extends now to borrowers who are unemployed, deployed in the military or volunteering with the Peace Corps.
Title: Give Cancer Patients a Break on Student Loans

Content: Sarah DeBord was 24 when she first noticed blood in her stool. She saw a gastroenterologist who did a procedure called a flexible sigmoidoscopy to examine her lower colon and rectum, then gave her a diagnosis of hemorrhoids.
Title: What Young People Need to Know About Colon Cancer

Content: Eating processed meat is associated with an increased risk for breast cancer, a review of studies found.
Title: Eating Processed Meats Tied to Breast Cancer Risk

Content: DUBLIN — The Irish government announced on Monday that it was opening an official inquiry and setting up phone help lines and emergency testing after it emerged that a publicly funded smear test program had mistakenly cleared at least 208 women who later received diagnoses of cervical cancer.
Title: Ireland Investigates Cervical Cancer Screening Scandal

Content: Since a cancer diagnosis in 2008, I have always taken reading material with me on all hospital trips. For one visit, which took nine hours, my reading material included a posthumously published memoir: Paul Kalanithi’s “When Breath Becomes Air.”
Title: A Cancer Memoir of Literature and Science

Content: The risk of developing obesity-related cancer is increasing in successive generations, along with increasing rates of obesity.
Title: Obesity Tied to Higher Cancer Rates in Younger People

Content: Scientists have used genetically reprogrammed bacteria to destroy tumors in mice. The innovative method one day may lead to cancer therapies that treat the disease more precisely, without the side effects of conventional drugs.
Title: New Weapons Against Cancer: Millions of Bacteria Programmed to Kill

Content: Obesity is linked to an increased risk for colorectal cancer in younger women, new research has found.
Title: Obesity Tied to Colon Cancer Risk in Younger Women

Content: Cancer immunotherapy drugs, which spur the body’s own immune system to attack tumors, hold great promise but still fail many patients. New research may help explain why some cancers elude the new class of therapies, and offer some clues to a solution.
Title: Cancer’s Trick for Dodging the Immune System

Content: After many rounds of chemo, radiation and surgery, Christine Bray was told she had one month to live. Then, doctors looked at her cancer’s DNA — and found its Achilles’ heel. FoundationOne®, FoundationOne®Heme, and FoundationOne CDx™ are diagnostic tests to identify genomic mutations associated with your cancer. This information, along with other information, may be used by your physician to identify potential treatment options. But these diagnostic tests do not confer any therapeutic benefit. The tests might not identify therapies that could be of benefit to you and you might not have positive outcomes with therapies identified through these tests. The outcomes described in this video are not typical and you should not expect to experience similar results. Consult your doctor about whether diagnostic testing is appropriate for you. Treatment decisions are the responsibility of your physician. These tests are available by prescription only. FoundationOne CDx™ is a next-generation sequencing based in vitro diagnostic device for detection of substitutions, insertion and deletion alterations, and copy number alterations in 324 genes and select gene rearrangements, as well as genomic signatures including microsatellite instability (MSI) and tumor mutational burden (TMB) using DNA isolated from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor tissue specimens. For the complete intended use statement, including companion diagnostic indications and warnings and limitations, please see the FoundationOne CDx Technical Information, www.foundationmedicine.com/f1cdx.
Title: The Promise of Precision Cancer Treatment

Content: Alex Trebek, the long-time “Jeopardy!” host, announced on Wednesday that he has pancreatic cancer. Mr. Trebek acknowledged that the disease has a low survival rate but said he plans to beat it.
Title: Trebek Reveals Cancer Diagnosis
