Content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved the second in a radically new class of treatments that genetically reboot a patient’s own immune cells to kill cancer.
Title: F.D.A. Approves Second Gene-Altering Treatment for Cancer

Content: After many rounds of chemo, radiation and surgery, Christine Bray was told she had one month to live. Then, doctors looked at her cancer’s DNA — and found its Achilles’ heel. FoundationOne®, FoundationOne®Heme, and FoundationOne CDx™ are diagnostic tests to identify genomic mutations associated with your cancer. This information, along with other information, may be used by your physician to identify potential treatment options. But these diagnostic tests do not confer any therapeutic benefit. The tests might not identify therapies that could be of benefit to you and you might not have positive outcomes with therapies identified through these tests. The outcomes described in this video are not typical and you should not expect to experience similar results. Consult your doctor about whether diagnostic testing is appropriate for you. Treatment decisions are the responsibility of your physician. These tests are available by prescription only. FoundationOne CDx™ is a next-generation sequencing based in vitro diagnostic device for detection of substitutions, insertion and deletion alterations, and copy number alterations in 324 genes and select gene rearrangements, as well as genomic signatures including microsatellite instability (MSI) and tumor mutational burden (TMB) using DNA isolated from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor tissue specimens. For the complete intended use statement, including companion diagnostic indications and warnings and limitations, please see the FoundationOne CDx Technical Information, www.foundationmedicine.com/f1cdx.
Title: The Promise of Precision Cancer Treatment
A Woman's Guide To Understanding Gynecologic Cancers

Content: Cancers of the colon and rectum have been declining in older adults in recent decades and have always been considered rare in young people. But scientists are reporting a sharp rise in colorectal cancers in adults as young as their 20s and 30s, an ominous trend.
Title: Colon and Rectal Cancers Rising in Young People

Content: Raylene Hollrah was 33, with a young daughter, when she learned she had breast cancer. She made a difficult decision, one she hoped would save her life: She had her breasts removed, underwent grueling chemotherapy and then had reconstructive surgery.
Title: A Shocking Diagnosis: Breast Implants ‘Gave Me Cancer’

Content: In every cup of coffee, there is a chemical linked to cancer.
Title: Should Coffee Come With Cancer Warnings? California Says No

Content: Colorectal cancer is typically considered a disease of aging — most new cases are diagnosed in people over age 50. But even as the rates decrease in older adults, scientists have documented a worrisome trend in the opposite direction among patients in their 20s and 30s.
Title: Colorectal Cancer Rises Among Younger Adults

Content: I often find my most interesting stories in unusual places. Last year I went to Duluth, Minn., from my home in Britain to film Chris Plys, an Olympic curler. On my last evening, Chris began telling a story about his young friend Mike Marz, an amateur storm chaser in Minneapolis. Another local man had just reached out to Mike to see a tornado after he’d found out he had lung cancer. The man, Mark Zabawa, was a divorced, 60-year-old former serviceman and a recovering alcoholic. When I came back to Britain, I was determined to follow up and tracked Mike down on Facebook to discuss making a film about his experience of chasing storms with his new friend as he fought cancer.
Title: Fighting Cancer by Chasing Tornadoes

Content: Dr. Nikhil Wagle thought he had a brilliant idea to advance research and patient care.
Title: New Cancer Treatments Lie Hidden Under Mountains of Paperwork

Content: As commissioner of the Mayor’s Office of Immigrant Affairs, Nisha Agarwal would often lobby legislators on behalf of vulnerable New Yorkers. On Monday she was lobbying again — but for herself.
Title: ‘It’s My Life’: Brain Cancer Motivates City Commissioner’s Activism

Content: About two-thirds of smokers will die early from cigarette-based illnesses. Cigarettes are also very addictive. Because of this, it seems reasonable to place warnings on their labels.
Title: California, Coffee and Cancer: One of These Doesn’t Belong

Content: About two-thirds of smokers will die early from cigarette-based illnesses. Cigarettes are also very addictive. Because of this, it seems reasonable to place warnings on their labels.
Title: California, Coffee and Cancer: One of These Doesn’t Belong

Content: Pancreatic cancer has a bad reputation. It is a terrible disease, but most people do not realize there are ways that early detection can help.
Title: Early Detection Is Possible for Pancreatic Cancer

Content: People who buy organic food are usually convinced it’s better for their health, and they’re willing to pay dearly for it. But until now, evidence of the benefits of eating organic has been lacking.
Title: Can Eating Organic Food Lower Your Cancer Risk?

Content: The headline had some of my friends in a panic.
Title: A Link Between Alcohol and Cancer? It’s Not Nearly as Scary as It Seems

Content: President Bush's decision to cut the budget for a cancer detection program makes no sense. In human terms, it is cruel. From a budget standpoint, it is self-defeating.
Title: NYT: Illogical Cutbacks on Cancer

Content: A rural resident in China is 30 percent more likely to die after a cancer diagnosis than an urban resident. Three rural families trying to beat these odds — “cancer refugees” — share their stories of battling the disease far from home and the financial ruin it causes.
Title: How China Creates Cancer Refugees

Content: Taking low-dose aspirin is a daily routine for many people because it may lower the risk for heart attacks and strokes, and some research has tied it to a lower risk of colorectal cancer. Now a new study in JAMA Oncology suggests it may lower the risk for ovarian cancer as well.
Title: Daily Baby Aspirin May Lower Ovarian Cancer Risk

Content: Not long before Mihir Shah was to be married in 2007, his soon-to-be mother-in-law got a diagnosis of breast cancer. She underwent chemotherapy and survived, wearing a wig to the wedding.
Title: A New Way to Detect Breast Cancer

Content: This past winter, my friend Jan embarked on two unrelated quests. While tracing her ancestry, she was attempting to find out whether she had cancer. A visual artist, not a word person, Jan enlisted me as her scribe in the hope that her story might be useful. I’m glad she did. Her efforts at detection suggest that although many of us remain quite limited in what we know about our bodies and ourselves, we can nevertheless steer our way toward even the most startling discoveries.
Title: Tracking Cancer and Ancestry, With Mysteries in Each

Content: Women considering surgery to receive breast implants should be warned of the risk of serious complications, including fatigue, joint pain and the possibility of a rare type of cancer, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday.
Title: Women Should Be Warned of Breast Implant Hazards, F.D.A. Says

Content: Many people associate palliative care with hospice care, but medical professionals are offering it to children and adolescents living with cancer as well as to those dying from it.
Title: For Kids With Cancer, Focusing on Quality of Life

Content: More than 7 percent of cancer cases in the United States are attributable to excess body weight, a new study reports.
Title: Excess Weight Contributes to More Than 7 Percent of Cancers

Content: The Environmental Protection Agency’s revised rule on arsenic contamination in drinking water has resulted in fewer lung, bladder and skin cancers.
Title: Arsenic Reductions in Drinking Water Tied to Fewer Cancer Deaths

Content: I first met my patient, a man in his late 80s, in 2012, when he had been living with myelodysplastic syndromes, a form of bone marrow cancer, for five years — longer than the average survival for those diagnosed with the condition. He was a former high school math teacher who was unerringly precise about his laboratory values. He also had a spark to him that no cancer could extinguish.
Title: A ‘Sentimental Journey’ in the Cancer Clinic

Content: Eating substantial amounts of fruits and vegetables may lower the risk for breast cancer, a new study has found, and some kinds may be more effective than others.
Title: Cauliflower, Kale and Carrots May Lower Breast Cancer Risk

Content: Two women in my cancer support group died last year; both were considerably younger than I am. Furious at the disease, I’m starting the new year with a yowl.
Title: A Cancer Rap, With Thanks to Nina Simone

Content: Two years ago, I spent a week in Houston helping my stepbrother while he underwent treatment for Stage 4 lymphoma at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. I sat with him while a nurse cleaned his chemo port and made records of her work, to keep his medical team updated. I accompanied him for the blood tests that determined his readiness for the next treatment. I stayed by his bed as his stem cells were harvested for a transplant, one of the cutting-edge, evidence-based therapies that ultimately saved his life.
Title: Treat Addiction Like Cancer

Content: A medical device that can add years to the lives of cancer patients is about to become unavailable, because its manufacturer has decided to stop producing it.
Title: A Lifesaving Pump for Cancer Patients Is Being Phased Out

Content: Fear of breast cancer is widespread, yet many women don’t realize that adopting protective living habits may help keep it at bay. The habits described below may also help to ward off other life-threatening ills, like heart disease and diabetes.
Title: You Can Take Steps to Lower Your Breast Cancer Risk

Content: The incidence of mouth and throat cancers caused by the human papillomavirus in men has now surpassed the incidence of HPV-related cervical cancers in women, researchers report.
Title: 7 Million American Men Carry Cancer-Causing HPV

Content: Because ovarian cancer initiated a stealthy assault before I discovered it, it seems the clear aggressor, and I the injured party. Yet as my physicians use their weapons to counterattack, collateral damages mount. Fatigue envelops me.
Title: When Your Personal War on Cancer Is Exhausting

Content: The American Society of Clinical Oncology, which represents many of the nation’s top cancer doctors, is calling attention to the ties between alcohol and cancer. In a statement published Tuesday in the Journal of Clinical Oncology, the group cites evidence that even light drinking can slightly raise a woman’s risk of breast cancer and increase a common type of esophageal cancer.
Title: Cancer Doctors Cite Risks of Drinking Alcohol

Content: On my way to a meeting on cancer and personalized medicine a few weeks ago, I found myself thinking, improbably, of the Saul Steinberg New Yorker cover illustration “View From Ninth Avenue.” Steinberg’s drawing (yes, you’ve seen it — in undergraduate dorm rooms, in subway ads) depicts a mental map of the world viewed through the eyes of a typical New Yorker. We’re somewhere on Ninth Avenue, looking out toward the water. Tenth Avenue looms large, thrumming with pedestrians and traffic. The Hudson is a band of gray-blue. But the rest of the world is gone — irrelevant, inconsequential, specks of sesame falling off a bagel. Kansas City, Chicago, Las Vegas and Los Angeles are blips on the horizon. There’s a strip of water denoting the Pacific Ocean, and faraway blobs of rising land: Japan, China, Russia. The whole thing is a wry joke on self-obsession and navel gazing: A New Yorker’s world begins and ends in New York.
Title: The Search for Cancer Treatment Beyond Mutant-Hunting

Content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Cervical cancer could be eliminated in Australia within the next two decades because of a government program to vaccinate children against the cancer-causing human papillomavirus, according to a new report.
Title: In Australia, Cervical Cancer Could Soon Be Eliminated

Content: This is a story about cancer, and baseball, and how they intersected over a week in the life of the Mets.
Title: A Shared History of Cancer, a Love of Baseball and a Cubs-Mets Game

Content: More cases of an unusual cancer linked to breast implants have been reported to the Food and Drug Administration, the agency said on Wednesday.
Title: More Cases Are Reported of Unusual Cancer Linked to Breast Implants

Content: When Kelley Oliver Douglass got breast cancer, a genetic counselor posed an odd question: Do you and your children have trouble finding hats that fit?
Title: A Rare Genetic Mutation Leads to Cancer. The Fix May Already Be in the Drugstore.

Content: Q. My father died of pancreatic cancer, and my understanding is that one of the reasons it is so deadly is that it is usually found when it is fairly advanced. Is there a routine screening for this cancer?
Title: Can You Screen for Early Pancreatic Cancer?

Content: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg is cancer free and on the mend after her recent surgery for the disease, a Supreme Court spokeswoman said on Friday.
Title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Is Cancer Free After Surgery, Supreme Court Says

Content: Alex Trebek, the longtime host of the classic trivia television show “Jeopardy!”, announced in a video on Wednesday that he has Stage IV pancreatic cancer.
Title: Alex Trebek, ‘Jeopardy!’ Host, Has Pancreatic Cancer

Content: WASHINGTON — Harry Reid, the former Senate Democratic leader from Nevada, underwent surgery on Monday to remove a cancerous tumor from his pancreas.
Title: Harry Reid Has Surgery for Pancreatic Cancer

Content: My grandfather was a statistician, and from a young age he taught me to always consider the odds. A pragmatic man, he couldn’t help teaching me when to hedge my bets, especially when it came to playing Uno. Unfortunately, he never could have prepared me for the odds I would face in the years to come.
Title: After a Cancer Diagnosis, Playing the Odds

Content: Two types of bacteria commonly found in the gut work together to fuel the growth of colon tumors, researchers reported on Thursday.
Title: Gut Microbes Combine to Cause Colon Cancer, Study Suggests

Content: When researchers reported earlier this year that colorectal cancer rates were rising in adults as young as their 20s and 30s, some scientists were skeptical. The spike in figures, they suggested, might not reflect a real increase in disease incidence but earlier detection, which can be a good thing.
Title: More Young People Are Dying of Colon Cancer

Content: Odds of survival can greatly improve for people with the most common type of lung cancer if they are given a new drug that activates the immune system along with chemotherapy, a major new study has shown.
Title: Lung Cancer Patients Live Longer With Immune Therapy

Content: “I thought I was completely healthy.”
Title: With Cancer in the Past, Ryuichi Sakamoto Returns to His Calling

Content: The Food and Drug Administration for the first time has authorized a genetic testing company to offer screenings for three breast cancer mutations common in Ashkenazi Jews, giving consumers the ability to initiate testing at home and see results without talking to a doctor or counselor.
Title: F.D.A. Approves First Home Testing for 3 Breast Cancer Mutations, With Caveats

Content: Millions of Americans will be wondering how Senator John McCain is coping with the news that he has an aggressive form of brain cancer known as glioblastoma. I certainly am: I found out that I had the same type of deadly tumor 18 months ago.
Title: John McCain’s Brain Cancer, and Mine

Content: This article was reported and written in collaboration with ProPublica, the nonprofit journalism organization.
Title: Top Cancer Doctor Resigns as Editor of Medical Journal

Content: LONDON — AstraZeneca announced on Thursday that a cancer drug in development had not shown as much progress as expected, a setback for the pharmaceutical company, which is grappling with weak sales and competition from manufacturers of generics.
Title: AstraZeneca’s Cancer Drug Trial Disappoints, Sending Shares Lower

Content: Is you is or is you ain’t my cancer? I was in a funk about what to do about a possible cancer diagnosis until Beethoven came to the rescue.
Title: While Facing a Cancer Choice, Beethoven to the Rescue

Content: The Times's Sheryl Gay Stolberg on the announcement that Tony Snow's cancer has spread to his liver.
Title: Back Story on the White House Spokesman's Cancer

Content: After receiving a diagnosis of prostate cancer, Scott Blackmun, the chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, announced he would not travel to South Korea for the opening ceremony of the Olympics next month.
Title: U.S.O.C. Chief Executive Has Cancer

Content: Annie Krause moved into a nursing home in Detroit in 2015, when she was 98 years old. She had grown frail. Arthritis, recurrent infections and hypertension had made it difficult for her to manage on her own.
Title: For Elderly Women With Breast Cancer, Surgery May Not Be the Best Option

Content: WASHINGTON — On March 29, Georgetown University Hospital opened a proton-therapy cancer unit that is expected to treat about 300 patients a year at premium prices using what its proponents promote as the most advanced radiology for attacking certain tumors.
Title: For Cancer Centers, Proton Therapy’s Promise Is Undercut by Lagging Demand

Content: On Oct. 15 at 8 a.m., Andy Lindsay stood atop 21,247-foot Mera Peak in Nepal, a wildly improbable place for him to be both athletically and medically.
Title: When the Lung Cancer Patient Climbs Mountains

Content: WASHINGTON — Dr. Norman E. (Ned) Sharpless, director of the National Cancer Institute, will serve as acting commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Alex M. Azar III, secretary of health and human services, announced on Tuesday.
Title: National Cancer Chief, Ned Sharpless, Named F.D.A.’s Acting Commissioner

Content: Researchers report that eating red meat is associated with an increased risk for breast cancer, and eating white meat with a reduced risk.
Title: Eating Red Meat Tied to Increased Breast Cancer Risk

Content: The October breeze felt exhilarating on my scalp as a hairdresser shaved my head. With mixed feelings, I watched my wild, frizzy brown locks fall away and leave behind a clean, neat half-inch buzz.
Title: Hiding My Cancer Under the Hijab

Content: From 1991 to 2015, the cancer death rate dropped about 1.5 percent a year, resulting in a total decrease of 26 percent — 2,378,600 fewer deaths than would have occurred had the rate remained at its peak.
Title: Cancer Deaths Continue a Steep Decline

Content: Does a widening waistline put you at risk for cancer? Apparently so. According to a new study, nearly 6 percent of cancers are attributable at least in part to  obesity and diabetes.
Title: Two Hidden Cancer Causes: Diabetes and Obesity

Content: James F. Holland, a founding father of chemotherapy who helped pioneer a lifesaving drug treatment for pediatric leukemia patients, died on Thursday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 92.
Title: James F. Holland, Trailblazing Cancer Researcher, Dies at 92

Content: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded on Monday to James P. Allison of the United States and Tasuku Honjo of Japan for their work on unleashing the body’s immune system to attack cancer, a breakthrough that has led to an entirely new class of drugs and brought lasting remissions to many patients who had run out of options.
Title: 2018 Nobel Prize in Medicine Awarded to 2 Cancer Immunotherapy Researchers

Content: Q. Does eating smoked fish, such as smoked salmon or whitefish, increase the risk of colorectal cancer or other cancers, the way processed and deli meats do?
Title: Do Lox and Other Smoked Fish Increase Cancer Risk?

Content: LONDON — The Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis said on Monday that it had offered to buy Advanced Accelerator Applications of France for $3.9 billion in cash, as it seeks to bolster its portfolio of cancer treatments.
Title: Novartis Looks to Buy French Firm to Bolster Cancer Portfolio

Content: 65 percent
Title: More Americans Are Dying of Cirrhosis and Liver Cancer

Content: Jim Kelly, the Hall of Fame quarterback who led the Buffalo Bills to four consecutive Super Bowl appearances in the 1990s, announced on Thursday that he had again received a diagnosis of cancer.
Title: Hall of Famer Jim Kelly Announces His Cancer Has Returned

Content: A rare cancer first linked to breast implants in 2011 has now been associated with nine deaths, the Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday.
Title: 9 Deaths Are Linked to Rare Cancer From Breast Implants

Content: I have a severe intestinal condition known as ulcerative colitis. For some time, I’ve taken an immunosuppressant to control the flare-ups. Like all drugs, this one comes with side effects. While I’m on it, I have an increased risk of developing myelosuppression, a condition in which my bone marrow might stop producing blood cells and platelets. I also have an increased risk of developing skin cancer.
Title: Birth Control and Breast Cancer: Putting the Risk in Perspective

Content: U.S. regulators on Friday approved a new drug for an aggressive type of breast cancer that’s spread in the body — including into the brain, where it’s especially tough to treat.
Title: FDA Approves Pill for Aggressive Breast Cancer That's Spread

Content: Elena Altemus is 89 and has dementia. She often forgets her children’s names, and sometimes can’t recall whether she lives in Maryland or Italy.
Title: Too Many Older Patients Get Cancer Screenings

Content: BEIJING — For millions of Chinese, the new year opened under an oppressive shroud of smog that has closed highways, delayed or canceled hundreds of flights and shut down schools, forcing some students to follow their lessons from home through online streaming.
Title: A Poem Praises Smog, and Why Not? It’s From Cancer’s Perspective

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Age, Exercise and Cancer

Content: Textured breast implants made by Allergan that have been linked to an unusual cancer are being recalled in the United States at the request of the Food and Drug Administration, and will also be recalled globally, the agency announced on Wednesday.
Title: Breast Implants Linked to Rare Cancer Are Recalled Worldwide

Content: Although I usually refrain from writing columns linked to national health observances, I believe that Colorectal Cancer Awareness Month, in March, is too important to ignore. There are simply too many people who are still getting and dying from this preventable disease because they failed to get screened for it, including people without excuses like ignorance, lack of health insurance or poor access to medical services.
Title: Colon Cancer Screening Can Save Your Life

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Alternative Therapies, Cancer and Cholesterol

Content: The man was 23 when the delusions came on. He became convinced that his thoughts were leaking out of his head and that other people could hear them. When he watched television, he thought the actors were signaling him, trying to communicate. He became irritable and anxious and couldn’t sleep.
Title: He Got Schizophrenia. He Got Cancer. And Then He Got Cured.

Content: Two new studies revealed bad news about minimally invasive surgery for cervical cancer, a widely used procedure performed through small slits in the abdomen instead of a big incision.
Title: Studies Warn Against Minimally Invasive Surgery for Cervical Cancer

Content: I’m driving my mother to her second week of radiation on a glorious spring day. Pale green leaf-lace froths on the trees, a verdant scribble working its way up the foothills of Mt. Greylock. Spring is an irrepressible fact in New England, not a cliché. And the weather is our favorite subject now that Mom has moderate Alzheimer’s.
Title: Dementia’s Gift: Facing Cancer Without the Fear

Content: With the arrival of two revolutionary treatment strategies, immunotherapy and personalized medicine, cancer researchers have found new hope — and a problem that is perhaps unprecedented in medical research.
Title: A Cancer Conundrum: Too Many Drug Trials, Too Few Patients

Content: Women with metastatic breast cancer are living longer.
Title: Women With Aggressive Breast Cancer Are Living Longer

Content: WASHINGTON — A top official of the American Cancer Society has resigned in part because of concern over some of the organization’s fund-raising partnerships.
Title: Cancer Society Executive Resigns Amid Upset Over Corporate Partnerships

Content: The Broadway star Marin Mazzie brings the same exuberance to living with late-stage ovarian cancer that she displays in her performances. Or perhaps the roles she has undertaken in musicals like “Ragtime,” “Kiss Me Kate” and “The King and I” have contributed to her proactive efforts to improve the fate of other women who will have to cope with the disease.
Title: How the Broadway Star Marin Mazzie Confronts Cancer

Content: Women with an aggressive type of breast cancer lived longer if they received immunotherapy plus chemotherapy, rather than chemo alone, a major study has found.
Title: Immune-Based Treatment Helps Fight Aggressive Breast Cancer, Study Finds

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Marriage, Nuts and a Cancer Breakthrough

Content: The death rate from cervical cancer in the United States is considerably higher than previously estimated and the disparity in death rates between black women and white women is significantly wider, according to a study published Monday in the journal Cancer.
Title: Wider Racial Gap Found in Cervical Cancer Deaths

Content: Vaccines against the human papillomavirus have sharply reduced infections, genital and anal warts, and precancerous lesions in young women and girls in more than a dozen wealthy countries, a major new study has found — powerful evidence that these vaccines will ultimately cause major drops in cervical cancer.
Title: HPV Vaccines Are Reducing Infections, Warts — and Probably Cancer

Content: A Chinese hospital treating the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Liu Xiaobo has invited cancer experts from the United States, Germany and other nations to join his team of doctors, judicial officials said in a brief statement Wednesday.
Title: Chinese Hospital Invites Cancer Experts to Help Treat Nobel Laureate

Content: NEWARK — Devils center Brian Boyle said he had plenty of things on his mind besides his battle with chronic myeloid leukemia when he stepped onto the ice Nov. 1 for his first shift of the season. More than anything, he wanted to help his new team win.
Title: After a Cancer Diagnosis, the Devils’ Brian Boyle Is Thriving

Content: Nice but noisy
Title: Waging the Cancer War, Surrounded by Signs of Life

Content: It can be hard for physicians to follow current thinking of experts on medical care. It must be exponentially harder for the public to make sense of it. Recently, the United States Preventive Services Task Force changed its recommendation on prostate cancer screening from a D (that is, don’t do it) to a C (discuss it with your doctor).
Title: The ABCs and Ds of Whether to Get Prostate Cancer Screening

Content: WASHINGTON — In a major test case, Medicare is poised to cover a promising but expensive new type of cancer treatment, with significant restrictions meant to hold down the cost.
Title: Medicare Aims to Expand Coverage of Cancer Care. But Is It Enough?

Content: Julia Louis-Dreyfus has breast cancer, she announced on Thursday, less than two weeks after her record-setting Emmy win for “Veep.”
Title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Shares Breast Cancer Diagnosis

Content: The pink ribbon, that ubiquitous emblem of breast cancer awareness, has long been an object of controversy and derision, but the poet and essayist Anne Boyer doesn’t just pull it loose, unfastening its dainty loop; she feeds it through a shredder and lights it on fire, incinerating its remains.
Title: ‘The Undying,’ an Extraordinary and Furious New Memoir About Cancer

Content: Compared with women who have never given birth, those who recently had babies may have a slight increased risk of breast cancer that peaks after about five years and then gradually declines, according to a study published this week.
Title: Breast Cancer Risk May Rise After Childbirth, but Is Still Low

Content: Many women with early-stage breast cancer who would receive chemotherapy under current standards do not actually need it, according to a major international study that is expected to quickly change medical treatment.
Title: Good News for Women With Breast Cancer: Many Don’t Need Chemo

Content: THE BREAKTHROUGH Immunotherapy and the Race to Cure Cancer By Charles Graeber Illustrated. 302 pp. Twelve. $28.
Title: Could Immunotherapy Offer a Cure for Cancer?

Content: ISTANBUL/ANKARA — Demet Isil Yilmaz was halfway through a debilitating chemotherapy course when the coronavirus pandemic erupted, intensifying her struggle for health which she has chronicled for her thousands of Instagram followers.
Title: 'This Will Pass': Turkish Cancer Blogger Hopeful Despite Coronavirus
A Revolutionary Cancer Therapy Made From Patients’ Cells

Content: Computers were as good or better than doctors at detecting tiny lung cancers on CT scans, in a study by researchers from Google and several medical centers.
Title: A.I. Took a Test to Detect Lung Cancer. It Got an A.

Content: They are among the most challenging prostate cancer patients to treat: about 150,000 men worldwide each year whose cancer is aggressive enough to defy standard hormonal therapy, but has not yet spread to the point where it can be seen on scans.
Title: Two Prostate Cancer Drugs Delay Spread of the Disease by Two Years

Content: Lindsey Wilkerson was given a tour when she first began working in the event and patient-liaison department at St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital in Memphis more than 14 years ago.
Title: Love Not Lost: Two Childhood Cancer Survivors Marry at St. Jude

Content: Noreen Fraser, a television producer who used her broadcasting skills to raise money and public awareness in a national campaign against breast cancer, died on Monday at her home in Brentwood, Calif., more than 15 years after she learned she had the disease. She was 63.
Title: Noreen Fraser, Who Led a Public Fight Against Cancer, Dies at 63

Content: When Nancy M. Cappello learned that she had breast cancer, and that mammography could not find it, she turned her misfortune into a tireless campaign that led 36 states to require fuller disclosure to women about their mammogram results and the limitations of the test.
Title: Nancy Cappello, Breast Cancer Activist, Is Dead at 66

Content: TOKYO — More than seven years after a devastating earthquake and tsunami caused meltdowns at a nuclear power plant in Fukushima, Japan acknowledged for the first time this week that a worker died from cancer after being exposed to radiation.
Title: In a First, Japan Says Fukushima Radiation Caused Worker’s Cancer Death

Content: Dr. Alan S. Rabson, who helped define the field of cancer pathology, who figured out why shingles and recurrent cold sores occur, and who helped lead the National Cancer Institute into new eras over several decades, died on July 4 in Skillman, N.J. He was 92.
Title: Dr. Alan S. Rabson, Influential Cancer Researcher, Is Dead at 92

Content: FLORENCE, Italy — The black-and-white checkered floor of the taxi looks a bit like home flooring. The seats are yellow, purple and orange leather, while the pea-green interiors are plastered with daisy stickers. When riding in the cab, passengers can play with plastic swords and a megaphone, or make soap bubbles.
Title: ‘Taxi Therapy’ for Young Cancer Patients in Italy

Content: Dr. Peter C. Nowell, who with a colleague discovered the first genetic defect proven to cause cancer, died on Dec. 26 in Newtown Square, Pa. He was 88.
Title: Dr. Peter Nowell, Who Helped Transform Cancer Research, Dies at 88

Content: YONKERS — Miguel Ramos’s mother, Mirna, set off for the United States when he was almost 4. She was both running away from a violent domestic situation and running toward the same opportunities that have drawn generations of immigrants toward America’s borders.
Title: Mother and Son Reunite Only to Face Her Cancer Diagnosis

Content: In 2010, Dr. Pamela Munster mailed her saliva to 23andMe, a relatively new DNA testing company, and later opted in for a BRCA test. As an oncologist, she knew a mutation of this gene would put her at high risk for breast and ovarian cancer. She was relieved by the negative result.
Title: Don’t Count on 23andMe to Detect Most Breast Cancer Risks, Study Warns

Content: Last year, one of my best friends learned he had cancer.
Title: My Friend’s Cancer Taught Me About a Hole in Our Health System

Content: Women who rely on birth control pills or contraceptive devices that release hormones face a small but significant increase in the risk for breast cancer, according to a large study published on Wednesday.
Title: Birth Control Pills Still Linked to Breast Cancer, Study Finds

Content: One in three breast cancer patients under 45 removed the healthy breast along with the breast affected by cancer in 2012, a sharp increase from the one in 10 younger women with breast cancer who had double mastectomies eight years earlier, a new study reports.
Title: More Women With Breast Cancer Opt to Remove Healthy Breast

Content: Gabriele Grunewald, the elite runner who gained the support of thousands of followers on social media for her perseverance in competing while facing a rare metastatic cancer, died on Tuesday in Minneapolis. She was 32.
Title: Gabriele Grunewald, Runner Who Chronicled Journey With Cancer, Dies at 32

Content: Japanese companies’ overseas shopping sprees tend to be overpriced. Takeda Pharmaceutical is the latest acquirer to pay over the odds. Takeda, a $34 billion drug maker, is spending $5.2 billion, a 75 percent premium, for Ariad Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company with a middling cancer drug.
Title: Takeda’s Bid for Cancer Drug Maker Looks Expensive

Content: WASHINGTON — Senator John McCain, the 2008 Republican presidential nominee known for his independent streak over more than three decades representing Arizona in the Senate, has brain cancer, his office disclosed Wednesday night in a statement from the Mayo Clinic.
Title: John McCain Has Brain Cancer, Senator’s Office Says

Content: A drug that fights inflammation can reduce the risk of heart attacks and strokes, and possibly lung cancer, in people who have already had one heart attack and are at high risk for another, a new study finds.
Title: Drug Aimed at Inflammation May Lower Risk of Heart Disease and Cancer

Content: You don’t think twice about getting multiple bids for a construction or plumbing project, so why hesitate on multiple “bids” for your health?
Title: Love Your Cancer Doctor? Get a Second Opinion

Content: A New Jersey jury ruled unanimously for Johnson & Johnson on Wednesday in the latest lawsuit to reach a verdict over accusations that the company’s talc-based powder products contained asbestos and caused a consumer’s cancer.
Title: Johnson & Johnson Cleared by New Jersey Jury in Latest Talc Cancer Trial

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Fats, Bones and Surviving Cancer

Content: Dr. Kenneth A. Forde, a pioneering surgeon who helped educate the public about cancer risks by performing a colonoscopy on Katie Couric that was later televised, died on June 2 at his home in Scarborough, N.Y. He was 85.
Title: Dr. Kenneth Forde, Surgeon Who Fostered Cancer Screening, Dies at 85

Content: This article was reported and written in a collaboration with ProPublica, the nonprofit journalism organization.
Title: Cancer Center’s Board Chairman Faults Top Doctor Over ‘Crossed Lines’

Content: The news about Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s operation for two cancerous lung nodules is encouraging but incomplete.
Title: Cancer Doctors See Encouraging Signs for Ruth Bader Ginsburg

Content: A drug that can slow the progression of advanced breast cancer has been shown for the first time to lengthen survival in women whose disease started before or during menopause, researchers reported on Saturday.
Title: A Drug Prolonged Life in Younger Women With Advanced Breast Cancer

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Cellphones, Cancer and Broken-Heart Syndrome

Content: A half-century ago, when researchers said cancers were caused by exposure to toxins in the environment, Dr. Henry T. Lynch begged to differ.
Title: Dr. Henry Lynch, 91, Dies; Found Hereditary Link in Cancer

Content: Dr. John Mendelsohn, who led the prestigious University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center through an era of substantial growth, and who, as a scientist, helped pioneer a new type of cancer therapy, died on Jan. 7 at his home in Houston. He was 82.
Title: Dr. John Mendelsohn, 82, Researcher Who Led Top Cancer Center, Dies

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Cancer, Alzheimer's and Vitamins Gone Gummy

Content: Over the past 20 years, hundreds of thousands of women with breast cancer have taken the drug Herceptin, typically for a year or more. The medicine, used to treat an aggressive form of the disease, is credited with saving many lives, but it also has some tough side effects, particularly damage to the heart.
Title: Good News on Early Breast Cancer: Herceptin Treatment Can Be Shortened

Content: A new study offers a glint of hope to people in a desperate situation: Patients with melanoma, the most serious form of skin cancer, that has spread to the brain.
Title: Immunotherapy Drugs Slow Skin Cancer That Has Spread to the Brain

Content: At diagnosis, quite a few cancer patients spy Eros rushing out the door. I know I did. For some, eroticism vanishes during or after treatment. Anhedonia, the inability to feel pleasure, can afflict both men and women with cancer. We often get more help from one another than from the medical specialists who are beginning to address this challenge.
Title: Sex After Cancer

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Organic Food, Risky Weather and Cancer

Content: Researchers have made new discoveries about the in-between spaces in the human body, and some say it’s time to rewrite the anatomy books.
Title: Is This Tissue a New Organ? Maybe. A Conduit for Cancer? It Seems Likely.

Content: Harvard Medical School sends out an email when an esteemed faculty member passes away, and more often than not I delete it without clicking. I feel shame for not taking the time to read about the death of colleague whose life was devoted to medicine or science, but I do think about death a lot for someone my age — perhaps too much.
Title: Chasing My Shadow as a Cancer Patient in Talk Therapy

Content: Coffee sellers are mulling how to fight a California judge’s ruling that would require the beverage to be branded with cancer warning labels.
Title: Coffee Drinkers Need Cancer Warning, Judge Rules, Giving Sellers the Jitters

Content: Getting a positive mammogram result, then learning on follow-up that nothing is really wrong, is good news. But a false positive mammogram has a dangerous downside: It may reduce the likelihood that a woman returns for later screenings, increasing her risk for a late-stage cancer.
Title: Mammogram Results Can Be Misleading

Content: Matthew Knowles, the father of the artists Beyoncé and Solange, recently announced that he had been told that he has a breast cancer caused by a BRCA2 gene mutation and that his children have a 50 percent chance of inheriting it.
Title: Beyoncé’s Dad Has a Mutation More African-Americans Should Be Tested For

Content: BEIJING — Liu Xiaobo, the jailed Chinese dissident who received the Nobel Peace Prize for his writings promoting democracy, has been given medical parole to be treated for late-stage cancer, his lawyers and the prison authorities said on Monday.
Title: Liu Xiaobo, Chinese Nobel Laureate, Leaves Prison for Cancer Care

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Weight Loss, Memory and a Cancer Cure

Content: When Rhonda Bey’s appendiceal cancer did not respond to typical treatments, her doctor turned to genomic testing. Her cancer’s DNA revealed what was driving the growth of the tumor. FoundationOne®, FoundationOne®Heme, and FoundationOne CDx™ are diagnostic tests to identify genomic mutations associated with your cancer. This information, along with other information, may be used by your physician to identify potential treatment options. But these diagnostic tests do not confer any therapeutic benefit. The tests might not identify therapies that could be of benefit to you and you might not have positive outcomes with therapies identified through these tests. The outcomes described in this video are not typical and you should not expect to experience similar results. Consult your doctor about whether diagnostic testing is appropriate for you. Treatment decisions are the responsibility of your physician. These tests are available by prescription only. FoundationOne CDx™ is a next-generation sequencing based in vitro diagnostic device for detection of substitutions, insertion and deletion alterations, and copy number alterations in 324 genes and select gene rearrangements, as well as genomic signatures including microsatellite instability (MSI) and tumor mutational burden (TMB) using DNA isolated from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor tissue specimens. For the complete intended use statement, including companion diagnostic indications and warnings and limitations, please see the FoundationOne CDx Technical Information, www.foundationmedicine.com/f1cdx.
Title: How Decoding Cancer’s DNA Can Revolutionize Patient Treatment

Content: A federal jury on Wednesday ordered Monsanto to pay more than $80 million in damages to a California man whose cancer it determined was partly caused by his use of the popular weedkiller Roundup.
Title: Monsanto Ordered to Pay $80 Million in Roundup Cancer Case

Content: Breast implants made by Allergan that have been linked to an uncommon form of cancer are being taken off the market in Europe, French authorities announced on Tuesday.
Title: Allergan Halts Sales in Europe of Textured Breast Implants Linked to Rare Cancer

Content: Men whose prostate cancer comes back after surgery are more likely to survive if, along with the usual radiation, they also take drugs to block male hormones.
Title: Hormone Blockers Can Prolong Life if Prostate Cancer Recurs

Content: When Angela Durden found out that she had tested positive for the breast cancer gene mutation, she decided to share the information with her daughter, Alexis, who was 14 at the time. That meant telling the teenager about her own future risk — that she had a 50 percent chance of carrying a mutation that had already riddled their extended family — both male and female — with the disease.
Title: When to Tell Daughters About a Genetic Breast Cancer Risk

Content: BEIJING — Liu Xiaobo, the political prisoner and Nobel laureate who is on medical parole in a Chinese hospital to treat late-stage liver cancer, is fit to travel abroad to receive medical care, doctors from the United States and Germany said on Sunday.
Title: Doctors Say Chinese Dissident Is Fit to Travel for Cancer Treatment

Content: Marc Rybczyk admits that before he met Aloysia Jaques in January 2014, he had some misguided ideas about women’s basketball.
Title: The Coaches’ Game Plan: Beat Cancer, Get Married

Content: The news that Senator John McCain has brain cancer appears — at least momentarily — to have unified sharply divided Republican and Democratic politicians in support of a man some praised on Wednesday night as an “American hero.”
Title: Lawmakers Unite in Support for John McCain After Cancer Diagnosis

Content: Exercise could improve the life expectancy of adults who survive cancer as children, even if the activity begins years after treatments end, according to an inspiring new study.
Title: For Survivors of Childhood Cancer, Walk

Content: VAN NUYS, Calif. — She strolled slowly through the neighborhood, a down-to-earth sprawl of sun-blasted ranch houses, and Sandra Lee was in her element.
Title: Cancer Pushes New York’s ‘First Girlfriend,’ Sandra Lee, Onto Political Stage

Content: PANAJACHEL, Guatemala — If someone had come to her community in western Guatemala sooner to offer cervical cancer screening, perhaps Micaela Yac Jeteya, 56, wouldn’t be fighting for her life. Now Yac Jeteya, a mother of six whose youngest son is 16, is suffering from a disease that is both very common and highly preventable.
Title: We Have the Resources to Prevent Cervical Cancer. Do We Have the Will?

Content: Thousands of women across the country are suing the consumer goods giant Johnson & Johnson over its baby powder, claiming that talcum particles in the popular product caused their ovarian cancer.
Title: Risk on All Sides as 4,800 Women Sue Over Johnson’s Baby Powder and Cancer

Content: Good morning.
Title: California Today: Cancer Worries Over a Common Weedkiller

Content: Alex Trebek, the longtime host of “Jeopardy!,” appeared on “Good Morning America” on Wednesday for a frank interview about his experience with Stage 4 pancreatic cancer, including his struggle with depression during chemotherapy.
Title: Alex Trebek Talks Cancer and Depression: ‘I Just Take It as It Comes’

Content: Ten years ago, David Jones stopped working so he could look after his son, who has autism and needed constant care.
Title: After Cancer, ‘Trying to Be the Best Father’ to a Son With Autism

Content: They treaded water for seven hours before a neighbor heard their screams.
Title: ‘To Hell and Back’ as a Cancer Survivor, Storm Victim and Caregiver

Content: (Reuters) - AstraZeneca Plc said on Tuesday it would start a clinical trial of its cancer drug Calquence to assess its potential to control the exaggerated immune system response associated with COVID-19 infection in severely ill patients.
Title: AstraZeneca to Test Impact of Cancer Drug Calquence on Coronavirus Patients

Content: What does it really cost to bring a drug to market?
Title: What Does It Cost to Create a Cancer Drug? Less Than You’d Think

Content: “I had spent the past six years going to the oncologist every three months trying to keep cancer away, and here was something I had put in my body to try to help me feel more like a woman, and it gave me cancer.”
Title: Quotation of the Day: They Got Breast Implants, Then a Rare Cancer

Content: PARIS — France has banned several types of textured breast implants that have been linked to a rare form of cancer.
Title: France Is First to Ban Breast Implants Linked to Rare Cancer

Content: In what may be the largest award so far in a lawsuit tying ovarian cancer to talcum powder, a Los Angeles jury on Monday ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $417 million in damages to a medical receptionist who developed ovarian cancer after using the company’s trademark Johnson’s Baby Powder on her perineum for decades.
Title: $417 Million Awarded in Suit Tying Johnson’s Baby Powder to Cancer

Content: Dr. LaSalle D. Leffall Jr., a surgeon and educator who as the first black president of the American Cancer Society was a leader in promoting awareness of the risks of cancer, particularly among African-Americans, died on May 25 in Washington. He was 89.
Title: LaSalle Leffall Jr., 89, Dies; Cancer Society’s First Black Leader

Content: WASHINGTON — Senator John McCain of Arizona, who has been battling brain cancer for more than a year, will no longer be treated for his condition, his family announced on Friday, a sign that the Republican war hero is most likely entering his final days.
Title: John McCain to Discontinue Treatment for Brain Cancer, Family Says

Content: Charles Jencks, whose writing on architecture helped define the field after Modernism, and who put his ideas into practice both in memorable landscape architecture and in overseeing the creation of Maggie’s Centers, buildings specifically designed for cancer patients, died on Sunday at his home in London. He was 80.
Title: Charles Jencks, 80, Dies; Helped Define Postmodern Architecture

Content: After the artist Prune Nourry received a diagnosis of breast cancer in 2016 at age 31, her experiences of treatment began to inform her art. “Serendipity” is both a document and an extension of that process — a self-portrait in which Nourry showcases past projects and explores how her artistic impulses evolved.
Title: ‘Serendipity’ Review: Turning a Cancer Diagnosis Into Art

Title: Top Sloan Kettering Cancer Doctor Resigns After Failing to Disclose Industry Ties

Content: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities have refused permission for Liu Xiaobo, a Nobel Peace laureate paroled from prison for cancer treatment, to go abroad for care, one of his lawyers said on Thursday.
Title: China Won’t Let Liu Xiaobo, Nobel Laureate, Get Cancer Treatment Abroad

Content: Breast cancer is the most common cancer in American women except for skin cancers.`
Title: Researchers Predict a Quarter-Million New Cases of Breast Cancer in the U.S.

Content: A type of breast implant linked to a rare cancer can still be sold in the United States, even though it has been banned in many other countries, the Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday.
Title: F.D.A. Won’t Ban Sales of Textured Breast Implants Linked to Cancer

Content: For decades, health experts have struggled to determine whether or not cellphones can cause cancer. On Thursday, a federal agency released the final results of what experts call the world’s largest and most costly experiment to look into the question. The study originated in the Clinton administration, cost $30 million and involved some 3,000 rodents.
Title: Study of Cellphone Risks Finds ‘Some Evidence’ of Link to Cancer, at Least in Male Rats

Content: The mother was in a grocery store on the North Side of Chicago when she got the news. “I talked to a doctor who might be able to help figure out what’s wrong with your son,” her friend said. The words were a relief; she had been searching for months.
Title: Scans Suggested the Boy Had Cancer. But No Doctor Could Prove It. Why?

Content: A heart attack or stroke may be an early sign of cancer.
Title: Heart Attack May Be Early Sign of Cancer

Content: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Baseball, Cancer Treatment and the Early Benefits of Exercise

Content: Psychological distress may increase your chances of dying from cancer.
Title: Depression and Anxiety Tied to Cancer Deaths

Content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Oregon resident George Polas learned in March he had an aggressive type of prostate cancer that would require surgical removal - just as the coronavirus pandemic began spreading rapidly in the United States.
Title: 'Waiting Game' for Oregon Patient Needing Cancer Surgery Amid Coronavirus

Content: Julie Yip-Williams, whose candid blog about having Stage IV colon cancer also described a life of struggles that began with being born blind in Vietnam and her ethnic Chinese family’s escape in a rickety fishing boat, died on Monday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 42.
Title: Julie Yip-Williams, Writer of Candid Blog on Cancer, Dies at 42

Content: (Reuters) - Seattle Genetics Inc's add-on therapy for an advanced form of breast cancer that has progressed despite prior treatment was on Friday approved months ahead of schedule by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.
Title: Seattle Genetics Wins Early U.S. Approval for $18,500 Breast Cancer Therapy

Content: (Reuters) - AstraZeneca Plc said the third phase trial of its top-selling cancer drug Tagrisso, aimed at showing the drug's benefit in lung cancer treatment, will be unblinded early after a recommendation from an independent data monitoring committee.
Title: AstraZeneca's Top-Selling Cancer Drug Sees Early Unblinding in Key Trial

Title: Weekly Health Quiz: Weight Gain, Cancer and Deadly Dog Food

Content: Doctors and medical organizations often advise that past a certain age, older adults can forgo various screening tests for cancer. But many patients, no matter how old or sick they may be, are reluctant to abandon tests they’ve long been told can be lifesaving.
Title: With Cancer Screening, Better Safe Than Sorry?

Content: Because he was in such a hurry to get to his granddaughter’s high school graduation, James Riddick did not realize he had forgotten his cane until he reached the bus.
Title: After 2nd Bout With Cancer, Seeking to Heal His Body and Mind

Content: On a hazy morning this spring, at the entrance of the Al-Bayrouni cancer center in northeast Damascus, a wall of tires teetered atop a long mound of dirt. Where there were no tires, jagged sheets of metal or rusting barrels had been propped up to create a makeshift shield. The edges of the flat roof were lined with barrels and sandbags. The 500-bed facility, the biggest oncology hospital in Syria, stands on the edge of an old highway, near the Al-Assad and Harasta suburbs, overlooking an active front line between government and opposition forces. As the engines of passing warplanes sucked at the air overhead, soldiers patrolled the grounds. For the government, the highway is a direct supply line to the police hospital and barracks beside the cancer center. For the opposition, controlling the road would provide them a chance to break a siege that has left most medical facilities destroyed or empty.
Title: Braving Cancer Amid the Chaos of Syria

Content: CRAVING By Esther GerritsenTranslated by Michele Hutchison 192 pp. World Editions. Paper, $15.99.
Title: In These Novels, Women With Cancer Decide to Ditch the People-Pleasing

Content: The 86 cancer patients were a disparate group, with tumors of the pancreas, prostate, uterus or bone. One woman had a cancer so rare there were no tested treatments. She was told to get her affairs in order.
Title: Cancer Drug Proves to Be Effective Against Multiple Tumors

Content: Wendy MacNaughton is a graphic journalist based in San Francisco. You can find her via website and Instagram.
Title: Radon Causes Cancer. These Tourists Drink It Up.

Content: It was the sort of bad news every patient fears. Merlin Erickson, a 69-year-old retired engineer in Abingdon, Md., was told last year that a biopsy of his prostate was positive for cancer.
Title: The Lab Says It’s Cancer. But Sometimes the Lab Is Wrong.

Content: Mark Richards thought he was done being a photojournalist. Then he had a rare cancer diagnosed. He had devoted his life to documenting the world, but now he wanted to tell his own story.
Title: Photographing His Own Cancer Treatment: ‘A Hell I Wasn't Ready For’

Content: A federal jury found Tuesday that Monsanto’s popular weedkiller Roundup was a “substantial factor” in causing a California man’s cancer, dealing a significant blow to the company as it aggressively defends its products against thousands of similar claims.
Title: Monsanto Weedkiller Roundup Was ‘Substantial Factor’ in Causing Man’s Cancer, Jury Says

Content: One of the country’s most influential researchers in cancer screening has resigned from his post at Dartmouth College, after a two-year internal investigation concluded he had plagiarized a graph included in a paper published in a prominent journal.
Title: Prominent Cancer Researcher Resigns from Dartmouth Amid Plagiarism Charges

Content: The long-term use of oral contraceptives reduces the risk for ovarian and endometrial cancers, and the effect is especially evident in smokers, the obese and those who exercise infrequently, a new study found.
Title: Oral Contraceptives Reduce Risk for Ovarian and Endometrial Cancers

Content: No one expected the four young women to live much longer. They had an extremely rare, aggressive and fatal form of ovarian cancer. There was no standard treatment.
Title: Doctors Said Immunotherapy Would Not Cure Her Cancer. They Were Wrong.

Content: When faced with an actual or potential diagnosis of cancer, most people are inclined to consult Dr. Google, often before they see a real live medical expert. Unfortunately, Dr. Google doesn’t always know what’s best.
Title: When Cancer Meets the Internet

Content: After learning he had early stage prostate cancer, Paul Kolnik knew he wanted that cancer destroyed immediately and with as little disruption as possible to his busy life as the New York City Ballet’s photographer.
Title: Popular Prostate Cancer Therapy Is Short, Intense and Unproven

Content: John Dalman had been in the waiting room at a Loxahatchee, Fla., dermatology clinic for less than 15 minutes when he turned to his wife and told her they needed to leave. Now.
Title: Skin Cancers Rise, Along With Questionable Treatments

Content: For the last two years or so, the artist Prune Nourry has thought of herself as a sculpture. Ms. Nourry, who is French and splits her time between Brooklyn and Paris, was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2016. As she went through treatment, including chemotherapy and reconstructive surgery, she thought of her doctors as the sculptors and herself as the material they were fashioning. Now, Ms. Nourry, 33, has created her own work in response to that experience, as a tribute to breast cancer survivors everywhere.
Title: ‘A Catharsis Sculpture’: An Artist Makes a Monument to Cancer Survivors

Content: A mysterious bacterium found in up to half of all colon tumors also travels with the cancer as it spreads, researchers reported on Thursday.

Content: Recently, I met a very unlucky man. A financial adviser in his mid-60s, he seemed chronically short of breath, and he had an odd habit of widening his eyes and raising his brows every time he finished a sentence.
Title: What We Learn When Two Ruthless Killers, Heart Disease and Cancer, Reveal a Common Root

Title: Is It Time to Remake Our Digital Lives?

Content: As lieutenant governor of Pennsylvania, John Fetterman is a very busy man. But he was prepared to drop everything on Friday and drive to a Weis Markets in Lebanon, Pa., to hand deliver a personal check for $109.63, the exact sum of groceries that a woman with advanced cancer was recently convicted of stealing.
Title: A Cancer Patient Stole Groceries Worth $109.63. She Was Sentenced to 10 Months.

Content: Three weeks after a British man told PayPal that his wife had died at 37 and that her credit account should be closed, he opened a letter from the company: Her death, it seemed, was in violation of the company’s contract rules.
Title: PayPal Apologizes for Letter Demanding Payment From Woman Who Died of Cancer

Content: Elvis Costello has canceled the remainder of his European tour to recover from a cancer operation.
Title: Elvis Costello Cancels European Tour after Cancer Surgery

Content: A jury in Oakland, Calif., ordered Monsanto on Monday to pay a couple more than $2 billion in damages after finding that its Roundup weed killer caused their cancer — the third jury to conclude that the company failed to warn consumers of its flagship product’s dangers.
Title: $2 Billion Verdict Against Monsanto Is Third to Find Roundup Caused Cancer

Content: Married people are more likely than the unmarried to get timely diagnosis and treatment for malignant skin cancer.
Title: Married People Less Likely to Die From Melanoma

Content: DURHAM, N.C. — I once imagined my life as an uninterrupted line from birth to decline. There would be some creditable achievements and great love sandwiched in the middle, of course, but time was a durable thing.
Title: How Cancer Changes Hope

Content: Over the past eight years I underwent two stem-cell transplants, each preceded by intense chemotherapy. My oncologist believes I am probably cured. The chemotherapy damaged my kidneys to the point that I am now on dialysis, and other systems are affected as well. There is also a small but significant risk that other malignancies may occur in the future as a result of the chemotherapy.
Title: I’m a 73-Year-Old Cancer Survivor. Can I Accept a Kidney?

Content: Robotic surgery was never approved for mastectomy or any other cancer-related treatment, but that has hardly deterred doctors in the operating suite. The equipment is widely used to operate on patients with various malignancies, from breast cancer to prostate cancer.
Title: Cancer Patients Are Getting Robotic Surgery. There’s No Evidence It’s Better.

Content: NASUGBU, The Philippines — Pock. Pock. Pock.
Title: Who Hits Golf Balls Into the Sea?

Content: Two tenured scientists at a renowned cancer hospital in Houston have resigned, and the hospital is seeking to fire a third, in connection with an investigation into possible foreign attempts to take advantage of its federally funded research, the authorities said.
Title: Wary of Chinese Espionage, Houston Cancer Center Chose to Fire 3 Scientists

Content: One of the most important benefits of exercise is in how it reduces our risk of developing a number of types of cancer — especially colorectal cancer, which according to some estimates is the malignancy most influenced by physical activity. But how workouts guard against colon cancer remains largely unknown. Physical activity speeds the movement of waste through the intestines, as anyone who has had to hunt for a bathroom during a workout knows. But this does not seem to fully account for the protective effects of exercise. Instead, a small study published in February in The Journal of Physiology suggests we should also look to changes in our bloodstream after exercise.
Title: Why Does Exercise Guard Against Cancer? Inflammation May Play a Role

Content: NAIROBI, Kenya — In a remarkable initiative modeled on the campaign against AIDS in Africa, two major pharmaceutical companies, working with the American Cancer Society, will steeply discount the prices of cancer medicines in Africa.
Title: As Cancer Tears Through Africa, Drug Makers Draw Up a Battle Plan

Content: ZHANGJIAJIE, China — Tang Chunwu set off from his room in a ramshackle inn just after sunrise, the beginning of Day 92 in his search for his son.
Title: A Chinese Pharmacist Found Out He Had Cancer. Then He Vanished.

Content: WASHINGTON — Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg underwent surgery on Friday to remove two nodules from her left lung, according to Kathleen Arberg, a Supreme Court spokeswoman. The nodules were discovered during tests following a fall in November in which Justice Ginsburg fractured her ribs.
Title: Ruth Bader Ginsburg Undergoes Cancer Surgery

Title: Paula Schneider on Running American Apparel and Fighting Cancer

Content: In cases of melanoma, the most serious form of skin cancer, doctors will determine its spread by examining a lymph node. If malignant cells are found, the standard treatment is to surgically remove all the lymph nodes in the same area.
Title: With Melanoma, Lymph Node Removal May Not Improve Survival

Content: The approval of gene therapy for leukemia, expected in the next few months, will open the door to a radically new class of cancer treatments.
Title: Companies Rush to Develop ‘Utterly Transformative’ Gene Therapies

Title: Glioblastoma, John McCain’s Form of Brain Cancer, Is Aggressive and Rarely Cured

Content: ACONCAGUA PROVINCIAL PARK, Argentina — Isabella de la Houssaye and her daughter, Bella, struggled to breathe in the thin air of the high Andes as they trudged up a zigzag trail to the top of Aconcagua, the highest summit outside Asia.
Title: She Had Stage 4 Lung Cancer, and a Mountain to Climb

Content: Dr. Oliver Sartor has a provocative question for patients who are running out of time.
Title: ‘Desperation Oncology’: When Patients Are Dying, Some Cancer Doctors Turn to Immunotherapy

Content: When James Garish married his kindergarten crush Liz Stipkovits on Feb. 17 near their hometown, McKeesport, Pa., it wasn’t with the expectations many couples entertain, about raising a family and growing old together.
Title: Bride Dies Two Months After Her Dream Wedding

Content: When Emily Caudill learned she had an ovarian germ cell tumor at the age of 25, she did not want to undergo chemotherapy. An accomplished bluegrass fiddler, she knew that hearing loss is a common side effect of some chemicals — so common that drugs harmful to the ear have acquired an adjective: they are ototoxic.
Title: When Music Is the Best Medicine

Content: SANTIAGO, Chile — The Chilean poet Pablo Neruda, a Nobel laureate, did not die of cancer, as his death certificate indicated, according to a group of international forensic experts who analyzed samples of his remains.
Title: Cancer Didn’t Kill Pablo Neruda, Panel Finds. Was It Murder?

Content: Henry Fountain reports on a faulty dam that threatens a California city; Science Times Editor Jim Gorman talks to a scientist researching the little-known mammal, called a fisher, that's moving into the suburbs and Denise Grady explains the latest findings about breast cancer detection and treatment.
Title: A vulnerable dam in California, a mysterious creature in the suburbs and advances in breast cancer diagnosis and treatment

Content: WASHINGTON — Senator John McCain, who is battling brain cancer, has returned home to Arizona and is likely to miss the Senate’s vote this week to approve a sweeping tax overhaul, though President Trump said on Sunday that the senator would return if his vote was needed.
Title: McCain, in Treatment for Cancer, Is Likely to Miss Senate Tax Vote

Content: The dermatologist Ellen Marmur says she has always appreciated a striking painting or photograph, but she only began collecting art seriously after she learned she had skin cancer in 2006.
Title: A Collection That Owes Its Existence to a ‘Carpe Diem’ Event
